title: Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I AM most disturbed by Roy Bongartz's article on conceptual art, Question: How Do You Buy a Work of Art Like This? [Aug. 11]. I, too, am interested in expanding art forms, but not through gimmickry and outright quackery. The conceptional movement seems to be sadly lacking in imagination and any real creativity. If shooting someone in the arm is art, then does a murderer (under different circumstances) qualify as an artist?

title: Foyt, Follmer, Race of Chompions
description: A. S. Foyt, George Follmer and Bobby Allison have been named to complete the 12driver field for the second field for the Second International. Race of Champions, the race proznoters aariolinced yesterday. The sixrace series at hree trackstwo ovals and one road coutsein to determine, whimsically, the best allround driver in the world. Drivers from all major forms of racing will compete.

title: Infant Killed and 9 Are Injured As Car Jumps Curb in Harlem
description: A 1yearold boy was killed and nine persons, including his mother, were injured yesterday afternoon as a car swerved around a truck on West 118th Street into a crowd and crashed into a building.

title: Suit to Test Freedgrn Of Speech
description: EVESHAM TOWNSHIP The American Civil Liberties Union will go to cant in defense of two local resiWilts who contend that, because they exercised their right of free speech, they have been included in a multimillion dollar lawsnit against this Burlington County township and its officials.

title: Miss Service Fiancee of David Seabury
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ann Service to David S. Seabury of Mountain Lakes, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Seabury Jr., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George B. Service Jr. of Glen Rock, N. J., parents of the future bride.

title: Protecting Tax Returns
description: During the impeachment hearings in July, many members of the House Judiciary Committee exhibited particular dismay at evidence of White House abuse the manipulation of Government agencies, especially the, Internal Revenue Service. In the wake of those hearings, parallel consideration is being given on Capitol Hill and in the executive branch to ways of guarding against future misuse of I.R.S. and its files.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Having had the experience of putting on a press conference at which both Gloria Steinem and Helen Gurley Brown appeared, I was particularly fascinated by your article, Ms. versus Cosmo: Two faces of the same Eve (by Stephanie Harrington, Aug. 11). At that time we at the National Abortion Rights Action League were trying to draw attention to the fact that the Supreme Court abortion decision was under attack. We were protesting the fact that so few women had been allowed to testify at Senate, Judiciary subcommittee hearings on constitutional amendments which would ban all abortions.

title: Karen Williamson Affianced To Thomas Zuniga of Belize
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irving Alexander. Williamson of St. Louis of the engagement of their, daughter, Karen Elizabeth Williamson, to Thoinas Mark Zuniga, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Zuniga of the city of Belize in Belize, formerly British Honduras.

title: Factory Will Become Housing
description: HOBOKEN  What was once a factory for 75 years is being converted into an apartment house under the aegis of Hoboken's widely praised Model Cities program.

title: Glen Cove, Nassau and Developers in a Dispute Over Use of the Pratt Estate
description: GLEN COVEDevelopers, the City Council of Glen Cove and its Mayor, Vincent A. Suozzi, are considering possible compromises to a controversy over the future use of Welwyn, the Harold Irving Pratt family estate, some 212 acres of undeveloped land on the North Shore of Nassau County.

title: Staffs of Governor Candidates Reflect Their. Campaign Styles
description: The campaign organizations of Howard J. Samuels and Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic candidates for Governor, reflect the personal styles of the candidates.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Believing saliva tests for horses to be antiquated, the New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday announced that the New York Racing Association and The Jockey Club would join in a bloodtesting program conducted by the Cornell University, Veterinary College.

title: Jersey News Briefs
description: ASBURY PARKArnold Gee, a 16yearold senior at Asbury High School, is the most recent appointee to the Board of Trustees of the Asbury Park Public Library.

title: For Some It Is a Religious Revival
description: The corner on pietism in Washington has long appeared to be held by pressure groups, chanting and praying from the fringes, sometimes as though there were devils to be exorcised from the official halls.

title: To Govern, To Choose
description: Although President Ford has been in office for only three weeks, the pressures of the Presidency are already crowding in upon him, The public's goodwill and hopefulness persist but so do the public's problems. When Pierre MendesFrance was Premier of France and urging that. nation to cut its losses in Indochina, he frequently reminded his colleagues in the Chamber Deputies that to govern is to choose.

title: SPECULATORS ACT TO SELL PROPERTY
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 31Realestate developers, hurt by the recent slump in residential and commercial construction, are asking Suffolk County to buy many of the choice farmland properties they bought for speculation.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: An Iron Yacht/New Water Holes /The Pearl Is a Pearl
description: To the Editor: In. all the accounts of the America's; Cup preliminaries, I see many references that this is the first time nonwooden boats have competed. This is, of course, note true.

title: 2Day ShoW Slated By Model Rail Club
description: CRANFORD  Operating modelrailroad layouts, modelbuilding demonstrations and a wide variety of other activities will be featured at a modelrailroad hobby show to be held here on Nov. 2 and 3.

description: Photography Exhibitions

title: Huge Building Alters Landscape ln Queons,
description: It still bothers Arthur Ratner that New York City lost Fedders. On the other hand, it didn't lose Robert Hall Hah!

title: Shore patrol
description: DOWN

title: Harry Truman, liberal
description: The past two years have seen publication of a wide assortment, of books about Harry S. Trumandaughter Margaret's ode to her father's Administration, Bert Cochran's radical critique of the Truman years and Merle Miller's oral biography. Amid all this, the first comprehensive and thorough study of Truman's policies by an American historian, though it appeared a few months ago, has escaped attention. Yet in many ways Alonzo L. Hamby's Beyond the New Deal is the most important of the new Truman books.

title: Princeton Gets Fischer Papers
description: PRINCETONThe papers of the late Louis Fischer, as well as much of the library of the news correspondent and authority on the Soviet Union, have been given to the Princeton University library.

title: Poets, Printers and Painphleteers
description: If your receiver of future shock has not yet picked up the reverberations coming from the socalled underground presses and their affiliatessome 2,000 independent small presses and magazines you've been missing one of the liveliest cultural phenomena of our day. This most recent form of dissent from the literary and publishing establishments has so rapidly gained ground it is assuming the proportions of a movement comparable to the paperback revolution of the fifties. Though I had not missed the distant rumblings (who does not know the Feminist Press, Ferlinghetti's City Lights, the sublimely angry The Smith?) I came upon it full blast early in July at the New York Book Fair. In a novel kind of experiment, some 250 representative presses of the alternate publishing culture convened from all parts of the country to exhibit their waresand possibly to sell them. To their own surprise, about 10,000 people, including members of the publishing establishment, turned up to look, buy and even applaud.

title: Eplogue
description: Almost Home

title: School Rolls Drop In Nassau County
description: ALBANY  A continuing decline in the number of children attending public schools in Nassau County was reported last week by the State Education Department.

title: Blast at Lincoln Center
description: A small bomb fashioned from a propane cylinder exploded in a clump of gushes at Lincoln Center early yesterday, about 30 feet from the Metropolitan Opera House, the police reported. They said the blast, in Damrosch Park, caused no injuries and no damage to prdperty. a search of the area turned up no other devices, the police said. They, described the bomb as a propane cylinder with some wire around it, connected to a detanating device.

title: Shinnecocks Hold Annual Powwow
description: SOUTHAMPTON  The Shinnecock Indian tribe is holding its annual powwow this weekend at the reservation here. The threeday program will include ritual dancing, the sale of Indian foods and the smoking of the peace pipe by the chiefs of 15 United States and Central American tribes attending the festival.

title: Area Seeks to Save Theater
description: Loew's Triboro Theater, long an escapist fairyland for moviegoers of all age has become the center of a controversy involving civic groups, a construction company, and the city's Landmark Preservation Committee.

title: Ideas&Trends Continued
description: The preparation of children for citizenship in a democracy is one of American education's main functions, but the evidence that educators often fail in that purpose is everywhere at handnot the least of it in Washington during the last two years.

title: Art
description: AS OF this Tuesday, September 3, the Museum of the American Indian will be open again at Broadway and 155th Street in Manhattan, a location it shares with three other distinguished though oddly mated institutions: the American Academy of of Arts and Letters, the Hispanic Society and the American Numismatic Li Society. It will be open, but in what condition? And for how long? These are crystalball matters as to which a reasoned prognosis would be hard to reach.

title: Miss Kocian Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry A. Roden of Ridgefield, N. J., have made known the engagement of, their daughter, Geraldine Kocian, to Don Pannacciulli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick Pannacciulli of Little Ferry, N. J. The wedding is planned for Oct. 11.

title: Maryland Rebuffed Anew On Preserving Its Beaches
description: SALISBURY, Md., Aug. 31 (AP)Maryland has lost another round in its court battle to prevent building on the beachfront in the Ocean. City resort area and to preserve the beach for public use.

title: Museum Sparks a Dispute
description: LONG BRANCHA picturesque, but somewhat rundown, old church in the fashionable Elberon section of Long Branch has become the center of a political wrangle.

title: Old Hand at an Older Craft
description: LAVALLEITE.  Charles Hankins, a big, burly man with pleasant, knobby, features, is one of New Jersey's list builders of handmade Wooden boats.

Allot, two of his sons and his campaign nanager have become involved a conflictofinterest conroversy that has produced the esignation of three persons rom city commission posts. The dispute involves interetatIon of recently adopted rections of the city charter that overn conflicts of interest and he operation of the cityowned tiers, including Fisherman's Wharf, a leading tourist atraction. The amendments, effective text January, were voted in rune and led City Attorney lomas M. O'Connor to advise ohn A. Sutro, a leading lawyer sere, that his continued service on the Airports Commission vas probably in violation. Mr. Sutro immediately reigned. His firm represents lients, such as Standard Oil California and Pacific Telehone, that have contracts vith the Airports Commission. These contracts would be ubject to cancellation and Mr. utro would be subject to prosecution under the amendaents, Mr. O'Connor said, if, fr. Sutro took any income hrough his law firm from fees raceabla to those contracts, though he had abstained

title: CableTV Gains in Popularity
description: NEWARKThe state is experiencing a boom in cable television. There are now about 50 franchises serving 142 of New Jersey's 567 communities; another 107 municipal franchises have been certified by the state's Office of Cable Television, but are not yet operational.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: For Nixon: Indictment, Pardon Or a Deal?
description: WASHINGTONThe troubles that would not go away are with him still, behind the walls of San Clemente. Richard M. Nixon spoke of those troubles last Nov. 17, insisting that he never obstructed justice, never profited from his years in public office, and that he welcomed an examination of all he has done.  people have got to know whether or not their President is a crook; well, I am not a crook.

title: ALBERT I. OELBAUM
description: Albert I. Oelbaum, president of the Revere Textile Prints Corporation of Sterling, Conn., and president of Textile Prints Corporation of this city, died, on Friday at Seth Israel Hospital, appareritly of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 40 East Ninth Street.

title: Early to Bloom
description: ONE day several years ago in early April was prowling about our newly acquired property searching for signs of spring, when I happened to glance at the neighboring centuryold house, now unkempt and neglected. I was startled to see what looked like an enormous spill of bright blue ink, spreading among brown leaves. Upon close examination, they were a colony of Siberian squills thriving on many years of neglect. I determined to plant some myself and started reading about Scilla and the other minor bulbs.

title: What They Are Saying
description: President Ford, a centerlinebacker at the University of Michigan, was picked as the team's most valuable player in his senior year, 1934. Benny Oosterbaan, retired head coach at Michigan, recalls a particular game; Minnesota was the national champion that year. We weren't supposed to have a chance against Minnesota, but in our game with them the score was 00 at halftime. We nearly, scored twice. We had put up such a great fight and Jerry Ford was the leader of that fight with his tremendous linebacking. I was assistant coach and in charge of scouting that year. I remember being so proud of Jerry and all the rest of our players that tears came to my eyes the dressing room at halftime. Of course, Minnesota swamped us in the second half. Our fellows had simply, drained themselves dry.

title: Miss Mitchell, E. J. Sullivan Plan Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. Mitchell of Flower Hill, Manhasset, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Ann Mitchell, to Edward Joseph Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Sullivan, also of Flower Hill.

title: Police Decoy Cabbies Hold Stabbing Suspect
description: Two plainclothes policemen operating a decoy cab in Queens arrested a suspect in a stabbing yesterday after he had hailed them and asked to be taken to the Bronx.

title: Ford Seeks to Defer October Pay Rise for Federal Employes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Ford set in motion today a threemonth deferral of pay increases scheduled to take effect Oct. 1 for all 3.6 million Federal employes.

title: In Summary
description: After rising steadily for 17 years, the F.B.I.'s index of serious offenses dropped slightly in 1972, and there was hope that the crime rate would continue to go down. But estimates for 1973 indicated that crime was on the rise again, and the final figure, disclosed last week by Attorney General William B. Saxbe, shows that the increase was even worse than predicted.

title: ART
description: BridgehamptonExhibition with Sheila Isham, Polly Kraft, Robert Fabian, Paul Sisko and Esther Gentle, through Sept. 26, daily except Wednesdays, noon to 6 P.M., Benson Gallery, Montauk Highway.

title: CHILEAN CLERGYMEN IN APPEAL TO JUNTA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 31 (AP)Religious leaders in Chile have appealed in a letter tol Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, the chief of state, for an end to the strife in the nation and pardons for political prisoners.

title: The World/continued
description: LONDONOne common view of the British is that they really don't care where they stand in the league tables of major powers, that if their country economically falls behind Italy, Spain and Portugal, then so be it. After all, there is that special quality of life here, the conviviality of the pub, the beauty of the parks on a sunny afternoon, and the welfare state that will take care of you.

title: BOSTON WILL ALLOW STUDENT TRANSFERS
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Students assigned to schools in Boston under courtordered desegregation will be able to transfer if their race is in a majority at their assigned school.

title: Notes: A Sticky Business
description: ALETTER came in the other day from Robert A. Philibert of Burlington, Conn. It read in part as follows: I had just returned from, New Orleans on Delta Airlines Flight 328, scheduled to arrive at Kennedy Airport at 7:45 P.M. When I arrived the actions of a traffic guard made me forget all the excellent service I had been provided with on my trip.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1974
description: West Germany agreed to lend Italy $2to help get her out of her financial crisis. The loan was announced jointly by Premier Mariano Rumor of Italy and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany after a long meeting in Bellagio, a resort in Northern Italy. West Germany will transfer marks and other hard currencies from the West German Federal Bank to the Bank of Italy. Part of the Bank of Italy's gold reserves will be put up as collateral, Mr. Schmidt said. Mr. Rumor said that only a small portion of the gold reserves would be used as collateral. [1:8.]

title: New DayCare Program
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 31 (AP)A new program to expand daycare facilities for lowincome farrillie's and to free welfare mothers, to work has been announced by Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. West Virginia will pZ ioneer: the grant program with a $1.2. million grant from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, he said at a news conference Thuraday.

title: Janette Rae Falls Is Wed
description: Janette Rae Falls and Thomas McKerrow Kerr were married here yesterday afternoon in the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Victor Baer. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Falls Jr. Mr. Kerr's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Kerr Jr. Both families live in Manhattan.

title: Warren Ayres to Wed Susan West
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph O'Neal West of Wellesley, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan DeForest West, to Warren William Ayres, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Ayres of Pittsburgh.

title: A Buoyant Restaurant Plan
description: The first floating restaurant in the city will soon, be installed at the foot of Fulton Street in Brooklyn, on the spot where the old Fulton, ferryboats docked on their crossriver run carrying passengers to and from Manhattan.

title: School Boards Turning to Public Relations Experts to Keep the Parents Informed
description: EAST BRUNSWICKWhen school resumes this week, increasing numbers of New Jersey residents will be getting information about their children's education from professional writers employed by their local school board.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: AN unusually sophisti cated slide projectoi made specifically for the newer 110 (pocket camera) size slides has been introduced by Hanimex; an Australianbased. company whose American headquarters are located at 7020 North Lawndale Avenue, Chicago, Ill. Called the Rondette 110, this unit differs from most other projectors in that slides are not held in it tray, wheel or cubethey are attached to clips which are mounted on an endless nylon belt that is powered by a paire of motor driven spindles.

title: Sapersteins Have Child
description: A daughter was born July 29 to Rabbi and Mrs. Marc Saperstein of Cambridge, Mass., in the Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. The child has been named Sara. Mrs. Saperstein, the former Roberta Shapiro of Brooklige, Mass., is a candidate for a PHD. degree in Middle Eastern studies at Harvard University, as is her husband. Rabbi Saperstein serves at Temple Beth David in Canton, Mass, He was formerly assistant rabbi at the Central Synagogue here.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Early in life, most of us probably observe an unhappy relationship between labor and wealth  to wit, the heavier the labor, the less the wealth.

title: Lord Raven Winner in L.I. Show
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Ang. 31Ralph de SariCtis's Lord Riven won the intermediate jumper championship at the Rice Farm's horse show: today and in the process pieked up ground in the race for the Long Island High. Score Awards Association di

title: Heart Recipient Fine
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP)Eugene Michel, 47 years old, of Salt Lake City, was reported In satisfactory condition today after undergoing a heart transplant at the Stanford Medical Center, He's doing fine, said Carol Haggerty, nursing supervisor at the hospital.

title: L. I. Farmstands Thriving Despite Increase in Costs
description: Farmstands Continuing to Thrive A Farm Supermarket Flowers for Sale Likes Gardening

title: Highway Uglification
description: The billboard lobby never gives up. Last year it tried unsuccessfully to make the Highway Construction Act a vehiCle for relaxing regulations that, since 1970, have restricted these advertising blights on the nation's scenery. Now they are seeking to put across proposed amendments even worse than those that failed last time. John Francis of the Department of Transportation describes them as a potential disaster, and a sellout the billboard interests.

title: New Look at Fringe Benefits
description: NUTLEY,At many companies, the tick of 5 P.M. sends employes heading for home at blinding speed, espectally when the time of year permits a few holes of golf or, perhaps, a set or two of tennis.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In terms of political vulnerability and public disfavor, the oil and gas industry is today near the top of the listperhaps at the top.

title: Hartford Man Hanged in Cell
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 3 (AP)A 37yearold man arrested on misdemeanor offenses was found dead, hanging from his shirt early today, shortly after he had been placed in the lockup at Police Headquarters, authorities said. The man, Jose Gonzales, of Hartford, charged with, threatening and breach of the peace, was being held because he had failed to post a $400 bond, the police said.

title: EDWARD O. STANLEY
description: Edward O. Stanley, a retired New Jersey lawyer and former vice president and general counsel of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, died Thursday at the Inglemoor Nursing Home Livingston, N.J. He was 88years old.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author'S name and title of work.

title: James Pope Weds Kathleen M. Gillis
description: The marriage of Kathleen Marie Gillis, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Leo Gillis of Milton, Mass., and the late Dr. Gillis, to James Selkirk Pope, son of Mrs. James Gross Pope of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Mr. Pope, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Old Schoolhouse Is Still in Use
description: LYNDHURST  The bell will ring again this week at what is believed to be the only little red schoolhouse still in use in New Jersey, and until next midJune it will serve as the seat of learning for 25 Lyndhurst firstgraders.

title: U.S. Swimmers Set 2 World Marks, Tie One and Lead Germans, 96 to 67
description: CONCORD, Calif., Aug. 31 Roland Matthes, the East German swimmer who had not been beaten for seven years and had won two gold medals in each of the last two Olympics, was defeated tonight by an exuberant John Naber as the United States team took a commanding 9667, lead over the East Germany after the first day of the twoday dual meet between the world's strongest teams.

title: Lila Jenkins Is Wed to a Broker
description: In the Episcopal Cathedral pf St. Philip in Atlanta at noon yesterday, Lila Jenkins became the bride of Ernest Cruikshank 3d, an investment broker with White, Weld & Co., Inc., in Atlanta.

title: Is the Stock Market Saying Anything on Its Way Down?
description: WASHINGTONDoes the disturbing decline in the stock market reflect things in the economy that happened in the past, or things that are happening right now, or is it a signal of even worse things to come?

title: Avon Rings No Bells On Wall Street
description: The wasting away of Avon Products, Inc., on the stock market ticker is one of the grimmer tales of woebegone Wall Street. The price of the stock of the world's largest cosmetic company has declined from $140 in March, 1973, to $25, its closing price last Friday. The ratio of its price in the marketplace to its earnings per share has shrunk from 60 to 11 (on projected 1974 earnings).

title: Arnold Bennett
description: Arnold Bennett has always been perceived as a man of parts, most of them contradictory. Soon after he came down to London from the Potteries in the 1890's, he began to edit the weekly Woman and contribute to the trashy TitBits and the esthetes Yellow Bookpolarities that have often been taken as prophetic of his entire career. His trademark was versatility: he wrote swiftly, in all the genres and on every level. His best novels (The Old Wives Tale, Clayhanger, Hilda Lessways, These Twain and Riceyman Steps) were admired by James, Conrad, Wells and Gide; and Bennett was widely praised for his ability to render the variety, beauty, drama and significance behind the drab surfaces of provincial life.

title: Most of the Suburbs Are Better Off, But Not By Much
description: We've managed to abolish the business cycle in New York City. Now we no longer have recoveries. With these gloomy words, the metropolitan region's top labor market analyst, Herbert Bienstock, summed up the city's last five years of sputtering economic growth. While the rest of the country and much of the New York region moved from a slump into a boom, the city itself stayed behind, watching the ranks of its employed shrink year by year.

title: News of the Realty Trade 42d St Holdout Renovated
description: An alteration job is transforming the former Vim building on 42d Street near the Avenue of the Americas into a sixstory branch office for a bank.

title: The cultural Revolution, Then and Now
description: CHICAGOThe present campaign to criticize the late Lin Piao, the former sole Deputy Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist party, and ConfuciuS is considered in China to be the latest phase of the continuing Cultural Revolution, which began in 1966: But the present campaign is totally different from the early phases of the Cultural Revolution from 1966 to 1968.

title: The East Germans: Recognition Comes at Last
description: BONNLA few Weeks ago, in Berlin, an East German official said: When Washington recognizes us, we really will have all we want from the West. Washington plans to do that this week, and Mrs. John Sherman Cooper of Kentucky will finally have her longstanding dream of being the Ambassador's wife, albeit in East Berlin, fulfilled.

title: Future Events
description: Sept. 5  The Stony Brook Foundation's first awards dinner will honor Perry B. Duryea, Speaker of the Assembly, and Dr. H. Bentley Glass, Distinguished Professor of Biology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L. I. Tickets for the event for 750 at Colonie Hill in Hauppauge, L. I., are $75 a person, $125 a couple. The foundation, an oncampus affiliate, serves as development arm for the university. Edward J. Gunnigle is dinner chairman.

title: The Czechs: Still Repressed
description: LONDONDespite indecisive intrigues at the top and Samizdat literature being spread underground, Czechs and Slovaks seem now prepared to forget about politics, and enjoy, along with their East German neighbors, the highest standard of living in the Communist bloc.

title: Milk Coop Backs A Move to Recover Illegal Donations
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 31 (AP)  Members of the Associated Milk Producers, Inc., approVed by a nearly unanimous voice vote today a plan to recover funds illegally made to political campaigns.

title: Fashion
description: The first day of I school is almost here, and the newest nursery schoolers are ready with a nofuss wardrobe of classics  skirts, shirts and sweaters, stretchy pants and comfortable tops.

title: SMOG ESTIMATES DIFFER ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31Los Angeles County discovered recently that its smog measuring machines had been producing results that were different from those produced on machines used by its five, neighboring counties.

title: Book Ends
description: Trends. A lot of people are asking, What are the current trends in books? Herewith a quick rundown on the current hot subject matter, as gleaned from here and there. Our first trend comes to us courtesy of a friend whom, because he prefers anonymity, we'll dub Constant Reader. Constant Reader writes us in a state of alarm over. the newest wave of doomsday books that have been flooding the market for the past year or so. The primary disaster areas are (a.) what's going to kill us because we don't have enough of it and (b.) what's going to ruin us financially. He lists such titles as You Can Profit From Monetary Crisis, Soviet Conquest From Space, Are You Radioactive? Mortgage on America, The Ameiican Food Scandal, Meat Eaters Are Threatened, The Coming Credit Collapse, The Great Wall  Street Scandal, The Wall Street Gang, The Brain Changers, Facing Starvation, etc., etc. Even such big thinkers as Richard Goodwin (The Human Condition) and Robert Heilbroner (An Inquiry into the Human Prospect) are gloomy. With all that disaster about it's not surprising that another trend is death. It appears that we have, saturation of the market, though, so this trend is shall we say a dying one. Rape, self defense, consumer selfprotection are some more trends for your collection. And confessions of former con men and also cops (the two are not necessarily interchangeable). There is a certified trend in Sherlock Holmes books; also Patty Hearst books. Perhaps we can anticipate a book that has Holmes solving the Hearst case. Meanwhile, back at the political stock market, Watergatefigure books are holding, Presidential memoirs are quoted high and impeachment issues are being hastily retired. Disaster is also afflicting the novel, as it is the movies, with two books about fires in highrise office towers outthe two of them will be made into one movie, which is thrifty. Novels about killer bees, killer sharks, killer whatevers, as well as normal rabbits, are big. Selfhelp is always big, sometimes threatening to make the Best Seller List resemble a Reader's Digest table of contents. What's coming up in this category? We're going to sayjust two words: Stress and Depression (small wonder with all those disaster books). And don't forget prehistoric visitors from outer space the occult, old age. Espionage, suspense, intrigue, paranoia are all big in fiction. Women's books are outexcept those by Victoria Holt and Susan Howatch. There is a glut of paperback romances on the market so production controls are being instituted; also, one company has decided not to call gothics gothics any moresuspense is preferred. Gothics, however, are doing well in paper; also maleaction series and Look for Words puzzles. Oh yes, first novels are outthey don't sell; consequently all writers should begin their careers with third novels. All the above trends will now selfdestruct.

title: Letters: Telephonitis In the Tourist Offices
description: In connection with. Joyce Jensen's article, Information, Please! (Trai/el Section, Aug. 18), I think that most of the young ladies who work in government tourist offices in New York are afflicted with a disease that is hinted at in the piece but never defined: telephonitis.

title: Coal's Uncertain Role in Energy Shortage
description: WASHINGTONA stall but controversial 13month coal miners strike, which threatened to upset the forthcoming negotiations for a national coal contract, was settled last week by the United Mine Workers and Eastover Mining Company of Harlan, Ky.

title: Deaths
description: ABLERGussic Beloved wife of the late Morris Abler, mother of ??? Littman and Dr. Charles Abler, loving grandmother of Lynne Littman and Berdlne Abler. Deceased Friday, August 30, 1974. Funeral private.

title: Whippet Judged Best at NewtonShow
description: NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 31The speediest dog in the final was quickly judged winner on the treerimmed grounds of St. Paul's Abbey today, when Mrs. Margaret Hodges's whippet, Ch. Stoney Meadow's Moon Mist, was named best of 1,279 dogs at the Newton Kennel Club show.

title: Director of City College Center For Performing Arts. Resigns

title: News Summrary and Index
description: West Germany agreed to lend Italy $2billion to help get her out of her financial crisis. The loan was announced jointly by Premier Mariano Rumor of Italy and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany after a long meeting in Bellagio, a resort in Northern Italy. West Germany will transfer marks and other hard currencies from the West German Federal Bank to the Bank of Italy. Part of the Bank of Italy's gold reserves will be put up as collateral, Mr. Schmidt said. Mr. Rumor said that only a small portion of the gold reserves would be used as collateral. [1:8.]

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SUMMITRY has taken on a new dimension, and the world will likely have to wait long past the end of President Ford's economic summit to know whether it works. This particular summit meeting takes on new dimensions almost daily It has become marathon.

Part of the adventure is arranging the flowers in unusual containers to match and blend with the interior decor.

title: Jim Bishop again

A relative had told herwhat others had carefully avoided sayingthat Lucy Mercer Rutherfurd had been sitting in the Warm Springs room when the cerebral hemorrhage struck and that this longtime love of the President had been to dinner at the White House a number of times when the First Lady was away, with Anna acting as hostess. Now, slamming the door, Mrs, Roosevelt whirled and shrilled accusing questions to the daughter.

title: A talent for taking advantage of situations
description: Nostalgia, as this book suggests, need not be mere flight from an unsatisfactory present. It can also be a means of reconstructing he happier moments of childhood, and  more importantlyof reconstructing those semiconscious decisions that, being the products of happier moments, prefigure a successful adult life. Proust I see no way to avoid this ferociously overblown comparisonreconnoitered his childhood through the memory of tastes and smells. Dick Cavett, the sometime TV talkshow host, works back through the voices he heard on the radio as a boy in the 1940's.

They also won limitations on the right of the owners to hire members of their families for some jobs.

title: Red Smith; Victory at Sea (At Any Price)
description: One week from Tuesday an Australian bucket named Southern Cross sets sail from a buoy off Brenton Reef Light in Rhode Island Sound with a single purpose in viewto remove a singularly ugly silver pitcher from the oaken table to which it stands bolted in the trophy room of the New York Yacht Club at 37 West 44th Street. Southern Cross is the 22d sailboat to challenge for the Royal Yacht Squadron Cup since Aug. 22, 1851, when the schooner America beat seven British schooners and eight cutters around the Isle of Wight and brought the trophy to the United States, where it has been known for 123 years as the America's Cup. This is the Aussies third try for the leaky old carafe, and it is devoutly to be hoped that they get a better shake this time than their predecessors received.

title: Letter from Madrid
description: MADRID. Despus Francoy: clue? After Franco what? Serendipity, or a reporter's luck, took me to Madrid this summer just when it looked as if fate was about to give a definitive answer to that old Spanish riddle. Overtaken at last by the ineluctable march of time and mortality, Generalissimo Francisco Franco, dictator of Spain for 35 years, lay apparently dying. By the afternoon of July 19, when he signed over his powers as head of the Spanish state to his chosen political heir, Don Juan Carlos, Prince of Asturias and leading scion of Spain's old royal house of Bourbon, it seemed, indeed, as if the end had come.

title: Joyce Carol Oates is frankly murderous
description: Joyce Carol Oates has managed to be in this age of aggression without seeming to be of it. Her interviews radiate reserve, delicacy, politeness; she is a professor of English in Ontario. Her life is so much at the typewriter that she has published 19 books in half as many years. Yet aut of this earnest, scholarly life Oate.s has written novel after novel of cruelty as the one overpowering lust. In them, her brilliantly dense masterpiece on the Detroit riot, she orchestrated burnings, shootings and lootings into a chorale of American losers whose rage is putifying, ennobling, whose violence has the harmony of fate.

Carleton, executive director of the nonprofit organization that sends thousands of New York City children out of the city on twoweek vacations with host families or at camps run by the fund.

title: Gang in Brooklyn Tuning in to God
description: Fifty members of the Satans, a division of the Temahawks, one of Brooklyn's most notorious street gangs, have said they have defected from a life of violence and criminal behavior and have vowed to devote themselves to efforts that will make their community a better and safer place to live. Despite skepticism in many quarters, the leader of the SatanTomahawks has promised that the pledge will last as long as he dots.

title: Ndoo Wins 15Mile Run
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 31 (AP)Philip Ndoo, a 28yearold Eastern New Mexico University student from Kenya, won the second Charleston 15mile distance run today, beating John Vitale of Connecticut by two seconds. Ndod completed the course in 1 hour 18 minutes 3 seconds.

title: Calcium Loss May Limit Space Flights
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 30  The most extensive series of physiologic experiments yet conducted in space have confirmed that man can live and work effectively in weightlessness for longer periods than once suspected. But for just how long remains an unanswered question.

title: 2 L.I. Areas Freeze Rents in Apartments
description: Declaring itself in a state of housing emergency by a 3 to 2 vote under the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, North Hempstead last week froze rents for 1,961 apartments, effective today, becoming the first town to freeze apartment rents.

title: Inflation and Change Threaten a Bucolic Enclave inthe Village
description: In 1971, former residents came from as far as California and Oregon to join their successors in the MacAougalSullivan Garden for a 50th anniversary party. The revelers filled the garden until dawn, celebrating 50 years of success. There had been problems, of course  any sort of communal living generates them but the garden had survived.

title: 3 KILLED, 6 HURT BY COAST SNIPER
description: INDIO, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP) A sniper terrorized motorists on a lonely stretch of desert for nearly six hours before dawn today, killing three persons, injuring six others and riddling several cars.

Tysen of New York has announced her daughter's engagement. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Mr. Tysen, who was chairman of the board of Previews, Inc., the realestate firm.

title: Martha Bateman

Players Association's most significant freedom issues in an antitrust suit brought in San Francisco by Joe Kapp, the former Viking Super Bowl quarterback. If Judge Sweigert decides in our favor, said Kapp's attorney, last week the association has won the strike,

What emerged from the President's careful response to a reporter's question was a clear indication that the United States will not try io derail an escalating LatinAmerican effort to end the sanctions and reopen the doors of the Organization of American States to Fidel Castro's Government.

It is interesting that no age grouping has been indicated by the publishers forany of the three.

Connell's novels the characters, prudent and cautious folk with healthy talents for survival, walk into traps so interesting of prospect and so cleverly disguised that they seemed before they snapped shut to be the very plan of a successful life. description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into unfinished news events.

title: Food: Hazelnuts make the difference
description: It is at times mindboggling to dis,. cover the extent to which one ingredient can alter, even glorify, the nature of a dish. Some years ago, we came into possession of a cheesecake recipe that seemed to be the essence of all great cheesecakes. It was delicate, rich and subtly flavored. Moreover, it was ultimately refined in texture. Sometime, later, we purchased a pound of toasted hazelnuts at the Maison Glass, New York's finest source for toasted nuts. These we ground and blended into the cake's batter. The result is to our minds paradigm of cheesecakes. We hasten to add that hazelnuts are a luxury. Already toasted, a pound costs $5 at Maison Glass. Many supermarkets carry untoasted hazelnuts which may be roasted in homeovens before using.

However, New Jersey lawenforcement officials contend that an everincreasing narcotics problem in the state involves the antiseptic offices of physicians, brightly lighted drug stores and scores of big drug companies.

title: What's Doing in DAKAR
description: THE CITYDakar, the capital, of the West African republic of Senegal, is an oceanfronted oasis at the door to the Sahel, the southern border of the vast Sahara. Of the country's 3,822,000 inhabitants, 600,000 live in the capital, which is about as African as any city on this continent even though there are strong French influences in the downtown, area. Dakar, like the rest of Senegal, is predominantly Moslem. The faithful spread their rugs five times at daywherever they areand pray while facing Mecca. Dakar's grand mosque on Allees Coursin dominates the area with a high tower from which most of the city can be seen. An impressive Catholic church, the Cathedral du Souvenir Africain, sits on Boulevard de Is Republique. Like each of the Frenchspeaking, predominantly Moslem countries in Africa, Senegal celebrates both Christian and Moslem holidays. Throughout the city, street hawkers are common and persistent. Many of them try to sell fake jewelry and watches, demandink exorbitant prices at first, then lowering them again and again in hopes of making sale. Street beggars are also a common sight.

title: Ford Son Says 76 Bid Has Effects on Family
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., Aug. 31 (AP)  President Ford's 22yearold son, Jack, says his father's apparent Intention to run for President in 1976 has created some family pressure.

Yet still ahead of him is a much more difficult and potentially more important task: changing the personnel and the procedures that served a President who liked a minimum of contact with people, centralization of authority and a regal lifestyle, characteristics that so far seem foreign to Mr. Ford.

Protection Act,last November created an atmosphere of hope that the numismatic hobby would at last be able, to mount an effectiye attack. against its most pernicious enemythe sale of unmarked imitations, and deliberate counterfeits of valuable coins, medals, paper money and political memorabilia. title: When Patti Wowed Her Fans She Really Tndid Then.
description: THE title prima donna has been bestowed all too lightly on opera singers in this century. Even the most imposing of today's divasin terms of the grandness of their nianners and the greatness of their egospale in comparison to Adelina ???(18431919), the singer who would seem to have given the term prima donna its definitive meaning. From her first appearance as a toddler of 7 at Tripler's Hall in New York City in 1850 to her final concert (after 35 years of farewells) at a London Red Cross benefit in 1914, Patti lived her role to rthe hilt, often traveling in a private railroad car, only consenting to make recordings in her Welsh castle and then only when the spirit moved her, and otherwise delighting and thrilling her admirers with her utterly outrageous behavior. What made it ail so joyous, of course, was that she was a great artist pasiessed with a genuinely great voice and her art seemed to have a universal appeal for fans and connoisseurs alike.

title: Money is still the flypaper of political campaigns
description: WASHINGTON. Nathan Cummings, 77, made a fortune in the grocery business and became a patron of the arts, giving copiously to museums in Chicago, New York, Montreal and Minneapolis. With equal fervor, he also became a patron of the Republican party. Two years ago, according to the list which Rose Mary Woods kept in her drawer, his patronage of the Finance Committee to Reelect the President amounted to $44,356.28. In earlier campaigns, Cummings says, he has given as much or more.

title: New. & Novel
description: There's hope for you, says Slade (Butch) Harris's Aunt Ann. All the rest of us are lost. Butch is a 14yearold when the book opens, living dur ing. the 1950's in rural North Carolina. His father is gone and the boy and his mother live off the bounty of relatives: Uncle Cleve and Aunt Dora, Aunt Ann and Uncle Harvey. Uncle Cleve is a mechanic who fixes cars in his front yard, where he has a block and tackle slung between trees. Rats run ad lib through Cleve's house until he gets drunk one day and kills two dozen with a semiautomatic. In the living room. Uncle Harvey is a heavy drinker who pieces out his income by running moonshine. For the women soap operas and sex are alternate daytime diversions.

title: Computer Joins the Typewriter Among News Reporter's Tools
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31  Until fairly recently, all a bright young man or woman needed to know to get ahead in the news business was how to write clear sentences, find the way to City Hall and handle a fearsome city editor.

title: Yanks Rout White Sox, 186
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31Maybe the Yankess aren't nennant bound, but they put on a championship demonstration tonight. They produced 25 hits, a season high in the American League, smashed their way to an 186 victory over the Chicago White Sox and moved within three games of the East Division lead.

title: Legislature Returns To Familiar Issues
description: TRENTON  The Legisla ture is scheduled to reconvene here Thursday amid new efforts to take up the highly controversial issue of publicschool financing, a problem that it failed to resolve before recessing in July.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching the number, win $10.000, Tickets with the five numbers in reverse win $1,000. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first middle or last three numbers In sequence win $25. Losing tickets are eligible for a special prise drawn on Thursdays.

title: The Region
description: New York State's Democrats, traditionally fractious, may have outdone themselves this year. With only a few days to go before the Sept. 10 primary, the possibility exists that the party hierarchy's designees for four major offices all will lose to challengers.

title: September
description: September comes, and summer ends and autumn hasn't quite begun. But September is a season by itself, a time of pause and slow transition, neither growth nor completion, a time of sweet. and fragrant accomplishment. Sumac, alwyas impatient to be in the colorful van

title: Jane Blalock Leads
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 31 (AP)A violent. thunder,. storm halted play near the midway point in the second round of the $35,000 Southgate open today, but not before a determined Jane Blalock surged into the lead by one stroke.

title: ThreeShow,TwoSite Circuit Attracts Entry of 5,866
description: The threeshow circuit of Tuxedo Park, Somerset Hills and Westchester that runs Friday through next Sunday has drawn a total of 5,866 dogs. Tuxedo, with 1,319, and Westchester, with 2,704, are being held at Lyndhurst, the national landmark in Tarrytown, N. Y., just south of the Tappan Zee Bridge on Route 9. Somerset, which is at the. Fair Grounds in Par Hills, N. J., limited its entry because of space conditions and will have 1,843. This is the fourth Tuxedo event since a group headed by Alexander (Sandy) Schwartz and Mrs. George B. St. George reactivated the show in 1971. That show, the first for the club since 1953, was staged on the old golf course adjacent to Route 17.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1JULIO FERNANDEZ

title: 22 Chinese Seize a Junk For Escape to Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 31 (AP)  Twentytwo persons from the Chinese mainland hijacked) a fishing junk in a small part in Kwangtung Province and forced its twoman crew to sail to Hong Kong, the police reported today.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Once an author has started with a success, it becomes increasingly harder for him to keep up the good work, but James McClure manages to do so in THE GOOSEBERRY FOOL (Harper & Row, $5.95). This is the third of McClure's South African police novels featuring Lieut. Tromp Kramer and his Bantu sidekick, Mickey Zondi. There is something of an added attraction here (Kramer's feud with a superior officer), in addition to a pair of apparently unrelated cases.

title: Filipinos Sampling Jersey Blueberries
description: TRENTONSample trays of cultivated blueberries grown in South Jersey were recently flown to Manila, the first such shipment to the Southwest Pacific. The freshpicked fruit was distributed to Manilaarea bakeries, restaurants and hotels.

title: Rockefeller Rebuts Proxmire's Charges on Spending
description: BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 31 Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller, leaving his summer place this Labor Day weekend, defended himself today against what he described as big spender charges made earlier this meek by Senator William Proxmire.

title: Chess: The Way to Beat the Swiss Is to Win, and Win, and Win
description: What is needed for success in Swisssystem tourneys is a hardhitting style that brings in points. Unlike roundrobin events, Swisssystem competition mixes players of all levels, thus making It necessary for the few highrated favorites to mow down the field to keep up with each other.

title: Highs, horns and bugs crawling
description: Short of money, long of ambition, in need of a glamorous research topic, the young Viennese doctor had read of a new wonder drug being prescribed by the brash physicians of Americaa magical potion, so its advocates claimed, that could dissipate fatigue, alleviate depression and cure everything from tuberculosis to acid dyspepsia. Sigmund Freud ordered the drug from Merck Laboratories and began to experiment on himself and Dr. Ernst von Fleischel, a close friend and a morphine addict. Between 1884 and 1887, Freud presented his findings in Uber Coca and five subsequent papers, creating something of a sensation in European medical circles. For what he described was a substance of seemingly limitless potential, a source of exhilaration and lasting euphoria that permitted intensive mental or physical work [to be] performed without fatigue. It is as though the need for food and sleep were completely banished.

title: Governmental Agencies Are Expecting to Receive a Sufficient HeatingOil Supply
description: TRENTON  Spokesmen for various governmental agencies throughout the state expressed confidence last Week that, unlike last winter, there will be a sufficient supply of heating oil this year. It also was reported that prices of oil and other fuels, although high, appear to have stabilized.

title: Bembridge Golf Victor
description: WENTWORTH, England, Aug. 31 (AP)Maurice Bembridge of Britain put on a strong finish today with four successive birdies and won the $70,000 Viyella Professional Golfers Association championship. His finalround 64 gave him a 72hole total, of 278. Peter Oosterhuis finished second, one shot behind.

title: Brooklyn Man Drowns In Pool
description: A 21yearold Brooklyn man crowned early yesterday when he and three other persons were swimming after hours in the BedfordStuyvesant community pool at Marcy and DeKalb Avenues, shortly before 3 A.M. The police said that the victim, Lawrence Hodges, of 56 North Oxford Walk, had climbed the fence with another young man and two girls to take an earlymorning dip in the closed pd.

title: MEANY IS FEARFUL OF A DEPRESSION
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Late TV Listings
description: Eyewitness News Conference: The guest is James Auerbach, president of the New Jersey Federation of Teachers, Channel 7, 12:30 P.M.

title: Broadway, the Exhibition Center.
description: AGOOD many people were stocked earlier this summer when Bernard Jacobs, speaking to the First American Congress of Theater at Princeton, came right out with it and said that he saw no future in the profit theater we have known. What he nieant, of course, was the Broadway commercial theater, and I imagine that those who have always been most vocal in their opposition to the Broadway commercial theater were as stunned by the remark as any present. Those in opposition, of course, do need something to oppose. Take that away, and what happens to the fun?

title: Town Dump Yields Gifts
description: For Picket

title: A Season in the Life of the Jets: A Guard Dog for Namath, Pink Slip for Maynard
description: The Physical Fitness Center [at Hofstra university] which housed the jets locker room',  squats next to the field at the back of the campus. The entrance to the field and locker room is guarded by a cop who retracted the fencing upon official, request, none of which was the slightest hindrance to couple of teenaged girls, who sneaked in through a back door used by the laundry and equipment men and hid in one of the toilet stalls.

title: DAVID SOLON
description: David Solon, a sales executive with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for, more than 40 years until his retirement in 1951, died yesterday in Long Beach (L.I.) He was 88 years old and lived at 522 Shore Road, Long Beach.

title: Recordings
description: THE idea of recording literature on tapes and phonograph records is certainly nothing new. Talking books for the blind have been available for many years and the list of titles from the Library of Congress as well as prillate companies is always lengthening. Spoken word specialists  Caedmon, Spoken Arts, CMS and Folkwayshave issued hundreds of albums offering readings by some of the world's most prominent actors, actresses and authors.

title: SAUDIS SAID TO BAR LOWER OIL PRICES
description: LONDON, Aug: 31  Saudi Arabia, the world's, major oilexporting country, his agreed with Algeria not to lower oil prices, the official Algerian Press Service reported today.

title: Mets Rally in 8th Inning To Turn Back Braves, 65
description: On some days, the Mets aren't content with a normal, easy victory. Like yesterday when they squandered a 40 lead over the. Atlanta Braves, but delighted a crowd of 31,211 by rallying for two runs in the eighth inning to post a 65 triumph, the sixth in their, last seven games. New York's third triumph in 11 games with the Braves seemed likely to be a routine one until Atlanta overcame a fourrun deficit with three runs in the sixth and two in the seventh off Jerry Koosman, the Met starter.

title: Miss Cole Fiancee Of Gregory Kinch
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Ashley Cole of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Cole, to Gregory Phillip Kinch, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Kinch of Murray Hill, N. J. The wedding is planned for Nov. 30 in Short Hills.

title: The World
description: Tentatively and by indirection, President Ford has clearly raised the possibility of a reconciliation with Cuba; at the same time, Fidel Castro is speaking more Moderately about the United States and pressure is increasing in LatinAmerica for an end to the ostracism of Havana.

title: Short Way to Connecticut
description: PORT JEFFERSONFrom late May through midOctober, residents of this small North Shore village hear the horns of the Martha's Vineyard blare out eight times a day as she maneuvers her way through Port Jefferson Harbor.

title: Schools (and  Males) Prime  for Women's  Sports Push
description: With the 1974 school year about to begin, and with women expected to make the greatest demands for athletic fields and facilities in history, the male establishment is bracing itself. Women's participation in school athletics, having tripled since 1971, is expected to hit the 3million mark by the end of the school year.

title: European Title Track. Setfor RomeTomorrow
description: Olympic champions are entered in 22 of the 39 events of the 11th European track and field championships, which begin tomorrow in Rome's Stadio Olimpico, site of the 1960 Olympic Games.

title: Why This Bear Market Is Different
description: After the close on the New York Stock Exchange last Tuesday, a vice president of a Wall Street brokerage firm stopped by to check the Dow Jones ticker that was humming with gentle, cricketlike chirps. Good Lord? he exclaimed. The Dow is down another 16 points!

title: Amritraj Tops Borg In FiveSet Struggle
description: From the moment Vijay Amritraj, the tall courtly Indian entered the stadium yesterday to play Bjorn Borg, the Swedish teenager, in a secondround match at the United States Open tennis championships, the 14,115 fans faced a problem.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events in Metropolitan Area
description: TodayDrag racing at MadiSon Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N.J. Track opens 1 P.M., eliminations at 6 P.M. TomorrowInternational Mo

title: Bullfighting, FrenchStyle
description: THE pineforested Landes section of southern France, just across the Pyrenees from Spain, has its own version of the bullfight. The bulls are cows, the matador is an dcarteur and there is no cape, no sword and ito moment of truth. At the end tof each fight the bullor rather the cowlives to fight again.

title: Susan Lederer Becomes Bride Of E. P. Torpey
description: Susan Kay Lederer, daughter of Dr.and Mrs. Ludwig G. Lederer of Stamford, Conn., and Edward Phillip Torpey, son of Mr.and Mrs. Walter A. Torpey also of Stamford, were married there yesterday afternoon in St. John's Lutheran Church. The Rev. Bernard Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: State Extends Programs For Driver Rehabilitation
description: Five of the state's six experimental rehabilitation programs for drunken drivers and other habitual traffic violators will be extended until next April 1.

title: INFLATION A PERIL TO ILLEGAL LIQUOR
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (UPI)Inflation is threatening to do what stateand Federal agents have been unable to do in Georgiaput the moonshiners out of business.

title: Controversy Over Burns and Fed's Role
description: In The New York Times article challenging the Olympian Fed that appeared Aug. 18, it was reported that Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, had been charged in the July issue of Fortune magazine With excessive expansion of the money supply to help the reelection of President Nixon in 1972.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York,N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A SURVEY MADE by the Senate investigations subcommittee shows that major American industries blame the energy crisis, environmental control and high interest rates for the shortages of critical materials. Capital appropriations by the nation's 1000 largest manufacturers in the second quarter totaled a record $16.29billion, Up 39 per cent since the first quarter, according to the Conference Board The Index of Leading Economic Indicators rebounded in July to 178 (1967=100), up 1.8 per cent from the June level, which had declined 0.6 per cent from May.

title: New Center Is Helping Kidney Patients
description: TEANECK  Three times a week, Frances Fritzenschaft must go to a hemodialysis center for kidney treatment. It once was a long and tiresome ordeal, but no longer.

title: RepresentativeU.S.Team Forming Under Cramer
description: In the past, the United States national team had been a mixture of professionals, semiprofessionals and amateurs. Without a fulltime coach, it had been made up on the spur of the moment, without any substantial preparation, and with players from limited areas of the country.

title: Stuart Cantor Fiance Of Lisa Faith Deutch
description: Mr.and Mrs. Murray Deutch of New York and Hewlett, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Faith Deutch, to Stuart Marc Cantor, son of Mr.and Mrs. Mel Cantor of Woodmere, L. I.

title: Entrance Test Set By Reading Clinic
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Enttrance tests for the fall session of the Rutgers Remedial Reading Clinic will be held at 9 A.M. next Saturday in Rooms Athrough A7, Hardenbergh Hall, George Street.

title: 46 Candidates Are Campaigning in 19 Primary Contests for Seats on the City Council
description: In the primaries for City Council, six candidates are locked in a freeforall in the complicated political terrain of the Lower East Side; a veteran Councilman is waging an antibossism campaign to survive in Queens, and two controversial Councilmen are engaged in a struggle for control of the South Bronx slums.

title: The Nielsen RatingsAnd How I Penetrated Their Secret Network
description: THE A.C. Nielsen Company, whose survey reports on Share of Audi ence determine the fate of mos television series, has gone to great lengths to shield from prying journalist the supposedly typical persons whose Viewing habits they regularly study. For instance Marvin Kitman, the television columnist for Newsday, once offered a cash reward to any of the 1,200 people whose sets are connected by special telephone lines to the central Nielsen computer in Dunedin, Florida, who would come forward to be interviewed. All Kitman heard from, however, were Nielsen's lawyers who threatened a law suit. (It's illegal to offer what amounts to a bribe for the breaking of the contract that Nielsen panelists sign and that forbids them to talk to the press, among others.) Life magazine was all set to publish interviews with several members of the Nielsen hookup until similar legal threats intervened. Writers for TV Guide have been trying unsuccessfully for years to pin down someone who would admit to being a part of that powerful electronic secret society.

title: Kathryn Ann Aronson Plans June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Aronson 2d of Far Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Ann Aronson, to Michael A. Caruso Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Caruso of Old Bridge, N. J.

title: Patricia Kissida Wed To David N. Speis
description: Patricia Ann Kissida, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Kissida of Piscataway, NJ., was married yesterday afternoon to David Neil Speis, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Speis of North Brunswick, N.J.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Having concluded their business with the American League's Western Division for the season, the Yankees Will return home and hope to narrow the gap between themselves and the firstplace Boston Red Sox. Tomorrow, they will face the Milwaukee Brewers in a Labor Day doubleheader at Shea Stadium, starting,at 1 P.M. They will face the Brewers again on Wednesday at 2 P.M. The Detroit Tigers come to town for a twilightnight doubleheader at 5:30 P.M. on Friday and a 2 P.M. game on Saturday. On. Saturday, the first 10,000 youngsters of 14 or younger can take pictures of their favorite Yankees starting at 11:30 A,M. The Mets wil be on the road all week for games in Chicago and St. Louis.

title: Arthur Schwartz, 77, Dead; Published Legal Directory
description: Arthur, Schwartz, board chairman of the Commercial Publishing Company in Mount Vernon, N. Y., publisher of The Commercial Bar, a legal directory, died Wednesday in Decatur, Ga., where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: EQUIPMENT RULES ATTACKED BY G. M.
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31General Motors chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, said today that such Governmentordered devices as the seat belt ignition interlock system were driving up the prices of cars and called for their elimination.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: New Jersey
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeWhat the Butler Saw. Today, 7:30. P.M.; Thursday through Sat. urday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50. $3.90; group rates.

title: even Days In August
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  When Fletcher Knebel and Charles W. Bailey wrote the book SeVen Days in May, a dozen years ago, most people regarded the idea of a military coup d'etat as merely the theme for an entertaining novel.

title: U.S. Swim Squad Tops E. Germans
description: CONCORD, Calif., Sept, 1An explosion of ekcellence, no less dazzzling for having been predicted, produced five more world records and one recordtying effort tonight as the United States swiinming team cornpleted a 198145 victory over East Germany.

title: Lexington Ave. Y Stepping Up LongLimited Musical Activity
description: Introducing New York's Litties Cultural Centerthe 92d Street Y  Size Isn't Everything. So runs the slogan to be used by the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. to announce its reentry into the thick of New York's concert life this fall.

title: Television
description: 6:10 (2)News (5)MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY TELETHON CONTINUES TO 6:30 P.M.

title: Organized Labor: Awaiting the Crash
description: Behind all the polite assurances of cooperation President Ford is receiving this Labor Day from the leaders of organized labor is a sense of apprehension only a few steps removed from panic. It is not that the union panjandrums, from George Meany down, are frightened of the amiable Michigander who has replaced their chief hate, Richard Nixon, in the White House, On the contrary, they like Mr. Ford just fine, even though in his quartercentury In Congress his batting average of right votes on the A.F.L.C.I.O. scoreboard was a sickly 148.

title: European Track Meet Opens in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 1 (UPI)President Giovanni Leone officially opened the 11th European track and field championships today. About 1,500 athletes from 29 countries will begin competing tomorrow in the Weeklong games held every two years in between Olympics. Many coaches predicted the championships would be the most open in the last 20 years. I think these are very evenly balanced chainpionships, said Igor TerOvanesian, the coach of the Soviet team.

title: A New Vacation Pattern: Stay Home and Pay Less
description: Millions of Americans appear to have abandoned traditional vacation patterns this summer to try something new as a resuit of inflation, doubts about the nation's faltering economy, high gasoline prices and psychological aftershocks of last winter's gasoline shortage.

title: Catholics Hold Vigil In Manila to Protest Raid on a Novitiate
description: MANILA, Sept. 1  About 5,000 Filipinos gathered in an emotional but orderly prayer meeting this afternoon in the concrete and stainedglass Manila Cathedral to pray for redress of injustices.

title: Arthur L. Smith Weds Miss Dorsey in Suburb
description: Sharon Michelle Dorsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Foster Dorsey of Larchmont, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to Arthur Lawrence Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Norbert Smith of Houston The Rev. Kenneth MacKenzie performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont.

title: PALESTINIANS SEIZE 4 IN BEIRUT KILLING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 1A member of the terrorist Black September Organization and four of his followers have been arrested here by security organs of Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla group, on suspicion of having kidnapped murdered a 30yearold Lebanese citizen.

title: 2 Supermarkets Plan Link For Savings and Shopping
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 26Eggs, milk, deposit paycheck, bread, cookies. $100 cash for weekend.

title: ARABS SET TALKS ON PEACE TACTICS
description: CAIRO, Sept. 1The Arab League today set Oct.26 as the date for a conference of Presidents and Kings in Rabat, Morocco, to work out a joint strategy for the next phase of Middle East peace talks.

title: Voluntary Hospitals Seen Owing City $200Million
description: Auditors for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation believe that the private, or voluntary, hospitals in New York may owe the city as much as $200million because the city has not checked in six years to see if the hospitals are providing all of the services they have been paid for.

title: John F. Shelley, Labor Leader, Legislator, Coast Mayor, Dies
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1(UPI)John F. Shelley, who began his career as a labor leader and later served as a State Senator, United States Representative and Mayor of San Francisco, died today of Jung cancer in St. Mary's Hospital. He would have been 69 years old Tuesday.

title: U.S. PLANS GRANTS TO HELP JOBLESS IF RATE GOES UP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan said today that his department had prepared a program of gradually rising payments to local governments to create jobs if national unemployment mounted.

title: Issues Demanding Action Given Priority at Home
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1President Ford inherited a number of major foreignpolicy problems from Richard M. Nixon and has already been confronted with some new ones in his first weeks in office.

title: Diver Dies in Shallow Pool
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1(UPI)Michael Hoban, 21 years old, of Scranton, Pa., was killed yesterday after he dived from the secondfloor balcony of the Burgundy Motel and landed in a pool in three feet of water.

title: Jazz Returns to Newport After Absence of 3 Years
description: NEWPORT, R. 1., Sept. 1 (AP) Outdoor jazz concerts returned to Newport this weekend after an absence of three years. About 5,000 persons attended last night's concert, featuring Herbie Mann and Ahmad Jamal.

title: City U. Grading Practices A re Found to Vary Widely
description: Grading practices in the City University's 18 undergraduate colleges vary so widely that whether a student graduates with honors, or perhaps even graduates at all, may depend as much on which campus he attends as on his ability.

description: Night Baseball

title: FEED COSTS HIT POULTRY NEN
description: Mounting cost pressures or the production of broiler chick ens on the Delmarva Peninsula could kill off much of the In dustry by the end of the yearand as much as 20 per cent of Maryland's production capacity could be gone by Christmas.

title: 3 Seeking to Unseat Murphy in 17th District Primary
description: Stretching across the suburban landscape of Staten Island to the town houses of Greenwich Village and the polyglot tenements of Chinatown, Little Italy and the Lower East Side, the 17th Congressional District is one of the least likely pieces of political real estate in the city.

title: TRADERS ACCUSED OF BILKING INDIANS
description: FARMINGTON, N. M., Aug. 31Whites and Navajo Indians accused the United States Postal Service this week of allowing Indian traders to confiscate or retain Federal welfare and pension checks to pay grocery bills.

title: Jet Spans Atlantic in Less Than 2 Hours
description: FARNBOROUGH, England Sept. 1 (AP)A United States Air Force spy plane broke the speed record between New York and London by nearly three hours today.

title: Browns Top Bengals in Last Minute
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 1(AP)Mike Phipps's passing led Cleveland to two touchdowns in the last 30 seconds today, giving the Browns a 2117 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals. It ended the Bengals perfect National Football League exhibition season.

title: Nicklaus Overtakes Snead as Storm Suspends Golf
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Sept. 1Thundershowers and lightning disrupted today the final round of the Tournament Players Championship, forcing a suspension until tomorrow.

title: Deborah Marinsky, Editorial Aide, Wed
description: Deborah Marinsky and Frank DiGiacomo were married yesterday afternoon at the Gramercy Park Hotel by Rabbi Albert B. Belton.

title: A Coed Camp That's Run Like amountain Resort
description: NARROWSBURG, N. Y.A little bit of history was made at Camp Keowa here recently: Two hundred girl and boy Explorers spent a week at camptogether.

title: Ford's Foreign Problems and Prospects: The View From Major World Capitals
description: In an address to a joint session of Congress the week fore, last, President Ford said that he intended to continue the foreign policies of President Nixon In the accompanying dispatches, correspondents of The New York Times report on how capitals around the world currently view their chief problems in relations with the United States. A dispatch from Washington gives the view of the problems from there.

title: Carey Stresses His Experience; Vows Unity and an Open Door
description: I'd hate to be ahead the way he's ahead, Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn declared. He better look over his shoulder because someone's going by himwith your help.

title: Union Breakthroughs
description: In recent years labor has had few organizational victories to cheer about outside the burgeoning civil service. In unionism's traditional bluecollar strongholds membership has been sliding downhill under the combined impact of new technology and the labor movement's own internal stagnation.

title: GermanItalian Deal Ignores U.S.Policy
description: The evaluation of gold at a price higher than the official $42.22 an ounce in the new loan agreement between West Germany and Italy is regarded by economic observers as a revival, of the use of gold in the battered world monetary system.

title: Poles Win in Soccer
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 1 (UPI)  Poland, playing without the finesse that won it the bronze medal in the World Cup this year, beat Finland, 21, today in a European Nations Cup Group Four soccer match.

title: Stock Market Closed
description: All securities and commodities exchanges in the United States will be closed today in observance of Labor Day. Banks and government offices also will be closed. Exchanges overseas will observe normal trading hotirs.

title: Labor Parties Falter in New Zealand and Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 1 The Labor parties of New Zealand and Australia returned to power in 1972after long periods in parliamentary oppositionunder the leadership of two strong personalities: Norman E. Kirk and Gough Whitlam.

title: Parents Form Group to Fight Religious Cults Hold on Young
description: DENVER, Sept. 1A small group of parents whose children have become members of fringe religious groups announced yesterday the formation of a national organization to fight the influence of socalled religious cults on young people.

title: Puerto Ricans and Police Clash in a Riot in Newark
description: A Labor Day weekend festival at a park in Newark erupted into a riot yesterday afternoon as hundreds of Puerto Ricans hurled rocks and bottles and fought a gunshotpunctuated pitched battle with clubswinging policemen.

title: Parents Fight for Survival Of Model Children's Clinic.
description: East Harlem parents are fighting to save a demonstration child health clinic they say is the first with a staff that understands their problems and provides the kind of personalized care they want for their children.

title: Typhoon Kills 2 in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1 (AP)A typhoon battered western Japan with 60mileanhour winds today, leaving two persons dead, 15 injured and three missing, officials said.

title: Tennis or Darts or Backgammon, Anyone?
description: Tennis or Darts or Backgammon, Anyone?

title: Doctors Report Franco Can Resume Customary Life
description: MADRID, Sept, 1  A sevenmember medical team declared today that Generalissimo Francisco Franco had completely recovered from his recent illness fand was able to resume his customary life.

description: ACROSS

title: Wall St. Firms Getting Set for Bullion
description: Among the few optimists in Wall Street today are those preparing to trade in gold bullion after New Year's Dayor conceivably soonerwhen it will become legal for Americans to own and deal in the metal for the first time in more than 40years.

title: 2 in Senate Race Wary on Backing Victor of Primary
description: Each of the two major contenders for the Democratic United States Senate nomination, Lee Alexander and Ramsey Clark, refused yesterday to say that he would, if defeated in the primary next week, support the other against the Republican incumbent, Jacob K. Javits, in November.
