description: Grading practices in the City University's 18 undergraduate colleges vary so widely that whether a student graduates with honors, or perhaps even graduates at all, may depend as much on which campus he attends as on his ability.

title: Sikkim Leader Says India Illegally Seeks Absorption
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's decision to place Sikkim under Indian sovereignty has unleashed angry attacks on the Indian Government.

title: A Gallup Poll Finds 56% Want Nixon to Face Criminal Charges
description: A majority of the American people believe that former President Richard M. Nixon should be tried for possible criminal charges arising from the Watergate case, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: ChinaMalaysia Ties Due
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  Malaysia and China will establish diplomatic missions later this month, the Foreign Ministry announced here today.

title: Blalock Tied for Golf Lead
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 1(UPI)Sue Roberts chipped in a 30foot birdie on the 18th hole today and tied Jane Blalock at the 36hole mark of the $35,000 Southgate women's golf tournament. Both will go into the final round of the raindeliyed tournament tomorrow with twounderpar totals of 142.

title: State Leads Exports of 3 Major Industries
description: New York State, one of the five biggest exporting states, leads in exports by the instrument industry, the printing and publishing industry and the apparel industry, the New York State Department of Commerce reported this weekend.

title: Yugoslays Strive to Identify Train Crash Victims

title: Brazil Expects a Slowing of Economic Miracle
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 1 Arab, Japanese and American investors, rural migrants, and skilled technicians from all over Latin America are still flowing here to take part in the world's newest industrial revolution.

title: ARCHBISHOP FACES JERUSALEM TRIAL
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 1Archbishop Hilarion Capucci, the head of the Greek Catholic Church in Jerusalem, will go on trial in the district court there later this month as an alleged gunrunner for Al Fatah, the Palestinian guerrilla organization, officials said today.

title: OffDuty Officer Kills Man.
description: An off  duty police officer last night shot and killed a 21yearold Bronx man in a bar and grill after the man refused to surrender his gun, the police reported. Officer Richard Lomax, 44 years old, said he observed a man, identified 4 Michael Daniels, of 700 East 156th Street, holding a 25  caliber pistol in the men's washroom at the Dixon Lounge, 690 East 161st Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The 17th Congressional District is one of the least likely, pieces of political real estate in New York City. But it has attracted an unlikely trio of reform Democrats who are trying to take the Congressional nomination from Representative John M. Murphy, a sixterm incumbent who is so confident that he has printed the date of the Nov. 5 general election on his campaign brochures to save himself another trip to the printer after the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Yachts Idle; Cup Choice Due Tonight
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1There was no wind on the ocean here today and no race between Courageous and Intrepid at the America's Cup trials. But the slugging between the 12Meter yachts will definitely end tomorrow with the 20th match race between the two whitehulled vessels.

title: Hawaiians Top Texans
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 1 (AP) Norris Weese, who lost his starting quarterback job last week to Ed Hargett, regained it tonight when he rallied the Hawaiians to an uphill 33.15victory over the Houston Texans in the World Football League.

title: Army Is Hurt by Rulings on Detection of Drug Users
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Aug. 29  A United States Army officer here says that court decisions that random urinalysis could not be used to identity drug users had hurt but not crippled the Army's efforts to control drug abuse among its 183,000 soldiers in Europe.

title: Thousands of Portuguese Troops Are Leaving Bissau
description: BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea, Sept. 1The departure of the 33,000 Portuguese troops here has begun as formal recognition of this territory's independence nears.

description: Now that the Jets have escaped the mosquitoes and other bugs of New Orleans, they can concentrate on eliminating the bugs in their offense that have plunged the team's prospects from promise to pessimism.

title: Botswana Schedules Election
description: GABERONES, Botswana, Sept. 1 (Agence FrancePresse) The Botswana Parliament has been dissolved and a general election will be held Oct. 26, the Government Gazette announced this weekend. Botswana, formerly Bechuanaland, gained independence from Britain Sept. 30, 1966.

title: BLAKE CABOT, 69, MEDICAL WRITER
description: Blake. Cabot, a writer and medical publisher, died yesterday of a brain tumor at his home, 530 East 72d Street. He was 69 years old and also lived in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Dr. Harold Yochum, Headed Capital University in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 1(UPI)The Rev. Dr. Harold Leland Yochum, former president of Capital University here, died today at Grant Hospital of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Now that the days of the string bikini are numbered, at least for this season, it's time to start thinking about something a bit more substantial. A pair of suede trousers, for instance, or a furtrimmed leather coat. Or, if you can afford it, a suede suitwith pants or skirtto slip into when the weather turns chilly.

title: McGraw. Gets First Shutout as Aaron, Bids Farewell
description: Good pitching is making the difference for, us lately, said Manager Yogi Berra of the Mets yesterday after his club scored a 3.0 triumph over the Atlanta Braves on the strength of a fivehit shutoutthe first of his nineyear careerby Tug McGraw.

title: Browns Top Bengals in Lastkinute
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 1(AP)Mike Phipps's passing led Cleveland to two touchdowns in the last 30 seconds today, giving the Browns a 2117 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals. It ended the Bengals perfect National Football League exhibition season.

description: Rebecca Graff Courland, a leader in Zionist and Jewish educational activities, died Saturday at her home, 285 Central Park West. She was 84years old.

title: Dr. Horace Sowles, Surgeon At Massachusetts General
description: FALMOUTH, Me., Sept. 1 Dr. Horace K. Sowles, former surgeon in chief at the Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, died yesterday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

description: TROY, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP)s The switchboard at The Times Record was flooded with calls this weekend, many of them from really irate citizens wondering what had become of the newspaper's obituaries.

title: Kissinger on Virgin Islands

R., Sept. 1(UPI)Secretary of State Kissinger has been reading a lot land swimming a little during a brief vacation at a Rockefellerowned resort on St. John Island in the Virgin Islands, an aide to Secretary Kissinger said today. Mr. Kissinger and his wife Nancy arrived Friday at the Caneel Bay resort owned by the Rockefeller family.

description: Millions of Americans appear to have abandoned traditional vacation patterns this summer to try something new as a result of inflation, doubts about the nation's faltering economy, high gasoline prices and psychological aftershocks of last winter's gasoline shortage.

title: RapeRobbery Suspect Seized in a Similar Case
description: A 27yearold former convict was arrested by Queens detectives Saturday night and charged with the July 6 robbery of a beauty parlor in Jamaica, in which a lone gunman stripped and fondled nine women customers And Raped nother BeFore Taking Their money.

title: Red Smith
description: When Charles. Francis Adams owned the Boston Braves, the Boston Bruins and Suffolk Downs, Kenesaw Mountain Landis ordered him to get out of baseball racing. (The first and greatest baseball commissioner had nothing against hockey, perhaps being aware that bookmakers refused to handle action on a game that could be fixed by bribing only one player, The goaltender). C. Adams was no profound /student of baseball but he was a noted connoisseur of money, and his race track was doing livelier business than his ball club. This was 1940 when the Braves had a lastplace team that regularly finished next to last because the Phillies were in the same league. In spite of an amusing manager named Casey Stengel and an outfielder named Johnny Cooney who was hitting .318, prospects were not bright that they could become a gate attraction to rival the Red Sox, who had people named Ted Williams, Jimmy Foxx, Lefty Grove and Doc Cramer. title: Dragged Into Progress
description: Those who believe that public education ought to be an independent force for progress find it depressing whenever school authorities wait for the courts to remind them of their responsibilities. The latest case in point is the order by Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel, directing the city's Board of Education to provide bilingual instruction in basic academic subjects to all Spanishspeaking pupils whose difficulties with English would otherwise impede their educational achievements.

title: To Our Readers
description: Effective today, the newsstand price of the weekday New York Times has been increased to 20 cents in the New York metropolitan area and Long Island. Sharply higher operating costs, particularly the cost of newsprint, have made this price increase necessary.

title: Budget Unit Finds City Costs Up As Much as 482% Since 1964
description: The city is spending nearly six times as much for welfare as, it did 10 years ago, almost three times as much for education and three and a half times as much on health services.

title: Era, of Good Feeling
description: The transition from Richard Nixon's clandestine and oligarchical reign to the open Presidency ushered in so appealingly by Gerald Ford has already done much to rekindle public faith in the integrity of constitutional government. Durable confidence in the President's capacity to deal with the nation's problems, however, calls for a swift recognition in the White House that this restoration of public trust cannot long survive on a diet solely of relief and euphoria. Dismantling the Nixon Administration's machinery for national mastery must be viewed as only a prelude to effective leadership.

title: Andretti 2d To Redman On Coast
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 1(UPI)Brian Redman of England won the California Grand Prix today at Ontario Motor Speedway by 26 seconds over Mario Andretti and took the lead in the Formula 5000 series. Both drivers were in LolaChevrolets.

title: Petty Favored in Southern 500 Today
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 1 (UPI)  Richard Petty, starting from the pole position is favored to win the 25th Southern 500 stock car race tomorrow. Buddy Baker; David Pearsoh and Cale Yarborough round out the first two rows and are expected to stay with Petty around the narrow 1mile Darlington Raceway, the nation's oldest superspeedway. About 70,000 persons are expected to watch the silver anniversary running of the Southern, one of the most prestigious events of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing circuit. Although Petty has won more races and money than anyone else in NASCAR history, he has never placed much emphasis on winning the pole position The Southern 500 will be only the second time this season that he has held the pole, despite having won eight races.

title: Ford's Advisers Oppose Keynesians

Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Boardthink that exactly the opposite is true.

title: Kennedy Galleries Marks 100 Years of Americana
description: When the Kennedy Galleries opened its doors on John Street in Lower Manhattan in 1874, the Metropolian Museum had been around for only four years and the Whitney Museum of American Art wouldn't be founded for another 40 years. Except for Knoedler's in New York and Vose in Boston, Kennedy, which was then known as H. Wunderlich & Co., was one of the few art galleries in the country.

title: 2 Convicted Killers Missing
description: TRENTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)Two women convicted of murder who were on escorted furloughs from the Correctional Institution for Women in Clinton have not reported back to the prison A spokesman for the state's Department of Institutions and Agencies said today that the women, Vivian Pemberton, 39 years old, of Newark, and Jacqueline Reaves, 32, of Trenton, were on separate furloughs. The spokesman said that Miss Pemberton went to visit her daughter in Newark and that Miss Reaves went to visit her family in Trenton.

title: Merciful But Lawful
description: During a month's vacation spent in New York, California, Hawaii and Indiana, most of the Americans I spoke to said they had no desire to see Richard Nixon prosecuted. title: Maltese Boxer. Dies

title: Market Place:Novel Proposal To Aid Utilities
description: President Ford is committed to doing something for the nation's capitalstarved utilities, but the question is what? Borrowing costs are astronomical today and some utilities have withdrawn issues of bonds, deferring vital power projects rather than pay an unacceptably high price for money. It wouldn't be so bad if the utilities could call bonds a few years hence for reissuance in a lower interest rate period. Reserving this option in today's market, however, merely makes an issue even less acceptable.

title: CAREY THREATENS TO WITHHOLD HELP IF SAMUELS WINS

title: Primary for Democrats
description: One clear lesson of Watergate is the need for much greater vigilance by the voters themselves in getting to know and evaluate the qualifications of aspirants for major public office. title: Advertising: Selective Coupons
description: When Richard Rovsek founded the Media Sampling Corporation three years ago, his concept was to provide corporations that wanted to reach the public with sample products an opportunity to do so inexpensively and with the consumer picking wanted items.

title: HENRY H. DUDLEY, 83, ADJUTANT OF LEGION
description: OMAHA, Sept. 2 (UPI)Henry H. Dudley, national adjutant of the American Legion from 1948 until his retirement in 1957, died here Saturday. His age was 83.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: A MOON FOR THE MISBEGOTTEN, a play by Eugene O'Neill. Directed by Jose Quintero, starring Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst. Reopening at the Morocco Theater, at 7:30, through Nov. 17.

title: CARELLA OPTIMISTIC ON LOTTERY'S FATE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 2 (AP) With the legality of stateoperated lotteries in doubt, State Lottery Director Charles Carella says he is hopeful that the New Jersey lottery will live on.

title: ISAAC GOLDMERSTEIN
description: Isaac R. Goldmerstein, structural engineer, died Sunday at his home, 210 Riverside Drive. He was 87 years old.

title: Learning the Art of Cuisine: From Boiling Water to Boning Duck
description: New York's culinary, schools are one breed of academy that in recent years have thrived and multiplied in response to a popular demand that has kept their halls well stocked with students.

title: FRANCO RESUMES HIS ROLE AS CHIEF
description: MADRID, Sept. 2Generalissimo Francisco Franco reassumed full power today as Chief of State, a day after his doctors declared him cured of his recent illness.

title: SexSlaying Case Raises Issues for Justice System
description: On Nov. 3, 1969, a Manhattan grand jury indicted Charles W. Yukl for the firstdegree strangulation murder of a young woman.

title: Population Talks Called Valuable First Step
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 1Delegates from 135 nations apparently agree that the first intergovernmental conference on world population problems has been a success despite the indefinite nature of the policy statement they drafted here and in the face of assertions that they took only token notice of the population growth rates.

title: 11 ARE APPOINTED TO INDUSTRY UNIT
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday the appointment of 11 members to the New York City Industrial Development Agency, a new corporation set up to encourage industry and stem the decline in manufacturing jobs.

title: Storm Here Disrupts Power, Blocks Roads and the L.I.R.R.
description: Earlymorning thunderstorms dumped .87 inches of rain on the city yesterday between midnight and 3:30 A.M. Accompanied by strong winds, the storms toppled power lines, causing some blackouts, flooded roadways and cused two washouts on the Long Island Railroad.

title: The Music Fades
description: One of the pleasures of living in the New York Metropolitan area has been the ready access to a variety of classical music on the radio. In much of the country, there is virtually no alternative to the endless barrage of country, rock and Western music that rules the air.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two new consumer laws went into effect in New York this weekend. One measure, effective Sunday, outlaws the harassing of tenants by relocation companiesby the withholding of services or initiation of spurious servicesto force the tenants to move from buildings scheduled for demolition. Yesterday a law barring chain, or pyramid, distributor schemes in the state went into effect. Both laws were approved by the 1974 session of the State Legislature.

title: Auto Makers Find Little to Celebrate on Their New Year's Eve
description: DETROIT, Sept. 2  It is now New Year's Eve in the Motor City, by the auto industry's calendar.

title: Peyser Staff to Explain Pension Reform Law
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Persons seeking information about the details of the new pension reform act were offered help today by Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester County.

title: OWNER OF BAR DEAD IN SUSPICIOUS FIRE
description: A Bronx bar owner, who was robbed and asaulted by two thugs last Thursday, was found dead by firemen in his burning and apparently ransacked apartment over the bar early yesterday. The police said he might have been slain by the same assailants.

title: Bitter AntiCommunism Seems to Be on the Wane in Greece
description: SIDEROKASTRON, Greece, Aug. 30In the late nineteenforties, when Communist guerrilla bands roamed northern Greece, they abducted thousands of children and sent them to Communist Eastern Europe for indoctrination. Two of the children were brothers of George Tsalparas, a medical orderly in this town about nine miles from the Bulgarian border.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 2 (UPI)The dollar advanced strongly on almost all international currency markets today dropped only in Paris and stayed the same in Tokyo.

title: New Law Rebuffs A.B.A. on Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The pension reform legislation that President Ford signed today contains a provision that may force conservative leaders in the legal profession to abandon a campaign to restruct the form of prepaid legal insurance that is favored by labor unions.

title: IRVING ASTRACHAN IOF STUYVESANT HIGH
description: Irving Astrachan, former chairman of the English department and dean of students at Stuyvesant High School, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 545 East 14th Street.

title: Skewed Sacrifice
description: Useful as it is to have the Federal Government try to set an example of belttightening in the war against inflation, we see little fairness in President Ford's decision to compel 16 million Federal employes to wait three extra months before receiving the 5.5 per cent pay raise they were scheduled to get Oct. 1.

title: Two Soviet Astronauts Given Order of Lenin
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (UPI) The two Soyuz 15 astronauts, Gennady Sarafanov and Lev Demin, have been awarded the title Hero of the Soviet Union and the Order of Lenin, according to reports today on Moscow television.

title: 75 Million Loss Reported In a Lloyds Bank Branch
description: PARIS, Sept. 2One of the bluest of the bluechip British banks, Lloyds Bank, Ltd., announced today that it has suffered losses of up to $75million because of irregularities, including unauthorized foreign exchange dealings at its branch in Lugano, Switzerland, near the Italian border.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WNCN. Carnival Overture, Dvorak; Concerto Grosso in A minor, Torelli; Chattering Monkeys from Java Suite, Godowsky; Les Mans, Franck; Overture to the Birthday Ode, 1768, Boyce; Romanesca for Trumpet and Continuo, Marini; Sonetto 123 del Petrarca, Liszt; Overture to Il Signor Bruschino, ROssini; Chernomor's March from Russian and Ludmila, Glinka; Concerto Grosso, Handel.

title: Tanner Beats Nastase
description: After 12,168 frustrated fans had run around outside the Forest Hills stadium yesterday trying to see all the fiveset thrillers going on at once at the United States Open tennis championships, they finally were rewarded with a big upset inside the stadium. Seventhseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the 1972 champion, was toppled by 22yearold Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn.

title: 7 in Cash Family Hurt
description: HENDERSONVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2 (UPI)Seven members of the Johnny Cash family were injured today, when their jeep hit a mud puddle, swerved out of control and overturned en a driveway near Mr. Cash's home. John Carter Cash, 4yearold son of the country music singer and June Carter, appeared to be the only one with more than minor injuries. The boy sustained head injuries. He was rushed to Vanderbilt Hospital at nerby Nashvile. Mr. Cash himself was out of town.

title: Italian Communists Vow To Retain Western Ties
description: ROME, Sept. 2The Italian Communist party, in the latest intensification of its campaign to obtain a share in government power, is seeking to reassure the United States that it would not weaken the Western alliance.

title: Girls, Boys, Cats, Dogs, Presidents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2President Ford is a cat man and has sons. These facts have been overlooked by the political analysts, although nothing else we know about him tells more precisely what a radical departure he is from the main line of modern Presidents.

title: COUPLE FOUND SLAIN IN BRONX TENEMENT
description: The bodies of, a young woman and a former convict were found early yesterdaY on the topfloor landing of a tenement at 642 Concord Avenue, in the South Bronx. Both had been shot.

title: Samuels Doesn'tMiss a Bet Campaigning Among His Old Friends
description: Out on the city's sweltering sidewalks, imploring the votes of a largely cynical and apathetic multitude, Howard J. Samuels seldom misses an opportunity to drop into the branches of the Off Track setting Corporation that lie along his path.

title: Nudity Increases in America
description: DENVER, Sept. 2Long accustomed to casual dress, Americans showed this summer that they were becoming increasingly tolerant of and open about casual undress.

title: Limited Redress
description: The court ordered destruction of a file the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been keeping on the correspondence of a New Jersey student with the Socialist Workers party constitutes only minimal redress of an obvious misuse of police power.

title: Hudson Parkway to Get Alternating Traffic Plan
description: At the request of Riverside Drive residents, the city's Transportation Administration will test an alternating northsouth trafficflow plan on the stretch of Henry Hudson Parkway between 72d and 79th Streets, which is undergoing major repairs.

title: Dave Anderson
description: His fiancee is America's Sweetheart but he's considered to be the Ugly American of tennis. Jimmy Connors is the Wimbledon men's champion. His betrothed, Chris Evert, is the Wimbledon ms. champion. But their images are so different. She is prim and proper. He's petulant. His small eyes peer out from a narrow face framed in a pageboy. With his shirttail flying he moves with the aggressive arrogance that has endeared Pete Rose to most baseball fans but he lacks that certain style that tennis devotees demand. Not that he seems to care. The way I play, he said yesterday, is the way I want to play. On his 22d birthday he defeated John Alexander of Australia, 61, 7.5, 67, 64, to advance to a fourthround match today with Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia in the United States. Open championships. But the loudest bursts of applause in Forest Hills Stadium had been for the Australian as the spectators were embarrassed by Connors's behavior.

title: President Returns To Mountain Retreat To Study Amnesty
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Sept. 2 (UPI)President Ford took a briefcase filled with homework on the amnesty question when he returned today to this Presidential retreat after he had signed the pensionreform bill at the White House.

title: $75,000 in Valuables Missing From Home
description: Jewels and furs valued at between $75,000 and $100,000 were reported missing last night from the Brooklyn home of a widow who had been away for the Labor Day weekend, the police said.

title: Ray Charles Plays Delayed Program At Park Festival
description: A bomb threatlater proved to be a false alarmremoved Ray Charles from the Schaefer Music Festival two weeks ago but he came back to Central Park yesterday to honor the original engagement. The usual Ray Charles arrivedbacked by his big band, joined by his singing group, the Raelettes, and with the comfort of his long string of hit songs to fall back on.

title: CARIBBEAN STORM HITS MEXICAN COAST
description: MERIDA, Mexico, Sept. 2 (AP)  A hurricane ripped ashore on Mexico's sparsely populated Caribbean coast today with torrential rains and winds gusting up to 175 miles aan hour.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 2The track and field picture at Rutgers hasn't been too bright the last few years, but that should change within a short time. Mr. Gags has returned to New Jersey and Rutgers has him.

title: ANEW DISORDERS FLARE IN NEWARK; POLICE MOBILIZE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 2New disorders erupted here late today while Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson sought through conferences to calm tensions in the Puerto Rican community growing out of yesterday's clashes, in which three men were shot and 13 other persons were injured.

title: Cale Chevy Scores at Darlington
description: DARLINGTON, S. C Sept. 2 (AP). Cale. Yarborough, the only aurviltor arnong the prerace, favorites, won the silver anniversary. Southern 500 stock car race today. The event turned into horrendous destruction of expensive racing machinery.

title: Joseph A. Beime of Phone Union Dies
description: Joseph A. Beirne, an outspoken labor leader who had served as president of the 500,000member Communications Workers of America from the time he helped found it in 1947 until his retirement in June, died yesterday of cancer in the Washington Hospital Center. He was 63 years old.

title: Nicklaus Wins on 272 By 2 Shots
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Sept. 2Jack Nicklaus put the finishing touch today on the projectstarted yesterday. He won the Tournament Players Championship, which, with two days of interruptions by thunderstorms and lightning, turned out to be about as long as Gone With the Wind.

title: BRITISH TO EXPAND POLICE IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept 2Britain today announced a new security plan for Northern Ireland that is designed to transfer more responsibility for defense against terrorism from the British Army to the citizens of the province.

title: Oil Producers Dampen Hopes Of a Cut in Prices for Gasoline
description: VIENNA, Sept., 2 (UPI)the oilproducing nations today dampened hopes of a cut in gasoline prices by agreeing to recommend to its members that crude oil prices should stay at their present level for the rest of this year.

title: Franco Back in Power
description: Generalissimo Francisco Franco reassumed full power yesterday as Chief of State of Spain, a day after doctors pronounced him cured of his recent illness. Page 13.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Hunting accidentsand the upland bird season will soon begin in the Northeast separate into three main categories: carelessness, selfdelusion, and, rarest of all, sheer chance.

title: Poodle Chosen Top Dog Of 1,388 in Jersey Show
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., Sept. 2  The poodle has been America's most popular dog for 14 years. Of more than a million dogs registered last year with the American Kennel Club, 193,400 were members of that breed, However, bestinshow victories have not been too frequent of late.

title: Swedes Win First World Star Race
description: LAREDO, Spain, Sept. 2 (AP)Hamburg XVIII, skippered by Pelle Peterson and Ingvar Hanson of Sweden, won the opening race today in the 51st World Star Class sailing championship. American yachts finished second and third among the fleet of 51 boats from 12 countries. Swiff, with Tom Blackaller and Ron Anderson aboard, finished second, and Cat Willy, with Larry. Whipple and Jim Alexander, was third in the first of six races in the series. Switzerland finished fourth and Italy was fifth.

title: GOING OUT GULDE
description: ARTSY C1RAFTSY Twice a year, the streets of Greenwich Village become filled with the wares of artists and artisans from around the city. It's one of the biggest outdoor art shows in New York, and one of the few such shows left. A lot of critics belittle the achievements of the artists, of course, but they simply miss the point. The Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit (as it's called) it one of the real friends of the city's sidewalk tourists  in other words, the people who live here all year round.

title: State's Tomato Crop This Year Called The Biggest and Best in Recent Times
description: CAMDEN  While drought has shriveled the nation's grain crop, New Jersey is producing the biggest and best tomato crop the East has seen in years.

title: 75Million Loss Reported In a Lloyds Bank Branch
description: PARIS, Sept, 2One of the bluczi 4 the bluechip British banks, Lloyds Bank, Ltd., announced today that it has suffered losses of up to $75million because of irregularities, including unauthorized foreign exchange dealings at its branch in Lugano, Switzerland, near the Italian border.

title: JEROME WAGNER
description: Jerome Wagner, president of Wagner Advertising, Inc., 25 West 43d Street, which he founded about 40 years ago, died Sunday. He was 63 years old. He lived at 250 East 65th Street.

title: Break in Phone Rates
description: ALBANY, Sept. 2 (UPI)The Public Service Commission said tonight it had accepted a proposal by the New York Telephone Company to allow fraternities, sororities, convents and monasteries to receive directory listings under their formal names and still receive residential rates.

title: Rare Whale Dies on Beach
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)A rarely seen false killer whale became grounded and died on a Monterey beach yesterday. Scientists speculated that the 1,500pound, 13footlong mammal beached herself and died of old age.

title: Franco Back in Power
description: Generalissimo Francisco Franco reassumed full power yesterday as Chief of State of Spain, a day after doctors pronounced him cured of his recent illness Page 13.

title: Palestinians Said to Seek A Meeting With Kissinger
description: CAIRO, Sept. 2The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization has reportedly informed the United States, through third parties, that it would like to enter into direct discussion with Washington, preferably by a meeting of Secretary of State Kissinger and Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization's chairman.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Riots Mar Campaign For Newark.Harmony
description: The weekend's disturbances in Newark flared despite the Gibson administration's longtime effort to soften the city's image of racial polarization and to restore municipal integrity, stabilize taxes and ease severe housing shortages and high crime rates and unemployment.

title: Talks Open Today In the Coal Industry As Strike Threatens
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP)  Contract negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association begin tomorrow, less than three months before the expiration of their present threeyear pact.

title: Congress Plans Hearings on Dogfighting
description: A Congressional begin subcommittee will begin hearings in washington this month into illegal dogfighting, gambling and otherillegal activity associated with the fights throughout the country.

title: Stars Triumph, 2416, To Share Lead in East
description: Undismayed by the smallest crowd to see a World Football League game in the United States, the Stars last night formed their own cheering section as they defeated the Philadelphia Bell, 2416.

title: E. F. Hutton Showing Wall Street How to Scramble
description: Smile Wall Street executives call their competitors at the E. F. Hutton Group, Inc., aggressive. One says Hutton is ruthlessly aggressive.

title: 18 Food Businesses Cited as Infractors Of City Health Code
description: The Health Department has named 18 more food businesses for failing their second Health Code inspection and has warned that closure notices will be issued if the violations persist upon a final visit by inspectors. The establishments cited are the following:

title: SCHOOLS VIEWED AS CITY LESSON
description: The experience of school decentralization in New York City shows that election of local boards or councils is probably essential if other government services are to be similarly decentralized.

title: Rams Kay Sidelined
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)A Los Angeles Rams, linebacker, Rick Kay, who underwent surgery yesterday for torn knee ligaments, will be out of action for 12 weeks, a team spokesman said today. A cornerback, Eddie McMillan, who suffered a concus sion and pinched neck nerve Saturday, is not scheduled to play this Sunday at San Francisco.

title: Illinois Woman Elected President of W.C.T.U.
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP)  The national Woman's Christian Temperance Union today elected Mrs. Herman Stanley of Evanston, Ill., as its new president.

title: Vacation Changing In France
description: PARIS, Sept. 2  The sacred annual August vacation, which drains Paris and other major cities of France, is over.

title: Rams Kay Sidelined
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)A Los Angeles Rains linebacker, Rick Kay, who underwent surgery yesterday for torn knee ligaments, will be out of action for 12 weeks, a team spokesman said today. A cornerback, Eddie McMillan, who suffered a concussion and pinched neck nerve Saturday, is not scheduled to play this Sunday at San Francisco.

title: 2 REPORTED KILLED BY CHILEAN POLICE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The Washington Post reported today that two supporters of the late Chilean President, Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, were fatally shot after having been detained by the police near Santiago.

title: Dr. Jack Goldberg Dies at 53; Dean of Social Work at N.Y
description: Dr. Jack R. Goldberg, dean of the New York University Graduate School of Social Work and a former city Commissioner of Social Services, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 3 Washington Mews.

title: Canadian Colt Wins Rich Race
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP)The Canadianbred Greek Answer led virtually all the way to score a threequarterlength victory today in the $204,175 ArlingtonWashington Futurity at Arlington Park.

title: Book Publishers Cautious on Fall List
description: Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., ran off 6,500 copies of Margaret Drabble's biography of Arnold Bennett with the last page left out by mistake. William Morrow & Co. is sending an orange tabby cat to hobnob with book critics on national television shows. Harper & Row's crusty senior editor, Cass Canfield, has decried the natural extravagance of Americans while preparing his own $17.50 book on J. Pierpont Morgan.

title: CYPRUS ECONOMY CRIPPLED BY WAP
description: LAPITHOS, Cyprus, Sept. 1 Millions of unripe lemons still cling to the trees in the rich groves near this abandoned Greek Cypriote town on the northern coast of the Island.

title: PATH TO COLLEGE NARROW IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP)For Valery, a 1974 graduate of a Soviet secondary school, there has been no vacation. Most of his time since June has been spent in study.

title: Young Mountain Climber
description: PORTLAND, Ore. Sept. 2 (UPI)  Fiveyearold Penelope White reached the top of Oregon's Mt. Hood tonight. Her sister Samantha clhnbed. Mt. Kilimanjaro at the age of 8 a year ago. Penelope reached the 11,236foot summit of Mt. Hood with Samantha and her parents.

title: REV. L. S. ATHERTON OF FORDHAM DEAD
description: The Rev. Lawrence S. Atherton, a faculty member and administrator at Fordham University from 1936 to 1956, died here Sunday at the age of 72. He lived at the Mount Manresa retreat house in Rosebank, S. I.

title: Blanche H. Smith, 80, Dies; Led Meriden Newspaper
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 2 (AP) Mrs. Blanche Hixson Smith, board chairman and editorial chairman of The Meriden Record Company, died Saturday. She was 80 years old.

title: STUDENT D. PLAN SCORED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A plan for District of Columbia high school students to carry photo identification cards is under attack on the ground that the system would not help solve discipline problems but could lead to an atmosphere of repression.

title: City Schools a Pattern For Widen Local Rule
description: A staff report issued by the New York State Charter Revision Commission, based on a study of school decentralization in New York City, suggests that elected local boards or councils run things or other government services are decentralized in the future.

title: Pension Reform Bill Signe by President On Historic Day
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2President Ford signed into law today a mammoth pension reform act that is aimed at protecting the retirement benefits of 23 million workers from bankruptcies of employers and looting by union officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your editorial reaction so far to Turkey's intervention in Cyprus lacks historical perspective and seems so automatic in condemnation of the Turks that it invites the judgment of being irrelevant.

title: Cambodia Said to Doom 2 High School Students
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 2 (UPI)A military tribunal has sentenced two high school students to death and ordered long prison terms for 10 in the deaths of Cambodia's Minister of Education and his top aide, the press here reported today.

title: CAREY THREATENS TO WITHHOLD HELP IF SAMUELS WINS
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey warned yesterday that he might not support Howard J. Samuels for Governor if Mr. Samuels won the Sept. 10 primary unless he stopped what Mr. Carey called personal, vindictive and vicious attacks on himselfand his brother, Edward Carey.

title: BISHOP INDICTED FOR GUNRUNNING
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 3The Most Rev. Hitenon Capucci, the Greek Catholic Patriarchal Vicar of Jerusalem, was indicted today on three counts involving gunrunning for Arab guerrillas.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: 230 Nonteaching Employes At Polytechnic Go on Strike
description: Two hundred and thirty nonteaching employeg at the Brooklyn and Farmingdale, L. I., campuses of Polytechnic Institute of New York went but on strike yesterday as the first day of fallterm registration began.

title: Coal Talks Open as Both Sides Voice Hope of Avertini Strike
description: WASHINGTON; Sept. 3 (UP) The United Mine Workers and the nation's soft coal producers began bargainirm today on a new contract, with the union presenting about 200 demands for higher wages and improved safety rules and fringe benefits.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: CAIRO, Sept. 3 (AP)Verdi's Atidathe opera commissioned for the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869 will be performed here again next summer when the canal reopens, the newspaper Al Ahram said today.

title: FORD IS EXPECTED TO NAME GEN. HAIG NATO COMMANDER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Gen. Alexander M. Haig, Jr., chief of the White House staff, is expected to be appointed supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and of United States forces in Europe by President Ford, two authoritative Administration officials said today.

title: Jets Send Schmitt, 31, To Packers
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, Sept. 3 At the age of 31, John Schmitt is finally leaving home.

title: FARM PRICE RISE SET FOR EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 3The European Common Market promised its 10 million farmers today that it would take measures later this month to increase their incomes.

title: City's Weather in August
description: City's Weather in August

title: Spirit of 64 Has Yanks Surging Like Mets of '73
description: As if touched by destiny, the Yankees are following a timetable that resulted in a Mets pennant last year.

title: New Corn Type Exceeds Beef in Quality of Protein
description: EL BATAN, MexicoScientists at the International Corn and Wheat Improvement Center here have developed a new variety of corn that surpassis beef in protein quality and, pound for pound, contains twice as much protein as milk.

title: OIL ACCORD REACHED BY OPEC'S ADVISERS
description: VIENNA, Sept. 3 (UPI) Advisers to the world's major oil exporting nations ended six days of talks today in agreement to recommend that their governments cut back crude oil production to maintain the high price of oil, conference sources said.

title: JAMES L. O'LEARY, 68, GYNECOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. James L. O'Leary, a physician and prominent Roman Catholic layman, died on Saturday at the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 68 years old and lived at 1655 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: NEWARK ORDERS CURFEW AND BANS SIRE PROTESTS
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3A curfew was ordered tonight in a 10squareblock area for residents younger than 18, while street demonstrations even those involving as few as three personswere prohibited throughout Newark in new efforts to avert disorder.

title: News Summary and Index
description: News Summary? and Index

title: 3 Killed in Plane Crash
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (UPI) Three members of a Texas family were killed today while apparently attempting to return to the Blue Ash Airport, north of here, after their singleengine airplane developed engine trouble. Officials identified the victims as Robert A. Williams, 29 years old; his wife. Barbara, 29; and their son, Jeffrey, two months. Mr. Williams was the administrator or Caprock Hospital in Floydada, Tex.

title: Mitchell Asks for No Seal On Watergate. Trial Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, arguing that prospective jurors could not become any more prejudiced against him than they are already, asked today that the jury in the upcoming Watergate trial not be sequestered during the trial.

title: White House to Abolish Position Held by hsuit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The White House position held by the Rev. John McLaughlin, a Jesuit priest who was one of President Nixon's chief defenders, is being abolished, President Ford's chief spokesman said today.

title: Citizens Union Lists Choices For Legislature and Council
description: The Citizens Union yesterday endorsed candidates for Senate, Assembly and City Council races in next Tuesday's Democratic primary.

title: CLARK PRESENTS INFLATION STAND
description: Leonard Rose and Ann Scott released their position paper on inflation yesterdayits basic points presented outside Greenwich Village A, & P. by Ramsey Clark, the United States Senate candidate whose campaign has featured research documents by volunteer specialists such as Mr. Ross and Miss Scott.

title: It's 50 Years Since Saks Led the Trek North of 42d St.
description: There was a coffin in the middle of the car, and the two men plunked themselves down on top of it. Then, there in the seclusion they had been seeking, they reached an agreement that was to electrify the retail trade and have dramatic implications for the future of the city.

title: Rosewall, Amritraj, Ashe Win
description: Ken Rosewall and Arthur Ashe, who know their way around, found their way, out of trouble and into the quarterfinals of the United States Open tennis championships yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Stormy Pirates Anchor Grip on First
description: Nobody really tries to figure out the Pittsburgh Pirates anymore. All that's known for certain is that the Pirate crew is a hardy band of individualists, at times given to mutiny, who presently rule the seas in the National League East and threaten to take no hostages.

title: Red Smith
description: So now Courageous, a new tin bucket from the Bronx sailed by a brand new skipper from Marblehead, Mass., stands elected as defender of the America's Cup. Picking the latest baby of the naval architect, Olin Stephens, over her woodhulled predecessor, Intrepid, was no easy task for the New York Yacht Club's selection committee, for in a summer of headandhead competition, Intrepid outsailed her rival 11 times in 20 matches, or 13 in 22 if you count two informal races on the club's annual cruise. However, earlier results were thrown out when the final round of trials began three weeks ago, and it all boiled down to the last race Monday, when Ted Hood took charge of Courageous for the first time.

title: Jets Send Schmitt, 31, To Packers
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 3 At the age of 31, John Schmitt is finally leaving home.

title: Heart Transplant on Coast
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 3 (UPI)  A Salt Lake City man with a transplanted heart has been reported in stable condition following the operation at the Stanford Medical Center. Dr. Norman Shumway and his staff performed the operation Friday on Eugene Michel, 47 years old. It was the 76th heart transplant at the center.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL IN LIGHT TRADING
description: After scoring gains in the first hour, prices on the American Stock Exchange retreated and closed sharply lower for the day in light trading. Prices on the overthecounter market also dropped.

title: A Febrile Congo Brings Out Rhythm Of Ballet Hispanico
description: Tina Ramirez's Ballet Hispanico of New York always draws enthusiastic crowds, and its dancers always seem to be enjoying themselves. There is a zest to its productions and Monday evening at Lincoln Center Plaza was no different.

title: ULSTER EXTREMISTS PICK ENOCH POWELL
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 3One of England's most controversial politicians, Enoch Powell, was chosen by the hardline Ulster. Unionist party tonight as a candidate for the British Parliament.

title: Steel Output Down 0.6% During Week To 2.65 Million Tons
description: Steel production declined 0:6 per cent to 2.65 million tons in the week ended Aug. 31, compared with the previous week's 2.66 million net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: ABU DHABI ACQUIRES 60% OF OIL CONCERN
description: ABU DHABI, Sept. 3, (Reuters)An agreement was signed here today giving the government of Abu Dhabi a 60 per cent share of the Abu Dhabi Petroleum Company, retroactive to January, 1974.

title: Motorcycle Stunt Man Hutt
description: WEST RICHLAND, Wash., Sept 3 (UPI)A good friend of Evel Knievel, the motorcycle stunt than, was seriously injured last night when he crashed while attempting his first professional jump. Gary Edelin of Kennewick, Wash., an experienced dirt jumper, failed to get enough speed and his motorcycle hit the end of a 60foot ramp and flipped him over.

title: Dow Chemical to Expand Its Louisiana Complex
description: MIDLAND, Mich., Sept. 3 (Reuters) The Dow Chemical Company plans to spend more than $165million to expand its Louisiana division complex in Iberville and West Baton Rouge parishes.

title: 2Party Economic Approach Is Ford Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 In a sharp departure, President Ford has moved to make management of the economy a bipartisan policy, in much the same way that foreign affairs has traditionally been.

title: A Legal Services Program Set Up for Union Members
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 3 (UPI)The Tolley International Corporation announced today that it had established the first prepaid legal services program for members of a labor union under terms of an amendment to the TaftHartley Act.

title: Air Deaths Linked to Storm
description: JENA, La., Sept. 3 (UPI)Lasalle Parish, La., officials have attributed the deaths of four persons in a light plane crash to a heavy thunderstorm the aircraft flew into 50 minutes after takeoff. The Beechcraft Bonanza, which went into a straight spin and crashed into a wooded area Sunday, was flying from Shreveport, La. to Pensacola, Fla. The victims were identified as Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Cassard, their son Michael, 18 years old, and Anthony T. Goeders, 20, all from Shreveport.

title: Ticket Lag Threatens Giants TV Here
description: If you're counting on watching the New York Giants home football games on television again this fall, better consider other alternatives: the Giants may not sell out any of their Yale Bowl games.

title: Mets Beat Cubs, 20 and 114; Extend Winning Streak to 6
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3Jon Matlack pitched a fourhit shutout and Tom Seaver won his ninth game today in 20 and 114 victories for the Mets over the Chicago Cubs. The Mets have now won six straight games.

title: NEWARK ORDERS CURFEW AND BANS STREET PROTESTS
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3A curfew was ordered tonight in a wide area for residents younger than 18, while street demonstrationseven those involving as few as three personswere prohibited throughout Newark in new efforts to avert disorder.

title: Morgenthau Says Record Backs Him on Bruce Trial
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, contender for Manhattan District Attorney, produced court transcript yesterday that he said supported his allegation that his oppdnent, District Attorney Robert H. Kuh, had tried to prevent Lenny Bruce, the late comedian, from being free on bail while preparing his appeal on obscenity charges. on obscenity charges as a hard line on law and order. Mr. Kuh had asked for a prison term for Mr. Bruce.

title: Television
Big Board Is Asking S. E.C. for 7% Rise On All $2;000 Deals
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for a 7 per cent rise in commissions on all brokerage transactions worth more than $2,000. The exchange had indicated earlier that it would seek an increase of up to 10 per cent.

title: Smile. The Prophets of Gloom and Doom Are Not All Right
description: Many formerly optimistic social observers have come increasingly, to believe in the negative characteristics of being human.

title: Advertising: New Magazine Tack
description: A quiet revolution is going on in the magazine world as publishers, plagued with rising paper and postal costs, are putting tremendous emphasis, on singlecopy sales.

title: Portuguese guineans End Spying Life
description: CUNTIMA, Portuguese Guinea To the farmers, herdsmen] and Portuguese soldiers in this forested region just south of] Senegal, Mamadu Ba was simply a hardworking, constantly traveling merchant who did not make much money despite his cleverness as a smuggler.

title: Uruguay Will Permit Foreign Currency Deals
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 3 (UPI)  Carlos Ricci, central bank president, announced today that Uruguay would soon allow unrestricted buying of foreign currency.

title: People in Sports
description: John Shumate, the former Notre Dame allAmerica basketball player and the firstround draft choice of the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association last May, has been hospitalized with a blood clot in his left lung. The 6foot9inch, 235pound Shumate, the son of an Elizabeth (N.J.) minister, was hospitalized with a blood clot in his left leg that put him on the critical list during his sophomore season at Notre Dame. Shumate, recalling the incident, said, At first the doctors weren't sure if I'd live.

title: Maddox Is Beaten for Governor In Runoff Primary in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 3Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox, one of the most outspoken and flamboyant segregationists still in Southern politics, was decisively defeated today in his hid to win the Democratic nomination for Georgia's governorship.

title: There Is Never an Ideal Time, just So Little Time
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 The economic outlook is increasingly grave. The Ford Administration's response is ambigubus and inadequate.

title: BONN CHIEF EXPECTS A EUROPEAN PARLEY
description: BONN, Sept. 3  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, returning to Bonn this morning from his talk with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, said that he was quite sure that there would be a meeting of European heads of government this year.

title: Intrepid Planning Another Try in 77
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 3 (UPO)Woodhulled Intrepid will return in 1977 with her nickel, dime and dollar West Coast effort in vest of an elusive third America's Cup defense.

title: SEOUL CAUTIONS TOKYO ON BREACH
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3The South Korean Ambassador warned today that his nation's relations with Japan had reached dangerous and delicate stage.

title: 2 Brothers Die in Car Crash,
description: EMPIRE, solo., Sept. 3 (UPI), Two brothers from New York were killed today after their car went out of control and struck a sign post and a barrier rail near Empire. The Colorado State Patrol identified the victims as Steven T. Mueller, the driver, 23 years old, of 22128 Fairbbry Avenue, and Barry J. Mueller, 29, of 8980 Springfield Boulevard, both Queens Village, Queens. The brothers were visiting relatives in Colorado, of ficials said.

title: A Strike Threat and Costs Plague Nonpublic Schools
description: Amid inflationrelated rising costs, pressures for higher salaries and pinched family budgets, religious schools serving nearly threequarters of a million pupils in the metropolitan New York area and in New Jersey begin opening their doors this week for a new school year.

title: Religious Writer in Soviet Said to Receive Exit Visa
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (Reuters) Anatoly LevitinKrasnov, a major dissident writer and spokesman in a campaign for religious freedom in the Soviet Union, has received permission to emigrate, friends said today.

title: REP CAREY ALTERS STAND ON SAMUELS
description: Repersentative Hugh L. Careey reversed himself yesterday and told Howard J. Samuels, his Democratic gubernatorlai primary opponent, that he would endorse him should Mr. Samuels win the primary election next Tuesday.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX:
description: Page

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)July constructim fell 0.7 per cent, or $900million, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $137.2billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Borzov Wins 100Meter Dash in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 3  Valery Borzov, the Soviet Union's double Olympic sprint champion in 1972, rose to the occasion again today to win his third straight title at the European track and field championships in Rome's Stadio Olympico. Borzov won by two feet from Pietro Mennea of Italy in 10.27 seconds, equal to his winning time in 1971 at Helsinki, Fineland.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.)Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. (RadioWHN, 2:30 P.M.)

title: NEOFASCISTS ASKED ABOUT ITALIAN BLAST
description: ROME, Sept. 3Two senior officials of the Italian neoFascist party were questioned today by a state prosecutor investigating the terrorist bombing of a train last month in which 12 persons were killed.

title: Russians Cite Anxiety on Bonn's Berlin Office
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3  The Communist party news aper Pravda today sounded a fresh note of Soviet displeasure over the setting up of a West German environmental office in West Berlin, contending that its presence created serious concern and anxiety among the world democratic public.

title: Marion Canby, Poet, Dead; Widow of Review Founder
description: Marion Canby, poet and the widow of Henry Seidel Canby, founder and editor of the Saturday Review of Literature, died Friday at Kent, Conn. She was 89 years old.

title: MOOD IS CAUTIOUS IN CREDIT SECTOR
description: The credit market began the week on a cautious note yesterday, with prices of fixedinterest securities moving narrowly in the absence of trendsetting major offerings. Prices of Treasury bills and coupon issues were generally off a bit in quiet dealings. The Federal Reserve's only appearance in the market was as a seller of bills on behalf of a customer, which dealers suspected was the Bank of England.

title: Bulls Acquire Thurmond Warriors Get Ray, Cash and Draft Pick
description: The Chicago Bulls, who always claimed they were a center away from challenging the Milwaukee Bucks for the National Basketball Association Midwest Division title, filled that void yesterday with Nate Thurmond.

title: U. S. WINS TALKS ON NAZISM CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3East Germany has agreed for the first time to hold discussions on the possible compensation of Jewish victims of Nazism, State Department officials said today. The talks would come sometime after tomorrow's establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States.

title: BERYL COLLENS
description: Beryl Collens, a retired manufacturer of aircraft instruments, died Sunday at his home on Springwater Lane, New Canaan, Conn. He was 70 years old.

title: Top of the Slate
description: New York's Democratic voters face difficult choices Tuesday in hotly contested primary races for three positions at the top of the party slate for the November statewide elections. The winners will face a designated Republican ticket headed by Gov. Malcolm Wilson, Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso running for Lieutenant Governor, Mayor Stephen May of Rochester for Controller, and veteran Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Holiday Fights
description: Monterrey, Mexico  Ruben Olivares, Mexico, knocked out Enrique Garcia, Mexico, 5 rounds, featherweights.

title: Pro Transactions
Maddox Is Defeated
description: Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox was defeated in his bid to win the Democratic nomination for Governor of Georgia in a runoff primary. George Busbee, the moderate majority leader of the Georgia House, won. Page 21.

title: Lloyds Loss Spreads Distress Abroad
description: LONDON, SEPT.3A new wave of uncertainty spread through the European financial; community today following the disclosure of heavy foreignexchange losses at a Swiss branch of Lloyds Bank, Ltd., one of London's Big Four banks.

title: Meter It. Parked After Car
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa (AP)D. H. Short parked his automobile as usual. He returned to find a parking meter had been installed and he had been given a $5 ticket for not feeding it.

title: Robert H. Minton Is Dead; Retired Stockbroker, 70
description: Robert H. Minton, a retired Stockbroker, died Monday at his home, 19 East 72d Street. He was 70 years old.

title: Major League Baseball and Standings
description: Major League Baseball and Standings

title: Pressed Steel's Dividend Up
description: The Standard Pressed Steel Company announced yesterday the third increase in its common stock dividend in nine months, doubling the quarterly, payout during the period. The quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share, payable Sept. 27 to holders of record Sept. 13 was increased from 8 cents.

title: Byrne Holds Unusual Hearing on Bill To Permit Motorcycles on Parkway
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3  In highly unusual move today, Governor Byrne conducted a public hearing in his outer office to help him decide whether to sign a controversial bill to permit motorcycles on the Garden State Parkway.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Entertainment Events Today

title: Farm Commodity Futures Fall As Traders Rush to Liquidate
description: Farm commodity futures plunged yesterday in Chicago, as a wave of liquidation overpowered strong opening prices on the Board of Trade.

title: Carey and Samuels Debate Financial Backing
description: Quarreling over the sources of each other's support, the Democratic candidates for Governor spoke at the New York Times yesterday in a debate that is excerpted here. Representative Hugh L. Cirey, a veteran of Congressional argument, was the challenger, politelybut persistentlyinterjecting objections that threw Howard J. Samuels, former head of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, off verbal stride. Mr. Samuels, animated and discursive, gesticulating as he spoke, criticized loans to the Carey campaign by the candidate's brother, an oil man. Mr. Carey, brisk and confident, gazing reflectively at the tabletop, challenged Mr. Samuels over campaign contributions from people who had done buiness with OTB. Each interpolated occasional strained praise for the other, but only at the end did they hurriedly speak of how they planned to beat Malcolm. Wilson, the Republican incumbent.

title: Werker Named to U.S. Bench
description: Henry F. Werker of Greenville, N.Y., a former Greene County judge, was sworn in here yesterday, as a Federal District Judge for the Southern District of New York.

title: Heavy Rains Snarl Traffic and Power
description: Scattered torrential rainstorms swept over the metropolitan area yesterday, flooding highways, disrupting electric service in northern New Jersey and causing major traffic problems on both sides of the Hudson River.

title: TV: Mama and Darrow Offer Glimpse of Season
description: Tonight at 8 o'clock, ABC gets a jump on the new television season with the first episode of a series called That's My Mama. At 9:30 P.M., NBC offers the season's first prestige special in Clarence Darrow, an adaptation of the successful stage production starring Henry Fonda. These two offerings provide a glimpse of television's potential at its dreariest and at its best.

title: Boxing Franchise Sold
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)  World Team Boxing said today it had sold a franchise to a group in the Virgin Islands for $10,000. Robert Barbuto, vice president of World Team Boxing, said the franchise was purchased by a group headed by Raymond Jones, a resident of St. Thomas and a retired New York politician.

title: BIG PLANT CONTRACT IS WON BY CHEMICO
description: The Chemical Construction Corporation, a unit of the General Tire and Rubber Company's AerojetGeneral Corporation, announced yesterday that it I was a member of a consortium of companies awarded a contract valued at $850million to build what is described as the world's largest plant for the liquefaction of natural gas. The contract award was announced Monday in Algiers by Sonatrach, the Algerian National Oil and Gas Company.

title: FORD IS EXPECTED TO NAME GEN. HAIG NATO COMMANDER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Gen. Alexander M. Haig, Jr., chief pf the White House staff, is expected to be appointed supreme commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and of United States forces in Europe by President Ford, two authoritative Administration officials said today.

title: Storm Cuts Power And Snarls Traffic
description: Widely scattered torrential rainstorms yesterday evening caused power failures and flooding of subways and highways in the metropolitan area.

title: Canada Victor, 21
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept 3 (Reuters) Canada's field hockey team beat Argentina, 21, today to tie their threematch series at 11. The winner will be the American representative in next year's World Cup competition in Malaysia.

title: Fullback, 20, Dies
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 3 (UPI)Sylvester Williams, a 20yearold Florida A. and M. fullback collapsed and died yesterday on the practice field. Williams, from Apalachicola, Fla., collapsed, before practice and was pronounced dead on arrived at Tallahassee Memorial Hospital.

title: Sports News Brief
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 (AP)Japan dominated the action at the Asian Games again today, setting three records and increasing her number of gold medals to 17 in the international competition of 24 nations.

title: Patty Cake 2 Years Old; Mother Pregnant Again
description: From the perspective of the first gorilla born in the metropolitan area the timing could have been better. For no sooner had Patty Cake dug into a banana shortcake presented yesterday in honor of her second birthday than the Parks Department announced that her mother, Lulu, was pregnant again.

title: Belmont Crowds, Betting Up Sharply With Tax Cut
description: Give New York horseplayers a looser parimutuel tax rein, and they'll respond like Secretariat.

title: LAND DEVELOPER TO MAKE REFUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced its final acceptance today of a negotiated settlement requiring a Miami land development company to refund nearly $3million collected for parcels of land in Florida and Arizona.

title: Exxon, Mobil Abandon Well
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) Exxon, U.S.A. and the Mobil Oil Corporation announced today they had abandoned the first well drilled on the Destin anticline in the Gulf of Mexico, 40 miles southwest of Panama City, Fla. Drilled to a depth of 10,930 feet, the unproductive well is on a block for which Exxon, Mobil and the Champlin Petroleum Corporation bid $212million at a government auction.

title: S. WINS TALKS ON NAZISM VIE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3East Germany has agreed for the first time to hold discussions on the possible compensation of Jewish victims of Nazism, State Department officials said today. The talks would come sometime after tomorrow's establishment of diplomatic relations with the United States.

title: Environment Officials Await Ford Signal on Future
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3President Ford and Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will have their first meeting tomorrow afternoon at a time of real uncertainty about the new President's position on the environment and willingness to spend large amounts of Federal money to improve it.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Ford Aide Is Wary on Inflation Meetings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The man who is organizing, for President Ford, the forthcoming conferences on inflation cautioned today against expectations that dramatic actions would immediately follow the meetings.

title: SIX IN FAMILY SEIZE CONSULATE ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP) Six members of a French family barricaded themselves inside the French Consulate today and one said, We have enough gasoline to burn down the building and we're willing to burn with it unless we get justice.

title: Robertson Ends Career; N.B.A. Great Accepts CBSTV Pact
description: Pro basketball has lost what once was its greatest and most complete player.

title: Libyan Urges Arabs to Continue Using Oil as a Political. Weapon
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 3Col. Muammar elQaddafi said today that the Arabs should continue to use oil as a weapon to obtain political objects.

title: Benjamin Greenspan Dead; Lawyer Active in Community
description: Benjamin Greenspan, a lawyer active in community affairs, died Friday at the Yale Medical Center in New Haven. He was 81 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West here.

title: FILIPINO BISHOPS ASK END OF CURBS
description: MANILA, Sept. 3The Roman Catholic bishops of the Philippines have formally asked President Ferdinand E. Marcos to lift martial law and restore civil liberties so as to give meaning to his New Society reform program.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Southern California Edison Company has issued a letter of intent to purchase four Westinghouse Electric Corporation's steamturbine generators for the Kaiparowits Power Project in southern Utalt. The commitment for the fossil fuel generating equipment is valued at about $100million. The total value of the coalfired generating station project is $1.4billion.

title: Illinois Gets Campaign Law
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP)Illinois today became the 47th state with a campaign finance disclosure law. Gov. Daniel Walker signed legislation requiring candidates for state and local office and their campaign committees to report contributions of $150 or more.

title: U.S. JUDGE ALLOWS TEACHER PICKETS
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept 3 (AP) Declaring that their constitutional rights were violated, Judge Hugh Bownes of Federal District Court ruled today that pickets could resume their demonstrations in the nation's longest teachers strike.

title: As If You Didn't Know Already, We Are in a Recession
description: My answer to the question of whether the United States economy is in recession is yes, though the full story is still unfolding. What has happened so far this year bears a strong resemblance to previous recessions.

title: Newark Urban Coalition Sets Up a Rumor Line
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3  The Greater Newark Urban Coalition announced tonight that the newly formed Hispanic Emergency Council had set up a rumorcontrol center and monitoring agency in Room 108 of the Y.M.C.A. at 600 Broad Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Public Service Commission declined yesterday a request from the Long Island Lighting Company lump $30million with its current $57.9million raterise request. But the agency said it would conduct a new investigation of LILCO's construction and maintenance budgets to determine if the $30million was needed.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GENRE NOIR This is a month for cinematic celebration. The New York Film Festival starts in a week or so at Lincoln Center, and today the New York Cultural Center (5812311) begins a salute to Jean Renoir with a showing of eight films, many, of them very rarely seen.

title: Mr. Ford's Inherited Diplomats
description: BRUSSELSPresident Ford has not had time to look over the United States ambassadors he inherited from the Nixon Administration in Europe, but a strong case could probably be made for reappraisal and change.

title: Egyptian Food Shortages and Economic Ill Stir Bitter Criticism
description: CAIRO, Sept. 3In one of the most heated debates ever held in the Egyptian Parliament, members harshly questioned the Minister of Trade recently and told him that if he felt he could not do his job he should resign.

title: Market Place:
description: The bear market dropped International Business Machines 8 points yesterday to close at 183, a new low for the year. The decline represented a loss on I.B.M.'s 146,858,000 shares of about one and a quarter billion dollars on the day.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CRANFORD, Sept. 3Fathers and sons competing together in golf or tennis is nothing new. But the James Harringtons, Senior and Junior, did accomplish something new in New Jersey sports history recently when they competed in an Amateur Athletic Union decathalon meet.

title: 3 City Street Names Now Spelled Correctly
description: Correcting errors that city maps and record books have carried for more than 70 years,. Mayor Beame signed legislation yesterday correcting the misspellings of three streets.

title: 19,000 ACRES SOLD BY AGRONOMICS
description: The American Agronomics Corporation, a developer of oitrus groves, announced yesterday the sale of 19,000 acres of land in Desoto County, Fla., for about $12.4million. The company said anagreement in pin Merger ciple had been News reached to enable it to acquire 1.458 million shares of its common stock from Jules and Jack Freeman and their families, or about 60 per cent of the common shares outstanding. The Freemans, it was said, will resign as directors of the company. The company said also that it had agreed to settle the class action suits involving claims of about 3,000 investors who purchased more than 25,000 acres of orange groves from 1960 to 1972. The suits alleged that the company and several individuals violated Federal securities laws and other statutes by misrepresenting the merits of investing in orange groves.

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC OPERATING AGAIN
description: Striking members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers returned to their jobs yesterday at 13 of 16 plants of the Western Electric Company following ratification of a new contract.

title: Samuels Children Plan To Vote a Split Ticket
description: A split has developed in Howard J. Samuels personal, if not political, familyat least two, and perhaps five, of the children of the Democratic gubernatorial primary candidate endorsed a different candidate for Lieutenant Governor than the one supported by their father.

title: People and Business
description: Ross D. Hill, who retired Sept. 1 as president of the Union Dime Savings Bank, has been named vice chairman and a member of the board of trustees of Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, a Bostonbased teal estate investment trust whose adviser is the Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A. Mr. Hill, 62, had been with Union Dime 45 years.

title: Ford Reported Likely To Address the U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP)  White House sources said today that President Ford was tentatively planning to address the United Nations General Assembly later this month, following the example of recent Presidents.

title: Books of The Times
description: In July of 1969, on a beach near Southampton, Jack Willis and Mary Pieshette were bodysurfing when a wave caught Jack and broke his neck. He was 36, she was 24 and they were planning to marry soon. Judging by the photograph on the jacket of  But There Are Always Miracles, they were, before the accident, a handsome, vitallooking couple. He is smiling a bit too vehemently and there is a hint of coarseness in her expression, but this may be a result of the angle at which her face is tilted.

title: Cotton Markets
description: Cotton Markets

title: Music Clubs Resist Perils of Overkill
description: Rockmusic clubs are now in upheaval in New York. But they continue to pose an alternative to the swelling gigantism of popmusic concerts, and to play a vital part in the contemporary Music business.

title: New Shellfish Warning
description: BOSTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)Massachusetts health officials renewed their warning today against shellfish harvesting in a broad area on the northern. New England coast after four persons were stricken with paralytic shellfish poisoning. The four became ill after eating mussels they dug in a state park at Rye, N. H.

title: NEVADA CHECKING A CASINO'S CREDIT
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 3An investigation into questionable credit dealings with the Tropicana Hotel casino here is being conducted by the Nevada State Gaming Control Board, a board member said today.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures

title: Song Wins $30,500 and a Piano
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 3The finals of the American Song Festival began at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center here at 7:45 last night, 45 minutes late. They ended, for all practical purposes, at 5:55 A.M. today, when Skitch Henderson of the judges panel announced the festival grandprize winner.

title: DEAN BEGINS TERM FOR MVERUP ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 3 (AP) John W. Dean 3d began his prison sentence today, more than a year after he publicly confessed his complicity in the Watergate coverup and accused the President of the United States of also being involved. As Mr. Dean surrendered to begin a onetofour year term for obstructing justice, he refused to comment when asked whether former President Richard M. Nixon should also be charged with Watergate crimes.

title: New Border Clash Reported by Israel, Second This Week
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Sept. 4Two Arabs were killed and four Israelis were killed or wounded this morning when group of Arab infiltrators tried to cross into Israel. The clash took place near Fasuta on the border with Lebanon.

title: Some Link Rioting To Chrohic Neglect
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3  In August, 1967, following the July riots in Newark and other New Jersey cities, Gov. Richard J. Hughes appointed a Select Commission on Civil Disorders to determine the causes of the disturbances.

title: Some Link Rioting To Chronic Neglect
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3  In August, 1967, following the July riots in Newark and other New Jersey cities, Gov. Richard J. Hughes appointed a Select Commission on Civil Disorders to determine the causes of the disturbances.

title: Weather For Month of September
description: Weather For Month of September

title: Robertson Ends Career;
description: Robertson Retires for TV Career a third time and find something else.

title: LISTEFERS OFFER MN $100,000
description: Thousands of listeners to classical music on FM radio station WNCN have offered to contribute to a Save WNCN campaign organized last week after William F. Buckley Jr. revealed that the station would change to a popmusic format Ion Oct. 5.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Belmont Race Charts

title: NAUMBURG ORY IS GIVEN SIN PARK
description: The Naumburg Symphony Orchestra's summer concerts on the Central Park Mali have fallen into a pattern in recent years. The fourth and final program, which takes place on Labor Day, is now regularly devoted to opera, usually one that is rarely performed. On Monday night it was Rossini's Il Conte Ory.

title: FEDERAL UNIONS VOW FIGHT ON PAY DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Angry Government employe union leaders have vowed an allout fight in Congress to overturn President Ford's proposed threemonth delay of Federal whitecollar pay raises.

title: Stocks Slide Again; Dow Drops by 15.25
description: Prices resumed their recent losing pattern on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday Friday's sharp technical rally ran out of steam.

title: Maddox Far Eehind
description: Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox was apparently defeated in his bid to win the Democratic nomination for Governor of Georgia in a runoff primary. He was lagging well behind George Busbee, the moderate majority leader of the Georgia House. Page 21.

title: Papp to Give Course In Directing at Yale
description: Joseph Papp, producer and founder of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has been named Visiting Critic in Directing by the Yale School of Drama for the 197475 academic year, it was announced yesterday by. Robert grustein, dean of the school.

title: Box Scores
description: Box Scores

title: Papandreou Forms Athens Leftist Party
description: ATHENS, Sept. 3Andreas Papandreou formed a new political organization today and sharply criticized the Government of Premier Constantine Caramanlis for not rooting out the remnants of the military dictatorship that ruled Greece for seven years.

title: Suburban Schools Opening With Threats of Strikes
description: Teachers in Yonkers voted yesterday to strike public schools there, and strikes appeared likely in the East Meadow, L. I., and North Haven, Conn., school districts.

title: LEBANON CHARGES ISRAELI INCURSION
