description: Fight Promoter Denies Wrongdoing

title: Jeremy Musher Dies at 38; A Professor of Chemistry
description: Dr. Jeremy Musher, professor of chemistry at Yeshiva University's Belfer Graduate School of Science and a research authority on the structure and bonding of molecules, died yesterday at New York Hospital of cancer and complications from pneumonia. He was 38 years old and lived at 55 Central Park West.

title: French Foreign Minister To Visit Israel Oct. 31
description: PARIS, Sept. 6  The French Foreign Minister, Jean Sauvagnargues, will pay an official visit to Israel Oct. 31and Nov. 1, it was announced here today.

title: Socialists Seek to Transform the Democratic Party
description: Social Democrats, U.S.A., descendants of the Socialist party, began their national convention here yesterday pledging to work with the trade union movement and the Democratic party to achieve socialist goals.

title: U.S. and Soviet to Resume Arms Talks; Wide Differences Are Said to Remain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 President Ford announced today that the SovietAmerican talks on limiting strategic nuclear arms would resume on Sept. 18.

title: Wilson's Net Worth
description: Governor Wilson released a networth statement yesterday, reporting that he and his wife had $632,580.14 in assets, and no liabilities. Page 16.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Ford Joins 600 at Funeral for Abrams
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the Army Chief of Staff, was buried today in rainswept Arlington National Cemetery, mourned by President Ford and comrades from World War II to Vietnam.

title: Two Swipes Help Snap New York Streak at 7
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6Lou Brock got two hits in four times at bat, knocked in a run, scored another and went two for three in thefts on the basepaths tonight to spark the St. Louis Cardinals to a 30 victory over New York that snapped the Mets sevengame winning streak.

title: Franklin Doubles Dividend
description: The Franklin Mint Corporation announced yesterday in Franklin Center, Pa., that it was raising its quarterly dividend on common stock to 10cents per share from 5 cents. The dividend is payable on Sept. 30 to shareholders of record Sept. 16.

title: FORD TO CREATE CLEMENCY BOARD
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (President Ford has decided to establish a clemency review board to consider the cases of Vietnamera deser Lers and draft dodgers, an aide said tonight.]

title: President Has Doubts on Federal Aid for Child Carel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6President Ford told the heads of 16 of'the nation's bestknown women's organizations today that he had serious reservations about the desirability of creating a program of Government  financed child  care centers. He promised, however, to look further into the matter.

title: Bowling in Moscow
description: SKOKIE, Ill., Sept. 6 (AP) The Soviet Union's first bowling center will be open to the public on Sept. 27 in Moscow's. Gorki Park, it was announced today by the Brunswick Corporation, the company installing the 16lane plant. Fred (Skee) Foremsky of Houston and Mary DeBarbrie of Belmont, Calif., professional bowlers, will be brought to Moscow to teach the Russians how to bowl.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Tokyama, JapanSusumu Hanagata, 111 pounds, Japan, knocked out Ernie Tembal, 119, Guam, 4 rounds.

title: Dobson Tops Lolich Game Is Called in 7th Inning
description: The Yankees at least proved that they were good mudders at Shea Stadium last night as the American League's Eastern Division race moved into the homestretch. Playing in a continuous rain, they topped the Detroit Tigers, 62, in the opener of a scheduled twilightnight doubleheader that was halted after six and a half innings by heavy rain.

title: Ehrlichman Prosecutor Leaving Federal Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6(UPI)  William H. Merrill, head nf, the plumbers unit for the Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, resigned today to return to private law practice in Detroit.

title: Glaring Disparity Seen on Sentences
description: An unusual study has found glaring disparity in sentencing by 50 Federal judges in New York, Connecticut and Vermont. The study of sentences in 10hypothetical cases will be presented today to 500judges and lawyers attending the annual judicial conference of the Court of Appeals for the Second CircuitChief Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the circuit said the disparity evidences a clear need for reform. The conference took place at Buck Hill Falls, Pa.

title: Business Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept 6 (UPI)Venezuela, the biggest exporter of oil to the United States, will cut back her production by more than 10 per cent in 1975 to 2.8million barrels per day, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said today.

title: $6Million Health Center Opens in the South Bronx
description: Pledging family doctor service to 55,000 of the city's poorest residents, a $6million healthcare center opened in the South Bronx yesterday.

title: Dow Climbs 7.12As Trading Gains
description: The stock market closed higher far the second consecutive session yesterday in moreactive trading despite gloomy comments on the state of the economy.

title: Political Race for Nonpolitical D.A.
description: It has been a typical political campaign for the office of Manhattan District Attorney  an office that has been largely nonpolitical. It has also offered an opportunity for concentrated discussion of issues affecting the criminal  justice system. But mostly the issue in the Democratic primary race has been one of style, personality and experience, and both candidates have been sullied in the process.

title: 3,830 See Blazers T op Stars,1715
description: Bad luck and bad weather obliterated the Stars last night as they ended the first half of their first World Football League campaign.

title: Charter Terminal Is Closing at Kennedy
description: The North Passenger Terminal at Kennedy International Airport, the isolated airport center for charter flights that has been assailed for years as an overcrowded jetage Ellis Island, will be closed Nov. I.

title: Mr. Harvard Law School, 90 Years Old, Shows Disregard for the Calendar
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Justice Holmes once invited Prof. Austin W. Scott, of the Harvard Law School, to visit him, and Professor Scott brought a friend, Sayre McNeil.

title: TURKS OFFER TERMS FOR TROOP PULLOUT
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 6(AP)  Premier Bulent Ecevit indicated today that Turkey could begin withdrawing her invasion forces from Cyprus if the United Nations arranged safe passage for Turkish Cypriotes from Greek Cypriote territory to the Turkishoccupied north.

title: Pro Transactions
description: Pro Transactions

title: Money
description: Money

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GEWGAW What is an antique? The question is one of those things subject to mild debate these days, at a time when people speak of urban archeology unearthing artifacts a couple hundred years old. Antiques can be ancient or they can be fairly modern. And there are all kinds of items that qualify as antiques. This is a weekend especially for people interested in the subject, because of the Portobello Road Fair, a festival of antiques from two sides of the Atlantic tomorrow at Vanderbilt Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Javits and Pell, in Reversal By U.S., Get Visas for Cuba
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The State Department, in a reversal, said yesterday that it would validate passports for Senators Jacob K. Javits and Claiborne Pell for a trip to Cuba.

title: Colleges Face Year Of Economic Worry
description: A calm year appears in store for American higher education, but the joy of administrators at the prospect of continued tranquility is tempered by apprehension over an economic climate that is having a growing influence on academic decisionmaking.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: A Multibillion Purchase of Treasury Issue Due
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Sept. 6Saudi Arabia ban decided to purchase several billion dollars of a special bond issue by the United States Treasury, Government financial sources said today.

title: Random House Is Raising Michener Novel to $12.50
description: Random House plans to raise the retail price of James A. Michener's bestselling Cennial by $1.55from $10.95 to $12.50because of inflationary pressures that have struck the book trade, an executive of the publishing house said yesterday.

title: Tiffany Is Cutting Price Of Silver by 10 Per Cent
description: As if to put a new shine on the tarnished adage that what goes up must come down again, Tiffany & Co. disclosed yesterday that it is cutting all silver prices is its silver department by 10 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Westport Rediscovers the Bus
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  Like hundreds of other suburban communities across the country, this is the land of the twocar family, where the station wagon is king and anyone without an automobile has always seemed a helpless and pitiful oddity.

title: Greece Will Seek Common Market Entry
description: PARIS, Sept. 6Greece will seek full membership in the European Common Market and closer political ties With Western Europe, Foreign Minister George Mavros said at a press conference here today.

title: LIMELITERS OF 1974JUST LIKE OLD FOLK
description: Eleven years after they split up when folk music was in flower in the land, the Limeliters decided to get back together, and the 1974 version of the folk trio appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday. A little heavier physically and musically (they now carry a sixpiece backup group) and certainly a little hairier, Glenn Yarborough, Alex Hassilov and Lou Gottlieb strove, not very successfully, to avoid the blastfromthepast approach to their concert.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Belmont Race Charts

title: People in Sports
description: Cazzie Russell is going south for the winter. The former University of Michigan all American basketball player has signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers following the expiration of his contract with the Golden State Warriors in northern California, Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Crilly Says Outlook Fir Pan Am Merger With T. W. A. Is Dim
description: William M. Crilly, whose resignation as a director and an executive vice president of Pan American World Airways was announced Thursday, said yesterday that the reason he decided to leave the company was that a diversification program he headed could no longer be pursued because of Pan Am's severe financial problems.

title: Duke, Fox Terrier, Takes Tuxedo Park K.C.'s Best
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 6Form held true at the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club's fixture, at Lyndhurst today, when Sunnybrook Spot On, vas named best of 1,321dogs:

title: BIG DETROIT BANK CUTS PRIME TO 11%
description: The $1billion Michigan National Bank of Detroit announced yesterday that it was cutting the loan rate for its most creditworthy customerswidely known as the prime rate from 12 to 11 per cent.

title: Nalson, a Rookie, Leads By Shot an 67 for 135
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 6(AP)Larry Nelson carded a threeunderpar 67 today for a 135 total and a one shot lead at the halfway mark of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1974
description: Portugal and the guerrilla movement of Mozambique will sign an independence agreement today. It will end Portugal's 400yearold sovereignty over the East African territory and will mark the end of a 10year guerrilla war against the Portuguese. [1:8.] Kuwait and Saudi Arabia have joined other Arab countries seeking investments for the rapidly growing accumulation of funds arising from the recent quadrupling of oil prices. Kuwait offered to pay the equivalent of $246million for a British commercial real estate company in what may be the largest Arab investment disclosed so far in the West. It proposes to buy all of the shares of the St. Martin's Property Corporation's real estate holdings, which are concentrated in London's financial district and extend to Europe and Australia. [1:7.] Saudi Arabia has decided to purchase several billion dollars of a special bond issue of the United States Treasury. Government financial sources said. An American diplomatic source speculated that the amount and timing of the bond purchase would be geared to progress toward a political settlement between the Arabs and Israel. [1:6.]

title: A Multibillion Purchase of Treasury Issue Due
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Sept.6Saudi Arabia has decided to purchase several billion dollars of a special bond issue by the United States Treasury, Government financial sources said today.

title: Reconvened Continental Congress Starts Bicentennial
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6Slightly ahead of the official calendar, America's bicentennial celebration was given a gala inauguration here today as the reconvening of the First Continental Congress ended in historic Carpenters Hall.

title: Hurricane Likely to Strike Along Gulf Coast Tomorrow
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 (AP) Residents along the coast of the Gulf of Mexico from Louisiana to Florida kept vigil today to learn where Hurricane Carmen would come ashore.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses To Bow Out of Case Of Ft. Lee Bribery
description: NEWARK, Sept. 6Denounca defense motion that contended he was prejudiced, Federa) District Court Judge Frederick B. Lacey refused today to disqualify himself from presiding over the trial of two men charged with attempting to bribe the Mayor of Fort Lee.

title: Computer to Aid Courts Is Urged by State Official
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6New. Jersey judges, lawyers and Prosecutors may do their legal research at computer consoles in the next few years, according to a plan envisioned by Judge Arthur J. Simpson Jr., acting administrative director of the courts.

title: Court Hieroglyphics
description: Democratic voters in Tuesday's primary again will have to consult a Rosetta (or should it be called a Frank Rossetti?) stone to figure out the judicial choices. In the State Supreme Court races, they will be voting for candidates whose namesliterallydo not appear on the ballot. For the Civil Court, they are asked to vote in ghost municipal districts although Municipal Courts no longer exist in the city.

title: New Panel to Study Financial Problems Of. Jersey Colleges
description: TRENTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The State Department of Higher Education announced today the formation of a committee to study the possible need for higher tuition at state colleges and related problems.

title: New York Stock Exchange Bond Trading
description: FRIDAY, SEPT. 6, 1974.

title: $246Milillion Bid Made for a British Concern
description: LONDON, Sept. 6Kuwait, one of the richest Middle East oil countries, offered today to pay the equivalent of $246million for a British commercial real estate company in potentially the largest Arab, investment disclosed so far in the Western world.

title: Namath Faces Raiders Today With a New Shield
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 6The first fullscale test of the 1974 New York Jets, with allowances for injuries, will take place here tomorrow against the Oakland Raiders, with Joe Namath at quarterback in the last exhibition game of the season. Kickoff in the University of California's stadium is set for 4 P.M., New York time. Channel 5 will televise it in New York.

title: Study of U.S. Judges Finds Glaring Gap in Sentencing:
description: Fifty Federal judges in New York, Connecticut and Vermont were given identical facts about 30 hypothetical criminal cases but handed down a glaring disparity of sentences when asked to rule on them, an unusual study has found.

title: Olivieri Ousts Top Aide, Citing $1,500 Transaction
description: Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivier, one of three Democratic aspirants for Lieutenant Governor, yesterday asked his campaign manager, Matt Shipman, to step down.

title: Recession Barometer
description: Unemployment, harshest of all measures of economic distress, is continuing its slow upward creep. It would be irresponsible to make much of the slight increase registered in the national joblessness rate last month if it were not simply an extension of a climb that began last Octoberone that already has added roughly halfmillion workers to the lugubrious roster of those looking for jobs they cannot find.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: OvertheCounter Quotations

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS MILITARYAID CUT FOR SOUTH KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has proposed that American military aid to South Korea be sharply cut now and phased out completely by 1977because of what it called the increasingly repressive measures of the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Notes on People
description: In the new edition of Webster's American Biographies, to be published by the G. & C. Merriam Company on Oct. 15, there are 1,248 pages, and they list 3,082 Americans, past or present, from Hank Aaron to Vladimir Zworykin. The book does not list Gerald R. Ford.

title: Charity Support Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) President Ford says inflation, is hurting the nation's charities and urged full support of the United Way campaign that begins this weekend.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: Lebanon Says Israelis Raided Several Houses
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Sept. 6(Reuters)Israeli troops broke into several houses in a southern Lebanese town early today looking for Palestinian commandos, according to reports from residents of the area.

title: Political Race for Nonpolitical D.A.
description: It has been a typical political campaign for the office of Manhattan District Attorney  an office that has been largely nonpolitical. It has also offered an opportunity for concentrated discussion of issues affecting the criminal  justice system. But mostly the issue in the Democratic primary race has been one of style, personality and experience, and both candidates have been sullied in the process.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON INDEPENDENCE FOR MOZAMBIQUE
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 6Portugal and the guerrilla movement of Mozambique reached agreement tonight on independence for the East African territory, ruled by Portugal for 400 years.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Surley if Billie: Jean King had been playing tennis When the MistMimed into rain, she would have scolded to stop: And it would have stopped. Billie Jean scolds everybody, especially herself. It might be the best part of her, game. She had lost the first set to Julie Heldman Yesterday in their semifinal match in the United States Open championships and she was'struggling in the second Set. But, suddenly, she was herself again. Just as suddenly, Julie, Heldman Was herself, too, and Billie Jean had qualified, 26, 63, 61, for the opportugity win the United States title tomorrow Forest Hills for the fourth time. If she scolds herself sufficiently, she probably will win.

title: People in Sports
description: Cazzie Russell is going south'for the winter. The former University of Michigan allAmerican basketball player has signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers following the expiration of his contract with the Golden State Warriors in northern California. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: The McFeeley Test
description: In a remarkable display of cheek, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has been testing the public's integrity on the ground that the Police Department has been testing that of the patrolmen. It is hard to say which is the more dismaying, the wrongheadedness the comparison or the audacity of Ken McFeeley, the union's newlyelected president, in making himself an assessor of the public's ethics.

title: BOWATER PROFITS SHOW A 23.3% RISE
description: The Britishbased company's report, issued yesterday in London, said difficult economic conditions were likely to persist, but the company expected continued advances in the second half.

title: Rev. Joseph J. Tennant, 66, Of Shelter Island Church
description: The Rev. Joseph J. Tennant, pastor since 1969 of the Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church on Shelter Island, L. I., died Wednesday of a heart attack in the church rectory. He was 66 years old.

title: PANAMA IS RESUMING BANANA SHIPMENTS
description: The United Brands Company announced yesterday it had resumed shipments of bananas from Panama after a sixweek stoppage caused by the effort of the Panamanian Government to levy a box export tax.

title: Kravetz Dies at 47; Professor of Mathematics
description: Dr. Saul Kravetz, professor of mathematics at the State University center at Stony Brook, L. I., died last Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 47 years old and lived here.

title: British Plan SexEquality Law as Voting Nears
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) Britain's Labor Government proposed legislation today that would protect women and men against sex discrimination through a special equal opportunities commission.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: Red Sox Lose, Orioles Gain, Reds Bow
description: Slogging through, rain that halted the game, in the seventh inning last night, the New York Yankees widened their lead in the Eastern Division of the American League. The Yanks beat Detroit, 62, as Boston was losing to Milwaukee, 20, and dropping 1 games back of New York. The Red Sox had led the division by seven games two weeks ago.

title: Redskins Turn Back Colts, 76.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6(AP)Billy Kilmer hit Charley Taylor on a 15yard touchdown pass, tonight to give the Washington Redskins a 76 victory over the Baltimore Colts in a raindrenched windup of their exhibition season.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 6 (AP)A fit and eager United States squad prepared today for a move into the finals of the world rowing championships. Dick Dunham, a bteam official, said: This is where we separate the men from the boys.

title: 3 Held in Panty Hose Theft
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 6 (AP)Three men have been charged in connection with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's recovery yesterday of 12,500 pair of panty hose, nylons and other undergarments bearing the J. C. Penney label. They were stolen from an interstate truck shipment, the bureau said. The F.B.I. identified the suspects as Howard Colburn Jr., 44 years old, a former National City councilman; Oscar Gomez, 28, of San Diego, and Spencer Cosner, 31, of Jamul.

title: Betsy, Harry is Conrad Now
description: Recently, Betsy Wade described on these pages her quest through the West Side to find what would appear to be a simple thing: a hairdresser who could give her a good haircut at a modest price. The one craftsman who had provided this service for her, Harry, had moved. Since, then she had been intimidated, harried and overcharged by an army of practitioners. Miss Wade concluded her article with the following appeal to reason: Look, there cannot be only one Harry; logic teaches this. Her plaint resulted in a wealth of letters offering commiseration, comfort and most important, a profusion of Harrys. Below is some of the mail.

title: Crucial Greek Mission
description: Greece's Foreign Minister, George Mavros, has set off on a tout, of crucial importance not only to his own hardpressed country but to Western Europe and even to the United States. Mr. Mavros will try to speed reactivation of Greece's association agreement with the European Economic Communitylooking to eventual full membershipand to negotiate badly needed credits from the Common Market countries.

title: Rep. Reid Supports Carey; 6 Officials Back Samuels
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for Governor, called yesterday for the nomination of Representative Hugh L. Carey in the primary on Tuesday.

title: Contract at Bell Telephone Is Approved in C.W.A. Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Members of the Communications Workers of America have Approved by a 2to1 margin new nationwide threeyear contract with the Bell Telephone System.

title: The Presidency and New Ideas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 There was a widespread feeling here today that yesterday's presummit meeting of economists with President Ford had been useful and a success, even though it would riot solve the nation's economic problems. The main reason for the satisfaction was so obvious that it could easily be overlooked: Unlike almost any other device, it opened the President of the United States to direct verbal presentation of ideas that he would otherwise not be likely to hear, or at least not hear with emphasis.

title: People and Business
description: Common sense revolts against the notion that we are already in the middle of anything that could meaningfully be called a recession, Francis H. Schott, vice president and economist of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, said yesterday.

title: Antiques: Mary's Dish
description: Ogden House, the 18thcent brownshingled saltbox that Mary Allis called home in Fairfield Conn., for 42 years, is one of Connecticut's oldest houses and youngest museums.

title: Ado With Election Sign Used as Getaway Car
description: Three armed robbers switching getaway cars after a $31,000 bank robbery in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday commandeered a station wagon with a twofoot high electioneering sign yesterday.

title: Wilson's Net Worth
description: Governor Wilson released a networth statement yesterday, reporting that he and his wife had $632,580.14 in assets, and no liabilities Page 16.

title: Rival Cypriote Leaders Finally Confer
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 6President Glafkos Clerides, the leader of the Greek Cypriote community, and Rauf Denktash the head of the Turkish Cypriote administration, met prirately here tonight for the first time since the Geneva confertrice en the Cyprus crisis collapsed more than three weeks ago.

title: Rep. Rosenthal Assails Western Union In Report Suggesting a U.S. TakeOver
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal described Western Union yesterday as a reluctant messenger when it came to consumer telegraph service and proposed that Congress consider shifting telegram service to the United States Postal Service unless Western Union and the Federal Communications Commission undertook exten**sive reforms.

title: JESUIT DISMISSED ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: The Jesuit order has dismissed a priest who baptized the son of a Massachusetts other who advocated a woman's right to choose abortion.

title: Art: Treasures of the Morgan
description: This has been a great year for the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: Some Questions and Answers on Monetary Policy
description: At the first of a series of meetings President Ford has called to deal with the nation's economic problems, many leading economists recommended Thursarby that the Federal Reserve System ease monetary policy because the economy appears to be slipping into a recession.

title: Bowling in Moscow
description: SKOKIE, Ill., Sept. 6 (AP) The Soviet Union's first bowling center will be open to the public on Sept. 27 in Moscow's Gorki Park, it was announced today by the Brunswick Corporation, the company installing the lelane plant. Fred (Skee) Foremsky of Houston and Mary DeBarbrie of Belmont, Calif., professional bowlers, will be brought to Moscow to teach the Russians how to bowl.

title: Rep. Reid Supports Carey; Six Officials Aid Samuels
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for Governor, called yesterday for the nomination of Representative Hugh L. Carey in the primary on Tuesday.

title: BONY H. PEACE JR.
description: GREENVILLE, $. C., Sept. 6(UPI)  Bony Hampton Peace Jr., honorary chairman of The Greenville NewsPiedinont Company, died yesterday following surgery. He, was 68 years old.

title: F.B.I CHIEF DENIES EXCESS WIRETAPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Clarence M. Kelley, branded tonight as patently false, absolutely ridiculous reports that the agency was promiscuously involved in electronic wiretaps.

title: Waldheim Asks $22Million To Aid Refugees in Cyprus
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 6(UPI)Secretary General Waldheim appealed to all United Nations member states today to contribute 22million for humanitarian relief in Cyprus, where more than 200,000 persons have been driven from their homes in nearly two Months of fighting between ethnic Greeks and Turks.

title: Ford Sees Inflation Defeated by 1976;
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6President Ford, speaking tonight at a dinner honoring the reconvening of the First Contimental Congress, said the nation would defeat inflation before its 200th anniversary on July 4, 1976.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Democrats in several Congressional distnicts in New York State are electing delegates in the upcoming primary to a first charter convention to be held in December in Kansas City. This is an important convention, but unfortunately it is not receiving much attention. The convention will attempt to write the first constitution for a major party, which will set the rules for governing the party.

title: S.E.C. Ending Suspension Of Westgate California
description: The Securities & Exchange Commission announced in Washington yesterday that it would terminate its suspension of trading in the shares of Westgate California Corporation and its subsidiary, Air California, at midnight last night, permitting trading on Monday.

title: The Dance
description: Genius is an emotional word that comesquickly to mind for describing the protean energy and invention of Twyla Tharp. Though one suspects that she would prefer the professional designation of superb craftsman as more in keeping with her own classical temperament. Miss Tharp offered the premiere of a marvelous duet from work  in  progress Thursday evening at the Delacorte Theater's New York Dance Festival.

title: Soviet Indirectly Rebuffs Ford on Ocean Bases
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6The Soviet press today bolstered Moscow's contention that there were no Soviet naval bases in the Indian Oceanby publishing official denials from the countries where the bases were report, to be.

title: 3 Latin Nations Ask An End to Cuba Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Three Latin  American countries today formally proposed to the Organization of American States that the group consider lifting its decadeold political and economic sanctions against Cuba.

title: Colleges Face Year Of Economic Worry
description: A calm year appears in store for American higher education, but the joy of administrators at the prospect of continued tranquility is tempered by apprehension over an economic climate that is having a growing influence on academic decisionmaking.

title: Open Interest
description: Open Interest

title: Handling of Egg Market Spurs a Rift in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 6Official handling of a sensitive egg market, including the destruction of 14 million reggs at a time of rising prices and a world shortage of protein, has upset Canadian consumer groups and caused a rift in Pritne Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Cabinet.

title: SELASSIE IS ACCUSED OF DIVERTING MONEY
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 6 (AP)The Ethiopian military today accused Emperor Haile Selassie of having diverted money from a state brewery, newspapers here reported.

title: Banks in Jeopardy
description: The disclosure by Lloyds Bank, one of Britain's Big Four, that a Swiss branch'has suffered losses of up to $75 million because of irregularities in its foreign exchange dealings has sent a chill of fear through the entire international financial community.

title: PAPER COMPANY TO ACQUIRE LAND
description: The International Paper Company, which is trying to acquire the General Crude Oil Company for $278million, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement for another $145million acquisition of timberland and lumber mills in Arkansas. International Paper said It had agreed to purchase the Cabe. Land Company and the Gundon Lumber Company, Inc., both of Gurdon, Ark., from the Cabe family.

title: Mennea of Italy Wins European 200Meter Track Title, Thrilling 50,000 in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 6Pietro Mennea of Italy delighted a crowd of 50,000 Romans today by winning the men's 200meter dash at the European track and field championships.

title: Wellstood Recalls Eddie Condon Era At Michael's Pub
description: To bill the performances by the jazz group currently led by Dick Wellstood at Michael's Pub, 211 East. 55th Street, as the Eddie Condon Scrapbook seems a gratuitous use of Mr. Condon's name and memory. The music played by Mr. Wellstood, on piano, with Kenny Davern, soprano saxophone, Billy Butterfield, trumpet, Milt Hinton, bass, and Ronnie Cole, drums, relates to Mr. Condon only in the very broad sense that it is improvised smallgroup jazz that frequently draws on the repertory of tunes played not just by Mr. Condon but by most other jazz men in the nineteenthirties and forties.

title: Saxbe Is Giving Congress 90 Days to Act on Lottery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Attorney General William B. Saxbe assured Governors and lottery officials of 13 states today that there was no present danger of prosecution of those involved in state lotterids but warned that he would seek an injunction to halt the lotteries unless Congress clarified the law within 90 days.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Sohio to Reduce Prices of Gasoline 2 Cents a Gallon
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced that effective today it would reduce by 2Gents a gallon the price of gasoline at its companyoperated stations and on gasoline sold to dealers. Robert G. Griffin vice president  marketing, said the prices were being dropped in anticipation that Soltio's crude oil costs would decline somewhat over the next 60 days.

title: Easing of Money Opposed By Greenspan and Simon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Ford Administration's two top economic officials expressed opposition today to the suggestions of some economists that the nation's money supply should be expanded.

title: Gibson Keeps Protest Ban; Vows to Arrest Violators
description: NEWARK, Sept. 6Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today that his ban on street demonstrations would continue until further notice in an apparent attempt to avoid further confrontations between the police and residents of this tense city, which was racked by four days of violence earlier this week.

title: Beame Acts to Add Hours and Workers At Welfare Centers
description: To end chaotic conditions and long lines of weary recipients at the many city welfare centers, Mayor Beame yesterday ordered that 800 caseworkers be hired, that work days be extended and that centers be opened for half a day on Saturdays.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Two Writers in Praise of Rabelais and Each Other
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif.  Certainly anyone whose book is on the best feller list (even if at the bottom) needs no review, no boosting. These few words, therefore, are gratuitous, or, if you like, homage from one writer to another. Above all, a warm, heartfelt tribute to a woman writer, the like of which l have never known.

title: Family to Rebuild BurntOut Winery in Middlesex
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 4The Paszamant family has decided to rebuild on the ashes of its winery here after a twin tragedy raised doubts that the 40yearold enterprise would continue in business.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: Nuclear Plant Is Set
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 6(UPI)  The Atomic Energy Commission has given the Mississippi Power and Light Company authority to proceed with plans to build a $1.2billion nuclear generating plant on the Mississippi River near Port Gibson, the company's officials announced yesterday. The first of the two generating units, each of which will have a capacity of 1.25 million kilowatts, is scheduled for completion by 1979, with the second to be completed two years later.

title: Mrs. King Is in Final; Chris Evert Trailing
description: With Billie Jean King already home a winner and waiting to see who her opportent would be in the final of the women's singles, the rains interceded yesterday in the United States Open tennis championships. A steady downpour postponed the other semifinal match, with Chris Evert down by a love set to Evonne Goolagong and trailing, 43 in the second set.

title: Cadillac to Introduce A MiniCaddy for 1975
description: DETROIT, Sept, 6 (UPI)Cadillac will introduce a new miniCaddy in January and expects to sell between 20,000 and 25,000 before the end of the 1975 model year next September, Robert D. Lund, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said today.

title: NORTH CRITICIZED OVER INTEGRATION
description: NORTH CRITICIZED OVER INTEGRATION

title: Mrs. Ford Hints Aid For Rights Amendment
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 6 (UPI)Betty Ford said today that she would campaign for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment for women if her schedule permitted.

title: GREECE RECEIVES 100MILLION LOAN
description: ATHENS, Sept. 6Greece received a $100million loan today from a consortium of international banks to help ease her growing balance  of  payments problem. It amounted to less than half the amount Athens originally sought, according to well informed sources.

title: Thomas V. Tozzi, Lawyer And Civic Leader in Bronx
description: Thomas V. Tozzi, a retired Bronx lawyer and civic leader, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx following a stroke. He was 73 years old and lived at 2400 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, and in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Fans Gather to See Knievel Try to Sail Over Canyon in Idaho in SkyCycle
description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 6Beyond the first row of campers parked in Tim Qualls horse pasture was a dirt motorcycle track on which racers were chasing one another with angry bursts of sound from their engines, and 109 yards past the noise and flying mud, close to the lip of the deep Snake River Canyon, was the most celebrated piece of merchandise to rise out of the Idaho earth since the baking potato.

title: European Track and Field Summaries
description: 200Meter Dash1, Pietro Mennea, Italy, 20.6 seconds; Manfred Ommer, West Germany, 0:20.8; 3, HansJurgen Bombach, East Germany, 0:20.8; 4, Joseph Arame, France, 0:20.9; 5, FranzPeter Hofmeister, West Germany, 0:20.9; 6, Bruno Cheerier, France, 0:21.

title: Art: The Universes of Arakawa
description: Among current undertakings in art, none are more ambitious in scale than The Mechanism of Meaning, the openended series of very large paintings that the Japanese painter and filmmaker Arakawa has been working on for a number of years. Each is more than mansize; they will number in the end no fewer than 300; Arakawa is not interested in showing them individually and is, in fact, holding back until every possible aspect of the subject has been exhausted. Then the paintings, when hung side by side, will very likely stretch the entire length of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre or the facade of the Metropolitan Museum.

title: Israel Wins Medal in Swim
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. (AP)Israel won its first gold medal of the seventh Asian Games today, making another slight crack in Japan's swimming monopoly, but Japanese swimmers, gymnasts and shooters still accounted for a healthy share of gold medals.

title: $246Million Bid Made for a British Concern
description: Special to The New York Times LONDON, Sept. 6Kuwait, one Of the richest Middle East oil countries, offered today to pay the equivalent of $246million for a British commercial real estate company in, potentially the largest Arab investment disclosed so far in the Western world.

title: Several Increases Due
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6  The Chrysler Corporation said today that its cost had gone up an average of $71 a vehicle month this year and warned that it would need several price increases on its 1975 models, indicating the first could be as much as $500.

title: Contract Awards
description: A $40million contract has been signed by the Marubeni Corporation, Tokyo, for the export of a thermal power plant to the Manila Electric Company. The contract calls for the completion of the plant at Malaya, on the outskirts of Manila.

title: Seoul Promises to Pay Japan For Ransacking of Embassy
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 6Premier Kim Jong Pil publicly expressed regret today over the ransacking of the Japanese Embassy by, about 200 demonstrators and promised compensation for damages.

title: The Waiting Game
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Are the Democrats in Congress going to stand still while President Ford implicates them in his donothing approach to the economic situation?

title: Bridge: LongShot Bid for Contract Better Than No Shot At All
description: A long shot for the contract is usually better than no shot at all. It would not be true to say always, a dangerous word in a bridge context, since the long shot may involve a risk of an increased penalty. A player who can escape for a 200point penalty in four spades doubled should not try for a miraculous ten tricks and a score of 790 if the likely result is down thre and minus 800.

title: U.S. Efforts Continue to Obtain Agreement on Soviet Migration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6White House officials and Congressional aides continued negotiations toady in an effort to reach a compromise next week that would lead to passage of the Adm'nistration's trade bill and steppedup emigration of Soviet Jews.

description: Major League Leaders

title: Books of The Times
description: CAVETT. By Dick Cavett and Christopher Porterfield. 373 pages. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $8.95.

title: Westport Rediscovers the Bus
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  Like hundreds of other suburban communities across the country, this is the land of the twocar family, where the station wagon is king and anyone without an automobile has always seemed helpless and pitiful oddity.

title: Wilson Reports His Net Worth As $632,580, No Liabilities
description: With less than a week before the opening of his election campaign, Governor Wilson yesterday released a networth statement, reporting that he and his wife have a total of $632,580.14 in assets, and no liabilities.

title: An AliDay Theatir
description: LONDON (AP)When Britain's National Theater opens its new home next April, it will be open around the clock with Sunday, lunchtime and latenight performances in addition to the usual matinee and evening showings, the director of the theater said.

title: Easing of Money Opposed By Greenspan and Simon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Ford Administration's two top economic officials expressed opposition today to the suggestions of some economists that the nation's money supply should be expanded.

title: Large Trade Deficit Suffered by Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Australia last month suffered its worst monthly trade deficit since 1951, official figures released today showed.

title: French Isles Off Canada Depend on Paris
description: ST. PIERREThe French island territory of St. Pierre and Miquelon is changing, but the change is coming as slowly and gently as the islands perpetual earlymorning fog.

title: LACEY 10 RETAIN TRIAL ON BRIBERY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 6Federal District Court Judge Frederick B. Lacey today denied a defense motion that he disqualify himself from presiding over the trial of two men charged with attempting to bribe the Mayor of Fort Lee.

title: Otto Kruger, Suave Star Of Stage and Screen, Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6Otto Kruger, who had performed on the stage and in radio, television and motion pictures since 1905, died today of a stroke on his 89th birthday.

title: James Swinnerton Dead at 98; Pioneer Newspaper Cartoonist
description: James Guilford Swinnerton, originator of one of the country's earliest comic strips, who in later life turned toserious painting, died Thursday in a Palm Springs hospital in California of complications resulting from a broken leg. He was 98 years old.

description: Sports Today

title: MATTEL TO CHECK ITS PROFIT REPORTS
description: Mattel, Inc., the nation's largest toy producer, which has had large deficits in each of the last three years, onnounced yesterday that earnings for two years may have been misstated.

title: Rail Freight Total Lags
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Association of American Railroads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8billion ton miles, 2,3 per, cent below the corresponding week, a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 538,213cars, 2.9 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 34per cent below last year.

title: KUNSTLER LOSES BID ON CONTEMPT RULING
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (UPI) The contempt convictions of three Chicago 7 defendants and their chief lawyer, William M. Kunstler, were upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The court agreed that Mr. Kunstler had made a vicious personal attack on the judge.

title: The Vacation Swap: There's No Place Like Someone Else's Home
description: Instead of vacationing in Maine, as they usually do, Madeline and John Spadola toured France this summer with their two young children.

title: TESTS SEEK SPEED FOR WATER FLOW
description: Columbia University researchers believe they are on the track of a substance that would significantly reduce water drag on suitably coated surfaces, such as those of water skis, submarine hulls or irrigation pipes.

title: Steinbrenner Cuts Yank Ties for Month
description: A few hours after having agreed not to talk to anybody connected with the Yankees, George M. Steinbrenner 3d went to Shea Stadium last night to cheer for his firstplace club.

title: Australians Vexed by Inflation, Stress Bargain Shopping and Budget Menus
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept 6In the small town of Bateman's Bay, about 150 miles down the southern coastline from Sydney, a group of businessmen recently pooled their resources to insert an advertisement In a Sydney newspaper starting a campaign called T.O.O.

title: OUVIERI REMOVES CAMPAIGN LEADER
description: Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri, one of three Democratic aspirants for Lieutenant Governor, yesterday asked his campaign manager, Max Shipman, to step down. He acted following disclosures that Mr. Shipman had given $1,500 last June to a state committeeman two days before the State Democratic Committee met in Niagara Falls to endorse candidates.

title: Prof. Doris Leberfeld Dies; Led Speech Therapy Center
description: Prof. Doris Trepel Leberfeld, director of the Center of Communication Disorders at the Hunter College School of Health Science died yesterday, at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 56 years old and lived at 175 West 93d Street.

title: Hirschfeld Endorsed by Troy Almost
description: Maintaining that a commitment is a commitment, an exuberant Abraham Hirschfeld, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, scurried about the corriodrs of City Hall yesterday to announce an endorsement that he had learned moments earlier he would not get.

title: WINE TALK
description: This is the time of year when the experts take over your life. They tell you what you are going to see at the movies, what you are, going to read in the bathroom and what, you will have to wear at a lot of parties no brie is going to invite you tet, anyway.

title: Wilson Reports His Net Worth As $632,580, No Liabilities
description: With less than a week before the opening of his election campaign, Governor Wilson yesterday released a networth statement, reporting that he and his wife have a total of $632,580.14 in assets, and no liabilities.

title: PANEL IS CAUTIOUS ON CLEANAIR RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) Some Federal cleanair standards may be too tough, but the effect of relaxing them is not fully known, the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: COMMODITY LIST MIXED AT CLOSE
description: Futures prices of farm prodducts closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Suybeans and soymeal were lower; corn was higher, as were iced broilers, oats and soybean oil, while wheat prices were irregular.

title: S.&P. Lowers Its Rating On Kaufman & Broad, Inc.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday it had lowered its rating on Kaufman & Broad, Inc., commercialpaper to A3 from A2. The action, according to Standard & Poor, reflected deterioration in the company's earnings coverage and asset rotection.

title: In One Brooklyn Section, Apathy Is Nonpartisan
description: Political apathy comes in many guises in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: Conserving Newsprint
description: The shortage of newsprint, triggered by strikes in Canada and exacerbated by a railroad strike there, has eased, but many conservation moves by newspapers remain in effect. Details on Page 35.

title: WARREN FRANKLIN
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I, Sept. 6(UPI)Warren Franklin, a publicrelations executive and former reporter and editor for United Press International, died last night in Huntington Hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: In Stormy Brighton, Britain's Unions Vote Not to Rock the Boat
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 6  All week this resort town, with its festive improbability, its white gingerbread piers and bandstands, has been pounded by gales and violent brown seas.

title: Wilson Among 12 Governors At Philadelphia Ceremonies
description: Wilson Among 12 Governors At Philadelphia Ceremonies

title: Anchovy Resumption Set
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 6 (AP)Peru's Fisheries Ministry plans to resume anchovy catching next October after a normal prohibition of two months. The Government Is awaiting a final report of the Peruvian Sea Institute to determine the quantity to be caught during the second part of the annual season.

title: TAPE SAYS MEXICAN BACKS ABDUCTORS
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 6 (Reuters)A tape recording was released here today purporting to show that the kidnapped fatherinlaw of Mexico's President, Luis Echeverria Alvarez had endorsed the leftwing views of his abductors.

title: DR. M. JOSEPH LOBEL OTOLARYNGOLOGIST
description: Dr. M. Joseph Lobel, a specialist in otolaryngology, die early yesterday of a heart at tack in his home at 169 East 69th Street. He was 69 years old and had an office at 9 East 62d Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Manhattan grand jury indicted Charles W. Yukl yesterday on charges that he murdered Karin Schlegel, a 23yearold aspiring actress, by strangling her with a necktie in Greenwich Village. Her body was found on Aug. 21. Acting State Supreme Court Justice George Roberts held Mr. Yukl, 39 years old, without bail, after arraignment on the murder indictment. Mr. Yuki pleaded not guilty to the charge.

title: FORD TO CREATE CLEMENCY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 President Ford said tonight that he would establish a national review board to consider clemency for Vietnamera deserters and draft resisters.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON INDEPENDENCE FOR MOZAMBIQUE
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 6Portugal and the guerrilla movement of Mozambiqite reached agreement tonight On independence for the East African territory, ruled by Porttigtil for 400 years.

title: Charter Terminal Is Closing at Kennedy
description: The North Passenger Terminal at Kennedy International Airport, the isolated airport center for charter flights that has been assailed for years as an overcrowded jetage Ellis Island, will be closed Nov. I.

title: 3 Latin Nations Ask An End to Cuba Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 6Three Latin  American countries today formally proposed to the Organization of American States that the group consider lifting its decadeold political and economic sanctions against Cuba.

title: Social Security Pioneer
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Sept 6(UPI)Ida Fuller, the first person to receive a Social Security check, celebrated her 100th birthday today. Miss Fuller, who received Social Security check No. One for $22.54 in January, 1940, has received 416monthly checks since. Her footprint is preserved at Social Security headquarters in Washington.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS MILITARYAID CUT FOR SOUTH KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has proposed that Americanmilitary aid to South Korea  be sharply cut now andphased out completely by 1977because of what it called theincreasingly repressive measures of the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Saxbe Is Giving Congress 90 Days to Act on Lottery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Attorney General William B. Saxbe assured Governors and lottery officials of 13 states today that there was no present danger of prosecution of those involved in state lotteries but warned that he would seek an injunction to halt the lotteries unless Congress clarified the law within 90 days.

title: Newspapers Are Conserving Newsprint Despite Easing of the Recent Shortage
description: Last August, when newspapers throughout the nation faced a severe shortage of newsprint, The Elmira StarGazette, an upstate New York daily, cut the size of its comics section by onefourth. At the same time, The Arizona Republic discontinued its bulldog, or early edition, and hundreds of other newspapers began taking similar conservation steps.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 5.4% IN AUGUST, HIGHEST SINCE 72
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Unemployment rose slightly in August, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Laser Speeds Newspaper Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Laser equipment is being offered newspapers as a means of speeding up the preparation of their printing plates so the presses can start. The LaserGraph method is already in use by a newspaper in Elmira, N.Y., and another paper in Fresno, Calif., has placed an order for January.

description: High Tides Around New York

title: Beame Acts to Add Hours and Workers
description: To end chaotic conditions and long lines of weary recipients at the many city welfare centers, Mayor Beame yesterday ordered that 800 caseworkers be hired, that work days be extended and that centers be opened for half a day on Saturdays.

title: Lykes Dividend Is First in Four Years
description: The LykesYoungstown Corporation, whose Youngstown Sheet and Tube subsidiary is the nation's eighth largest steelmaker, resumed dividends on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 25cents a share. Payable Oct. 15to holders of record Sept. 18, it is the first dividend the company has paid since 15 cents a share was paid on Sept. 101970.

title: 3 Young Men Held In HoldupMurder Of ExStockbroker
description: ORANGE, Sept. 6 (AP)Three young men have been jailed on charges of murdering a 78yearold retired stockbroker in a holdup attempt in his drive here.

title: Election Shift Ruled Out
description: OKLAHOMA, CITY, Sept. 6(AP)Oklahoma's primary run, off date is set by state law and cannot be changed although it conflicts with Jewish holy days, the state election board secretary, Lee Slater, said yesterday. The Sept. 27 runoff coincides with Rosh haShanah.

title: Maximum Mortgage Rate In Jersey Raised to 9.5%
description: TRENTON, Sept. 6The Byrne administration today raised the state ceiling on interest rates on conventional home mortgage loans to a maximum of 9.5 per cent, a move calculated to ease New Jersey's housing and real estate crisis.

title: Mexican Rider Brings In His First Belmont Victor
description: Octavio Aviles likes New York, and hopes to stay around for some time. The19yearold jockey from Mexico City rode here for the first time last Monday, and yesterday he came through with his first local winner, at Belmont Park. At the Race Tricks

title: Giants Lose By 2317In Overiime
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 6  The New York Giants, who have been trying to discover their proud past, found themselves buried by history tonight in a 2317 suddendeath defeat to the Buffalo Bills.

title: Carnegie Fund's $250,000 to Aid Channel 13 Move
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York, a foundation whose activities have mainly been in education, has made a gift of $250,000 to WNET/13 to help finance the public station's move to new quarters at what is now the Henry Hudson Hotel on West 57th Street. The hotel is to become a multipurpose building of offices, shops and apartments.

title: GAR's Big Bankrolled of 1972
description: At many turns in the unfolding tale of Watergate, the role and propriety of campaign contributions from big business have come under scrutiny.

title: Red Smith
description: Henry Fonda's, towering television performance as Clarence Darrow was watched with curiously mixed feelingsadmiration, warm pleasure, and discomfort tracing back to a gaffe committed 21 years ago and never atoned for or forgotten. It all goes back to 1953 when Native Dancer, an irongray steed with a silver face, was the finest racehorse in North America, Jud Bailey was sports director of CBS, and Fonda was starring on Broadway as Mr. Roberts.

title: Ann Weathers Wed to Professor
description: In the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Congregational Church yesterday afternoon, Ann Brooks Weathers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot B. Weathers of Scarsdale, was married to Robert Howard Callender, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Callender of St. Paul. The Rev. Gary Brown performed the ceremony.

title: Rape and Women's Self Defense
description: Reported rapes area on the rise, with the highest incidence taking place during the summer monthsso much so that a van staffed by police officers and Woman's Rape Coalition Volunteers has been touring the city demonstrating selfdefense techniques and alerting women to the danger of sexual assault.

title: Retarded Adults Learning Basic Skills
description: Diana Watkins is part of an unusual staff, training low functioning mentally retarded adults in basic living skills, such as personal hygiene, cleaning and cooking, in a newly established model Adult Day Care Center, 277 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: 4,000 Recall Beatles, Yeah, Yeah, Yeah
description: The Beatles broke up five years ago, but they remain the most popular rock group of all to judge from the 4,000 of so Beatlemaniacs who packed the Commodore Hotel yesterday afternoon for the first day of Beatlefest 74. The convention, which commemorates the 10th aniversary of the Beatles invasion of America, will continue this afternoon and evening.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It appears that we have about 50,000 youngish citizens outside our borders, some deserters from the armed forces, others dropouts from Selective Service.

description: BRIELLEEvery seaside town attracts visitors. This one is unusual in that it also attracts many people who never go near the water.

title: Most Effects Are. Drastic But Temporary
description: What happens to man when he goes up in space? Eyes redden. Lids thicken. Sockets feel; puffy. The face becomes rounder. Veins in the neck, temples and forehead swell and protrude. Noses feel stuffy and sinuses congested. Voices take on a nasal twang.

title: Cards Defeat Mets, 21 On Brock's Hit in Ninth
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7Lou Brock didn't steal any bases, but he smashed a basesloaded single with two out in the ninth inning to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 21 victory over the New York Mets before 36,007 fans in Busch Stadium tonight.

title: SLAYING SITE HERE DEFENDED AS SAFE

title: Mills Finally Has a Foe, and She Hits Hard
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 6 Representative Wilbur D. Mills has a Watergate of his own and with it his first opponent for reelection in eight years.

title: British Election
description: Prime Minister Harold Wilson is apparently on the verge of calling Britain's second general election of 1974. No one is eager for an election this fall; no one seems to believe the results will be any more satisfactory than the standoff outcome of last February. But there seems to be no palatable way to avoid it. The Labor Government, twenty seats short of a majority in the House Commonsand thus almost constantly dependent for survival on support from the Liberals and the Scottish and Welsh Nationalistscannot face the prospect of trying to carry on in such circumstances through difficult winter.

title: Rutgers Offering Jobs by Telephone
description: NEW BRUNSWICKFinding out about administrative and professional job openings at Rutgers University is now as easy as dialing a telephone number. The State University has opened a job opportunity line that prospective applicants can dial in order to heat a listing of available professional positions.

title: Bridal in Maine For Sally Lee, Peter Blair Jr.
description: Sally Sprague Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Lee Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Prouts Neck, Me., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Heyliger Blair Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blair of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Brutality Is Common

title: Rolinda Wald Bride of Gary Schaefer
description: Rolinda Adrian Wald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Richard Wald of Bronxville, N.Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married in the Reformed Church of Bronxville yesterday afternoon to Gary Brian Schaefer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Schaefer of Pinon Hills, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Caries L. Coperhaver performed the ceremony.

title: Joanne Gordon Married to Roger Olsen
description: Joanne Lee Gordon and Roger Milton Olsen, both of Washington, were married yesterday afternoon in a Greek Orthodox ceremony in Cortland, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in Grace Episcopal Church by the Rev. Michael C. Harmand of St. Sophia's Greek Orthodox Church in Syracuse.

title: $1,300 To Read an Annual Report
description: Annual reports have traditionally been a means for companies to promote themselves. Now comes an annual report that actually is the company's product.

description: Seven members of New York State's delegation to the House of Representatives, most with long years of service, decided not to seek reelection this year, and voters will pick the candidates for their seats in Tuesday's primary election.

title: Recordings: New Roles for Nilsson
description: ALTHOUGH Birgit Nilsson's name has been synonymous with the past 15 years, she has Wagner's heroines for only once ventured past Isolde and Brilnnhilde at the Met: seven performances as Elisabeth in Tannhtiuser, three in 1961 and four in 1966 (when she also doubled as Venus). The reason for such specializing is fairly obviousa number of fine sopranos have always been on hand to sing Senta, Elsa, Eva, Sieglinde and Kundry, but for Isolde or Britnnhilde only Nilsson will do and audiences invariably feel shortchanged if she is not in the cast. The wise impresario, therefore, will act accordingly.

The match, which begins here on Tuesday, has not been very friendly so far with the Americans appalled at the manners in the challenging camp and the Australians on guard against Yankee trickery.

title: The Region
description: The Puerto Rican residents of Newark are twice cursed: They live in a city that has escaped none of America's urban ills, and they have been overshadowed politically, economically and socially not only by Newark's whites but also by its black majority. Last week, Newark's Puerto Ricans rioted.

title: Bridge
description: A surprising number of bridgeplayers suffer from acrophobia, or fear of heights. When the bidding reaches the sevenlevel, and thousands of points are at stake they tend to get nervous and flustered, and lose their heads.

title: If?
description: 334 is the title of Thomas M. Disch's important big novel (Avon, $1.65); it is also the number of a room in a nearfuture megalopolis, into which a strange yet familiar succession of people come to live, to interact, to love, and from which they go to grow or die or, as in all such, just disappear. Disch's special power is in his handling of people and of taboos; the former he knows unabashed by their vices or eccentricities, the latter he does not break so much as ignore. 334 is not Disch's great book, though that one is absolutely sure to come, for this young poetnovelist shows that certainty in everything he does. There are those who will find 334 disorganized and anecdotal, without a single driving statement, but there are others, myself included, whO say the hell with that, as Disch does with taboos, and simply relax and enjoy.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Too many people view baseball players as they do animals in a zoo. They stare at the lion but ignore the leopard. They wait for the lion to roar, as they wait for Henry Aaron to hit another home run. In the safety of the zoo they revere the lion because of his thickmaned majesty as the king of the jungle. But in the reality of the wild the antelope tears the leopard as much as it does the lion, In the reality of baseball the pitcher fears Lou Brock's cunning swiftness as much as he does Henry Aaron's muscular strength. And in baseball, for a change, this is the year of Lou Brock, the year of the stolen base, the year of the leopard.

title: New in Paperback
description: Inevitably, when The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz was first published in 1959, its hero was branded a Canadian Sammy Glick. From boyhood on, Duddy ran  dealing in stolen hockey sticks amid the squalor of Montreal's Urbain Street, squirming his way through the blackboard jungle of Fletcher's Field High School, gladhanding as a waiter in the borscht belt ofthe Laurentian, servicing nuptials in stylish Outremont. But unlike Sammy, Duddy knew why he ranto buy land, because (as his grandfather told him) without land you're nobody. As a bonus, there are a number of flavorsome portraits of odd characters Duddy passes during his dash for the longdistance crown. Americans who have met Duddy in the recent prizewinning film of the same name should read the book as well, for Mordecai Richter's novel is, as one reviewer put it, as brass and blatant as a sports car rallyand as suggestive of power.

One major problem was said to be the exact wording of the legislation permitting the Soviet Union to get both nondiscriminatory tariff treatment and continued Government  backed ExportImport Bank credits. title: New & Novel
description: Jan Wolkers writes with, the verve of a Dutch Henry Miller. (Wolkers is a painter, and Miller has been doing watercolors since 1928, if you collect parallels.) Like Miller, Wolkers writes with a tremendous appe tite for life and a painterly approach to the sensuous. His novel is so named because this soft sweet is the only candy its once beautiful heroine can manage with her loose teeth, at the end of a brief and devastated life, Bitter? Yes indeed, but the bitterness is significant in terms of the joie de vivre that precedes it.

The sculpture, drawings and all art objects offered have been donated by friends of the Spoleto Festival, founded in 1958 by Gian Carlo.Menotti. title: Book Ends
description: Screws. There have been a plethora of books the past few years written by prislners, notably Eldridge Cleaver's Soul on Ice and George Jackson's Soledad Brother, but we can't recall any written by the men on the other side of the clanging doorthe guards. Now, suddenly, we have a brace of them, both first novels, The Rap, by Ernest Brawley, published in June by Atheneum, and Lethal Gas, by Ron Kurz, published in September by M. Evans. Mr. Brawley is a 37yearold Californian who grew up within the walls (his father was a guard) and worked as a guard himself for a year. The Rap, is in a realistic style and the publisher likened it to James Jones's work. Lethal Gas falls into the black humor category and is in the form of diary entries by a prisoner called The Creep, letters, internal memoranda, news clippings and excerpts from the warden's Daily Bulletin (Information and Guidance from the Office of the Warden)as well as standard novelistic scenes. Lethal Gas has evoked in one blurb writer the name of Nathanael West, while Herbert Katz, editorinchief at M. Evans, terms it a prison Up the Down Staircase. In publishing, people tend to think in soandso is another soandso terms. At any rate, Mr. Kurz, a 33yearold Baltimore native, did eight years as a guard, administrator and troubleshooter at four different Maryland correctional institutions, at a time of much turbulence, corruption and administrative shakeupsall reflected in his book. Permanently paroling himself from prison work, he, became the manager of two theaters in Baltimore and wrote much of Lethal Gas in his office. Mr. Brawley's hero is a prison guard, as is Mr. Kurz's. The former discovers that the villain of the story is a cousin of his (Mr. Brawley says that it is not uncommon for prison guards to have relatiVes in prison); Mr. Kurz's hero, an idealistic young man named C. C. Thomas is friendly with a black prisoner and ends up siding with the prisoners. Both books have been sold to the movies, and Ring Lardner Jr., who wrote the screenplay for M*A*S*H, will do the honors for Mr. Kurz's book. As we said, Lethal Gas is another M*A*S*H.

title: Glen Oak Towers to Open in January
description: North Shore Towers, three 33story rental buildings On the site of the former Glen Oaks Country Club on the QueensNassau border near Grand Central Parkway, will open in January, the devolper said last week.

title: From the chaos of the Congo, Mobutu has wrought a nation
description: Why Zaire? It seems bizarre that Muhammad Ali should make his challenge against George Foreman for the world heavyweight boxing title on Sept. 25 in a Central African country whose name means little even to the few people who can correctly pronounce it (it's not Zaire to rhyme with Claire, but Zyeeer to rhyme with Dieear). To those who do know Zaire, the event is note quite so incongruous. In Africa, think big, was the advice of Cecil Rhodes, and no one has taken it more seriously than Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko. For him, nothing could be more natural than to hold the biggest fight in historyit will cost nearly $12million to stagein Zaire's capital, Kinshasa.

title: Compassion Plus
description: Under a law enacted in the Johnson Administration, Congress has no choice but to appropriate $450,000 in transition funds to enable former President Nixon to wind up the affairs of his former office. Under an even older laW, he cannot be denied the $55,000 pension owed him for the balance of the fiscal year of the $96,000 If he is allowed for the employment of a staffwhether he uses it to answer mail or defend him in court. But when President Ford proposes to pry a further$249,000 out of Congress for Mr. Nixon's personal benefit, the public is entitled to cry, Hold, enough!

title: Hearing Is Set on Professional Status for Social Workers
description: TRENTON  The Senate Democratic majority leader has scheduled a public hearing next month on a controversial measure that would establish state licensing power over New Jersey's social workers and accord them the same professional status given to engineers, psychologists and physicians. Matthew Feldman, the Democratic leader from Bergen County and principal sponsor of the bill, said he had arranged to hold the public herrings brcause of the intense pressure for and against certain aspects of the measure.

title: Cynthia Becton, Ballet Teacher, Becomes Bride

Richardson Jr. of Blue Hill and Sewickley, Pa, The Rev. John Herrick performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Blue Hill.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (AP)Bobby Chacon landed a right uppercut to the chin of Alfredo Marcano in the ninth round and stopped the Venezuelan in their World Boxing Council featherweight championship fight tonight. The title had been vacant.

title: One Black Manager: Enough? Too Many?
description: I have been writing a book about the great players and managers of my day, and it is just about completed. The recent article expressing your point of view as to the need for a black manager now creates an interest for including a word or two about it in the book.

description: Bicycle sales may turn out to be a profitable sideline for gasoline station operators, if the experience of Angelo. Sutera at his Sunoco station in Media, Pa., is any indication.

title: All She out Opera Learned in America
description: from tragedy to comedy. She handles with equal authority the stylistic requirements of Mozart or Janacek. She sings in English, Italian, German and Frenchwith all the versatility expected these days of an American artist. But, as she herselfis quick to point out, she has her limitations. Her personality is too forceful for ingenue roles: Her tastes and sympathies also impose boundaries upon her activities. The bel canto repertoire, for example, is beyond her comprehension. Most of the Bellini, Donizetti and Rossini operas strike her as stupid. She has sung Rossinis. Mose and admires it, yet she has little patience with the rest of his works. All they basically require, she remarks, is someone who can stand still and sing. She calls arias like Cam nome and numbers like the Sextet from Lucia inane. In such music she can find nothing to identity with, nothing that speaks to her of human concerns. She admires Beverly Sillss ability to bring a feeling of real drama to works of this sort, but even so she finds little for herself.

title: Barbara Leigh Mortimer Is Manied to Lawrence D. Stone
description: In St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Barbara Leigh Mortimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Watson Mortimer of Riverside and Colebrook, Conn., became the bride of Lawrence Daniel Stone. The Rev. Kenneth E. Hulme performed the ceremony.

title: W. Michigan Victor
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept. 7 (UPI)Western Michigan scored three touchdowns in the first 13 minutes of play today to win its opener from Texas  Arlington, 336. Jim White scored from 1 yard out at 3:05 of the first quarter and Wesley Cates tallied from the same distance at 8:59. A little more than three minutes later, Cates raced 24 yards around end for the third touchdown.

title: The Gerald Ford Identikit
description: In commenting, several years ago, on Richard Nixon's 1968 advertising campaign, a writer for the British journal Encounter remarked that the object of that effort had been not simply to create what is commonly called a better public image of Mr. Nixon, with his own virtues enhanced and his weaknesses diminished, but rather to substitute an entirely different image of him, a kind of Identikit, of which every, feature corresponded not to anything in Mr. Nixon himself, but to the supposed emotional needs and demands of his audience.

title: U.S. Will Meet Mexico; Cramer in Coaching Debut
description: Tonight's soccer game between the United States national team and Mexico at Texas Stadium in Dallas will mark the first appearance of Dettmar Cramer as coach of the national team in the United States. Cramer, acknowledged as having one of the most fertile minds in soccer, has selected the team for tonight's match. It is comprised of 16 players, all members of the North American Soccer League. The team will have virtually the same formation that faced Mexico in Monterrey Thursday in the first of the twogame friendly series.

title: The Rockefeller Fortune Is Only Barely Visible
description: WASHINGTONThe Senate Rules Committee plans to hold a closeddoor meeting this week to consider an unusual matterthe investigation Nelson Rockefeller's finances in preparation for hearings on his nomination to be Vice President. The hearings have not yet been scheduled, and for good reason. The investigation is not easy.

title: Numismatics
description: THE General Services Administration has closed the books on its fifth and final sale of Carson City, silver dollars, and collectors who have a good head for, business can go over the figures and make their own judgment as to the success of the operation, Here's the picture.

title: Parent and Child
description: Each day, roughly 700 sets of parents throughout the United States are cruelly reminded that medicine has not yet conquered genetic disease. About one in 14 babies is born with a genetic disorder; the afflicted range from the diabetic who may become a tennis champion to the hopeless cripple who may live only a few days. Genetic mistakes, according to the National FoundationMarch of Dimes, afflict some 2.9 million Americans with mental retardation, 4 million with diabetes, 1 million with congenital bone, muscle or joint disease, 500,000 with complete or partial blindness, 750,000 with impaired hearing and some 6 million others with imperfect organ systems.

description: Uncertain Rain Patterns

title: A Museum Relives Suffolk's Past
description: RIVERHEAD  At first glance, the Museum of the Suffolk County Historical Society here seems like any smalltown repcisitory of local artifacts, complete with slightly musty, dimly lit galleries lined with glass cases so jammed full of items that you can barely tell a collection for all its specimens.

title: State Begins Ousting Families for New Reservoir
description: ALLAMUCHY TOWNSHIP In a move designed to expedite planning of the proposed Hackettstown Reservoir, the state has begun condemnation proceedings against five families here.

title: Paperbacks
description: Just 30 years ago, the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrtidinger published an influential little book entitled What Is Life? Schrodinger then thought that the existence of life posed a deep problem: what physical and chemical processes allow like to beget like? As crossbreeding experiments of the first four decades of this century had shown, organisms carry their heredity in units called genes. These genes must have the double capacities to direct the biochemical reactionsthat make an organism what it is and to produce faithful replicas of themselves, so that the progeny can be endowed with a true copy of the parental genes. But nobody knew in the 1940's what genes are or how they manage to do their thing.

title: Minth M. Kim Bride Of Peter T. DiNapoli

title: The Stages Are Being Set  on Broadway and Around the Land
description: ANOTHER theater season is taking shape in New York, heralded by the harumphings of Broadway press agents clearing their brassbound throats for the media battles ahead, and by the commotion of hopeful producers beating the financial bushes for angels who may be willing to rush in where even fools have learned to tread with care. Naturally, in these days of economic gloom, most theatrical plungers are not eager to risk money on a show that doesn't have something extra going for it in the way of a triedandtrue reputation, strong popular appeal or glamour.

title: CANADIANS TO TRY BASEINCOME PLAN
