title: Hundreds of unusual Americans who have chosen to stay
description: SAIGON. Of the 2.6 million Americans who spent time in Vietnam at one point or another during the, last decade, it is safe to say that not many liked the place much. Most knew to the day how long it would be until they could get back to the world and stop seeing their buddies killed and crippled. Some descended into the depths of brutality in villages like My Lai, or into the hopelessness of heroin addiction in the back alleys of Saigon.

title: The Black House
description: It is a tribute to Paul Theroux's energy and industry that at the age of 33 he has produced seven books of fiction. Moreover, it is a tribute to his integrity and ambition that he is not content to keep repeating himself. But unfortunately his new novel, The Black House, an abrupt departure from the comic vision of his earlier work, does a serious disservice to his talent and will likely disappoint those who enjoyed Jungle Lovers and Saint Jack.

title: Dance
description: THE scarcity of choreographers does seem to be an obsession of this column. Yes, there are plenty of bad choretographers around, people doing their best, with their best being terrifyingly inadequate. They can promote bunions and falling arches for dancers, and misery and fading interest for audiences. No, the real scarcity is in the moderatetogood choreographers, I have said it before and, unfortunately, I shall be saying it again: The true choreographer is the rarest of contemporary artists.

title: Centennial
description: In more ponderous and charitable times, what James Michener has attempted in Centennial would have been hailed as a monumental task or maybe an epic labor. The commission is conveniently spelled out for narratorhistorian Lewis Vernor by the editors of US magazine: an indepth analysis of one American community  nothing less than the soul of America  as seen in microcosm. Vernor is to submit (for polishing) arbitrarily selected insights into the character and background of Centennial, Colo., and its settlers. And, in one of the trickiest reviewerdisarmings since Hawthome's ploy of the Salem Custom House manuscript, the editors reassure Professor Vernor (who at this point thinks he should have stayed at Georgia Baptist Cole lege) that he is not to bother about literary style. Evidently he takes them at their word.

title: Democracy in Trouble
description: DUBLINA political journey across Western Europe these days is a depressing and expensive business. Inflation has produced doubt and anxiety about the institutions of liberal democracy. Not since World War II have the free nations been so dependent on one another  so much at the mercy of events beyond their bordersor at the same time so stubbornly nationalistic and preoccupied with their own internal struggles.

Cowen, the board chairman, said this would add $340million a year to the railroad retirement system.

title: Haitian Primitives: From Art Form to Souvenirs
description: THESE days it would seem as if any Haitian who can lay his hands on a tube of paint and a brush is busy painting a woman with a basket on her head, a cockfight or voodoo drummers, Selfstyled art dealers stand along the highways, in front of hotels and at the piers where the cruise ships dock, hawking the paintings for anywhere from 80 cents to $25. The art galleries, even the most respectable such as Issa's, the Red Carpet and Nader's, look like warehouses. Canvases are piled on top; or each other. More cover every inch of wallspace. An endless stream of Last Suppers, Native Festivals and Adam and Eves in the Garden of Eden has filled backroom bins to overflowing. The abundance is.such that primitive painting is considered the nation's fourth largest industry after sugar cane, coffee and tourism.

title: 60's Had Hot Summers'; Blacks Now Play It Cool
description: During the summer of 1974, there was little beyond inflation to divert the nation's attention from the story of the final unraveling of the Nixon Administration. Certainly there were none of the flashes fury in America's cities on which attention was focused during the nineteensixties. In that respect, the summer of 1974, despite the flareup in Newark last week, was like the five that preceded it. Whatever the weather may have been, they were not what we came to call long hot summers.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Richard Reeves's review of The Crime Control Establishment (Aug. 11) has left me somewhat perplexed. The book was an attempt to stitch together somewhat disparate writings into a central thesisthat, as Reeves correctly notes, There indeed exists a specific combination of men and agencies who shape public attitudes toward crime and transform their views  into law and law enforcement. Apart from some allusion to the tone of my analysis (which the reviewer characterized as strident; I would prefer blunt) and an attempt to link me to a new internal political science school, there is no ed. Ague of either the arguments or the evidence.

title: Gouldner's vinegar
description: The history of sociology has seen a great many departures, but relatively few arrivals. When Alvin Gouldner published his massive study The Coming Crisis of Western Sociology in 1970, it was instantly greeted as a major departure in social theory from the dominant functionalist traditon. But even among Professor Gouldner's admirers (and I count myself one of, them), there were those who wondered whether he had really arrived at a formidable and radically different alternative.

title: The Pension Fiasco
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Figuratively speaking, members of Congress nearly broke their arms this week patting themselves on the back for passing the private pension bill. President Ford even helicoptered in from Camp David on Labor Day to sign it.

title: Fugitives 1851 Antislavery Riot Is Detailed in an Exhibition Here
description: On Sept. 11, 1851, a bloody clash took place in Christiana, Pa.. between a Maryland slave owner and a group of fugitives who had handed together to resist reenslavement.

title: Sailboat Show in Shadow of Cup Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7While Courageous and Southern Cross hold the attention of seagoing viewers here next week in the America's Cup match, more than 400 sailing craft will be on display ashore at the fourth annual Newport International Sailboat Show.

title: Anne Jones Married to a Physician
description: Anne Ewing Jones, daughter of Associate Judge Hugh R. Jones of the State Court of Appeals and Mrs. Jones of New Hartford, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon, to Dr. Charles Thomas McHugh of Chicago, where he is director of medical education at the ColumbiaCuneoCabrini Medical Center.

title: At the Pinnacle of G.M.
description: DETROITAt the place where automobile man Thomas A. Murphy works

title: Nuptials for Anne Gay Hartranft
description: Anne Gay Hartranft, daughter of Mrs. Raymond Dwight Stitzer of Bernardsville, N.J., and Glen Hartranft of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to William Henry Osborn 3d, son of Mr. Osborn Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., and the late Dorothy Blackwell Osborn.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: It looks as if the auto industry will get the last laugh on the prophets of doom who predicted last January that between 1.000 and 6,000 of the nation's 25,199 car dealerships would go out of business because of the energy crisis.

title: Gangs of Girls Terrorize Staff and the Retarded At Children's Unit Here
description: An adolescent girl, shortly after her recent admission to the city's Children's Center, was taken by a group of other teenage girls to a room where she was raped by a gang of youths and young men who had come into the building from the street.

title: Bandits Kill 7 on Thai Bus
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 7 (AP)A band of men dressed in army fatigues held up a bus in northeast Thailand, killing seven persons and wounding three, the police said today. They said the bandits apparently opened fire when the pasSengers hesitated in handing over valuables.

title: The Born Exile
description: Seventy years after his death George Gissing continues to hold an equivocal place among the late Victorians. He is an author who will neither stay in obscurity nor emerge into the limelight, who won't go entirely out of print but will not be easily available, who has established himself as a figure worthy of academic study, but not as a novelist who has to be rediscovered and read if one is to keep up with literary fashion.

title: Twice as many Americans kill themselves as kill each other
description: About once an hour, the telephone rings at New York's SaveALife League. The caller may start talking or burst into tears, or say nothing at all. Sometimes there is a challenge: I've got these pills here and I'm going to take them unless you tell me why I should live. Or questions: How much Valium is lethal? How long does it take the gas to work? Other times there is awkwardness and embarrassment: I've never called you before; how do I start?

title: Charismatics Gain in Churches
description: NEW ORLEANSAbout 50 persons assembled one night recently in the music room of St. Edward the Confessor parochial school, half of them seated at desks gathered in circies of four or five and the rest standing behind them with their hands on the initiates heads or shoulders.

title: City Opera
description: Catherine Malfitano, an alumna of the High School of Music and Art and the Manhattan School of Music, made her New York City Opera debut at the New York State Theater Saturday afternoon and proved beyond doubt that she is a hometown girl who is making good.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 15 persons demonstrated along Military Park in Newark yesterday to protest alleged police brutality during civic disorders earlier in the week. The demonstration, organized by the Progressive Labor Party and the Workers Action Alliance, also was aimed at what supporters termed racist unemployment.

title: Polish Teacher Captures European Decathlon Title
description: ROME, Sept. 7Eastern Europeans continued to dominate the victory stand today at the European track and field championships in Stadio Olimpico.

title: Brooklyn: A Home of Monuments and Graffiti
description: In the world of Brooklyn's historical statues and monuments, General Washington and the Puerto Rican flag have learned to accommodate each other.

title: Network Neanderthals Vie For Saturday Ratings
description: SA EFI ye turn arohan? That means What are you doing with the strangers? in the Paku language. Paku? No, they don't teach it at Berlitz, but your children may pick it up from television this season. For Paku is a rudimentary, 200word language invented expressly for television cavemen, and children's television this year is specializing in cavemen.

title: Mozambique Radio Seized by ExPortuguese Soldiers
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 7 (Reuters) A clandestine organization of former Portuguese soldiers, which calls itself the Dragons of Death, seized control of Mozambique's main radio station tonight and called for immediate independence for the territory without the participation of the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique.

title: Will Ford Follow Nixon in Support of the Lon Nol Regime
description: Early this year, President Nixon sent a letter to Marshal Lori Nol, President of the Cambodian government in Phnom Penh, assuring him in fervent rhetoric that the United States retrains fully determined to provide maximum possiXe assistance to your heroic selfdefense and Will continue to stand side by side with the republic in the future as in the past.

title: Greening the Arts
description: The tenth anniversary of the National Endowment for the Arts is a cause for celebrationand for concern in this time of budget austerity. When Congress willed It into existence with a modest $2.5million appropriation, the principle was established that the Federal Government had a real role to play in underwriting the cultural life of the country. Hope that Federal participation will keep expanding, not slip backward, is encouraged by President Ford's declaration that he has become a convert to the arts program and his promise that we're going to do infinitely better in it.

title: Photography
description: LONG with babies and birthday cakes, dogs are among the most frequent subjects of vernacular photography. Everybody has pictures of their dog.

title: Best Seller List
description: ??? on reports front more man 950 bookstores in 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not neoessarity consecutive.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW, Stocks Overcome
description: Early Weakness

title: Frank Sheed's love affair, with God
description: There are two books here, neither of them altogether successful, but that really is to the author's credit. One /desires more than what he gives, especially from the first book, which is a mere or less chronological account of the initiation rites, courtship, betrothal and enduring relationship between Frank Sheed and the Roman Catholic Church. Both he and it have greatly changed, since he grew up in Australia, son of an eccentric Protestant father land a Catholic mother. As a college student he came to wonder whether he was intellectually inferior because he knew that others suffered doubt, whereas I had never hid one.

title: Boiling Along in a Kettle on the New Hope Night Freight Run
description: BACK in the nineteenthirties, Lester Kobler was our town's most fanatic train buff. When he was about 10, so the story goes, he almost drowned in the surf one day. As they were trying to revive him, the 4:45 came down the tracks from Jersey City and Lester opened his eyes and whispered to one of the lifeguards: Please  count the cars.

title: Team Physician: Constant Conflict
description: In light of the sordid news stories of physicians linked even peripherally with gamblers, excessive and multiple cortisone shots and the alleged prescription of amphetamines to produce supercharged performance, the vulnerability of the team physician points to the pressures to which he is exposed.

title: The Guest Word
description: Translators Arise!

title: CalfRoping, BarrelRacing Tie This Family Together
description: THOROFAREHe sits tall in the saddle, and so does she.

title: Miss Hackley Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sherlock D. Hackley of New York and Nassau, the Bahamas, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helena Elizabeth Hackley, to Roman Martinez 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martinez of Miami and Nassau, formerly of Santiago, Cuba. The wedding will take place on Dec. 20.

title: Utility Board Starts GasCrisis Planning
description: TRENTONFaced with the prospect of an additional 10 per cent cutback on top of the 18 per cent reduction ordered by the Federal Government last winter, New Jersey will begin determining this week how it will grapple with the impending shortage of natural gas when the cold weather begins.

title: A 1957 Film Speaks of Watergate
description: BEFORE we all drown in postWatergate euphoria, there should be a widespread revival of A Face in the Crowd, which was written by Budd Schulberg, directed by Elia Kazan, and released in 1957. (It was shown recently at the annual Filmmakers of the Hamptons Festival.) The movie focuses on a guitarpunishing primitive (Andy Griffith), who's first discovered in an Arkansas jail by Patricia Neal, a venturesome Sarah Lawrence graduate. She puts him on a local radio station, and is then sucked into his careeras a media monster known as Lonesome Rhodes.

title: Ellen Meek Is Bride of David B. Tweedy
description: Ellen Meek, an assistant production editor at Harper & Row, book publishers here, and David Belden Tweedy who is in the managementtraining program of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, were married yesterday afternoon in Mount Airey, Philadelphia, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Meek, the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Weeks, a Baptist minister.

title: This Week in Sports
description: A master stroke of schedule planning has sent the New York Yankees away from Shea Stadium and their fans while they continue their fight for first place in the Anierican League Eastern Division. Fans must content themselves with seven straight days of the Mets, who play the Montreal Expos tomorrow and Tuesday nights at 8:05 and the St. Louis Cardinals and basestealing Lou Brock Wednesday and Thursday nights. The Chicago Cubs play the Mets Friday starting at 5:35 In a twilightnight doubleheader and in single games Saturday and next Sunday at 2:15 P.M.

title: J. A. Haddad Weds Carol J. McCowen
description: Jerrier A. Haddad of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., corporate vice president for engineering, programing and technology of the International Business Machines Corporation, married Carol Jane Mc, Cowen, a secretary at I.B.M. in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in Millbrook, N. Y.

title: The World's Greatest Traveler
description: THE world's greatest traveler. Marco Polo? Neal Armstrong? Henry Kissinger? The faculty, students and alumni of Brown University in Providence, R. I., shake their heads with notsomodest disdain; They know the real champion: their own Prof. J. S. Carberry.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Long before the 1974 major college football season began yesterday with a smattering of games across the nation, the stage was set for a weekly battle over which teams should and should not be named to the top10 list each Monday.

title: Who Makes Music and Where
description: WEDNESDAY FRIDAY THURSDAY SATURDAY TUESDAY NEW YORK CITY OPERA NEW YORK STATE THEATER OTHER EVENTS TODAY

description: Overthe Counter Quotations WEEK ENDED SEPT. 6, 1974

title: Votes in Congress Last Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area
description: I. Vote on amendment to Energy Transportation Security Bill that would make bill's pro. visions effective only when the President determined a need for them, which was was rejected, 48 to 24, Sept. 5.

title: Lynne Parmelee, Mark Warns Wed
description: Lynne Parmelee, daughter of Mrs. Llewellyn W. Lord Jr. and Edward T. Parmelee, both of Rye, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Stephen Warns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Warns of Olean, N. Y.

title: Prices of Fish Scaled Down at Sheepshead Bay
description: The tide was out so the deck of the boat was 10 feet lower than the dock, which was lined with people eager to buy the day's catch.

title: Y.W.C.A. Succeeding in Selling Properties
description: Two months after Its disclosure that it would close down and sell its last residences in Manhattan, the Young Women's Christian Association is finding a market for its disparate and aging propertig.

title: Bloomingdale's and Its Customers Dancing Chic to, Chic
description: They ooze out of the subway station of the Lexington Avenue Express and into the store's trendy lower levels. They march in past the street peddlers who flank the doorways on Third and Lexington Avenues. They ascend and descend the escalators through eight stories temptation. They come to Bloomingdale's to see and be seen.

title: Suffolk Sculptor Learned Craft in Bavaria
description: NOYACKHThe sound of a chisel striking wood is oddly at home in this quiet hamlet near Sag Harbor. It is here that Peter LipmanWulf carries on the ancient craft of wood carving that he learned as a boy apprentice in a studio in Oberammergau, Bavaria.

title: British Football
description: Arsenal 0, Burnley 1. Carlisle United 0, Stoke Cite 2. Coventry City 2, MancheSter city 2. Derby County 2, Newcastle United 2, Ipswich Town 1, Everfon 0. Leeds United 1, Luton 1. Liverpool 5, Tottenham Hotspur 2, Middlesbrough 1, Chelsea 1. Qucens Park Rangers 0, Birmingham City 1. West Ham United 1, Sheffield United 2. Wolverhampton Wanderers 1, Leicester City 1.

title: Some Classics, A Few Stars, Out of Town
description: HERE is a highly selective guideto some of the more exploratory productions that have been anpounced by theaters outside of New York for the coming season, plus a few of the more promising ventures in conventional programing.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Sunday: A debate between Howard J. Samuels and Hugh L. Carey, candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Bayside Housing Awaits Hearing
description: A Board of Estimate hearing on Thursday should clear the way for renewed construction on the $60million housing complex in Bayside, Queens, sources close to state investigation of the project said last week.

title: An Octogenarian and Still a TrendSetter
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  With a childhood divided among Southampton's summer colony, as it was known back at the turn of the century, and trips to Europe, fussing governesses, French lessons, and the rigors of coming out as a New York debutante, Frances Breese Miller might be expected to be something of a grand dowager at this time in life, but nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Rabin Sends a Plea To American Jews To Purchase Bonds
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 8  Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, in a cabled message, called on American Jews today to intensify their financial support of his nation because of its economic need.

title: McCarter Pushes Repertory
description: PRINCETONThe curtain is about to rise again on another season for the McCarter Theater Company, a season in which the accent will be on a program of professional repertory.

title: Television
description: THE first Presidential press conference of the new Administration prompts some thoughts on two fairly unrelated matters. First, there is the television presence of Gerald Ford. And second, on a more subtle and parochial trade level, there is the absence of Dan Rather, the CBS correspondent who has been shifted from covering the White House to other important duties at CBS News. The pressconference forum, it seems, won't have Dan Rather to kick around any more.

title: Tense, Uneasy Feeling Confronts Giant Players
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 7An air of uncertainty suddenly has surfaced on the New York Giants, one week before the regularseason opener with the Washington Redskins at Yale Bowl.

title: Rape Laws in 4 States Restrict Testimony on Chastity of Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 7New rape laws that substantially reduce the potential humilianon of a woman at her attacker's trial have been signed into law in four states during the last few weeks. At least five other states are expected to pass similar legislation next year.

title: Condominium Plans Gain at Pt. Pleasant
description: POINT PLEASANTClark's Landing, the last place in town where one can rent a rowboat for an inexpensive day of fun in the water, seems destined to crumble before a municipality trying to protect its pocketbok.

title: How to Get a Pocketful of Strikes
description: Getting lined up is the secret behind shooting consistently high scores in bowling. But where does a bowler start? And, once Ite's found the line, how does he stay there?

title: Should the States Be Allowed to Dirty Air Now Clean?
description: WASHINGTONIn the treatment of environmental pollution, as in that of bodily ills, there are two complementary approachescure and prevention. In the environmental lexicon, prevention is known as conservation, or, in the case of air and water, nondeterioration.

title: Mr. Ford Is In Residence
description: President Ford appears to be concluding Phase 1 of the transition, as his ceremonial meetings and healing rhetoric have been informally described in the White House, and is entering into Phase 2remaking the executive branch into what will be known, when he is finished, as The Ford Administration.

title: Brezhnev Expects 1974 Soviet Grain To Meet Goal of 205 Million Tons
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, disclosed today that the Soviet Union expects not a bad harvest this year, despite an unfavorable situation in parts of Siberia and, Kazakhstan in the eastern part of the country.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Under a compromise plan now in the final stages of negotiation between the Administration and Congress and said to have Moscow's approval, at least 60,000 Jews and others could emigrate yearly from the Soviet Union. Highly reliable informants said that if agreement could be reached in the next week or two, passage of the Administration's longsought trade reform bill would be assured but, they said, the differences still holding up final approval were not insignificant. One major problem was said to be the exact wording of the legislation permitting the Soviet Union to get both nondiscriminatory tariff treatment and continued Government  backed ExportImport Bank credits. [1:8.]

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 7 A court martial today upheld the death sentences of eight persons convicted, of Conspiring to overthrow the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

title: FunLoving 3Man Racing Team Is Going After Obscure Records
description: A 45yearold former world champiop nearing retirement, the son of a successful driver who quit racing himself because he was scared, and a film star in between About The Towering Inferno and Motor  D r owning Sports Pool will team up, in the name of a spaghetti sauce, in two weeks and try to break speed recordssome set more than two decades ago by a 68yearold former mayor of Salt Lake City.

title: City's 966 Schools To Open Tomorrow On Optimistic Note
description: The city's 966 public schools will start the fall term tomorrow with their lowest enrollment in eight years and, despite some problems, widespread optimism over prospects for a peaceful and productive academic year.

title: Home Improvement
description: FIRE breaking out in an occupied home or apartment is always a frightening experience and a serious hazard, but when the fire occurs in the middle of the night while everyone is sound asleep there is a far greater likelihood of someone being seriously injured, or even killed, before all members of the family can be safely evacuated. This is because most fire victims are overcome by smoke or by the poisonous gases given off by combustion while they are still asleepbefore the actual flames ever reach them.

title: Crafts to Be Shown in Paramus
description: PARAMUS  Thirty members of the New Jersey Designer Craftsmen will show and demonstrate their skills at the fifth annual Designer Craftsmen Fair. The event will be held at the Bergen Community Museum of Arts and Science from 11 A.M. to6 P.M. on Sept, 28 and 29.

title: College Head Appointed
description: GLENVILLE, W. Va., Sept. (AP)The West Virginia Board of Regents has named a Tennessee education official as the new president of Parkersburg Community College. Jerry Jones, who Is 37 years old, will succeed Dr. Robert H. Stauffer as head of the twoyear college. Dr. Stauffer left last month to become president of Erie, N. Y., Community College.

title: Camera World
description: Camera World

title: DEMOCRATS TERM GOVERNOR'S RACE TOO CLOSE TO CALL
description: The race for the Democratic nomination for Governor, which began last January with Howard J. Samuels the heavy favorite, has moved into its final hours as a contest too close to call, in the view of many top Democrats.

title: Diana Couch Is Married
description: Diana May Couch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Couch Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Bay Head, N.J., to George Bennett Ritter, son of Mrs. George Harold Ritter, also of Upper Montclair, and the late. Mr. Ritter. Msgr. James S. Foley performed the ceremony.

title: New HousingLaw Gets Mixed Reviews
description: WASHINGTONThe reaction among housing specialists to the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, signed late last month by President Ford, ranges from applause to muttered resignation. The response is muted by the realization that high interest rates and the shortage of mortgage money have driven the housing industry into the kind of depression that no such act, however sweeping, is likely to reverse.

title: VERMONT TO VOTE IN SENATE RACES
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 7The Republican primary on Tuesday to determine a successor to Senator George D. Aiken has become an unexpectedly close fight over fragments of the personal mystique that kept Mr. Aiken, who is retiring at the age of 82, in the Senate for 34 years.

title: L.I. Kennel Owner Talks With Charges
description: COMMACK, L. I.,Children's book publishers who frown on anthropomorphism, talking animals in stories, might change their attitudes if they met Hamish A. Cowie at his Fonab Kennels here.

title: Makarios, in Geneva, Meets Greek Minister
description: GENEVA, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  The ousted President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios and the Greek Foreign Minister, George Mavros, held talks here tonight on the future of the troubled island.

title: A New Light on Manuscript Illumination
description: IF YOU could get the right computer on the job, it might yield a surprisingly high percentage figure to help measure the increase in the American public's interest in of all thingsmanuscript illumination as that interest has changed between Nov. 37, 1966, and next Thursday. On the earlier of these date's the Pierpont Morgan Library held an exhibition of a new treasure, the Book of Hours of Catherine of Cleves, and on the latter the Metropolitan Museum will open a similar exhibition of the Belles Heures of Jean, Duke of Berryone of its finest possessions but until now far from its most widely known.

title: Puns and anagrams
description: Puns and anagrams

title: Frank Buxton, Pulitzer Winner For Coolidge Editorial, Is Dead
description: Frank W. Buxton, former editor of The Boston Herald and the first New England newspaper man to win a Pulitzer Prize, died Friday in a Newton, Mass., nursing home. He was 96 years old.

title: Rivers of America
description: Not since the regionalism of New Deal days has anyone paid much attention to local and regional history, least of all the historians. A generation of them weaned on the problems approach to American history has not cared to study areas, except as they might relate to larger national issues. And with the mass media homogenizing the culture and blurring distinctions between localities, even regional fiction has taken a dive.

title: Jean Genet's purest perverse romance
description: Jean Genet's five novels have secured him international recognition as one of the masters of modern French fiction. He wrote Querelle in the late 1940's after he had finished Our Lady of the Flowers, Miracle of the Rose, The Thief's Journal and Funeral Rites. In many ways Querelle is the purest and the most austere enactment of those romantic situations that Genet's envy of handsome young men caused. him to return to again and again. The charming little queens who graced Our Lady of the Flowers have disappeared, but they have been replaced by the more complex Lieutenant Seblon, naval officer who maintains a severely masculine exterior in order to disguise the fits of ecstasy he rehearses in daydreams about his steward, Querelle. Whereas Querelle and all but one of the other adult men in the book are heterosexual and stupid, Lieutenant Seblon is clandestinely homosexual and as brilliant, devious and eloquent as Genet himself. We are treated to many excerpts from the Lieutenant's diary, and Genet mentions parenthetically: While the other characters are incapable of lyricism, which we are using in order to recreate them more vividly within you, Lieutenant Seblon himself is solely responsible for what flows from his pen. What flows are poetic effusions celebrating desire and masochismand Querelle.

title: Music
description: IT is still a little before Christmas, but you might want to put it on list for future reference. And there are birthdays and such. Anyway, here's another present for the music lover who has everythingThe Discopaedia of the Violin by James Creighton, published (all 987 pages of it) by the University of Toronto Press, 33 East Tupper St., Buffal, N.Y. 14203, at (gulp) $125.00.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS CITE RISING COSD
description: The oak doors and wrought. iron gates of the city's private day schools swing open on a new school year this week still attracting students whose parents are willing to pay collegelevel tuition costs, but unsure of how much longer they can maintain quality in the face of constantly rising costs.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Surf Clams
description: By NELSON BRYANT Also called sea clam or skimmer the Atlantic surf clam (Spisula solidissima), which ranges from Nova Scotia to South Carolina, is undoubtedly the most widely used base for prepared clam chowder, but few housewives have ever ecountered one in the shell.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONWhat may turn out to be one of those rare eventsa new discovery in economicsis attracting attention here.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A new entrant into the supersomething series: Pulsar. It's not the name of a man but of a security service organization, and its hero, Tim. Kyle, is so favored by nature and training that he (like the cybernetic man in another series) reacts in terms of fractions of seconds. His fist, and he has good punch, travels at 73 miles an hour. Read all about him in PULSAR INT'L: THE LONDON SWITCH by Robin Moore and Al Dempsey (Pinnacle, $1.25). Ireland, Europe, a touch of porno, amiable idiocy everywhere.

title: A Deli With a Dutch Accent
description: HOBOKENThe accent is Dutch at the Von Holland Delicatessen and Imported Foods store at 600 Bloomfield Street, And, says the ownercook, Laurens A. Vander Laan, a former HollandAmerica Line employe, his may be the only store in the state with such an accent.

title: SEXUAL ACTIVITY FOUND INCREASING
description: A national survey has indicated that in the 1970's married couples are having sexual intercourse more often than those in the same age brackets did in the previous decade.

title: Bullet Purchase Suspended
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 7 (UPI)The purchase of controversial hollowpoint bullets for the police department has been suspended, according to the interim police chief, Robert L. Hanson. The American Civil Liberties Union and others assert that the hollowpoint bulIlets were outlawed for warfare and are designed to maim and injure severely.

title: Pollyanna Parrots Put on a Show
description: A troupe of performing parrots, under the guidance of their director and owner, Mrs. Alba Ballard of Huntington Station, has been bringing joy and laughter, to audiences in hospitals, nursing homes and libraries.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Daylight Time

title: INDIA COMPLETES VOTING ON SIKKIM
description: NEW DELHI, Sept 7 (AP)The Indian Parliament made the mountain kingdom of Sikkim an associate Indian state Saturday over the protests of its oncestrong ruler.

title: Man Catches HitRun Van And Is Shot by Occupant
description: A security guard who chased a blue Volkswagen van after it struck an 80yearold man late Friday night and then sped off was shot by one of three men in the van after he caught up with the vehicle, the police said.

title: American Conference: Steelers Waiting ill the Wings if Dolphins Cannot Go
description: Can a team win the Americaii Football Conference championship for the fourth straight year despite the departure of its defensive genius, the impending defection of three star players to another league and a feud between the coach and the owner?

title: What They Are Saying
description: Bobby Riggs, despite his chauvinist image and his loss to Billie Jean King, says he's happy: Girls love me now. They can't keep their hands off me. I've had all kinds of proposals [for marriage]. They always want to cook dinner for me. Everybody knows I'm the 55yearold sex symbol [he's actually 57 years old], the happy hustler.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE. The Curious Pattern in Textile Fibers
description: The textile fiber picture, particularly manmade fibers, presents a curious situation today. Demand for the fibers, such as polyester and nylon, has leveled off and may be starting downward. Yet there does not appear to be any chance of lower prices that would have any appreciable effect in textile markets or consumer apparel or home furnishings.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Large Fleet Is Available For Newport Spectators
description: The blue stadium where the 22d defense of the America's Cup begins Tuesday has no 50yard line, no fixed sidelines and no stands for spectators.

title: U.C.L.A. and Tennessee Wind Up in a 1717 Tie
description: U.C.L.A. and Tennessee Wind Up in a 1717 Tie

title: 4 DEMOCRATS FACE CONNECTICUT VOTE
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 7Democrats in Connecticut will be choosing candidates in two Congressional primary elections this Tuesday.

title: Chinese Hint That Mao's Works May Be Revised
description: PEKING, Sept. 7The gospel of Chinese Communism, contained in the selected works of Mao Tsetung, may be revised soon to remove a number of approving references to the guiding spirit of an earlier age, Confucius.

title: School Days Begin
description: SCHOOL days will begin for gardeners this month. Classes are held at local metropolitan botanical gardens on a wide range of topics from bonsai and amateur botany to plant propagation, soils and fertilizers.

title: $90,000 in Jewelry Stolen
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP)A woman posing as a potential customer and a man dressed as a deliveryman robbed Ltd., Inc., a downtown store of $90,000 in jewelry and $200 in cash yesterday, the police said.

title: Suffolk Nonparents Group Defends Right of Couples to Remain Child Free
description: SELDEN  There is a terrible stigma attached to the childfree couple, said Marcia Rothstein during a discussion held at her home here recently with some of the members of the Suffolk chapter of the National Organization for NonParyou (N.O.N.). When you say you are not planning to have children you are immediately pegged as being selfish, irresponsible and hedonigtic, or you are a terrible person and can't possibly love children. It's so unfair.

title: Mozambique Rebels Sign Peace Pact With Portugal
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  Portugal's African territory of Mozambique is to become an independent state next June and a government formed by the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique will take power shortly, under an agreement signed here today.

title: Notes: What Makes Chevy Run? $1,662
description: How much does it cost a year to operate an intermediatesize car driven about 10,000 miles annually? About $1,662 (or 16.6 cents a mile), according to estimates made by the American Automobile Association. Intermediatesize cars, says the A.A.A., have replaced the standardsize vehicles as the nation's typical car.

title: Editors Choice
description: ARNOLD BENNET, By Margaret Drabble. (Knopf, $10.) An avowedly partisan biography of the somewhat de trop English writer that emerges as a comprehensive and finely shaded portrait.

title: A New Musical With Plain But Deep Feeling
description: IT IS such a strange thing to be surprised by emotion. I was sitting in the Goodspeed Opera House here one evening last week, lulled a little by the Victorian charm of the painted cherubs on its horseshoeshaped gallery but otherwise behaving as neutrally and as responsibly as a reviewer ought, totting up the pluses and minuses.

title: Tilda Schwartz Is Wed
description: Tilda Robin Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Lee Schwartz of New York and La Jolla, Calif, was married yesterday eve ning to Hugh Kennedy Tirrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Alden Tirrell of Buffalo. The ceremony was performed in the gardens of Darlington House, headquarters of the La Jolla Social Service League, by the Very Rev. Calvin Cabell Tennis, dean of St. Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Seattle. The bridegroom is a business consultant in Atherton, Calif.

title: Entry of 2,705 in Westchester Dog Show
description: Sixtynine years ago the first Westchester Kennel Club show was held in White Plains. Today, this prestigious event will be held at Lyndhurst, a national historic landmark considered by many fanciers as the most beautiful show site in America.

title: Late Pass Wins For Morgan State
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP)Mark Durden caught a 39yard, winning touchdown pass in the fourth quarter today as Morgan State College beat Jackson State, 106, in the annual Philadjiphia Opportunities Industrialization football game.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Report on an American summer: We went to a house on an island and took two cats and were presently joined by guests with three cats, and soon afterwards by fleas in the carpets.

title: What's Doing in BRUSSELS
description: THE MIXTUREThe Belgian na. tional slogan is In Union, Strength, but it has not worked too well in a country where the division between Frenchspeaking. Wallonie in the south and Flern ishspeaking Flanders in the north grows every day. Nevertheless, union is what Brussels is alI about. This bilingual capital remains a blend of old Flemish earthiness and 19th  century French elegance, and the blend is apparent in everything from architecture to food. Although Brussels was originally Flerirish, its 1.1million inhabitants are now mostly Frenchspeaking, and French can be used anywhere in the city. While the cultural FrancoFlemish mix survives, its charm has been diminished by Brussels drive to become the political and economic capital of Europe. The European Economic Community, NATO and countless international companieb have established their headquarters here, and the invasion has caused an officebuilding boom that has destroyed much of the old face of the city and given it a businesslikeand, soullesscharacter.

title: John DeWitt Shuck Weds Robin Shelby
description: Robin Ann Shelby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Shelby of West Islip, L. I., was married yesterday to John DeWitt Shuck, son of Mr. and Mrs. V. DeWitt Shuck of La Jolla, Calif. The ceremony was performed in the United Methodist Church, Babylon, L. I., by the Rev. Jack Savage, the minister..

title: Radio
description: Wednesday Thursday Saturday Friday Tuesday Today: Leading Events The Week's Concerts Today Monday

title: Baroness Astrid von Heyl Married to Kippy Forbes
description: Baroness Astrid Mathilde Cornelia von Heyl zu Herrnsbeim and Christopher Charles Forbes were married yesterday morning in Herrnsheim, West Germany.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The 50story skyscraper at 1633 Broadway is now more than 95 per cent rented with the signing of the J. C. Penney lease for 450,000 square feet.

title: Shore Residents Recall Fire On Morro Castle 40 Years Ago
description: SPRING LAKEAt 3:23 on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934 40 years ago todayan OS went out from the Morro Castle, an American luxury liner touted as one of the safest ships afloat.

title: Interdependence Is Real
description: PARISIt used to be said that when the United States sneezes the rest of the world catches cold. That still applies, but now the reverse holds true.

title: Miss Nelson Has Nuptials
description: Deborah Nelson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Kasin of New Rochelle, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Ian Robert Glen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Glen of Dublin. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Justice Alvin Ruskin of the State Supreme Court.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSENSUS of leading economists who met with President Ford last week was that the economy does not face a big depression although it is likely to remain sluggish for the rest of the year. They concluded also that the Federal Reserve Board's tightmoney policy should be eased.  Chrysler Corporation is considering a price increase averaging $400 a car. But Lynn Townsend, the company's chairman, said 1975 Increases might be larger, depending on costs.

title: HighFlying Actors at the Aquarium
description: Austin McDevitt balanced himself on the dock and thrust a large hoop forward above the surface of the big pool at the Coney Island Aquarium.

title: Boston Tax at Same Level
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) Boston's property tax rate of $196.70 per $1,000 of assessed valuation will remain unchanged for the third consecutive year, Mayor Kevin H. White said Wednesday. Under an austerity program the number of city employes has been cut by 10 per cent, or 1,535, during the last 18 months.

title: Gary Player Leads 4Man Golf With 67
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7If the National Broadcasting Company wants to run golf tournaments, the least it could do is abide by the rules, which would include a twostroke penalty for slow play on at least four or five holes.

title: A Boys Farm Is Planning to Admit Girls
description: MILLINGTON  Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys, which occupies a 365acre spread in the rolling hills of Somerset County, is planning to drop for Boys from its name and admit girls. The institution currently offers treatment and education for ito17yearold boys whose home and school environment has been inadequate and who need psychiatrically oriented surroundings and special schooling without being hospitalized.

title: Hubbard and Byrd Lead Jazz Groups On Fisher Hall Bill
description: Two jazz groups, similiar in. some ways, led by Freddie Hubbard and Donald Byrd played at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening. The instrumentation was roughly the sametrumpet, saxophone, electric piano and heavy percussion in the rhythm sectionsand both groups held to a consistently loud, abrasive level, which permitted scarcely any tonal or textural coloration.

title: Fancy fantasy
description: The English have a penchant for fantasy. Their literature is populated with hairytoed hobbits, Heffalumps, Houyhnhnms hookahsmoking caterpillars and a host of other creatures. Indeed, the most successful recently imported British best seller is an epic story about rabbits. Americans, as rule, are suspicious of the fantastic in fiction, preferring realisM and the camera eye. Occasionally, a mystical sea gull or mutant mammary manages to slip by, but for the most part the American reading public is not quite comfortable with makebelieve that is meant to be taken seriously.

title: A Setback for Gambling at Lake Tahoe
description: TAHOE CITY, Calif.  Environmentalists are enjoying run of beginners luck in an area where preachers and other moralists usually went brokecurtailing the gambling industry on the Nevada side of Lake Tahoe.

title: A visit to Cornwall's Cornwell, far from the neurotic insecurity of John Le Carr's unholy underworld
description: PENZANCE, Cornwall. The house hangs there on the edge of England; the cliff falls over a hundred feet of rock and salty scrub to the sea. From here, only the enormous ocean stirs and grumbles between us and America. It is the toe of the Cornish peninsula, Land's End indeed, where the island peters out into the Atlantic in a vast and stunning panorama.

title: Miss Haines Wed to Austin Starkey Jr.
description: Pamela Leeds Haines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bowne Haines of Englewood, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church, to Austin Clarence Starkey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Starkey of Princeton and Bay Head, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Harry Chase and the Rev. John William Van Zanten performed the ceremony.

title: A Renaissance on the Hudson
description: NYACK, on the west bank of the Hudson River about 30. miles from New York City, was once a quiet resort community where Grover Cleveland took long summer walks and Edward }topper, the artist, spent cool evenings on his front porch. Ben Hecht came later, and so did Helen Hayes, who moved into a large white Victorian house set back from the tall shade trees of North Broadway, where she continues to live today. At the southern end of the street the writer Carson McCullers made her final home.

title: Mexican Chief's Kin Freed by Abductors
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Sept. 7The 84yearold fatherinlaw of Mexico's President returned home safely tonight, 11 days after he was kidnapped by leftists.

title: Frank S. Horne, First Director Of City Rights Panel, Dies at 75
description: Frank S. Horne, first executive director of the New York City Commission on Human Rights and an authority on minority group housing problems, died yesterday of arteriosclerosis at the Mayflower Hotel, where he had lived for the last four years, He was 75 years old.

title: Economists at the White HouseTelling It Like It Is
description: WASHINGTONPut a bunch of economists in the East Room of the White House for a day, have the President give them a pep talk, and you get an astonishing amount of agreement over what needs to be done to Improve the ailing American economy.

title: Roulette In the Courtroom
description: A businessman is convicted of tax evasion. A Federal judge sentences him to three years in prison and a $5,000 fine, the maximum allowed by law. The businessman may not know it, but if he had only been in, another courtroommaybe one just next door, or in the next Federal District, or in a neighboring statehe might have got off with three months and a $5,000 fine.

title: Jones's Panorama
description: This is a book, Howard Mumford Jones tells us in his preface, written for the fun of writing it, not for specialists but for anyone curious about the cultural origins of Western revolutionism and the social effects of romanticism. Mr. Jones's motives are, as admirable as his candor. Any scholarly book worth the paper it is printed on should be written for the fun of writing it, and his evident enthusiasm for searching out and evoking the dizzyingly diverse materials of his subject deserves respect. There is no reason, moreover, why major works of historical synthesis should not be directed toward a broad audience of nonspecialists, as the luminous example of Edmund Wilson's To the Finland Station suggests. Moreover, Revolution and Romanticism, conceived as the centerpiece of a trio of studies (the other two are O Strange New World: American CultureThe Formative Years, 1964, and The Age of Energy: Varieties of American Experience, 18651915, 1971) reflects a lifetime of scholarly work on the culturalhistorical relations between America.

title: Women's Exchange Moving
description: WESTFIELD  When the Newark Exchange for Woman's Work, popularly called the Woman's Exchange, announced its closing last January after 93 years in business, customers came from miles around to offer condolences and buy just one last handknit sweater or, perhaps, a package of oneofakind Christmas tags.

title: Cabby Fatally Shot in Harlem; Was Member of Police Patrol
description: A 23yearold taxicab driver who was a member of a drivers organization trained by the police to report crimes and distress in the streets was fatally wounded in Harlem early yesterday, the police said.

title: Cute Brautigan
description: The Hawkline Monster can be read as one more of Richard Brautigan's surpassingly pleasant divertissements in prose, for it is, like his other four novels, wanly pretty, curious, unexciting, winsome, sprinkled with both sparkling and foolish wit, likable, wispy. Brautigan's writing inspires adjectives, not nouns. The atmosphere is the thing, not events or characters or emotions. Better not dig too deep. No veins of anything solid here.

title: U.S. Said to Halt Uranium To India to Block Testing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7High officials of the Atomic Energy Commission and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said privately today that the United States had stopped delivery of uranium fuel to India until the Indian Government clarified its policies on nuclear tests. But Dr. Dixy Lee Ray, chairman of the commission, denied the report.

title: Paperbacks
description: 1 ONCE IS NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline Susann. (Bantam, $1.95.) More mental bubblegum from Miss Susann, this time about a movie producer, his Electral daughter and a rich lady.

title: To Buy Privacy In Woods Is to Learn
description: A few years ago a friend and I, confirmed city dwellers and renters, became desperate for a place to find peace and quiet, at least during weekends. We made those endless and frustrating trips upstate, to New Jersey, to Long Island, to Putnam County, answering ads that were enticing. But inevitably we were disappointed with what we saw, and the prices seemed terribly inflated. An Olympicsize wimming pool turned out to be a pond filled with algae.'A nearbly lake was miles away and obviously of no value for privacy in summer, when it would surely be crowded.

title: Magazine Venture Is a. Risky Game for Mrs. King
description: A few years ago Billie Jean King and the Virginia Slims tennis players were holding hurried business meetings at airports between flights, playing matches before handfuls of people in places like Sewanee, Tenn., & begging the newspapers and television stations to pay attention. Two of the touring pros even played a set of doubles against a Southern sports editor and an Associated Press reporter to get.

title: The Making of Modern Drama
description: Those who know Richard Gilman as a literary and dramatic critic who works close to the immediate and difficult terms of contemporary culturein articles in such magazines as The New Republic, Commonweal, Newsweek,. American Review and in his two previous books The Confusion of Realms and Common and Uncommon Masksmay be a little surprised by The Making of Modern Drama. It seems to me the best single study of the astonishing transformations dramatic art has undergone in the last century or so; but its mood is that of philosophical generality and its esthetic analysis is relatively detached from political and social issues. I'm tempted to suggest (not at all censoriously) that it reflects a larger removal of interest from the present and relevant toward the traditional, a removal that Gilman would not be alone in having experienced recently.

title: What's New in Art
description: TUESDAY MONDAY In the Galleries SATURDAY THURSDAY FRIDAY SATURDAY WEDNESDAY In the Museums RECENT OPENINGS What's New in Art

title: Yugoslavia Combats View That Her Jammed Roads Are Driver's Death Trap
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 Yugoslavia, which counts heavily on income from foreign tourists who arrive by car, is trying to change her imagethat of a motorist's death trap.

title: Knievel to Leap Today; He and Promoter Tense
description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 7 The two men with the most to gain tomorrow at the scene of Evel Knievel's attempt to rocket across the Snake River Canyon are the star of the show, the 34yearold darling of the motorcycle set, and a New York lawyer named Robert Anon, who put the extravaganza together.

title: Letters: Experiencing The Great Adventure
description: To the Editor: In reference to Ted Morgan's article on New Jersey's Great Adventure amusement park, Out of Chaos (and $45Million) Come Acres of Animals, Spectacles and Rides (Travel Section, Aug. 4), I would like to tell you that our Great Adventure could better be called a Great Nightmare, a Great Ripoff, and a Great Disappointment. My family of four ($30 for admission) left Stamford, Conn., at 9 A.M. At 11 A.M. we were at Exit 7A of the New Jersey Turnpike. Now the nightmare begins. Traffic moved at a crawl, and we did not arrive at the Great Adventure gates until 1 P.M. We paid our $30, and with great expectations entered Safari Forest. Once again unprecedented traffic halted us, and we did not reach the amusement area until 3 P.M. By this time my two children had been sitting in the car for six hours. Upon entering the amusement area, we found crowds of such magnitude and limes of such length that I must conclude that the enterprise was not planned with any regard to the poor working man. We not ony were ripped off for $30, but we had to stand in line to go to the restrooms, and to stand for 30 minutes to get a hot dog (no soda; they were all sold out by the time our turn came). We were not able to see any attractions.

title: The Nation
description: Ever since the Environmental Protection Agency, in 1971, limited the pollutants that cars could emit, the automobile industry has contended that the regulations were unnecessarily strict. But the agency's policy has now received influential support from the research findings of the National Academy of Sciences, which concludes that the regulations are barely strict enough to meet the atmospheric quality goals established by the Clean Air Act.

title: Tourist Gap
description: The Commerce Department reminds us that this country has a $3billion tourist gap. Americans annually spend about $6.2billion overseas, while foreign visitors to the United States spend $3.2billion.

title: SEXUAL ACTIVITY FOUND INCREASING
description: A national survey has indicated that in the 1970's married couples are having sexual intercourse more often than those in the same age brackets did in the previous decade.

title: The Queen Against Defoe
description: Heym, who became the leading writer of the German Democratic Republic after the death of Brecht, and won the National Prize as late as 1969, enjoys a privileged status in this country for many sentimental reasons. He came here fleeing Hitler. He served in the U.S. Armed Forces. He wrote bestselling novels (Hostages, The Crusaders), and went back to East Germany in protest against the Korean War and McCarthyite persecution. In the G.D.R. three of his works were found to be subversive and were banned, although he was allowed to publish, travel and even earn hard currency in the West. Last year the commissars relented and Heym's banned works were prepared for publication in the G.D.R. One of them, 45 pages long, is the title story of this collection, in which Heym suggests a parallel between the modern battle, for freedom of expression and Daniel Defoe's persecution in 1702.

title: State Seen Facing Transit Dilemma
description: TRENTON  At a time when the Byrne administration is encouraging greater use of mass transit to ease energy and pollution problems, it sees itself forced closer to two selfdefeating decisions: higher fares and reduced service.

title: Patricia A. Pollock Is Married To Edward Haley, Bank Aide
description: The marriage of Patricia Annette Pollock to Edward Coleman Haley took place In Rye, N. Y., at noon yesterday. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection by the Rev, Clement T. Greenan of the Canterbury School in New Milford, Conn.

title: Michele Wood to Be Bride of Thomas F. Ruhm
description: Mrs. John Walter Wood of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Michele Wood, to Thomas Francis Ruhm.

title: Their Ship's Finally Come In
description: The cargo piling up on American piers this year is not a sign of a longshoreman's strike or any other disaster. It is actually a sign of prosperity aod the soaring profits American shipping companies are enjoying.

title: The Statement by Nixon
description: I have been informed that President Ford has granted me a full and absolute pardon for any charges which may be brought against me for actions taken during the time I was the President of the United States. In accepting this pardon, I hope that his compassionate act will contribute to lifting the burden of Watergate from our country.

title: Qaddafi Emerges From His Seclusion But Seems Gloomy on Libyan Aims
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 7Col, Muammar elQuaddafi, the Lib yan revolutionary leader, last week made his first public appearance on the international scene since he was relieved of daytoday political functions last April. It was apparent that he did not enjoy his return to the spotlight.

title: State Medicaid Audit Lists NursingHome Overbilling
description: Out of $4.6million in alleged overcharges for Medicaid found in a recent spot check by state auditors, $611,120 came from establishments owned by a respected leader of the city's nursinghome industry.

title: Some Mixed Reactions in Foley Square
description: A few hours after President Ford's pardon of his predecessor was announced yesterday, Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Wainwright of Olean, N.Y., were strolling in Foley Square in lower Manhattan, looking at the public buildings.

title: Expanded Ft. Worth Museum Reopens
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 8The first public showing of 20th century art from 24 private Texas collections today marked the opening of an expanded Fort Worth Art Museum.

title: Search Ended for Youth On Lake Ontario Swim
description: YOUNGSTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 8 (UPI)The Coast Guard called off the search tonight for a young Toronto man who apparently drowned while trying to swim across Lillie Ontario.

title: To Garden Fans, the Show Is a RipOff
description: The crowd that went to Madison Square Garden yesterday to watch the closedcircuit telecast of Evel Knievel's attempt to vault the Snake River was a largely suburban throng, openly admiring and supportive of the daredevil.

title: Tough Kid, 17, Takes Forest Hills Junior Title
description: He may not be a prodigy like Bjorn Borg, but America's best junior has the potential of a Stan Smith or a Jimmy Connors and like any champion, he knows it.

title: OR. ROBERT KNAPP, TAUGHT PSYCHOLOGY
description: Dr, Robert H. Knapp, professor of psychology at Wesleyan University, died yesterday at his home in Cromwell, Conn. He was 59 years old.

title: TightMoney Policy Relaxed, Fed Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8High Federal Reserve officials have gone out of their way to point out, for the first time that the Reserve's highly restrictive monetary policy has already been eased to a significant degree, and they add that no substantial further easing is to be expected.

title: VOTING TOMORROW IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 8  New Hampshire's famous Presidential primary has long been a launching pad for national liberalsfor Democrats such as Estes Kefauver in 1952, Eugene J. McCarthy in 1968and George McGovern in 1972, and for Henry Cabot Lodge, Republican, in 1964.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WNCN. Flute Concerto No. 6, Vivaldi; Les Eolides, Franck; Quartet in F, (K. 370), Mozart; Nocturne in C minor, Chopin; Overture to Orlando, Handel; Trio in B flat, Beethoven.10:06Noon, WQXR: The Listening Room. Robert Sherman, host. Stanislaus Skrowaczewski, conductor, guest.

title: DEMOCRATS HERE CONDEMN PARDON
description: Democratic politicians in the metropolitan area  especially those running for offices in tomorrow's primaryreacted yes terday to President Ford's decision to pardon former President Nixon with expressions of outrage and indignation.

title: Television
Mariner Loses to France
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8Dr. Robin Wallace, race committee chairman of the Ida Lewis Yacht Club here, had a good idea. It was his proposal to match the five 12Meter yachts left over following the nomination of Courageous and Southern Cross to sail for the America's Cup beginning on Tuesday. Today's event was to have been a last huzzah for Intrepid, France, Gretel II, Mariner and Valiant.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT RAID INTO LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 8Israel and Lebanese artillery exchanged fire today after an incursion by Israeli forces across the border, military headquarters here reported tonight.

title: PAIN EXPRESSED
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 8President Ford's pardon for Richard M. Nixon evoked today from the former President an expression of regret and pain at the anguish my mistakes over Watergate have caused the nation and the Presidency.

title: WIFE ASSERTS FORD ACTED IN GOOD FAITH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) Betty Ford said today that the President had acted in good faith in granting an absolute pardon to former President Richard M. Nixon. She reported that her husband went to church and received communion before making the announcement.

title: Great Dane Takes Her First Top Award at Westchester Show
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 8In lengthening shadows cast by the centuryold copper beech trees at Lyndhurst, a national historic landmark, a, Great Dane triumphed in one of the country's most prestigious dog shows today.

title: Chris Evert Beaten
description: Evonne Goolagong of Australia defeated Chris Evert in the semifinals of the United States Open tennis at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, 6.0, 67, 6.3, and will meet Billie Jean. King in the final today. Details, Page 45.

title: U.S. Bound Plane W ith 88Crashes in Sea Off Greece
description: ATHENS, Sept. 8  A Trans World Airlines jet bound for the United States with 88 persons aboard crashed today in the stormy Ionian Sea off Greece. The Greek Civil Aviation Authority said there appeared to be no survivors.

title: DR. A. S. ZABOTINSKY
description: Dr. Abraham S. Zabotinsky, dentist for 47 years in the East Flattish section of Brooklyn, died yesterday in New York University Hospital. He was 72years old and lived at 618 East 93d Street, Brooklyn.

title: NO CONDITIONS SET Action Taken to Spare Nation and ExChief, President Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8President Ford granted former President Richard M, Nixon an unconditional pardon today for all Federal crimes that he committed or may have committed or taken part in while in office, an act Mr. Ford said was intended to spare Mr. Nixon and the nation further punishment in the Watergate scandals.

title: State Pdnil Charges City Fails to Pursue Fugitives
description: The State Commission of Investigation disclosed yesterday that the backlog of missing bail jumpers and probation violators in the city had risen during the last three years from 82,000 to 130,000.

title: PROXMIRE OPPOSES SUBSIDY FOR PAN AM
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 8 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Pan American World Airways lust either live or die in the freemarket system. He urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to reject the airline's request for a $10.2million monthly subsidy.

title: The Failure of Mr. Ford
description: In giving former President Nixon an inappropriate and premature grant of clemency, President Ford has affronted the Constitution and the American system justice, It is a profoundly unwise, divisive and unjust act.

title: Substitutes Given a Raise As L.I. Teachers Strike
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. (AP)The Westbury Board of Education today increased salaries of substitute teachers to $50 from $30 a day for the duration of what it termed an illegal teacher strike.

title: White Merchants Plan to Leave Bissau at End of Portugal's Rule
description: BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea, Sept. 8 Business has never been better, a white store owner said the other day, but like many Portuguese and Lebanese smallbusiness men in Bissau he plans to leave the country along with the departing Portuguese soldiers.

title: 70 Ill After a Dinner For the Little League
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP)Seventy to 80 persons who attended a Little League dinner were being treated for suspected food poisoning late today, the police said.

title: For Miss America 75 the Questions Get Tougher
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 8Miss America of 1975, clutching her chaperone's hand, walked nervously today through the lobby of a hotel that was also housing 2,000feminists. Finally, she found the meeting room with the wooden throne.

title: Bomb Kills 3 in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8(Reauters)  Three leftwing Peronist guerrillas, one young woman, were killed today in Rosario, 200 miles north of Buenos Aires, when a bomb they were carrying in a car exploded the police reported.

title: Cyprus Recapitulation: How U.S. Policy Appeared to Shift Course
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8American diplomacy during the Cyprus crisis, touched off by the overthrow of President Makarios July 15, was by most official accounts neutral. A neutral stance, however, tended to favor the Greek military junta in the first phase of the crisis and worked to the advantage of Turkey thereafter.

title: Italian President's Visit to U.S. Stirs Dispute Over NATO Role
description: ROME, Sept. 8A scheduled state visit to the United States by President Giovanni Leone is causing controversy here over Italy's commitments to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The computerized supermarket checkout is being viewed by the Consumers League of New Jersey and other such groups as a mixed blessing.

title: Stunt Pilot Killed in Crash
description: WEYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 8(AP)  A woman stunt pilot was killed today when her biplane crashed during an air show at the South Weymouth Air Station. With 100,000 persons watching, Shannon Leithoff, 31 years old, of Huntsville, Ala., lost control of her single engine biwing Decathlon during a series of spins and crashed. None of the spectators was injured.

title: Red Smith
description: The tale is told by Bud Leavitt, the angler, hunter and Maine Woods version of Johnny Carson who moonlights as sports editor of The Bangor Daily News. The story belongs to Bud Leavitt, is here being stolen brazenly from him, and if he sues for plagiarismwell, anybody America can get a full pardon these days: Pardons make attractive keepsakes; when Blinky Palermo was managing fistfighters and the numbers game in Philadelphia he had his pardon from the governor framed on his office wall, like a doctor's diploma. However, that is a digression.

title: A Resignation for Conscience
description: He did not explain, but Mr. terHorst later said that White House had information that Mr. Nixon was not well.

title: Knievel Safe as Rocket Falls Into Snake Canyon
description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 8Evel Knievel failed today in an attempt to rocket 1,600 feet across the Snake River Canyon when a tail parachute deployed prematurely on the takeoff of his vehicle.

title: U.S. Assailed in Berlin Clash
description: BERLIN, Sept. 8 (Reuters)About 500 antiAmerican demonstrators clashed with por icemen during a United States Air Force open day at West Berlin's Tempelhof Airport today. The police said one policeman and a German airport guard had been injured.

title: Venezuela Expects Rise Of 14% in Crude Oil Price
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  Oilexporting countries are likely to decide to raise the price of crude oil 14 per cent during their meeting in Vienna Thursday, Venezuela's Hydrocarbons Minister, Valentin Hernandez, said here today.

title: Martha Mitchell Sees Deal Made by Ford and Nixon
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. (AP)Martha Mitchell said today that she was bitter about President Ford's pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon and believed the whole thing had been prearranged before Mr. Nixon left office.

title: Africa's White Rebels
description: The armed whites who have seized the radio station the capital city will not be able to delay for long the agreement leading to the independence of Mozambique concluded over the weekend by Portugal and the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique (Frelimo). Mindless bloodshed and exacerbation of racial tension are all that this small rebel group, which includes some former Portuguese soldiers, can possibly hope to achieve Mozambique itself.

title: Mary Howard Is Jersey Bride
description: Mary Carrington Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Howard Jr. of Blairstown, N.J., and Westport, Mass., was married in Blairstown yesterday to Huxley Howard Conklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Conklin Jr. of Warwick, N.J.

title: Crowds Threatening Success Of Nudist Beach on Cape Cod
description: TRURO, Mass., Sept. 8Success may spell the doom of one of Cape Cod's most popular summer attractions in recent yearsthe nude beach at Truro.

description: Box Scores of Major League Games

description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Soviet Agency Reports Pardon Without Comment
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8The Soviet press agency Tass reported without comment today that. President Ford had granted former President Richard M. Nixon a pardon for any Federal crimeS committed while in office.

title: W.F.L. Stars Sign Two, Release Two
description: recently released by the New England Patriots after seasons in the National Football League. Huff is the brother of Andy Huff, the Stars fullback. Marty Huff played two seasons with the San Francisco 49ers and last season with Edmonton in the Canadian Football League. To make room, the Stars released John Moss, a linebacker, and David Shaffer, a tackle. Carter Campbell, the recently acquired, defensive end, has been activated for Wednesday's game with the Portland Storm.

title: End Play Helps Rams Beat 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8(AP)  The defensive end's, Fred Dryer and Jack Youngblood, teamed up on a 54yard play today to give the Los Angeles Rams their first touchdown in a 177 National Football League exhibition victory over the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Knievel Safe as He Fails To Rocket Over Canyon
description: TWIN FALLS. Idaho, Sept. 8Evel Knievel failed today in an attempt to rocket 1,600 feet across the Snake River Canyon when a tail parachute deployed prematurely on the takeoff of his vehicle.

title: Janet Wood Bride Of John S. Farley
description: Janet Currie Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde A. Wood of Missoula, Mont., was married there yesterday afternoon to John Scott Farley, son of Mr. and. Mrs. Adrian M. Farley Jr: of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Carl Schroer performed the ceremony in the University Congregational Church.

title: ExConvict Is on Panel On City Jails
description: When violence erupted earlier this summer at the Queens House of Detention, Kenneth Jackson heard the news on his radio and rushed over to the Kew Gardens prison.

title: STANLEY WOLDER,61; LAW FIRM PARTNER
description: Stanley Wolder, senior partner in Wolder & Gross, a laws firm at 521 Fifth Avenue specializing in patent, trademark, copyright and scientific law, died yesterday after a long illness at New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

title: T.W.A. Lists Passengers
description: Following is a list of crew and passengers aboard the Trans World Airlines plane that crashed yesterday off Greece The list was supplied by the airline's New York office. The names of the six cabin crew metnbers have not Yet been released.

description: After a sevenweek summer recess, the Legislature returns to work in Trenton today to resume deliberations on taxes and school financing and to deal with, some lesser problems.

title: Consortium Formed
description: BONN, Sept. 8The West German central bank will announce the formation of a consortium next Thursday to help an estimated 100 small private German banks to get through a severe liquidity crisis caused by months of tightmoney policies here.

title: Dr. Charles Connor Dead; A Cardiologist Here, 68
description: Dr. Charles A. R. Connor, a specialist in cardiovascular diseases, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived here.

title: EISENHOWERS HAPPY OVER FORD'S ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) David Eisenhower, former President Richard M. Nixon's soninlaw, said today that President Ford's decision to pardon Mr. Nixon was a personal relief for all of us.

title: Proclamation of Pardon
description: Richard Nixon became the thirtyseventh President the United States on January 20, 1969, and was reelected in 1972 for a second term by the electors of fortynine the fifty states. His term in office continued until his resignation on August 9, 1974.

description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 8The Andean Common Market is fared with its first major crisis over the rules for the treatment of foreign capital.

title: Task Force to Consider Ways of Stemming Terror Caused by Gangs of Girls at the Children's Center
description: A task force will be sent into the Children's Center by the city's Human Resources Administration, probably this week, of ending the situation in which gangs of severely disturbed teenage girls are terrorizing other children and the employes there.

title: Employable Members Found In Half of City's Relief Families
description: About half the welfare family and homerelief cases in New York City have an employable member but not more than 12 per cent of employables are being placed in jobs, according to a new study made for the State Labor Department.

description: ATLANTA, Sept. 8Senator Henry M. Jackson called on the Ford Administration today to move at once to reconsider the offer by the Nixon Administration to supply nuclear reactors to Egypt.

description: A survey for Newsweek magazine three days before President Ford granted Richard M. Nixon a pardon indicated 58 per cent of those polled were opposed to granting the former President amnesty.

title: HardPressed Upstate Town Induces Japanese to Build a Steel Mill

title: China Replaces Taiwan
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8. (AP)The AsianGymnastics Confederation has accepted China as a member, ousting Taiwan, officials said today. The confederation also accepted North Korea, Kuwait and Iraq as members.

title: Reaction to Pardon of Nixon Is Divided, But. Not Entirely Along Party Lines
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Reaction was sharply divided today over President Ford's pardon of former President Richand M. Nixon, but the division was not altogether along party lines.

title: Yanks Routed by Tigers, 113, And Drop Into a Tie for First
description: The American League's Eastern Division Pennant race took another turn yesterday and it was not one that bodes immediate benefit for the Yankees. New York was shelled, 113, at Shea Stadium by the Detroit Tigers while the Red Sox were topping the Milwaukee Brewers in Boston.
