title: Policeman Shot as He Stops Carl Carrying 4 Robbery Suspects
description: A police officer was shot in the leg yesterday by one of four men in a car he and his partner had stopped in the Bronx to question about an earlier crime.

title: Order of Nuns Making Yoga Part of Rites
description: ROUND LAKE, N.Y.It is 6130 A.M. and the chapel is etitty. The early sun coming through the trees has left a watery pattern of shadows around the altar. The table, which later in the day will be set with bread and wine, is bare now except for a green cloth stitched with the ancient Christian symbol of a fish. The nuns and their guests begin to file in, and as they do the pile of colorful pillows in the corner of the chapel disappears. Without a Word, but at the appropriate moment, those gathered drop into yoga positions and begin chanting the Jesus prayer. For the last two years, this is:liow the day has begun far a, sroup of Roman Catholic nuns living in this Methodist community 30 miles north of Albany. The sisters, who are five in number and range in age from 25 to the early 40's, are in the process of founding, a new religious order that combines Western Catholicism with Eastern rites.

title: The Statement by Nixon
description: I have been informed that President Ford has granted me a full and absolute pardon for any charges which may be brought against me for actions taken during the time I was the President of the United States. In accepting this pardon, I hope that his compassionate act will contribute to lifting the burden of Watergate from our country.

title: Bridge: Dominance in World Events Threatened by Young Teams
description: For many years it has been a case of Italy first, North America second and the rest nowhere in world standings. But there are signs that this dominance of the big two will soon end.

title: Kuh Asks Tighter Laws on 1 5Y earOlds
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan took time out from bicycling with his wife and Iwo children in Central Park yesterday to make public a prorposal for tougher penalties for 15yearold killers.

title: Six Papers in Ivy League Disapprove the Pardon
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 8(AP)A spokesman for the Princeton University student newspaper said today that the editorial boards of six Ivy League papers disapproved of the pardon granted former President Nixon.

title: Bike Thefts Multiply In Suburbs as Well
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y.,  During the past several months, a serious problem has developed in New Rochelle, Police Commissioner William G. Hegerty told the City Council the other day. It's a problem experiL enced by many other municipalities, and one that is defying a valid solution.

description: The State Commission of Investigation disclosed yesterday that the backlog of missing bailjumpers aria probation violators in the city had risen during the last three years from 82,000 to 130,000.

title: On Keeping a Diary
description: Diaries are no longer dear; as the invention of the telephone began the decline of letterwriting, the invention of the tape recorder has led to the atrophy of the personal diary. Many of us record our words but few of us record our thoughts.

title: Red Sox Regain Share of Lead, but Orioles Falter
description: The Boston Red Sox scrambled back into a tie for the lead in the American League Eastern Division yesterday after the Yankees were beaten by the Detroit Tigers. Meanwhile the Baltimore Orioles missed a chance to share the lead when their 10game winning streak was broken by the Cleveland Indians.

title: HARLEM OPPOSES PRISON FACILITIES
description: Twentynine Harlem clergymen, business leaders, educators and community residents have sent Governor Wilson letter charging the state with an act of arrogance by thrusting new correctional prison facilities into their neighborhood.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor, apparently has no plans to challenge the validity of the unconditional pardon that President Ford bestowed today on Richard M. Nixon, according to a spokesman for Mr. Jaworski.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8President Ford granted former President Richard M. Nixon an unconditional pardon today for all Federal crimes that he committed or may have committed or taken part in while in office, an act Mr. Ford said was intended to spare Mr. Nixon and the nation further punishment in the Watergate scandais.

title: Stanley Keyser, 74, Dies; Led Consolidated Cigar
description: Stanley S. Keyser, president of the Consolidated Cigar Corporation of New York from 1959 until his retirement in 1966, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 150 East 77th Street.

title: Ford Plans Speech Today
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (UPI) President Ford will be the principal speaker tomorrow at the opening of the threeday annual conference on transportation at which the problems of urban areas in moving people rapidly and efficiently will be explored. There was no advance word on Mr. Ford's topic, but convention planners were hopeful that he would outline his Administration's policy on urban transit.

title: About the Mets
description: Cleon Jones, suffering from a sore knee the last couple of weeks, went in to play left field for the Mets in the eighth inning. The Mets announced they had purchased Brock Pemberton, a first baseman, and Nino Espinosa, righthanded hurler, from their Victoria farm in the Texas League. Pemberton, a 20yearold switchhitter, batted 322for Victoria, which completed a threegame sweep of the league playoffs Saturday night. Espinosa, a 21yearold Bronxite who was born in the Dominican Republic, had 98 wonlost record and a 3.42 earnedrun average. Both players were scheduled to join the Mets in New York today for the first of a twogame series with Montreal.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PARAMUS, Sept. 8If there is a better bowling league in the country than the Paramus Eastern Classic, Tony Lakawicz would like to know about it. Twenty teams, with many of the leading names in pro bowling on their rosters, will open the Eastern Classic's 22d season tomorrow night on the Paramus Bowling alleys.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8J. terHorst, whose appointment as White House press secretary was the first in President Ford's new Administration, resigned tonight in what he said was a protest over the granting of an unconditional pardon to former President Nixon.

title: The Midwest Is What's Left Over
description: Before too many exotic political analyses are based on Gerald Ford's being a Midwesterner, I would like to point out that he is not a Midwesterner. He is an Expatriate Midwesterner. They form a separate subculture, like the Overseas Chinese. For the past quarter of a century, he has lived in the East with a wife who is, I suspect, sophisticated enough to refer to this justasimpleAmericanlad business as his Grand Rapids number. My suspicion about Mrs. Ford's views is based not on inside information but on my own wife's habit of lumping certain of my attitudes into what she calls my Kansas City act.

description: BOSTON, Sept. 8On Aug. 9, after taking the oath of office of President, Gerald Ford said: The Constitution works. One month later, in a sudden and illconsidered gesture, he has frustrated the process of law and the Constitution. The damage to his own hopes will be grave, perhaps irreparable.

title: 4Year Connecticut Study To Focus on ExPrisoners
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 8 Hundreds of prisoners and parolees in Connecticut who are suddenly being given their freedom because of a court ruling will be studied for the next four years in an effort to determine whether shorter sentences could safely have been given and whether parole as an institution is worth keeping at all.

title: List of Candidates Running in Primaries Tomorrow
description: Following are the candidates in contests for Democratic, Republican, Conservative and Liberal party nominations for public office in tomorrow's primary here. Unoppossed candidates are nominated automatically, and their names will not appear on the ballot. Asterisks denote incumbents.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The United States Senate has scheduled confirmation hearings for later this month on the nomination of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut to fill a longvacant seat on the Federal Court of Appeals, Second Circuit. This appears to indicate that Mr. Meskill has cleared a review of his case by President Ford. And Mr. Meskill's sponsor, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, said he would expect the Governor to step down from his state post soon after the hearings were held, should the Senate approve the nomination.

title: East German Women Snap World Marks in High Jump, 400Meter Relay
description: ROME, Sept. 8East Germany set two world records on the concluding day of the European track and field championships before a crowd of more than 60,000 in Rome's Stadio Olimpico today.

title: Yugoslav Sees Work. Laxity Behind Zagreb Train Crash
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8, (Reuters) A top Yugoslav Communist party official said today that an irresponsible attitude toward work and a lack of discipline were responsible for the train crash last week in Zagreb in which 124 people died.

title: The Major Events of the Day
description: President Ford granted former President Nixon an unconditional pardon for any Federal crimes he may have committed during his term in office. The pardon exempts Mr. Nixon from indictment and trial for, among other things, his role in the coverup of the Watergate burglary. Mr. Ford said the pardon was intended to spare both Mr. Nixon and the country further punishment resulting from the Watergate scandals. Philip W. Buchen, the White House counsel who advised Mr. Ford on the legal aspects of the pardon, said it was an act of mercy on the President's part and was done without making any demands on Mr. Nixon and without asking the advice of the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski. [1:8.]

title: Lawyer, 36, Is Liaison for Presidents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Benton L. Becker; the young lawyer who acted as intermediary between President Ford and former President Richard M. Nixon in the negotiations that led to today's pardon announcement, was described by a former colleague in the Justice Department as a real wheelerdealer.

Queens.

The police said about 1,500 people took part in the protests in Seoul and in provincial cities. Moon Sekwang, a 22yearold Korean who lived in Japan, has been arrested in the shooting.

description: The American League's Eastern Division Pennant race took another turn yesterday and it was not one that bodes immediate benefit for the Yankees. New York was shelled, 113, at Shea Stadium by the Detroit Tigers while the Red Sox were topping the Milwaukee Brewers in Boston. That dropped the Yankees into a tie for first place with the Red Sox with 23 games left. The Baltimore Orioles, who lost to Cleveland after 10 straight triumphs, are one game behind.

title: Clark Rebuts Attacks by Rivals in Last TV Debate
description: Ramsey Clark defended his Middle East proposalscombining military aid to Israel with economic aid to the entire warring regionfrom attack on both sides last night as the three contenders for the Democratic United States Senate nomination met in their final, televised debate.

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing FIRST$7,000, trot, Class C.1, mile.

title: CANDIDATES SKIRT LAWSON FINANCING
description: Big moneyfrom family fortunes and large contributorsplayed a major role in the Democratic primary campaigns despite new state and Federal campaignfinance laws that were supposed to have reduced its influence.

title: VICTOR J. DEMASI
description: Victor J. DeMasi, a partner in Clarke & Rapuano, Inc., consulting engineers and landscape architects, died Saturday of lung cancer in Stamford (Conn.) hospital. He was 57years old and lived at 137 Berrian Road, Stamford.

title: Peterson Edges Fittipaldi To Win Italy Grand Prix
description: MQNZA, Italy, Sept. 8 (AP)  Ronnie Peterson of Sweden, upsetting the favored Ferraris on their home track, drove his Lotus to victory by less than a second in the Italian Grand Prix today and the race for the world championship got even closer.

title: Samuels and Carey Trade Some Old Charges and a Few New Ones in Final Two Debates
description: In their last two debates yesterday, the two contenders for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination traded familiar charges, added a few new ones, shook hands and agreed that there was little more for them to do than to wait for the votes to decide at the polls tomorrow.

title: D.& H. Railway Credits Black Ink to Workers
description: COLONIE, N.Y., Sept. 6The Adirondack, the only Passenger train operating over the tracks of the Delaware & Hudson Railway, roared into the station here today at 4:05P.M. It had left Montreal at 9:30 A.M. and was due in New York City at 7:50 P.M.

title: HardPressed Upstate Town Induces Japanese to Build a Steel Mill
description: AUBURN, N. Y.The business card that Mike Peduto hands out proudly to identify himself as executive vice president of the Auburn and Cayuga County Chamber of Commerce has gone bilingual. It is printed in English on one side and in Japanese on the other.

title: Miss Evert Bows
description: The Forest Hills tennis stadium offered one of its outstanding triple features yesterday.

title: 2 Children Killed In Race Car Crash
description: TELL CITY, Ind., Sept. 8(AP)  Two children were killed and five persons hospitalized with serious injuries today after a race car smashed through a protective fence at a small race track near this southern Indiana community.

title: MARKETS GREET EASING OF CREDIT
description: The Federal Reserve System, cast in the uncomfortable role, of a tightfisted villain, reacted last week with a wellpublicized move to ease the supply of credit in the money market. And the market place, grateful for any relief from tight money, responded with a mild rally in the prices of the bettergrade fixedincome securities.

title: Police Hold Moscow Jews Protesting for Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Sept, 8 (AP)Half a dozen Moscow Jews, seeking permission to emigrate, lined up today under the statue of Yuri Dolgoruky, the city's founder, and unfurled paper banners urging Freedom for Prisoners of Zion.

title: Russians Seek to Expand MachineTool Sales Here
description: CHICAGOThe Russian machinetool industry hopes to sell $1.5million of its products in the United States this year. At the same time, it will import $63million of American machine tools.

title: SURVEY INDICATES DEEPENING SLUMP
description: The National Association of Purchasing Management's August indicators all point to deepening recession involving deteriorating business activity, a slowdown in new orders and production, and signs the nation faces increasing unemployment, The Associated Press reports.

title: Shore Crowds Set Record But Inflation Hurts Resorts
description: WILDWOOD  Despite an anxious winter because of the gasoline shortage, New Jersey's resort industry drew record crowds to the shore for the 1974 season.

title: Deaths
description: ASTRACHANIrvine. The Faculty of Stnvesant High School would like to express their sorrow at the passing of Irving Astrachan, beloved teacher & administrator for over forty years. He will always be remembered by his friends & his students.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
One Dies in Plane Collision
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 8(AP) Two light planes collided in flight near here today, killing the pilot of one. The second airplane, with four persons aboard, landed safely at a nearby airport, the state police said. Killed was Robert S. Lilienthal, 47 years old, of Bethlehem, the police said.

title: Statement by the President in Connection With His Proclamation Pardoning Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8(AP)Following is President Ford's statement in which he pardoned former President Richard M. Nixon:

title: Toy Shop Enchants Owners
description: MANCHESTER CENTER, Vt.  The white clapboard house sits under old trees on a patch of lawn on Route 7, about two miles north of town: Outside the house is a sign that reads: The Enchanted Doll House, And for its inhabitants, the house is enchanted.

title: Retailers Wary on Profits; Certain on Dollar Volume
description: The nation's retailers have become avid watchers of economic data that can indicate the trends in consumer spending and the probable increases in sales for the balance of 1974.

title: Portobello Packs'em in Like Kippers
description: The Portobello Road Fair was a scene of curbtocurb people yesterday morning, hours before Mayor Beame arrived to open officially the Britishaccented and boisterous antiques extravaganza.

title: Spraying Set in Bay State
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The state Department of Public Health will start spraying swamps in southeastern Massachusetts on Wednesday to curb the danger of eastern equine encephalitis, a rare disease that has been contracted by three area residents recently: The disease noramlly affects horses and is transmitteed by a kind of mosquito that does not ordinarily bite humans. A 6yearold Foxboro boy dided of the disease Aug. 30 and two other persons remained hospitalized with it.

title: Cyprus Crisis Stirred U.S. To Protect Atom Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 8 Since the Cyprus crisis erupted in midJuly, the United States has taken precautionary measures to protect and if necessary, to remove atomic warheads stockpiled in Greece and Turkey, Defense Department officials disclosed today.

title: Will the World Fertilizer Shortage Hit Home?
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Sept. 6There is a world fertilizer shortage. This gloomy fact was reported only last week, along with the prospect of fertilizer being diverted from such ornamental usage as lawns and shrubbery to help grow crops in underdeveloped nations.

title: New F.P.C. Proposals Define Energy Emergency
description: The Federal Power Commission has prepared a set of proposed guidelines for use in determining what constitutes an electricalenergy emergency and under such circumstances, how it will act to see that the nation's electrical energy needs are met.

title: Wolfgang Windgassen Dies, Tenor Led Stuttgart Opera
description: STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 8 (AP)Wolfgang Windgassen, director of the Stuttgart Opera and one of West Germany's bestknown Wagnerian tenors as well as a former singer with the Metropolitan Opera in New York, died here today. He was 60 years old.

title: Their AlmostCouture Fashions
description: There are, according to Huibert Zuur, a lot of women who don't have the time to spend planning a wardrobe and/or pulling themselves together. Mr. Zuur and Edward J. Austin have an infant business designed to cater to just such incidental problems in life.

title: Proclamation of Pardon
description: Richard. Nixon became the thirtyseventh President the United States on January 20, 1969, and was reelected in 1972 for a second term by the electors of fortynine the fifty states. His term in office continued until his resignation on August 9, 1974.

title: DENVER SCHOOLS INTEGRATE EASILY
description: DENVER, Sept. 8The Denver public schools completed Friday their first week of citywide school desegregation, with an unblemished record of racial harmony and with enrollments running at 93 per cent of the totals that school officials had expected.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)Nolan Ryan almost matched his unpublicized record of 100.9 miles an hour for a pitched baseball last night and said he didn't care for the scientific scrutiny o his pitches. I don't like to do it because it takes too much away from my concentration, the California Angel strikeout king said after beating the Chicago White Sox, 31. His fastest pitch recorded by infrared radar was 100.8 m.p.h., a ninthinning fastball to Bee Bee Richard, who wound up walking.

title: CANDIDATES SKIRT LAWSON FINANCING
description: Big moneyfrom family forth tunes and large contributorsplayed a major role in the Democratic primary campaigns despite new state and Federal campaignfinance taws that were supposed to have reduced its influence.

title: Ford Signs Delinquency Bill, But Opposes Full Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) President Ford announced today the signing of a juvenile jus ice and delinquency prevention act. However, he said he would not ask for full funding of the programs at a time when the economic situation demands acrosstheboard restraint, especially in the Federal budget.

title: Fezler's 65 for 271 Gives Him First Tour Victory
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 8(AP)Forrest Fezler captured the $100,000 Southern open today with a fiveunderpar 65 on the final round to win his first professional golf tournament.

title: Beame Will Fly to Coast In Behalf of Transit Fare
description: It may seem like the long way around, but Mayor Beame will fly to San Francisco this week as part of his effort to save the city's 35cent subway and bus fare. He will meet with the mayoral lobbyists on the Legislative Action Committee of the United States Conference of Mayorsthe group that formed around his predecessor John V. Lindsay, and helped provide a backdrop for the Lindsay Presidential camjpaign. There is a ceremonial element. The mayors will be helping to dedicate the Bay Area Rapid Transit system.

title: AGENT SAYS NIXON WANTS TO BE HEARD
description: Irving Lazar, a literary agent, said yesterday that former President Richard M. Nixon, whom he described as tanned, invigorated and in complete command of the situation, had authorized him to negotiate the sale of his memoirs for what will probably be more than $2million in advance payments. The Associated Press reported.

title: Reforming Welfare
description: Welfare reform, the most imaginative and humane initiative of the Nixon Administration, is one of those items shoved aside by Watergate that deserves early and favorable attention by President Ford.

title: Sri Lanka and Pakistan Plan A Joint Development Group
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 8Sri Lanka and Pakistan will establish a joint committee to promote cooperation in industrial and economic development, it was announced today. The announcement was made simultaneously in Islamabad and Colombo at the end of fiveday visit to Pakistan of Sri Lanka's Prime Minister, Sirimavo Bandranaike.

title: Rowing Summaries
description: Elite Double Sculls1, Bdigarla, 6 minutes 44.26 seconds; 2, U.S., 6:44.38; 3, Belgium, 6:49.20; 4, France, 6:50.31; 5, Sweden, 6:53.97; 6, Switzerland, 8:21.66.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was with a feeling of shock, coupled with disbelief, that I read of President Ford's request that Congress grant former President Richard M. Nixon almost a million dollars in expenses as  fixed by law in the Presidential Transition Act of 1963.

title: Brock Steals 2, Needs 1 To Tie Mark
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8Lou Brock got on base twice and stole two bases today to tie Max Carey for the National League career record, but he wasn't able to steal another base or the game for the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Joan F. Poll Married to Leonard Stern
description: Joan. F. Poll and Leonard Stern, student at the New York Medical College, were married here yesterday at noon in the St. Moritz. Rabbi Mosche Lewish, executive director of the Jewish Education Center in Elizabeth, N. J., performed the ceremony.

title: Ethiopians Assail Emperor
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 8 (Reuters)Thousands of people chanting Hang the Emperor demonstrated in the Ethiopian capital today. It was the second public demonstration against Emperor Haile Selassie in the last week. Soldiers urged the crowd to go home.

title: Nixon Tapes Must Be Kept 3 Years for Use in Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Richard M. Nixon and the Ford Administration have reached an agreement under which the former President will ultimately be permitted to destroy the White House tape recrdings that led ti his cownvnfall.

title: Big Drop in Auto Pollution Reported Around State
description: State environmental officials disclosed yesterday that the levels of automotive pollution in New Jersey, described last year as nearly the worst in the nation, dropped by 45 to 99 per cent in the first six months of 1974 in comparison with the first six months of 1.973.

title: Chris Evert Beaten
description: Evonne Goolagong of Australia defeated Chris Evert in the semifinals of the United States Open tennis at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, 6.0, 67, 6.3, and will meet Billie Jean King in the final today, Details, Page 45.

title: 10 COUNTRIES JOIN IN WEATHER STUDY
description: YOFF, SenegalThe pilots who are briefed daily in a white brick building off Senegal's international airport here get their instructions in English, with immediate translation into Russian and French.

title: Helen Lazarus Is Wed to Lawyer
description: At the Rockdale Temple in Cincinnati at noon yesterday, Helen Lazarus was married to Ronald Michael Freeman by Rabbi Harold D. Hahn.

title: About New York
description: Cafeteria dining is on the way out, although this is scarcely the talk of Paris, or the lament of Sutton Place. The day of the tray is giving way to fast food in New York, and another local institution is punching out its last checks.

title: Head of Sikkim Asks. India to Delay Action
description: CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 8(AP) The oncestrong ruler of Sikkim publicly appealed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and the Indian President today to delay making his Himalayan territory an associate state of India.

title: TRIAL IS ON TODAY IN 4 FIRE DEATHS
description: Joseph Satkin, the owner of a large number of apartment buildings in Passaic, and two codefendants go on trial today in Superior Court in Newark in the murder of a woman and three children in a Passaic fire last year.

title: Stage: Britain's Glory
description: LONDON, Sept. 8  When Britain's National Theater was founded in 1962, there was never any intention for it to become a chauvinistic organization, devoted exclusively or even primarily to the production of British plays. That policy was insisted upon by its founder and first director, Laurence Olivier, and will certainly be maintained by Lord Olivier's successor, Peter Hall. Interestingly, two of Mr. Hall's first productions admirably point up the theater's determination to give the British public a completely international view.

title: Indian Police Kill 2 in Riot
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 8 (UPI)Two persons were killed and 12 others wounded today when the police fired on a crowd of 6,000 rioting refugees in Mena in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, Government officials said. The clash erupted in a dispute over the distribution of food and other relief supplies the officials said.

title: Derailment Delays IRT Line;
description: Subway service on the IRT Pelham Bay Park line in the Bronx was curtailed for 90minutes yesterday after one car of a northbound local was derailed just north of the Hunts Point Avenue station at 2:52P.M. No one was injured, and Ithe Transit Authority said the cause of the mishap was under investigation.

title: A New Kind of Coverup
description: If I am wrong, said Gerald Ford, Cribbing from Lincoln in his effort to &infer instant innocence on Richard Nixon, ten angels swearing I was right would make no difference. Even *hundred angels caroling in unison OA the steps of the White House could net rectify the horrendous blunder Mr. Ford made in giving Richard Nixon advance pardon for any and all criminal acts he may have perfdrmed from Jan. 20, 1969, through Aug. 19, 1974.

title: Roundabout Makes the RKO 23d Its Home
description: The Roundabout Theater Company, which has won recognition as one of New York's outstanding repertory institutions, has leased the RKO 23d Street Cinema, and is converting it into a legitimate theater.

title: Magnavox Omits Dividend
description: The Magnavox Company said yesterday its board of directors voted to omit payment of its regularly scheduled fourthquarter dividend and all dividends until further notice. No reason was given for the action. North American Philips is currently tendering for Magnavox stock at $9 a common share.

title: Meany Sees Boycott Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) George Meany, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, renewed his support today for the United Farm Workers efforts to organize grape and lettuce workers and asserted that the boycott against nonU.F.W. products was having an impact.

title: Facts on Security Parley
description: Following is some basic information about the second phase of the European security conference, which reopened yesterday in Geneva after a sixweek summer recess.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Reidar Sogntutes, acknowledged as one of the world's foremost dental detectives, will report in London today that he has conclusive evidence that Martin Bormann, Hitler's onetime righthand man, is dead and not hiding in Argentina. Dr. Sognnaes, professor of oral biology and anatomy at the University of California, Los Angeles, will tell the world congress of the International Dental Federation that Bormann committed suicide in Berlin in 1945 by biting a cyanide capsule.

title: Sawhill Fears Jobless Rise In Coal and Gas Shortage
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  The Federal energy administrator, John Sawhill, predicted today that shortages of coal and natural gas in the near future could lead to further unemployment.

title: Utility Requests Total $597.4Million Since'72
description: The state's three major utilities have requested a total of $597.4million in rate increases since the beginning of last year.

title: WILSON PREPARES FOR MAIN CONTEST
description: As the contenders in the Democratic primary directed their final blows at one another, Governor Wilson yesterday prepared for the main contest with some quiet road work.

title: VOTERS TO CHOOSE CANDIDATES TODAY IN STATE PRIMARY
description: The eightmonth long Democratic gubernatorial primary campaign ended last night with the candidates making their final appearances at clubhouse rallies but with the real campaigning going on behind the scenes with massive telephone, and personal canvassing operations designed to get out the vote.

title: A Professor's Unusual Collection: Jump Rope Rhymes
description: STORRS, Conn. How many women can read the skip rope rhyme above without having it call forth memories of schoolyards and sidewalks, scraped knees and flying pigtails?

title: Marciano's Widow Dies
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 9 (AP)Barbara Marciano, widow of Rocky Marciario, the former heavyweight boxing champion, died yesterday at her home. She was 45 years old. Mrs. Marciano's husband, who retired undefeated after six years as champion, was killed in a plane crash in Iowa in 1969. Survivors include her mother, Elizabeth Cousins, and two children, Rocky Jr. and Mary Ann Marciano.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: SENATE UNIT CALLS FOOD AID POLITICAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  A staff report for the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition today criticized the United States for using a large portion of its food aid for political, purposes and called on the United States to take the lead at the upcoming World Food Conference in efforts to alleviate human suffering.

title: Reward Offered for Data On Sponsors of Dogfights
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9The Animal Protection Institute, a national animal welfare organization, has offered a $5,000reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons promoting dog fights in Illinois, where a grand jury is investigating the illegal practice.

title: A L, I. SCHOOL AIDE DENIES CHARGES
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 9Mortimer J. Abramowitz, Superintendent of Great Neck schools, denied charges of insubordination, incompetence and neglect of duty to tumultuous applause from crowd of more than 1,500 people at the Board of Education meeting here tonight at the Great Neck North Senior High Scnool.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Missouri Pacific System, of St. Louis, said it had selected seven companies to build freight cars and diesel locomotives for a $100million equipment order. Involved are 3,000 freight cars and 80 diesel locomotives, the largest single order in its history, the railroad said.

title: AMTRAK IS SEEKING HIGHSPEED TRAINS
description: Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, sent Congress a fiveyear plan yesterday for highspeed service between major cities that in Chicles raising the average speed in the BostonNew YorkWashington corridor to 110 miles an hour.

title: KENNEDY JEERED ON BOSTON BUSING
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9Senator, Edward M. Kennedy was driven from the speakers stand of an antischoolbusing rally here today as he sought to calm hostile, booing crowd of parents.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day International National Metropolitan The Other News Quotation of the Day CORRECTIONS

title: Magnuson Linked To 72 Party Gifts From Airline Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Senator Warren G. Magnuson, head of a committee that handles airline legislation, was credited with raising $9,450from a dozen airline executives for the Democratic party in 1972, according to court documents.

title: Notre Dame Downs Georgia Tech, 317
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (AP) Notre Dame, embarrassed when its defense was shredded for an early touchdown, rallied behind Tom Clements's passint and running and smothered Georgia Tech, 317, tonight.

title: Disney, Expert in Mass Transit, Offers to Aid Cities
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9The people who gave the world Mickey Mouse said today that they would attempt to help the nation's cities cope with their masstransit problems.

title: Price of Amex Seat Up
description: I A regular membership on the American Stock Exchange was transferred yesterday at $39,1000, up $5,000 from the last sale on Aug. 8. The current bid is $29,000, and $38,000 offered.

title: Americans in Greece Feeling the Tension
description: ATHENS, Sept, 9 The wife of an army officer calls a taxi, but when the driver hears her American accent, he refuses to come.

title: Connors, Mrs. King Win Singles Crowns In U.S. Open Tennis
description: Jimmy Connors, overwheimingty, and Billie Jean King excruciatingly, became the United States Open tennis champions yesterday. The title was the first for Connors and the fourth for Mrs. King at Forest Hills. Each won $22,500, an automobile and other prizes.

title: Economists Laud Easing by Fed
description: Some of the nation's leading economists applauded yester day the recent moves by the Federal Reserve Board to ease monetary policy slightly. But the expertsseveral of whom attended President Ford's presummit inflation meeting last weekdiffered sharply on how much further the central bank should loosen policy.

title: McCrane Trial On Today
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9The trial of former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. on charges of tax fraud allegedly committed during the 1969campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill is scheduled to begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court.

title: WALTER C. CROCCO
description: Walter C. Crocco, retired vice president of the Story & KellySmith Company, newspaper representatives, died Sunday in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N. J. He was 78 years old and lived at 148 Claremont Road, Ridgewood.

title: Cost of Ford's Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Only 24 hours after the event, it was evident today that President Ford had already paid a substantial political price for his decision to grant a n unconditional pardon to former President Richard M. Nixon. The President's decision cost him the services of his press secretary, J. F. terHorst  a loss that meant more than the ordinary departure of a White House aide.

title: LLOYDS BANK DEALER ARRESTED BY SWISS
description: LUGANO, Switzerland, Sept. 9 (Reuters)A Swiss foreignexchange dealer at the Lugano branch of Lloyds Bank International has been arrested on charges of disloyal management and falsifying and suprpssing documents, the Public Prosecutor said today.

title: State Department Upholds Stand U.S. Did Not Interfere in Chile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9In a dispute that could lead to partment declared today that further hearings, the State Deit was standing by the testimony of senior officials who previously had asserted at Congressional hearings that the United States had not intervened in the internal affairs of Chile after the election of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Dr. Gertrude E. Perlmann Dies; Authority on Protein Chemistry
description: Dr. Gertrude E. Perlmann, member of the faculty of Rockefeller University for 28 years and an authority on protein chemistry, died of cancer early yesterday at New York Hospital, She was 62 years old and lived at 155 East 93d Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: Dow Chemical Pact Signed
description: MIDLAND, Mich., Sept. 9(UPI)The Dow Chemical Company and the United Steelworkers Union signed a new threeyear contract today, the last formal act ending a 177day strike, the longest in Dow's history.

title: 2 IN MURDER CASE HELP PROSECUTION
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9A Superior Court judge today agreed to delay the murder trial of Joseph Satkin, a Passaic County landlord, and two codefendants after one of the prosecutors told the court that the codefendants had given statements regarding the case. The prose, cutor requested immunity for the two people.

title: MORS AMENDS ITS MERGER PLAN
description: The proposed merger agreement of the Natomas Company and the Thermal Power Company, both of San Francisco, has been modified to the benefit of Thermal's shareholders, it was announced yesterMerger day. In amending News the original prof posal of a taxfree exchange of four shares of Thermal Power for each share of Natomas, Natomas now will provide a minimum of $14 in marker value of its shares for each Thermal share exchanged, up to a maximum of one share of Natomas for every 31/4 shares of Thermal.

title: Courageous Will Begin Defense of Cup Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I. Sept. 9The 22d challenge for the America's Cup begins tomorrow at 12:10 P.M. with Southern Cross from Australia challenging Courageous of the United States and the New York Yacht Club.

title: First Editions of Ibsen Are Stolen in Norway
description: SKIEN, Norway, Sept. 9 (AP) Twelve first editions of Henrik Ibsen's works were stolen today from Ibsen House hi the town of Skien, the Norwegian radio reported, together with a rare English work, Harof London.

title: People in Sports
description: John Matuszak, the 6foot8inch, 285pound defensive lineman, lost the first round yesterday in his bid to jump from the Houston Oilers of the National Football League to the Houston Texans of the World Football League. Judge Arthur Lesher, a Texas state district court judge, issued a temporary injunction in Houston prohibiting Matuszak from joining the W.F.L. Matuszak, the N.F.L.'s No. 1 draft choice in 1973, had left the Oilers and signed with the Texans on Aug. 28, contending his Oilers contract was invalid and that he was coerced into signing it.

title: Books of The Times
description: As he lay dying in 1679, the Earl of Rochester expressed the hope that his only son might never be a wit. As the greatest wit of his time, he knew what it had cost him. Once recognized, he could never relent. Like Ixion on his wheel, he had to continue all his life, turning phrases, writing satires, outraging his peers as a form of shock therapy to jolt them out of their idiocy. Irreverent by definition, he could not take anything seriously Rochester's most famous poem is Upon Nothing. He had to buzz from nothing to nothing, like a bee seeking nourishment among artificial flowers. His wit could afford no exceptions; it bit his friends as well as his enemies, It became a reflex he could not control, made him see the world as deformed. Since brevity is the soul of wit, he had to be inconstant too, betraying a lively, attractive wife for a mistress only to betray her in turn with the rankest prostitutes of the age.

title: DISSIDENTS GAIN IN OPPOSING PACT FOR MOZAMBIQUE
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 9  Jubilant white settlers and a coalition ofl black politicians strengthened their grip on this city today.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: How They Stand Today TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS

title: Polaroid to Offer LowPrice Version Of SX70 Camera
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9(Reuters)The Polaroid Car4poration said today it would introduce a lowerpriced version of its SX70 camera later this month. The instant  picture camera will have a list price or $149.95. The SX70 model now on the market lists for. $180.

title: Television
description: There will be special reports, on the primary elections on channel 2 at 10P.M. and on channel 13 at 11P.M. All other television stations will incorporate their coverage Into their regular newscasts.

title: $50,000 IN JEWELS STOLEN FROM HOTEL
description: A French tourist reported yesterday that a $30,000, 12carat diamond brooch and other jewels had been stolen from her room in the Summit Hotel, apparently while she was at Bear Mountain Sunday.

title: First School Day Is Quiet As Million Pupils Show Up
description: The academic year got off to a generally tranquil start yesterday in most of the city's 966 public schools as nearly 1.1 million pupils showed up, many of them buzzing with excitement.

title: BILINGUAL BALLOT ERRS IN SPANISH
description: The Spanish translation on today's primary ballot, the first bilingual ballot in the city's history, is so full of mistakes that Spanishspeaking voters may he confused or seriously misled by badly translated voting instructions that in one case say exactly the opposite of the English original.

title: Jaworski Aide Resigning In Apparent Nixon Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9A chief aide to Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, gave notice today that he was resigning in what was an apparent protest over the pardon given by President Ford to Richard M. Nixon.

title: Experts Assert Some Nixon Legal Problems Remain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The pardon President Ford gave Richard M. Nixon has not ended the former President's legal problems, but it may have indirectly improved the outlook for a number of his former associates, both in and out of prison.

title: People in Sports
description: John Matuszak, the 6foot8inch, 285pound defensive lineman, lost the first round yesterday in his bid to jump from the Houston Oilers of the National Football League to the Houston Texans of the World Football League. Judge Arthur Lesher, a Texas state district court judge, issued a temporary injunction in Houston prohibiting Matuszak from joining the W.F.L. Matuszak, the N.F.L.'s No. 1 draft choice in 1973, had left the Oilers and signed with the Texans on Aug. 28, contending his Oilers contract was invalid and that he was coerced into signing it.

title: Latest Rent Increases Here Displease Both Sides
description: Tenants of hundreds of thou sands of New York City apartments, many already hardpressed by inflation, are getting news these days that is hardly comforting: The rent is going up still more. Flowever, this does not necessarily please their landlords who often say that the increases are not enough. The news comes in different forms and at different times, depending on the category of apartment a tenant lives in.

title: Babe Sneva Injured
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 9(AP)Edsol (Babe) Sneva Jr., one of five brothers of a Northwest auto racing family, was in critical condition with a skull fracture here today following a stock car crash during a practice sessio at Cranbrook, B. C. His brothers include Tom Sneva, a United States Auto Club Championship, car and sprint driver who appeared in this year's Indianapolis 500.

title: The Political General
description: The news that Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. is expected to be recalled to active duty and appointed supreme commander of NATO should be disturbing to anyone concerned about keeping the Army out of politics and politics out of the Army. Without questioning in any way General Haig's qualifications for the job or his performance as White House chief of staff, his return to active duty in a high position in the Army would set a bad precedent.

title: Cuba's Backers in O.A.S. Cite Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Three LatinAmerican countries cited profound changes in the international situation in calling on the Organization of American States today to lift political and economic sanctions against Cuba.

title: CLASH ON WORDING
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 9Former President Nixon successfully beat back White House efforts to have him make a full and revealing statement of his role in the Watergate affair in conjunction with his pardon, reliable sources disclosed today.

title: Sadecki Wins for Mets, 71
description: The unhappy Mets, who continue to play winning ball although apparently too far out of contention to duplicate last season's miracle drive to the National League pennant, enjoyed easy pickings at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Japan Lashed by Typhoon; 13 Die and 24 Are Injured
description: TOKYO, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Thirteen persons died and 24have been injured in floods and landslides as a typhoon lashed southwestern Japan with heavy rain, the police said today.

title: TAKEOVER STUDY STARTED BY S.E.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Citing the growing amount of foreign money available to buy American companies and the depressed price of many corporate securities in the United States, the Securities and Exchange Commission today announced that it had begun an investigation of corporation takeovers.

title: TV: Girl Inmate Is Focus of Born Innocent Film.
description: NBCTV's World Premiere Movie is the latest addition 0 the roster of madeforTV Him slots. It begins tonight al 8 o'clock with Born Innocent, a twohour portrait 01 a detention home for young girls. The executive producers are Rick Rosenberg and Robert Christiansen, whose producing credits include, The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman. Their track record is impressive.

title: Public Advocate Files Suit On Civil Service Residency.
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9 (AP)The. Department of the Public Advocate filed suit today against a state regulation requiring 12month residency in New Jersey for eligibility to take a Civil Service test.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: BARBARGATE (Barbar), Monrovia Sept. 22, Tema 25, Lagos 28 and Douala Oct. 8; sails from Hamilton Ave., Brobklyn. RED JACKET (American Export), istanhul Sept. 27; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In a few hours Muhammad Ali would be off for Africa with 35 in his entourage.

title: TRIAL FOR PODELL BEGINS TOMORROW
description: The trial of Representative Bertram L. Podell of Brooklyn on charges of conspiracy, bribery, conflict of interest and perjury will begin tomorrow, the Federal judge in the case said yesterday.

title: Hidassah Head Denies Women Make Up Oppressed Minority
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9The head of Hadassah, the largest voluntary women's group in the country, sarply rejected today the concept that American women were an oppressed minority. She said they were a majority whose influence was being felt in the nation's political social welfare and cultural life.

title: MAJ. ROSE M'MAHON
description: Maj. Rose McMahon, mother of John F. McMahon, the commanderinchief of the Volunteers of America, a national social welfare organization, died yesterday at the home of her son at 12 Elaine Terrace, Yonkers. She was 92 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The death last, month of a key state witness led yesterday to the dismissal of criminal charges against four former Hudson County officials. Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Lamer dismissed the indictment when the Prosecutor's office said it was unable to proceed. The case fell apart on Aug. 26 with the death of John J. Marinan Sr., a Jersey City penal director.

title: McCrane Goes on Trial On Tax Charges Today
description: NEWARK, Sept 9The trial a; former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. on charges of tax fraud allegedly committed during the 1969 campaign of former. Gov. William T. Cahill is scheduled to begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court.

title: Pardon for Calley Sought
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 9(UPI) Representative Jack Brinkley, Democrat of Georgia will ask President Ford for an absolute and complete pardon for former first lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is serving a 10year prison sentence for the 1968 murder of South Vietnamese civilians at My Lai, Bob Fort, a press aide, said Mr. Brinkley would make the reguest because Mr. Ford had pardoned Richard M. Nixon.

title: Long Indian Trial. Has Altered Lives
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 8The Wounded Knee trial which goes to the jury here this week after more than eight months, has had a noticeable effect on the lives of more than a score of people.

title: Alex Johnson to Join Yankees Today as dh
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9  The New York Yankees today announced the acquisition of Alex Johnson, the 1970 American League batting champion, from the Texas Rangers. Johnson, a 31yearold outfielder, was used primarily as a designated hitter this season.

title: 6Man fury Named On Goldman's Role hi the Penn Central
description: A threeman, threewoman jury was selected here yesterday to decide whether Goldman, Sachs & Co., a leading dealer in promissory notes of major corporationscommonly known as commercial paper should be made to return $3million to three companies to whom it had sold conunercial paper in the Penn Central Transportation Company. The Penn Central filed bankruptcy proceedings on June 21, 1970.

title: Capital's Transit System Is Using New Concepts
description: WASHINGTONFive years after the groundbreaking for Metrothe capital area's 98mile rapid transit rail systemthe nearest thing to a subway train in the new tunnels is a strangelooking vehicle called the moon dog.

description: The Winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Senate Passes GreenAcres Bond Issue
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9  The State Senate today gave final egislative approval to a $200million greenacres bond issue the largest in the state's history.

title: Two White Groups Play Black Rhythm At the Bottom Line
description: Elvin Bishop and Average White Band, two white groups who opened at the Bottom Line, West Fourth Street on Sunday, are both locked firmly into black music. Mr. Bishop, from California, makes his music tough, having carefully assimilated the hard urban rhythm and blues form. It is heavy electric and eclectic blues that he plays and I Love My Baby Like a Groundhog Loves His Hole, one of his zoological numbers, shows that Mr. Bishop, who sings hoarsely and plays guitar intelligently, is hardly after refinement. Indeed Mr. Bishop's nickname, Pig Boy Crabshaw, underlines his earthy streak.

title: Ethiopia Says ExOfficial Blocked News of Famine
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 9 (Reuters).The former president of the lower house or Ethiopia's Parliament was accused today of having suppressed news of the famine last year in which some 100,000people died.

title: DISSIDENTS GAIN IN FIGHTING PACT ON MOZAMBIQUE
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 9  Jubilant white settlers and a coalition of black politicians strengthened their grip on this city today.

title: Minority Workers Win Job Preference in Layoff
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9 (AP)The Jersey Central Power and Light Company has been ordered by a Federal judge to protect newly hired minority workers in preference to union members with seniority, in a proposed layoff of 200 employes.

title: MONETARY RESERVES OF OIL NATIONS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Official monetary reserves held by nine oilproducing countries rose to $24.9billion in July from June's $22.7billion, according to International Monetary Fund statistics released today.

title: 26 Coast Guard Vessels Task: OutTack 1,500 Spectator Boats,
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 9Do not let them crowd you, a Coast Guard officer told his men today on the eve of their America's Cup patrol mission. If they start crowding you, just push em back.

title: Calcutta Father Frets About Inflation: Whom Can He Afford to Feed Today?
description: CALCUTTA, IndiaM. R. Sen Gupta recently faced difficult decision: Should his 2yearold child be given milk every day, or should it be given to his 73yearold father, who is a diabetic?

title: Teacher Strikes Continuing in 2 Nassau Districts
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 9Strikes by teachers in two Nassau County school districts continued today after uegotiatiops over the weekend failed o Itsolve contract disputes.

description: Persistence, as well as skill, plays an important role in successful fishing, and none knows this better than Dr. Einar F. Grell of New York.

title: Cabbies Mourn Slain Driver and Assail Public Apathy
description: More than 100 taxicab drivers gathered in Brooklyn yesterday to pay tribute to a murdered colleague and express outrage over what they regard as lack of public concern for their safety.

title: Business Briefs
description: A regional electricutility group in Pennsylvania and Ohio announced yesterday cancellation of one major generating station and postponement of six others one to two years. The five utilities known as the Central Area Power Coordination (CAPCO.) Group, said the Changes would mean a reduction of more than $700million in the.19751979 period.

title: William L. Nassau Jr., 78, Senior Tennis Winner in 42
description: William L. Nassau Jr., who won the United States National Senior Tennis championship at Forest Hills in 1942, died yesterday at his home in Paoli, Pa. He was 78 years old.

title: Verrazzano Welcomes First Freshmen
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 9Verrazzano College opened for its first, academic year here today with 42 students, eight fulltime faculty members; five buildings, two dormitories and a conviction that there is room in the Americans educational spectrum for an oldfashioned small liberal arts college.

title: New Indictments Expected In Fort Lee Bribery Inquiry
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Sept. 9This may not be another Carson City or Sacramento, but for almost two decades, this sleepy, slightly rundown town atop the Palisades has been as much of a bonanza to the right people as any mining town in the Old West.

title: Forego, 126, Top Weight In Marlboro
description: The weights assignments for the 11 horses in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park on Saturday were revealed yesterday by the New York Racing Association. Kenny Noe, At the the racing secretary and handiRace capper for the Tracks N.Y.R.A., made the assignments last week before departing for Paris where he planned to meet with European authorities on a revision of the scale of weights in thoroughbred competition.

title: RANDELL PLEADED GUILTY TO FRAUD
description: Cortes W. Randell, who created a campus marketing venture that captivated Wall Street in the nineteensixties, has quietly pleaded guilty to four counts of stock fraud, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Nadjari's Office Is Beset by a Dispute Over Jurisdiction in Goldman Inquiry
description: A dispute over whether the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, exceeded his jurisdiction in the handling of the investigation of the city Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Irving Goldman, has erupted in Mr. Nadjari's office.

title: Atoms for Peace?
description: The United States Government is reportedly threatening to stop delivery of uranium fuel to India unless New Delhi offers assurances that such Material will not be used for additional nuclear tests. Although the Atomic Energy Commission denies that any deliveries have actually been withheld thus far, the apparent new policy of denying nuclear aid to countries which fail to provide adequate guarantees against nuclear weapons development is long overdue.

title: Novel Written by Lindsay
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay has written a 300page manuscript of a political novel with a main character who is a handsome, Lindsayesque Congressman struggling to preserve civil liberties, wellplaced publishing informants said last night.

title: Dance: A Final Mixture
description: After a year's suspension The New York Dance Festival completed its 12th and eminently successful year at Delacorte Theater Sunday evening. Mime, ethnic, modern dance and ballet combined for the final program before a ftill and appreciative house.

title: Senate Backs First Copyright Reform in 65 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The Senate approved today the first revision of the United States copyright law since 1909 After killing proposed royalties for performing artists whose recordings are played on radio and jukeboxes.

title: Brazilian Enrolls
description: WICHITA, Kan. Sept. 9(UPI)Wichita State University today enrolled Milton Setrini, a member of the Brazilian national basketball team. Setrini, a Bfoot3inch 170pound guard, is starting as a freshman.

title: Nixon, Facing Possible Action, To Resign From California Bar
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. board 9 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon, faced with possible disciplinary action by the state bar of California, plans to resign his bar Membership Mr. soon, one of his attorneys said today.

title: Capital Gap Predicted for U.S.
description: The New York Stock Exchange predicted yesterday that the United States could fall short by about 8650billion in the funds it is expected to need between now and 1985 to pay for new homes, plants, transportation facilities and other major investments.

title: Weather Seen Just Right for First Race Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 9(AP)  Weather forecasters say tomorrow's weather should be warm, wtih moderate southwest winds and no predictable fog for the opening America's Cup race.

description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Two Arab guerrillas were sentenced today to life imprisonment by a military court for having planned a mass killing in two Haifa theaters last year.

title: Mob Figure Pleads Guilty to Contempt hi Garden Inquiry
description: James Napoli, reputed to be one of the five leading Mafia chieftains in the metropolitan area pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal contempt before a Manhattan grand jury that five years ago was investigating the fixing of fights at Madison Sgilare Garden.

title: Sugar Prices Soar Daily Limit On Effect of Hurricane Carmen
description: Fears that Hurricane Carmen might seriously damage the Louisiana canesugar crop sent world sugar futures soaring in London yesterday, where markets open earlier than in New York. Playing follow the leader, sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange jumped the daily 1cent limit yesterday in most delivery months.

title: U.S. INQUIRY BEGUN INTO T.W.A. CRASH
description: The Trans World Airlines jet that crashed off Greece Sunday had suddenly pitched upward and rocked its wings before plunging into the stormy waters of the Ionian Sea, according to initial reports from the pilot of another airliner.

title: Chess:
description: When it comes to opening traps, there is nothing more embarrassing than getting hoist with your own petard. That happened most grievously to a New York master, Nat Helper, in a celebrated game he contested with Frank Marshall, United States champion from 1909to 1936.

description: High Tides Around New York

title: Rodino Rejects Revival of Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Some Democrats in Congress sought today to reopen formal proceedings to impeach former President Richard M. Nixon, but Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, declared that impeachment is dead.

title: Knievel Leaves Idaho in a Controversy
description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 9Evel Knievel and his entourage left Idaho today, leaving this farming community to clean up the debris left fin his wake.

title: COMMODITIES BILL VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Senate passed a bill today to expand sharply Federal regulation of commodity futures trading, sometimes blamed for high grocery bills.

title: 52 Hospitalized by Banquet
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP)Fiftytwo persons who attended a weekend Little League banquet remained hospitalized today for treatment of food poisoning. In all, 109 persons were treated for severe diarrhea, vomiting and cramps after a banquet of Polish sausage, sauerkraut, chicken and ravioli in a southwest Chicago church yesterday afternoon.

title: PRESIDENT BOOED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 President Ford postponed today, his announcement of a plan to deal with VietnamWar draft evaders and deserters.

title: Panel Urges Curbs on Food Additives
description: An expert panel on nitrites and nitrates issued final recommendations to the Department of Agriculture yesterday, suggesting that these widely used food additives be restricted and in some cases banned,

title: 7 KILLED IN BLAZE AT HOME FOR AGED
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 9 (AP) (AP)Fire swept through a nursing home early today, killing six elderly women and the 11yearold son of the home's owners, the police said.

title: Advertising: Scaring Off Bears
description: Since the bears came out of hibernation and have been stalking the investment community it's not surprising that they've scared a number of securities firms into not advertising.

title: Pardon Me
description: I have your traffic ticket which was left on my automobile in August for a parking violation, said violation having occurred when I briefly left my car in a forbidden space while shopping for wine at Henry's package goods store near the Steamboat Wharf. Your ticket instructs me to remit payment of $5 in punishment, and would do so immediately were I not firmly persuaded that such punishment would constitute an injustice with which neither you nor the Town Selectmen wish to have your names forever linked in history.

title: Lindsay, Late Arrival, Can't Cast Vote Today
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay will be unable to vote in today's Democratic primary because he has not resided in his election district for the required 30 days.

title: Cop Art: Artistic Brush With Police
description: At first glance, it looked like the most heavily guarded art show in the city, As it turned out, however, the men and women in uniform were the artists themselves.

title: ELINOR GORDON, 54, CIVIC LEADER, DIES
description: Elinor L. Gordon, formerly president of the Citizens Committee for Children of New York and chairman of the State Department's Conference on Racism and American Education, died Sunday at Sloan; Kettering Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 54 years old and lived at 733 Park Avenue.

title: Stockton, Graebner Gain at Net
description: CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Sept. 9Thirdseeded Dick Stockton of Dallas demonstrated today that he possesses an excellent memory as well as a good tennis game. He defeated Butch Seewagen of Bayside, Queens, 61, 62 in the first round of the Perspectus Tennis Classic at the Bradford Bath and Beach Club.

title: KENNEDY JEERED ON BOSTON BUSING
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9Senator Edward M. Kennedy was driven from the speakers stand of an antischoolbusing rally here today as he sought to calm hostile, booing crowd of parents.

title: CLASH HIGHLIGHTS ROME SLUM ISSUES
description: ROME, Sept. 9Rioting in a suburb in the last few days has heightened tensions in the slum belt that rings Rome, laid City Hall open to charges of sloppy administration and widened the rift between the Communist party and militant ultraleftist groups.

title: Special Phones to Take VoteLaw Violations
description: Special election telephone numbers, both for general information and for reporting violations of Federal election laws, have been set up for voters in today's primary.

title: Honorable Withdrawal
description: Jerald F. terHorst's abrupt departure from the Ford Administration is a refreshing throwback to a simpler time in American political life. First of the President's appointees, Mr. terHorst chose to give up a new and heady job as White House press secretary rather than to temporize with his principles.

title: Mormon Avoids Question on Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter  day Saints did not answer today when asked at a news conference when the Mormons might change their exclusionary practices toward blacks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Persons concerned with the environment would do worse than to pause for a moment and reflect upon some of the notsonice consequences of their activities. We have reached a point when intelligent people address themselves to the question whether trees have rights. Before environmentalists worry too much about the status of trees, it might be morally profitable to pause and ask ourselves whether we have first taken into account the rights of all our people to obtain for themselves a decent habitat.

title: Seoul Halts AntiJapan March; 15 Protesters Cut OH Fingers
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 9(Reuters)  Policemen firing teargas shells today blocked an attempt by angrydemonstrators to march on the Japanese Embassy.

title: 2 Girls Seized. After Fire In City Children's Center
description: Two 15yearold girls living in the Children's Center at Fifth Avenue and East 104th Street were arrested yesterday and charged with having set fire Sunday night to a thirdfloor dormitory at the center.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TROUBLED LENS Cornell Capa's photo essays are well known to anyone who has read Life magazine. He is considered one of the significent figures in the photographic documentation of war, poverty and the problems of humanity. His pictures force the viewer not simply to be impressed by the photographer's skill, but also to be moved to do something about violence and degradation.

title: Giants Welcome Back Ron Johnson, Say Goodby to Williams, Among Others
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 9Ron Johnson worked out with the New York Giants for the first time, but Willie Williams said his final farewell after being cut by the National Football League team.

title: ISRAEL'S PREMIER SEES FORD TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Pre. Inlet Yitzhak Rabin of Israel will arrive tomorrow for consultations with President Ford and other officials that, the United States hopes, will accelerate the pace of ArabIsraeli negotiations toward a Middle East settlement.

title: Reports of Nixon Ill Health Are Questioned by Visitors
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Several persons who have recently visited former President Richard M. Nixon cast doubt today on reports that he is in poor health, one of the reasons cited by President Ford yesterday in granting Mr. Nixon an unconditional pardon.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ADVANCES BY 0.9%
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 7 edged ahead by 0.9 per cent to 2,673,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 109.6, compared with 108.6a week earlier when a total of 2,649,000 tons were poured.

title: Left Scores Slight Gain In San Marino Election
description: SAN MARINO, Sept. 9(Reuters)  The Communists and Socialists of San Marino, the world's smallest Republic, made slight gains in yesterday's general election at the expense of the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats. Each of those two parties lost two seats.

title: Rethinking Amnesty
description: While tens of thousands of draft evaders, deserters and veterans with undesirable discharges from the Vietnam war live in limbo, President Ford has indefinitely postponed consideration of their cases because of his preoccupation with the case of one private individual, Richard M. Nixon, and the backlash that this untimely pardon has caused in the country.

title: Israeli Says Syria Flouts Troop Pact
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 9 Israel charged today that Syria had advanced her frontline positions on the Golan Heights into the United Nations buffer zone between the Israeli and Syrian lines.

title: Lordi Expands Inquiry Into Newark Disturbances
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9The Essex County Prosecutor, Joseph; P. Lordi, said today he was substantially expanding the investigation of disturbances that grew out of a clash between the police and members of city's Hispanic community last week.

title: EXCHILEAN AIDE HELD IN DRUG CASE
description: A former narcotics chief of Chile's Federal police was charged here yesterday with accepting more than $500,000in an alleged conspiracy to smuggle cocaine into the United States.

title: Rodino Rejects Revival of Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Some Democrats in Congress sought today to reopen formal proceedings to impeach former President Richard M. Nixon, but Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, declared that impeachment is dead.
