title: F.T.C. Alleges 5 Store Chains Bilked ChargeAccount Holders
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Government charged today that five department  store chains with New York stores had bilked their Chargeaccount customers out of more than $2.8million.

title: Indians Down Red Sox, Stay in Race
description: Gaylord Perry kept the Cleveland Indians in contention last night, as the 35yearold righthander stopped the slumping Boston Red Sox on five hits in a 31 victory. It was the Indians fourth straight and they remained within striking distance in the Eastern Division race.

title: BRITISH PROPOSE PENSION BEFORE
description: LONDON, Sept. 11  The Labor party Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson today proposed sweeping pension reforms and increased Government spending on construction.

description: More than 350 lawyers struck, the Legal Aid Society here yesterday, forcing postponements of hundreds of trials or ings in the Criminal Court and the State Supreme Court.

title: City Investigating Death After Treatment at Jacobi
description: The death of a 22  year  old Bronx mother within hours after she was sent home from the Jacobi Hospital emergency room is being investigated by the city Mecijcal Examiner and the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: RESPONSE IS GOOD FOR TAXEXEMPTS
description: Three new competitive offerings in the taxexempt market yesterdayfrom Maryland, Alaska and Nassau County, L.I. were given an apparently cordial reception by investors. The largest offering was Maryland's $85million of various purpose bonds, rated triple A, which were won by underwriters headed by the First National City Bank. Reoffered at prices yielding from 5.5 per cent in 1977 to 6 per cent in 1989, the Maryland bonds were reportedly sold down to a balance of $31million yesterday afternoon.

title: Pardon for 2 Aides Reportedly Sought In Last Nixon Days
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Diking President Nixon's last days in office, his former chief assistants, facing trial in the Watergate case, reportedly made a vain appeal to the White House for executive clemency.

title: Pathet Lao Reported Ready To Free American P.O.W.
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Thursday, Sept. 12 (AP)Informed diplomatic sources said today that the Pathet Lao pledged it would free pilot Emmet J. Kay of Hawaii, the last American firmly known to be a prisoner of wa rin. Indochina as part of general exchange next Thursday.

title: Brothers on Fight Card
description: A pair of brother acts have been lined up for next Monday night's boxing card at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden. In a pair of eightrounders, Frankie Benitez of San Juan, Puerto Rico, will meet Bobby Hughes of New. York City in a lightweight match and Wilfredo Benitez will meet Bobby's twin brother, Al, in a welterweight bout.

title: C. ROY MORTIMER
description: C. Roy Mortimer, who had been an agent of the Travelers Insurance Company for 50 years, heading his own company, C. Roy Mortimer, Inc., of New York, died Monday at his home, 7 Shore Road, Old Greer wich, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: TRIAL OPENS for AIDE TONEY
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11Alderman Thomas F. Keane, the secondranking leader of the Cook County Democratic organization, went on trial today in, Federal District Court on charges of mail fraud and conspira cy.

title: MERTON Y. GLANT
description: Merton Y. Giant, regional public affairs officer for the North Atlantic Region of the Internal Revenue Service, died Sunday of cancer at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 45 years old and lived at 27 Morewood Place, Port Washington, L. I.

title: ATHENS'S PULLOUT ACCEPTED BY NATO
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 11  Secretary General Joseph M.A.H. Luns of The North Atlantic, Treaty. Organization said today, after a meeting with Foreign Minister George Mavros of Greece, that he had accepted as final the Greek decision to pull out of th military structure of NATO.

title: Winners: AntiEstablishment Democrats
description: It was a bad day for the Democratic party establishment on Primary Day. Representative Hugh L. Carey and three other statewide candidates demonstrated that a candidate does not have to be antiorganization to win, but it sure helps.

title: San Antonio Man to Plead Guilty In Death of Bride on Honeymoon
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 11 (UPI)Claudius James Giesick, 26 years old, of San Antonio, accused of plotting the death of his New Jersey bride while honeymooning in New Orleans, will plead guilty to manslaughter and testify against an alleged accomplice in the case, according to Mr. Glesick's lawyer.

title: Exchange Membership Is Sold for $66,000
description: A New York Stock Exchange membership was sold yesterday for $66,000, down $9,000 from the last sale on Aug. 28 and the lowest price since Oct. 21, 1957.

title: Ford Pledges More Job Funds In a Blunt Session With Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 President Ford, opening a blunt giveandtake discussion with the nation's most powerful labor leaders, said today that he was taking immediate action to make more Federal money available for public service employment.

title: Contract Award
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received a $100million order from the Taiwan Power Company. Involved are two 950,000watt nuclear reactor systems, plus nuclear fuel, for a new generating station to be built on the southern tip of the Nationalist Chinese island. The initial unit is expected to be operational in April, 1981. The order brings the number to 110 of Westinghouse reactor systems in operation, under construction or on order.

description: More than 350 lawyers struck the Legal Aid Society here yesterday, forcing postponements of hundreds of trials or hearings. The State Supreme Court's Appellate Division threatened to recommend dismissals and barassociation penalties. Page 76.

description: PARIS, Sept. 11  For the first time since Valery Giscard d'Estaing became President of France three months ago, one of his spectaculars has been greeted with irreverent guffaws instead of respectful applause.

description: In a frank appraisal of the state of the Roman Catholic Church in the modern world, Pope Paul VI yesterday conceded that the church is in difficulty. At his weekly general audience, held in the courtyard of his summer residence in Castel Gandolfo, south of Rome, the Pontiff said:

title: Fluoridation on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (UP1)  The City Council adopted today; 105, a controversial measure to fluoridate the city's water supply. A spokesman for the council said it would tie two years before the water supply was completely fluoridated.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Utility representatives asserted that unless legislation proposed by Mayor Beame to insure the safety of storing liquefied natural gas was amended to exempt their existing operating facilities, customers might face a hard, cold winter. They were testifying before the City Council's Public Safety Committee.

description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 11Jim Del Gaizo is convinced that being traded to the New York Giants couldn't have worked out better for me.

description: Oozing confidence, the winners of the state Democratic primary laid plans yesterday to campaign as a team and began the ritual that is likely to lead to Liberal party nominations for the top of their ticket.

title: Bill Proposes Bank to Help Revitalize Depressed Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI))Legislation to create a Federal domestic development bank to foster the growth of depressed urban and rural areas was proposed today by Senators Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Thomas J. Mclntypre, Democrat of New Hampshire.

title: R. D. MAZZARRINI, 68; EXAIRLINE OFFICER
description: Richard D. Mazzarrini, a former airline and hotel industry executive, died Tuesday in Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 68 years old.

description: There's a general attitude in this city that trees don't count for anything  as though they weren't even alive.

title: City Consumer Aide Bids U.S. Consider Subsidy for Staples
description: Food prices have risen so sharply that consumer subsidies for such staples as rice, milk and wheat may be needed to help moderate and lowincome consumers, according to Elinor C. Guggenheimer, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

title: WILLOWBROOK AIDES TARGET OF PROTEST
description: A group of parents of retardates at the Willowbrook State School held a protest there yesterday during which they alleged that a number of employes with criminal backgrounds had threatened and intimidated other members of the staff.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Rain and thundershowers may develop today from the Northeast and lower lake region across the Ohio and Misssissippi. Valleys to the Central Plains States; cloudy skies will continue westward into the central Rockies. It will be warm and humid throughout the East; from southern New England to the Gulf Coast, and warm across the South and along the Pacific Coast. Cool temperatures will spread from the upper half of the Mississippi Valley to the northern half of the Rockies and the northern plateau region. Fair to partly cloudy skies and or mild conditions will prevail elsewhere.

title: Massachusetts Democrats Optimistic on Governorship
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11Massachusetts Democrats said today they saw the best chance in a decade of regaining the Governor's office with the nomination of Michael S. Dukakis, a 40yearold lawyer and the legislative sponsor of the state's nofault automobile insurance law, the first in the nation.

title: Barkum Is Healthy, Rusty and Eager for Jets Opener
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 11 When Jerome Barkum plays wide receiver for the Jets, he's the target for Joe Namath's passes and for defensive backs ferocious tackles. Sometimes, though, Barkum makes other people his targets, as when he pours water on them from 10 floors up in the Hofstra University dormitory.

title: MERGER OF CERRO AND MARMON SET
description: The Cerro Corporation, a company engaged in mining, realestate development and trucking with assets of more than $250million, has agreed to merge with the Marmon Group, Inc. (Michigan) into a cornMerger party that will be News named the CerroMarmon Corporation, Cerro announced yesterday. Under terms of an agreement in principle, 6.5 million shares of new CerroMarmon Class A common stock will be issued to the GL Corporation, owner of 100 per cent of the equity interest in Marmon. In return, GL will cancel its present holdings of Marmon capital stock.

description: The Brooklyn Congressional delegation, whose members, once wielded more power in Washington than those of any other area of the State, will be radically altered in January as a result of Tuesday's primary.

description: MIAMI, Sept. 11 (UPI) While the tropical storm called Elaine veered farther from land, a tropical depression skirting the northern coast of the Dominican Republic threatened today to become the season's sixth storm.

description: More than 400 magazineadvertising salespeople and super salespeople (publishers) applauded frequently yesterday as Alvin Hempel of Benton & Bowles delivered a paean to print. It's the kind of thing they like to hear.

title: ETHENIC GERMANS SEEK SOVIET EXIT
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11 They come from a minority group that Moscow considers Soviet citizens, but they insist that their true homeland lies beyond the Soviet borders. And to get there, they have increasingly turned to public appeals, hunger strikes and demonstrations despite official reprisals.

title: STUDY IS DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11President Ford is not giving consideration to blanket antnesty or pardons for the Watergate defendants, spokesmen for the President said today.

description: Barely 12 hours after claiming his victory as Democratic nominee for United States Senate, Ramsey Clark attacked his Republican opponent, Senator Jacob K. Javits, demanding that the Senator go to the White House, to President. Ford and demand that he abide by the rule of law whatever the consequences.

title: VICTOR I. CRAIG
description: Victor I. Craig, an advertising sales and promotion man with magazines for some 40 years at his retirement in 1964, died yesterday in a Westchester nursing home. He was 78 years old and lived at 8 Midland Gardens, Bronxville, N.Y.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Congress that went away last month heaving sighs of relief returned in force today to find that Watergate had not gone away.

title: Advance in Soybean, Corn and Oats Near Limits
description: Heavy buying as a result of expectations that a Department of Agriculture report, issued after the close, might show a decrease in the size of crops plus concern about a possible frost in the corn belt this week, sent gain prices up sharply yesterday in heavy buying on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: I.D. Cards for School Employes Weighed in New Security Plan
description: To tighten security in the city's schools, top officials of the system have drawn up plans to require the Board of Education's 144,000 employes, including about 65,000 teachers and 5,000 school supervisors, to carry identification cards with their photographs and finger prints.

title: Byrne Weighs State Help to Utilities In Building PowerGenerating Plants
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11Governor Byrne said today that he was considering proposing legislation that would create state authority to finance the construction of powergenerating facilities in New Jersey.

description: ATHENS, Sept. 11  Any withdrawal of American, flu clear weapons froth Greece would hurt relations between Washington and Athehs, just at a point when they were starting to show a slight improvement, an authoritative Government source said tonight.

title: CHRYSLER PLANS 8.5%o PRICE RISE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11  The Chrysler Corporation said today it was raising prices of 1975 model carsby an average of 8.5 per cent, or $400, and the American Motors Corporation said it was posting tentative 1975 model prices showing an increase averaging 7.7 per cent, or $300.

description: Birgit Nilsson will open the New Jersey State Opera Company's season on Nov. 10 in the leading role of Puccini's Turandot in a benefit performance at Newark's Symphony Hall, it was announced yesterday.

title: Miss Cooperstein Gains
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12A pair of former metropolitan champions, Judy Cooperstein of the host club, and Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of St. George's, moved into the 36hole final of the fifth women's Long Island match play championship today over the par72, 5,963yard Glen Oaks Club red and white courses. In their semifinal tests today, Miss Cooperstein defeated Mrs. Karl Clement of Nassau Country Club, 2 up, and Mrs. Dempsey eliminated Mrs. Sanford Goldvier of Cold Spring, 5 and 4.

title: ELIZABETH F. BROWN
description: Elizabeth Fincke Brown, a member of the immigration and naturalization assistance section of the continuing education department of the Stamford public schools, died Wednesday of heart attack, while visiting relatives in Lebanon, Pa. She was 46 years old and lived at 242 Cedar Wood Road, Stamford.

description: Mayor Beame, saying he was very alarmed at skyrocketing municipal costs and fading revenues, yesterday ordered review of spending by city departments that could cause cutbacks in lowpriority programs and the loss of some jobs.

title: The Lion at Sunset
description: Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, who has been wielding nearly absolute power longer than any other living head of state, was gradually stripped of all of his prerogatives over the last six months by an anonymous group of army captains and majors, and has lately been leading a ghostlike existence.

title: Mets Tour of Japan Will Cost About $2Million
description: The Metropolitan Opera's tour of Japan next spring will cost about $2million, and tickets to its performances there will be priced from $23 to $53.

title: Murphy's 65 Leads World Open Field
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 12 Pudgy Bob Murphy, back on the tour after an absence of four months with an injured left thumb, told himself this morning he would be happy with a 69 or 70 in the opening round of the World open. With the good feeling that comes from putting welleight oneputt greensMurphy outdid himself to shoot a 34, 3165 to take a onestroke lead over Don Iverson, a journeyman whose best finish this year has been a tie for 12th.

title: Storm Threats Subside
description: MIAMI, Sept. 12 (AP)Tropical storm Elaine moved farther into the North Atlantic today. Forecasters said it posed no threat to land. The National Hurricane Center said a tropical depression that had caused heavy showers over eastern Cuba would continue to diminish as it moves westward.

description: NEWS INDEX

title: New Hospital Is Requested
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 12 (AP) Officials at Cooper Hospital have asked the state for permission to construct a new facility instead of continuing a $32million renovation. Administrator W. Herman Jenkins said the construction of a new facility would take three years, considerably less than the 10 years required for renovation, and would cost about the same.

title: RUGBY RESULTS
description: Redruth 15, Truro 3.

title: Ford Presents Congress With Priority List for Action
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 President Ford presented Congress today with his priority list for action before the Congressional term expires in a few weeks, a list that some on Capitol Hill found noteworthy for its omissions as well as its contents.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate yesterday formally approved the nominations of Shirley Temple Black to be Ambassador to Ghana and John Sherman Coopers the former Senator, to be the first United States Ambassador to East Germany. It also approved Kenneth Rush, economic coordinator for former President Richard M. Nixon, as Ambassador to France, and Philip C. Habib, a career foreign service officer, as Assistant Secretary of State. Senator Hugh Scott, the Republican from Pennsylvania, was particularly pleased with the nomination of Mrs. Black, who as a child movie star sailed on the good ship Lollipop, to be an officer on the ship of state. She has been successful in transferring her skills from the screen to the arena of public service, said Mr. Scott, and since her nomination to the post in Ghana, which she has never visited, she has steeped herself in the problems of Africa and Ghana.

title: Festival of Tennis Opens Tonight
description: A Festival of Tournaments, with leading men and women tennis players from the East competing, begins tonight at the Port Washington (LI.) Tennis Academy. There will be a total of 38 tournaments, all indoors on weekend nights, in men's singles, women's singles, men's doubles, women's doubles, men's 35 and mixed doubles. Poin's will be awarded in all events, with a top prize of $1,000 for the men and $500 for the women.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lincoln Hospital, a 65yearold municipal institution serving the south Bronx, has been stripped of its accreditation by a national commission that found what physicians termed shocking conditions of overcrowding and inadequate facilities.

title: New Books
description: A FarOff Place by Laurens van der Post (Morrow,. $7.95). A bushman and his wife help two young whites escape terrorists in South Africa.

title: Washington Policy On Cyprus Assailed
description: ATHENS, Sept. 12A New York Congressman, Benjamin S. Rosenthal, today strongly criticized United States policies, in the eastern Mediterranean, declaring that Washington shares responsibility for the crisis in Cyprus.

title: Screen: 'Miller Odyssey':Documentary Focuses On Life of Writer
description: Today, Henry Miller's name triggers a reflexyou can't disassociate it from the gleeful humiliation of the women in his books. But Robert Snyder's excellent 1969 documentary, "The Henry Miller Odyssey," illustrates that Mr. Miller has far more to offer a contemporary audience than his sexual politics (which aren't reflected in this movie). The film is playing today and tomorrow at the First Avenue Screening Room. Don't miss itif you care at all about writers or writing, it will ralse your morale.In many fascinating flashbacks, the movie details a writer's apprenticeship on the road from Brooklyn to Big Sur, while Mr. Miller narrates in his hoarse, nasal voice. In high school, he volunteered that his vocation might be clowningan impulse that's recalled when we see him (aged 78) laughing at his own long, rubbery face in a mirror. Early on, he worked in his father's tailor's shop, then became the employment manager of Western Union, and edited the catalogue of a mail-order house. Then he quit all jobs to write: "I walked up Broadway feeling like the happiest man on earth"since he planned to be his own boss forever. "Then began 10 years of misery"when he doubted his ability and couldn't sell his workfollowed by the exhilaration of Paris, "where I found my voice," which surfaced in "Tropic of Cancer."Although Mr. Miller scorns all conventional work and celebrates play, a sense of his own enormous industry surges through the film. He also exults over the freedom that youthful poverty can give a writerwhile the camera ogles windows full of succulent French food that he couldn't afford in the thirties. It was invigorating to have "no crutch of any kind," to learn to be "a bird of prey, an animal." Though he stresses his lifelong interest in the occult, his worship of the arts, and his studies of dreams, his romanticism is usually cut with comedyit's rather as though Huck Finn had been an urban esthete.The movie jumps most skillfully between past and present, between California and France. At one moment, the writer is treading water and talking about his mother, who consulted him (aged 4) about having a wart removed. She got blood poisoning and blamed him for itfor which he never forgave her. Soon, he's cheerfully discussing suicide with Lawrence Durrell. Both agree that it was much more tempting when they were young.There are fond visits with his old friends, including Anais Nin. He also reads a very moving passage about a favorite relative, an aunt who lost her mind. As an adolescent, he had to take her to the asylum; on that journey, she saw blue and green cows, whose names she knew. His rage at the society that insisted on confining her sounds like fuel for his future rebellions.In the last shot, Mr. Miller vanishes on a bicycle. All in all, he has some of the gaiety that Yeats attributed to sages, and it's a privilege to see it on the screen.

description: Foreign Exchange

description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: Owens Tops Solomon at Jersey Net
description: CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Sept. 12Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., seeded second and regarded by many as the United States's best clay court player, was defeated by Charles Owens of Houston, Tex., here tonight, 3.6, 63, 76, in the second round of the Perspectus Tennis Classic on the clay courts of the Bradford Bath and Tennis Club.

title: SHELLERGLOBE TO ACQUIRE VLN
description: Approval of the shareholders of the ShellerGlobe Corporation and the VLN Corporationat separate meetings yesterday has cleared the way for ShellerGlobe to acquire VLN through an exchange of stock valued at Merger about $25million. News Both companies manufacture equipment for the automobile industry and ShellerGlobe makes office supplies, special car bodies and motor homes.

title: Yankees Down Orioles, 30, Lead by 2 as Wallace Stars
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12Storming the field as if they had just swept to a World Series victory, the Yankees swatted one another on the back tonight in celebrating a 3.0 decision over the Orioles.

title: Soviet Plans to Test Hardware in Flight Before Joint Shot
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)The Soviet Union has expanded its commitment, for next July's joint AmericanRussian space flight to include a full dress rehearsal in orbit, the chief of Soviet astronaut training said yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A New Jersey wholesale gasoline distributor charged yesterday that the Mobil Oil Corporation and seven other major petroleum companies were trying to drive him out of business, allegedly by limiting the amount of gasoline that the distributor and other independents could receive. The suit was filed in Federal Court by the Mien Oil Company, Union, against Mobil, from which the company has received 10 million gallons of gasoline and other petroleum products yearly for the last five years.

title: Radio
description: 910 A.M., WNCN. On Hearing the First Cuckoo in Spring, Delius; Cockaigne Overture, Eiger; Hary Janos Suite, Kodaly.

title: Group Health Purchases The McGrawHill Building
description: Group Health, Inc., a medical insurance concern, has purchased the former McGrawHill Building, which has been vacant for about three years, for $5.5million.

title: TAX BREAK ASKED TO HELP HOUSING
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 12A coalition of industry groups affected by the severe depression in housing construction and sales presented to skeptical Government officials today a ninepoint rescue program.

title: President Urges More Saigon Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12President Ford appealed personally to Congressional leaders today to restore the hundreds of millions of dollars cut from the Administration's foreign aid roiliest for South Vietnam and the rest of Indochina.

title: Jersey Bell Denied Interim Rate Rise; Sought $40Million
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12  The Board of Public Utility Commissioners rejected today a request by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company for an interim rate increase of $40.7million on the ground that the utility had failed to prove it was in financial difficulty.

title: Nixon Pardon Lightens a Sentence Here
description: A Federal judge canceled prison sentence for a tax evader yesterday because of the Presidential pardon for former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: GERMAN LEADER TO VISIT SOVIET
description: BONN, Sept. 12Chancellor Helmut Schmidt will break with tradition and go to Moscow at the end of October to meet the Soviet leaders before having met with the United States President, Foreign Minister HansDietrich Genscher said last night.

title: Unfamiliarity With Cup Course Breeds Challenger's Contempt
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 12 We expect to win this Cup.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A middle ground between wageprice controls and the upward spiraling of wages and prices should be explored. The use of price anchors is a middle ground which has not yet been advocated or explored in the current discussions about policies to meet inflation.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has been awarded a $31.3million Navy contract for procurement of P3 aircraft.

title: Fishing in Local Waters Is Reported as Excellent
description: AREA. AFishing off the New Jersey shore generally is excellent. Blues, school tuna, bonita, sea bass, porgies and fluke are being taken in sizable numbers. Capt. John Bogan Sr. of the Manasquan Inlet fleet reports that blues, tuna and bonita are being found particularly at the Klondike and the Mohawk about seven miles southeast of Brielle. They seem mostly interested in smelts and butterfish and are being captured by drifting as well as anchored boats. Inshore, bottom fish are being seen from Seaside to Spring Lake by drifters using smelt, squid and spearing. There are still some blues off Barnegat Light but apparently there are many more near the end of Barnegat Ridge and north of it.

title: About New York
description: The matter of accent is once again emerging as one of the most utterable excesses of the political campaign that has already begun. Ramsey Clark has received the Democratic nomination for Senator and we will, in our finest tradition, have an outoftown tongue, this time an authentic Texas twang, to make a pitch for our ears.

title: SAFIRE MANUSCRIPT CALLED DEFICIENT
description: William Morrow & Co, explained at an arbitration hearing yesterday why it had rejected as unacceptable William Safire's manuscript of A Hurry to Be Great a book based on his experiences as an aide to President Nixon.

title: Chenault Sentenced to Die Nov. 8 in Church Murder of Mrs. King
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 12Marcus Wayne Chenault, 23 years old, was convicted today and sentenced to die in the electric chair for the murder last June 3 of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., mother of the slain civil rights leader.

title: Chile's Junta After a Year: Unrelenting Dictatorship
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12A year after the coup d'etat that overthrew the freely elected minority Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, the military junta that took power has strengthened its hold over Chile and appears determined to continue its repressive, authoritarian political style and conservative, austere economic policies.

title: Brazil Deplores U.S. Move
description: RIO DE JANIERO, Sept. 12Brazil formally condemned today the United States decision to impose stiff duties on Brazilian footwear.

title: CONCERN BY INDIA ON C.I.A. RELATED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Daniel P. Moynihan, ambassador to India, has privately warned Secretary of State Kissinger that recent reports of Central Intelligence Agency activities in Chile have confirmed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's worst suspicions and genuine fears about American policy toward India.

title: CLASSIFIED
Television
National City Bank Receives Permission, For Franklin Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12(UPI) The Justice Department disclosed today that it had given the first National City Bank permission to participate in any plans the financially troubled Franklin National Bank has for selling outstanding loans and commitments.

title: New Delhi Is Blamed for the Worsening Food Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 11Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and he advisers have come under in creasingly bitter criticism as a result of the intensifying food crisis in India.

description: New York 34, Portland 15. Memphis 46, Birmingham 7. Detroit 15, Florida 14. Hawaiians 24, Houston 17. Philadelphia 41, Jacksonville 22 (overtime). Southern California 31, Chicago 28.

title: Duryea Critical of Assembly Democrats
description: UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 12Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly Speaker, began an assault on the Democrats today identifying them as feeders of inflation, in an effort to keep them from gaining, majority power in the November elections.

title: Suit Challenges Demonstration Ban
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12  The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey filed a classaction suit in Federal District Court today contending that state statute under which Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson has banned all street demonstrations here is unconstitutional.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IN THE CARDS The invention of the postcard has changed the way travelers think of their travels, probably. What other vehicle is there for the disjointed non sequiturs we come to associate with friends abroad too busy to write real letters. Now we're told that the postcardis an art form, as well, which should not come as a surprise to New Yerkers, who know from experience that works of art begin at their doorsteps and end on subwalls.

title: Other Cabbies Help Hunt Thief Who Bilked Visitors
description: The taxicab driver who swindled three young nonEnglish  speaking visitors from Mexico of $167 for a ride from Kennedy International Airport to the Upper. West Side on Wednesday is known as the Thief to his fellow cab drivers. They say he prowls the airport seeking out LatinAmerican arrivals whom he sizes up as uneducated or inexperienced firsttime visitors to New York.

title: Ford and Israeli Leader, Weigh Next Step in Talks With Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12President Ford and Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel agreed today that further progress was necessary to maintain momenJuin for a Middle East settlement, but they left open whether Israel should negotiate next with Egypt, Jordan or both of them.

title: VIOLENCE MARS BUSING IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12  Rockthrowing, jeering crowds in South Boston marred the start today of a busing program designed to integrate Boston's public schools, and tonight Mayor Kevin H. White banned any gatherings in the streets of the troubled section.

title: JAY S. HARRISON, 47, MUSIC EDITOR, DEAD
description: Jay S. Harrison, music editor of The New York Herald Tribune from 1948 to 1960, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 47 years old and lived at 741 West End Avenue.

title: Japanese Exports at Record
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Japanese exports last month rose a record 70.3 per cent compared with August, 1973, the Trade and Industry Ministry said today. Revised Ministry figures, based on export declarations, showed the value of the country's exports was 5,42million.

title: Bridge:
description: If there was a prize for the best defensive play of the year. Steve Goldberg of Marietta, Ga., would be a strong candidate for it. He would submit the diagramed deal, played in the recent Internation Team Trials in Washington.

title: Another March Takes 2 Classes
description: GREENVALE, L.1., Sept. 12 Harry Gill's Another March did double duty at the Nassau County Horse Show today and, with Rod Jenkins riding, captured two classes in two divisions.

title: Altering of Smith Work Stirs Dispute
description: Clement Greenberg, the renowned art critic who also an executor of the estate of David Smith, an artist regarded by many experts as the greatest of American sculptors, acknowledged yesterday that he had personally authorized changes in the visual appearance of certain Smith sculptures aftter the artist's death in 1965.

title: Farewell to the Lion
description: It was an inglorious end to an absolute rule that had endured nearly six decades, a poignant exit for the wisp of an Emperor who once had jabbed at the conscience of the world, and whowhatever his shortcomingshad in recent years provided direction and leadership and counsel for the struggling new nations of his continent.

title: BEAME AND GOLDIN IGNORE EACHOTHER
description: Mayor Beanie and Controller Harrison J. Goldin met at a Board of Estimate hearing yesterday for the first time since their feud over municipal accounting practices began two months ago, and sat next to each other for 20 minutes without speaking or otherwise acknowledging the other's presence.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BALTIMORE (AL)Purchased Tim Nordbrook, Infielder, from Rochester of the International League.

title: Rothko Trial Is Ofi to Sept. 23; Judge Urges All Sides to Settle
description: Trial of a suit to recover millions of dollars worth of Mark Rothko paintings, and to dismiss executors of the abstract expressionist's will, has been adjournd in Surrogate's Court until Sept. 23.

title: NIXON'S PHLEBITIS IN LEG WORSEN
description: Former President Richard IV Nixon is suffering from spreading phlebitis in his lef leg that apparently has wor sened since last Sunday, whe lie was pardoned by Presiden Ford. But the emotional state Mr. Nixon is not known.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell slightly to 229.6 from 230.6 last week.

title: Housing and Inflation
description: Industry Fears Both Rising. Prices And Efforts to Curb Those Prices

title: JAVITS SEES A NEED TO OUTSPEND CLARK
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that because of his very extensive record, which my opponent does not have, he had no recourse except to outspend Ramsey Clark, the Democratic nominee, in the Senatorial election campaign this year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Local School authorities shut down a Bronx elementary school yesterday for the second time since the fall, term began on Monday in the face of a continued parent boycott over allegedly hazardous physical conditions.

title: Secret War on Chile
description: On the very day that President Ford extended preventive pardon to Richard Nixon, another high crime of the Nixon Administration was being disclosed in The New York Times. Public outrage because of the pardon must not be allowed to obscure this sordid story of indefensible American intervention in the internal affairs of Chile, in the years just before the violent overthrow of the Allende Government and the death of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Market Place:Wall st. Viwed  Edson Gould
description: The stock market took another battering yesterday and according to Edson Gould, things are going to get worse on Wall Street before they get better. Mr. Gould's views are worth considering, inasmuch as he is one of a handful of market analysts who have been pretty much on target during the disastrous decline of the last year.

title: Wallace Donations Exceed $1Million For Campaign Use
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has raised and spent more than $1million this year to prepare fora possible4un for the White Hotise in 1976, his finance reporti show.

title: Brick Township Selling City Hall for $1Million
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 12 (AP)For sale: One Town Hall, complete with offices, a host of unusual features, and a fully equipped municipal court. Included, at no extra charge, is a 21acre tract. Asking $1 million, but willing to negotiate.

title: F.T.C. Accepts Agreement. On Ward Collection Cases
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday in Washington that it has provisionally accepted an agreement directing Montgomery Ward, a division of Marcor, Inc., to bring account collection cases in courts close to where its customers reside.

title: Baseball's Longest Night Ends. 3 Hours Before Sunrise at Shea
description: For all those anxious wives and mothers who telephoned Shea Stadium in the early morning hours yesterday, asking if there was a curfew on a baseball game, the answeras they probably know by nowis no. At least, not for the team that Casey Stengel used to call my amazing Mets.

title: Inquiry Into Shell's Role On Broadcast Data Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, has asked the Justice Department to determine whether the Shell Oil Company attempted to intimidate environmentalists and broadcasters earlier this year with information that was fraudulently obtained.

title: WNCN LISTENERS RALLY ON FORMAT
description: Two groups of listeners of station WNCN have organized and are petitioning the Federal Communications Commission in an attempt to stop the FM radio station from scuttling its classicalmusic format in favor of pop.

title: AMEX DECLINES; TRADING IS HEAVY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped again yesterday in steppedup tradiq. In the overthecounter market, prices also fell on increased volume as investors vainly awaited some news that could be construed as bullish.

title: Stars Pin 3415 Loss On Storm
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 11 (AP)A running back, Jim Ford, scored twice on 1yard runs and the New York defense did the rest as the Stars defeated Portland 3415, tonight for their second World Football League victory over the Storm this season.

title: Widow Slain in W 77th St. Apartment
description: A 59yearold widow was found strangled in her ransacked apartment at 40 West 77th Street yesterday morning, and within hours the police announced the arrest of a suspect, after questioning hundreds of the slain woman's neighbors.

title: Ethiopian Crown Prince Hears News of Succession on Radio
description: GENEVA, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  Crown Prince Asfa Wossen learned from a radio news broadcast today that he had been named King of Ethiopia to succeed his deposed father, Emperor Haile Selassie, a spokesman for the Prince said here.

title: New Books
description: A FarOff Place by Laurens van der Post (Morrow, $7.95). A bushman and his wife help two young whites escape terrorists in South Africa.

title: Joan Kennedy Enters A Clinic in California
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Joan Kennedy, wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has entered a private clinic in California for a rest, a spokesman for the Kennedy family said today.

title: Capt. Ernest H. Nelson, 80, Dies; A Skipper for Export 32 Years
description: Capt. Ernest H. Nelson, a master of the American Export Lines for 32 years and commander of the liner Constitution at his retirement in 1958, died Tuesday at the Huntington (L. I.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

title: Henry. B. Cabot, Lawyer; Boston Symphony Trustee
description: Henry B. Cabot, a lawyer and a member of one of Boston's oldest families died Wednesday at his home in Dover, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: People and Business Looser GasPrice Rules Urged
description: The chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates oil and gas in Texas, has warned Federal officials that the diversion of natural gas to national pipelines from state lines would not solve power shortages but only bring politics further into energy policy.

title: Carey Challenges Wilson To Oppose Nixon Pardon
description: Appearing with his running mates for the first time, Representative Hugh L. Carey called on Governor Wilson yesterday to cast off your timidity and speak out against the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: ROCKEFELLER VOICES MIDEAST PEACE HOPE
description: Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller last night made his first appearance at a public function since his nomination, substituting for President Ford at the annual dinner of a Zionist organization and speaking confidently of the momentum for security and peace in the Middle East.

title: Courageous Wins
description: Courageous again defeated Southern Cross yesterday and leads, 2.0, in the America's Cup yachting series. Details on Page 43.

title: Cardinals Top Mets By 125
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, proving that they don't need a lot of rest to win games, came back last night after 7hour4minute, 25inning 4.3 victory over the Mets Wednesday night, produced their biggest run output of the season in a 125 victory at Shea Stadium and swept the twogame series. The Cards also crept within PA games of firstplace Pittsburgh in National League East.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary, And Index, Page 39

title: The Lion at Sunset
description: Emperdr Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, who has been wielding nearly absolute power longer than any other living head of state, was gradually stripped of all of his prerogatives over the last six months by an anonymous group of army captains and majors, and has lately been leading a ghostlike existence.

title: Eurodollars Are Cited
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  The Western American Bank, Ltd., a consortium enterprise partly owned by three major American banks, has significantly cut back its staff and operations because Of the dramatic shrinkage of the Eurodollar market in recent months.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Lawyers for the Houston Texans and John Matuszak said they had appealed today the temporary injunction that is keeping Matuszak from playing for the World Football League team, but the W.F.L. season could end before the appeal is completed. The Texans attorney, Bill Pakalka, said the Texans had appealed the injunction ruling by State District Judge Arthur Lesher to the Texas Court of Civil Appeals.

title: Courageous Wins For 20 Cup. Lead
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12If the 22d defense of the America's Cup is a mismatch, it's a mismatch of crews rather than boats.

title: State FairCampaign Code to Govern Nov. 5 Vote
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12Political espionage and slurs based on race, sex, religion and ethnic background are prohibited in Fair Campaign Code adopted today by the State Board of Elections.

title: Gen. Aman: Ethiopian of Many Roles
description: A 50yearold Ethiopian general emerged yesterday as the head of the provisional military government that took power as Emperor Haile Selassie was deposed. But whether he is the titular or real ruler was unclear.

title: Jones Is Not Speedy Enough to Avoid Giants Cut
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 12Larance Jones returned a kickoff for 100 yards and, averaged 19.4 yards on eight punt returns during the exhibition season, but it still wasn't good enough to win a job with the New York Giants this year.

title: Music: Maria Stuarda
description: In this age of operatic underfinancing, it might seem strange for a company to mount an opera only once in a season. But that is exactly what the New York City Opera is doing this fall, with two of the three operas in its Donizetti Queen cycle, Maria Stuarda and Roberto Devereux. The third opera, Anna Bolena, is being given several times.

title: Democrats Expect Pardon to Dominate House Races
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12New Jersey's Democratic leadership said today that the dominant issue against Republican incinnbents in the Congressional elections would be President Ford's pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon, all act that Democratic candidates said was an outrage and consequence of a secret deal between the two men.

title: Checks Introduced at McCrane's Trial
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12 The Federal Government today introduced as evidence 50 invoices and checks it contends were used by contributors to William T. Cahill's 1969 gubernatorial campaign to disguise their gifts as legitimate taxdeductible business expenses.

title: Estella Warner, Physician; Joined Public Health in 32
description: Dr. Estella Ford Warner, the first woman to become an officer in the United States Public Health Service, died Tuesday in a hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. She was 82 years old and had lived in Albuquerque since her retirement in 1955.

title: Norman Wonnacott Dies, Headed Willcox & Gibbs
description: Norman Wonnacott, former president and vice chairman of the board of Willcox & Gibbs, Inc., an international manufacturer of industrial equipment, sample cards, books and allied equipment, died yesterday in North Bay, Ontario, where he had lived since his retirement. He was 71 years old.

title: Landlords Protest 4 New Laws They Expect to Increase Costs
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 12Nearly 200 New Jersey landlords gathered here today to hear and complain about four new state laws and a Federal insurance plan that will affect their relationships with tenants.

title: 2 BIG UTILITIES CUT EXPANSION PLANS
description: Two major electric utilities announced yesterday large cuts in expansion plans at almost the same time as the head of a leading supplier of powergeneration equipment was insisting that the electric utilities were ordering fossilfueled generating systems at a record rate.

description: Nelson A. Rockefeller was reported yesterday to have given Congress an estimate of $33million as his immediate personal worth.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The judge in the Watergate coverup case denied today requests by three of the six defendants that charges against them be dropped, because the pardoning of former President Richard M. Nixon had created the public impression that they were guilty:

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.09billion, up 13 per cent from the yearearlier $956million. Total retail store sales were about $10.11billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $9.22billion.

title: LIT BID TO DIVEST AVIS CONSIDERED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The Justice Department is considering a proposal from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the divestiture of Avis, Inc., as required under a consent decree negotiated three years ago.

title: Frank Robinson Is Sold to the Indians
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)The California Anels sold Frank Robinson, the only man ever to win the most valuable player award in both leagues, to the Cleveland Indians today for the $20,000 waiver price.

title: U.S. and Europe Push FarmMarket Fight
description: PARIS, Sept, 12Although droughts have intervened to reduce quantities of feed grains that American farmers can export, the United States and Europe are still fighting to obtain greater access to each other's agricultural marketsand still quarreling over the protectionism each sees growing across the water.

title: ALL IN CREW FLEE BLAZE ON LIND
description: KEY WEST, Fla. Sept. 12 (UPI)Fire raged out of control through five decks of the luxury cruise ship Cunard Am. bassador tonight, knocking out the ship's emergency power supply and forcing fire fighters to abandon ship.

title: OFFICER BEATEN INTRUCK ROBBERY
description: An offduty police officer, badly pistolwhipped during truck hijacking in Scarsdale, N. Y. was dumped unconscious in the East Side this afternoon, the police reported.

title: Classes Are Suspended In Textbook Dispute
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va. Sept. 12 (AP)Classes for more than 44,000 students were suspended today because of growing violence in a dispute over alleged anti Christian textbooks, school officials said.

title: Former Prosecutor Wins the Dismissal Of Drug Indictment
description: A former narcotics prosecutor, accused of giving a small quantity of the drug Quaalude to two colleagues, won dismissal of his indictment yesterday in State Supreme Court here.

title: Ford Raises Prices 7.7%, Less Than 8.5% by G.M.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12  The Ford Motor Company which indicated last month that it wanted to raise prices of its 1975 model by $500, settled today for an pverage of $391, or 7.7 per cent.

title: Loan to Italy Extended
description: PARIS, Sept. 12  French sources said today after a meeting of the Italian and French Finance Ministers that the European Economic Community would extend for three more months $1.8billion shortterm loan to Italy that was to have been repaid this month and had agreed in principle to convert the loan to a mediumterm credit.

title: Reds Win 2 as Geronimo, Bench Belt Grand Slams
description: Johnny Bench continued to wage his personal pursuit of the National League's Western Division pennant yesterday as he smashed two homers, one a grand slam, and drove in all the Cincinnati runs in a 62 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: 3 MIGRANTS GIVEN U. S. PROTECTION.
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12 (AP)Federal authorities said today that they were protecting three Puerto Rican farm workers whose lives were in danger because they had testified about conditions in migrant camps in South Jersey.

title: Connors Seeded No. 1
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI)Jimmy Connors, United States Open and Wimbledon champion, has been topseeded for the $100,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament, which begins Monday at the Los Angeles Tennis Club. In the Grand Master's part of the tourney, Frank Sedgman was ranked No. 1, with Pancho Gonzales second.

Now the trio is at Max's Kansas City (through Sunday), and the three women in it seem to be winning more fans there.

title: More Women Running for Office And More Achieving Successes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12More women are running for office this year than in the past, and they are achieving more successes.

title: Name Boutiques Thrive, and Courreges Joins In
description: Who's afraid of big, bad inflation? Certainly not the couturename buyers who flock to the New York branches of European boutiques.

title: Waldheim Sees Rich Countries Losing Interest in Foreign Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12Secretary General Waldheim said today that governments that had traditionally assisted poor countries were becoming disenchanted about continuing.

title: Lefkowitz Seeking To Alterand Enlarge SmallClaim System
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday made proposals for protecting and strengthening the rights of people trying to collect on judgments granted in Small Claims Courts.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
BOND PRICES DROP IN QUIET TRADING
description: New Bond Issues UTILITY BONDS

title: TAX BREAK ASKED TO HELP HOUSING
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 12A coalition of industry groups affected by the severe depression in housing construction and sales presented to skeptical Government officials today a ninepoint rescue program.

title: Exchange Seat at $65,000; Lowest Price in 19 Years
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of two exchange seats at $65,000 each, down $1,000 from the previous sale on Wednesday. This is the lowest price for a seat since Oct. 20, 1954. Current quotations for the seats are $56,000 bid, offered at $75,000.

title: INDIAN TAKEOVER NOW BEFORE JURY
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 12  The jury in the Wounded Knee trial adjourned tonight without reaching a verdct in the widely publicized case, and told the court that it would resume deliberations at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP 39?, IN AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Wholesale prices recorded their biggest monthly rise in year in August as food prices surged upward again for the second month in a row and the pace of price increases for industrial commodities continued essentially unabated.

title: Foreign Stock Exchanges
description: TORONTO

title: President Fighting Cuts in Saigon Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12President Ford appealed personally to Congressional leaders today to restore the hundreds of millions of dollars cut from the Administration's foreign aid request for South Vietnam and the rest of Indochina.

title: Stock Trading Change
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges annonnced yesterday that they would extend their trading half an hour, to 4 P.M. in the hope of attracting more business, Details on Page 49.

title: Seoul and Tokyo Fail to End Quarrel Over Assassin
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 12  Foreign Minister Kim Dong Jo of South Korea and Ambassador Torao Ushiroku of Japan are nearly at an impasse in their negotiations over Japan's position on the attempted assassination of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea on Aug. 15, authoritative Korean sources said tonight.

title: 1,300 PASSENGERS QUIT THE FRANCE
description: LE HAVRE, France, Sept. 12 She lay dead in the water two miles off the Channel coast of France, a rusting ghost shrouded in mist and gusts of slashing rain.

title: U.S. Expects Rise In Friction at Sea Over Fishing Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The United States Government expects ocean incidents to increase along this country's continental shelf as a result of a decision to bar foreigners from catching lobsters, crabs and other shelf creatures there, a high American official said today.

title: Opera: Updating Commedia dell Arte
description: Composers today are experimenting with new forms, and William Russo is representative of the younger men who are trying something different. Mr. Russo has been associated with jazz for, some years; he was one of Stan Kenton's arrangers. He also had an ambitious symphonic work presented by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE BY LIMIT
description: All soybean futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade jumped the daily permissible 20centabushel limit yesterday, responding to the Department of Agriculture's crop report released after the close ofl trading Wednesday.

title: MIRIAM YOUNG, 62, WRITER, IS DEAD
description: Miriam Young, whose book Mother Wore Tights became one of the first of a Hollywood supermusical, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Lake Katonah, N. Y. She was 62 years old.

title: Tanaka Begins 16Day Tour, of Americas
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12Premier Kakuei Tanaka left Japan today for a 16day tour of Mexico, Brazil and Canada that will also include a brief stopover in Washington for a meeting with resident Ford.

title: Imperial Retirement
description: General Services Administrator Arthur Sampson has juggled the figures a bit in attempting to justify the Ford Administration's request for $850,000 to support former President Nixon through the end of the fiscal year, but the proposal still adds up to a wildly extravagant and uncalledfor expenditure of public funds. As we have noted before, there is a certain sum to which the former President is entitled by lawfor his pension, his office staff and for transition expensesbut Mr. Ford has asked Congress to appropriate a quarter of A million dollars over and above what is required by law to ease the former President's change in status following his forced resignation.

title: Forego Gets No. 2 Post for Marlboro Cup Tomorrow
description: Strawberries and ham and eggs were the featured items at a Belmont Park brunch yesterday morning held to provide the backdrop for the annual chore of picking post positions for Saturday's $250,000 Marlboro Cup, The 1mile Invitational, won by Secretriat last year, has attracted a field of 11 stakes winners. Favored and assigned to carry the top weight of 126 pounds was Lazy F Ranch's Forego. Both roles are familiar to the seasonal campaigner.

title: Chile's Junta After a Year: Unrelenting Dictatorship
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12A year after the coup d'tat that overthrew the freely elected minority Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens, a Marxist, the military junta that took power has strengthened its hold over Chile and appears determined to continue its repressive, authoritarian political style and conservative, austere economic policies.

title: Wilson Asserts Carey Is Deserting Inflation Fight
description: FREEPORT, LI., Sept. 12Governor Wilson said today that inflation is a national problem and that if his Democratic opponent, Representative Hugh L. Carey, wanted to fight inflation, Mr. Carey is deserting his post.

title: He Converted to Islam and Took a Wife
description: LAMU, Kenya  When Abedi Shepardson decided to get warded lie was eager to follow the proper form.

title: Shipping/Mails
People in Sports
description: Last May when Jim Finks quit his job of 10 years as general manager of the Minnesota Vikings, losers in the 1974 Super Bowl, he said, It was time for a chatge.

title: Fodor Is the First Artist Under the Roof for Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The state dinner given tonight by President and Mrs. Ford for Premier and Mrs. Yitzhak Rabin of Israel marked the first such affair during Mr. Ford's Presidency at which an artist was invited to perform.

title: Market Averages
description: Thursday, September 12, 1974

title: Why Gold Stocks Fell
description: A market letter that sent gold stocks tumbling this week represented a quick change of views by E. George Schaefer, who had been reccmmending gold and silver issues since 1971.

title: House Panel Votes To Trim Gains Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The House Ways and Means Committee, yielding to the appeals of the securities industry, voted today to reduce greatly the tax on some capital gains. The new formula adopted by the committee would bring the greatest benefits to those who had the largest increases in the value of stock or other property that they had bought at least five years ago.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.2 billion tonmiles, 3.3 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period, which included the Labor Day holiday, totaled 453,838 cars, 4.2 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 3.2 per cent below last year.

title: Tito Discloses Uncovering Of Stalinist Party Group
description: JESENICE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 (AP)  President Tito said today that about 30 foreigninspired Communists had been arrested for a conspiracy to organize a new Stalinistline Communist party in Yugoslavia.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (UPI)Britain's trade gap narrowed by a third last month from $1.14billion to $762millionthe lowest since last Novemberthe Department for Trade announced today.

title: Queens Woman Has Baby In Daughter's Schoolroom
description: Mrs. Hattie Thomas arrived at her daughter's kindergarten the mother of three, and left the mother of four.

title: Courageous Wins
description: Courageous again defeated Southern Cross yesterday and leads, 20, in the America's Cup yachting series. Details on Page 43.

title: Money
description: LONDON METAL MARKET

title: 27 of 30 Indicted Men Arrested As Part of Oistate Robbery Ring
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12The 12 indictments unsealed today by the Essex County Prosecutor's office contained 64 counts ranging from firstdegree murder to receiving stolengoods against 30 men accused of being involved in a robbery ring that has operated in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for the last several years.

title: BRIBE PLOT LAID TO TWO NEWSMEN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 12Two reporters for The Indianapolis Star, both members of a newspaper team that has been investigating police and political corruption in Marion County for over a year, were indicted today by a local grand jury on charges of conspiring to bribe a policeman.

title: Ford Raises Prices
description: The Ford Motor Company, which had indicated it wanted to raise prices by $500 on 1975 models, announced yesterday it would settle for $391, or 7.7 per centless than the $426, or 8.5 per cent rise, set by General Motors after pressure from Washington to limit its increases. Details on Page 53.

title: 2 European Banks Invest in Lehman
description: Lehman Brothers, Inc., one of Wall Street's oldest investment banking houses, said yesterday that two European banks had agreed to invest a total of $7million in the securities of Lehman Holding Company, Inc., which has been formed to hold Lehman shares.

title: Problem for Parents: Explaining the Pardon To Puzzled Youngsters
description: Problem for Parents: Explaining the Pardon To Puzzled Youngsters

title: Schering Builds in Ireland
description: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 12 (UPI)The Schering Corporation announced yesterday that it would build a new plant to make pharmaceuticals on a 100acre site at Killaloan Clonmel in County Tipperary, Ireland. The plant will cost $25million and will employ about 130 people when it goes into operation in 1976.

title: Seatrain Reports Cut in Its Deficit
description: Seatrain Lines, Inc., a major unsubsidized company shipping bulk commodities but deriving about half of its revenues from container services, reported yesterday higher revenues and a reduced deficit M the fiscal year that ended June 30.

title: THOUSANDS OF JOBS PROMISED IN CITY
description: Federal officials said yesterday that New York City could expect to get enough money to put several thousand unemployed people to work immediately under the expanded public service employment program President Ford announced Wednesday.

title: DumDum Bullets in Use
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. Sept. 12 (UPI) Dumdum bullets; outlawed under the international rules of war, are standard ammunition for hand guns used by the Pennsylvania State Police. Dumdum bullets named after the British round developed to stop insurgents in India late in the late 18th century  flatten out on impact and usually remain embedded in the target. A police spokesman said they were being used because of their stopping power.

title: Woman Was Elected To State Office in 24
description: Contrary to widely circulated reports, State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak, who won the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor in Tuesday's primary, is not the first woman to carry a major party designation for statewide office in New York.

title: Cathedral School Goes Coed in Lower Grades
description: The 72yearold Cathedral School, adjacent to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, went coed yesterday.

title: Sharply Diverse Views on Food Price Inflation Due at Chicago Parley Today
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12Representatives of farmers, farmrelated industries and consumers began gathering here tonight to seek common ground for an attack on food price inflation, widely regarded as the most serious element in current economic problenis but also perhaps, one that is most susceptible of solution.

title: About Real Estate
description: From the air the New Jersey coast is a long, lovely beach thrashed by a foaming white surf. It is tempting and development has not ignored the temptation.

title: Connors Seeded No. 1
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI)Jimmy Connors, United States Open and Wimbledon champion, has been topseeded for the $100,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament, which begins Monday at the Los Angeles Tennis Club. In the Grand Master's part of the tourney, Frank Sedgman was ranked No. 1, with Pancho Gonzales second.

title: Showdown in House Is. Sought For Committee Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The chief architect of the first proposed reorganization of committees of the House of Representatives since 1946 appealed today to the House Rules Committee to send the longdelayed issue to the House floor for final action.

title: OPEC Views Tax on Foreign Oil Exports
description: VIENNA., Sept. 12Ministers of the world's major oil exporting countries discussed today a new tax on foreign oil company exports, that would consolidate the present high level of petroleum prices.

title: Lefkowitz Seeking To Altet and Enlarge SmallClaim System
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday made proposals for protecting and strengthening the rights of people trying to collecton judgments granted in Small Claims Courts.

title: Johnson and Bruno Tied In Met. Golf
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Sept. 12 Bob Bruno of Pelham, a former national club pro titleholder, and Howie Johnson of Sunningdale each beat par by four shots with 68's for 138 today to take the lead after 36 holes of the 59th $12,500 Metropolitan open, being played over the 6,576yard Middle Bay course. The final round will be played tomorrow.

title: 2 Held as Hostages In the North Bronx; 2 Captors Give Up
description: Three men, armed and apparently bent on robbery, seized two hostages, reportedly an elderly man and a youth, and held them captive in private dwelling in the Bronx last night as the police surrounded the building.

title: More Women Running for Office And More Achieving Successes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12More women are running for office this year than in the past, and they are achieving more successes.

title: ONE PRICE CEILING IS URGED FOR GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The Federal Power Commission's staff recommended today a single nationwide price Ceiling for old natural gas sold by producers to interstate pipe lines, a move virtually certain increase gas prices.

title: 2 Elis in Shrine Game
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12 (AP)Two Yale football halfbacks, Rudy Green and Elvin Charity, have been chosen to play in the Dec. 28 EastWest Shrine game in Stanford, Calif., a Yale spokesman said today.

title: Other U.S. Stock Exchanges
description: MIDWEST

title: Johnson and Bruno Tied In Met. Golf
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Sept. 12 Bob Bruno of Pelham, a former national club pro titleholder, and Howie Johnson of Sunningdale each beat par by four shots with 68's for 138 today to take the lead after 36 holes of the 59th $12,500 Metropolitan open; being played over the 6,576yard Middle Bay course. The final round will be played tomorrow.

title: FORD SAID TO BAR PRETRIAL PARDONS OF EXNIXON AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 President Ford does not intend to pardon any of the Watergate defendants before trial as he did former President Richard M. Nixon, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: Legal Aid Rejects Lawyers Proposal for Arbitration
description: Striking Legal Aid Society lawyers offered to return to work yesterday if the society's management agreed to submit the disputed contract issues to binding arbitration. But the offer was rejected.

title: SIR ARTHUR FRASER, AUTHOR AND ENVOY
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP)Sir Arthur Ronald Fraser, author and former British diplomat, died today at his home in Oxfordshire County west of London. He was 85 years old.

title: Rockefeller Attica and Pardons
description: Three years ago today, 39 inmates and correction officers died in a police assault at the Attica State Correctional Facility made necessary because the Governor of New York State, Nelson A. Rockefeller, believed that would be an abuse of executive power to grant the inmates immunity from prosecution for their part in the uprising.

title: Doan Says Pardon Can't Change Facts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 John M. Doar the House Judiciary Committee's special counsel on impeachment, declared today that the record of President Nixon's role in the Watergate scandal was clearly established for history despite President Ford's pardon of his predecessor. Mr. Doar said he was firmly convinced that justice was done in the forced resignation of Mr. Nixon.

title: HOSPITAL OFFERS HOTEL AS HOUSING
description: The French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center has proposed and the city's Department of Relocation has endorsed a plan to house Manhattan's temporarily homeless in the former New Yorker Hotel, which the center hopes someday to convert into a modern medical facility.

title: 4 Parties in City to Pick 14 judgeship Candidates
description: The Democratic, Republican, Liberal and Conservative parties in the city are to nominate candidates for 14 positions on the State Supreme Court at judioial conventions today and tomorrow.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate yesterday formally approved the nominations of Shirley Temple Black to be Ambassador to Ghana and John Sherman Cooper, the former Senator, to be the first United States Ambassador to East Germany. It also approved Kenneth Rush, economic coordinator for former President Richard M. Nixon, as Ambassador to France, and Philip C. Habib, a career foreign service officer, as Assistant Secretary of State. Senator Hugh Scott, the Republican from Pennsylvania, was particularly pleased with the nomination of Mrs. Black, who as a child movie star sailed on the good ship Lollipop, to be an officer on the ship of state. She has been successful in transferring her skills from the screen to the arena of public service, said Mr. Scott, and since her nomination to the post in Ghana, which she has never visited, she has steeped herself in the problems of Africa and Ghana.

title: 2 Arrested in Drug Case
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (UPI) Two Federal narcotics agents were robbed of $8,000 and held prisoner in a West Side home for 20 minutes last night by three men from whom they were to purchase 150 pounds of marijuana. The agents were released unharmed after the police and other agents stormed the house and the suspects surrendered.

title: World Football League
description: World Football League

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1974
description: Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, who ruled his country for 58 years, was deposed peacefully by the military. He was taken from his palace in Addis Ababa to army headquarters and later reportedly to palace ouside the capital for his personal safety. He had been progressively stripped of his absoute powers amid charges of corruption against his government. [1:8.]

title: David Eisenhower Says Confession Was Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)David Eisenhower said today that representatives of President Ford had sought some kind of confession before deciding to pardon former President Richard M. Nixon, but that they were refused.

title: Lincoln Hospital Stripped Of Accreditation by Panel.
description: Lincoln Hospital, the 65yearold municipal institution serving the South Bronx, has been stripped of its accreditation by a national commission that found what physicans termed shocking conditions of overcrowding and inadequate facilities.

title: House Panel Votes To Trim Gains Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The House Ways and Means Committee, yielding to the appeals of the securities industry, voted today to reduce greatly the tax on some capital gains.

title: SuperInflation
description: The price indexes are shobting up to their own summit as the Ford Administration plods toward the peak of its great publicrelations venture In the sky.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: U.S. Assailed on Care of Jamaica Bay Refuge
description: Local conservationists fear that the worldrenowed Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge may be on the verge of destruction as a result of what they view as the Federal Government's mismanagement and misdirected priorities.

title: Food, Service Are FineSo Why Only the One Star?
description: If the management of Dorrian's Red Hand, a bistrotype restaurant on Second Avenue at 84th Street, would rip out the juke box, I'd give it two very bright stars with a possible third off in the distance.

title: Dawson of Chiefs to Get His Plays From the Sideline
description: The Kansas City Chiefs won the 1970 Super Bowl with what phrasemakers were quick to dub the offense of the 70's. However, since the Jets last saw the Chiefs, in 1971, that offense seemingly has deteriorated into the offense of the 20's. That's why Hank Stram, the dapper little coach with the fancy big offensive repertory, will call all the plays this season.

title: Stock Trading Change
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that they would extend their trading half an Mar, to 4 P.M., in the hope of attracting more business. Details on Page 49.

title: Group Health Purchases The McGrawHill Building
description: Group Health, Inc., a medical insurance concern, has purchased the former McGrawHill Building, which has been vacant for about three years, for $5.5million.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12Quarterbacks, linebackers, offensive tackles, defensive tackles, safeties, tight ends, punters, kickers and even haircuts are some of the problems that face the New Jersey college football coaches.

title: Books of The Times
description: UNITED NATIONS JOURNAL: A Delegate's Odyssey, By William F. Buckley Jr. 280 pages. Putnam, $7.95.

title: Civic Groups Will Sue to Prevent Superhighway on the West Side
description: A coalition of 37 civics and environmental groups gave the required 60day notice yesterday of intention to file suit to block construction of an interstate superhigway as a replacement for the dilapidated West Side Highway.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP 3.9% IN AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Wholesale prices recorded their biggest monthly rise in a year in August as food prices surged upward again for the second month in a row and the pace of price increases for industrial commodities continued essentially unabated.

title: Forego Gets No. 2 Post for Marlboro Cup Tomorrow
description: Strawberries and ham and eggs were the featured items at a Belmont Park brunch yesterday morning held to provide the backdrop for the annual chore of picking post positions for Saturday's $250,000 Marlboro Cup, The 1mile Invitational, won by Secretriat last year, has attracted a field of 11 stakes winners. Favored and assigned to carry the top weight of 126 pounds was Lazy F Ranch's Forego. Both roles are familiar to the seasonal campaigner.

title: Nixon Rebuffed in His Attempt To Resign From California Bar
description: SAN, FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 The California State Bar Association recommended tonight that former President Nixon's letter of resignation be rejected.

title: DR. LOUIS A. LAZAR
description: Dr. Louis A. Lazar, a cardiologist and an internist, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Tuesday in Paris, where he had been on vacation with his wife. He was 58 years old and lived in Goshen, N. Y.

title: Beame Says City. Has Higher Costs But Less Revenue
description: Mayor Beame, saying he was very alarmed at skyrocketing municipal costs and fading revenues, yesterday ordered a review of spending by city departments that could cause cutbacks in lowpriority programs and the loss of some jobs.

title: India and Pakistan Resume Talks on Restoring Links
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 12 Talks between high Indian and Pakistani officials for restoration of travel facilities and telecommunications between their countries started today in Islamabad after a break of about three months.

title: EDWARD A. M'MILLAN
description: PRINCETON, N. J. Sept. 12Edward Allen MacMillan, former superintendent of Princeton University's department of grounds and buildings, died today at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived at 160 Prospect Avenue.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1974
description: Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, who ruled his country for 58 years, was deposed peacefully by the military. He was taken from his palace in Addis Ababa to army headquarters and later reportedly to a palace ouside the capital for his personal safety. He had been progressively stripped of his absoute powers amid charges of corruption against his government. [1:8.]Clearly indicating that he intended to maintain the sort of support of previous Administrations for the Saigon Government, President Ford appealed personally to Congressional leaders to restore the hundreds of millions of dollars cut from the Administration's foreign aid budget for South Vietnam and the rest of Indochina. In a special message to Congress on foreign aid priorities, Mr. Ford also said that he was concerned that restrictive amendments to bill, approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, would  severely limit his ability to conduct United States foreign polciy. Initial reaction on Capitol Hill to the President's request for the restored funds was unenthusiastic. [1:8.]

title: 4 Try to Save a Tree, Fail and Are Arrested
description: BRISTOL, Conn., Sept. 12 (AP)Four young men who tried to prevent the Public Works Department from cutting down a huge ash tree today were arrested for breach of the peace.

title: Other Cabbies Help Hunt Thief Who Bilked Visitors
description: The taxicab driver who swindled three young nonEnglish speaking visitors from Mexico of $167 for a ride from Kennedy International Airport to the Upper West Side on Wednesday is known as the Thief to his fellow cab drivers. They say he prowls the airport seeking out LatinAmerican arrivals whom he sizes up as uneducated or inexperienced firsttime visitors to New York.

title: Medical Report Dooms Reed's Career
description: Mail arrived yesterday at Madison Square Garden, the offices of the Knicks team doctor, and Larry Fleisher, Willis Reed's lawyer, that apparently ended the playing days of the Knick captain.

title: The Appeals Judges
description: The least qualified of the candidates, Jacob D.
