Fuchsberg, who has never sat even as a justice of the peace, has received the largest vote total in the Democratic primary for the state's highest and heretofore most respected court. Those who went to the polls voted for the one name they recognized, and the Democratic party especially in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, where he rolled up the bulk of his winning margindid little to oppose his candidack for the Court of Appeals or support the much more highly qualified nominees who carried the party's official designation.

title: Red Smith
description: MENEMSHA, Mass., Sept. 12The newborn day was mostly gray but a red ball hung an inch or two above the horizon when Doug Fischer took passengers aboard and cast off from Dutcher's Dock. It might raise the literary tone of this tale to say that Doug Fischer, like Oliver Goldsmith's schoolmaster, wore the day's disasters on his morning face but the fact is he wore blond mustache and the peaceful expression a professional who knows he isn't getting paid. Doug is a fishing guide who spends his summers here on the waters where he grew up and in the winter takes anglers out of Captiva, off Fort Myers, Fla. On this occasion he had four freeloaders aboard, including his father, Ozzie, and the Dexter Goodwins, father and son. Goodwin Ore is fugitive from Connecticut now relocated on Martha's Vineyard; Goodwin fits is based in Charlottesville, Va.

title: STOCK MARKETS TO EXTEND HOURS
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday they would extend their trading hours by half an hour to 4 P.M. in the hope that it might attract more business to the sagging stock markets.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, twilightnight doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt. Avenue and 126th Street, 5:30 p.m. (Television Channel 9. 8 P.M.)) (Radio  WHN; 5:30@P.M)

title: US. More Hopeful Than the Israelis
description: United States experts discern serious dangers in the military situation developing in the Middle East, but at the moment they do not view the immediate future as somberly as do the Israelis.

title: Coast G.O.P. Strategist Arrested on Morals Charge
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 13 (UP1)A prominent Republican strategist, Dr. Gaylond B. Parkinson, has been arrested on sex perversion charge, the police said yesterday.

title: Long Beach Out of Funk May Not Meet Its Payroll
description: LONG BEACH, Sept. 13The City Manager of Long Beach warned today that his city was about $2million in the red and might not be able to meet its payroll for the balance of the fiscal year.

title: Trucker Gets 10year Term
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) Edward 3. Ostrander, one of five men convicted in a rockthrowing incident that killed York County truck driver during the national truckers strike last January, has been sentenced to 10 years in Federal prison. The other truckers are awaiting, sentencing in the death of Ronald Hengst, 33 years old, of Spring Grove.

title: WALTER GREENWOOD, BRITISH NOVELIST, 71
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Walter Greenwood, author of Love on the Dole, a bestselling novel of the nineteenthirties, was found dead at his home here today. He was 71 years old.

title: People in Sports
description: This was the missing link in my career as a driver and I'm looking forward to working with our team to come up with a competitive Formula I, said Mark Donohue yesterday as he announced that he would be coming out of an agonizing eight months retirement to go behind the wheel in the Canadian Grand Prix next week in Roger Penske's new Formula I car.

title: American Motors Recalling 20,000 Jeep Vehicles
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13 (UPI)The American Motors Corporation said today that more than 20,000 Jeep vehicles were being recalled because of a suspension system problem that had resulted in three minor accidents.

title: Javits Denies Letting Down Backers In Heading Nixon Reelection Drive
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits denied yesterday that he had let down his supporters by directing the New York reelection campaign of former President Richard M. Nixon two years ago.

title: DR. ASA LINCOLN, 83, INTERNIST, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Asa Liggett Lincoln, New York physician who also had been professor of clinical medicine at Cornell University Medical College, died yesterday at his home in North Salem, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: Planes for Sale: A FullDress U.S. Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13With a brass band as an opener and 0, musical comedy as a finale, Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger spent the day today trying to prevail upon four European defense ministers to buy an American fighter plane.

title: ERNEST COLWELL, BIBLICAL SCHOLAR
description: DELAND, Fla., Sept, 13 (AP) Dr. Ernest Cadman Colwell, president of the University of Chicago from 1945 to 1951, died of leukemia at a hospital in Orlando yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Cahill and Kugler Testify for Sherwin In a NewTrial Bid
description: FREEHOLD, Sept. 13Forit mer Gov. William T. Cahill ands his State Attorney General apOared today as witnesses in a hearing on a motion seeking a new trial for Paul J. Sherwin, once the Cahill administration's Secretary of State, who was convicted two years ago on highway bidrigging and kickback charges.

title: 63 Puts Miller Ahead
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Sept. 13 The number 63 has come to be identified with Johnny Miller. That is what he shot in the final round to win the 1973 United States Open, and that is what he shot today to take a onestroke lead at 136 in the second round of the World open at the Pinehurst Country Club.

title: Doctor Says Nixon Has a New Attack Of Phlebitis in Leg
description: Former President Richard M. Nixons physician, Air Force Major Gen. Walter Tkach, said late yesterday that Mr. Nixon had suffered a new attack of painful phlebitis in his left leg and that a new blood clot had formed. Mr. Nixon rejected the advice of his doctors and Umily that he enters hospital.

title: Nixon Expenses Now Coming From Ford Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Government auditors have ruled that the General Services Administration had no authority to spend money for former President Richard M. Nixon's transition to private life without first getting on appropriation from Congress.

title: Despite High Hopes, Fashions at the Party Were Mostly Old Hat
description: The fall party season got under way with a roar Thursday night when about 500 revelers from the worlds of fashion, society and show business gathered to honor Stevie Wonder, the blind rock star, and to eat what was billed as soul food.

title: Belmont Park Charts  1974, by Triangle Publications Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)
description: Horses I isted in order of Post Positions. Lefler designates OTB listing.

title: Recorder on Eastern Jet Indicates Nothing Abnormal
description: CHARLMTE,.N.C., Sept. 13 (UPI)A playback of a cockpit recorder aboard the Eastern Air Lines jetliner, that crashed Wednesday indicated no abnorinalities, the chief investigator said today.

title: Commodity Customers To Get Broker Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  Brokers who deal in commodity futures will be required under new Federal regulations to keep their customers advised monthly on how they are doing in the market.

title: LASER CALLED AID TO DOWNED FLIERS
description: A Navy scientist seeking to develop an optical memory system for computers has stumbled on a scheme that his colleagues believe could increase the chances of finding a downed flier to 99.8 per cent, even in total darkness.

title: Bulldozers of Progress Are Destroying The City's Buried Historic Treasure
description: In 1916, when workmen were tunneling to build the Seventh Avenue subway, the constructiongang foreman was James A. Kelly. A sometime vaudeville singer, he wore, even underground, a threepiece suit with a watchchain across his vest.

title: Franklin National Delays Proposal to Sell Loans
description: The Franklin National Bank said yesterday it had shelved at least temporarily a proposal to sell about $125million worth of loans to a group of banks led by the First National City Bank in New York.

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Electric Company has been awarded two contracts totaling $31.9million by the Pentagon. One for the design, manufacturing and installation of generators on the Columbia River in Washington State. The other for $9million from the Air Force for engines for the T2E aircraft program.

title: Arab Boats Blown Up
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 13 (AP)Two motorboats reportedly used by Palestinians were mysteriously blown up, today at Saida, on the Lebanese coast 25 miles south of Beirut, Government sources reported. There was speculation that Israeli frogmen might have planted the explosives during the night.

title: ROBERT M. DANFORD RETIRED GENERAL, 95
description: Maj. Gen. Robert Melville Danford, U.S.A., retired, commandant of the New York City Patrol Corps during World War II and chief of field artil: lery of the Army at his retirempnt in 1942, died Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived on Contentment Island Road, Darien, Conn.

title: Law Partner Ousted by Firm and Gulf & Western in Fee Misuse
description: Joel Dolkart, a partner in Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, one of the city's most prominent law firms, has been dismissed by that firm and by Gulf & Western Industries, one of Simpson, Thacher's most important clientsof which he was a director and general counsel because he had apparently appropriated for his own benefit, certain fees paid to [Simpson, Thacher].

title: Mr. Ford on Transit
description: President Ford built masstransit boosters up to jarring letdown in Pittsburgh the other day when he told transportation experts there that last winter's energy crisis had driven home the message that we must make major progress in improving urban transit. Most of the President's subsequent remarks made it painfully evident that this transit message had failed to penetrate the White House with any real sense of urgency.

title: Dodor Says Nixon Has a New Attack Of Phlebitis in Leg
description: Fonner President Richard M. Nixon's physician, Air Force Major Gen. Walter Tkach, said late yesterday that Mr. Nixon had suffered a new attack of painful phlebitis in his left leg and that a new blood clot had formed. Mr. Nixon rejected the advice of his doctors andfam ily that he enter II hospital.

title: Major League Baseball Results and Standings
description: How They Stand Today TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS National League American League Mets' Box Scores

title: Amex Prices Slide, Counter List Drops
description: Prices continued to slide yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market as investors remained unconvinced that there was anything bullish in the economy at this time.

title: Business Briefs
description: Responding to a drop in the world copper market, the Phelps Dodge Corporation cut prices yesterday for a key product used by copper wire makerswhole plate electrolytic copper cathodesfrom 85 cents to 79 cents a pound.

title: People in Sports
description: This was the missing link in my career as a driver and I'm looking forward to working with our team to come up with a competitive Formula I, said Mark Donohue yesterday as he announced that he would be coming out of an agonizing eight months retirement to go behind the wheel in the Canadian Grand Prix next Sunday in Roger Penske's new Formula I car.

title: Inflation in World Is Reported Easing, But U.S. Rate Rises
description: PARIS, Sept. 13 (AP)The rate of inflation appears to he easing slightly for industrial nations, but the United States was among those continuing to show an increase, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.

title: Andrea Dunham Wed to M. R. Burt
description: Andrea Dunham, a partner and executive vice president of Dunham & Marcus, Inc., a venture marketing concern here, and Michael Robert Burt, senior vice president of Norman Craig & Kummel, Inc., an advertising agency, were married yesterday afternoon in the State Suite of the Plaza. The Rev. Dr. Theodore P. Fritsch of the Bronxville Reformed Church performed the ceremony.

title: Beaths
description: ASHTONCharles B. Of Cambridge N.Y. died September 12 after a long illness. Services at Cambridge Presbyterian Church, 10 A.M., September 14.

title: Cup Race Fogged Out; Aussies Shuffle LineUp
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 13 Fog spoiled a great afternoon for yacht racing today and the third race of the America's Cup had to be postponed. Southern Cross the challenger from Australia, and Courageous, the defender leading by two victories to none, will attempt to race tomorrow with weather conditions more promising.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:15 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2:10 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2:15 P.M.)

title: 18to21 Weddings by Clerk Go Smoothly
description: One year ago, the City Clerk's office in Manhattan refused to marry George Davis, then 26 years old, and Lorianne Young, then 18, because neither of the wouldhe bride's Parents were present. Miss. Young's Mother had recently died, and the young woman was reluctant to seek her father's permission.

title: GEORGE KRAMER
description: George Kramer, owner of the KramerAzif Company, a textile conversion concern here, died late Thursday at the Franklin General Hospital in Valley Stream, L. I. He was 63 years old.

title: TV New Land, New Show Old Stuff
description: The 197475 season, continued. The new series opening tonight:

title: Antiques: Isaac, at Jewish Museum
description: The modest space allocated by the Jewish Museum for its temporary exhibition The Binding of Isaac, has been extremely well used.

title: Weekend Pro Football
description: Washington (24) at Giants. (24), George Mlen has never lost an opening game or any game to Giants. Bill Arnsparger would like to surprise in debut. Redskins by 7 points.

title: Decoder Reproduces 4 Sounds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Columbia Broadcast System is about to market a, decoder that will enable the Many owners of stereophonic record players to reproduce sound on four loudspeakers instead of two. The speakers may be set in the four corners of the room, surrounding the listener with concert hall reverberance.

title: ILLNESS DISRUPTS 2 INDIANS TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 13A juror in the Wounded Knee trial became seriously ill today, forcing a suspension in the jury's, deliberations and raising the possibility of a mistrial in the, eightmonth case.

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Covert Activities Are Not Vital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, said today that there would be no major impact on the nation's security if the United States peased all cloak  and  dagger operations, against foreign countries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In the aftermath of Watergate, the initial mood has been one of conciliation and cooperation. It seems highly desirable for the President to give as much momentum as possible to this prevailing mood in the hope that we can regain a greater sense of national unity and purpose. A step in this direction is the summit conference on the economy.

title: GEORGE E. LEIGHTON
description: George Eliot Leighton, vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York until his retirement in 1962, died, apparently of a heart attack, while driving in Fairfield, Conn., on Thursday. He was 80 years old and lived in Fairfield.

title: Detroit Wipes Out New York's Early ThreeRun Lead
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13The cold, the hex and the gopher ball slowed the Yankee pennant express tonight as the New Yorkers lost, 63, to the Detroit Tigers. The lastplace Tigers have won 11 of the 16 games played between the teams this season.

title: Greek and Turkish Cypriotes to Begin Prisoner Exchange Monday
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 13 (Reuters)A partial exchange of prisoners between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes will begin Monday, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Conflict Brews in Volkswagen Over Possible American Plant
description: BONNa conflict is brewing between Rudolph Leiding, head of the giant Volkswagen company, and other members of the company's board of directors about whether to build an assembly plant in the United States, Consequently a decision is not expected this year.

title: JERSEY TO RECEIVE MORE U.S. JOB AID
description: State and local governmentsin New York and New Jersey, will receive $8,587,772 in Fedleral funds, providing about rvi 700 new jobs for the unenrployed, as the initial step in, President Ford's program for expanded publicservice employment.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Bruno Wins Met. Open. By 2 on 209
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Sept. 13LBob Bruno of Pelham captured the 59th. Metropoliton:open championship today with a 54hole total of 209, seven strokes under par. In winning the first prize of $2,500, the 40yearold Pelham pro posted cards of 70, 68 and 71 over the par72, 6,711yard Middle Bay Club course.

title: The Politicians Big EqualJusticeUnderLaw Baloney Picnic
description: Some years ago a colleague of mine, a reporter, was sent to the Maryland Penitentiary to witness the hanging of three felons, two of whom were black. The white man was hanged first, which prompted my colleague to note in his story that in Maryland, even on the gallows, the white man went first.

title: Race for Cup Runneth Over With Money
description: Money is hardly a strange commodity to the 11 horses invited to compete in today's Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park. A total of $3,582,432 has been earned by the elected participants, a financial background quite in keeping with the rich purse structure being offered in the second running of the 1mile handicap.

title: Dave Anderson
description: His income exceeded $400,000 last year because was the first jockey with mounts that earned more than $4million in a year. Laffit Pincay Jr. is expected to make that much money again this year, but not without certain measure of selfdenial.

title: Rockefeller's Future; Having Openly Sought the Presidency, Will He Be Content in Second Place?
description: Now there is a date certain: One week from Monday, at 10 A.M., Nelson A. Rockefieller will have to start answering questionsall those questions about his money, his policies and politics, and again his money. But one important question is unlikely to be asked, and perhaps could not be answered fully by anyone not even Mr. Rockefeller: Is it possible for him to be reasonably contented let alone happy in a position that he among many others has consistently held in low esteem?

title: Driver Shot in Violence Over Textbooks,
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept., 13 (UPI)A truck driver was, hot and wounded today in a wave of violende caused by new school textbooks that gedly defame religion, morality and patriotism.

title: Blaze on Cunard Liner Reported Under Control
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 14 (AP) A twodayold fire burning through the $27million luxury liner Cunard Ambassador was contained late today but was not quite extinguished, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: U.S. Pledge Nearly Doubles Aid to Refugees on Cyprus
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Agency for International Development announced today that It had pledged $3million more for relief assistance to refugees in Cyprus. This almost doubles previous United States aid to the Cypriote refugees, which totaled $3.6million.

title: Eye Drops Are Recalled Over Packaging Error
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of an overthecounter eye drop preparation called PrefrinZ, saying that some purchasers of the drops may have gotten boxes containing a potent anesthetic eye drop product.

title: Crew of the France Continuing Occupation
description: LE. HAVRE, France, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  The crew of the liner France defied the Governthent today and continued its occupation of the ship as I unions organized, a worldwide strike by French seamen on Monday and Tuesday.

title: WILSON RUES END OF DEATH PENALTY
description: TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP)Governor Wilson told New York City policemen today that abolition of the death penlty was a mistakeke.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT OFF 0.4% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Industrial production declined 0.4 per cent in August, the Fediral Reserve Board, reported today. The drop was the first significant downturn in this key indicator of economic activity since the energy shortage period of last winter and spring.

title: STATE IS WARNED OF GAS SHORTAGE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13 (AP)Witnesses at a public hearing today underscored the fears of state officials that. New Jersey could face a critical naturalgas shortage this winter.

title: Youth, 19, Seized in Death Of a Connecticut Woman
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., Sept. 3 (UPI)A 19yearold Connecticut youth was arrested today in the murder of a 24yearold woman whose body was found on the edge of college parking lot in Torrington.

title: Irving Trust Unit Approved
description: The Irving Trust Company said yesterday it had received Federal Reserve Board, approval to open a foreigntrade subsidiary in Los Angeles. The unit, which is expected to begin operation later this year, will be known as Irving Trust Company InternationalPacific.

title: Ford Meets Black Republicans; Vows He Will Be Their Friend
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) President Ford met today with nearly 30 black Republicans and told them that they have a friend in the White House.

title: Stock. Market Plunges 14.55 Points To Lowest Level in Almost 12 Years
description: The stock market plunged yesterday in active trading, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest closing level in almost 12 years.

title: Business Records
description: THE CRESCENT GROUP, INC, 435 W. 23 St., N.Y.Liabilities, 812,384; assets, $625.

title: Kidnapping Case Ended By Woman's Sentencing
description: A Federal judge closed the books yesterday on a bizarre case of the bungled kidnapping of a bookmaker by sentencing 21yearold Bronx woman to year in jail. Two men accomplices had been sentenced earlier, and two others were murdered in the last few months.

title: Tanks Withdrawn in Ethiopian Capital
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 13Ethiopia's provisional military government today withdrew tanks from the streets and relaxed some of the restrictions imposed yesterday as Emperor Haile Selassie was removed.

title: Chase Sets 9% Level
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it planned to raise the interest Irate it charges on commercial loans to small businesses to 9 per cent from 9 per cent. The bank also said it would raise rates on consumer installment loans, bringing them up to levels set by several other big banks recently.

title: Children Injured Imitating Knievel
description: They tried to be like Evel Knievel, who tried to fly over the Snake River, but they landed abruptly in Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: FIVE PUBS APPROVED ON RUTGERS CAMPUS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 13 The Rutgers University board of governors today approved a i$75,000 allocation for developing five campus pubs. The action came after the city withdrew its efforts earlier this week to tax two proposed pubs at the Rutgers and Douglass College campuses here. The three other pubsat the university's Newark, Camden and Livingston College campusesencountered little opposition and have been in limbo while problems with the question of the two local pubs was being resolved.

title: OUSTER EXPECTED FOR U.S.I.A HEAD
description: WASIIINGTON, Sept. 13President Ford has told a political associate that he will dismiss James Keogh front his post as director of the United States Informatibn Agency; the associate said today. There was no indication when the President would act.

title: City Budget Imbalance Tied to Misreading of Economy,
description: Mayor Beame's announcement Thursday that his carefully drawn $11.1billion expense budget, not yet three months old, was being thrown off balance badly by inflation and a turndown in the economy raises the question of how good he and his advisers are, as economic forecasters. In a brief statement and in an equally brief impromptu news conference, Mr. Beame blamed higher interest rates, higher energy costs and higher welfare costs resulting from high unemployment for pushing city expenditures $200million higher than he anticipated.

title: $2,500 Offer to Eagleton
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (UPI)Missouri's Republican challenger for a United States Senate seat, former Representative Thomas B. Curtis, said today he would pay Senator Thomas F. Eagleton $2,500 if Mr. Eagleton would debate him. Mr. Curtis said the offer matched the highest honorarium paid to Mr. Eagleton for a speaking engagement last year.

title: Erik Bruhn Tries Hand As an Actor
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 13Erik Bruhn, who danced his way to world fame in ballet, made his debut as an actor last night playing a wildeyed Samurai in Akiro Kurosawa's Rashomon to generally favorable reviews.

title: Kuwait Extends Interest In St. Martins Property
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) The Kuwait Investment Office has purchased more interest in the St. Martins Property Corporation, it was announced here today.

title: MENTAL CASES ADD 10 HOTEL WORRIES
description: Murders and muggings have become a constant fear in recent years of the elderly or infirm who live in the socalled welfare or singleroomoccupancy hotels.

title: Lois Lenski, AuthorIllustrator Of Children's Books, Dies at 80
description: Lois Lenski, author and illustrator of children's books for more than 40 years, died Wednesday at her home in Tarpon Springs, Fla. She was 80 years old.

title: DECLINE CONTINUES IN GRAINFED BEEF
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The production of grainfed beef continued to decline sharply in August, but total meat production remained on the rise, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

title: State Rights Panel Tells Little League To Let Girls Play
description: The State Division of Human Rights has ruled that all Little League chapters in the state must allow girls to play on their teams.

title: Company Reports
description: Company Reports

title: South Vietnam: New Martyrs, New Paupers and New Friends
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13On the surface, it looks like fiery 1963, the last year of President Ngo Dinh Diem. With disquieting regularity, desperate men are dousing themThe Talk selves with gasoof line and burning to death on the Saigon streets of Saigon. In the last four months, six men  three of them war veterans  have immolated themselves in public. A seventh, a monk, was saved by the police on Sept. 2 as he burned in front of Saigon's rococo city hall.

title: CHEMICAL MAKERS PLAN SUIT PLEAS
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13. (AP)Eight of the nation's largest chemical companies, including E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. and the Allied Chemical Company, plan to plead no defense to a Federal criminal charge that they fixed prices in the $480million dye industry, attorneys for the companies said today. If the pleas are accepted, eoch of the giant companies could be fined no more than $50,000.

title: FARM ROLE CALLED SLIGHT ON PRICES
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13  Participants in the White House Conference on food and agriculture here today agreed that there was little they could do, wanted to do or dared do at the farm level to reduce rising prices to the consumer.

title: French Design a 10Franc Coin Elevating Money to Art Form
description: PARIS, Sept. 13Modern art will make its appearance on a French coin.

title: U.S. JUDGE REJECTS DEAL FOR JACOBSEN
description: DALLAS, Sept. 13 (UPI)Refusing to recognize a Justice Department pleabargain agreement with Jake Jacobsen, former attorney for the Associated Milk Producers, Inc., Judge Robert M. Hill of United States District Court said today that it would not be in the interest of justice to drop bribery charges against Mr. Jacobsen.

title: Power Here Cut 5%; Temperature Hits 88
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reduced power by 5 per cent to 200,000 customers in Manhattan south of 42d Street yesterday between 1:34 P.M. and 4:55 P.M., causing airconditioners and elevators to operate at lower efficiency on a day when the temperature reached a high of 88 degrees at 2:20 P.M.

title: State and Jersey. Get 6.8Million Job Aid
description: State and local governments in New York and New Jersey will receive $8,587,772 in Federal funds, providing about 1,700 new jobs for the unemployed, as the initial step in Preident Ford's program for expanded publicservice employment.

title: The Nixon Documents
description: In approving an agreement which recognized former President Nixon's title to his White House tapes and documents, President Ford and his legal advisers followed a questionable precedent when it would have been most appropriate to reexamine it.

title: Bulldozers of Progress Are Destroying The City's Buried Historic Treasure
description: In 1916, when workmen were tunneling to build the Seventh Avenue subway, the constructiongang foreman was James A. Kelly. A sometime vaudeville singer, he wore, even underground, a threepiece suit with a watchchain across his vest.

title: Jurors Are Told McCrane Urged Payments for Work Never Done
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13 (UPI)The treasurer of Florida's Hialeah Park Racecourse testified today that at the behest of former New Jersey Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. the track sent a Cherry Hill public relations concern two $1,000 checks in 1969 for services the company never performed.

title: Conflict Brews in Volkswagen Over Possible American Plant
description: BONNa conflict is brewing between Rudolph Leiding, head of the giant Volkswagen company, and other members of the company's board of directors about whether to build an assembly plant in the United States. Consequently a decision is not expected this year.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:15 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2:10 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2:15 P.M.)Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. (TelevisionChannel 11, 2:15 P.M.) (RadloWMCA, 2:15 P.M.)

title: Arabs Seek a Palestine Debate at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 13 The Arab countries presented a formal request tonight that the United Nations General Assembly, which is scheduled to open next Tuesday, consider the question of Palestine as separate item on its agenda.

title: Boston School Buses Stoned a 2d Day, but City Is Mostly Calm
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13Escorted by police motorcycles, buses carried 25 black students to South Boston High School today as most of the city went peacefully through its second day of courtordered integration.

title: Dr. David Sashin, 74, Dies; Orthopedic Surgeon Here
description: Dr. David Sashin, an orthopedic surgeon with offices in Manhattan and Great Neck, L. I., died at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L. I., on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and lived at 14 Pinetree Lane, Roslyn Heights, L. I.

title: 3 TO ASK NEW DELAY IN COVERUP TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Lawyers for three Watergate defendants, John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, plan to appeal Judge John J. Sirica's refusal yesterday to dismiss the indictments against them or delay the coverup trial, now slated to begin Oct. 1.

title: Books of The Times
description: You'll adore my apartment, said a young Newport matron in September, 1950, to her visitor from Matunuck, R. I., while having luncheon it Christie's, at present headquarters for America's Cup buffs. It's the head groom's apartment of a house a man built mostly for his horses, and now it's empty. Seven rooms are a lot to scrub, but it's so convenient to Bailey's Beach that you can get there at the right time and have the housework all done. The visitor was duly impressed with the spacious seven rooms. Then the friend pointed to some planking resting on a saw horse. Walk up there, she said, and open the door.

title: Notes on People
description: Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy from its creation in 1970 until he resigned last month, will return to the academic world and write a book. The 35yearold Mr. Whitehead, who has a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was once on the staff, will divide his time between being a research associate at M. I. T. and a fellow of the Institute of Politics at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of government. During his tenure as former President Richard M. Nixon's chief communications adviser, Mr. Whitehead often made controversial statements that television network officials found worrisome. The book he plans to write, he said, will deal with communication policy in the United States from the perspective of history. Communications policy has remained largely static since the passage of the 1934 Communications Act, said Mr. Whitehead. There is, as a result, an important need for a reexamination.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT OFF 04% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Industrial production declined 0.4 Of cent in August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The drop was the first, significant downturn in this key indicator of economic activity since the energy shortage period of last winter and spring.

title: WINE TALK
description: Robert Drouhin, head of the prestigious Burgundy firm of Joseph Drouhin, showed up in New York last week to discuss his own wines, the wines of Burgundy in general, and to offer a few of his wines for a tasting at the Wine Writers Circle.

title: Suspect Drifted Here for Last 4 Years
description: The man who is a suspect in the murder of 11 West Side women is a former convict and Idrug addict who has been drifting from one cheap hotel to another in the city for the last four years.

title: Television
description: Television

title: SIMON: NO LETUP IN INFLATION RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, said today he expects inflation to continue at about current rates for the rest of the year, thereby establishing a virtual consensus among top Administration economic advisers that little relief is in sight.

title: Miss Reff Bride of Maurice Sieradzki
description: Elizabeth L. Reff and Maurice Sieradzki, counsel to Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, were married yesterday evening at the Regency Hotel, State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts performed the ceremony.

title: P.S.C. Says Con Ed Is Making a Profit
description: The staff of the Public Service Commission said yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company, far from being on the verge of receivership, was making money, a profitable trend having set in last May. According to the staff's findings, in July the company's income was $50  million, or $12  million more than it had projected.

title: Flexible Amnesty Plan Is Reported Set by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 13 (AP)  Administration sources said today that President Ford's conditional amnesty plan would require repatriated war resisters to spend between six and 24 months in alternative service. Mr. Ford will issue his amnesty program next week, these sources said.

title: CATHOLICS OPPOSE EASED SOVIET TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) The United States Catholic Conference today gave its support to a Congressional amendment to deny mostfavorednation trading status to the Soviet Union. The Most Rev. James S. Rausch of Minneapolis, general secretary of the conference, said its support of the amendment by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, was given because of the continuing restriction on basic human rights in the Soviet Union.

title: TRAIN CORD PULLED 53 HURT IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) More than 50 persons were injured, seven seriously, Friday when one elevated commuter train hit the rear of a second train on which a passenger pulled an emergency cord.

title: LAND IS OPTIONED FOR COAST REFUGE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13A land conservation organizetron based here announced tolay that it had obtained an tien to buy 38,000 acres of a salt manufacturer's property for $18.5million that would alrhost double the size of the San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge and make it the largest publicly owned Urban refuge in the world.

title: Lottery Chief to Testify
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The head Of the New Jersey Lottery will meet next Thursday in Washington with a top Justice Department official for his second discussion there in two weeks on Federal lottery laws. The director, Charles. C. Carella, will meet with William S. Lynch, chief of the department's organized crime section. The meetings stem from an investigation into possible violations of Federal laws by the 13 states with lotteries.

title: Dow Hits 12Year Low
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in active trading, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average down 14.55 points to 627.19, its lowest closing level in almost 12 years. Details on Page 35.

title: Ford Doffs His Jacket At Warm Capital Party
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  President and Mrs. Ford forsook the airconditioning of the White House tonight to join in a sweltering party convened to honor the President's official photographer, David H. Kinnerly. The Fords stayed for almost two hours. The gathering of 70 guests was held in the threestory townhouse of John Full, a pbotographer with United Press International.

title: Homer in 11 th by Cub Rookie Wins Second Game
description: Having suffered from battle fatigue following their disheartening 25  inning defeat by the Cardinals early Thursday morning and having been shellshdeled by the same Redbirds, 125, that night, the Mets showed early signs of a quick recovery last night.

title: BROWNING TO CLOSE 2 OR 3 OF 10 STORES
description: Browning Fifth Avenue, Inc., the men's clothing chain, plans to close two or three of its 10 stores in the metropolitan New York area but will continue to operate its Fifth Avenue store.

title: OIL OVERCHARGE SEEN BY SAMILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Federal Energy Administrator, John C. Sawhill, said today that a number of oil companiei had overcharged consumers by $100million in 1974 under a regulation that let them recover twice their costs for ome crude oil.

title: 12 Killed by Bomb in Madrid Restaurant
description: MADRID, Sept. 13 (Reuters) A bomb exploded, in a restaurant near the national police headquarters in central Madrid today, killing at least 12 people and injuring more than 40.

title: FRANCE ASKS U.S. TO REDUCE RATES
description: PARIS, Sept. 13The French Government has taken up a new cause in the struggle for financial order in the world by urging the United States, most recently at last weekend's gathering of Finance Ministers, to reduce its shortterm interest, rates, according to informed French sources.

title: Golf Results
U.S. AIDES CRITICIZED ON AID TO TURKEY
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 13Representative Lester Wolff charged today that forces are at work within the State Department to impede Congressional efforts to cut off aid to Turkey if she goes ahead with her decision to resume cultivation of opium poppies.

title: Outflow Sets a Record
description: The nation's mutual savings banks lost a record of $800million in savings last month, as depositors withdrew their money to reinvest in higheryielding securities.

title: Music: Ford's Fiddler Under Roof
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Eugene Fodor offered an exuberantly played program of encores last night at the White House as entertainment for the first state dinner during Gerald R. Ford's Presidency at which an artist was invited to perform.

title: Schoenberg Center Site Is Dedicated at U.S.C.
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13The University of Southern California dedicated today the site of the new Arnold Schoenberg Institute on the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth.

title: Legal Aid Lawyers Renew Offer To Submit Issues to Arbitration
description: Striking Legal Aid Society lawyers yesterday renewed their efforts to submit contract issues in their threedayold strike to binding arbitrationa position rejected on Thursday by the society's management, which offered to submit the dispute to mediation.

title: HOUSE PANEL HEARS OF RECORD REMOVAL,
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Government employes removed Government records and gave them to a United States official for use in his defense on bribery and perjury charges, a House committee has been told.

title: Budget Austerity Backed At Parley on Food Prices
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13  Strong support for the Ford Administration's advocacy of budget austerity and monetary restraint emerged among business and trade association leaders attending a conference on foodprice inflation here today, and Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said this was one of the messages that he would take back to the President.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The staff of the Public Service Commission said that the Consolidated Edison Company far from being on the verge of receivership, was making money, a profitable trend having set in last May. According, to the staff's findings, in July the company's income was $50million, or $12million more than it had projected.

title: Kotar s Grin Now a Happy Giant Puzzle
description: Doug Kotar has this strange grin that has puzzled coaches from high school to the pros. Tomorrow, the New York Giants hope it will puzzle Coach George Allen of the Washington Redskins.

title: Questions Raised By Art Alterations
description: At what point in the life of a work of art does a technical alteration constitute an artistic revision? Under what, if any, conditions is it permissible for the heirs or executors of an artist's estate or anyone else, for that matterto authorize posthumous alterations in the work? And how are such changes, once executed, to be regarded? Should a work of art that is altered after the artist's death still be considered a legitimate part of his oeuvre?

title: Local Governments Face Delays In RevenueSharing Fund Snarl
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)Some 6,000 state and local governments may face delays of three months or more in receiving millions of dollars in Federal revenuesharing aid because they have not filed the proper forms.

title: Miss Blalock Gets Lead by Shot at 69
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 13. (AP)Jane Blalock, on a misty, cold day, shot a sparkling 69 today and captured the firstround lead in the $40,000 Charity golf classic.

title: SINATRA AND TROUPE PLAN A 9CITY TOUR
description: Frank Sinatra will be accompanied on a ninecity tour next month by Woody Herman and his orchestra, Pat Henry, a comedian, and the Veterans, an acrobatic comedy troupe from Stockholm. The tour will start Oct. 2 in Boston.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Soviet Journal Wary on New Airliner
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13An influential monthly journal here has disclosed some Soviet scientific concern about the possible environmental hazard created by the TU144 supersonic transport being developed by the Soviet Union.

title: Art: Drawing Reborn in de Kooning's Painted Women
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Something funny happened to women in 1950; They got roughed up, in art, in quite a new way, and an ancient, misleading, perfunctory dignity was withdrawn from them was done in France by Jean Dubuffet in his Corps de Dame series, and it was done in this country by Willem de Kooning. Women had never been seen like that before; Dubuffet's intrusive gougings and de Kooning's outsized ribaldry made a formidable combination.

title: Radio
description: 8.9 A.M., WQXR. Symphony No. 5, Schubert; Cello Concerm in B flat, Boccherini; Overture to Olympia, Kraus; English Horn Concertino, Donizetti; Symphony No. 2, Tchaikovsky; Marche de Triomphe and Second Air de Trompettes, Charpentier; Cortege Solennel in G, Glazunov; Piano Concerto in F minor, Henselt.

title: Anker Reinstates CoPrincipals Removed by Fuentes Opponents
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker last night reinstated, for the time being, two coprincipals of Public School 188 on the Lower East Side, where parents demonstrated and boycotted the school this week to protest the removal of the two men.

title: GARROW'S LAWYER TO PREPARE APPEAL
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP)Frank Armani, whose defense of Robert Garrow focused public attention on the issue of lawyers ethics, will prepare Mr. Garrow's appeal of the murder conviction.

title: Curb Urged on Repricing of Shelf Items
description: MINEOLA, LI., Sept. 13Alfonse M. D'Amato, Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, said that a twomonth investigation by his staff into five major supermarket chains in the Hempstead area had disclosed as many as five price markings on the same package, and that price increases ranged between 10 and 15 per cent.

title: 4 Alleged Abductors Held After Siege
description: Two men held hostage for five hours in their home in the Woodbridge section of the Bronx were safe early yester day after three alleged gunmen surrendered and a fourth apparently fell asleep, enabling the hostages to overpower him.

title: Julian Davis, Gold MinerPoet Of Cripple Creek, Is Dead at 72
description: Julian Oavis, who had been a gold miner and a poet, picturing the lore of the days of hunting for gold, died last Friday in his native Cripple Creek, Colo., where he lived most of his life. He was 72 years old.

title: ExConvicts Go Right On From Training to Jobs
description: It was a revival meeting, a session of prayer, a moment of theater, but officially it was graduation day yesterday for 32 exconvicts who had completed 13 weeks of job training through the cooperation of city, state and Federal agencies and 10 private corporations.

title: Boston U. Tops Maine by 76
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP)A sophomore running back, Glenn Murphy, scored from the 1yard line at 5 minutes 43 seconds of the second period to pace Boston University to a 76 Yankee Conference football victory over the University of Maine tonight.

title: Ah! Sweet Mystery of Life, at Last I've Found Thee
description: Ready for Bulling Facts Is Facts Old Dad's Wisdom A Matter of Pull

title: 5 Canadian Boats Seized
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 13 (AP) Five Canadian trawlers have teen seized off the coast of Waeshington for allegedly fishing illegally within United States territorial waters, the Coast Guard announced today. The Coast Guard had first announctd the seizure of two of the trawlers, the Wendy Mureen and the Arlene. A spokesman later said the trawlers Silver Ann, Debbie Mack and Dixie also were saized.

title: Mayors to Lobby for Mass Transit Aid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13A conference of mayors from big, medium and small cities adopted the suggestion of Mayor Beame of New York today to mount an intensive broadbased effort in Washington for more mass transit operating subsidies.

title: Supreme Court NonVote
description: The Democratic judicial convention this evening New York will choose four new candidates to run for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and the Bronx) and probably redesignate a fifth whose term is expiring. Is this convention, if it can be called that, for real?

title: Sports News Briefs.
description: STAMFORD, England, Sept. 13 (AP)A Soviet Olympic star, Vladimir Laniugin, surged into the lead in the world threeday equestrian championships at Burghley House today while West Germany led in the team event. United States riders were close behind the leaders.

title: New Yorker, 25, Is Israel Piano Winner
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13 (AP)Emanuel Ax, 25 years old, of New York, has been named winner of the first prize of $5,000 in the Artur Rubinstein International Piano Competition. Mr. Rubinstein, the 88yearold virtuoso, was one of the judges, and he gave Mr. Ax a bear hug after the winners were announced last night.

title: Fumes Evacuate Town
description: BELOXI, Miss., Sept. 13 (UPI) Firemen sprayed water on compressed hydrogen chloride as leaking from a tanker truck last night, unwittingly creating lydrochloric acid fumes that forced the evacuation of 2,500 )ersons for about eight hours.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater, Puccini's Manon Lescaut, 2; Cherubini's Medea, 8.

title: Grant Game Tomorrow Will Not Be Televised
description: There will be no telecast of the New York Giants regularseason home opener against the Washington Redskins tomorrow at Yale Bowl.

title: Nixon's 5 Days at Annenberg Estate: An Isolated Visit in Regal Comfort
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Sept. 13One of the few regular visitors, to the desert resorts of the Coachella Valley at this time of year is the sloping wall of smog that spills through the San Gorgonio Pass at nightfall like ghostly reminder of the Indian legends in which dead spirits walk the awesome brow of the San Jacinto Mountains.

title: Fighting in Prison
description: STILLWATER, Minn., Sept. 14 (UPI)Fighting broke out at Stillwater State Prison yesterday over the playing of torn toms by Indian inmates. The situation was quickly brought under control.

title: St. Clair Linked to a Plea By Haldeman for Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Hours before President Nixon made his resignation speech on Aug. 8, his attorney, James D. St. Clair, asked H. R. Haldeman's attorneys to send over a package containing proposals for general pardons, according to informed sources.

title: Car Sales. Up 13.4% for 10 Days
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13Domestic car sales climbed by 13.4% per cent in early September, the best performance for the period in recent years and, only the third time in 1974 that sales have topped the 1973 levels.

title: People and Business
description: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Lewis A. Engman, said yesterday that the commission would step up its enforcement of antitrust laws as a means of reducing inflation.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Export interest in soybean oil developed during trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, resulting in a sharp rise in soybean futures prices and an increase of the permissible ly, limit for most soybean oil contracts.

title: Chase Sets 9% Level
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank planned yesterday that it planned to raise the interest Irate it charges on commercial loans to small businesses cent. 9 per cent from 9 per cent. The bank also said it would raise rates on consumer installment loans, bringing them up to levels set by several other big banks recently.

title: BRITISH TO PAY MORE FOR GUYANESE SUGAR
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Sept. 13Britain has agreed to buy 85,000 tons of sugar from Guyana at 140 ($323) a ton. A statement yesterday by the Foreign Affairs Ministry indicated that the British Government had accepted the terms of a $27.5million deal worked out here last Monday by Prime Minister Forbes Burnham and Britain's Minister for Agriculture, Federick Peart.

title: FRANCE ASKS U.S. TO REDUCE RATES
description: PARIS, Sept. 13The French Government has taken up a new cause in the struggle for financial order in the world by urging the United States, most recently at last weekend's gathering of Finance Ministers, to reduce its shortterm interest rates, according to informed French sources.

title: Running Backs Hold Spotlight As Major Elevens Play Today
description: Archie Griffin of Ohio State, Tony Dorsett of Pittsburgh, Anthony Davis of Southern California, Tony Davis of Nebraska, Mike Esposito of Boston College and many others will start carrying footballs today when most major college teams begin what is expected to be another big year for running backs. A few of the major teams started last week, while Notre Dame and Georgia Tech played Monday night before a national television audience.

title: Jets Look Ahead, See Some Hope
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 13 If last Saturday's game with Oakland, the final exhibition encounter, had been a dress rehearsal, the Jets show would have been closed before it opened. If it had been military maneuvers for a war, the war would have called off.

title: Standard Time Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The Senate Commerce Committee has approved a Housepassed bill to return the United States to standard time from Oct. 27 to Feb. 23, 1975.

title: LAND DEAL IS SET BYPAPER COMPANY
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the United States Steel Corporation for the acquisition of 50,000 acres of timberland owned by U. S. Steel in Merger Baldwin County in News Alabama. The purchase price for the property, which is across Mobile Bay from Mobile, Ala., is $65million, to be paid in cash. The sale does not include any mineral rights.

title: JULIE EISENHOWER TO BE TV HOSTESS
description: Julie Nixon Eisenhower, the younger daughter of former President Richard M. Nixon, will substitute for Barbara Walters as moderator of the syndicated television series Not for Women Only during one of the three weeks Miss Walters will be absent.

title: Northern Illinois Coal Mine Is Closed After 49 Years
description: WILMINGTON, Ill., Sept. 13 (UPI)  The Wilmington Coal Mine, described by its manager as the last coal mine in northern Illinois, closed yesterday after 47 years of operation in Kankakee County.

title: Bus Strike Talks Resume
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 131 (UPI)Talks resumed yesterday under a news blackout in an effort to end the 33dayold bus strike in four southern California counties. More than 700 mechanics walked off their lobs Aug. 12 in a wage and, fringe benefits dispute. The strike affects 450,000 commuters in Los Angeles, Riverside and San Bernardino Counties and parts of Orange County.

title: Justice Rinaldi's Reelection Is Assured
description: State Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi was assured of reelection when he was nominated yesterday by the Democratic and Republican parties in Brooklyn and Staten Island at their judicial conventions.

title: ExConvict Called Slayer of 11 Women
description: The District Attorney's office said yesterday that a 26yearold former convict had unequivocally implicated himself in 11 murders of women on the West Side during the last two years.

title: BERT R. J. HASSELL, GREATCIRCLE PILOT
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 13 (UPI)Bert R. J. Hassell, an aviation pioneer, who held Pilot's License No. 20, died yesterday at Rockford Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Peterson Gains Pole In Michigan
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Sept. 13A driver who had never before raced on an oval course won the pole position and the Indianapolis 500 winner was the slowest in qualifying for tomorrow's first race in the International Race of Champions series.

title: Hopes for Mozambique Amity Voiced
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 13A small advance contingent of black guerrilla troops of the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique arrived today and promptly had lunch with tough Portuguese marines who had fought the Frelimo troops in long guerrilla war.

title: Soviet ABlast Reported
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 13 (AP) A probable underground nuclear explosion in the Kazakhstan area of the Soviet Union was recorded at seismological observatories in Sweden and Norway this morning, a spokesman for Stockholm's Uppsala seismological Institute said. Norway's NORSAR seismologicall observatory near Oslo also detected the blast.

title: Ford in Michigan on Oct. 10
description: LANSING, Mich., Sept. 13 (AP)President Ford will return to his home state to be guest of honor at a Republican fundraising dinner on Oct. 10 in Detroit's Cobo Hall, it was announced today. The $50aplate dinner will collect money for Gov. William G. Milliken's reelectlon campaign.

title: Australia Factory Site Would Peril Bird Migration,
description: NEWCASTLE, Australia, Sept. 7Swirling down to the mangrove swamps and mudflats, huge flocks of birds have been arriving at Kooragang Island in an annual migration from the Northern Hemisphere that is believed to have been taking place for thousands of years.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Other Games on Today's Schedule British Football Scores on WQXR Thursday's Fight

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A State Superior Court jury convicted an East Orange man yesterday on charges of taking part in the murder of a Black Muslim leader, James Shabazz, in the driveway of the victim's Newark home a year ago.

title: OUSTER EXPECTED FOR U.S.I.A. HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 13President Ford has told a political associate that he will dismiss James Keogh from his post as director of the United States Information Agency, the associate said today. There was no indication when the President would act.

title: Budget Austerity Backed At Parley on Food Prices
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13  Strong support for the Ford Administration's advocacy of budget austerity and monetary restraint emerged among business and trade association leaders attending a conference on foodprice inflation here today, and Secretary of Agriculture Earl L Butz said this was one of the messages that he would take back to the President.

title: Turkey Is Ineligible
description: Cutting off American military aid to Turkey may, as Secretary of State Kissinger contends, be ineffective and counterproductive so far as getting the Turks roll back their occupation of Cyprus is concerned; but it is mandatory under the law. In pretending for nearly a month to be studying this question, the State Department is clearly stalling, as it has stalled at every point since the outset of the Cyprus tragedy when action was called for to demonstrate this country's disapproval of aggression.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: FirstPlace Clubs Falter; Red Sox Pick Up Ground
description: It was Jimmy Breslin, writing of the earlyvintage Mets, who said, Can't anybody here play this game

title: Nastase Gets Lead as Rain Halts Match
description: CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Sept. 13Ilie Nastase's drive toward the $10,000 top prize in the Perspectus Tournament was stalled by a thunderstorm midway through his quarterfinal match with Ray Ruffels of Australia tonight at the Bradford Bath and Tennis Club.

title: $65Million Timber Sale
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle with the United States Steel Corporation for the acquisition of about 50,000 acres of timberland at a purchase price of about $65million. Details on Page 42.

title: MERCHANTS FEAR RALLY IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13  Merchants in the vicinity of the North Ward, whose shops were hit by four days of fires and looting last week, voiced apprehension today about Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's approval of a demonstration planned for the area tomorrow.

title: 18to 21 Weddings by Clerk Go Smoothly
description: One year ago, the City Clerk's office in Manhattan refused to marry George Davis, then 26 years old, and Lorianne Young, then 18, because neither of thg wouldhe bride's parents were present. Miss Young's mother had recently died, and the young woman was reluctant to seek her father's permission.

title: House Buyers Ignore Newark Trouble
description: NEWARK, Sept. 13 Some 500 persons attended an auction here today for innercity land and housing that netted nearly $200,000 and disaproved fears that the four days of disturbances last week would frighten buyers away.

title: Rabin Says He and Ford Agree on Drive for Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel concluded four days of talks with President Ford today and asserted that Israel and the United States were agreed on how to proceed in Middle East diplomacy and on the need to keep Israel militarily strong.

title: FORD AIDES SILENT ON LINK OF PARDON AND NIXON HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Presidential spokesmen declined today for the sixth straight day to say specifically how reports of former President Richard M. Nixon's poor health figured in the President's decision to pardon Mr. Nixon only a few days after Mr. Ford had indicated he would await legal process before making a decision.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Several pieces of concrete, one of them 10 by 4 feet in size, fell onto northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive about 3:15 A.M. yesterday near overpass at 58th Street. Highways Department crewmen, who closed the lanes until 4:20 A.M. to clean up the debris, reported that the concrete pieces were about two inches thick and had fallen from a reinforced concrete structure overhead. At about 11 A.M. the lanes were again closed for a brief time while workmen took away some more overhead concrete that appeared loose and about to fall.

title: Prisoners at Attica Ask $100Million Damages
description: A suit seeking $100million in damages was filed in Federal District Court here yesterday by lawyers for prisoners from the State Correctional Facility at Attica.

title: LAND DEAL IS SET BY PAPERCOMPANY
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the United States Steel Corporation for the acqulsition of 50,000 acres of timberland owned by U. S. Steel in Baldwin County in Alabama. The purchase price for the property, which is across Mobile Bay from Mobile, Ala., is $65million, to be paid in cash. The sale does not inelude any mineral rights.

title: Subpoena From Protesters Opposed by Nixon Lawyer
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 13 (AP)An attorney for former President Richard M. Nixon has formally objected to subpoena seeking materials from Mr. Nixon in connection woth a Billy Graham Day rally here nearly three years ago.

title: Wayne Bishop, Investigator For Senate Watergate Unit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (UPI)Wayne Bishop, former chief field investigator for the Senate Select Watergate Committee, was found dead of heart attack in his apartment today. He was 54 years old.

title: ROSE KOCH
description: Rose Koch, president of the Republic Container Corporation since the death of her husband, Louis, in 1958, died Thursday at the home of her daughter in Neponsit, L.X. She was 85 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South.

title: Delegation From China
description: URBANA, Ill., Sept. 13 (UPI) Ten plant scientists from mainland Chinathe third of several scholarly delegations to viist the United States this year joined more than 2,000 Illinois farmers on a tour of crop production research on the University of Illinois South Farm yesterday.

title: Dow Hits 12Year Low
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in active trading, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average down 14.55 points to. 627.19, its lowest closing level in almost 12 years. Details on Page 35.

title: 3 Japanese Threaten to Kill 9 Seized at an Embassy in Hague
description: THE. HAGUE, Saturday, Sept. 14Three armed members of Japanese tourist organization seized part of the French Embassy here yesterday and threatened to kill the Ambassador and eight other hostages one by one unless a comrade was freed from prison in France.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: BRITISH TO PAY MORE FOR GUYANESE SUGAR
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Sept. 13 Britain has agreed to buy 85,000 tons of sugar from Guyana at 140 ($323) a ton. A statement yesterday by the Foreign Affairs Ministry indicated that the British Government had accepted the terms of a $27.5million deal worked out here last Monday by Prime Minister Forbes Burnham and Britain's Minister for Agriculture, Federick Peart.

title: Planes for Sale: A FullDress U.S. Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13With a brass band as an opener and a musical comedy as a finale, Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger spent the day today trying to prevail upon four European defense ministers to buy an American fighter plane.

title: MOST OPEC LANDS. AGREE ON 57% RIS FOR TAXES ON OIL
description: VIENNA, Sept. 13All the major petroleumexporting countries except Saudi Arabia agreed today to a tax increase of neatly 5 per cent on oil exports by foreign oil bmpanies.

title: Outflow Sets a Record
description: The nation's mutual savings banks lost a record of $800million in savings last month as depositors withdrew their money to reinvest in higheryielding securities.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ETHNOCENTRIC New York is a city that takes its divergent ethnic vitality in stride, something to take pride in so long as no fuss is made. This weekend, however, there is to be a fuss. The Armenian Diocese (6860710) is joining with the city to celebrate the city's ethnic groups at a One World Festival starting at 1 o'clock this afternoon and tomorrow afternoon at the park adjoining St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 35th Street between Second and First Avenues.

title: Nastase Gets Lead as Rain Halts Match
description: CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Sept. 13Ilie Nastase's drive toward the $10,000 top prize in the Perspectus Tournament was stalled by a thunderstorm midway through is quarterfinal match with Ray Ruffels of Australia tonight at the Bradford Bath and Tennis Club.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Tiffany & Co is introducing a new green gemstone from East Africa that is even more brilliant and durable than an emerald.

title: New Plywood Announced
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Potlach Corporation announced today it planned to introduce a new plywood, using a core of directionally oriented reconstituted wood fiber. The company's president, Richard Madden, said the company would invest $8million to $9million in a new automated plant at Lewiston, Idaho, to use the new process. Initial output next year will be equal to about 204 million square feet of quarterinch plywood.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day International International National Metropolitan The Other News Energy Quotation of the Day Sports

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: ExConvict Called Staffer of 11 Women
description: The Manhattan District Attorneys office said yesterday that a 26yearold former convict had unequivocally implicated himself in 11 murders of women on the West Side during the last two years.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, Sept. 13For the first time in his six years as head baseball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University, graduation last June presented a major problem to John Orsino. Last spring, the Knights compiled a 229 wonlost record, the most successful in their history. Helping the team achieve gig success were seven seniors who have to be replaced.

title: Bridge
description: One of the least popular characters in any bridge club is the Result Merchant. His first reaction to any postmortem problem is to say: You could have made it if you had played  or, If you had bid soandso it would have turned out better.

title: Cahill and Kugler Testify Sherwin
description: FREEHOLD, Sept. 13  Former Gov. William T, Cahill and his State Attorney General appeared today as witnesses in hearing on a motion seeking new trial for Paul J. Sherwin, once the Cahill administration's Secretary of State, who was convicted two years ago on highway bidrigging and kickback charges.

title: Iron Scrap Quota Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Commerce Department said today that the ferrous scrap export quota will be 2.1 million tons in the fourth quarter, unchanged from three previous quarters. The department said about 1.9 million tons will be allocated under the same formulas used Previously to countries in proportion to their use of United States ferrous scrap between 1970 and 1973.

title: WHITE HOUSE DEFERS. NIXON TAPE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The White House has halted the planned turnover to former President Richard M. Nixon of his tapes and records because the special Watergate prosecutor's office argued that the material was necessary for the continuing investigation of the Watergate conspiracy, an informed source said today.

title: CHICAGO TODAY ENDS AND FORD MOURNS IT
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI)1 Chicago Today, afternoon sister, of The Chicago Tribune, ceased publication today with a final issue that carried a letter from President Ford on the front page.

title: MOST OPEC LANDS AGREE ON ro RISE FOR TAXES ON OIL
description: VIENNA, Sept. 13All the major petroleumexporting countries except Saudi Arabia agreed today to a tax increase of nearly 5 per cent on oil exports by foreign oil companies.

title: BLANCHE DICKINSON
description: Blanche Schnitzer Dickinson, economist and marketing consultant, died Monday at a medical center in Pitssfield, Mass. She was 70 years old and lived in Washington. Her husband Melville D. Dickinson died in 1954.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Most of the major petroleumexporting countries agreed to raise their taxes almost 5 per cent on oil produced and sold by foreign countries. Saudi Arabia, however, the world's largest exporter, refused to apply the tax increase adopted by all the other members of the 13:nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Companies at their meeting in Vienna, until she completes negotiations with her foreign partners in the Arabian American Oil Company, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Petroleum said. Saudi Arabia is trying to. increase its ownership share in the company from 60 per cent to 100 per cent. A key issue in the negotiations is the price that her American partners will have to pay for Saudi oil in the future if the Government acquires full ownership of the company. [1:8.]

title: Integration in Boston
description: The resistance to United States District Court Judge Arthur W. Garrity's order that the Boston schools be integrated is very real and deeply emotional. News stories and television images flowing from that city over the last few days have been reminiscent of similarly ugly scenes during the Southern school integration crises in the late fifties. But the similarities are more apparent than real because of the high quality of leadership Boston provided by a variety of elected and appointed officials and by a broad spectrum of civic leaders, both black and white.

title: FORD AIDES SILENT ON LINK OF PARDON AND NIXON HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Presidential spokesmen declined today for the sixth straight day to say specifically how reports of former President Richard M. Nixon's poor health figured in the President's decision to pardon Mr. Nixon only a few days after Mr. Ford had indicated he would await legal process before making a decision.

title: New Archbishop of York Is Appointed in England
description: LONDON, Sept. 13  The Right Rev. Stuart Yarworth Blanch, a farmer's son who was a navigator in the Royal Air Force during World War II, was today appointed Archbishop of York, the second highest post in the Church of England.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Acrostic puzzle

title: Cup Race Becalmed
description: The third race of the AmerIca's Cup series between Courageous, the United States defender, and Southern Cross of Australia was abandoned yesterday off Newport, R.I., after the yachts were becalmed and could not finish within the 5hour time limit. Courageous leads the fourofsevenrace series, 20. Details in Section 5.

title: Closing of Old Iron and Steel Company in Roebling Idles 1,400
description: ROEBLINGA fourth attempt to revive the Colorado Fuel & Iron steel plant here has ended in failure, thus dooming hopes in the Trenton area that the 1,400 people who lost their jobs on June 30 would be reemployed.

title: Mary land Halted by Alabama
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 14Alabama jumped to an early lead over Maryland today and then came up with the big plays at the end to win by 2116.

title: Suburban Madison Fears It's Going Urban
description: MADISON  This Morris County borough is an established community, with many mature buildings and little room for growth. The greatest concern here is maintaining the suburban flavor of Medison, for its re sidents recently have had to face some urban problems including increasing vandalisin and the possible need for lowincome housing.

title: Diane F. DeOrchis, Nurse, Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. E. DeOrchis of Kings Point, L. L, and Killingsworth, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Frances DeOrchis, to Nils VogthEriksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jens VogthEriksen of Oslo, Norway. The wedding will take place next June.

title: Policemen Learn Spanish
description: GARDEN CITYIn an effort to establish a better relationship with the Hispanic communities, 75 policemen have enrolled in a course in Spanish conversation.

title: Fulbright Leaves China
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (AP)  A congressional delegation led by Senator S. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, wound up a 12day tour of China today and left Shanghai for home, a Peking broadcast reported.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board

title: Television
description: IMMEDIATELY after Gerald Ford made his Presidential acceptance speech, Walter Cronkite, in whom I once had:faith, said on CBS television that the speech had been a good one though it had been flawed by grammatical errors and non sequiturs. Mr. Cronkite then asked us to declare honeymoon on our criticism of such lapses. How is a honeymoon declared? Who has vested in Mr. Cronkite the power to let precision of speech go to hell in a handbasket? This honeymoon is one I do not intend to take part in, let alone declare; I am too btisy attending the funerals of decent and lawabiding words.

title: The Coming Crisis for the Arts: Who Going To Foot the. Bill?
description: FUNDING for the performing arts a relatively arcane subject that usually doesn't interest anyone except us poor beggars who have to rattle the tin cupis now threatening to become a topic of national debate as a result of a report recently issued by the Ford Foundation. The report, which was four years in the making and cost $500,000 to produce, is titled The Finances of the Arts. What this weighty, massive, 446page document manages to sayby means of summaries of answers to questionnaires, graphs, statistics, computer analysis, sociological data and other such entertaining devicesis that if you think the performing arts are in financial trouble now, just wait until 1981. Assuming even the most optimistic upturn in the economy, the earnings gap (the Foundation's current euphemism for deficit) is expected to increase threefold in the next seven years, and.the increase is more likely to be almost sixfold when all the inflationary effects are taken into account.

It's almost as if the N.F.L. is showof ing reruns. Almost but The Time, not quite, because the Plittsburgh Steelers will be starting a black quarterback. Joe Gilliam has displaced both Terry Bradshaw and Terry Hanratty after spectacular rehearsals. If he retains his role, Joe Gilliam will be the N.F.L.'s most significant player this season. Equally important, Chuck Noll will be its most significant coach.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Three stars are in order for John L. Hess for The best American food is Chinese (Aug. 18). His tale of woe is, unfortunately, borne out by many frustrating dinners at many wellintentioned establishments. The  outstanding treatment accorded Esquire's Roy Andries De Groot is, however, available to us mortals. The philosophy that a great dinner requires both advance planning and the investment of an evening is, unfortunately, not well understood in America. if it were, I feel that more truly great restaurant meals could be had.

title: Businessmen, arise!
description: This small volume with its arresting title virile to hand a few weeks ago, and my first thought was that another business executivethis time M. A. Wright, chairman of Exxon, U.S.A.was, as it is said, communicating. On the first page was the telltale sentence: Business has failed to do an effective job in communicating its point of view to the general public. All disasters in executive prose begin with these words. Then came the compulsive overstatement: Let there be no mistake: an attack is being mounted on the private enterprise system in the U.S. The life of that system is at stake. (The overemphasis is mine.)

title: News Summary and Index
description: International Negotiations for the release of the French Ambassador to the Netherlands and eight other hostages held by Japanese terrorists at the French Embassy in the Hague reached an impasse yesterday. The conditions of the captives was not known. The captors, who said they were members of the Japanese Red Army, a terrorist group, seized Ambassador Jacques Senard and the others in the embassy Friday, demanding the release from a French prison of a man named Yutaka Furuya. The prisoner was flown from France to the Hague but was said to have refused to leave the plane. [1:4.]
