Nadjari to supersede the city's five District Attorneys in corruption cases in the criminaljustice system, the appointment triggered wide controversy, distrust and hostility among policemen, politicians and prosecutors.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article Impeachment and Business in 1868 (Aug. 11), is a confused attempt to lend historical perspective to the recent impeachment crisis.

title: A New Novel of shapes and surfaces
description: Perhaps now, with the publication of Conducting Bodies, his 11th novel and seventh to appear in English, Claude Simon will finally gain full recognition in the United States as one of France's most eminent novelists and as one of the most inventive and truly profound exponents of fiction anywhere. The Flanders Road, The Grass and especially Histoire did earn critical praise this side of the Atlantic but Simon, like most practitioners of the French New Novel, is still insufficiently read. The highly complex structure of his works requires a great effort from the readeran effort amply rewarded. Simon is concerned primarily with the outer limits of fiction: the probe into the process of fiction itself, the novel about the novel. However, where Proust analyzed its genesis, Simon explores the very mechanism of fiction, its fictivity.

title: Surrealism, Now Turning 50, Has Lost Its Euphoric Innocence
description: SURREALISM is one of the great success stories of the avantgarde era. Launched as an effort to liberate the human spirit from what its founder Andr Breton called the reign of logic, it swamped the Paris art scene  and a good deal more than the art scene  in the 1920's and 30's when Paris was still the artistic capital of the West. It won a secure place among the patrons of the haut monde at the same time that it established itself as a force on the political Left. Its scandals, its debates, especially perhaps its suicides, were legendary, and its artistic innovations affected the work of a great many artists  including some of the greatestwho were not, strictly speaking, observers of the faith.

title: Daffodils, Synonym for Spring
description: DAFFODILS are so lovely and carefree, I cannot resist buying a few more varieties each autumn. Last fall, I had a hard time finding an empty space. My choice was a halfdozen bulbs of the large white Ice Follies with wide, ruffled cream cups.

title: Congressional Race Fails to Excite a Michigan District
description: EAST LEROY, Mich., Sept. 14In this cluster of perhaps 35 sparkling white, treeshaded clapboard houses that might be the twin of many a small Vermont village except for the grain elevator at its center, people live by two rhythms: that of urban industry and that of the countryside.

title: Between social theory and social activism
description: For several years in the mid1960's Americans watched wideeyed and appalled as blacks were burning city ghettos and looting stores in broad daylight. National Guardsmen and enraged blacks were firing weapons at each other  even killing each other. That  and it seems like so much history now  was only the most visible aspect of the urban crisis that captivated the nation and its media in those days of national purgation.

title: 11 Driving Champions Fail To Catch Bobby. Unser
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Sept. 14So Bobby Unser told a fib. What he told the 12,000 spectators at Michigan International Speedway today about strategy for the first International Race of Champions event was in no way related to the way he won the 100mile contest.

title: Above all, Peter Handke is an original
description: Peter Handke is a 32yearold Austrian novelist and playwright. Prior to this novel written in 1971, only two other books by him had appeared on the American market: a collection of three plays, Offending the Audience, SelfAccusation and Kaspar, and another novel, The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick. Handke is a securely established star of the Germanspeaking literary world, the darling of the West German critics (Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung), long since the key figure of his generation (Christ and Welt).

title: First Love
description: Shorts indeed  the play Breath takes barely half pagebut length is not always a value in shorts, which are also a nourishing byproduct of wheat milling, as well as refuse discarded during manufacturing. Words are all we have, Beckett has said, and he is economical with them, as befits the son of a quantity surveyor. Here his American publishers have collected shorts spanning a quarter of a century, from First Loveone of four nouvelles written in the midfortiesto Not I, play brought to New York by Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn in 1972. The others are From an Abandoned Work, Enough, Imagination Dead Imagine, and Ping, all of which have been more or less available in other covers.

title: Israel Is in No Mood to Rally Round The Flag
description: JERUSALEMDespite the lighting words of Israel's leaders, the nation's mood is far from belligerent. For the last two months Premier Yitzhak Rabin and Defense Minister Shimon Peres have reiterated that war may be the only alternative to an enforced Israeli withdrawal without substantial Arab concessions toward future peace. The implication is that Israel must restore her military reputation to reach a workable settlement.

title: SEOUL MAY YIELD IN JAPAN DISPUTE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 14The position of the South Koreans appeared to soften today in their diplomatic confrontation with Japan.

title: Film
description: Today is the 80th birthday of Jean Renoir, frequently called the father of the French film. To celebrate the occasion, The New Yorker Theater will soon show Renoir's most recent film, Le Petit Thddtre de Jean Renoir, and on Tuesday and Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will present a minifestival consisting of La Chienne, The Golden Coach and A Day in the Country. On Nov. 5, Atheneum will publish Renoir's autobiography, My Life and My Films, and it is likely that during the coming season movie buffs will be treated to revivals of such major Renoir works as Boudu Saved From Drowning, Grand Illusion, Rules of the Game, The Southerner, The River and Picnic on the Grass.

title: Lisbon Premier Promoted
description: LISBON, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Premier Vasco dos Santos GoncalveS was today promoted from colonel to brigadier general in a list of 54 highranking promotions by the Council of Chiefs of Staffs.

title: Governor Confidene of a Fall Victory
description: Assessing his chances in the fall elections, Governor Wilson said yesterday that I approach them with confidence.

title: Adrienne Stetson Wed To Bently T. Elliott
description: In St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., Adrienne Nissly Stetson was married yesterday afternoon., to Bently Thomas Elliott. The Rev. William H. Wood performed the ceremony.

title: terHorst Says Ford Spent Inordinate Time on Haig
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14In his first newspaper column since resigning as President Ford's press secretary, J. F. terHorst said today that Mr. Ford was spending an inordinate amount of time soothing his own loyalists and placating the sensitive feelings of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the chief of staff of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: BOSTON IS FEARFUL IN BUSING DISPUTE
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14After two tense days of sporadic violence, Bostonians are taking weekend break, in nervous expectation of the first full week of busing to integrate the public schools here.

title: Raincoats
description: hat old favorite, the trench coat, is this season's foulweather favorite. Their waterrepellent fabrics are varied but they have one thing in common: lengths are getting shorter.

title: REPORT ON MEN'S WEAR
description: T hey're called leisure suits and they're the top news of the season. Leisure suits have shirtstyled jackets, an easy cut and reflect the eagerness with which more and more men are embracing the relaxation of dress rules and keeping their worsteds, pinstripes and plaids for the office, dinner parties and other such occasions. Another reason for their importance: leisure suits are simpler to make and can be more reasonably priced than tailored clothing. The countrylook of both casual wear and more traditionally styled suits is carried over to their fabrics: the season's most favored are camel's hair, Donegal tweed, corduroy. Colors are softertans and greens are prominent and white has become a coldweather color for sport jackets and outerwear. Other notable trends are the return of classic polo coats, wool trench coats, vested suits and brightlycolored plaid flannel shirts. And no roundup would be complete without mention of the Western shirt hat has become as popular as country music.

title: LEGAL AID CHIEF RESIGNS JOB HERE
description: Franklin E. White, acting attorneyincharge of the Legal Aid Society, resigned yesterday as the strike of 350 staff lawyers of the organization went into its fourth day.

title: Ideas&Trends/continued
description: When schools opened last week in Palo Alto, Calif., some parents were given the option of an alter. native school: It was new because it has an unabashed devotion to the Three R's. That is roughly equivalent to General Motors offering the running board as optional equipment.

title: MRS. EMILE ZIMMER
description: Virginia Torrance Zimmer, wife of Emile Zimmer, a management consultant, died of a stroke at her home on Long Neck Point Road in Darien, Conn., on Thursday evening. She was in her 60's.

title: PRICES STUDIED ON PRESCRIPTIONS
description: It will cost more to brush teeth, remove corns and unclog sinuses, but the cost of the tranquilizers needed to calm the Inflationfrazzled consumer should not add to his anxiety about stretching a dollar.

title: Buddhist Group Joins Saigon Opposition
description: Buddhist Group Joins Saigon OppositionSAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14The important An Quang Buddhist faction tonight, threw its support behind a program of peace and national reconciliation amid signs that the nonCommunist opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu is beginning to coalesce into a loose front.

title: College, School Results
description: SOCCER

title: Caroline Kast Married to W. P. Acton
description: In the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew and Holy Communion in South Orange, N. J., Caroline Sue Kast, daughter of Mrs. Harold Lyle Kast and the late Mr. Kast, was married yesterday afternoon to Winsor Paul Acton, son of Mrs, Paul H. Acton of Salem, Ore, and the late Mr. Acton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert B. Wardrop.

title: terHorst Says Ford Spent Inordinate Time on Haig
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14In his first newspaper column since resigning as President Ford's press secretary, J. F. terHorst said today that Mr. Ford was spending an inordinate amount of time soothing his own loyalists and placating the sensitive feelings of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the chief of staff of former President RiChard M. Nixon.

title: Rubin Goldberg, Comedian, Radio Actor, Is Dead at 92
description: Rubin Goldberg, an early radio actor and stage comedian, died Sept. 7 in Unity Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 92 years old and lived at 101 Brightwater Court, Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. Jay Grotas Has Son
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Jay Alan Grotas on Aug. 27 at Mount Sinai Hospital, where Dr. Grotas is a resident in surgery. The child has been named Jason Adam. Mrs. Grotas is the former Melanie Susan Garfinkel.

title: Housing Shortage Plagues Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOKThe State University Center here is expertencing a housing shortlitge for the second consecuItive year, with more than 900 freshmen being housed in 300 rooms designed for occupanty by only two.

title: Office Planners Relying More On Solar Energy
description: Solar energy is attracting such widespread attention among office developers and designers that it may transform the shape of the skyscraper once the ailing office building market comes in from the cold.

title: BONN IS AWAITING GESTURE BY PARIS
description: PARIS, Sept. 14Chancellor Helmut Sdiunidt of West Germany is hoping that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France will make a significant gesture toward European unity and drop past objections to a political decisionmaking role for the Common Market's nine foreign ministers, according to sources in Bonn.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONLY onethird of the preliminary meetingsfour sessionshave been held so far in preparation for the Administration's heralded 'Summit Economic Conference toward the end of this month. But a large catalogue of recommendations for dealing with specific problems has already been assembled, and more are certain to come in the next two weeks. The American economy is obviously in need of repair. Meanwhile, only five weeks of the new Ford Administration have passed, and some major difficulties have already surfaced after its highly promising start. The normal 100day honeymoon with a new Chief of State may not have ended, but the period of bliss may already be diminishing.

title: The Case Of The Vanishing AllWool Sport Coat
description: Although they're still around, those.beefy allwoolen sport jackets are becoming increasingly hardertofind. A look through the city's stores shows that their number has noticeably decreased (blended fabrics are far easier to come upon) and when they do appear, it's likely to be in a price category once reserved for suits.

title: This Violinist Plays an Independent Tune
description: GERALD TARACK is a violinist, but more important, and far more unusual, he. is a freelance concertmasterthe Only one Curently pursuing the craft with consistency and success in New York. Mr. Tarack not only has the field to himself but, much in the manner of a soloist, he is often singled out, both by concertgoers and critics, for his abilities as a fiddler as well as a concertmaster. In the latter guise; he is the first violinist leader of the string section and, in essence, surrogate conductor. He also has at least one other guise, having recently founded what he calls the Tarack Chamber Ensemble which has been giving concerts at the Brooklyn academy of Music. This season, their tWo scheduled appearancei, beginning With a performance on Nov. 1, are already sold out.

title: History's Parallels Are Plentiful, and They All Say No
description: LONDONStatistically, logically and histOrically, democracy and inflation will not mix: One comes out on top and the other must go under. Democracy requires a strong sense of national unity and inflation sets one group of society againskanother. But which is going to win?

title: Homeowners Keep Coney Island Property
description: Thirteen homeowners on West 31st Street, north of Mermaid Avenue, in Coney Island will be permitted to retain their property in a compromise hammered out last week shortly before the latest phase of the massive Coney Island Urban Renewal Plan was adopted by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: The World/continued
description: WASHINGTONDespite the vagaries of weather and crop disease, world grain production rises almost every year. But not this year: Most recent estimates indicate the world's 1974 harvest will be nearly 2 per cent less than in 1973, and with 70 million more people to feed, the drop is serious.

title: JEWISH HOLY DAYS BEGIN TOMORROW
description: Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year, will begin at sundown tomorrow with solemn synagogue services.

title: ExConvict Gives Details of Seven West Side Murders
description: Calvin Jackson, the 26yearold former convict, who is said to bah implthated himself in the murders of 11 women on the West Side, has provided authorities details of seven killings that could have been known only by the slayer, investigators said yesterday.

title: Legislative Notes
description: state's present $640million aid program, at least to wealthier districts, until the Legislature has complied with a court order to enact an equitable financing system.

title: Jaworski Reportedly Ignored In Ruling to Return Nixon Tapes
description: Washinton, Sept, 14 The special Watergate prosecutor's office, although strongly opposed to the decision to return While House tapes and documents to former President Richard M. Nixon, was given no direct role in that concha.sion, according to several wellplaced sources. The views of Leon Jaworski, the special were re

title: Mott Leader Is Freed
description: PARIS, Sept. 14 (UPI)Jean Jacques Susini, a former leader of the secret organization that fought against Algerian independence from France, was provisionally released today from the Sante Prison in Paris. He had been held there since 1972 on suspicion in the kidnapping and disappearance of an officer of the organization who disappeared in 1968.

title: Photography
description: MARK Feldstein is young painter who lives in Soho and goes around early in the morning with a 4x5 view camera photographing odd bits of architectural detail on the older commercial buildings of lower Manhattan. A group of his pictures attracted favorable attention last season when they were included in the exhibition Manhattan Now at the New York Historical Society. Another group is now on exhibit at Modernage's Discovery Gallery on East 44th Street in Manhattan.

title: Ford and Advisers Consider Strategy For Arms Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 14 (UPI) President Ford met for two, hours today with his National Security Council to discuss next week's resumption of talks with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic nuclear arms.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES jumped 3.9 per cent In August, the biggest monthly increase in a year. Agricultural products rose 7.6 per cent, and Industrial commodities went up 2.5 per cent. Ford raised car prices an average of 7.5 per cent. This compares with Chrysler and General Motors rises of 8.5 per cent and an American Motors increase of 7.7 per cent. The Industrial Production Index declined 0.4 per cent in August to 125.2 from July's 125.7.

title: COLD WEATHER FABRICS BASK IN THE LOOK OF SUMMER
description: T wo warm weather favorites, lively madraslike plaids (they are not as sharp as, and a bit blurrier than, those usually found on hefty fabrics) and snowy white, turn up to put summer spirit into wintry woolens.

title: The Same Old Question
description: Secretly and in contradiction to what he said he would do, but nevertheless irrevocably, President Ford has given an absolute pardon to Richard Nixon. The reaction to that single act, which may turn out to be the most important of his inherited Presidency, made it clear that Mr. Ford had disinterred the concern that was the foundation for all the conflict of the last two years: Is the White House telling the nation the truth?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Midtown Realty Owners Association has announced its opposition to a proposal that the former New Yorker Hotel be used to house the temporarily homeless. The association, in a letter to Mayor Beame on Friday, said that an influx of homeless families at the hotel, at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street would disrupt the vital business services essential to the area.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Namath Only Probablefor Jet Opener
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 14In the 10th year of Joe Namath and the first of Charley Winner, the Jets open the season againstthe Kansas City Chiefs tomorrow, hoping to prevent the threat of a poor season from becoming a reality.

title: Kyra Hawkins Is Married
description: Kyra Schutt Hawkins of Syosset, L. I., widow of Ashton W. Hawkins, an investment banker, was married yesterday noon to Charles V, Hickox of Old Westbury, L. I, a widower and retired insurance broker. The Revs. Charles U. Harris and Nils Blatz performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L. I. The bride was given in marriage by her son, Ashton Hawkins, secretary and counsel of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Mildred Hutcheson Dent Bride Of John D. Stuart in Capital
description: Mildred Hutcheson Dent and John Douglas Stuart, finance director of the Republican party of Kentucky, were married yesterday afternoon in Washington at St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Harper, rector of the church, and the Rev. John Turnbull. The bride's maternal greatgrandmother, Mrs. Edward Mugge, the former Mildred Carrington Hutcheson was married in the same church in 1896.

title: College Soccer Outlook: More Teams, More Games
description: More teams participating and longer schedules: This is the collegiate soccer scene this season. Besides more teams and more regularseason games, a number of colleges have followed basketball's example and will stage tournaments, a scarcity in the past. Another change experienced coaches have noticed is that more and more students are going out for the sport this season.

title: Overcoming the Fear of the Fear
description: Sydney Cooper, who retired from the New York City Police Department in 1972 with the reputation of being a tough and honest commander, began a new job last week as head of the city school system's Office of School Security. Last school year nearly 900 assaults on teachers, almost double the number of two years ago, were reported. There were about 5,000 individual incidents, including assaults, robberies, intrusions by outsiders, bomb scares and fires. Mr. Cooper's mandate in the $36,000ayear job is to review the system's safety program, and to manage the more than 900 unarmed school security officers deployed in the city's high schools.

title: Lisbon Premier Promoted
description: LISBON, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Premier Vasco dos Santos GoncalveS was today promoted from colonel to brigadier general in a list of 54 highranking promotions by the Council of Chiefs of Staffs.

title: Son to Mrs. Bernstein
description: A son was horn to Dr. and Mrs. Marc Bernstein of Port Washington, L.I., on Aug. 21 at the New York University Hospital. The child has been named Andrew William. Mrs. Bernstein is the former Joyce Bleiberg of Livingston, N.J. Dr. Bernstein is a dentist in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Mrs. Grasso Is Holding a Series of Forums Around Connecticut in Her Gubernatorial Bid
description: United DURHAM, Conn., Sept, 14United States Representative Ella Grasso, the Democratic candidate for Governor, has begun a series of forums around the state that she hopes will establish an unpretentious and amiable tone to her campaign.

title: How Mr. Nixon Perceives What Happened to Him
description: Prior to Aug. 8, 1974, Richard M. Nixon had spoken and written at length on Watergate in a variety of forums, for what appeared to be a multiplicity of purposes. But, as we now know from the disclosure he was forced to make on Aug. 5 about his lack of candor, those statements told little about his real understanding of the crimes and abuses his administration and about their implications.

title: A.E.C. Studies Plan for Storing Of Radioactive Waste in Vaults
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission is considering building a $100million complex of vaults aboveground to store the most dangerous radioactive wastes from the nation's nuclear power industry.

title: Embryo Transfer Aids Cattle Breeding
description: PAVILION, N.Y.On a dairy farm near this tiny upstate hamlet lives a small herd of Holstein cattle with a collective worth of perhaps $2million.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:15 P.M: (TelevisionChannel 9. 2;10 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2:15 PM.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit: (TelevisionChannel II, 130 P.M.) (RadloWMCA, 1:30 P.M.)

title: U.S. DRAFTS RULES FOR CITIES TO GAIN RAPIDTRANSIT AID,
description: The Ford Administration has drafted the first national criteria for determining which. cities across the country will receive Federal aid to build modern, fixed rapid transit systerns and which will have to settle for buses.

title: News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 14 (AP) Ambassador Daniel P. Moyni ban returns to Washingtor this week for consultations at the State Department following publication of a blunt diplo. matic dispatch by him on United States intelligence activitie' and India's nuclear plans.

title: Under Ford's helmet
description: One of the things that Robert T. Hartman, as an old newspaperman, has always done for Jerry Ford is watch the wire. The ticker now rests on Hartman's White House window ledge, plunking away in the grand hush of his new chambers as a Presidential counselor. But not all that long ago it was located far down Pennsylvania Avenue at an altogether different branch of government,Sometimes their only link with whatever the hell was really happening up at this other end. One day, Hartman recalls, there came over the wire the first release on the White House enemies list. He stared as name after name was writ large in alleged infamy, finally tore off the whole screed and took it in to his boss. Jerry Ford looked it over, kept looking a lohg time, and then said, Anybody who can't keep his enemies in his head has too many enemies.

title: Asking Moscow
description: A major possible source of financial relief for the developing world is in danger of being overlooked by international institutions, by the developed nations of Europe, America and Japan and even by the hardpressed potential recipients. There is no reason why the Soviet Union should not be nudged from all sides into participation in the worldwide emergency effort to help the poorest nations carry the mounting burdens of increased oil, food and other commodity prices.

title: Judge Rejects Lawsuit By Illiterate Student
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (UPI)  A Superior Court Judge has thrown out a $1million lawsuit brought in behalf of a high school graduate who achieved only fifthgrade reading level.

title: Inflation Pinthing Princeton's Budget
description: PRINCETON  William G. Bowen, president of Princeton University, welcomed 1,130 freshmen at a jovial garden reception last Sunday. The next day, he cheerlessly greeted the faculty with the news that Princeton's financial picture, unlike its landscaping, was far from rosy.

title: Home improvement
description: In one, of your columns about a toilet tank that kept running you suggested removing the ball valve at the bottom and replacing it with one of the newer flapper type valves. What kind of valve is this (local hardware store did not know what I meant) and is this a doityourself job? L.M.Y., Rochester, N.Y.

title: Moiseyev at Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE  The Moiseyev Dance Company will conclude a threemonth tour of 13 American cities with a farewell performance next Sunday, at 4 P.M., at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum here. Tickets are available at the box office and through Ticketron outlets and are priced at $10, $7.50 and $5.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports
description: TodayN.A.S.C.A.R. Delaware 500, Grand National race at Dover Downs International Speedway, Dover, Del, 12:05 P.M.

title: Grumman F14's Aboard Carrier for Pacific Duty
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Sept. 14The 24 planes that make up the first two operational squadrons of the Grumman Corporation's F14 fighter were aboard the U.S.S. Enterprise this weekend.

title: La Traviata to Open Monmouth Series
description: RED BANKVerdi's La Traviata, with Boris Goldovsky conducting, will be presented at the Monmouth Arts Center, formerly the Carlton Theater, Oct. 5 and 6.

title: N.F.L. Gate Drops By 1,385,319 in 74
description: Total attendance at the National Football League's 78 exhibition games this yearmast of them played during the strike of veteran players was 2,858,901, a drop of 1,385,319 from 1973, the league office reported.

title: $21Million Suit Over Prank
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP)  The father of a Lehigh University student killed during a fraternity prank last fall is suing the school, the fraternity and several of its members for $21million. Mitch R. Fishkin, a 19yearold Delta Phi fraternity pledge, died a year ago yesterday when he leaped from a moving automobile and struck his head. The car was filled with fraternity members staging what was called a prank.

title: Susan Foster Has Nuptials
description: Susan Pinkney Foster, daughter of Raymond Celden Foster Jr. of Boston and the late Mrs. Foster, was married yesterday afternoon to Allen William Hamill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamill Jr. of Houston. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: INQUIRY ORDERED IN INDIAN SCANDAL
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 14Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has ordered an inquiry into a scandal over import licenses at the insistence of members of her own governing Congress party in Parliament.

title: Books About Beckett
description: Samuel Beckett is one of the world's foremost unread authors. Many people find his works impenetrable; others call them profound statements of existential anguish (a more polite way of saying that they didn't like them). To some, his work is an oldfashioned relic of Joycean experimentalism; others find it too avantgarde. His novels are among the finest written in this century, but he is known mainly as the author of a single play, Waiting for Godot.

title: Eleanor Dick Is Wed To Barclay Douglas Jr.
description: The marriage. of Eleanor Swan Dick, daughter of C. Mathews Dick Jr. of Washington and Newport, R.I., and the late Mrs. John T. Murray, to Barclay Douglas Jr., son of Mr. Douglas of Newport and the late Mrs. Douglas, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Inflation: a Presidential catechism
description: Harry Truman once said of Bernard Baruch that he had difficulty understanding why Baruch liked to describe himself as an adviser to Presidents. All Presidents, Mr. Truman observed, had far more advice than they could use. Still, Mr. Ford is a newcomer, and his association with my part of the general political community has never been intimate. And, as he himself must suspect, if the economic guidance he has inherited had been adequate, the economic problem which he has inherited, namely, inflation, would long since have been solved. Or, at a minimum, it wouldn't be getting worse.

title: Jazz/Rock/Folk/Pop
description: WEDNESDAY

title: Nancy Beinbrink Has Nuptials
description: The Congregational Church of Manhasset, L. I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Nancy Beinbrink, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Beinbrink of Manhasset, and Charles A. Gilman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Manuel A. Gilman of Garden City, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alexander B. Ferguson.

title: TERRORIST GROUP SHIFTS OPERATION
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14The Japanese Red Army, which the police believe is behind the seizure of the French Ambassador and eight other persons in The Hague yesterday, is neither Communist nor an army, and it has practically ceased operating in Japan.

title: Owners Seeking Uses For West Side Hotels
description: A city moratorium on additional residences for the elderly has forced the owners of several old West Side hotels to find alternative incomeproducing uses for the properties.

title: McCrane Is Linked To Hialeah's Check For Cahill Election
description: NEWARK, Sept. 14 (AP)The prosecution in the trial of former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane said today that $14,000 contribution to former Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign had been funneled through the Cherry Hill Inn, a Camden County hotel.

title: BLACK IS BACKED FOR U.S. BENCH
description: Civil Court Judge Henry Bramwell, a Brooklyn Republican, has been recommended for Presidential appointment to the Federal bench in the Eastern District of New York by both New York Senators.

title: Miss Sills Ill Today
description: Beverly SillS, who is reported suffering from laryngitis, will be replaced in the title role of LuCia di Lammermoor by the soprano Ruth Welting at today's matinee of the Donizetti opera at, the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center.

title: N.C. State Beats Duke
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 14 (AP)Stan Fritts and Roland Hooks slashed Duke's defense and on Buckey caught two touchdown passes as North Carolina State beat the Blue Devils, 3521, tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference football game.

title: F.P.C. IS ACCUSED OF IMPROPER ACTS ON GAS PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The General Accounting Office, following a 10month investigation, has accused the Federal Power Commission of acting improperly in allowing number of the nation's natural gas producers to raise prices to millions of their customers.

title: And What Everyone Else May Now Never Find Out
description: WASHINGTONThere is a widespread belief in this cityyou hear it from Congressmen and cab drivers, from students and shopkeepersthat further horror stories would be revealed in Richard Nixon's still undisclosed tape recordings. Some believe that if all the tapes were heard there would be more examples of wiretapping and burglary. Others are confident that the tapes would show the former President scheming to convert vast sums of campaign money and Government funds to his personal use.

title: News of the Stage
description: Charles Bowden and Ronald S. Lee have joined forces for the production of a new thriller on Broadway titled Don't Call Back, by Russell O'Neill, which will star Arlene Francis and opens Feb. 10 at the Helen Hayes Theater.

title: Ohio State Opens With. 3419 Victory
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 14 (UPI) An AllAmerica tailback, Archie Griffin, set a school career rushing record when he ran for 133 yards and one touchdown today to lead topranked Ohio State to a seasonopening 3419 victory over Minnesota.

title: MESKILL FACING MORE OPPOSITION
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14Gov. Thomas J. Meskill is expected to have rough sledding as the Senate begins hearings Tuesday on his appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Shipping/Mails
Jane Kremer Betrothed To David Greenberg
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herman S. Kremer of Elmont and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the gagement of their daughter be Kremer, to David H. GI, berg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Greenberg of Bennington, Vt.

title: Belmont Park Charts
description: Belmont Jockeys

title: Mott Leader Is Freed
description: PARIS, Sept. 14 (UPI)Jean Jacques Susini, a former leader of the secret organization that fought against Algerian independence from France, was provisionally released today from the Sante Prison in Paris. He had been held there since 1972 on suspicion in the kidnapping and disappearance of an officer of the oroanization who disappeared in 1968.

title: The Accent Will Be On Classics
description: LOOKING through the programs for this season of the major American symphony orchestras, some of which start this week, does not provide any surprises or suggest any trends, but the overall repertory looks fairly well balanced. No two people will agree as to whether enough contemporary music is included or whether enough outoftheway works are given a hearing. These categories will never be of sufficient size to please those seeking novelty and will always be too big to suit the traditionalists. To a large extent, though, conductors seem to be striking an acceptable coinpromise, weighted in favor of the classics but providing some fresh material.

title: Nicklaus Ties Miller for Lead at 209
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Sept. 14Jack Nicklaus thought he never would get into the game today. But all being well that ends well, Nicklaus made up a deficit that at one time was five strokes to tie Johnny Miller for the, lead after the third round of,. the World open golf tournament.

title: Diane R. Brown Becomes Bride Of W. S. Frank
description: Diane Ryerson Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. K. Brown of Southport, Conn., and Dorset, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to William Scott Frank, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lorenz Scott Frank of Littleton, Colo. The Rev. James B. Arnold performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

title: Big Spruce Captures. $250,000 Cop at Belmont
description: Big Spruce flourished grandly in the $250,000 Marlboro Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday: Under the guidance of Mike Hole, the 5yearold Elmendorf campaigner won the 1mile race by 2 lengths against a strong field that included Forego, Prove Out and True Knight.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Roane Arledge, president of A.B.C. Sports, said yesterday that Fred Williamson. no longer would be assigned to announce the Monday night National Football League televised games. In the booth for the first regular season contest tomorrow night at Buffalo between the Oakland Raiders and Bills will be Alex Karras, former Detroit Lion defensive tackle.

title: Dance
description: SURPRISINGLY, and perhaps dangerously, Israel has two dance companies. For a country with, at least to some extent, an emergent culture, this may even seem excessive. Yet, clearly, Israel has a great love of the dance. Dance is deeply embedded in the Judaic tradition, and, of course, the number of Jewish dancers who have found world fame outside Israel would be enough to launch any number of ballet companies.

title: Whimsical Amalgam of Pop Art and Surrealism
description: Jim Nutt's style, says the critic, 'seems hybrid, insular and oddly inexpressive.'

title: FARMERS IN TEXAS ASK FEDERAL HELP
description: SULPHUR SPRINGS, Tex., Sept. 14  Hundreds of angry, frustrated beef and dairy farmers brought out 3,000 protesters in this north Texas community of 10,500 yesterday to send a warning to the Ford Administration and to American consumers.

title: PlaneCrash Toll Rises; 2 From City Are Listed
description: The toll in Wednesday's Eastern Airlines plane crash in Charlotte, N. C., has risen to 70, with the death of a 17yearold girl from New York City.

title: Brooklyn Women's Health Coop Expanding to Other Areas
description: When the Unimposing building at 999 Third Avenue in Brooklyn's Bush Terminal section opened its doors to the subscribers of a prototype prepaid health plan for women three months ago, it was the first step in a program to develop similar health cooperatives nationwide.

title: Confessions of an ExMonster Who Cut His Hair
description: Here I am in Kitchener, Ontario, still wondering about my image. It's still being kept alive. I guess it's my fault. created the Frankenstein monster and now every year I have to live it down, or try to convince people that I'm living it down.

title: Pope Visits Aquinas Site
description: FOSSANOVA; Italy, Sept. 13 (AP)  Pope Paul VI came by helicopter to Fossanova Abbey today to visit the burial site of St. Thomas Aquinas. The Pope, who arrived from his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, was cheered by thousands here.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Much like the monster creations of science fiction, the northward swarming of vicious African honeybees through South America is causing such concern in the United States that steps are being taken to control or neutralize them before they become a threat here.

title: Bari Shearer Is Wed To Richard Edwards
description: Bari Anne Shearer and Richard James Edwards were married yesterday afternoon in St. Vincent Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Madison, N.J., by Msgr. Vincent Puma. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Ralph Lassell Shearer of Madison. Mr. Shearer is a merchandising manager with West PointPepperell here. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Szulborski of Bethlehem, Pa. His father is with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 387.6 from 416.0 a week earlier. A year ago it was 424.6.

title: Kristen Heffner Bride of William Alpert
description: Kristen Lee Heffner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Heffner of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon in the Irvington Presbyterian Church to William Titlar Alpert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Alpert of Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick F. Jenkins performed the ceremony.

title: At the Heart of Health Reform, Economics
description: National health insurance is a politically popular proposal, endorsed by leading Democrats and labeled a top domestic priority by Mr. Nixon and Mr. Ford after him. Yet a national health insurance bill has failed evert to reach the House floor, let alone leave it with a vote of approval.

title: L. I. R. R. to Be Upgraded
description: ALBANYThe State Department of Transportation has signed an agreement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for two projects to upgrade the Long Island Rail Roada $3million program to improve the tracks between MasticShirley and Speonk and million to convert and rehabilitate 20 multipleunit coaches.

title: SHAKY TRUCE SET IN TEXTB00K RIFT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 14The widespread picketing by adults to protest public school textbooks ended today with a fragile agreement by the Kanawha County Board of Education to withdraw the disputed books pending a fresh review of their contents by a citizens committee.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Negotiations for the release of the French Ambassador to the Netherlands and eight other hostages held by Japanese terrorists at the French Embassy in the Hague reached an impasse yesterday. The conditions of the captives was not known. The captors, who said they were members of the Japanese Red Army, a terrorist group, seized Ambassador Jacques Serm and the others in the embassy Friday, demanding the release from a French prison of a man named Yutaka Furuya. The prisoner was flown from France to the Hague but was said to have refused to leave the plane. [1:4.]

title: Vibrant Benny Goodman Returns to Carnegie Hall
description: Thirtysix years and eight months after Benny Goodman and his orchestra played the first jazz concert held in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Goodman returned to the hall on Friday evening and to a setting very similar to the one that greeted him in January, 1938. Once again, the hall was sold out, an overflow crowd was seated on the stage, and everything the musicians did was greeted with enthusiastic cheers.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment striking section of copyright bill providing royalties for performers who make sound recordings, which passed, 67 to 8, Sept. 9.

title: Constance Meyer Married to Writer
description: Constance Meyer, daughter of Dr. Bernard C. Meyer and the late Elly Kassman Meyer, was married here yesterday afternoon to Michael S. Pressman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Pressman of New York. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's father and stepmother by Justice Martin Stecher of the State Supreme Court.

title: Epilogue
description: Fifty years have passed, but memo. ries of the Scopes monkey trial live on in Tennessee. Last year, the Tennessee Legislature passed a Genesis law which required that all of the state's biology textbooks give equal treatment to all theories of the creation of man, including the Biblical version. Now the Nashville Chancellery Court, which rules on all civil challenges to state laws, has ruled that the Genesis law is unconstitutional, because it runs counter to the constitutional doctrine of separation of church and state. State legislative leaders are undecided about whether they will attempt to pass a new version of the law next year.

title: HIGHER GOALS SET BY '74 FRESHMEN
description: This year's high school graduates are beginning their college studies more undecided about their ultimate career plans than last year's graduates, but more certain than previous freshmen that whatever they choose to do they want to get postgraduate degrees.

title: Author as Editor and Publisher
description: The publishing industry can no longer support quality fiction. For novelists this situation may be an opportunity in the guise of a disaster. To grasp this opportunity a sizeable group of established novelists has formed The Fiction Collective to select, edit, produce and distribute the books of its peers on the basis of literary merit, free of the implicit commercial standards of the book business.

title: Three. New Shows Don't Make a Season, but This Trio May Make a Trend
description: RACIAL/ETHNIC, single and unable to resist a wisecrack. It may not be a trend precisely, but that seems to be the most popular formula for situation comedies this season. Taking them, in descending order of effectiveness, there's Rhoda (New YI;rk Jewish) on CBS, Chico and the Man (Los Angeles Chicano) on NBC, and That's My Mama (Washington, D.C., black) on ABC.

title: Growing Old Is an Activity at Center in Jamaica
description: On the shelf behind her desk at tho Archer Avenue Senior Center in Jamaica, Queens, Theodora Jackson, director of the center, has two figurines.Both are seated, one is reading a newspaper and the other is knitting.

title: A tale of Jersey jobbery
description: It was one of those chance occasions, writes Christopher Norwood, when the people of Passaic County, N. J., could actually get an open view of the forces controlling their lives. An important pol's funeral. These particular last ritesfor Joseph G. Bozzo, the Republican county chairman, in 1969even revealed a sudden power realignment. The reform mayor of Paterson, N. J., Lawrence F. Kramerafter three years of futile struggle against such as Bozzo and his corrupt, hackney ilkhad gone mournfully over to the side of the bereaved.

title: LAWYERS SOUGHT FOR CONSUMERS
description: Another drive to recruit lawyers to provide free services for needy consumers who have been cheated or believe that they have other problems with credit transactions has been started by the New York Regional Consumer Protection Council.

title: Early Bird Studies in Union County
description: SCOTCH PLAINSUnion County residents are being afforded a chance to take some courses before going to work or school.

title: The space age pinball machine
description: In a modishly hip bar and luncheon spot on Lexington Avenue in New York, two young women on lunch break cautiously approach what appears to be a cross between an oscilloscope and a blackandwhite television set mounted in a standup, 6foothigh console.

title: Monmouth Museum Gets Home of Own
description: LINCROFT  After nine years of staging exhibits in rented galleries, the Monmouth Museum finally has built itself a spacious permanent home.

title: The winner will be a brave new baby conceived in a testtube and then planted in a womb.
description: Gauntlooking and unassuming in manner, Dr. Douglas Bevis from Leeds University, in England hardly seemed a man who would first surprise and titillate, then outrage medical researchers on both sides of the Atlantic. The 55yearold gynecologist was about to deliver a paper in July at a British Medical Association conference on embryo research. But first he handed out a press release with some quietly astonishing news: Human embryos conceived in test tubes had been successfully implanted the wombs of three women, and the women had given birth to normal babies. The three women had all been infertile due to diseased, blocked or missing Fallopian tubes, Dr. Bevis's press release reported. The researchers had surgically removed eggs from them, fertilized the eggs in test tubes with the sperm of their husbands and then reimplanted them in the women's wombs. Out of 30 such attempts, Dr. Bevis said, three had been crowned with success. The babies were said to range in age from 12 to 18 months. All were developing normally, he claimed.

title: Design
description: It wasn't the typical barn remodeling. There are no rustic beams overhead, no wide floor boards underfoot, no stone fireplace, no early American furniture. Nostalgia is not the owner's style. Nor, as barns go, was this thoe romantic vintage model that prompts an immediate love relationship with the prospective buyer. It was, in fact, a rather prosaic, gambrelroofed structure with a twocar garage stuck on one side and clapboard siding rather than the cherished weathered barn siding. The setting, too, was undramatican acre and a third in Greenwich, Conn., studded with mature trees, but no real view. What sparked the imagination of architectowner Charles Gwathmey was the huge interior space. Within two months he and his partner, Bob Siegel, had redesigned that space into a fresh sculptural interiorall pristine white with hardly any furniture. The lowest level (below ground level on the entry side, but exposed at the back) became a bank of four bedrooms and tvc'o baths linked to a large, twostory high playroom. (See floor plans on opposite page.) The ground level on the entrance side houses the livingdining area and the kitchen. This room soars 30 feet to the roof peak. Its height is made even more dramatic by the circular stairwell that rises to the lofts. Those lofts, which overlook the living room, are actually a duplex with a master bedroom suite topped by a topofthehouse study.

title: Ivy League: Dartmouth Is Usual Choice, but Yale Looms as Champion in 1974
description: It is easy to pick Dartmouth as the favorite to win the Ivy League title, which the Big Green has won or shared for the last five seasons. It is also dangerous to pick any team in this scramble for a championship, since the Ivies are unpredictable if they are anything.

title: Child to the Daniel Jonesei
description: A daughter was born on Aug. 16 at Mount Sinai Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Nelson Jones of New York and Shelter Island, L.I. The child has been named Jennifer Tate. Mrs. Jones, the former Nancy Alice Tate, is an assistant vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company here. Mr. Jones is a financial analyst and economist with the investment firm of Edwards & Hanly.

title: BLACK IS BACKED FOR U.S. BENCH
description: Civil Court Judge Henry Bramwell, a Brooklyn Republican, has been recommended for Presidential appointment to the Federal bench in the Eastern District of New York by both New York Senators.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SPARTA  Browsing for Bowser?

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Wages are Down, But Fringes Soar

title: Most Saudis Benefiting From Economic Boom
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Sept.  While Western countries struggle with inflation, recession and sagging stock markets, Saudi Arabia is enjoying an economic boom that benefits both the rich and the poor.

title: Rita and Nellie and Marge in Liverpool
description: Admirers of Beryl Bainbridge's Harriet Said, published last year, will not find that novel's gothic tension in her newest work. But The Secret Glass has another kind of interest; it will attract readers not for its suspenseentertainment but for its sharp character study and unrelenting Naturalism. In this tale of two aunts and their teenage niece in wartime Liverpool, with the American army encamped nearby, Miss Bainbridge employs the same gray Lancashire landscape, the same circular form of plot (she begins at the end, with an unpremeditated murder, then works up to how it happened, to show how it was, somehow, inevitable) yet with quite different effects.

title: Confessions of an ExPlayer Representative
description: The National Football League season will open today. But not for me. I was tut last Tuesday by the New York Giants, which taught me a lesson about trying to carry picket signs and footballs at the same time.

title: Cup Race Becalmed
description: The third race of the AmerIca's Cup series between Courageous, the United States defender, and Southern Cross of Australia was abandoned yesterday off Newport, R.I., after the yachts were becalmed and could not finish within the 5hour time limit. Courageous leads the fourofsevenrace series, 20. Details in Section 5.

title: People and Business
description: Although most economic forecasts indicate a continuing downturn in many sectors of New Jersey business, a 40yearold West Trenton company is projecting that its annual sales volume will increase from its present $1million to $3million during the coming year.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey. daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: What's New in the Art World
description: FRIDAY

title: FollowUp on The News
description: At the time of his graduation from West Point in June, 1973, James J. Pelosi of Hempstead, LI., had been subjected to 19 months of the Silence by his fellow cadets.

title: SWALLOWED TABS ON CANS A DANGER
description: The accidental swallowing of tabs and rings from beer and soft drink cans is becoming a serious medical problem, according to officials of the American College of Radiology of Chicago.

title: SingleRoomOccupancy Hotels Were, Home to 16 Slain in Year
description: At least 16 persons have been murdered in singleroomoccupancy hotels on Manhattan's West Side in the last 12 months, according to records of the two police precincts in which most of the city's SRO's are found.

title: INVESTING Stocks Find a New FocusWhat's the Yield?
description: Which of these Duke Power Company securities has the greater appeal: its 13 per cent notes or its common stock yielding 13 per cent?

title: Wounds of Harness Trial Heal Slowly for Drivers
description: YONKERS, Sept. 13Some mornings Del Insko gets out of bed, thinks of the day ahead, and wonders, Is it all worth it?

title: Northeast Warned It Faces Winter Natural Gas Ctisis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Northeast and some other regions of the United States are moving toward a natural gas shortage this winter that will be the worst yet, according to industry and Government experts.

title: State Studies 15 Counties Air
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Environmental Protection is studying 15 New Jersey counties likely to encounter problems In maintaining healthful airquality standards from 1975 to 1985 because of projected rapid growth and industrialization.

title: Shirt Patterns Play A Running Game
description: ariations on the classic patterns are the rule for shirtings this fall. The sophisticated stripes, checks and circles look as good over a backgammon board as they do in the board room.

title: Gary Gruber Weds Harriet Broughton
description: Harriet Wooten Broughton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Melville Broughton Jr. of Raleigh, N. C., was married yesterday afternoon to Gary Harrison Gruber, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Gruber of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. B. Daniel Sapp performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Raleigh.

title: Market Chiefs Seek Unity in Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Sunday, Sept. 15The Common Market's nine heads of government went into a brainstorming, session last night at a dinner given by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing to tackle Europe's critical economic problems while trying to get the community in better working order.

title: Headliners
description: In a political world of purges and pardons, virtually anything can happen. Charles Goodell, once a Senator from New York, is now a friend and adviser to Gerald Ford. Mr. Goodell is not unfamiliar with the dark side of politics. As a Republican who was an early opponent of the Vietnam War, he was tile victim of a White House campaign, spearheaded by then VicePresident Spiro Agnew, which helped unseat Mr. Goodell. Later he served on the defense team of Daniel Ellsberg, a fact which won him no new friends in the Nixon White House. But Gerald Ford remembered him as an old Congressional colleague who had helped him win the minority., leadership in the House in 1965. When Mr. Ford took the Presidency, Mr. Goodell returned to the good graces of the Republican Party. For me, it's a new day, a new world, he said.

title: Child to Mrs. Margolis
description: A daughter was born Sept. 3 to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Margolis of Larchmont, N.Y., in the New York University Hospital. The child has been named Pamela June. Mr. Margolis is public utilities counsel in the Municipal Service Administration.

title: 11 Guest at Bar Mitzvah, Is Raped in a Queens Synagogue
description: An 11yearold girl attended a bar mitzvah in a Queens synagogue was allegedly raped yesterday afternoon by a 151 yearold youth who had been under psychiatric care since he was 9 years /old, authorities said.

title: New Image Shown By Martha Reeves At the Bottom Line
description: More and more Motown acts are resisting the parent label and its formulas for success. Sometimes they do this within the company. Sometimes, however, the break is more traumatic, and that s the case with Martha Reeves, who opened Friday at the Bottom Line and will be playing there through tomorrow night.

title: Egypt Stages War Games
description: CAIRO, Sept. 14, (UPI) Egypt put her army on display today and staged war games, including a crossing of the Suez Canal watched by President Anwar elSadat and top army commanders.

title: The World Continued In Summary
description: Until he was deposed last week, the aged, diminutive but ramrodstraight Emperor Haile Selassie had been the symbol of Ethiopia, first half a century ago as it emerged from the worst extremes of its feudal past, then in defiance of the imperialist aims of benito Mussolini and more recently as a leading and reasonable exponent of African nationalism. Without him, Ethiopia seemed a leaderleis and stricken state.

title: Music
description: THE announcement that WNCN is changing from classical music to rock makes radio that much more of a wasteland. Presumably there were all kinds of economic pressures dictating the move. But now the metropolitan area is served by only two goodmusic stationsWQXR and, to a lesser extent, WNYC. What has happened, to the cultural explosion we were reading about 10 years ago?

title: A.K.C. Proposes Change In Point Scoring System
description: For years fanciers have complained bitterly about the system of awarding championship points. They are particularly irate in the case of specialty shows, in which there are. big entries and still only the winners dogs and winners bitch receive points. For example, at the Westchester show last Sunday. there were 238 Great Danes, 200 of whom were class dogs or bitches. There were 99 dogs and the winner received 5 points. Although the reserve winner defeated 97 other Danes, he left with only a ribbon, but no points.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Right Now: The guest is Mario Merola, Bronx District Attorney, who will, speak on the rising crime rate, on Channel 9 at 9:30 A.M.

description: District 18 of the Department of Community Development of the Human Resources Administration is going into court in an attempt to force the Penn Central Railroad to erect protective fencing along all of the railroad company's track lines that run through Brooklyn.

title: The Pocketed Leather Jacket
description: he mostprized jacket in a gentleman's wardrobe (if he can afford it) is likely to be of leather or suede. The animal skin coat has come a long way from its darklyshaded, heavy weight, unstyled versions. This season further refinements include fashionaware treatments and livelier colors.

title: What's New in Camera World
description: YEAR  ROUND, college accredited workshops in basic, intermediate and advanced photography will be conducted by the newly established Sun Valley Center, in Sun Valley, Idaho. Each session will be from six to eight weeks in length, with the first series scheduled to run from Oct. 7 to Nov. 15. Others will follow from Jan. 13 (1975) to Feb. 21, and from March 31 to May 23. In addition, there will also be oneweek and weekend workshops in such specialized areas as color printing, photojournalism and nonsilver processes, plus seminars with wellknown instructors.

title: Giscard Envisioning a Greener Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 14President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has decided that the French are nation of tree haters. He has therefore decided that they shall have more, whether they like it or not.

description: Twentysix courses will be offered by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden beginning Thursday.

description: The Ford Administration has drafted the first national criteria for determining which. cities across the country will receive Federal aid to build modern, fixed rapid transit systerns and which will have to settle for buses.

title: Work Is Begun on Phone Cable
description: NETCONG  Construction of the first leg of a 2.000milelong, supersophisticated telephonetransmission cable is under way just south of here. Upon completion of the entire project in the nineteeneighties it will be able to handle more than 450,000 calls simultaneously.

title: BOSTON IS FEARFUL IN BUSING DISPUTE
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14After two tense days of sporadic violence, Bostonians are taking weekend break, in nervous expectation of the first full week of busing to integrate the public schools here.

description: HARTFORD, Sept. 14Gov. Thomas J. Meskill is expected to have rough sledding as the Senate begins hearings Tuesday on his appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

J., was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Zielinski Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Zielinski of Jersey City. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Herbert A. Donovan Jr. in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair.

description: Photography Exhibitions

Radio
description: Tuesday

title: Cubs Rout Mets, 120, On 4Hitter by Hooton
description: Although deeply entrenched in the National League East'S cellar, the Chicago Cubs performed yesterday as if they were powerful pennant contenders determined to enjoy the full advantages of Fun City.

title: BRONX ARTS MUSEUM PICKS NEW DIRECTOR
description: Judith Van Baron, former managing editor of Arts magazine, has been hired as director of the Bronx Museum of the Arts. She replaces Elizabeth Beirne, whose dismissal last July by the museum's board of directors set off a dispute.

title: Elizabeth Averett Robertson Married to Laurence Arnold
description: Elizabeth Averett Robertson and Laurence Ray Arnold were married at noon yesterday in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Baltimore. The ceremony was performed by the associate rector, the Rev. Francis O. Chapelle, assisted by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Thomas Grover Cleveland, who teaches at Milton (Mass.) Academy.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1BLACK STAR/BOB FITCH

title: Pop
description: IT was around 1967 that I first heard both Tracy Nelson and Lorraine El. lison. I saw Miss Nelson performing at the Fillmore in San Francisco with her band, Mother Earth, and the power of her voice totally knocked me out. Miss Ellison's first album, simply titled Introducing Miss Lorraine Ellison, had been released in 1966. While I can't remember too much about the songs on it, I do recall how soulful and beautiful her voice was. In the succeeding years neither woman has become a big star, although Miss Nelson has taken repeated stabs: Over past eight years she has recorded for something like four different record labels while being touted as competition for Janis Joplin.

title: Art/Arehiteeture
description: I AM not the person to judge the statues in the Metropolitan Museum's show on New York City Public Sculpture (through Sept. 29) as art, because they are all my friends. Besides, my competence runs more to how public art affects public space.

description: Brooklyn Brownstone Fair II, the second annual conference for brownstone enthusiasts, will be held Oct. 5, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. in the main floor showroom of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company at 195 Montague Street.

title: Pakistan and India Sign Postal and Travel Agreements
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 14India and Pakistan moved closer to normal relations today with the signing of agreements for the restoration of postal, telecommunications and travel facilities that were broken during the 1971 war over Bangladesh.

title: ROSE SAYS RIVALS WERE WIPED OUT'
description: Alex Rose, a vice chairman of the state's Liberal party and its chief political strategist, said yesterday that a Queens faction of the party opposed to him and the rest of the leadership had been wiped out in last Tuesday's primary.

title: Felicity Russell Is Bay State Bride
description: Felicity Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Russell of Tenafly, N.J., was married in the town of West Tisbury, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., yesterday morning to Joel Bruce Kirschbaum, son of Mrs. Howard W. Kirschbaum of Los Altos, Calif., and the late Mr. Kirschbaum. The ceremony in the Mayhew Chapel in Christiantown was performed by the Rev. Donald Henry Lyons, rector of Grace Episcopal Church in Vineyard Haven, Mass.

title: The Birthday  Goat
description: Souci? Where is she? Everyone's seeking herMama, Papa, Pan, Paulette and Bridgetand that bulldog of a policeman, Constable Nero, too. She's not at the puppet show, the pony ride or apparently anywhere on the carnival grounds. Can it be that a certain blue overalled boar, the original greased pig, has napped kid Souci? It's posible. Papa Goat had warned them all to be careful because milkfed kids bring a premium price. But don't worry; Baby Souci will turn upor under somethingand the Goat family can continue its birthday celebration and have an oldfashioned country picnic with oatcakes and groatcakes and switohel to drink.

title: Son to the Stan Orbachs
description: A son was born to Dr, and Mrs. Stan Orbach on Aug. 26 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester, where Dr. Orhuh is a resident in oral surgery. The child has been named David Jason.

title: The Great Safari Suit Flap
description: safari suit in town is currently worth two in the African bush. Decoded, that means that you may now dine at such superelegant New York spots as the Hotel Pierre and the Regency garbed in a safari suit (without shirt and tie), or at La Grenouille and 21 (with a shirt and tie), but you would be less sartorially acceptable wearing the same macho Mogambo outfit in the African bush.

title: The greening of Fletcher Knebel
description: Not long ago an image surfaced in my memory of a 6yearold kid in Jackson Heights, N. Y., watching an old steam shovel gouge a pit for building foundations. 1 recall the boy's feeling fright and revulsion as the machine clawed at the weedy field where he played with other kids. In the child's eyes, an iron enemy assaulted his turf with evil intent.

title: Common Market Draws British Farmers Fire
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) Thousands of British farmers with tractors and combines blocked shopping centers in 200 villages today to protest rising feed prices and demand better prices for their produce.

title: Marjorie McWeeney Is Married
description: Marjorie Lucille McWeeney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Xavier McWeeney of Rye, N. Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Peter Maximus Kennedy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Jr. of Rye and Pomfret, Conn.

title: Islam Today: Moslem Faith Strong in a Secular Era
description: CAIRO  Attendance at Fridaynoon prayers is so great here that makeshift mosques are set up in the courtyards of office buildings.

title: New Looks For An Old Favorite
description: C orduroy has come a long way from its French ancestry as corde du roi (the king's cord). While still certain to receive a royal welcome in a man's wardrobe, it appears in versions never dreamed of by the early monarchs of France.

title: Mrs. Ford Backs Rights Of Women and Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) Betty Ford told black women's rights organization today that she would continue to speak throughout the country in support of the rights of women and blacks.

title: U.S. to Aid Kodiak, Alaska
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)President Ford authorized emergency aid today for Kodiak, Alaska, which lost its electric power supply recently. By declaring the city an emergency area, Mr. Ford cleared the way for the use of Federal funds to restore power to Kodiak until repairs on the city's own equipment are completed.

title: Police Fear Distortion On Crimes In Nassau
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau County Police Department last week refuted various interpretations of recent Federal Bureau of Investigation crime statistics that alleged staggering increases in violent crime in the county.

title: If you want to see his monument, look around
description: The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York has been launched with almost unparalleled fanfare, but even if it had been slipped quietly into the bookstores, its importance would have been quickly recognized, for it is the first extensive and comprehensive critique of one of the most powerful men of thisor any othercentury. More than any other single man, Robert Moses laid his hand on New York City and State. For over 40 years he wielded more influence and naked power than any governor or mayor: indeed, in the area of public works, more than all of them combined. Through the control of public authorities and commissions he exercised unprecedented influence over the physical development of the entire state and especially its metropolis. Shielded from normal democratic accountability by independent agencies, working in almost total secrecy, sustained by a fawning press and generally grateful public, he wove a concrete web of parkways throughout the metropolitan area, soldered together the fractured boroughs of New York with bridges and tunnels, and surrounded the city with green parks and white beaches. The majesty and extent of his public works have no analogue anywhere in the world. For four decades he spent money on a scale that made city and state budgets look almost like statistical errors.

title: Cards Down Phils, 92, and Take HalfGame Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP)Bill Robinson misplayed Lou Brock's secondinning tworun single, allowing two more runs to score, as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 92, tonight and took over first place in the National League East.

title: SeaLife Unit Gets U.S. Land
description: SEAVILLE  The Federal Government has deeded an 18acre tract and 30 buildings on it to the New Jersey Marine Sciences Consortium for use as a marinescience education and research center. The entire parcel is valued at $4million.

title: Recordings
description: OVER the next three or four years, we are going to be hearing a lot of American music  old as well as new and much of what we hear is bound to alter our perspectives on the entire subject. There's nothing like an anniversary celebration to spur action and stir up fresh thoughts, and from the look of things to come, the Bicentennial promises to inspire orchestras, opera comanies, record labels, foundations and musicians in every field to unprecedented efforts on behalf of native composers from the Revolution right up to 1976.

title: Lon Nol Said to Replace 11 Generals Weeded Out
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 14 (AP)  Government sources said today that Presil dent Lon Nol had promoted 11 colonels to be generals in a secret ceremony yesterday afternoon.

title: Point of View
description: New York City has lost 169,100 manufacturing jobs in the last four years, and the slide, which is manifested in empty loft and factory buildings, continues in 1974.

title: Horse From Westchester Finds a Home in Greece
description: Not many members of the equestrian set would be interested in purchasing a horse and sending it to Greece.

title: The Perilous Gard
description: The house is named Hatfield. The lady of the house, a redhaired princess named Elizabeth, is imprisoned in an unhappy life there by her jealous sister the Queen. Clumsy, smart Katherine Sutton and her pretty sister Alicia are maids of honor to the Lady Elizabeth.

title: Essays for benign occasions
description: The story used to be told at Yale of a debate between the philosophers Paul Weiss and Brand Blanshard. Weiss, it was said, had leaped to his feet at the conclusion of the argument, pounded the table, and cried, I'm absolutely right and you're absolutely wrong! To which Blanshard was alleged to have quietly replied, as he sat with arms folded, I am unmoved. The anecdote is, perhaps, slightly unfair to Weiss, but it catches Blanshard's manner admirably: a calm refusal to be carried away, the maintenance through all vicissitudes of the spirit of determined reasonableness that he sees as the mark of philosophy and of which this book is a further example.

title: E. S. Schwartz, Margaret Peet Planning Bridal
description: The engagement of Margaret Sherman Peet to Ernest Saul Schwartz has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Charles D. Peet of Bronxville, N.Y., and Monterey, Mass. Mr. Schwartz is a son of Mrs. Charles Schwartz of New York and Lake Placid, N.Y., and the late Mr. Schwartz.

title: Vatican Police to Carry Pistols Following Alert

title: New for Home and Shop
description: LIGHTWEIGHT LIGHTWEIGHT portable air compressor that can be used for spraying paint and inflating tires, or toys has been recently put out by Black & Decker. Pistonpowered like powerful commercial compressors, it will deliver constant air pressures of 55 to 60 pounds per square inch and it has a tough ABS plastic housing that is almost unbreakable. The compressor is doubleinsulated so that it is safe to use anywhere with a twoconductor cord, and it needs no lubrication. It is more powerful than the usual portable diaphragm type compressor, yet just as light and easy to carry around. Priced at under $50, it comes with a spray gun that features an inexpensive disposable nozzle and spray cap to eliminate need for cleaning, and with an inflator kit for tires and similar equipment. A special caulking gun is also available which enables the owner to use the compressor for applying an even bead of calking compound or similar sealant with only thumb pressure on the gun's trigger.

title: Two Pandas in London After Flight From China

title: The Camberwell Beauty
description: This is V. S. Pritchett's eighth collection of short stories, and he himself, a critic of genius, must be happy with what he calls this minor literary genre. The territory is familiar to anyone who has read Pritchett's fiction over the last 30 years: seedy antique dealers and Sunday sailors, adulterous academics, a confused editor of a leftwing periodical, an unlikely film director, lonely people with dogs; old age and remembered childhood. Is it all right? Are you alone? she said. Something awful has happened. Duncan's going to get married again. Irmgard has got her claws into him. I rang Alexhe always said I could ringbut he won't come. Why am I rejected?this kind of rather hectic Murdochery moves smoothly to pity (He was a tall man, all bones, and even his wrists coming out of a jacket that was too short in the sleeve seemed to be crying), and settles on exquisite malice; She looked formidably unknown. For him people's faces merged into the general plain lineaments of the convinced.

title: How Victoria set the American table
description: It all happened here in the 19th century, and perhaps one of the most important influences was the reign of Queen Victoria, who never set foot on our soil. The millions of American women who slavishly and often unwittingly followed her example of dutiful wifehood were not even her subjects, but every aspect of their lives, from their ample and rigidly Aft corseted waistlines to their religious principles, was organized as much as possible in imitation of the Queen.

title: Fashion
description: The Big Look or Droop or whathaveyou is causing a big furor as fall clothes turn up in the stores with their long, voluminous and generally overpowering proportions. At least that's the way they look to the average American woman who, stretch as she may, measures a statistical average five feet three inches. She needn't despair. Big fashion can and does work for small people when worn with flair and imagination. Actress Joan Hackett, whose stage presence belies her five feet four inches, finds that the swirl of capes, the droopiness of long skirts and the snappy cut of ridinghabit suitsall worn with the right accessoriescan be manipulated to make her look mysterious, romantic or swashbuckling as the mood strikes her.l like to tuck floorlength skirts into belts for a real winter peasant look. Sometimes I even wear knickersfor more drama

I. This is not some littleleague Borgesian fantasy of mine: There really was such a thesis, and it really did satisfy Columbia's requirements, and the person who wrote it is loose in the land even now, growing mold on the minds of innocent schoolchildren.

title: Aliosha as well as Ivan
description: At the height of the moral crisis of American intelligentsia  when the best and the brightest, who had masterminded the Vietnam war, were comfortably ensconced into foundation presidencies; when scientists could not find the heart to sever their profitable connections with the President's Scientific Advisory Committee or the Department of Defense  a voice of integrity was unexpectedly heard from Russia. Andrei Sakharov's manifesto, appearing in The New York Times in 1968, struck the intellectual and scientific world as a message of anguish but also of hope. Here, at last, was a true profile in courage. A man who was known, dimly, as the father of the Soviet thermonuclear bomb dared to break the fetters of silence that held his entire country and to appeal to reasonable people everywhere to abolish the twin nightmares, nuclear war and suppression of personal liberty.

But here's what surprises me most. Do you know what style almost all of the more assertive newcomers have chosen to adopt? The neorealism, with its emphasis upon atmosphere and its edge of nearpoetry, of Tennessee Williams, William Inge, Lillian Hellman, the whole company of men and women who dominated our stages until 15 years ago.
