title: Book Ends
description: Future Ford. In an analogously enviable position to Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, who found themselves with a biography of Gerald Ford on their hands when Mr. Nixon resigned, is a small publisher called The Third Press. The company commissioned a biography of Vice President Ford (as he then was) around the first of this year, and the writer they chose to do it was the then Washington bureau chief of The Detroit News, Jerald F. terHorst. So Third Press now has on their hands the nearly completed MS. of Gerald Ford and the Future of the Presidency, which they will rush through for late October publication. Joseph Okpaku, the Nigerianborn president of The Third Press, explained his prescience matteroffactly. He was looking around for a political book related to the Watergate troubles (as who wasn't?) and after several possibilities fell through, decided to focus on the postWatergate situation. This led him to zero in on Mr. Ford as the future Mr. Republican; the remaining problem was to choose an author. Mr. terHorst had the obvious credentials of being from Mr. Ford's home state and a respected political journalist; he also fit Mr. Okpaku's criterion of avoiding an Eastern liberal writer. Events moved apace and as the deadline for an ad announcing the book drew near, the title was not set, though Gerald Ford: Past, Present and Future was a front runner. But as Mr. Nixon's departure became more urgently likely the present title was chosen, the day before the resignation. Mr. terHorst's appointment as press secretary did not alter the content of the book in any way, Mr, Okpaku said. The President merely told him to be objectivenobody's perfect. So the promise, at least, is of an open biography. The book ends with Mr. Ford's accession and Mr. terHorst's speculations on what stamp Mr. Ford will place on the office. The Third Press is sometimes vaguely thought of as a black publishing house, but actually Mr. Okpaku has always sought a general list. At any rate, he is anticipating the company's first best seller, plans a 50,000copy first printing and expects to double that. Incidentally, Mr. Okpaku does not always guess right politically. Before the French Presidential elections, he commissioned a book by Francois Mitterand, the Socialist candidate, who lost.

description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Paul Drexler of Suffern, N.Y., on Aug. 25 at the Good Samaritan. Hospital there. The child has been named David Carlton, Mrs. Drexler is the former Elise Ann Gordon, daughter of State Senator and Mrs. Bernard G. Gordon of Peekskill, N.Y. Mrs. Drexler is regional director in southeastern New York for the Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation of Milwaukee.

title: Marilyn G. Brandman Plans to Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard J. BFandman of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, to Howard Schnidman, son of me and Mrs. Morris Schnidman of Rochester.

title: 65,946 FRESHMEN APPLIED TO CITY U.
description: Freshman applications to the tuitionfree City University reached a record this fall, prompting expectations of the largest freshman class in the university's history.

title: KISSINGER CALLED CHILE STRATEGIST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Secretary of State Kissinger personally directed a farreaching Nixon Administration program designed to curtail economic aid and credits to Chile after the election of President Salvador Allende Gossens in 1970, wellinformed Government sources said today.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's televison programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Nobody Said Wigger'
description: It was, alas, close to four decades ago when Miss Mildred Sullivan told her seventhgrade art class at the. Sherwin Grammar School in Roxbury that they were ready to paint people instead of the simple exercises she had given them to teach balance and symmetry. She explained that people weren't really white, they were more orangey; when the class painted people they were to use the orange watercolor.

title: Greenburgh Police Sergeant Says He Lied to Grand Jury That Dismissed Allegations of Ejection Fraud
description: A police sergeant in the Town of Greenburgh now says he did not tell the truth to Westchester County grand jury that investigated, and finally dismissed, allegations of forgery on 1967 town election petitions.

title: Janet Erstein Fiancee Of Kenneth Schiffrin
description: Janet Lee Erstein and Kenneth Howard Schiffrin, a lawyer in the office of the General Counsel for the New York City Transit Authority, plan to be married in December.

title: Mr. Ford's Folly
description: With his signature on President Nixon's pardon a week ago today, President Gerald R. Ford committed an act of monumental folly that assured the coverup of a coverup, subverted the spirit of the law and the Constitution, plunged the country once again into bitter political division and undermined Mr. Ford's own credibility as a man of judgment, candor and competence.

title: Critics Now Cooperative As Nadjari Ends 2d Year
description: Two years ago when former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller appointed Maurice. H. Nadjari to supersede the city's five District Attorneys in corruption cases in the criminaljustice system, the appointment triggered wide controversy, distrust and hostility among policemen, politicians and prosecutors.

title: Resurfacing to Begin on Section Of L.I. Expressway Tomorrow
description: The section of the Long Island Expressway between Maurice Avenue in the ElmhurstMaspeth area and Queens Boulevard will be completely resurfaced.

title: The World
description: The leading bankers of the industrialized nations, concerned by a serious question of confidence in the system. serious economic commentators are debating whether there are only 25 banks in the world that can be totally trusted not to failgathered in Switzerland last week to seek remedies.

title: Who Makes Music
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA

title: $21Million Suit Over Prank
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP)  The father of a Lehigh University student killed during a fraternity prank last fall is suing the school, the fraternity and several of its members for $21million. Mitch R. Fishkin, a 19yearold Delta Phi fraternity pledge, died a year ago yesterday when he leaped from a moving automobile and struck his head. The car was filled with fraternity members staging what was called a prank.

title: Edythe August Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Neil August of Ossining, N.Y. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Edythe Robin August, to Barnett R. Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Parker of Miami. Miss August is a senior at the University of Rochester, where her fianc, an alumnus of the University of Massachusetts, received a master's degree and is completing studies for a doctorate.

title: New York Grand Prix Project Considered Again At Flushing Meadow Park But With a Lot of Ifs
description: The Grand Prix of New York, an idea for an auto race that has been kicked out of Central Park quicker and more often than most muggers, has resurfaced again this time at the site of the 19641965 World's Fair in Flushing Mead ow Park. The race, which would be for the same Formula One cars that compete roundtheworld on the Grand Prix circuit, is still not much more than a promoter's dream to make New York more famous than Indianapolis, Monte Carlo and even Sebring, Fla.

title: Metropolitan Colleges: Post Strong
description: Rutgers football players may be the only ones in the nation other than Army and Navy players, who are already looking with great anticipation to their final game of the season. The Scarlet will conclude their 106th season against the University of Hawaii in Honolulu, Nov. 30.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Historians are not certain, but rumor has it that sometime in the early 1960's a divine revelation came to the managers of medium sized companies. Investment bankers seemed to be inspired by five fundamental truths:

title: Northeast Warned It Faces Winter Natural Gas Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Northeast and some other regions of the United States are moving toward a natural gas shortage this winter that will be the worst yet, according to industry and Government experts.

title: Rhodesia Finishes Rail Link to Border With South Africa
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 14The first direct rail link between Rhodesia and South Africa: completed this week. The line runs for 90 miles from Rutenga in southeast Rhodesia to Beitbridge at the South African border. The first train carrying Rhodesian exports to South African ports will run Oct. 1.

title: Clurman Says He's Barred As Bicentennial Unit Head
description: Richard M. Clurman, the chairman of City Center and former New York City Parks Commissioner, says the White House has told him that he is no longer the prospective chairman of the National Bicentennial Advisory Council, a 25member panel to be appointed by the President.

title: Labor
description: The high command of organized labor, strangers to the White House through the last year of the Nixon chill, traveled to the economic summit at President Ford's invitation last week. They climbed down, warmed by the personal charm of the new tenant at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue but worried that they had been used as shills in a White House cosmetic operation.

title: Toonkels Have Daughter
description: A daughter was horn Aug. 28 at University Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Toonkel of New York. lvfrs. Toonkel is the former Jane Dystel, whose father, Oscar Dystel, is president and chief executive officer of Bantam Books. The child has been named Jessica Fanny.

title: Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: IENJOYED reading Dick Adler's article about his attempts to meet Nielsen families, especially the part where he mentioned my own work in this field [The Nielsen RatingsAnd How Penetrated Their Secret Network, Sept. 11. However, there was a small error in his reporting.

title: The Pardon Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Arthur Ratner should be praised tot his efforts to keep jobs and industry in New York City [Huge Building Alters a Landscape in Queens, Sept. 1], but there are certain faults with the Rental. Plaza that should be pointed out so that the same mistakes are not made in the future.

title: SHAKY TRUCE SET IN TEXTB001 RIFT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 14The widespread picketing by adults to protest public school textbooks ended today with a fragile agreement by the Kanawha County Board of Education to withdraw the disputed books pending a fresh review of their contents by a citizens committee.

title: How to Help Golf Swing In Area Where It Counts
description: Lee Trevi'o's swing is highly unorthodox and scarcely a model for the weekend golfer except where it counts in the hitting area. Trevino probably has the best action throngh the ball of any contemporary player. Even Ben Hogan has complimented him for his hand action, and Hogan passes out compliments about as freely as your neighborhood filling station gives away gasoline.

title: National Court League Is Organized for Girls
description: The time is right, the girls want to play, says George Dramby, who for seven years directed the Rhode Island Babe Ruth baseball program, and so he has organized AllAmerica Girls Basketball Conference, Inc. The league, the first for girls on a national scale, is scheduled to start late this month in. East Greenwich, R. I., in two divisions seniors (ages 14 and 15) and juniors (ages 12 and 13). A national tournament will be held each December in East Greenwich. The cenference was incorporated in April and Dramby, the commissioner, has received responses from more than 20 states.

title: Reports on NATO Post for Haig Stir a Lively Army Controversy
description: Reports that President Ford intends to appoint Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr:as supreme allied commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have provoked lively and often bitter, controversy within the Army's officer corps.

title: Negotiations Stall As Terrorists Hold 9 in Hague Embassy
description: THE HAGUE, Sunday, Sept. 15Tense negotiations for the, release bf the French Ambassador and eight other hostages held by Japanese terrorists in the French Embassy here were at an impasse today, and the condition of the captives remained unknown.

title: A Major but Unobtrusive Factor in Carey Victory: Mayor Beame
description: Mayor Beame has emerged in Interviews with politicians as the behindthescenes force in the major move in the CareyforGovernor chronologythe leader's deal to deliver enough convention votes to put Hugh L. Carey on the ballot without making him circulate nominating petitions.

title: Allende's Fall, Washington's Push
description: The disclosure that the United States had directly participated in the economic and political undermining of the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile between 1970 and 1973 is only part of the dismal tale of what took place between Washington and Santiago during the three years he held office.

title: ARTHUR J. O'DEA
description: Arthur J. O'Dea, a retired Bergen County judge, died yesterday at his home, 250 Mill Street, Westwood, N. J. He was 68 years old.

title: Chess:
description: The Manhattan Chess Club has always provided refuge for a special class of patzer that might be dubbed the hoverer.

title: Lots of critics and social scientists
description: With Henry Kissinger at the top of the pollsters current list of most admired men, the trajectory of assimilation for American intellectuals appears to be complete. Long outsiders in a practical and businessminded society, intellectuals now hold secure positions in universities and dispense advice as consultants and counselors to government and private organizations. With the growth of the reading public, they enjoy an expanding market of the reading public, they enjoy an expanding market for their work and an audience broad enough to make some of them celebrities. Many control large research staffs, in that classic test of capitalist virility, they even have to meet a payroll. Ideas have become important property, and so leading intellectuals, like other men of property, have become implicated in the bureaucratic life of modern society.

title: Best Seller List
description: Best Seller List

title: BacktoCity Group Holds Meeting Here On Updating Homes
description: A national Back to the City conference drew more than 200 peoplerepresentatives of neighborhood organizations, city planning boards and plain oldhouse enthusiaststo the WaldorfAstoria Hotel over the weekend to share ideas about the restoration of older structures as middleclass residences.

title: Meehan Picked to Run For Supreme Court
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 (AP)  District Attorney Robert R. Meehan of Rickland County, who was defeated in the Democratic primary for the nomination for State Attorney General, has been selected as one of four Democratic candidates for State Supreme Court justice for the inth Judicial District.

title: Mercy Was Satisfied, But the Constitution Requires Justice
description: A pardon is an act of grace, Chief Justice Marshall wrote in 1833, tracing the practice back to the king's prerogative in England. The Constitution laid down almost no rules for.pardoning offenses against the United States. It confided the power in the broadest terms to the President, leaving it to him to issue pardons for his own reasons.

title: Keith Carabine Marries Virginia Stone Taft Here
description: Virginia Stone Taft, who received a master's degree in English literature last year from the University of Kent in Canterbury, England, was married here yesterday afternoon to Keith Carabine, a lecturer in English and American literature at the university.

title: Bold Plaids: The Angler's Choice
description: hose wildlyshaded, wooly shirts sporting bold, mansized plaids are back again and more popular than ever with with an outdoorsminded generation. The only difference is that the new versions are apt to be more wild than wooly: the constantly rising cost of wool has made blends and substitute fabrics mandatory.

title: Californians Defend Coast From Oil Companies
description: MORRO BAY, Calif.Not everyone in Morro Bay was as agitated as Chris Boyce when listening devices and burglartype trip wires were installed in the ledges and cracks of the 576foothigh Morro rock that sits at the entrance to the bay like a giant wart on the profile of the California coast.

title: Women in jail Fight Drugs
description: CLINTON TOWNSHIPFor years, Jackie Harris's life followed a pattern familiar to many drug addicts.

title: He started a kind of revolution among migrant workersbut a rival union is now. reaping the harvest.
description: CALEXICO, CALIF. No one who sympathizes with him wants to admit that he is defeated. Some of his Anglo supporters still pace the sidewalks front of city supermarkets, imploring customers to boycott the grapes and lettuce inside, but their posture now indicates to the skeptical outsider that they are engaged in a lonely vigil, not a dynamic national movement. His most zealous farmworker followers still stand at the dusty edges of the vineyards and lettuce fields, waving the redandblack banners and shouting, Huegar (Strike), at the workers bent between the rows of ripe crops, but their rhetoric these days is more anguished than inspired. He still speaks with relentless enthusiasm at rallies in school auditoriums and town parks, but the cheers of his loyalists stem as much from nostalgia for the past struggle as from desire to hang in there for future battles.

title: Gas and Oil Refunds Vowed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP)Twentyfour New England concerns have agreed to refund total of more tharr $54,000 In overcharges for gasoline and oil, the Federal Energy Administration regional office here announced yesterday.

title: 5YearOld Asphalt Case Is Bogged Down on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 In February, 1969, representatives of eight oil companies, including five of the largest in the world, pleaded not guilty to charges of collectively overcharging for asphalt by more than $20million in five Western states over a 10year period.

title: Cynthia Halsey, 1970 Debutante, Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Van Rensselaer Halsey of Locust, N. J., and Thendara, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Everett Halsey, to H. William Snyder Jr., son of Mrs. Audrey J. Snyder and Howard W. Snyder of Hamilton, N. Y.

title: Youth
description: With the publication of Youth: Transition to Adulthood, the members of a Presidential panel join the everexpanding ranks of school critics. But theirs is a criticism with a new twist. Schools are not, as many critics would suggest, training grounds in docility designed to prepare the majority for the alienating labor that will inevitably be their lot as adults; on the contrary, having come to monopolize the route from youth to adulthood, schools are unable to provide the proper experiences for a successful transition.

title: Catholics Revising Parish Structure
description: KEARNY  The Senate of Priests of the Archdiocese of Newark has voted to revise the system under which 253 parishes have been serving 1.5 million Roman Catholics in North Jersey. The parishes will be reorganized into 11 vicariates, each under an episcopal vicar who will be the representative of Archbishop Peter L. Gerety.

title: For Fair Reform
description: Even in this climactic Watergate year an ominous amount of money is being spent in election campaigns. The Democratic primary for Governor of this state was a glaring example, and so was the abortive Senatorial campaign of Abraham Hirschfeld. Yet the longdiscussed Federal campaign financing reforms still await action by a Congressional conference committee, with no more than a hope that they will emerge in full strength and be signed into law.

title: Child to Dr. Hochstadt
description: A daughter was born Aug. 24 to Dr. Harvey Ozer and Dr. Joy Hochstadt of Worcester, Mass., in the St. Vincent Hospital there. Dr. Ozer and his wife, who retains her maiden name, are senior scientists at the Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology in Shrewsbury, Mass. They have named their child Juliane Natasha HochstadtOzer.

title: Cruise Ship Fire Is Out; Liner Going to Key West
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 14 (UPI)  Fire fighters succeeded today in putting out a fire that had burned for two days and damaged six decks of the Cunard Line's luxury cruise ship Ambassador.

title: A mixed trio
description: Mark Dintenfass is an original. True, he reminds one of the early John Barth and the recent Thomas McGuane. He possesses an ample portion of Barth's wit and his way of making the most abstract and abstruse passages read like dramatic scenes. He has much of McGuane's acuity and his flare for stylizing confrontations between man and man, and man and his ideLs. But ultimately, like all good writers, Dintenfass has an individual voice, a quirky vison and a vitalky of language which is More than matched by his intelligence. Perhaps it is this last gift which is most impressive: Ideas flash from Dintenfass's prose, yet never blind one to character or action.

title: Forest Hills Fans Angered by RipOff
description: Fans at the United States Open Tennis championships in Forest Hills sat on benches in the stadium last week, muttering words like ripoff and cheat.

title: The Modern Wardrobe: Oriented to the Sun Most of the Year
description: Once it was only people of ??? wealth who could afford travel south for sun and fun in the middle of winter. Today, even with inflation, younger people as. well as less affluent ones are managing it.

title: Jaworski Reportedly Ignored In Ruling to Return Nixon Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, SEPT. 14 The special Watergate prosecutor's office, although strongly opposed to the decision to return While HouSe tapes and documents to former President Richard M. Nixon, was given no direct role in that conchasion, according to several wellplaced sources.

title: Britain's Liberal Party Looks to Elections With Deeply Mixed Emotions About Joining a Coalition
description: LONDON, Sept. 14It is all too soggy, said Robin Otter, a delegate from the west country who was trying to persuade the Liberal party conference to sharpen a resolution.

title: Neglect is his second cousin
description: It's all the time like that, Chekhov once complained to Ivan Bunin about his reputation, Korolenko and Chekhov, Potapenko and Chekhov, Gorky and Chekhov. The fate of William Gerhardie has been scarcely better, and a great deal worse. Gerhardie does not even have the luxury of being coupled with another author; he is rarely, if ever, mentioned and when he is, it is merely in passing to say that he has been the model for more famous successors. Neglect has now become his second cousin.

title: Now It's on to the Real Election
description: With Democrats more hopeful than at any time in the last 16 years and with Republicans conceding, at least privately, that they may have cause for concern, the New York State election campaign has begun in earnest.

title: West German Found Dead After Error in NATO Game
description: NEUMUNSTER, West Germany, Sept. 14 (Reuters)A West German army officer who helped organize a night drop by British paratroopers in which at least five men were drowned in the Kiel Canal has been found hanged, officials here said today.

title: Navy Blunts Virginia Bid, Wins, 3528
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 14 (AP)Navy built a 28point fourthquarter lead and then staved off a frantic Virginia rally today for a 3528 victory over the Cavaliers.

title: GUIDE TO DIALECT BARRED IN TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 14A TaiwaneseEnglish dictionary in limited circulation has aroused a controversy that points up the sensitivity of the Taiwanese dialect as an issue here.

title: The Hoarders
description: Now come the hoarding days, not only for the traditional bee and ant but for all provident creatures. Field mice have been harvesting and stowing seeds for weeks. So have chipmunks, stocking their winter granaries with everything from grass seed to acorns. Squirrels put even the ants to shame with their scurrying industry, stowing nuts by the bushel, at least a third of which they probably never will find again; that is the way the woodland spreads. And the woodchucks, gorging on grass and clover and fruit and laying up their harvest in body fat, hoarding their winter reserves under their own skins.

title: Israeli Party Joins Rabin
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Central Committee of Israel's National Religious ??? voted today to rejoin Premier Yitzhak Rabin's ??? give it with 10 additional seats, a clear majority of 71 seats in the 120member Parliament.

title: Unlikely Hero Puts Cards 1  Games Up
description: Alan Hrabosky is one of the least known of the St. Louis Cardinals. Most people even have trouble pronouncing his name (ruhBOSskee), but the 25yearold Cards lefthander has become a big man in the St. Louis stretch bid for the National League Eastern Division title.

title: Inmates Still on Protest Diet
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Sept, 15 (AP)Three Walpole prison inmates, protesting conditions in the solitary confinement unit, were in the 22d day of a hunger strike today.

title: Life in Washington Gives Mormons a New Outlook
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Before 8 A.M. on Sunday in Chevy Chase, Md., one of this city's most affluent suburbs, the heavy cars come quietly through the streets past the lovely, costly homes, arriving in, a group and clogging the entrance to the asphalt parking lot behind the brick church.

title: What Work Can Do to You
description: BALTIMOREA year ago Tom Meade, a young worker at a chemical plant in Colunpus, Ohio, noticed weakness in his arms and legs. Soon he could hardly walk. Yet doctors could find nothing wrong with him. Then other workers began to complain of similar problems, and eventually it was discovered that 66 of them, including Meade, had.a serious nerve disease caused by a toxic chemical they worked with. The company stopped using the chemical, but too late for Tom Meade. At the age of 23 he was permanently crippled. He wore braces on his legs, and his hands wouldn't perform even simple tasks such as turning on a lamp.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Soviet authorities used bulldozers, dump trucks and waterspraying trucks to break up an unofficial, nonconformist art exhibition in suburban Moscow. A crowd of several hundred persons ran for cover when dump trucks and bulldozers overran what had been announced as the Soviet Union's first autumn outdoor art show. Three American correspondents were beaten by young men who patrolled the area, intimidating onlookers. The police made no effort to stop the violence. [1:5.]

title: Hudson Lemkau Sr., 63, Dies; A Partner in Morgan Stanley
description: Hudson Bardon Lemkau Sr., a limited partner of Morgan Stanley & Co., the investment banking concern, and an investment banker since 1942, died yesterday while playing golf on the Creek Club course, Locust Valley; L.I. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Book Club for the Modern Woman in the Modern World
description: When Gloria Norris was a girl growing up in Holcomb, Miss. (Pop. 200), in the heart of Faulkner country, the most popular woman's book in her town library was the pristine White Orchids, by Grace Livingston Hill.

title: McGraw Takes 54 Loss As Error Proves Costly
description: More bottom fell out of the New York Mets deteriorating season yesterday as the Chicago Cubs scored a 5.4 victory before a paying crowd of 17,288 at Shea Stadium.

title: THE RESTAURANTS OF NEW YORK
description: Wittiest and best guide to 202 dining spots. Paperback. At bookstores. ADV.

title: Blue CrossBlue Shield Will Increase Benefits
description: Benefits will be increased beginning Oct. 1 for more than 2.5 million subscribers to the Rider 5 plan of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey. There will be no additional charges for the broader coverage.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Q38 bus, which will link Rego Park and Oakland Gardens in Queens, will make its first trip at 6:30 A.M. today. According to Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials, the bus, which will operate along Horace Hatding Expressway, will give commuters in Northeast Queens access to shopping facilities and the subway line along Queens Boulevard.

title: Dolphins Upset by Patriots
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 15The Who beat the What?

title: Attack on Untouchables Points Up Caste Tension in Rural India
description: LUCKNOW, IndiaRam Sunder Lal Yadav barely speaks now. He walks with a limp and his right arm is lame. His eyes bulge.

title: Swedish Premier Calls Chilean Leaderis 'Crooks
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Premier Olof Palme yesterday described the military government of Chile as despicable crooks and newspapers speculated today that the two nations might break off diplomatic relations.

title: Debacle in Housing
description: The housing industry and the thrift institutions that lend heavily to home builders and buyers have been harder hit by inflationand the tightmoney policies used by Government to fight inflationthan any other sector of the economy. Housing starts have fallen from a peak rate of 2.5 million units at the beginning of 1973 to 1.3 million this summer, and the rate is apparently still dropping. The most important cause of the slump is the flight of funds from the savings institutions, depositors seek higher interest returns or greater security elsewhere.

title: SONGS PRESENTED BY DOLLY PARTON
description: Country in New York got off to a rather disappointing second season Saturday night in terms of attendance: The Felt Forum was nowhere near full, and if anyone had had hopes for a second show, they must have been abandoned early on.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK 5 FOR JUDGE RACES
description: Reformers lost to regulars as the two factions of the Democratic party fought their first postprimary battle Saturday night  over the selection of candidates for five State Supreme Court judgeships in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: SINDONIA REPORTED IN A COURT INQUIRY
description: ROME, Sept. 15  Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, has been told by a magistrate in Milan that he is under investigation and has been advised to retain counsel, Italian newspapers reported today.

title: Amex Faces Increasing Pressure to Merge It Into the Big Board
description: Most major Wall Street brokerage firms have come to feel that they can do without one of the cornerstones of their industry, the American Stock Exchange: They want it merged into the New York Stock, Exchange, and, since they control The exchanges, they have the clout, tO.make it happen.

title: MRS. ROBERT W. YATES
description: Pauline M. Yates, wife of Robert W. Yates, senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York, died Saturday at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. She was 45 years old and lived at 792 Arrow Lane, Ridgewood. She was a member of the Ridgewood Country Club and the Salem Ridge Association.

title: TUNISIAN ASSERTS CONTROL OF PARTY
description: MONASTIR, Tunisia, Sept. 15 There is dissidence in Tunisia but little of it was heard in the modern convention hall here today when President Habib Bourguiba completed a process of reestablishing full control over the country s political apparatus.

title: Law Professor Suggests Jaworski Oppose Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Two nationally prominent lawyers disagreed today on the validity of the pardon granted to former President Richard M. Nixon a week ago by President Ford, with one lawyer saying that the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, should challenge the pardon in court.

title: Peking Wary of Conflict on Key Jobs
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 15With Chou Enlai on the sidelines in failing health, the emphasis in Peking seems to be on forestalling conflict over key leadership positions by making it plain that no one person is going to inherit the authority the Premier wieldedThe only one of the five chairmen of the Communist party who has put in any appearance at all in the last six weeks is Wang Hungwen, the young leader from Shanghai who suddenly emerged last year in the No. 3 position, ranking behind only Chairman Mao Tsetung and Premier Chou.

title: SOVIET NOT LEADER, RUMANIA STRESSES
description: VIENNA, Sept. 15(Reuters) Rumania's Communist party served notice today that the Soviet Union was no longer politically acceptable as the guiding center of the world Communist movement.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The sixth annual AfricanAmerican Day parade in Harlem yesterday attracted 75,000 onlookers along the northbound lane of Seventh Avenue and thousands more at the windows and roofs of buidings along the way. It was a neighborly kind of parade, mainy for fun with few overtones of militance or politics.

title: Wheat Hopes Fade
description: An early frost has dimmed the prospects for Canada's wheat crop at a time of food shortages in many countries. Details on Page 55.

title: Brooklyn Hasidim Believed Planning Large Colony at Upstate Resort Site
description: MONROE, N. Y.A colony, of several thousand ultraOrthodox Hasidic Jews from Brooklyn's crowded Williamsburg section is apparently taking shape in this Orange County summer resort area about an hour north of New York City.

title: Radnor II Takes Nassau Jumpoff
description: GREENVALE, L.1., Sept. 15, Radnor II, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Neal Eustace of Stonington, Conn., and handled by Melanie Smith, scored the only, clean round in the jumpoff and captured the Nassau Grand Prix today.

title: News Conference Likely Today, President Hints
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)President Ford indicated to reporters today that he might hold a news conference tomorrow.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Ailing Saigon Child in U.S.
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 15 (AP)A 3yearold South Vietnamese girl weighing 17 pounds was in an intensivecare ward in a hospital here today, awaiting tests to see if doctors can save her life. Tran Thi Het, who suffers from a heart defect, arrived early today in Houston from Saigon where she was found starving in the street a year ago. A spokesman at Texas Children's Hospital said that her physical condition would have to be built up before the tests.

title: William Hubben, 78, Dies; Editor of Friends Journal
description: William Hubben, an authority on the Quaker faith and editor of the Friends Journal from 1955 to 1963, died Sept. 8 in the Germantown Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 78 years old.

title: Polo Results
NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Queens Woman Tells Police Of Multiple Rapes by 3 Men
description: A 36yearold Queens woman returning from a church meeting late Friday night was kidnapped and raped by three men who had offered to drive her home, the police reported yesterday.

title: Robert Abrams Weds Diane Schulder
description: Robert Abrams, Borough President of the Bronx and Democratic candidate for state Attorney General, and Diane B. Schulder, a lawyer specializing in women's matrimonial law, were married in the Bronx yesterday afternoon.

title: Grenade Explosion. Kills 2 and Hurts 26 In Paris Drugstore
description: PARIS, Sept. 15  A hand grenade exploded in a crowd on the lower sales floor of the SaintGermaindesPres drugstore date this afternoon, killing two persons and wounding 26.Some of the injured were reported in grave condition.

title: Yanks Win, 102, Lead by 2Cubs Rally in 9th to Beat Mets
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15Larry Gura, called Guru by his teammates, picked up his fourth victory without a loss for the Yankees today by mesmerizing the Detroit Tigers, 102. The triumph stretched the Yankees lead over the secondplace Orioles to 2 games and to 3 games over the third  place Red Sox in the American League East race. The Orioles and Red Sox both lost today.

title: WORLD INFLATION STIRS A WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The International Monetary Fund warned the world'S industrial countries today that they will have to run their economies for a long time to come with higher unemployment and slower economic growth than they have been used to, if world inflation is to be conquered.

title: MARITIME UNIONS AID CONGRESSMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The maritime unions have poured at least $333,300 this year into the campaigns of members of Congress who supported a bill to require that a bigger portion of oil imported into the United States be shipped in American tankers manned by American crews, according to campaign finance reports made available today. The unions, whose members stand to get thousands of new jobs if the bill becomes law, contributed to 141 members of Congress who supported the disputed bill and to only four who opposed it, the reports show.

title: VESCO PANEL TO GET GUNRUNNING DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 15 (AP) Evidence that highly sophisticated rifles and shotguns were smuggled out of this country to a fugitive financier, Robert L. Vesco, will be presented at Senate subcommittee hearings scheduled for Tuesday, according to Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington.

title: Study Cites Gap in Aid to Puerto Rico
description: Travel Guide to the States for Puerto Ricans: The best place to move to is Boston. Stay away from Bolivar County, Miss. If you are torn between moving in with relatives in Newark or relatives in New York City, you're significantly better off with New York.

title: Budget Unit Names Director
description: Dr. Herbert J. Ranschburg, an economist, was named yesterday as director of research and secretary of the Citizens Budget Commission. He has been a staff member of the civic group since 1952. His election by the board of trustees was announced by William S. Benchard, the board chairman.

title: About New York
description: New York is a bookish town, in the class of Paris and London  local boosters say it may lead the classand its addiction to reading is reflected in its multitude of bookstores.

title: Theater: New Faustus Materializes
description: LONDONAlthough near!: all of Britain's bestknowi playwrights (Harold Pinte is a notable exception) have contributed new plays to the current London season, the Establishment theater has very healthy regard for the value of classic revivals. The Royal Shakespeare Company produced Peter Barnes's Te Bewitched and Tom Stop pard's Travesties earlier this season, but its repertory consists of Marlowe's Dr, Faustus, Maxim Gorki': Summerfolk and the firs( London showing of its production of Richard II, which was performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this year. It is a small but formidable repertory.

title: Canada's Wheat Hopes Fade At a Time of Food Shortages
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 15An early killing frost on the Canadian prairies has dimmed they prospects for this country's vital wheat crop, prospects that were already none too bright.

title: Warren Hull, Radio.TV Host Of Strike It Rich, Dead at 71
description: Warren Hull, the radio and television master of ceremonies perhaps bestknown for the Strike It Rich quiz show, died Saturday at Waterbury, (Conn.) General Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived hi Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn.

title: Public TV Starts National Fund Drive
description: The successful fundraising techniques developed by such public television stations as WNET/13 here and WGBH in Boston will be applied on a national scale in a new threeyear project whose objective will be to triple the number of households making annual contributions to public television.

title: Colleges Year Abroad Marks Jubilee
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13 Fifty years ago this month Margaret Duross MacKay, then a junior at Marymount College, sailed for Paris with six other young women as part of an experiment in education.

title: Texas a Major U.S. Center for Illegal Dogfighting and Gambling
description: DALLASIf it can be said that there is a capital of dog fighting, the illegal, usually organized, gamblers game that is growing from coast to coast, then it is probably in Texas.

title: VIETNAM CATHOLICS STAGE HUE PROTEST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept 15 (Reuters)  Thousands of Roman Catholics today protested in the city of Hue against alleged government corruption and the behavior of the police who dispersed a rally last week.

title: Jean B. Levin Wed To Bernard Albert
description: Jean B. Levin of Livingston, N.J., and Bernard L. Albert of Paterson, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's sister and brotherinlaw, Dr. and Mrs. Walter Nudelman, in South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Ely Pilchik of Short Hills officiated.

title: Kansas City Takes Opener by 2416
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 15Hank Stram, the dapper coach, called all the Kansas City plays from the sidelines today, but it was two plays he didn't call that carried the Chiefs to a 2416 victory over the Jets before 74,854 fans.

title: U.S Women Top Aussies At Cup Net
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP)  The United States Won its first Bonne Bell Cup team tennis competition today on a 63, 6.1 victory by its captain, Julie Heldman, over Evonne Goolagong, the Australian star.

title: About New York
description: New York is a bookish town, in the class of Paris and London  local boosters say it may lead the classand its addiction to reading is reflected in its multitude of bookstores.

title: Results of Nearby Yachting
description: Results of Nearby Yachting

title: Abernathy Given Award
description: BERLIN, Sept 15 (Reuters)  The Rev. Ralph J. Abernathy, President of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, received an award here this weekend for his services to AmericanEast German understanding, the East German newspaper Neue Zeit reported today.

title: Montreal: He's Singer to Every Family
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 15One of the largestselling recording artists in Canada these days is a 13yearold boy soprano whom most of the people in the country have never heard of. Rene Simard, Arts a tiny French Abroad Canadian with freckles, shoulderLength brown hair and an engaging smile, is enormously popular among the people of Quebec, who have bought several million dollars worth of his records in the last two years.

title: STEVENSON ASKS INQUIRY ON F.P.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d said today he was dismayed by a report by the General Accounting Office accusing the Federal Power Commission of improper procedures in allowing some price increases on natural gas. The Illinois Democrat called for a full investigation by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: U.S. Took Extraordinarily Soft Line In Allende's First Year, Envoy Says
description: In the late Salvador Allende Gossens's first year as Presi dent in Chile, the United State pursued an extraordinaril soft line and tried to develo a modus vivendi with the leftist Government, according to former Ambassador Edward M Korry.

title: HAIG EXPECTS COLE TO LEAVE FORD, TOO
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Gen, Alexander M, Haig Jr, says he expects his imminent departure from the White House post once held by H. R, Haldeman to be followed by the resignation of Kenneth R. Cole Jr., who succeeded John D, Ehrlichman as domestic policy coordinator.

title: Tower Seeks to Avoid Ford Setback in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Senator John G. Tower tried today to head off a movement at the Texas Republican convention to repudiate President Ford's position on amnesty for war resisters and his choice for Vice President.

title: WALTER W. RUCH
description: Walter W. Ruch, Detroit correspondent for The New York Times from 1941 to 1950, died yesterday at Bon Secours Hospital, Grosse Pointe, Mich. He was 61 years old and lived in Roscommon, Mich.

title: Blacks Urged to Attend Boston Schools
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15The head of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, reversing his previous position, called on black parents today to send their children to the tronbled South Boston schools.

title: Chess Contest, Opening Today, May Decide Fischer Successor
description: Two Soviet grandmasters will sit down at a chessboard in Moscow today to begin a match that could decide Bobby Fischer's successor as world champion.

title: Priscilla Meyer Is Wed
description: Priscilla Meyer and WilliamTrousdale, professors at Wesleyan University, were married yesterday. The Rev. William Roberts performed the Congregational ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Middletown, Conn. Both the bride and bridegroom have been married previously and divorced. Mrs. Trousdale is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Meyer of New York. Her husband's parents are Mrs. Everett Trousdale of Plymouth, N.H., and the late Mr. Trousdale.

title: Redskins Struggle to Beat Giants, 1310; Jets Lose on Two Chiefs Interceptions
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 15The Washington Redskins escaped with a 1310 victory over the New York Giants today before an openingday crowd of 51,764 at Yale Bowl.

title: OFFICER KILLS BOY DURING BURGLARY
description: A 14yearold Brooklyn boy was shot and killed last night by a police officer during an alleged burglary in a tenement in the Brownsville section of the borough, the police said.

title: Kathleen Reilly Bride Of Jonathan Whitcup
description: Kathleen Siobhan Reilly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Reilly of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Michael Whitcup, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Whitcup of Lawrence, L. I.

title: ANKER IS ASSAILED FOR REINSTATING 2
description: The head of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, which represents 3,500 principals and other supervisors in the city's schoool system, charged yesterday that Chancelor Irving Anker had caved in to the militancy of a small group of exremists by ordering the reinstatement of the acting coprincipals of a lower East Side School. The local school board had removed the two men.

title: Japanese Terrorist. Group Vows Retaliation for failings
description: DAMASCUS., Syria, Sept. 15 (UN)  The Japanese Red Army, three of whose members are holding hostages at the French Embassy in the Hague, threatened today to retaliate with more terrorism if any more of its members were prisoned.

title: Radio
description: Talks, Sports, Events News Broadcasts

title: ARTHUR MACKRETH, FORMER EDITOR, 94
description: Arthur R. W. Mackreth, a former editor, died yesterday at Hempstead (L. I.) General Hospital after having suffered a stroke a few days before. He was 94 years old and lived in Malverne, L. I.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Groups that have been protesting rising rates for electricity's natural gas and phone service might offer a bit of commiseration to those who do their heating and cooking with propane gas. Since May of last year the price of some users has gone up 125 to 300 per cent.

title: SAUDI ARABIA SAID TO RAISE, OIL PRICE
description: VIENNA, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Saudi Arabia has informed other oilexporting countries she intends to raise the average cost, of its oil by about 13 cents a barrel, oil sources said today.

title: Rabin Says Israel Hopes to Exchange Land for Egyptian Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel said today that his country hoped to trade further Israeli troop withdrawals in the Sinai Peninsula for Egyptian adeements to cease diplomatic and economic activity against Israel.

title: AGOSTINO NOVELLA
description: ROME, Sept. 15 (AP)Agostino Novella, Communist trade union leader and a former member of Parliament, died last night after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the title story of The Camberwell Beauty, a young antique dealer falls in love with the adopted daughter of another antique dealer, only to see her married off to a third elderly dealer who keeps her locked up and simply looks at her each night with the lust of a porcelain collector. The girl's husband warns her against other men, alleging that they are all as bad as her adopted father, who used to try to get into her bed. When her husband is out of the shop, the girl, who may be halfwitted, plays a marching drum and blows a bugle to frighten away possible rapists or seducers. After an unsuccessful try, the young antique dealer is disappointed in his love for her and the story ends.

title: Personal Finance: Costs of Buying a New Car
description: If you're thinking about buying a 1975 automobileand now is the time that auto manufacturers go all out inputting such thoughts in your headbe prepared for some whopping price increases over the 1974 models, and for the cost of financing it too.

title: Red Smith
description: Mary Bacon is a distinct success as a blonde, one of the most scenic this side of the chorus of Lorelei, but it would be a mistake to put her away as just another pretty face She is a jockey of recognized talent and an athlete of extraordinary hardihood. And now it turns out that on top of everything else she is a sportscaster as discerning aswell, as that fellow who now plays opposite Alex Karras on Monday night football. Mary was a member of the team that handled last Saturday's $250,000 invitational at Belmont for CBS. (The Philip Morris people put up hundreds of thousands to bankroll the production but couldn't call it the Marlboro Cup because their lawyers said that would be advertising cigarettes on the air.) Anyhow, interviewing Heliodoro Gustines before the race, Mary noted that his mount, Forego, had to carry more weight than any of his rivals. Pulling no punches, she askee. Will that help him hinder him?

title: Passerby Rescues Five Children Here In a Tenement Fire
description: A 40year old Brooklyn man passing by a burning tenement early yesterday morning rushed inside, roused the sleeping inhabitants and led at least five children to safety.

title: Industrialists Eager To Advise President
description: More than 40 of the nation's top business and industry leaders, many of them concerned about soaring interest rates and the need for cash to finance future expansion, meet today in Pittsburgh to offer advice to the Ford Administration.

title: The Pennant Race
description: The Pennant Race

title: Bette Ruth Rockmore Wed to S. N. Jacobson
description: Bette Ruth Rockmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Rockmore of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Stephen N. Jacobson, vice; president of Vanity Fabrics, a textile company here. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Banks Give Big Discounts For Prepaid Mortgages
description: Banks and other savings instittitions are beginning to offer, homeowners big discounts if they make full or partial prepayments on their mortgages. Generally those with mortgages can get as much as $5 knocked off their debt for $4 cash.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers

title: Grenade Explosion Kills 2 and Hurts 26 In Paris Drugstore
description: PARIS, Sept. 15  A hand grenade exploded in a crowd on the lower sales floor of the SaintGermaindesPres drugstore late this afternoon, killing two persons and wounding 26.

title: Ryan Throws 3Hitter To Gain 20th Victory
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP)Nolan Ryan won his 20th game with a threehitter, pitching the California Angels to a 62 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

title: Islam Today: The Koran as a Constitution
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia The sands that Mohammed trod here 13 centuries ago remain the spiritual capital for 530 million Moslems and the place where Islam is practiced in its most fundamentalist form.

title: Robert Bak, 65, ExHead Of Psychoanalytic Institute
description: Dr. Robert C. Bak, a psychoanalyst and former president of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society, died Saturday in Washington. He was 65 years old and lived at 1045 Park Avenue here, where he also maintained offices.

title: Steelers Change to Gilliam Pays Off in 300 Rout
description: A dramatic rolereversal helped launch the 1974 National Football League season yesterday.

title: Owners of Wetlands Ask For Tax Assessment Cuts
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE Owners of much of the state's 320,000 acres of wetlands are seeking sharp reductions in their taxes because, they contend, their land has been rendered virtually useless by the newly implemented New Jersey Wetlands Act.

title: Charred Cunard Vessel Tied Up at Key West Base
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Sept, 15 UPIThe charred luxury liner Cunard Ambassador, ravaged by fire for two days last week, tied up at the Key West Naval Station today and insurance investigators immediately hoarded her to begin an evaluation of damages.

title: A. WELLS PECK, 86, LED STORE CHAIN
description: A. Wells Peck, a former chairman of the Peck & Peck specialty store chain, died early yesterday at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Conn, four days after he was critically injured in an automobile accident at his country home in Litchfield. He was 85 years old.

title: MRS. DONALD SPICER, EXHEAD OF D.A.R.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Mrs. Donald Spicer, immediate past presidentgeneral of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died Friday at the age of 71. She lived in suburban McLean, Va.

title: SCHOOLS CLOSED IN TEXTBOOK RIFT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 15School officials, fearful of further violence by Fundamentalist critics of supposedly filthy, antiGod and unAmerican textbooks in the Kanawha County public schools, postponed tonight for at least another day the resumption of classes for 44,500 pupils in the West Virginia capital.

title: Events Today
description: DARLENE SHERVINGTON, singer, Lincoln Center LibraryMuseum, 6:30. LA TUERCA, Dominican Republic folk vault, Central Park Mail, 7:30.

description: How They Stand Today American League National League TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS

title: France Plans Naval Move
description: PARIS, Sept. 15 (AP)France will strengthen her naval presence in the Indian Ocean next month with an aircraft carrier and a detachment of marines, authoritative sources said today.
