description: Dog Show Results

title: Banks Give Big Discounts For Prepaid Mortgages
description: Banks and other savings institutions are beginning to offer homeowners big discounts if they make full or partial prepayments on their mortgages. Generally those with mortgages can get as much as $5 knocked off their debt lot $4 cash.

title: Kennedy Promises Answer Soon on His Plans for 76
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15Senator Edward M. Kennedy teases a ripple of laughter from his audience when he says that his delight at being here has absolutely nothing to do with California's 271 votes at the Democratic convention in 1976 or its 45 electoral votes in the next Presidential race.

title: Miller Wins World Open In Playoff
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Sept. 15If Johnny Miller were betting man, he would have lost two wagers. But even he did not anticipate how close the finish of the World open would bea fourman playoff that went to two extra holes.

title: Bay Area Transit Tunnel Opening to Public Today
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15Tomorrow, after 27 years of talking, 10 years of building, $1.6billion of spending and countless delays, malfunctions and other difficulties, this city's muchheralded futuristic mass transit system will finally open its last major segmentprobably.

title: LEBANON REPORTS 2 ISRAELI ATTACKS
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 15  Israeli fighter bombers stxuck today at targets in southeast Lebanon, killing one civilian and wounding two others, the Ministry of Defense said in a conlmunique.

title: Body of Girl Found in Pool
description: ELMONT, L.I., Sept. 15 (UPI) A 3yearold girl who wandered away from her parents yesterday was later found dead in the family's swimming pool, the Nassau County police reported today. The body of the child, Rennee Hakin, was found by her father, Schalom.

title: Islam Today: The Koran as a Constitution
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia The sands that Mohammed trod here 13 centuries ago remain the spiritual capital for 530 million Moslems and the place where Islam is practiced in its most fundamentalist form.

title: NIXON IS SECLUDED AS DEBATE GROWS ABOUT HIS HEALTH
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon remained secluded yesterday at his San Clerneute, Calif., estate instead of a hospital, as his doctors had recommended, amid growing concern and controversy over the true state of his physical and mental health.

title: Miriam K. Freund Has Nuptials
description: Miriam K. Freund of New York, national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, from 1956 to 1960, was married here yesterday morning to Harry Rosenthal of St. Paul. Rabbi David Kahane performed the ceremony in the Synagogue for the United Nations, of which the bride's former husband, the late Milton B. Freund, a financier, had been president.

title: Fat Clinics Challenged on Use of Drug
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 15Medical authorities across the country are pressing legal attacks against the rapidly growing number of weightreducing clinics that advertise medically supervised treatments using a drug that the Government refuses to approve as either safe or effective.

title: RUSSIANS DISRUPT MODERN ART SHOW
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15In a dramatic confrontation over nonconformist art, Soviet authorities used bulldozers, dump trucks and waterspraying trucks today to break up an outdoor exhibition of unofficial art as it was being set up in a vacant lot.

title: JACKSON IS STILL PUZZLE TO POLICE
description: Homicide detectives examined records of rape, robbery and assault cases and unsolved murders on the West Side yesterday in an effort to verify statements by Calvin Jackson, the 26yearold former convict, who is said to have implicated himself in the slayings of 11 women in the last two years.

title: Colleges unior Year Abroad Marks fubilee
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13  Fifty years ago this month Margaret Duross MacKay, then a junior at Marymount College, sailed for Paris with six other young women as part of an experiment in education.

title: Mayor Kept Off the France
description: LE HAVRE, France, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Maritime authorities today banned the Communist mayor of Le Havre from going on board the strikebound luxury liner France, anchored since Wednesday across the main approach to thi port. The mayor has promised the city's full support to the crew.

title: Gromyko Arrives in Bonn For 2 Days of Discussions
description: BONN, Sept. 15 (UPI) Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher of West Germany assured Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union today that Bonn was trying to make the European security conference on mutual cutbacks in armed forces a success, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: Advertising: Dry Sack Effort
description: Dry Sack Sherry, whose advertising and promotion budget last year was a mere $495,000, is bumping it this year to $3million with $2million going into television.

title: Rough Race In Michigan To Al Unser
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Sept. 15Al Unser won the Norton 250mile Championship Car race today and was lucky his mirrors were dirty. He didn't have to see the race.

title: JACOB L. RUDER
description: Jacob L. Ruder, a founder of the Ruder Brothers Furniture Company, died yesterday in Doctor's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 340 West 57th Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal, twinight doubleheader. (RadioWHN, 6:05 P.M.)

title: DISMISSAL URGED IN INDIANS TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 15Defense attorneys in the Wounded Knee trial asked Judge Fred J. Nichol in Federal District Court last night to dismiss charges against two American Indian leaders, Russell C. Means and Dennis J. Banks, because of what they termed misconduct of prosecutors and of Government investigators and witnesses.

title: LIBRARY IS SETTING FOR RUSH DANCERS
description: On Saturday night, Columbia University's imposing Low brary served as the somewhat cavernous performing space for the dance group called Rush.

title: First Medea of Season Staged by City Opera
description: Seven months ago the New York City Opera added Cherubini's Medea to i s repertory and, with Maralin Niska in the title role, made the venture seem at least somewhat worthwhile.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE ROAD TO MANHATTAN Bob Hope's career of entertaining the troops hhs taken him all over the world, as everybody knows by now. He is an institution, and even today young comedians seek to pattern themselves after him. And yet Mr. Hope is a friend of the mighty in such a fashion that he seems the essence of Middle America, a sort of jester to the powers that be.

title: Two Nursing Homes Show Range in the Quality of Care
description: The thing that bothers me most, a State Medicaid official confided recently, is that rates don't seem to be related to the level of care. Recent visits to two nursing homes here served to dramatize that concern.

title: 70 ON SAIGON JET DIE IN HIJACKING
description: SAIGON; South Vietnam, Sept. 15Sixty.two passengers and eight crew members were killed today when an Air Vietnam Boeing 727, apparently hijacked by a man demanding to go to Hanoi, exploded near a provincial airfield on the coast of South Vietnam.

title: Sun Myung Moon a Prophet to Thousands
description: His face is everywhere, it seems.

title: Sun Myung Moon a Prophet to Thousands
description: His face is everywhere, it seems.

title: Hackettstown Woman, 56, Wages Lone Sewer Fight
description: HACKETTSTOWN, Sept. 14Every day for a little more than six months, Mrs. Anne Souders has carried a yellow bucket across her front yard to the drycleaning establishment at which she works. In the lavatory there she fills it with water and then returns to her home next door, at 295 Main Street.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (UPI)Harness racing has a new glamour boy in 19yearold Peter Hatighton, son hall of fame reinsman, Bill Hauhgton. The younger Haughton won last night's $117,095 Colonial Trot at Liberty Bell and will be a focal point in this week's two big eventsthe $100,000 Little Brown Jug at Delaware, Ohio, on Thursday and the $100,000 Yonkers Trot at Yonkers Raceway next Saturday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Soviet authorities used bulldozers, dump trucks and waterspraying trucks to break up an unofficial, nonconformist art exhibition in suburban Moscow. A crowd of several hundred persons ran for cover when dump trucks and bulldozers overran what had been announced as the Soviet Union's first autumn outdoor art show. Three American correspondents were beaten by young men who patrolled the area, intimidating onlookers. The police made no effort to stop the violence. [1:5.]

title: ETHIOPIANS DEMAND TRIAL FOR SELASSIE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Teachers Association and various student groups called today for the courtmartial of Haile Selassie, the depqsed Emperor, but a spokesman for the Armed Forces Committee turned down the demands as premature and against the country's interests.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Closing session of 28th Assembly3 P.M.

title: SHOP TALK Tables That Evoke 1930's Hollywood
description: Although famous women are the inspiration of the first model rooms and a display of table, settings at Gimbels East, the Art Deco tables are the real stars of the show.

title: Churchmen Find a Lesson in Chinese Upheava
description: LOUVAIN, Belgium, Sept. 14  A weeklong international theological conference on China, which has excluded missionaries for more than 20 years, ended today with appeals to Christians to study the issues raised by her attempts to transform her society.

title: Engineer Shortage Seen In Nation's Energy Effort
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 15 (UPI) An oil trade magazine says a shortage of engineers will handicap efforts to unearth more energy supplies perhaps for as long as a decade.

title: Law Professor Suggests Jaworski Oppose Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Two nationally prominent laivyers disagreed today on the validity of the pardon granted to former President Richard M. Nixon a week ago by President Ford, with one lawyer saying that the Watergate special prosedutor, Leon Jaworski, should challenge the pardon in court.donits haste and almost secret nature  and said he thought it might have been better if clemency hearings had been held where arguments in favor or against could have been fully developed before decision was made.

title: Harlem Group Told State Cleared Way For Jail Facilities
description: Charges by an ad hoc committee of Hatlem residents that the state is thrusting new correctional prison facilities into their community without prior consultation have been disputed by the State Department of Correctional Services.

title: Now You See It
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15The controversy over the pardon has until now kept attention away from a related matter; the agreement made with Richard M. Nixon on the handling of the papers and tapes accumulated while he was in, the White House. It is an astonishing legal document.

title: Mr. Ford's Priorities
description: The personal qualities of simple virtue characteristic of President Ford are important and refreshing; but doubts will remain over his capacity to provide the necessary leadership to the country unless he now proceeds to surround himself with White House advisers extraordinary talent, untainted by the special interests of the deposed Nixon Administration. The absence of able counsel is cause for great uneasiness; the continuing echo of Nixonian voices is a matter for concern.

title: Cruelty to Children
description: The conclusions to be drawn from the disclosure that unruly teenaped girls have terrorized other youngsters and staff members in the Children's Center, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, are grimly familiar. They are conclusions that can only place almost as much blame on the public as on the responsible officials.

title: Susanna Esman Is Bride
description: Susanna Ruth Esman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron H. Esman, was married here yesterday to Peter Entin Singer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Singer. Both families are of New York. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Stanhope.

title: JUNGLE LAW AIDS PERUVIAN INDIANS
description: PUCALLPA, Peru  Even now in the dry season, tropical rains hammer down on this jungle center, gouging deep red mud gullies along main streets, cutting off the tenuous land tracks to outlying villages, downing light aircraft, theatening river and lakeside farms and leaving the sturdy riverboats as the only link to the forest people.

title: The C.I.A. in Chile
description: Disclosure that the Central Intelligence Agency authorized more than $8 million for covert activities aimed first at preventing Salvador Allende's election as President of Chile and then at destabilizing his Marxist Government would be appalling enough by itself. It is doubly so when stacked against flat denials of any such United States intervention or policy to intervene, some of it in sworn testimony before committees of Congress by former and present Government officials.

title: Arkansas Thinking No. 1 After Upsetting Trojans
description: Two years ago, the Arkansas Razorbacks were considered strong enough to become the No. 1 college football team in the nation if only somebody could trip mighty Nebraska along the way. Joe Ferguson was the Arkansas quarterback capable of leading the team that high and Frank Broyles, the coach, didn't hide his enthusiasm I for his team's chances.

title: History of Youth in Rape Case Shows Mental Illness in 1966
description: A 15yearold Queens youth charged with raping an 11yearold girt Saturday in a synagogue had been under periodic treatment for mental illgess dating to 1966, psychiatrists familiar with his case reported yesterday.

title: Dobryssinger
description: WASHINGTON Anatoly, I have the bottle of brandy you sent, said Henry Kissinger to Soviet Ambassador Dobrynin on the telephone a couple of years ago. The Secret Service is going over it now for hidden microphones.

title: Rescuers Clearing Debris in Search of Victims of Flash Flood at Village in Nevada
description: NELSON, Nev., Sept. 15 (AP)  Huge earthmoving machines clawed through a thick sheet of rock and silt today as rescue divers searched for seven persons missing following a flash flood in this lakeside village.

title: HOPE FOR A RALLY IN STOCKS IS DIM
description: Last Friday, the 13th, the Dow, Jones industrial average dashed the hopes of investors by sinking to its lowest level in almost 12 years. It has dropped 40 per cent in a year and a half. In relation to corporate earnings, it reflects the lowest state of investor confidence since 1949.

title: LEBANON REPORTS ISRAELI ATTACKS
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 15  Israeli fighter bombers struck today at targets in southeast Lebanon, killing one civilian and wounding two others, the Ministy of Defense said in a communiqu.

title: Julian Breen, Finance Aide For Jewish Relief Abroad
description: Julian Breen, director of the department of budget and finance of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, a relief agency aiding Jews overseas, died yesterday at his home in Geneva. He was 62 years old.

title: Bridge: High School Competition Virtually Nonexistent Here
description: In view of the considerable popularity of bridge among American adults, the lack of encouragement given to teenage players at school is distinctly odd. With Westchester as a limited exception there is virtually no activity at high schools in the New York metropolitan area, although chess flourishes.

title: Editors Officials Challenge Indictment of 2 Reporters
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 15 (AP) The indictment of two Indianapolis Star reporters who investigated alleged corruption within the city police represents a dangerous threat to the First Amendment, officers of two national editors associations said yesterday.

title: Giants and Jets Lose
description: Thee Giants and Jets lost yesterday as the National Football League began the regular season. The Giants were edged, 13.10, by the Washington Redskins at Yale Bowl. In Kansas City, the Jets were beaten by the Chiefs, 2416. The Miami Dolphins, last year's champions, were upset by the New England Patriots, 3424. Page 45.

title: MOZAMBIQUE NEEDY ARE GIVEN SUPPLIES
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Guerrillas and Portuguese soldiers began handing out food, today in the troubled shantytowns of Lourengo Marques, stricken last week by racial violence and looting that took more than 80 lives.

title: 70 on Saigon Plane Die as It Explodes During Hijacking
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15Sixty two passengers and eight crew Members were killed today when an Air Vietnam Boeing 727, apparently hijacked by a man demanding to go to Hanoi, exploded near provincial airfield on the coast of South Vietnam.

title: JOBLESSNESS RISE IN STATE IS SEEN
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Unemployment in New Jersey is expected to rise substantially by the end of the year because of possible fuel shortages and rising inflation, according to the state's Economic Policy Council.

title: Nine Men Linked to Organized Crime Go On Trial Today in Eight Murders
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Sept. 15Nine men linked to organized crime, eight of them blood members of the Campisi family and all accused of committing five murders and conspiring to commit three more, will go on trial here tomorrow. The defendants are also charged with conspiring to operate gambling and narcotics rackets financed by more than 100 armed robberies, and conspiring to murder criminal rivals, disloyal partners in crime and potential witnesses against them.

title: Slain Woman, 83, Found in a Grave; Autopsyls Awaited,
description: HAMMONTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The state police are investigating the murder of an elderly Hamilton Township woman whose body was discovered in a shallow grave over the weekend.

title: Aussies Sail Today With New Rudder
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15If an articulated rudder can't transmit articulate messages to a skipper, one solution is to fire the rudder.

title: Man Slain in West Side Bar
description: A patron in a West Side bar was shot and killed at 2 A.M. yesterday with his own gun by another man he had been arguing with earlier in the bar. The victim, Jose Garcia, 25 years old of 1470 Amsterdam Avenue left the bar at 405 Central Park West following the argument, returned with the gun and reportedly shot Charles White 32, of 1662 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx. Mr. White then took the gun from Mr. Garcia and allegedly shot him several times. Mr. White was treated for a superficial wound and arrested for homicide.

title: For Those Whose Goals Are Firm Muscles and a Svelte Body
description: Stretch, two, three, four. Reach for the, ceiling, reach for your toes. New Yorkers are physicalfitness happy, flocking to fancy salons or spartan gyms to groan their way to flat stomachs and slender hips.

title: Torme, at 49, Shows Growth as a Singer At Maisonette Stint
description: Mel Torme, who became 49 years old last week, is reversing the usual chronological development of pop singers. Instead of learning to fake his way around notes that he can no longer reach or hold, Mr. Torme has grown as a singer.

title: Shari Gruhn Bride Of Grant S. Lewis
description: Shari Janet Gruhn, associate editor of publications for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was married yesterday afternoon in Newton Highlands, Mass., to Grant S. Lewis, who is with the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae here.

title: Screen: Superb Bergman
description: Ingmar Bergman's Scenes From a Marriage, starring the incomparable Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson as lovers who don't always know it, is the first major film event of the autumn season. It's a movie of such extraordinary intimacy that it has the effect of breaking into mysterious components many things we ordinarily accept without thought, familiar and banal objects, faces, attitudes and emotions, especially love.

title: Wynn's Grand Slam Helps Dodgers Down Reds, 71
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15A seventhinning grandslain homer by Jim Wynn, shortly after some fancy clutch pitching by Don Sutton, gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 71 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today and restored them to a 2game lead in the National League West race.

title: 8th ATest of Year By French Reported In South Pacific
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 15 (UPI)  France today exploded her eighth nuclear device in three months of atmospheric tests in the South Pacifc, the governments of Australia and New Zealand reported.

title: Islam Parallels JudeoChristian Traditions, but Stresses Mohammed the Man
description: Islam, the youngest of the world's major religions, was born in Arabia in the early seventh century.

title: Marine Dies of Heat Stroke
description: CAPE LEJEUNE, N. C., Sept. 15 (UPI)Marine officials to day identified a young marine who died yesterday on a conditioning hike as Pvt. William; R. Jones of Paulsboro. Officials, said Private Jones, who had been confined to correctional; custody facilities at Cape LeJeune, apparently died of a heat stroke suffered while on the hike. An investigation was under way, a spokesman said.

title: Business Group Bids Congress Revise Defense Budget System
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 A group of businessmen urged today that Congress revise its procedures for passing on the defense budget by requiring longterm projections on the need for and cost of major weapons systems.

title: TEACHERS UNION SUPPORTING CAREY
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic nominee for Governor has won the endorsement of the state teachers union in a surprise weekend move that campaign stateglsts of both parties saw yesterday as greatly enhancing his chance of winning the endorsement of the State A.F.L.C.I.O. next month.

title: PALESTINIAN AIDES REPORTED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 15  Ranking members of the Palestine Liberation Organization the umbrella grouping of guerrillas, are believed to be among the hundreds of foreign delegates, officials and observers who arrived in New York over the weekend for the General Assembly of the United Nations.

title: Fat Clinics Challenged on Use of Drug
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 15Medical authorities across the country are pressing legal attacks against the rapidly growing number of weightreducing clinics that advertise medically supervised treatments using drug that the Government refuses to approve as either safe or effective.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: FREEa umple melte, from THE RESTAURANTS OF NEW YORK Random House. 201 E. 50th. Dept. 112. Adv.

title: Deaths
description: In Memoriam

title: Terrorists Free 2, Hold 9 in Embassy In the Netherlands
description: THE HAGUE, Monday, Sept. 16Two women hostage.s were released early today by the Japanese terrorists who had been in control of the French Embassy since Friday afternoon.

title: More on the Pardon
description: To the Editor: The Nixon pardon issue comes to this:

title: Terrorists Free 2, Hold 9 At Embassy in The Hague
description: THE HAGUE, Monday, Sept. 16 Two women hostages were released early today by the Japanese terrorists who have been in control of the French Embassy since Friday afternoon. A Dutch police official said the release showed that significant progress had been made in the negotiations with the terrorists to turn, over the remaining nine hostages seized in the raid on the embassy.

title: Energy Policy Combines With Inflation as Topic At Meeting of Businessmen and U.S. Officials
description: DALLAS, Sept., 15 Rogers C. B. Morton, the Secretary of the Interior, and about 40 members of Congress and officials of Federal agencies arrived here by Air Force jet today, bringing to Texas the Ford Administration's quest for a remedy for inflation.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Beset Queens Playhouse
description: Shifts to a Rock Musical the Queens Playhouse has a new crisis on its hands. It has postponed a scheduled fourweek run of An Inspector Calls, which was to open tomorrow and substituted a less expensive production for a shorter run.

title: CARL F. GREENWAY OF SPENCER TRASK
description: Carl F. Greenway, a former general partner and vice president of the investment banking firm of Spencer Trask & Co. and former president of the Metrpolitan Opera Club, died Friday of cancer in Los Angeles. He was 57 years old and had lived here until he moved this year to the West Coast.

title: BookBuying Plan Assailed by Anker As a Strait jacket
description: Chancellor Irving Anker, defending the school system's textbookpurchasing practices against new state criticisms, charged yesterday that some of the economy measures proposed by State Controller Arthur Levitt would put school programs in a Straitjacket if they were carried out.

title: Cunard Will Lease Its Great Hall to Postal Service
description: The United States Postal Service has leased the Great Hall in the Cunard Building facing Bowling Green, saving one of the country's most distinguished interiors.

title: Wilson Allots $2Million for Radio and TV
description: Although Governor Wilson insists he will not be a packaged candidate, his aides hope to run $2million worth of radio and television advertising  an expenditure that would put Mr. Wilson in the same class as his predecessor, Nelson A. Rockefeller. The first of the Wilson television commercials, emphasizing his long record in state service, went on the air last night statewide during the. Fiddler on the Roof movie on the American Broadcasting Company network. He knows how to get things done was the theme. Last night's TV time for the Wilson commercials cost $15,000 to $20,000.

title: MARKET LEADERS CONFER IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Sept. 15The heads of government of the nine Common Market nations achieved some small but possibly significant results at a working dinner here last night that was called to try to make their Community function better.

title: African Visitor to China Says Chou Had Surgery
description: HONG KONG, Monday Sept. 16 (Reuters)Premier Chou Enlai, who is suffering from a heart ailment, has undergone an operation but is now doing well, the Nigerian head of state, Gen. Yakubu Gowon said here today.

title: NIXON IS SECLUDED AS DEBATE GROWS ABOUT HIS HEALTH
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon remained secluded yesterday at his San Clemente, Calif., estate instead of a hospital, as his doctors had recommended, amid growing concern and controversy over the true state of his physical and mental health.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, Sept. 16

title: Liza Minnelli Wed to Jack Haley Jr.
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) Liza Minnelli and the film producer Jack Haley Jr. were married today before a few close friends in suburban Montecito.

title: Sandra Haynie Repeats Victory
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 15 (AP)Sandra Haynie shot four birdies in a fivehole span, overtook Jane Blalock with a record 66 today and defended her victory of last year in the $40,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association charity classic.

title: Parking Rules Suspended
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be suspended during the Jewish New Year, Rosh haShanah, tomorrow and Wednesday, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff announced yesterday. This involves only the threehour 8 A.M.to11 A.M. and 11 A.M.to2 P.M. restrictions and the garment district's fourhour 2 AM.to6 A.M. bans. Parkingmeter and all other parking and standing rules remain in effect.

title: Births
description: Births

title: Outdoor Events Lure Crowds in City Area
description: Yesterday was a sunny latesummer day that drew thousands of people in the metropolitan area to the outdoors. Here are some of the things they did and some of the things they saw.

title: Parking Rules Suspended
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be suspended during the Jewish New. Year, Rosh haShanah, tomorrow and Wednesday, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff, announced yesterday. This involves only the threehour 8 A.M.to11 A.M. and 11 A.M.to2 P.M. restrictions and the garment district's fourhour 2 AM.to6 A.M. bans. Parkingmeter and all other parking and standing rules remain in effect.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The ErieLackawanna Railway will start renting passenger cars to the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority for commuter service between Hoboken, N.J., and Port Jervis, N. Y. New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner, Alan Sagner, said the equipment would be provided at no cost to the state of New Jersey.

title: RUSSIANS DISRUPT MODERN ART SHOW WITH BULLDOZERS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15In a dramatic confrontation over nonconformist art, Soviet authorities used bulldozers, dump trucks and waterspraying trucks today to break, up an outdoor exhibition of unofficial art as it was being set up in a vacant lot.

title: Maryland Five Wins
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 (Reuters)The University of Maryland won the Intercontinental Basketball Tournament with an 8180 victory over Italy's Ignis Varese last night, Vilanova of Brazil finished third, beating Mexico's Aguascalientes, 8254.

title: Belles Heures New Star at Met
description: Any time between 1358 and 1416 it was a pretty good thing to be Jean, Duke of Berry. He was never actually King of France; but he was successively the son, the hrother and the uncle of the man on whose desk the buck stopped. At the age of 18 he was in control of onethird of the country. In times of great public strife and distress he usually saw to it that his own personal interest came out on top. And  what concerns us most herehe earned himself a place amens, the great patrons and collectors of all time.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)The Senate unanimously approved legislation today for Federal regulation of dealers in municipal securities. The bill, which goes the House of Representatives, require brokerdealers who handle only municipal securities to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the first time.

title: TOP BUSINESSMEN CALL FOR EASING OF MONEY POLICY
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18Forty of the nation's business leaders attending a White Housesponsored conference on inflation strongly expressed support today for the Administration's call for balanced budgets and cuts in Federal spending.

title: TV: ABC's ReEdited Version of The Sex Symbol
description: Every once in a while the swamp of primetime entertainment gurgles up a product that sets its own memorable standards for trashiness. Tonight at 8:30, ABC performs the doubleedged honors with The Sex Symbol, an overwrought drama based loosely but unmistakably on the career and death of Marilyn Monroe.

title: Court Decision Is Delayed In Bribery on Beef Here
description: A decision in the conspiracyto bribe trial of Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., and its cochairman of the board, Currier J. Holman, had been expected yesterday, but the trial was adjourned in State Supreme Court in Manhattan until Oct. 7.

title: Bridge: Popularity of Kenn Shown in a Big Schedule
description: The growing popularity of headtohead team play is Demonstrated not only by the remarkable popularity of Swiss team tournaments, but also less spectacularly, in knockout championships that continue throughout a ninemonth season.

title: Satellite Film Backs View on Early Flood
description: A halt century ago J. liarlen Bretz, a University of Chicago geologist, suggested that the barren, heavily scarred region of eastern Washington had been made that way by a flood of phenomenal dimensions.

title: TOP BUSINESSMEN CALL FOR EASING OF MONEY POLICY
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16Forty of the nation's business leaders attending a White Housesponsored conference on inflation strongly expressed support today for the Administratidn's call for balanced budgets and cuts in Federal spending.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Prices on the Amex continued to decline yesterday but those in the overthecounter market closed mixed as traders appeared to be doing considerable short covering.

title: In Africa Moslems Thoroughly Mix Their Culture With Their Faith
description: LAMU, Kenya  When Moslems here become ill, a black chicken is sometimes sacrificed as a spiritual gesture of healing. This is done according to Islamic principles of slaughter  with a sharp knife, the chicken's bead pointing toward Mecca, and while the participants repeat the words In the name of Allah, the great tone.

title: Jury Chosen for Podell Case; Trial Will Begin on Thursday
description: A jury of severfinen, and five women was selected yesterday for the trial of Representative Bertram L. Podell on charges that the Brooklyn Democrat took $41,350 in bribes to help a Florida airline obtain a route to the Ballamas.

title: Oil Users Frustration
description: VIENNA  The meeting of petroleumexporting countries that raised taxes here last Friday on their foreign oil companies has dashed consumer hopes of a decline in oil prices due to market forces or a spurt in Saudi Arabia's production. By raising the government take from each barrel of oil shipped from the Persian Gulf by 33 cents, the members of the Organizetion of Petroleum Exporting Countrieswith the important exception of Saudi Arabia have increased the minimum price of their oil, or taxpaid cost, to $9.74.

title: Rebel Aides in Mozambique To Take Over Government
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  Some 50 officials of the Mozambique Liberation Front flew here today from Dar es Salaam to take over the reins of power from the Portuguese authorities.

title: $59.5Million Interim Rate Rise Given To Largest Utility, With More to Come
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16The Board of Public Utility Commissioners approved a $59.5million emergency rate increase for the Public Service Electric & Gas Company today on the ground that the rise would enable the utility to secure financing vitally needed to meet legitimate service demands.

title: Morton Sees Continued Oil Price Curb
description: DALLAS, Sept. 16  Rogers; C. B. Morton, the Secretary of the Interior, said today that the Federal Government might have to keep price controls on domestic crude oil for two years or more because of the clanged that the international oil cartel would drive up a wholly unregulated price.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SKITS Comedy, they say, doesn't change. It follows rules that were put together by people who were writing comedy long ago, and the road from Aristophanes to television today is a short one, indeed. That, at any rate, might be the thesis of a revue that begins this evening at the Cubiculo, 414 west 51st Street, which is Opening its 197475 season.

title: Some Shifting Probable At TV Outlets for Fight
description: The postponement of the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman heavyweight championship fight yesterday had no immediate effect on the sale of tickets at the metropolitan area closedcircuit television outlets, a spot check revealed.

title: Buckley Backs WNCN Classics Aim
description: By LES BROWN

title: GEN. HAIG NAMED NATO COMMA NDER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford announced today the appointment of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

title: NEW YORK WINS LOTTERY GOAHEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Justice Department today gave the New York. State Lottery a clean bill of health, and exempted the lottery from a planned Federal crackdown.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA 8 P.M.)

title: AMERICAN MOTORS STRUCK BY U.A.W.
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 (UPI)Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and the American Motors Corporation broke off today and 15,000 U.A.W. members went on strike.

title: Man Held in Gulliver's Fire Seeks Dismissal of Charge
description: WHITE PLAINS Sept. 16 (UPI)  Motions have been filed to dismiss charges against Peter Leonard, indicted for starting the June 30, fire that killed 24 persons in a Port Chester discothque. Mr. Leonard's attorney, Stephen J. Pittari said today.

title: BOARD OF PHARMACY REVOKES 2 LICENSES
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The State Board of Pharmacy has revoked the licenses of two pharmacies and suspended the licenses of four others for improper distribution of prescription drugs, the State Attorney General's office announced today.

title: TROOPERS LIMITED AT CAMPISI TRIAL
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Sept. 16Superior Court Judge W. Thomas McGann today ruled that state troopers providing security at the trial of nine men linked to organized crime appear in plainclothes rather in uniform.

title: GEN. HAIG NAMED NATO COMMANDER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford announced today the appointment of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

title: DAILY REPORTS SET ON WHEAT EXPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)To prevent depletion of United States agricultural supplies, large exports of wheat and certain other products must be reported daily to the United States Government beginning this week.

title: Haig Pleaon Nixon Health Linked to Ford's Reversal
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 16The White House chief of staff, Gen, Alexander M. Haig Jr., after being advised of the alaiming state of Richard M. Nixon's health, was reliably reported today to have persuadedi President Ford to reverse his publicly stated position and grant an immediate pardon to the former President.

title: State U. Fears Falcons Were Killed
description: A pair of young peregrine falcons that had been carefully raised and then released to the wild at the State University College at New Paltz are missing, and one of them is believed to have been deliberately killed.

title: Steel Output Up 2.2% for the Week To 2,731,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 14 rose by 2.2 per sent to 2,731,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 111.9, which compared with the 109.6 of a week ago when output totaled 2,673,000 tons.

title: Walk, Roberson Go To New N.B.A. Five
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 (AP)The National Basketball Association's New Orleans Jazz acquired two players today, picking up a 6foot10inch center, Neal Walk, from the Phoenix Suns and a 69 forward, Rick Roberson, from the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Arnsparger Treads. Softly on Giants Slim Offense
description: In accepting the responsibility for the failure of his offense against the Washington Redskins, Coach Bill Arnsparger may have unveiled another phase of his reconstruction program for the New York Giants.

title: Byrne Signs Bill Continuing Safe Neighborhoods Plan
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) Governor Byrne signed a bill today appropriating $12milion to continue the safe and clean neighborhoods program in 24 cities and towns in New Jersey.

title: The Screen
description: REED: INSURGENT MEXICO, directed by Paul Leduc; screenplay (Spanish with English subtitles) by Juan later and Mr. Leduc; from John Reed's book Mexico Insurgents; photography, Alexis Grivas; editors, Rafael Casteredo and Giovanni Korporaal; released by New. York Films. At the Regency Theater, Broadway between 67th and 68th Streets. Running time: 110 minutes. This film has not been classified.

title: 200 PRINTERS TO QUIT IN AUTOMATION MOVE
description: Approximately 200 printers are expected to retire or resign from The New York Times and The Daily News by next January as a result of recent contracts negotiated with the papers, it was estimated yesterday by Bertram A. Powers, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BALTIMORE (AL)Purchased contract of Jim Northrup, outfielder, from Montreal Expos.

title: CANDY BAR PRICES SEEN HITTING 20C
description: Reductions in fuel, oil and copper prices were offset yesterday by a warning from the Agriculture Department that candy bar prices in vending machines are excepted to be lifted by 5 cents to 20 cents each.

title: Books of The Times
description: Superficially at least, Margaret Drabble's Arnold Bennett: A Biography appears to be one of those exercises in chronology of which the English are so fondone of those records compiled on the dogged assumption that a writer's life is the sum of his days and nights, and his days and nights the sum of the meals and drinks consumed, friends well met, and words committed to paper. (One gets this impression especially if one has had the bad luck, as I did to browse on page 194, where it is recorded that The principal event of 1913 was the removal to Comarques, the Bennett's new country house. Marguerite travelled there on Monday, 24 February, and Arnold followed her the next day. After months of preparation the house, naturally, was not ready: the stair carpet wasn't laid until the end of March, and on 1 April fenders and fireirons were still not complete.) All of which would mean, presumably, that Miss Drabble's study would be approximately as interesting as her subject's life, which does not inspire confidence, since Bennett, while colorful enough for a man of letters, was hugely prolific and therefore spent much of his time sitting at his desk and moving his hand across pieces of paper.

description: Deaths

title: ANY DEAL DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 President Ford said emphatically tonight that he had made no deal with former President Richard M. Nixon and insisted that the major reason for his decision to pardon him was to heal the nation.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's broadcast news conference from the White House last night as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The strike of Legal Aid Society staff lawyers ended its sixth day with both management and the union unable to agree on what form further negotiations would take. The strikers, members of the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys for the City of New York, the bargaining agent that represents 567 staff lawyers, continued to picket courthouses. But. Justice David Ross, citywide administrative judge, said the courts were maintaining a normal rate of productivity.

title: India's Moslems, OncePowerful Minority, Are Slow to.Play a Role in Secular Society
description: niversary of the saint's death.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Highs and Lows

title: 59 Hopefuls Take to Ice For Rangers
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 16Billy Fairbairn tipped in Rod Seiling's long shot today, and the New York Rangers were off and skatingone step nearer the goal of all National. Hockey League teams: the Stanley Cup.

title: A Class to Expand the Waistline, Not the Mind
description: Tom Kron, the Hungarian confectioner who indulges the sweet tooth of such luminaries as Bette Davis, Gloria Vanderbilt. David Susskind and other lesserknown chocolate addicts, has added something new to his stock of goodies  chocolate ice cream.

title: Amnesty But Not Generosity
description: The unconditional preventive pardon that President Ford extended to Richard Nixon is not really relevant to the conditional, halfhearted, halfpunitive amnesty Mr. Ford has offered to Vietnam war draft evaders and deserters. The Nixon pardon makes the amnesty plan look worse; but it does not really maize it worse. It would have been a bad plan whatever had been done about Mr. Nixon.

title: Four Youths Die in Crash
description: MILLRIFT, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP) Four New York youths died and two others were critically injured this weekend in a crash of their pickup truck on a rural road near here, The State Police identified those killed as Kenney Jackson, 19 years old, and Ronald Ludemann, 16, both of Sparrowbush, and Walter Sharp, 13, and his brother Robert, 15, both of Port Jervis. The two passengers hospitalized were Charles Sharp, 14, and Frances Ludemann, 18.

title: Turkish Premier Says He Will Resign
description: ANAKARA, Turkey, Sept. 16Premier Buient Ecevit said today he would resign in the next few days. A source close to the Premier described the resignation plan as a move to hold an early election to capitalize on the success of his policy of intervention in Cyprus.

title: Crossing the Bar
description: What the United States Congress failed to pursue after the resignation and what no Presidential pardon can prevent is now under close consideration in California and New York. It is to put a punctuation marka full stop instead of a dangling semicolonon the public and professional career of Richard M. Nixon, Esq.

title: Phog Allen, Basketball Coach Of Kansas Jayhawks, Diei at 88
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 16 (AP)Dr. Forrest C, (Phog) Allen, who coached basketball at the University of Kansas for nearly four decades and fought to add that sport to the Olympic Games slate, died today. He was 88 years old and lived here.

title: Six Suspended in RaceFix Study
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP)Investigation of a racefixing scheme at Pocono Downs resulted today in the suspension of five jockeys and a trainer indefinitely from all state racing activities.

title: Advertising: Cable TV Bulletins
description: Way out West on Oct. 7 a new cable television network will be going into operation with programing aimed at the farmer and his wife.

title: Franklin Details Plan for Independence
description: The Franklin National Bank disclosed in some detail yesterday its planfirst reported late in Augustto remain an independent bank scaled down in size and limited largely to Long Island.

title: President Publicly Backs Clandestine C.I.A. Activity
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford tonight publicly declared his support for the clandestine use of the Central Intelligence Agency to help implement foreign policy and protect national security, but he denied that the C.I.A. had been involved in the Chilean coup d'etat last year.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES DROP THE LIMIT
description: Grain and soybean traders in the Middle West looked at the clear weather yesterday, read forecasts of balmy days ahead and sold futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Womanelected Chairman Of G.O.P. National Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.16The Republican National Committee elected its first woman chairman, praised former President Richard M. Nixon and applauded his sucessor's appeal for an inflationproof Congress today.

title: , In South, Squirrel Hunts Mark the Arrival of Fall
description: HOGEYE, Ark., Sept 16Even today, a Monday when men and boys are supposed to be back at their sober pursuits, the unmistakable boom of a shotgun can be heard once or twice an hour from the vicinity of Carlskin Spring, up on Weber Mountain.

title: Jersey Reopens Its Search for Fraud In Financing of 1969 Cahill Campaign
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16State Attorney General William F Hyland said today that his office had reopened an investigation into alleged criminal fraud involving the financing of former Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 Republican gubernatorial campaign.

title: 2 Freed as Judge Scores U.S. Wounded Knee Case
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 16A Federal judge tonguelashed the prosecution, the Justice Department and particularly the Federal Bureau of investigation today and then dismissed the charges against the two men who led last year's Indian takeover of the community of Wounded Knee, S.D.

title: 3 Companies Seek Thermal Power Co.
description: A threeway contest for control of the Thermal Power Company of San Francisco emerged yesterday with a tender offer of the Union Oil Company of $16 a share for 840,000 shares, or 51 per cent, of Thermal Power's common stock. On Sept. 4, AlAquitane Exploration, a subsidiary of the Aquitane Company of Canada, Ltd., an oil and gas exploration company, announced a tender offer of $13 for all the common shares of Thermal Power. The AlAquitane offer expired yesterday.

description: Recently Published Books

title: Levitt Says Hospital Unit
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation was continuing to lose millions of dollars by failing to administer its contracts with affiliated voluntary, or private hospitals properly.

title: NEW YORK GETS LOTTERYGOAHEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Justice Department today gave the New York State Lottery a clean bill of health, and exempted the lottery from a planned Federal crackdown.
