description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Britain to Help the Ailing Ferranti Electronics Group
description: LONDON, Sept. 16The British Government has agreed to shore up the shaky financial position of one of the country's biggest electronics companies.

title: Muskie Speaks on Pardon
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 16 (AP)  Senator Edmund S. Milskie, Democrat of Maine, predicted today that President Ford's pardon of Richard M. Nixon ould have a weighty influence on the November elections.

title: 3 IN COVERUP CASE APPEAL SIRICA MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)Three defendants in the Watergate coverup case appealed today United States District Judge John J. Sirica's denial of their request for a further delay in their trial, citing publicity about the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Foreman's Eye Is Cut While Sparring, Delaying Title Bout a Week to 30 Days
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept, 16 (AP)George Foreman suffered a freakish cut over his right eye during a sparring session this afternoon, forcing the Government to postpone late tonight the heavyweight championship fight against Muhammad All scheduled for Sept. 25 here.

title: Mother in Pittsburgh Area Gives Birth to Quadruplets
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 (AP)A mother who used a fertility drug'gave birth today to quadrupletsthree boys and a girl at Magee Womens Hospital here.

title: Grand Jury to Get Report On Police Killing of Boy
description: The fatal shooting of a 14yearold Brownsville boy by police officer who had been called to check out a reported burglary in the Brooklyn neighborhood late Sunday evening was under investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday.

title: Schools in Charleston to Reopen Despite a Growing Mine Protest
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 16With sheriff's deputies assuring protection against violence in a protest over textbooks, public school authorities announced today that classes would resume here tomorrow after a twoday suspension.

title: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS ECOLOGICAL COSTS
description: DALLAS, Sept. 16Recent suggestions that the cost of environmental reforms might be contributing significantly to inflation were emphatically contradicted without dissent here today at a Federal conference on resources, the environment and inflation.

title: 2 JUDGES KILLED BY I.R.A. GUNMEN
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 16Two judges were shot dead in their homes here this morning, and the extremist Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army announced later that both had been warned frequently that they were part of the British war machine.

title: 2 Freed as Judge Scores U.S. Wounded Knee Case
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 16A Federal judge tonguelashed the prosecution, the Justice Department and particularly the Federal Bureau of Investigation today and then dismissed the charges against the two men who led last year's Indian takeover of the community of Wounded Knee, S.D.

title: Officials in Mercer Indicted on Charges Of Taking Payoffs
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16A Federal grand jury indicted two present Mercer County officials and a former one today on charges of extorting $31,346 from contractors since 1968.

title: The Price of Delay
description: After all the challenges to the Clean Air Act and all the attempts by the automobile industry to condemn that law's alleged excesses, the National Academy Sciences now finds its emissions standards amply justified on the grounds of public health.

title: EVANGELIST FACES GARDEN PROTESTS
description: Amid a growing controversy over the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and his wellpublicized appearance at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, some religious leaders and parents are organizing opposition to the 55yearold Korean evangelist.

title: Rivers Fast To Fill In As New Jet
description: For a man prepared to sit out the entire season to help enforce the players labor demands, Jamie Rivers appears ready to be an outstanding middle linebacker and help enforce the Jets defensive demands.

title: Zeferetti Is Apparent Nominee to Seek Carey Seat
description: Leo C. Zeferetti, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, appears to have won the Democratic nomination to Representative Hugh L. Carey's Brooklyn Congressional seat by a margin of between 49 and 165 votes.

title: In South, Squirrel Hunts Mark the Arrival of Fall
description: HOGEYE, Ark., Sept 16Even today, a Monday when men and boys are supposed to be back at their sober pursuits, the unmistakable boom of a shotgun can be heard once or twice an hour from the vicinity of Carlskin Spring, up on Weber Mountain.

title: Senator Criticizes Job Safety Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Senator Peter H. Dominick is leader of a group of Congressmen and businessmen in a fight to weaken the Federal agency charged with reducing jobrelated deaths and injuries. As part of his effort, the Coloredo Republican has charged that the agency threatened the livelihood of 400 of his constituents by telling a Colorado ski boot company that it would have to close immediately.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: Nat'l Football League

title: Alpine Lass, $41.80, Wins Matron Stakes at Belmont
description: Angel Cordero bumped his left ankle coming out of the gate on Ogden Mills Phipps's Alpine Lass in the $92,290 Matron Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The incident only seemed to spur the volatile Puerto Rican rider, for he proceeded to guide the daughter of Bold Ruler to a three  quarterlength success in the sevenfurlong stakes for 2yearold fillies.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 16 (AP)  The world lightheavyweight champion, Bob Foster, retired today after 14 title defenses, saying he didn't want to battle the world sanctioning bodies. I still think I can lick any a lightheavyweight in the world, but it's too much of a mental thing to fight the World Boxing Association and the World Boxing Council, too, said Foster, who is 34 years old.

title: Spokesmen for Draft Evaders and Veterans Groups Denounce Ford's Amnesty Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Members of Congress were generally pleased with President Ford's announcement today offering a conditional amnesty for draft evaders and military deserters, but, away from Capitol Hill, there were many vocal critics of the plan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the. Editor:. Now that Arthur Burns, Andrew Brimmer and the Ford Administration all accept the need for some kind of public service employment program, we feel that it is time for those of us who have long advocated this position in the past to sound a note of caution. The question we now face is not one of whether a public service employment program will be adopted but rather what kind it will be.

title: Britain Pledges Refund To Victimized Tourists
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)A British Cabinet minister said tonight that tourists who had lost the equivalent of $19million when the Court Line travel group went bankrupt are to have their money refunded in full.

title: J. WILLIAM H. MENCKE
description: J. William H. Mencke, who retired 12 years ago as manager of operations of the Getty Oil Company here, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summits N. J. He was 78 years. old.

title: INDICTMENTS CITE MERCER OFFICIALS
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16A Federal grand jury indicted two present Mercer County officials and a former one today on charges of extorting $31,346 from contractors since 1968. Jonathan L. Goldstein, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said the grand jury found that if you did not kick back a certain percentage of your county contracts to these men, you didn't get work.

title: U.N. Names French Envoy Economic Under Secretary
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16 Gabriel Van Laethem, a French diplomat and expert in industrial development, has been appointed Under Secretary General For Economic and Social Affairs. The 56yearold administrator succeeds Philippe de Seynes, who is retiring. Mr. Van Laethem was France's Ambassador to Australia and for four years earlier headed the Office of Industrial Cooperation in Algeria.

title: Board to Restudy Apartment Rent Rise
description: The head of the city's Rent Guidelines Board said yesterday that the board would meet soon to consider whether rentrise limits it recently announced for 400,000 apartments were too high.

title: DeLury's Son Named Among Three Judges Appointed by Beame
description: Mayor Beame appointed three persons as Criminal Court judges yesterday, including John J. DeLury, son of the president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association.

title: Breetings
description: COHENHenry I. family, 923 Fifth Avenue, New York City, Extend to All Our Relatives & Friends The Best of Health & Happiness for the New Year.

title: CYANAMID TO PLEAD. NOT GUILTY IN CASE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16 (AP)The Associated Press erroneously reported on Friday that eight major chemical companies planned to plead no defense to a charge they fixed the price of dyes in 1971.

title: 4 Die in Argentina In Wave of Bombing And Terrorist Acts
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16 (UPI)Four persons were killed in wave of bombings and other terrorist acts today, the 19th anniversary of the coup that overthrew President Juan Domingo Perlin in 1955.

title: NEW COMMITMENT FOR ISRAEL URGED
description: Rabbis appealed to Jews last night to intensify their moral and financial support for Israel and called on the free world to Safeguard Israel's territorial and political position.

title: I.F.C. INVESTMENTS SET RECORD IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The International Finance eorporation, the World Bank subsidiary that invests in productive enterprises in less developed countries, reported today a record total of $203.4million of investments in the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: EARITEDREENTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford offered conditional amnesty today to thousands of Vietnam era draft evaders and military deserters who agree to work for up to two years in public service jobs.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1974
description: President Ford, at a televised news conference at the White House last night, declared his support for the clandestine use of the Central Intelligence Agency to help carry out foreign policy and protect national security. He made the statement in response to questions about the alleged involvement of the C.I.A. in the overthrow of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile last year. He denied C.I.A. involvement in the Chilean coup d'etat. [1:12.] In another development related to Chile, it was learned that the staff of a Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee has recommended that contempt of Congress charges be placed against Richard Helms, the former C. I. A. director, and three retired Nixon Administration officials, including Edward M. Korry, Ambassador to Chile from 1967 to 1971, because of allegedly misleading Senate testimony on Chile. [10:4.8]

title: Cornell Elects Captains
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 16 (AP)  Dan Malone, a fullback from Detroit, and Rich Johnson, a defensive end from Northport, were elected co  captains of Cornell University's football team yesterday. Malone was the nation's 11th leading rusher as a sophomore in 1971.

title: 4 Astro Errors Costly
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP)The Dodgers capitalized on four Houston errors for seven runs tonight and Andy Messersmith, with relief from Mike Marshall, won his 18th game as Los Angeles beat the Astros, 72, and stayed 2 games ahead of Cincinnati in National League West.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fishing the Snake River
description: MOOSE, Wyo.  To one who has done most of his trout fishing on Eastern streams, Wyoming's Snake River is awesome.

title: DeLury's Son Named Among T hree Judges Appointed by Beame
description: Mayor Beame appointed three persons as Criminal Court judges yesterday, including John J. DeLury, son of the president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association.

title: S. L. Werkman Weds Phyllis Hart
description: Phyllis Cox Hart, daughter of Archibald Cox, former special Watergate prosecutor, and Mrs. Cox of Wayland, Mass., was married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass., to Dr. Sidney Lee Werkman, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Colorado School of Medicine.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Indian Ocean 11 A.M.

title: Where to Call or Write For Data on Clemency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 16The White House announced today that telephone inquiries about terms of the new clemency program for draft evaders or military deserters should be directed to the following:

title: Clean Water Bill Rises
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (AP)1 The State Environmental Protection Department estimated today that it would cost $12.2billion to pay for a thorough program of water pollution control through 1990, The estimate was revised sharply upward from last year when the department said it would cost $3.5billion to finance the state's needs.

title: Grand Jury to Get Report On Police Killing of Boy
description: The fatal shooting of a 14yearold Brownsville boy by a police officer who had been called to check out a reported burglary in the Brooklyn neighborhood late Sunday evening was under investigation by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday.

title: London Thrills to Trilogy Of Norman Conquests
description: LONDONRichard Wagner demands four nights of our lives with his operatic epic, Der Ring des Nibelungen, and many people regard it as time well invested. But three nights for a farce? That is precisely the demand that the English playwright Alan Ayckbourn asks of London audiences with his trilogy, The Norman Conquests. Here are three plays in repertoryin fact, even worse, they are three aspects of the very same play in repertory. And yet Mr. Ayckbcurn has gotten himself one of the hottest three tickets.in town. Audiences come in giggling and leave in convulsions. I have rarely spent Ulna with such physical audience chortling, nudging one another, having the time of their lives. Bayreuth should have it good.

title: U.S. Policy on Oceans: A Choice
description: WASHINGTONPolicy on oceans has until recent years been an obscure backwater of foreign policy. But in the last decade explosive growth in the use of oceans has forced a change.

title: Jersey Reopens Inquiry Into 69 Cahill Campaign
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16State Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that his office had reopened inyestiption into alleged criminal fraud involving the financing or former GOV. wilLiam T. Cahill's 1969 Republican gubernatorial campaign.

title: Chess: World Student Event Offers Preview of Olympiad Teams
description: The world students team championship, besides giving future champions the excellent opportunity for competition, provides a fair index of what the strength of the Olympiad teams will be in about five years. Boris Spassky and William Lombardy first came to prominence in student competition, although Bobby Fischer developed so rapidly at such an early age that he held himself aloof from it.

title: Two Memphis Policemen Are Suspended in Shooting
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 16 (UPI)Police officials were investigating today the death of a man stopped for a traffic violation who allegedly drew a gun on two policemen and was shot 10 times by the officers. Officials said the suspect did not fire a shot.

title: Joseph Durso
description: They are a strange bunch, these New York Yankees. They were 50to1 shots when the baseball season began. They go to work every day in somebody else's park. They play for a manager who was dismissed at the height of pennant race in Pittsburgh last September, and who was second choice in New York after Ralph Houk left and Dick Williams escaped. And half of them languished someplace else last season without distinction. Their best pitcher, Mel Stottlemyre, has had a sore arm for four months and hasn't pitched in two. Their best hitters, Bobby Murcer and Thurman Munson, both are having offyears. Their best bet for the future, Ron Blomberg presumably can't hit lefthanders. Their infield lacked a doubleplay combination. Their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, got into trouble with the Government over political contributions. And the only pennant that flaps over the stadium belongs to the Mets.

title: Iran Gets Kick Out of Soccer and Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16The Persian capital today celebrated the 33d anniversary of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's accession to the throne and the fresh, satisfying victories of Iran over her neighbors in the Asian Games sports competition.

title: LOANS TO REPLACE A TOWN'S WAGES
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 16A Long Island bank is expected to provide up to $1million in personal, interestfreel loans to this city's municipal; employes because the city isl $2million in the red, and unable to meet its payroll.

title: George Schwartz, Writer Who Taught Biology, Dies
description: George Schwartz, a writer and biology teacher, died Sunday at Princeton (N.J.) University Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Kingston, N.J.

title: Former Tenants Drop In for Lunch With the Beames
description: John and Mary Lindsay stopped off at their former home for lunch yesterday.

title: National Football League Standings
description: National Football League Standings

title: 4 Iraqis Killed at Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Four Iraqi soldiers were killed and four wounded in a series of border clashes with Iranian forces last night, and today the Iraq press agency reported tonight.

title: Gumball Maker Seeks To Keep Price at Penny
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 16 (AP)Despite skyrocketing material costs, one major producer of penny gum is determined to keep the price at one penny each.

title: HAIG'S COMMAND: BIG AND COMPLEX
description: As Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. will assume responsibilities that are more, extensive geographically and more complex militarily than those of any national commanders in the, North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Fires Delays Perinsy Trains
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (UPI)A fouralarm fire at a janitorial supply company in north Philadelphia Iast night resulted in twohour delays on the Penn Central Railroad's Anitrak and local lines.

title: Ronson Reports Court Stay
description: The Ronson Corporation, maker of cigarette lighters and jother products, announced yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York had granted a stay of a United States District Court order that permitted Liquifin, S.P.A., of Italy to name two directors to the Ronson Board. Liquifin has a 36 per cent stock ownership in Ronson, which it obtained through a tender offer earlier this year.

title: People and Business
description: Japan's Premier, Kakuel Tanaka, arrived in Brazil yesterday and set out to reassure Brazilians that Japan, despite its present economic problems, would continue its major investment plans in Brazil. Brazilian officials and businessmen are said to be concerned over the decline in bank loans from Japan and a slowdown in Japanese investments in their country.

title: 2 Colleges to Merge
description: WORCHESTER, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)Becker Junior College in Leicester have agreed to merge by next July. According to their presidents, Lloyd Van Bushkirk of Becker and Henry C. Borger of Leicester, it will be several years before any major changes take place. Becker has 600 students, Leicester, 230. Both are twoyear, coeducational institutions.

title: Haig Pleaon Nixon Health Linked to Ford's Reversal
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 16The White House chief of staff, Gen, Alexander M. Haig Jr., after being advised of the alarming state of Richard M. Nixon's health, was reliably reported today to have persuaded President Ford to reverse his publicly stated position and grant an immediate pardon to the former President.

title: Underground Art in Soviet Is Eclectic
description: An, emigre Russian writer who is working on a book about the underground art movement in the Soviet Union yesterday described the group whose outdoor exhibition was disrupted in Moscow as an eclectic circle unified by an unwillingness to conform to offi

title: French Seamen on Strike In Support of Liner Crew
description: LE HAVRE, France, Sept. 16 (Reuters)French seamen today began a 48 hour strike in support of the rebel crew of the liner France, who have been occupying the ship for the last five days in protest against Government plans to take her out of service.

title: Sperry Seeks Tokyo Listing
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday it had filed an application for the listing of its common stock on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: CORPORATE FUNDS IN POLITICS GROW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16A growing number of New York banks and brokerage houses solicit their employes to contribute to voluntary political funds to help local candidates, according to reports filed here with the House and Senate.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Serenade in Eflat, Mozart; Symphony, Die Rettung der Andromeda, Durch perseus, Dittersdorii.

title: Season's Sixth Storm
description: MIAMI, Sept. 16 (UPI)  A strong depression off the western tip of Jamaica grew into the season's sixth tropical storm today. DeSignated Fife, the storm was heading toward Grand Cayman Island with 50 mileanhour winds, forecasters said.

title: Major League Baseball September 17, 1974
description: Montreal 3, New York 2 (1st twi,) New York 3, Montreal 2 (2d). Cincinnati 9, San Diego 2 (n.), Los Angeles 7, Houston 2 (n.). San Francisco 4, Atlanta 2. Other teams not scheduled.

title: HEARING CHARTED ON ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The House Judiciary Committee, in its confirmation hearings on Nelson A. Rockefeller, is believed likely to examine not only the dollarsandcents figures of his and his family's fortunes but also the implications of this economic and political power on his eligibility for the VicePresidency.

title: Murder Toll in Doubt
description: For years, lawenforcement officials have argued that murder statistics are among the most reliable crime figures availableas certain and as final as the homicides themselves.

title: B.U.D. CITES STUDY ON ILLEGAL DEALINGS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Department of Housing and Urban Development has evidence that some financial institutions are cheating the Federal Government and forcing lowincome families out of their homes.

title: Cincinnati Wins by 9.2
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 16 (AP)Cesar Geronimo, Dave Concepcion and Johnny Bench drove in two runs apiece tonight and the Cincinnati Reds walloped the San Diego Padres, 92.

title: Contract Awards
description: Societe Framatome, the French licensee of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, will take part in the construction of two nuclear power plants in Belgium, estimated to cost well over $100million.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey has become the first state to adopt its own official symbol for the 1976 Bicentennial celebration. The design won out over four other finalist entries submitted to readers of the state's newspapers in a special referendum sponsored by the New Jersey Bicentennial Commission.

title: Text of Statement and Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following are the texts of a statement and a proclamation issued today by President Ford to initiate a program of reconciliation for Vietnamera draft evaders and military deserters:

title: $2Million School Deficit In Deer Park Investigated
description: DEER PARK, L. I., Sept. 16The State Department of Education began an investigation today of a $2.1million deficit incurred by the school district here and of why the matter was concealed from community residents for nearly three years.

title: College, School Results
description: SOCCER

title: Courageous Wins Third Race by 5:27 And Can Clinch America's Cup Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 16It was Courageous in another rout today of Southern Cross, the challenger for the America's Cup, on an afternoon that left no excuses. The United States defender won the third race of the fourofseven series by the massive margin of 5 minutes 27 seconds, and needs only a victory tomorrow to wrap up the Cup, 4 races to 0.

title: Unhealthy Trifling
description: Whatever the true state of former President Nixon's health, it is odd to find his own doctor conveying alarming details to the public press before they have even been reported to the patient's wife. This is precisely what the former, White House physician, Maj. Gen. Walter Tkach, admits to when he freely provided Newsweek with medical information that he says was withheld from Mrs. Nixon, for fear of frightening her.

title: Publishers Elect President
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 16 (UPI)M. W. Armistead 3d, president of Landmark Commucations, Inc., Norfolk, Va., was installed today as president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association durting its convention here.

title: INDIA SAID TO PLAN A NUCLEAR PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16India is prepared to give assurances that no nuclear fuel obtained from the United States will be used for conducting atomic explosions, a spokesman for the Atomic Energy Commission said today.

title: City to Restudy Rent Rise On 400,000 Apartments
description: The head of the city's Rent Guidelines Board said yesterday that the board would, meet soon to consider whether rentrise limits it recently announced for 400,000 apartments were too high.

title: Ford Offer Greeted Coolly By U. S. Exiles in Canada
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 16President Ford's offer of conditional amnesty was ropch ed coolly today by American draft evaders and deserters in Canada, the country that attracted the largest number of them over the years.

title: Hard Times Up High
description: Poverty is bursting out all over. Italy is bankrupt and Britain is shopping for loans among sandy emirs whom she once dismissed with a show of the Union Jack and a taste of the grape.

title: F. T. C. QUESTIONS LINGUISTIC POLICY
description: ship most of the city's largest stores, last year said it was in large part in favor of the city's proposal but raised several objections to specific parts of it. According to a spokesman for the retailer's association, one objection by its members was that they would be required to give Spanishlanguage disclosures to nearly all of their customers in order to protect themselves.

title: SAFETY UNIT REJECTS SAFE CIGARETTE IDEA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) The National Safety Council, citing what it calls sensitive conditions in the tobacco industry, has refused to support the development of a selfextinguishing cigarette designed to prevent accidental fires.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA 8 P.M.)

title: WILSON AD DRAWS WOMEN'S PROTEST
description: The National Organization for Women has sharply rebuffed Governor Wilson's campaign for enlisting a rape victim to take part in a TV commercial extolling the Governor's record on feminist legislation.

title: Ford Offer Greeted Coolly By U.S. Exiles in Canada
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 16president Ford's offer of conditional amnesty was received cooly today by American draft eva ders and deserters in Canada, the country that attracted the largest number of them over the years.

title: MENTAL PATIENT KILLED IN PLUNGE
description: A 28yearold mental patient who had been placed in isolation after setting fire in his hospital room set a second fire and then fell to his death from fifthstory window at Bronx State Hospital yesterday.

title: DETAILS PROVIDED. ON KAY'S RELEASE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos Tuesday, Sept. 17 (AP)The last, known American prisoner of the Indochina war will be released tomorrow by his Pathet Lao captors in territory the proCommunisennovement controls, informed sources here said today.

title: Dance Season Promises to Be Unusual
description: It will be another yearround dance season in 197475 and an unusual one too. It is a year that promises the return of Suzanne Farrell to the New York City Ballet, the transformation of Rudolf Nureyev, the Sleeping Beautys prince incarnate, into Rudolf Nureyev, the Martha Graham, and Paul Taylor dancer, and the debut of Mikhail Baryshnikov in a contemporary ballet by Roland Petit.

title: Barr, Bonds Pace Giant 42 Victory.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (UPI)Jim Barr's sevenhit pitching and home runs by. Bobby Bonds and Gary. Thomasson led the San Francisco Giants to, a 42 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

title: General Motors Expanding
description: DETROIT, Sept 16 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation announced today the establishment of the Delco Airconditioning division to assume the responsibility for the automotive airconditioning business now operated by the Frigidaire division. After Jan. 1, 1975, the Frigidaire division will be devoted exclusively to the manufacture and marketing of major household appliances, together with commercial laundry products and icemakers.

title: 10 Seized and Charged In Series of Robberies
description: Ten members of a gang known as the Bronx robbery squad have been arrested by detectives of the Police Department's Bronx robbery squad and charged with a series of armed robberies in the Bronx, District Attorney Mario Merola said yesterday.

title: GOODMAN FAVORS TIGHT JUVENILE LAW
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, said yesterday that greater control must be exercised over juvenile offenders in view of the weekend murdr of a taxi driver by two teenagers who had Kevious police records.

title: EDWARD QUINN FIELD
description: Edward Quinn Field, a former vice president of the Insurance Company of North America, died Saturday in Hartford, where he was vistiting relatives, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and Riled at 405 Edgewood Avenue, Westfield, N. J.

title: Steps for Reconciliation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following are the procedures to be followed by convicted and unconvicted draft evaders and military absentees under the reconciliation program proclaimed today by President Ford:

title: Butz Lost for Season
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (UPI)Dave Butz, a secondyear defensive tackle for the St. Louis Cardinals, underwent knee surgery today and will be sidelined for the remainder of the season. Butz, a 6foot7inch, 280pounder, injured his left knee against Philadelphia yesterday. He was the club's No. 1 draft pick in 1973.

title: Smoky FourAlarm Fire Damages a Brooklyn Pier
description: A smoky fouralarm fire caused extensive damage to an unoccupied Brooklyn pier and an adjoining warehouse yesterday morning.

title: Over $1Billion Injected, Presumably From Oil Producers
description: Shortterm interest rates dropped sharply yesterday as the Federal Reserve injected more than $1billion into the money marketpresumably using funds from oilproducing countries. The Federal Reserve also purchased Treasury bills for its own account, another action that tends to ease money and push interest rates downward.

title: Fire Halts L.I.R.R. Train
description: A Port Washingtonbound Long Island Rail Road train was knocked out of service yesterday morning by a small electrical fire under one of its cars. The railroad said the blaze forced the 821 from Penn Station to halt at the Elmhurst Station in Queens. The passengers boarded the following I train, the 8:51.

title: PROFITS INCREASE AT GREAT WESTERN
description: The profits of the Great Western United Corporation soared in the first quarter from $1.2million to $14.3million on the strength of record prices of refined sugar, the company said yesterday.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Man Drowns in the Colorado
description: BLYTE, Calif., Sept. 16 (UPI)Bobby Selva of New York City drowned in the Colorado River over the weekend when he decided to take a swim to cool off in the 100degree California desert heat.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Controller, Arthur Levitt, said that New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation was continuing to lose millions of dollars by failing to administer properly its contracts with affiliated voluntary hospitals.

title: Courageous Wins 3d; Title Bout Postponed
description: Courageous, the United States defender, defeated Southern Cross of Australia for the third straight race yesterday off Newport, R.I., and can clinch the imerica's Cup today.

title: Close Money Tie and Loan Urged on E.E.C. by Paris
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 16  In fresh moves to reanimate the European Economic Community, France proposed today that the ninenation block close monetary ranks by drawing its currencies into a tighter network of concerted floating and by borrowing, under joint guaranties, $2.5billion directly from oilproducing countries.

description: ACROSS

title: FOODAID INCREASE INDICATED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford said tonight at his news conference that he expected a very major decision in the next few days that would lead to an increase in the amount of food aid made available to foreign countries. He declined to go into details.

title: Evaders Allowed to Choose Their Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Officials in charge of administering President Ford's amnesty program said today that draft evaders and military deserters would be permitted to select the form of alternative service they wished to perform and to find their own jobs, subject to approval by their state Selective Service directors.

title: MRS. FREDERICK LUKS
description: Virginia Wilson Luks, the wife of Frederick Luks, outdoor editor of WestchesterRockland Newspapers, Inc., died yesterday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived at 40 East Birch Street, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Box Scores
description: Box Scores

title: Senate Staff Report. on Chile Accuses Helms and 3 of Contempt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The staff of a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee has recommended that contempt of Congress charges be placed against Richard Helms, former director of Central Intelligence, and three retired Nixon Administration officials because of their allegedly misleading Senate testimony on Chile last year, highly reliable Congressional suorces said today.

title: Major League Leaders.
description: BATTING NATIONAL LEAGUE HOME RUNS RUNS BATTED IN PITCHING

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Summit. High School, nestled in the rolling hills of New Jersey's Watchung Mountains, sends athletes to major colleges and then on to professional leagues with surprising consistency.

title: Cleveland Buys a Rare Painting
description: An extremely rare and important painting by the 16thcentury German artist Matthias Grilnewald has been purchased by the Cleveland Museum of Art. The painting, long believed lost at sea in a shipwreck, depicts the Christian martyr St. Catherine of Alexandria, and is the first direct evidenceapartfrom drawings of the. existence of a multipanel altar piece created by GrUnewald for the cathedral at Mainz, Germany.

title: Boston Youths Blocked in Bus Protest
description: BOSTON, Sept, 16Chanting bands of white youths roamed the streets of South. Boston today, protesting courtordered integration of the area's schools.

title: Million Is Estimate Now For Nixon's Transition
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16(AP)The Government estimated today that it would cost more than $1million instead of $850,000 to complete former President Richard M. Nixon's transition to private life in six months rather than eleven.

title: New G.O.P. Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Mary Louise Smith says she is a moderateconservative. But she supports the equal rights amendment, was one of the coconveners of Iowa's first women's political caucus, has taken a liberal stand on abortion and is a member of Planned Parenthood.

title: Yale, Penn Are Choices Among Ivies
description: Harvard's coach, Joe Restic, said yesterday, If I had to rate the Ivy League season, I'd say Yale, Penn, Dartmouth and then put us somewhere in the pack. Princeton will be a spoiler. Speaking at the football writers luncheon at the New York University Club, Restic said that Milt Holt, a lefthander from Hawau; has won the Crimson starting quarterback spot to replace Jim Stoeckel, one of Harvard's better qUarterbacks, who has graduated. Bill Campbell, Columbia's new coach, has given his starting quarterback job to Jose Rios as a result of a scrimmage last Saturday. Rios dropped off the team a year ago but returned to win back his position Wagner beat Columbia, 127, in the scrimmageCampbell seemed to lean toward Penn as an Ivy title choice because they are so strong at the skilled positions with a fine querterback and a good runner. These are Marty Vaughn at quarterback and Adolph Bellizeare at tailback. Brown opens its season Saturday, and the other seven, league teams begin Sept. 28.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Yields declined sharply on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: GUIDELINES SET BY BANKERS UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 16 The Federal Advisory Council, a group of leading private bankers that advises the Federal Reserve Board, issued today a set of guidelines to govern bank lending at a time of tight money such as the present.

title: Crops and Credibility
description: Unless President Ford's guarded reference last night to the debate now going on in the Administration on the level of food aid to be made available to developing countries indicates a reversal of Agriculture Secretary Earl Butz grim intimations, Mr. Ford may be headed for the first diplomatic disaster of his Administration.

title: Trial Opens Today on Charges By S.E.C. Against Coast Editor
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15The trial of a rare legal action by the Securities and Exchange Commission against a financial journalist opens on Tuesday in the Federal District Court here.

title: Bills Rally Wins, 2120; O.J. Injured
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 16 (AP)Joe Ferguson's 13yard pass to Ahmad Rashad with 26 seconds to play tonight rallied Buffalo to a 2120 victory over the Oakland Raiders in a National Football League opener.

title: Turnover Is the Heaviest in Three MonthsDow Rises 12.59
description: A late technical recovery yesterday ended the stock market's fivesession losing streak and stocks finished slightly higher in the heaviest turnover in more than three months.

title: 2 of 10 West Side Murder Victims Being Checked by Police Are Found to be Alive
description: Two elderly women being checked as possible victims of a suspect in several West Side murders have turned up alive, Detective Lieut. James F. Gallagher, commanding the Fourth Homicide Squad, said yester day.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Greeks and Milts on Cyprus Exchange Prisoners
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 16The Greek and Turkish communities of Cyprus took the first step today toward settling severe problems of human misery resulting from the summer's strife.

title: Yankees Bring Pennant Chase Home
description: How many bats you need? Bill Kane, the Yankees traveling secretary, asked Elliott. Maddox yesterday.

title: Mets' Records
description: Mets' Records

title: AUssie Cup Fans Watch Quietly, Drink Stoically
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept., 16Expectation turned to resignation here today for hundreds of Australians who came half way around the world in the hope of seeing Southern Cross win the America's Cup. It now appears they won't see their Fhallenger win anything.

title: Franchise Is Moved
description: The Carolina team in the American Basketball Association was sold to a group of New York area businessmen and moved to St. Louis in July.

title: Westchester's Legislators Approve Correction Head,
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP)  The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved by a 16to1 vote today the appointnient of Albert D. Gray Jr. as the county's Correction Commissioner.

title: FIRESTONE BELT TIRE HELD UNACCEPTABLE
description: Consumers Union said yesterday that it had rated the Firestone 500 Steel Belt tire not acceptable because the treads of seven of nine samples had separated in highspeed durability tests.

title: Goodyear Introducing Radial Tire With Keolar
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company  the world's largest tire manufacturerintroduced a new topoftheline belted tire using Kevlarthe new fiber produced by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.instead of steel. Kevlar is reported to have tested as stronger than steel.

title: Satellite Film Backs View on Early Flood
description: A half century ago J. Harlen Bretz, a University of Chicago geologist, suggested that the barren, heavily scarred region of eastern Washington had been made that way by a flood of phenomenal dimensions.

title: KARPOV, KORCHNOI DRAW IN CHESS GAME
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (AP)Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi agreed to a draw here tonight in the first game of their chess match to decide the challengeror the successorto Bobby Fischer, the world champion.

title: No Dtente for Artists
description: The brutal destruction of a nonconformist art show in a Moscow suburbwith bulldozers, waterspraying trucks and gangs of young Communist vigilantesis a dismaying commentary on the enduring insecurity of the Soviet leadership and the mindless conformity it still tries to impose even on the arts fiftysix years after the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: No Skyscraper Landmark
description: New York is not all bad news. Even as the Franklin Savings Bank prepares to demolish its fine stone palazzo in an act of real estate vandalism that diminishes an already tarnished neighborhood, the McGrawHill Building farther along West 42d Street will be saved.

title: JOB RULES PROPOSED FOR WELFARE CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The Ford Administration proposed today that some poor people be required to seek work as a condition of receiving welfare payments.

title: State Lottery Chief to See Justice Aide on Legality
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)Charles C. Carella, executive Director of the New Jersey Lottery, will go to Washington this week to discuss legal questions Federal officials have raised about state lotteries.

title: MAN ADMITS KILLING, THEN IS MURDERED
description: A 22yearold Bronx man who went berserk after reportedly confessing to a Lower East Side murder was killed last evening in a former girlfriend's apartment during a knife fight with her brother, the police said.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Yesterday was the kind of clear, brisk, sunshiny day that would have brought women out in suits a dozen years ago. Suits are hardly the rage these days, which means women are left to cope the best they can with what to wear during that period when summer wanes and fall hasn't quite set in.

title: Dairy Coop Funds Campaigns In South, Finance Data Indicate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)One of the nation's three biggest dairy cooperatives has been indirectly funneling thousands of dollars into 1974 Congressional and state campaigns in six Southern states, campaign fintince reports show.

title: Mets, Expos Trade 32 Decisions
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 16 With the temperature in the low 50's, the Montreal Expos gave the New. York Mets a cold welcome tonight by topping them, 32, in the opener of a doubleheader.

title: Hague Terrorists Given Food as Negotiations Lag
description: THE HAGUE, Tuesday, Sept. 17Three Japanese extremists who have been in control of the French Embassy here since Friday demanded and received two packages of food yesterday as negotiations for the release of their nine remaining hostages appeared to bog down.

title: BY DEAL DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford said emphatically tonight that he had made no deal with former President Richard M. Nixon and insisted that the major reason for his decision to pardon him was to heal the nation.

title: President Publicly Backs Clandestine C.I.A. Activity
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford tonight publicly declared his support for the clandestine use of the Central Intelligence Agency to help implement foreign policy and protect national security, but he denied that the C.I.A. had been involved in the Chilean coup d'etat last year.

title: Grand Jury Will Hear Baer's Charge Of Assault by a MigrantCamp Boss
description: WOODBURY, Sept. 16At a preliminary hearing here today, Superior Court Judge Charles A. Rizzi found probable cause to believe that the overseer of a migrantlabor crew committed atrocious assault and battery on Assemblyman Byron M. Baer, Bergen County Democrat, and Alex Morisey, executive director of the Farm Workers Corporation of New Jersey.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK RENAISSANCE BAND, Trinity Church, 12:45.

title: A REENTRY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford offered conditional amnesty today to thousands of Vietnam era draft evaders and military deserters who agree to work for up to two years in public service jobs.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Springfield, Mass., Schools Integrate Without Incident
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)  Classrooms were reported full today as Springfield elementary schools began as integration program requiring the busing of both, white and black children.

title: MENTAL PATIENT KILLED IN PLUNGE
description: A 28yearold mental patient who had been placed in isolation after setting fire in his hospital room set a second fire and then fell to his death from a fifthstory window at Bronx State Hospital yesterday.

title: Sir John Brocklebank, 59, Dies; Led Cunard Co. From 195965
description: Sir John Montague Brocklebank, former board chairman of Cunard Steamship Company and who at one time ran a millionton shipping group with 80 ships, died last Friday at his home in Malta. He was 59 years old.

title: Williams Asks Law Making Dogfighting A Federal Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. announced today that he had introduced legislation to make the practice of dogfighting a Federal crime.

title: CanadaU.S.S.R. Hockey Starts Tonight
description: The series that Canadians are calling Super Summit II starts tonight at Quebec City with Team Canada, composed of World Hockey Association players, facing the Soviet Union. All eight games in the seriesfour in Canada, four in the U.S.S.R.will be televised here on onehour delayed tape over Channel 13. Tonight's game will be shown at 9 o'clock.

title: SAUDIS RAISING BUYBACK PRICE
description: Saudi Arabia, long the chief proponent of lower crudeoil prices among the petroleumexporting nations, is raising her pricearid may have already raised itat the very time that she has been advocating price reduction.

title: ETHIOPIANS STOP STUDENT PROTEST
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 16Ethiopian soldiers today blocked attempts by about a thousand university students to demonstrate for an immediate return to civilian rule and for a speedy court martial and conviction of the deposed Emperor, Haile Selassie.

title: Inspector General For Child Services Backed by Duryea
description: ALBANY, Sept. 16Too many children get lost in the system that is meant to help them,  Assembly Speaker Perry D. DUryea declared today, saying he would assign a high priority in the 1975 session of the State Legislature to a bill that would create an Inspector General for Children and Family Services.

title: West German Chief For Summit Meeting At European Parley
description: BONN, Sept. 16Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today that he expected the European security conference in Geneva to be completed about the end of this year, and that he would support an EastWest summit meeting there of the leaders of the 35 participating nations.

title: LAWYER IS GUILTY OF ATTEMPTED FIX
description: A Brooklyn lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday to attempting to interfere in a criminal case involving a major bookmaker who was awaiting sentence before State Supreme Court Jus. tice Burton B. Roberts in 1973.

title: Just a Little Coaxing And Mrs. de la Renta Became a Decorator
description: Give Francoise de la Renta an inch and she'll decorate. Give her a room and she'll create a mood. Mrs. de la Renta loves decorating, as long as no one knows it's been done.

title: LAWRENCE KELLY OPERA IMPRESARIO
description: Lawrence V. Kelly, an opera impresario, died yesterday of cancer in Kansas City, Mo. He was 46 years old.

title: Belmont Park Charts
description: Belmont Jockeys

title: Islanders Open Camp With Style
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Sept. 16  Little signs of their slow growth as an expansion team were evident today as the New York Islanders  starting year No. 3  opened their hockey training camp here for the 197475 season.

title: 5 Russians Are Sentenced in Moscow After ArtShow Fracas
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16A municipal court today imposed 15day prison terms and fines on four artists and a photographer friend on charges of petty hooliganism for resisting bands of vigilantes who broke up an outdoor nonconformist art show yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Foote Player of Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (UPI)Barry Foote, the rookie Montreal catcher who drove in gamewinning runs in three consecutive contests last week, was named today the National League's player of the week.

title: Jury Picked in Paterson For Satkin Murder Trial
description: PATERSON, Sept.16A jury of 12 regular and four alternate members was selected today in the murder and arson trial of Joseph Satkin, a Passaic County landlord who is charged with conspiring to burn down a building he owned in Passaic last year.

title: NIXON'S LAWYERS SAY HE IS TOO ILL TO GIVE TESTIMONY;
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17Attorneys for Richard M. Nixon have contended in Federal court here that the former President is too ill to provide testimony in a North Carolina civil suit growing out of his appearance at a rally in Charlotte in 1971.

title: William Heller, 85, Head Of Aeolian Piano Company
description: William G. Heller, board chairman of the Aeolian Corporation of 33 West 57th Street, piano manufacturer since 1823, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Modernist Stirrings Felt, but Islam Strongly Resists Change
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Fazlur Rahman, once director of the Islamic Research Institute in Karachi, wrote a book eight years ago arguing that the direvelation in the Koranwhich Moslem orthodoxy holds to be the words of 0,11ahshould be seen as related to the personality of the Prophet.

title: DRAFT EVADERS RELEASED FROM PRISON ON FURLOUGH PENDING AMNESTY REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Government ordered today the release of approximately 95 draft evaders from prison on 30day furloughs while the President's new Clemency Board reviews their cases under the conditional amnesty program. An estimated 600 convicted military deserters remained in confinement.

title: Briefs On The Arts
TERRORISTS FREE HOSTAGES,FLY OFF
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands Wednesiday Sept 18 The three Japanese terrorists who seized the French Embassy in The Hague last Friday left the embassy last night. freed all nine remaining hostages and took off from Amsterdam's airport in a French jetliner.

title: About New York
description: The problem with going away from New York is that you have to learn to like it again when you come back. The promise is greater in New York than it is anywhere else, but so are the miseries, and to return to the city after five weeks in Ireland is to come back to a dark planet.

title: Notes on People
description: Peter M. Flanigan, who served as Assistant to the President for International Economic Policy from 1969 until last June, was named yesterday by President Ford to be Ambassador to Spain. Mr. Flanigan, who is 41 years old, joined the Nixon Administration after a successful career as an investment banker. If lie is approved by the Senate, he will succeed Horacio Rivero in Madrid. Mr. Ford also named Edward S. Little, a veteran diplomat, to be envoy to the Republic of Chad, a post formerly held by,Edward M. Mulcahy, who recently became Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. Mr. Little must also be approved by the Senate.

title: Aleksandr Galunov, Bolshoi Dancer With a Difference
description: Maya Plisetskaya is the indisputable luminary among the Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet who opened last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. But in Aleksandr Godunov, the famed Soviet ballerina has a new young partner who has attracted his own share of attention.

title: Upstate Fireman Accused Of Paying 3 to Start a Fire
description: CORAM, N.Y., Sept. 17 (AP) An 18yearold volunteer fireman was accused. today of giving three youths $20 to set fire to a vacant house.

title: Conn. Licenses First Dog Track
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 17 (AP)Connecticut's first greyhound racing license was awarded today to a man who, according to Federal authorities, is under investigation in connection with clog racing in New Hampshire.

title: DRAFT EVADERS RELEASED FROM PRISON FURLOUGH PENDING AMNESTY REVIEW; 95 LEAVING JAIL;
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Government ordered today the release of approximately 95 draft evaders from prison on 30day furloughs while the President's new Clemency Board reviews their cases under the conditional amnesty pro gram. An estimated 600 convicted military deserters remained in confinement.

title: Mozambique Leaders Cautious On Rhodesia and South Africa
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 17A spokesman for the Mozambique Liberation Front, which will soon assume control of this Portuguese territory, today avoided a commitment to a policy of confrontation or economic sanctions against the neighboring white minority governments of South Africa and Rhodesia.

title: German Economy Stable but Full of Contradictions
description: BONN, Sept. 11The Germans,, who have less inflation (7 per cent),, more foreign exchange reserves ($27billion), and less unemployment (2.3 per cent) than any other major industrial power in the world, call this enviable state of affairs stability."

title: Bar Group, at Senate Hearing Opposes Meskill as a U.S. judge
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 17The confirmation of Gov. Tho., mas J. Meskill of Connecticut for a United States Court of Appeals judgeship ran into expected snags today when the American Bar Association testified at Senate hearings.

title: House Panel Seeks to Cut Over Half of Nixon Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A House subcommittee sought today to bar the use of Federal funds to lease a storage vault in California for Watergate tape recordings and other documents and voted to cut by more than half an overall budget request for former President Richard M. Nixon's transition to private citizen.

title: Fuel Saving of 20% Seen in 75 Autos
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that air pollution control devices installed on most 1975 automobiles would result in average fuel savings of 20 per cent over current levels.

title: Public Service to Cut 200 From Its Payroll
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company said yesterday that it was planning to lay off about 200 employes, beginning next month, in what was termed a part of the utility's effort to cope with the rising cost of supplying electricity and gas.

title: Japaniese May Not Visit
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17 (UPI)Foreign Minister Toshio Kimura of Jan said todaythat he might postpone his visit to the United States planned week because of problems at home.

title: NuclearArmed Nuclear Sub Is 4th Launched by France
description: CHERBOURG, France, Sept. 17 (Reuters)France launched her fourth nuclear submarine today as the navy started converting its nuclear submarine fleet to carry multiplewarhead missiles.

title: Fed Appears to Act To Curb Rate Drop
description: The Federal Reserve appeared yestarday to flash a signal that want interest rates to decline till further in the money market

title: TEXTBOOK CRISIS FLARES UP ANEW
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 17An orderly but angry crowd of more than 500 shouting parents, many of them coal miners who are on strike, reopened the bookbanning crisis here today by staging a demonstration to demand the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of what they called dirty and Godless public school textbooks.

title: Attendance Rises at Schools in South Boston as Police Line Streets
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17Police men lined the streets of South Boston this afternoon and, for the second consecutive day, buses carrying black students rolled in an out of the area without serious incident.

title: Ford Rules Out Subsidies For Beleaguered Pan Am
description: President Ford has decided against providing Federal subsidies to help Pan American World Airways meet a critical cash squeeze beginning next month, Government sources said yesterday.

title: Westchester Inquiry Involves Heritage Hills Zoning Change
description: WHITE PLAINS Sept 17District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County said today that he had opened an investigation into possible zoning irregularities in the county's largest housing condominium Heritage Hills in Somers.

title: High SchoolCollege Coordination Urged
description: Overlapping programs in high schools and colleges are wasting the time of many students as well as often boring them, the State Board of Regents has declared in a new policy statement.

title: Courageous's Vast Superiority Makes Yachting Series Boring
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 Hans Isbrandtsen did it all with his feet.

title: Flexible Mortgages
description: The longterm, fixedrate mortgage, which has proved such a boon to home owners over the decades, may be falling victim to inflation, high interest rates and sophisticated new vehicles for personal savings. Among those coming to this controversial and politically risky conclusion is New York State's Superintendent of Banks, Harry W. Albright Jr., who intends to press for the introduction of some form of variable rate mortgage, coupled With greater flexibility in the interest rates which thrift institutions can pay to their depositors.

title: Books of The Times
description: This Is the first time that I am writing as I please, Colette says in The Evening Star. After 53 years of deadlines and commitments, this woman who has such a talent for pleasure is finally allowing that talent to dictate to her. She writes like someone humming to herself, someone pleasantly insomniac, watching images and memories pass before her eyes. She is fond of reading old letters from friends, browsing through yellowed photographs, and these pages are her own lettersletters to the worldher own memoryalbum of people, places, fragments of events, the midnight snack of a life in its 70's.

title: DR. DAN H. CAMPBELL
description: PASADENA, Calif Sept. 17 (UPI)Dr. Dan Hampton Campbell, a pioneer in immunochemical research at. the California Institute of Technology, died yesterday after a heart attack at a hospital here. He was 67 years old.,.

title: Connors Scores In Coast Tennis
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP)Jimmy Connors, scrambling to win a 97 tiebreaker survived a firstround scare from unseeded Mal Anderson and won, 75, 57, 76, today in the $100,000 PacificSouthwest tennis tournament.

title: Flags of Colonialism Lowering Worldwide
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 17As national liberation movements and international organizations put pressure on old imperial powers to yield the last shreds of once mighty overseas domains, the world's remaining colonies are fast disappearing.

title: U. S. PROMISES INDIA SOME HELP IN WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The United States indicated privately to India that she can expect some food aid this year, Indian and United States officials said today.

title: SANFORD GRIFFITH, BROKER AND TEACHER
description: Sanford Griffith, an authority on African art, social and political affairs who taught at New York University, City College and the New School for Social Research, died Monday at his summer hdme in Middletown, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived at 10 Sheridan Square.

title: Novel Glorifying Stalin Is Criticized in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17A new novel glorifying Stalin has come under attack for exaggerating the importance of the dictator's wartime leadership and glossing over his errors.

title: FORD MAY OFFER GREATER FOOD AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17President Ford is expected to announce to the United Nations tomorrow that the United States is prepared to increase its food assistance to poorer countries.

title: Wounded Knee Defense Reviews The Winningof a Politcal Trial
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 17In dismissing the charges in the Wounded KneeIndian trial here yesterday, :United States District Judge Fred J. Nichol said, I'm rather ashamed that the Government was not better represented in this case,

title: City's Consumer Agency Beset by Internal Strife
description: Lawyers and investigators, in the city's Department of Consumer Affairs say that the agency's lawenforcement division is. demoralized and decimated by personnel losses and has deteriorated rapidly during the eight months of the Beame administration.

title: ANDREW B. TRUDGIAN
description: Andrew B. Trudgian, retired chief counsel for J. P. Stevens & Co., the textile concern, died !Monday in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. Mr. Trudgian, who lived in Englewood, was 80 years old.

title: Hurricane Fifi Is Heading Toward Coast of Honduras
description: MIAMI, Sept. 17 (AP)Hurricane Fifi took a sudden turn to the southwest tonight and was expected to slam heavy rains and 100mileanhour winds on the northeastern coast of Honduras early tomorrow.

title: Dutch Queen forgoes Pageant in Crisis
description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept, 17 The Golden Coadh, a fairytalelike eighthorse carriage that the Queen of the Netherlands rides through The Hague on the third Tuesday of each September to open Parliament, stayed in its garage today.

title: City's Consumer Agency Beset by Internal Strife
description: Lawyers and investigators in the city's Department of Consumer Affairs say that the agency's lawenforcement division is demoralized and decimated by personnel losses and has deteriorated rapidly during the eight months. of the Beame administration,

title: Judicial Question
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuitcovering a complexity of cases that originate in the Federal District Courts of New York, Connecticut and Vermont.has always been regarded as second importance only fici the United States Supreme Court. When Learned Hand sat on this appellate cqurt, he was referred to as the Supreme Court's tenth man.

title: Conferees Agree On $2.6Billion Cut In Defense Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 17 (Reuters)A conference committee of the Senate and House of Representatives agreed today on a compromise defense appropriations bill of $82.57billion5.15 per cent below the Administration's reauestSenator John L. McClellan, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, announced today.

title: California Bar Backs Nixon's Second Bid to Resign
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17Richard M. Nixon's second attempt to resign from the practice of law in his home state was approved today by the Board of Governors of the California State Bar, who forwarded it to the State Supreme Court with the recommendation that it be accepted.

title: Clemency for Some
description: President Ford prefaced his clemency program for draft resisters and deserters with all the right words and sentiments. He invoked a national commitment to justice and mercy and the need to heal the scars of divisiveness.

description: Hundreds of New Yorkers gathered in Central Park's Sheep MeadOw yesterday to hear Bob Hope crack jokes about Manhattan's crowds and spray paint graffiti and watch Jackie Gleason join the Dow Jones averages in a plunge from a window ledge onto a deep pile of mattresses,

title: TERRORISTS FREE HOSTAGES, FLY OFF
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Wednesday, Sept. 18 The three Japanese terrorists who seized the French Embassy in The Hague last Friday left the embassy last night, freed all nine remaining, hostages and took off from Amsterdam's airport in a French jetliner.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kenneth Clark Accuses Police in Deaths
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark said yesterday that an analysis of persons killed by city policemen in the four years prior to 1974 showed that a shockingly high percentage of the victims were black or of Hispanic origin and between the ages of 22 and 26.

title: Hope and Gleason Jest in Central Park
description: Hundreds of New Yorkers gathered in Central Park's Sheep Meadow yesterday to bear Bob Hope crack jokes about Manhattan's crowds and spray paint graffiti and watch Jackie Gleason join the Dow Jones averages in a plunge from a window ledge onto a deep pile of mattresses.

title: LONG BEACH GETS LOANS APPROVAL
description: LONG BEACH, LI Sept. 17 Municipal employes here will receive their pay until the end of the fiscal year under an agreement reached today between city officials and the National Bank of North America.

title: Courageous completes 4 Race America s Cup Sweep
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17  Courageous lowered the boom on Southern Cross for the fourth straight time today and completed the 22d defense of the America's Cup, the international yachting prize the United States has never lost in 123 years.

title: Rangers Game Put Off
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 17 (UPI)  The scheduled game between the Texas Rangers and California Angels was postponed today because of wet grounds. A doubleheader with the Angels was set for tomorrow night.

title: COMPANY IS FINED ON CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The head of an architectural and engineering concern pleaded guilty today for himself and his corporation to charges of making illegal contributions totaling $10,000 to former President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 campaign.

title: Canadians Lifting Curbs On Imports of U.S. Eggs
description: OTTAWA, Sept 17 (AP)The Canadian Government has ternpoiarily lifted restrictions on United States egg imports, the Agriculture Department announced yesterday. The move was expected to have little ef fed on consumer prices because. American egg prices currently are higher than those. in Canada.

title: $12Billion Price Is Put On Jersey Water Cleanup
description: TRENTON Sept 17The State Department of Environmental Protection today projected the Cost of a total water pollution control program for New Jersey at $12 2billion through the year 1990.

title: McCracken to Prepare Policy Proposals for Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 17Paul W. McCracken, the Univarsity of Michigan economist and former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers has been asked by President ford to work out a set of policy proposals for dealing with the nation's current economic problems.

title: State's Con Ed TakeOver Could Cost $930Million
description: Consultants yesterday estimated that $930million would be needed for the State Power Authority to take over, finish and start up two Consolidated Edison power plants.
