description: State Aide Bars RailCrossing Gates

title: Some Long Shots Brighten Brighton Beach
description: There was a striking consistency between the two long shots that scored victories in the split divisions of the Brighton Beach Handicap at Belmont yesterday.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, Sept. 17"LoveItalian Style for Andy Rimol is a nocut contract to play basketball Italy. That is what the captain of last year's Princeton team got. The oneyear pact giving him three times the amount offered by the National Basketball Association's Buffalo Braves, is why he is in the training camp of the Scatto team of the Italian league. The season starts next Monday.

title: PAKISTAN CRITICIZES INDIAN ATOMIC BLAST
description: VIENNA, Sept. 17Pakistan today renewed her criticism of the Indian nuclear test explosion and declared that she was formally proposing to the United Nations General Assembly that the South Asian subcontinent be declared a nuclearfree zone.

title: Crashley, on 9th Club Of Career, Seeking Permanent Home
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario Sept 17A man and his dog came to the Islander training camp this week looking for a home. The man was Bart Crashley, a 28yearold defensenian who has played on nine professional teams the last 10 years. His dog is Sawsha, a 6monthold German shepherd that Crashley didn't want to leave behind with his parents when he left for yet another hockey training camp filled with unfamiliar faces.

title: Great Neck Schools Rescind an Order On Inquiry Reports
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 17 The School Board here has rescinded a resolution requiring weekly reports from the special counsel investigating allegations of misconduct against the District Superintendent.

title: Lionel Hampton Recovering
description: Lionel Hampton, the jazz musician, underwent surgery to arrest the massive internal bleeding that led to his hospitalization last Thursday. The 61year old musician was reported in satiffactory condition at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Market Place GL's CerroAssets Plan
description: A number of years ago when W. Clement Stone, the Chicago insurance millionaire, was a brash young man, he approached a major finance company about purchasing one of its subsidiaries.

title: AMEX ADVANCES AFTER 6 DECLINES
description: Traders on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market reacted to the announcement on Monday that the Federal Reserve was injecting more than $1billion into the money markets by sending prices up on both for the first time in seven sessions. The Reserve's move is expected to speCd the decline in shortterm interest rates.

title: Laird Samuels Press Chief Switches to Carey Campaign
description: Robert Laird, who until a week ago was Howard J. Sam uels press secretary yesterday joined Representative Hugh L. Carey's campaign in the same role.

title: Mainstream Drama Runs In Big Fish, Little Fish
description: Hugh Wheeler is a rewarding playwright entirely on his own, aside from such adaptations as Candideand A Little Night MuSic.

title: Senate Panel Votes Bill on Licenses
description: The Senate Commerce Committee approved yesterday a drastically stripped down version of the broadcast license renewal bill passed by the House last June.

title: DIVIDEND HALTED BY REALTY TRUST
Courageous completes 4 Race America s Cup Sweep
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17  Courageous lowered the boom on Southern Cross for the fourth straight time today and completed the 22d defense of the America's Cup the international yachting prize the United States has never lost in 123 years.

title: Soviet Says jailed Ukrainian Nationalist Is Alive
description: MOSCOW, Sept, 17The family of Valentin Moroz has been informed by the Soviet authoriteies that the 3Syearold Ukrainian dissident historian is alive. There were rumors earlier this month that he tiad died from a hunger strike.

title: Business Briefs
description: Phillips Agrees to Longer Leases

title: European Nations Map An Oil Consumer Front
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 17On the heels of still higher oil prices decreed by producing states in Vienna last week, the European Common Market countries moved today a step toward setting up their own consumer front.

title: Britain Coal Prices to Rise
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP)Britain's National Coal Board announced today that prices for industrial coal would be raised an average 28 per cent, effective Oct. 1. In March,

title: Dave Anderson
description: LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 17When the George ForemanMuhammad Ali heavyweight title fight was postponed yesterday, about threedozen newsmen were intercepted here before boarding an Air ,Zaire jetliner. I wonder if I'll have to take my shots again', one said. The yellow fever shot, he was told, is good for 10 years. In that case, the other replied, we might make it.

title: Chess: Karpov Baits an English Lion And Muffles Korchnoi's Guns
The Good Ship Lollipop
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Shirley Temple Black has sailed away to Ghana. George Bush, having lost the Vice Presidency, has been given a Chinese fortune cookie. Kenneth Rush, his economic wisdom unappreciated, has been dismissed from the White House and sent to enjoy himself at the Embassy in Paris.

title: Foreman's Car Bombed
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)A Firebomb destroyed today the stationwagon of a foreman for the Hughes Tool Company on the third day of a strike by 2,400 steel workers against the world's largest manufacturer of oil filed equipment. The automobile, belonging to James C. Jenkins, was parked in his driveway. No one was injured.

title: Andre Dunoyer de Segonzac, French Naturalist Painter, Dies
description: PARIS, Sept. 17Andre Dunoyer de Segonzac, France's most respected naturalist paintter, died of bronchitis here oday at the age of 90.

title: White House Denies Any Plans To Take a Job From Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The White House today denied news reports that President Ford's transition committee has recommended that he reorganize the National Security Council and strip Secretary of State Kissinger of his job as head of the council staff.

title: House Panel Seeks to Cut Over Half of Nixon Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A House subcommittee sought today to bar the use of Federal I funds to lease a storage vault in California for Watergate Rape recordings, and other documents and voted to cut by more than half an overall budget request for former President Richard M. Nixon's transition to private citizen.

title: Advertising: Detroit Thinks Short
description: The word from Detroit where the American automobile industry is on the verge of unveiling Its 1975 line to a waiting nation is that the longrange yearlong advertising commitment is almost a thing of the past.

title: Cardinals Win, Go 2 Up
DANIEL L. DAYTON JR.
description: Daniel L. Dayton Jr., a real estate broker, died yesterday. Mr. Dayton, who lived on Linden Lane, Upper Brookville, L. I., was 48 years old.

title: JANE R. SODOWICK
description: Jane R. Sodowick of 77 White Oak Drive, South Orange, N. J., wife. of I. Samuel Sodowick, president of Temple B'nai Abraham of Livingston, N.J., died yesterday of cancer in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston. Her age was 57.

title: Small Company Joins in Voice of Big Business.
description: PITTSBURGH Here's a job for the news media, the ministers, and the labor unions, proposed Richard Marshall, president and principal owner of Marshall Maintenance in Trenton, N. J. Let's make their next project one of making it stylish and patriotic to get to work every day and on time.

title: Stars for Mr. Haig
description: In the face of considerable opposition in this country and abroad, President Ford has proceeded with the appointment of Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe as well as commander United States Forces in Europe.

title: Canada Ties Soviet Six In Opener
DR. RENE SPITZ DIES; PSYCHIATRIST WAS 87
description: Dr. Rene A. Spitz, a retired psychiatrist who had served as a vice president of the. New York Psychoanalytic Society and a. professor of the graduate faculty, City; College of New York, died Saturday in Denver, where he lived. His age was87.

title: WILSON LEADING CAREY IN FUNDS
description: Governor Wilson is beginning his campaign with a surplus of $270;445 while his opponent, Representative Hugh L. Carey, has a deficit of S377,455 after his Democratic primary victory, statements filed by both candidates in Albany showed yesterday.

title: ELECTION FUNDING SPLITS CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 17A HouseSenate conference committee came close today to an agreement that Federal money would riot be allowed to finance Congressional election campaigns.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Welfare Mother Fined in $2.86 Theft

title: Boast in Bar Ends With Hudson Swim
description: An Englishman who says he swam the English Channel. in 1955 and an IrishAmerican aspiring actor who did his training at the Luxor Baths took cab to the Hudson River just after midnight Mondayafter a Iriendly drink in an Eighth Avenue barand, leaving their clothes on shore, dived in and swam to New Jersey.

title: MRS. ARNOLD L. FEIN
description: Margaret R. Fein, wife of Justice Arnold L. Fein of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan died Sunday in her home, 601 East 20th Street. She was 69 years old.

title: Seoul Leader Shakes Up Cabinet in a Bid for Unity
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 18  President Park Chung Hee of South Korea shook up his Cabinet today, replacing nine of 20 ministers in an effortto revitalize his adI

title: ARGENTINE STRIKE PROTESTS KILLING
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept, 17Buses and subway trains came to a standstill today throughout Argentina as transport workers called a 24hour strike to protest the assassination of a former leftwing Peronist leader of their union.

title: Saudis Arbia Clarifies Rise on Participation Oil
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  The Saudi Arabian Petroleum Minister, Sheik Ahmad Zaki Yamani, said today that he had informed American oil executives last June of a rise in oil prices but added that this did not conflict with Saudi Arabia's desire to see the price of oil go down generally.

title: C.I.A.'s Covert Role: Ford's Defense Runs Against Current Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 President Ford helped revive a dying issue last night. That issue was whether it was proper for a democracy, using its intelligence agencies, to intervenein the internal affairs of other countries.

title: UNION OR SEEKS THERMAL SHAH
description: A campaign to obtain contro of the San Franciscobasec Thermal Power Company al ready a controversial affair be came more so yesterday as the Union Oil Company of Califon nia bid for the company's shares Union Oil made tender offer for 840,000 shares of Thermal Power at $16 a share, an offer that could cost the large petroleum company at least $13.4million Thermal Power owns a quarter interest in a geothermal power project at The Geysers in Sonoma County, Calif.

title: ROBERT DUNCAN, 84, FUNDRAISER, DEAD
description: Robert F. Duncan, a fundraiser for nonprofit institutions for nearly 60 years, died Friday while attending a. meeting in Chicago. He was 84 years old and lived in Concord, Mass.

title: Hearst Names a Publisher
description: The appointment of William B, Bellamy as publisher of The San Antonio Light was announced yesterday by the Hearst Corporation, The Associated Press reported.

title: About the Yankees..
description: Jim Northrup joined the Orioles after one of the fastest shuffles in baseball: 39 days with the Montreal Expos. And that was after 900BD seasons with the Detroit Tigers. The lefthandedhitting outfielder, who belted three home runs with the bases loaded during one banner week 1968, was sold to the Orioles by the Expos after he had appearedin 21 games... , Whitey Ford has the Yankees pitching rotation lined up for the rest of the season, with four starters and one.extra man: Doc Medich, Pat Dobson, Rudy May, Larry Gura and Dick Tidrow.

title: Brazil and Japan Set Accord on Aluminum and Paper Ventures
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 17  Brazil and Japan reached agreement today for the construction of an aluminum industrial complex in the Amazon River Basin and a cellulose and paper industry in Espirito Santo State north of here.

title: BROKERAGE HOUSES REPORT JULY LOSSES
description: Some 250 brokerage house members of the New York Stock Exchange lost money during July, authoritative Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday, with the aggregate losses reaching $33.2million.

title: Brownsville Leaders Are Urging Calm
description: Communityleaders in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn strove yesterday to prevent further violence in the predominantly black neighborhood where teenagers clashed with the police Monday night, a day after a white police officer shot and killed a 14yearold black youth.

title: SENATORS SEEKING TO BAR TURKEY AIl
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17More than 20 Senators plan to seek Senate approval tomor. row of an amendment urging President Ford to cut off mill tary aid to Turkey because of what they describe as the il. legal use of United State: equipment during Cyprus crisis.

title: World's 12Meter Cup Is Proposed by Bond
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 A world championship for 12Meter yachts was announced tonight by Alan Bond, whose America's Cup challenger, Southern Cross, was routed by Courageous.

title: L. I. Crops Good, Income Down
description: WATER MILL, L. I., Sept. 17Tom Halsey had a busy day today on his family's 125acre potato farm here for this is the height of the harvesting season on Long island.

title: Cabby Who Killed Fare Is Freed Without Bail
description: A driver of a gypsy cab who shot and killed a passenger who he said had tried to rob him at knifepoint was released without bail yesterday in Criminal Court.

title: 2 Racket Busters Square Off For District Attorney in Nassau
description: MINEOLA L.I., Sept, 17William Cahn likes the title "RacketBusting District Attorney so much, he uses it on his publicity releases describing his sudden raids against pornography, drugs and bookmaking in his 12 years as Nassau County District Attorney.

title: ExF.B.I. Clerk Admits Deal With Crime Figure
description: NEWARK, Sept. 17 (AP)A former clerktypist for the Federal Bureau of Investigation pleaded guilty today to charges that she stole secret bureau files on an organizedcrime figure and sold them to the man, under investigation. Her husband, who allegedly helped arrange the sale, also pleaded guilty.

title: Photos of Mercury Rebegun
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 17 R(euters)  The spacecraft Mariner 10, zooming in for a second look at the planet Mercury, has started sending back photographs of the planet from more than two million miles out in space. Mariner,

title: DELPHIC FESTIVAL FOR CAFE SOCIETY
description: The Greek Art Theater has leased for 10 years the old Cafe Society at 1 Sheridan Square for the presentation in English of ancient and modern Greek plays, it has been announced by George Arkas, executive director of the theater group.

title: 29th U.N. Session Opens With Plea for Palestinians;
description: UNITED NATIONS N.Y.,Sept 17Foreign Minister Abdelaiiz Bouteflika of Algeria was unanimously elected President of the 29th General Assembly today as the Assembly began a 13week session. He accepted the post in. an unusually militant speech advocating selfdetermination for Polestinians.

title: TV: A. Glimpse of Reality
description: Last week's, start of the 197475 teleVision season, huffed and puffed mightily but still wound up with the typical mix of new series, ranging froth the bearable to the insulting. The most significant vibrations for TV's future were generated not by a series but by a madeforTV movie. The presentation of Born Innocent, a portrait of a juvenile detention home for girls, brought NBC a hefty batch of phone calls from irate viewers (700 in New York alone) and protests, from several station affiliates.

title: Questions on Health of Nixon Involve Treatment and Courts
description: How sick is former President Richard M. Nixon?

title: Key Items on U.N. Agenda
description: The agenda of the 29th General Assembly of the United Nations contains a record total of 113 items. The principal issues include the following:

title: A Safe Return
description: President Ford's endorsement of amnesty in August, which culminated Monday in the proclamation of a conditional amnesty program, touched off an important national debate, long overdue, on what the conditions for amnesty should be, or whether there should be any conditions at all.

title: NIXON MAY ENTER A HOSPITAL SOON
description: Julie Nixon Eisenhower, the former President's younger daughter, Said here yesterday that her father May soon be entering a hospital for treatment of the flareup of his chronic phlebitis.would probably be hospitalized in a week or so.

title: Bridge: Days of New York Dominance In National Play Are Past
description: Two decades ago New York experts habitually collected a majority of the major team titles at national championships. Those days are long gone, and in the Summer Nationals here in July, New York players failed to collect any titles.

title: Contract Awards
description: An agreement for the construction of the 530mile Norandean Oil pipeline worth $142million has been signed by Peru's state oil agency Petroperu and three United States companiesWilliams International Sudamericana, Ltd., a subsidiary of Williams Companies, of Tulsa; the Sedco Construction Corporation of Houston, and Horn International, Inc., a subsidiary of the Halliburton Company.

title: The New Gadflys
description: WINDSOR, Vt.The fulltime occupation of watchdog, or gadfly, of the American press, for some six decades exclusively belonging to the leftthe tough liberalshas suddenly been invaded by an even angrier and less reasoned right and by extreme rightists who attack the mass media, and especially the newspapers, which are still the most powerful makers of public opinion.

title: Alan Bond Promotes New Yachting Series
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 A world championship for 12Meter yachts was announced tonight by Alan Bond, whose America's Cup challenger, Southern Cross, was routed by Courageous.

title: Pole United With Family In U.S. After 28 Years
description: A 28yearold separation of a Polish man from his family that began when his relatives settled in the United States ended in tears of joy at Kennedy International Airport last night as John Orechwa, his wife, Alice, and 4yearold daughter, Edyta, stepped from a Lot Polish Airlines plane and passed through the United States Immigration and Customs Service.

title: People and Business
description: James Leonard Pate director of business research for the B. F. Goodrich Company, was nominated yesteday by President Ford to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. Upon confirmation by the Senate, Mr. Pate who is 39 years old will succeed Sidney L. Jones, who was appointed Deputy Assistant to the President in July.

title: Those Carnivorous PlantsYour Insects Will Hate Them
description: Now that your window boxes are filled with geraniums, your walls are dripping with wisteria and you can't see your terrace for the avocados, it's time to branch out into something more exoticlike carnivorous plants.

title: ENERGY MEETING SET BY MINISTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)Foreign and finance ministers of several of the world's biggest consumers of oil wil lmeet in Washington at the end of this month for informal discuisions of economic, financial and energy problems the State Department said today.

title: HASSAN BIDS COURT DECIDE SAHARA ISSUE
description: RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 17King Hassan II, seeking to head off a Spanish plan to hold a referendum in the Western Sahara, which is controlled by Spain and claimed by Morocco, proposed today that the two countries take their dispute to the International Court of Jus, tice in The Hague.

title: WAGEPRICE CHANGE HINTED BY FORD AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)Robert T. Hartmann, a White House counselor, said tonight that President Ford concelvably might change his Mind about wage and price controls if he faced a new Congross and a new set of economic conditions.

title: Broadway, Despite Inflation, Starts Off With a Full House
description: This fall there will be traffic jam on Broadway. Almost all the theaters are bookedwith new shows or with holdovers from last season. It's an unusual phenomenon, said a representative of the League of New York Theaters. In the midst of the highest inflation, the activity on Broadway is the best in five or six years.

title: NIXON'S LAWYERS SAY HE IS TOO ILL TO GIVE TESTIMONY
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17Attorneys for Richard M. Nixon have contended in Federal court here that the former President is too ill to provide testimony in a North Carolina civil suit growing out of his appearance at a rally in Charlotte in 1971.

title: Maya Plisetskaya Leads Bolshoi Stars
People in Sports
description: The AllStar second baseman of the Twins, Rod Carew, upset over being booed by Minnesota fans, wants to be traded. Carew, who leads the American League in hitting and is nearing a third straight league title, was booed by some of the 4,095 fans in Metropolitan Stadium in Bloomington on Monday night, after he dropped a pop fly in the ninth inning. It was his 30th error of the campaign.

title: Broadway, Despite Inflation  Starts Off With a Full House
description: This fall there will be a traffic jam on Broadway. Almost all the theaters are bookedwith new shows or with holdovers from last season. It's in unusual phenomenon, said a representative of the League of New York Theaters. In the midst of the highest inflation, the activity on Broadway is the best in five or six years.

title: General Motors Plans Saudi Arabia Venture
description: DETROIT, Sept. 17The General Motors Corporation said today it planned to he gin assembling cars and commercial vehicles in Saudi Arabia in late 1976.

title: Democratic Professor Winner In Oklahoma Governor Runoff
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 17 (AP)David Boren, a 33yearold college professor who promised a clean sweep of the old guard from state politics, swept to a surprisingly easy victory tonight in the Oklahoma. Democratic primary runoff for Governor.

title: BANK CONSORTIUM PLANS SINDONA AID
description: ROME, Sept, 17A consortium of four banks has been formed to shore up the sagging credit of the Banca Privata Italiana, one of the last pieces of the crumbling financial empire of Michele Sindona the Italian financier.

title: At the Barricades
description: Now that Paris's historic Les Halles has been replaced by two holes in the ground awaiting a subway and commercial complex, the President of France, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, has decreed a public garden for part of the site. With the additional announcement that plans for a Left Bank expressway are to be abandoned and that artists housing and potential green space are to be saved from speculative development, a more civilized urban policy seems to be emerging for the City of Light.

title: 3 Future Rangers Stars
Aleksei K. Gorchakov, 65, Kosygin's Chief of Staff
description: Aleksei K. Gorchakov, chief of staff of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, died last Wednesday in an automobile accident, the Soviet GOvernment newspaper, Izvestia, has announced. He was 65 years old.

title: Is Charged With Sex Bias
Against Halem Furniture Store
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs has acted against the Josephs Furniture Store in East Harlem, one of numerous furniture stores in the city that the department says prey mainly on lowincome consumers by enticing them with easy credit then selling them inferior goods at often inflated prices.

title: New Lottery Date Set Here
description: The date of the grandtier drawing in the $1million state lottery has been changed from Oct. 14, to give patrons more time to register for the drawing. The registration period for winning ticket holders has been extended from Oct. 1 through Oct. 12, he said. Five grandtier finalists will be drawn at 11 A.M., Sept. 30, at the No. World Trade Center building and the grandtier drawing, carrying a top prize of $1million, will be on Oct. 14.

title: Islam Growing Fastest in a Malaysian State; Charges of Pressure to Convert Are Heard
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: No Ali Foreman Bout Until Late October
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 17 The heavyweight championship boxing match between George Foreman and Muhammad Ali, originally scheduled for next Wednesday here, has been postponed at least until late October. Both fighters will remain in Zaire to train.

title: MINISTER IS GRANTED MURDERTRIAL DELAY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 (UPI)  The murder trial of the Rev. Samuel Corey, one of two persons charged with the hitandrun death of a honeymooning New Jersey woman earlier this year, was postponed today until Nov. 6.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Beame Administration said yesterday that it had worked out an installment type of payment plan for families about to be hit with sizable retroactive rent increases in rentcontrolled apartments.

title: ARABS REPORTED LENDING TO JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17Japan has arranged to borrow $1billion from a major Middle East oilproducing nation, believed to be Saudi Arabia, to cover her soaring oil import costs, it was reported here today.

title: Boast in Bar Ends With Hudson Swim
description: An Englishman who says he swam the English Channel in 1955 and an IrishAmerican aspiring actor who did his training at the Luxor Baths took a cab to the Hudson River just after midnight Mondayafter "a friendly drink in an Eighth Avenue barand, leaving their clothes on shore, dived in and swam to New Jersey.

title: Meeting Is Planned Friday By Kissinger and Gromyko
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) Secretary of State Kissinger and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, will confer in Washington Friday, the State Department announced today.

title: Where Are We Now?
description: PRINCETON, N. J.My grandfather, dying at 93, lies on his back on his hard hospital bed, watching the scene inside his eyelids where a young man strolls by the water. He is courting Helen Weed. His second wife, Billie, his darling, is hardly remembered, two years dead, and the 1940's are gone, the 50's and 60's blank, the halfcentury lived in Jacksonville faded and dim, and it's Charleston, West Va., he inhabit's now.

title: Alan Bond Gracious In Defeat
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17  Alan Bond, the muchcriticized owner of Southern Cross, became a model of graciousness tonight as he congratulated the men of Courageous for a tremendous effort in their defense of the America's Cup.

title: Byne, Gibson to Spar In Fund Raising Match
description: BROADBENT 4591774 Governor Byrne and Newark Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson will take part in a threeround exhibition boxing Match Saturday afternoon at Newark's Schools Stadium.

title: SENATE BARS CUT IN SAFETY FIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Senate rejected today a move to reduce sharply the coverage of the Federal agency responsible for improving the health and safety of workers.

title: Giants, Jets Find Center Is Not So Durable a Spot
description: Ailments at center, usually brie of the most durable positions in pro football, are causing the New York Jets and Giants to make adjustments in their lineups for Sunday's games.

title: For Tourists in Zaire, There's Still a Music Festival
description: The vice president of the organization coordinating tour arrangements for the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman heavyweight championship fight in Zaire says the twoweek tour will go on, but the one'week one will be delayed.

title: Solar Energy Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The Senate voted today to double Federal funds for solar energy research. The sill was sent to the House. The bill would authorize $100million for solar energy research in. the fiscal year that starts next July 1, double the $50million budgeted for the current year.

title: The Spinners of Vermont: A Chance for Skilled, Dignified Work
description: BURLINGTON, Vt. I became involved with the Spinners about a year ago, said Colleen Bingham, as she at at a rickety card table in the back room of the Shelburne Spinners little factory. I saw them demonstrating at a fair, she continued. Before, that, I didn't even know what a spinning wheel made.

title: Suspect in West Side Slayings Undergoing Psychiatric Tests
description: Calvin Jackson, who is said to have implicated himself the murders of a number elderly West Side women, began undergoing pyschiatric tests yesterday to determine whether he is competent stand trial for at least the one murder with which lie was charged last week.

title: COFFEE FUTURES CLOSE UP 2C LIMIT
description: After dropping about 7 cents a pound since the middle of last week, coffee futures rallied yesterday and closed at the limit of 2 cents a pound up on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The strengthening factors were a rush of buying by shorts to even their positions and some coffee roaster interest at the low prices.

title: Hope for Money Easing Pushes Stock Prices Up
U.S. AIDING STUDY ON ENVIRONMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)United States annunced today that 20 areas in this country had been designated as biosphere reserves for international research to aid the preservation of plants and animals.

title: U.N. Assembly President
description: When the General Assembly of the United Nations opened its 29th annual session yesterday, with the longest agenda in its history, its first order of business was the election of a President. By tradition, the post rotates to a regional candidate each year (the President of the 28th session was a LatinAmerican, Leopoldo Benites, a 67yearold Ecuadorian diplomat) and the choice this year was for the AfricanAsian countries. The new President is Abdelaziz Bouteflika, an Algerian who, at the age of 37, is the youngest person ever elected President of the General Assembly.

title: Amex and 6 Brokers To Test Option Plan
description: Six major Wall Street brokerage houses have volunteered to take part in a series of dry runs to be conducted by the American Stock Exchange prior to its introduction of trading in stock options this fall, the Amex diclosed here yesterday.

title: LACEY URGES TEST OF BAN ON CROWDS
description: NEWARK, Sept. 17Federal District Court Judge Frederick P. Lacey today asked that threejudge court be convened to determine the constitutionality of a state statute used by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to ban street demonstrations here following the recent disturbances.

title: Proposals for Reforms to Cut Health Care Costs Expected to Draw Fire at Parley Opening Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 17The Ford Administration's conference on inflation in health care costs, which starts Thursday, will consider basic shifts in the way medicine is practiced that are sure to draw the fire of the nation's doctors, hospitals and drug companies.

title: L. I. Crops Good, Income Down
description: WATER MILL, L. I., Sept 17Tom Halsey had a busy day today on his family's 125acre potato farm here, for this is the height of the harvesting season on Long Island.

title: SENATORS ORDER INQUIRY ON CHILE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, amid Congressional protests over President Ford's defense of clandestine intelligence operations, today authorized its staff to study available evidence that official testimony had been misleading about the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement in Chile.

title: E.E.C. Consumer Front
description: Member nations of the Eu ropean Economic Community yesterday moved a step closer to setting up their own can sumer front on energy. De tails on Page 59.

title: 29th U.N. Session Opens With Plea for Palestinians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria was unanlimously elected President of the 29th General Assembly today ad the Aasembly began a 13week session. He accepted the post in an unusually militant speech advocating selfdetermination for Palestinians.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES TAXSHELTER CURB
description: WASHINTGON, Sept. 17 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to include in its taxrevision bill curbs on realestate tax shelters, which are used extensively by investors not primarily in the real estate business.

title: Hood Only Skipper to Win 4 Major Titles
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 Frederick E. (Ted) Hood, skipper of the. America's Cup winner, Courageous, had already at the age of 15 made several sails for himself and his friends in his hometown of Marblehead, IVIltss. His next goal was to build his own yacht. He drew up plans for a 55foot sloop that he proposed to build in the family backyard.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP)Stable crews for the cofavorites, Boyden Hanover and Title Holder, were pleased today after the draw for Thursday's $132,630 Little Brown Jug. The middle jewel of 3yearold pacing's Triple Crown drew 17 colts, producing a record purse by more than 412,000 at the. Delaware County Fairgrounds. The entries forced two elimination divisions, with the first four finishers in each returning for a raceoff.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Bomb Threat Delays Flight
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 17 (UPI)A United Airlines 727 jetliner bound from Chicago to New York made an unscheduled landing at AllentownBethlehemEaston Airport today after airline personnel received a bomb threat by telephone. The 39 passengers are seven crew members. aboard Flight 904 left the plane safely and as the authorities searched the plane. No bomb was found.

title: Haig Denies That He Urged Ford to Pardon Nixon
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 17Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., outgoing White House chief of staff, said today that his strong personal desire for an immediate pardon for former President Richard M. Nixon had not been an operative factor in President Ford's decision to grant such a pardon.

title: Some Branch Libraries Forced to Curtail Hours
description: The traditional lengthening Of fall public service hours for the branch system of the New York Public Library will be curtailed indefinitely because of budgetary restrictions imposed by the city.

title: Ford's Address to. U.N. to Be Broadcast at Noon

title: CLAUDIA MORGAN, ACTRESS, 62, DEAD

title: There's a Brighter Side

The time has clearly come to take a look at what is right with the economy. Here are some notes gathered from all over. The United States is not going to have a depression, Mr. Ford and several leading financial institutions are saying.

title: PATRICIA CUTTS DIES; AN ENGLISH ACTRESS
description: Patricia Cutts, a British actress who appeared in: this country on television, Broadway and in Hollywood productions, committed suicide in her Chelsea, London, apartment, last week. She was about 47 years old.

Wallace cancelled today a planned trip to Tallahassee, Fla., and his aides said that the Governor would rest for the remainder of the week on his doctores advice.. Mr. Wallace had been scheduled to speak in Tallahassee tomorrow night. The Governor has been suffering from a low fever and swelling around a stitch, which is part of a procedure to improve functioning of his bladder.

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 18 (UPI)A Government statement today said the creation of a civilian provisional Government now was unacceptable to the Armed Forces Committee of military officers and enlisted men, who ousted Emperor Haile Selassie after 44 years of feudal rule in this ancient African kingdom.

title: A Ballistics Report Finds Carrasco Shot by Own Gun
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 18 (UPI)Fred Gomez Carrasco was killed with his own gun during an escape attempt from the Texas State Prison, according to aballistics report. presented to the Walker County grand jury yesterday. c

title: Correcting a Blunder
description: The decision by the Ford Administration to recognize former President Nixon's title to the tapes and documents of his Presidency, which looked bad enough when it was first announced, seems utterly indefenlible now. Although the objections of the Special Prosecutor's office to the proposed arrangement were known to the Department.of Justice, the final decision was made without participation by Mr. Jaworski or his representatives. Thus, the decision on the Nixon documents is of a piece with Mr. Ford's decision on the preemptive Nixon pardon. In each instance the decision was taken in virtual secrecy and with undue haste, without requisite consultation and without proper regard for the judicial process.

title: Draft Official Quits
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept: 18 (UPI)  The President of the Jefferson Parish draft board re signed today in protest against the Teniency program set up for Vietnam war. resisters, Ira L. Hinton also wrote a letter to President Ford saying he was on his way, to becoming the worst President ever.

title: Beame Forms Unit To Help Relocate Businesses in City
description: Mayor Beame formed an interagency economic office yesterday to relocate merchants and manufacturers displaced by urban renewal and other government projects.

title: MarketBasket Cost Up for 11th Week
description: The cost of feeding a family continued to rise here last Week as food prices, led by sugar and margarine, rose for the 11 th. consecutive week, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: FASHION TALK
description: For many New Yorkers, it was their first deep, serious look at long skirt fashions since 1970, when they were introduced  and rejected. At the beginning, it threw some into a state of shock, but within an hour many revived long enough to, try one on and, in softie cases, to send it home.The viewing. has come primarily at fashion shows staged by department stores to introduce fall readytowear collections of Europe, an couture designers.Long skirts have been pretty much accepted in European fashion circles for six months or so, But even in European fashion circles, Emanuel Ungaro's are a bit extreme. They usually stop at the middle of the calf, or descend even longer.He generally pairs them with loose, smocklike tops and the skirts themselves are rather voluminous.Stunned For Awhile So when the clothes were paraded at Saks Fifth Avenue recently before members and friends of the Assistant Board of Woman's Hospital at St. Luke's, the women first sat in stunned silence. They began to perk up when the skirts appearedin flowered wools and the shirts in smaller scale versions of the same flowers. By the time the sweatersin bold graphic designs or glittering metallics for evening turned up, the applause was genuine.Afterwards, the , women chatted about skirt lengths. I don't know about long for day, said L'auren call, who was wearing a mid knee length pleated skirt in mauve. with a matching Tshirt. Maybe with boots for winter it makes sense.", Lauren Feltz and Jan Chipman admitted they were pre sold: both wearing skirts that covered their knees,. The flowered. dress Mrs.'.: Peitz wore was' by Schemer, Mrs. Chipman's separates were Givenchy's. I like the feel of long skirts, Mrs. Peitz said. They're tricky for shorter women, Mrs. Chipman observed. Accept the. Lengths Saks later reported that the flowered things were all sold out; so were the tweed and ,The clothes by Valentino, shown yesterday at Bloomingdale's to inaugurate, his new shop there, were not quite as extreme and therefore easier to assimilate. The hemlines stopped an inch or so below the knee, which was the length of the Missoni outfit Polly Bergen was wearing.It's the length that looks best on inemidcalf is awful, she said happily as the styles were paraded.  The silk shirtssolid colored or printed with panthers, gii'aft'es or tigerswere what the viewers applauded during the show and purchased afterwards, despite price tags ranging from $135 to $175.

title: Big New Jersey Utility To Trim Construction
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company said yesterday it planned to cut $688million from its construction budget through 1978. This would reduce planned outlays to $1.9billion over the 19741978 period.

title: People and Business

Testifying before the subcommittee on foreign commerce and tourism of the Senate Commerce Committee, the Big Board chairman noted that the exchange had foreVast that $650billion would be needed over the next 12 years to meet United States expansion needs. One of the ways to help overcome this capital gap is to stimulate foreign investment, he said.

title: Antonia,' Film Portrait of a Conductor
description: The headlines refer to "triumphs." But the tone is patronizing: "Yankee Girl Startles Berlin Critics" (The New York Times, 1930.) Along with the acclaim for a deeply serious conductor, there's the lurch of astonishment at the mere fact of her sex. "Antonia," a superb documentary about conductor Antonia Brico, details the achievements and the struggles that began for a child who was first taught piano because she bit her nailsand continue for the 73-year-old who now leads a community orchestra in Denver.The film, directed by Judy Collins, singer, and Jill God-milow, film maker, who was co-director of the documentary "Tales," opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art and will run through Oct. 1.When she was 28, critics called Dr. Brico a great conductor. After directing the Berlin Philharmonic, she twice conducted the Metropolitan Opera. 'Ovations ensued, but she was denied a third concert because John Charles Thomas, the baritone, wouldn't work with a woman. Between 1934 and 1937, she assembled and conducted a women's symphony, which thrived until she tried to convert it into an ensemble of both sexes"I want people to mix in symphonies as they do in life." But the project was rejected by the board of directors at Carnegie Hall because the concept was undramatic. The press had eagerly quoted Dr. Brico when she said that "Art is sexless," or when Jose Iturbi sneered at women musicians. But when she simply performed as an artist, she wasn't sizzling copy.In the film's most searing moment. Dr. Brico tells Judy Collins (who was her piano student) that she has only about 5 performances a year  when she has the energy for 4 or 5 a month. While a soloist can play a piece for herself, a conductor needs the whole ensemble, along with the audience. Dr. Brico says. "I cannot play my instrument  which is the orchestra," adding that she rarely confides this "perpetual heartbreak" to anyone. Such a personal revelation is terribly rare on screen  clearly, it's due to Dr. Brico's friendship with Miss Collins. Also, the latter is a good listener  which is no surprise.Recently, we heard Henry Miller (in Robert Snyder's documentary) reminisce about his early frustrations as a writer. But he was able to look back on those youthful difficulties after years of recognition. Dr. Brico has known no such luxury. Told by many that it was ridiculous for a woman to think of conducting, she admits, "I felt that I'd never forgive myself if I didn't try." And the pain and deprivation which she has known all her life are over-shadowed in this film by her ebullient, forthright warmth.The narrative of her life alternates with glimpses of her at workrehearsing or teaching. She also reflects on the emotional experience of conducting (including the acute separation pangs that follow a concert, evaluates the work of other conductors, and. evokes the strong support that she had from Jean Sibelius, Sir Adrian Boult, and Albert Schweitzerwho telegraphed "Courage Love Success" before a major performance."Antonia" is biographical cinema at its best, and it will also encourage many women in fields other than music, thanks to Dr. Brico's determination, her refusal to be defeated. The film ends, as it should, with bravos and applause.Also on the program is Jordan Belson's "Light"7 minutes of beautifully shifting images that change radically in intensity and color. At moments the elusive patterns suggest stars, sand, water, or the sun. The results make the concept of psychedelia seem old-fashionedeven though the film appears as a highly sophisticated descendant of that movement.

Schmidt, the Corm, missioner of Food and Drugs, said today. At the same time, Mr. Schmidt said the agency was reconsidering some of its original proposals to restrict certain vitamins.
