description: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, Sept. 18 (AP)The Government of Irime Minister James Mitchell fell today after a noconfidance vote. Mr. Mitchell dissolved the Parliament and called for new elections. St. Vincent is an associate state in the British West Indies.

title: Only Slight Response Reported In Area to Ford Amnesty Offer
description: There has been little response in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the last two days to President Ford's conditional amnesty offer to Vietnamwar draft evaders and deserters. Nearly all of those who did call for information refused to give their names, and most of the calls came from women.

title: Strike Threat for 2 Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 18 (AP) The Airline Pilots Association said today it would strike Braniff International Airways and Hughes Air West at midnight Friday unless an agreement was reached on new contracts for pilots and flight attendants. The union represents 1,300 Braniff pilots and 550 Air West cabin attendants.

title: Dow Scores 3.13 Advance In Mixed Market Session
Senate Puts Off Its Action On the ExportImport Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Senate put off until tomorrow action that had been scheduled for today on legislation renewing the ExportImport Bank.

title: Mrs. Bela Kun, 84, Widow Of Hungarian Communist
description: VIENNA, Sept. 18 (AP) Mrs. Bela Kun, widow of the founder of the Communiststyle Hungarian Republic of Councils"in. 1919 and herself a lifelong fighter for Communism, died at the age of 84, the. Hungarian news agency, reported yesterday.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE TO CUT BUILDING
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18  Officials of the Public Service Gas state's largest utility, announced today that construction expenditures over the next five years would be cut by $688million.

title: A New, Different Cuba
description: LONDONThe mountains are moving to Mohammed. Without Premier Fidel Castro's having to take a step, most of Latin America is going his way and pressures are building up in the United States for a change in policy toward. Cuba.

title: NURSING SITE OPEN
description: The Towers Nursing Home, for many years the target of investigations and allegations of scandal, has been declared ineligible for Medicaid because of violations of the Federal firesafety node.

title: Fixed Fees Stir New Debate
description: A prominent college professor told stockbrokers here yesterday that they would be better off with price competition than with fixed fees and immediately ran into a friendly argument.

title: SOUTHWESTERN SETS REACTOR FINANCING
description: The General Atomic Company announced yesterday at San Diego, that the Southwestern Public Service Company wits planning to take the lead. in construction of the nation's first nuclear power plant that would use a gascooled breeder reactor.

title: UNPAID RENT CALLED SERIOUS PROBLEM
description: The state's Welfare Inspector General, William F. Meyers, charged yesterday that there was a serious problem of nonpayment of rent by welfare'recipients here and that the iBeame Administration was ignoring the matter.

title: Archer Will Face a State Bribery Trial
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that Norman D. Archer, a former assistant Queens district attorney, could be tried on state charges similar to those on which he was convicted by a Federal jury 20 months ago.

title: Ford Offers Plan Aimed at Assisting Distressed Pan Am
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 18The Ford Administration, after rejecting a Pan American World Airways request for a $10.2million monthly Federal subsidy, announced today en alternative sevenpart plan aimed at aiding the distressed airline. It includes three steps likely, to provoke an angry reaction from some foreign governments.

title: U.S. CHECKS REPLY BY ARMY TO SUIT
description: BONN, Sept. 18The United States Government has sent a legal official to West Berlin to investigate the response by the United States Army to a lawsuit charging its intelligence agents with illegal surveillance of American citizens.

title: CPC Increases Dividend
description: CPC International, Inc., announced yesterday in Englewood Cliffs, N. J., that it was incerasing its quarterly common stock dividend to 50 cents a share from 46,5 cents. The dividend is payable Oct. 25 to shareholders of record Sent. 30.

title: Teachers'
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 18The political arm of the New York States United Teachers contributed more than half a million dollars to political candidates in 1972 and did not file the regular Federal reports required by law until this month.

title: McCrane Loses 2d Bid for a Mistrial
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18 (UPI)Joseph M. McCrane Jr., former State Treasurer, moved for a mistrial today, charging that Monday's disclosure of a possible renewed state investigation of the 1969 campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill had prejudiced a Federal Jury's consideration of his taxfraud conspiracy case.

title: Blazers Top Bell, 2421, On Aerial
Inflation Parley Results
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18What has President Ford learned from the halfdozen meetings on inflation staged around the country in the last few weeks? He has probably observed the emergence of a rough, far from perfect consensus in a few broad areas such as monetary policy and wage and price controls.

title: David Carradine Arrested
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 18 (Reuters)David Carradine, star of the television series Kung Fu, was free on bond today after being arrested Monday for allegedly robbing and ransacking a neighbor's house in the Hollywood Hills.

title: MOSCOW ARTISTS REGAIN PAINTINGS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18Ten of the 18 paintings seized by young vigilantes and plainclothesmen at a nonconformist art show last Sunday have been returned to the artists and their friends.

title: U. S. and Soviet Resume Parley On Strategic Weapons in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Sept. 18 (UPI)American and Soviet negotiators today resumed their talks on the limitation of strategic arms after a sixmonth recess. They have been instructed to reach a comprehensive accord in 1975 to last for an initial period of 10 years.

title: 22 NIXON CHOICES ENDORSED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 18 President Ford has submitted a list of 22 names of holdover nominations made by President Nixon and has asked the Senate to confirm the choices.

title: F.E.A. Aide Is Optimistic On Winter's Fuel Supply
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)Duke Ligon; assistant administrator for the Federal Energy Administration, said today that the nation would not have major gasoline and fuel oil shaftages this winter unless there was another embargo by exporting nations such as the one last year.

title: Floating Mortgage Rates Scored by State Senator
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18 (UPI)William T. Conklin, deputy majority leader of the State Senate, today called the floating home mortgage interest rates proposed by the State Banking Department a roller coaster ride for the homeowner.

title: House Panel Finds Catches in 50 of 51 Warranties
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18A House subcommittee charged today that most manufacturers had escaped their obligations to consumers by offering product, warranties with important limitations and ambiguous langu1 age..

title: Premier Says Greece Will Hold Election Soon
description: ATHENS, Sept. 19 (Reuters) Premier Constantine Caramanlis said last night that a national election would be held in Greece as soon as possible.

title: Americans Top Texans By 4214
CAREY CRITICIZED ON ABORTION ISSUE Wilson Siores Hini for Not Signing Petition  More Pressing Problems Cited
description: GovernorWilson yesterday criticized his Democratic opponent, Representative Hugh L. Carey, for refusing to sign a Congressional, petition that would have permitted floor debate on the proposed antiabortion amendment to. the Constitution.

title: A Rumanian Sampler: It's Pretty Powerful Stuff
About Real Estate Modern Apartmehts Worry Colonial Village
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.Out of the fields of academe riding the great horse Enthusiasm has come a 35yearold builder whose efforts have left a strong impact on this picture book New England town.

title: SENATORS ASKING TIGHTER CIA. REIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 While President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger conferred today with nine Congressional leaders over United States intelligence practices, two Senators introduced a bill to reform and broaden legislative control of the intelligence community.

title: Senate Urges Ford to Halt Arms Aid to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Senate voted today to urge President Ford to cut off military aid to Turkey. The vote came after a sharp exchange behind closed doors between Secretary of State Kissinger and Senator Thomas F. Eagleton on the legality of the aid.

title: Healthy Housing
description: The decision of the city's Rent Guidelines Board review the blanket rent increases it authorized in new leases for 400,000 formerly decontrolled apartments makes sense, even if it is probably a response to political pressure from outraged tenants and the City Council.

title: Inflation Is Felt by Distilleries
description: Inflation has hit the bottle. Cork poppers and cap twisters haven't slowed their consumption of wines and distilled spirits, but sharp changes in commodity prices and production  costs for these beverages, combined with changing consumer tastes, have forced distillers to modify the character of some drinks as well as prices.

title: The Fords Give. Picnic For White Hoase Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  Everyone from the maids to the chief of staff turned out today for a White House staff picnic that President and Mrs. Ford gave on the White House south lawn.

title: Pilot and Familyof 3 Die in Monmouth Plane Crash
description: CLARKSBURG, Sept. 19 (AP) A New Hampshire family of three and a pilot were killed today when their plane crashed and exploded here, the police said.

title: Back to Office Hours
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 19 (AP)Dr. Bobby Brown, president of the Texas Rangers, said today he would begin devoting more time to his medical practice in Fort Worth after the World Series and would relinquish most of his duties with the American League club.

title: Hunt Says Silbert Shunned His Plea to Tell All in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 One of the original Watergate defendants has said that a month before the 1972 Presidential election, he was willing to tell all he knew about the origins of the bugging plot in exchange for leniency but that his offer was turned aside by the chief prosecutor in the case.

title: RAMPAGING YOUTHS INJURE 3 IN QUEENS
description: Three persons were assaulted by a rampaging band of 15 youths in a Queens bowling alley last night, the police re. ported. Three youths, who the police said may be members of a youth gang, were later ar. rested.

title: Television Producers Oppose Rule on Access to Prime Time
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Major television producers voiced their opposition today to the television primetime access rule, contending that the quality and diversity of programing had declined sharply since its adoption four years ago.

title: OIL NATIONS SPUR U.S. INVESTMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept., 19 (Reuters)The Treasury Department estimated today that oilproducing :nations invested about $7billion in the United States and about $8billion in Britain in the first eight months of 1974.

title: People and Business
description: Thomas E. Willem, chairman, president and chief exv ecutive officer of the Champion International Corporation, has resigned in a policy disagreement with the board of directors.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The nation's savings and loan associations sustained another big loss of savings money last month, but a Government official, reporting this today, said the industry was in sound financial shape, nevertheless. We do not have any major savings and loan association in any kind of problem, Thomas Bomar, the chairman of the Federal Home Land Bank Board, said at a news conference.

title: The Drama. Pure Desire
Pupil Who Skates 5 Hours a Day Is Excused From Calisthenics
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19 (AP)State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke decided today that a 10thgrade student who is practicing five hours a day to make the United States Women's Olympic figure skating team should not be required by local school officials to perform rigorous physical _education exercises as well.

title: Giants and Jets Favored Against Foes Who Have Some Questions to Answer
description: Are the Miami Dolphins in trouble? Are the New England Patriots for real? What's with the Chicago Bears After a surprising opening of regularseason play last week, answers to these questions could emerge from Sunday's second NaLeague weekend. The Dolphins, twotime Super Bowl champions, were stunned by the ambitious Patriots, 34.24, a defeat that prompted some Miami cynics to dub their heroes, Fat Cats; for the rich new contracts negotiated over the summer.

title: Court Will Consider Ousting State Judge
description: Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appeals yesterday ordered the convening of the Court on the Judiciary to consider whether State Supreme Court Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade should be removed from office.

title: DIABETES DRUGS CALLED OVERUSED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 19Three diabetes specialists agreed today that doctors grossly overprescribe the drugs that are taken by mouth to low, er blood sugarthe socalled oral antidiabetic drugs.

title: Britain Under Stress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 197Suffering froth the inflationandrecession problem in an advanced form, Britain heads into its second general election this year with the prospect for stronger national leadership distinctly discouraging.

title: Officer in Killing Relieved of Police Duty
description: A white police officer who shot and killed a 14yearold black boy in Brooklyn last Sunday night was relieved of police duties and stripped of his firearms yesterday as city officials and community leaders sought to end the nightly disorders that have wracked the streets of Brownsville.

title: BROKERS SEE ERA OF CONTRACTIR
description: Someof Wall Street's more successful stock brokers toot a realistic look at themselves. here yesterday and concluded that the nearterm outlook foi the industry was anything but promising.

title: Celebration for Graham
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 19 (UPI)  The Rev. Billy Graham opened a threeday celebration tonight to mark the 25th anniversary of the tent meeting he says transformed him from a country Baptist preacher into an evangelist who became widely known.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AMERICANA As the bicentennial nears, museums and exhibition halls are doing their share to salute those art works and artifacts that belong to a uniquely American heritage. Two exhibitions that are opening this week mark the trend with a collection of folk art and notsofolk art.

title: Opening Statements Given
description: Representative Bertram Podell was described by the prosecution at his bribery tria, yesterday as a United State: Congressman who agreed tc sell the influence of his office for money.

title: People in Sports
description: The only $100,000ayear performer in the World Football League, Charlie Harraway, was voted the Players Association president yesterday. Harraway, the Birmingham Americans fullback, said the, group had no connection with. the National League's players group, which struck the N.F.L. camps this year.

title: AMNESTY POLICY MAY OMIT ALIENS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Government lawyers said today that President Ford's conditional amnesty program might exclude any draft evader or deserter who had become a citizen of another country.

title: Accord Is Signed in Suit Over Employment Bias
description: United States Judge Lawrence W. Pierce signed a settlement agreement yesterday in a suit charging employment discrimination in the newspaper and publications delivery industry in the New York City area.

title: Bin ham Sketches Stir Dispute
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19The Mercantile Library here is seeking a buyer for 112 sheets of drawings by. George Caleb Bingham, raising.fears that this city will lose one of its oultural treasures.

title: RCA Names Director
description: William C. Hittinger, executive vice president of the RCA Corporation, has been elected to the board. He is responsible for RCA's consumer electronics, solidstate electronics and electronic components. Mr. Hittinger joined RCA in 1970 as vice president and general manager of the solid state division. Prior to joining RCA he was president of the General Instrument Corporation.

title: Moon'sUbiquitousSigns Disappear as Promised
description: Well, they're gone. The thousands of bright blue posters that, made many New Yorkera see red disappeared early yesterday evenmore swiftly than they had appeared,. and by dawn, dozens of boarded up storefronts and construction fences throughout the city had been stripped to their natural shabby state.

title: Italy Is Making Good on the Failure off Sinclona's Bank
description: ROME, Sept. 1The Banca Privata Italiana, a bank controlled by Michele Siridona; the financier, that had run up losses calculated.. at $200,rnilIion, fo be woUrid up as a legal entity tomorrow, but neither depositors nor creditoiS will be hurt, a high Italian banking official said today.

title: Judge in Jersey Declares McCrane Case a Mistrial
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Federal Judge Lawrence A. Whipple, after previously denying two similar petitions, declared a mistrial today in the Federal campaignfraud conspiracy trial of Joseph M. McCrane, the former New Jersey State Treasurer.

title: NORWAY SPURNS OILSHARING PUN Says It Can't Back Proposal Before Parliament Debate
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 19Norway told its partners in the 12nation oil consumers group today that it could not give definite approval, to the almost completed oilsharing plan until the measure is debated in its Parliament next month.

title: FORD LOSES BID TO DELAY RAISES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19President Ford lost his first test with Congress today as the Senate rejected by a wide margin his proposal to delay for three months a 5.52 per cent pay increase to 3.6 million Federal employes.

title: Ballet: Rose Malade of Bolshoi Stars
Tokyo and Seoul Formally End Dispute Created by Assassin
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19 The Japanese Government tendered to South Korea today two expressions of regret, one written, the other oral, over the attempted assassination of President Park Chung Hee by Korean resident of Japan.

title: Mozambique Guerrillas Free 197 Portuguese
description: NANGADE, Mozambique, Sept. 19 (Reuters) Nearly 200 Portuguese soldiers were unexpectedly freed today by Frelimo, the Mozambique Libberation Front, which will soon assume control of this Portuguese territory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN F. KOLB
description: John F. Kolb, a freelance writer and former editor of Product Engineering, a McSrawHill publication, died Sept. 11, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 137 Mount Vernon Street, Nutley, N. J. He was 58 years old.

title: Its Supplies Depleted, U.N. Asks Urgent Aid for Cyprus Refugees
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept, 19the United Nations High Comnission for Refugees called today for urgent action to help the 225,000 refugees in Cyprus.

title: PROSECUTORS CITED. FOR INDIANS TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 19 (UPI)Though harshly criticized by the trial judge for his handling of the Wounded Knee trial, the Federal prosecutor, R. D. Hurd, lhas received an award from the Justice Department for superior performance:

title: SOME EXPORTERS FACING TAX RISE Foreigners Get a Break in Buying Stock and Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (Rcuters)  Congressional tax writers voted today to raise some $33million from Americalls doing business abroad, but agreed to a big tax break for foreigners buying United States stocks and bonds.

title: Day Care Center With an Enviable Menu
description: PORT CHESTER, N. J. The chairman of the board of R: H. Macy 8e Co. and the children of the Carver Day Care Center here share a fondness for Portuguese cooking, especially a dish called Ameijoas Na Cataplana.

title: McCrane Judge Rules Mistrial, Citing Jurors Exposure to News
Jim Garrett Suspended By W.F.L.
Campisis Win Legal Point As Jury Selection Nears
description: MOUNT HOLLYLawyers for the Campisi family successfully opposed a request by the state [today that Judge W. Thomas McGann of Burlington County Superior Court ask prospective jurors what they thought about executive grants of clemency.

title: State Official Calls Furniture Buying Russian Roulette
description: When a family orders a piece, a set or a houseful of furniture, the chances are that it ties up a goodly amount of cash for a period ranging from weeks to more than a year. It also runs the risksas many consumers have learnedof forfeiting that money if the retailer goes bankrupt or Skips town. The Select Committee on Consumer Protection, a 12member bipartisan body of state legislators, has decided to take up the cudgels of beleaguered furniture buyers who complain more often about abuses than any other group except auto repair clients. Besides protecting the consumers down payment funds, the committee also hopes to find a way to save them from inordinate delivery periods and inadequate merchandise.

title: CostCutting Seen Needed For Pan Am Debt to Ease
description: Government officials and financial experts said yesterday that drastic moves to cut costs, ineluding suspension of some moneylosing services, would be a minimum requirement for any possible debtpayment extension for beleaguered Pan American World Airways.

title: 4 in Fort Lee Case Plead Not Guilty to Bribe Charge
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Four top officers of Investors Funding Corporation of New York were released in $100,000 band each today after they pleaded not guilty to charges that they had authorized $1.4 million in bribes to try to win support for a $250million highrise project near the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

title: NearSighted Kicker Beats the Stars
Civilians Turn Hostile To Ethiopian Regime
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 19The most fervently debated question in the Ethiopian capital following the removal of Emperor Haile Selassie is whether a conflict between the military regime and its former civilian backersthe trade unions, students and professionals  has become inevitable.

title: Matuszak Hints
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) John Matuszak, who tried to jump to the World Football League but was blocked in court, said today he would return to the National Football League if the Houston Oilers trade him.

title: SHORT INTEREST SHOWS A DECLINE
Fishing Outlook for Area Waters
description: October's warm days and cool nights are fast approaching, issuing in the month that is perhaps the most rewarding of all for east coast surf fishermen.

title: Jersey Senate Backs Transit Bond Proposal
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19The Byrne administration's $300million transportation bond issue was approved by the State Senate this evening.

title: TRANSPORT SETS JNFLATION PARIEY Officials Gather on Coast for Today's Meeting Cost of Fuel a Big Concern
RAY RICHARDS
description: LA HABRA, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP)Ray Richards, a star football player at Nebraska in the nineteentwenties and a professional player and coach, died yesterday of cancer. He was 68 years old.

title: Vietnam Truce Unit Facing Fund Crisis
TaxWriting Congressmen Aided by Special Interests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19Special interests that are trying to preserve or enlarge the favored treatment they now receive under the tax laws are contributing heavily to the campaign funds of members of the House Ways and Means Committee, which originates all tax legislation.

title: Red Smith
description: The National Labor Relations Board opens hearings in New York today inquiring into the mortality rate among player representativesin the National Football League. The player rep is the shop steWard, the team's delegate to the sport's labor union, and he has a shorter, shakier life expectancy than the second lieutenant in a combat infantry:. outfit. There are 26 player reps, Since the union opened its campaign to win for the hired hands some voice in their own destirty, 11 player reps or union offiners And two alternate reps have lost their jobs. A. hospital that lost patients at that rate would be. closed down

title: JAWORSKI CALLS NIXON TO TESTIFY IN COVERUP CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19A second subpoena, this one obtained by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, has been sent to Los Angeles for delivery to former President Richard M, Nixon commanding his appearance at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: POTATO FUTURES SINK TO LOW
Soviet Jews Fear Jackson Deal Ignores Spurious Security Issue.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19Four Jewish scientists today voiced fears that a compromise package on Soviet emigration being worked out in Washington by Senator Henry M. Jackson might still leave the Kremlin free to block legitimate emitrants by using exaggerated definitions of national security.

title: Broadway Tower Project Referred to City Planners
description: The Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday ordered Paul and Seymour Milstein, developers who have been seeking to build a 43story mixeduse tower at Broadway and 62d Street, to submit the plans to the City Planning Commission for approval.

title: Legislative Panel Sets Up Bistate Talks With New York
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)A legislative committee said today it was starting talks with the New York Legislature to discuss mutual problems of the two states.

title: About the Jets...
description: The Jets, who already have had to shuffle their offensive line for their game against Chicago Sunday, face another, problet. Rich taster, the tight end, was kicked the right knee in practice Wednesday. don't know if I'll be able to play or not, Caster said. It all depends on how the knee feels after I put heat on it tomorrow. It's a. deep bruise and I've just been able to put ice on it so far. If Caster is.unable to play, his place in the lineup will be taken by Willie Brister, a rookie.... The Jets will have another rookie on the starting offensive lineRoger Bernhardt. He. will start at. guard and Garry Puetz will, switch to center.... Wayne Mulligan, the starting center, remains in the hospital with pneumonia, and the backup center, Varren Koege has knee and ankle injuries.... Joe Naniath reported after yesterday's practice that he felt better than he had felt all week since suffering, a back spasm last Sunday;

title: Ford Seeks $73.8Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19 (UPI) President Ford asked Congress today to approve $73,8million in new budget funds for the Departments of Labor and Commerce.

title: TaxWriting Congressmen Aided by Special Interests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Special interests that are trying to preserve or enlarge the favored treatment they now receive under the tax laws are contributing heavily to the campaign funds of members of the House Ways and Means Committee, which originates all tax legislation.

title: Hurricane in Central America
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Sept. 19 (AP)At least 42 people were reported to have been killed as Hurricane Fifi moved along the northern coast of Honduras last night, but a Government emergency committee said that unconfirmed reports from amateur radio operators in the area indicated a death toll of about 200.

title: Bridge: Commitment to Convention Can Hide Simplicity's Appeal
description: One of the practical disadvantages of using a great many conventions is that the temptation to use one may be too strong even though simple, direct action could be better. If West had not had a convention available on the diagramed deal from the Spingold knockout teams here In July, he would perhaps have wound up more than 1,000 points better off.

title: FINANCE ACCORDS SET BY CERTAINTEED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP)The Certainteed Products Corporation, who manufactures and distributes diversified building materials, announced two agreements today involving $108million in financing.

title: Brock Is Hickok Winner
description: Lou Brock, who broke Maury Wills's major league record of 104 stolen bases for a season, has been named top athlete in August in the S. Rae Hickock Professional Athlete of the Year voting.

title: KISSINGER TELLS OF HOPE TO WIDEN TIES WITH SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Secretary of State Kissinger said today, that reduced tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union had opened the way for much broader EastWest collabora tion on such crucial global matters as food, energy and the environment.

title: A New Microwave Oven Is Introduced by Litton
description: Litton Industries, Inc, introduced here yesterday a new microwave oven with a variable cooking control that matches power levels with various cooking tasks. It enables the user to vary power from 65 to 650 watts. The new counter top unit, produced by Litton's Mi,, crowave Cooking Products division, will carry a price tag of $469.

title: DISTILLERS CORP. INCREASES PROFIT
Grumman to Delay Decision On ThirdPeriod Dividend
description: The Grumman Corporation, which is having difficulty financing production of its F14 fighter jets for the United States Navy and Iran, announced yesterday that it would delay further a decision on payment of a thirdquarter dividend on common stock.

title: T. C. Viviano Weds Kristina Wright
description: Kristina Young Wright, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Alan Wright of Montclair and Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday morning to Thomas Coulter Viviano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew Joseph Viviano of Plainfield, N.J.

title: House Unit, in Shift, Bars Reform Move On Real Estate Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The House Ways and Means Committee reversed today an earlier decision and decided to permit investors in real estate ventures to keep the special tax advantages they have now.

title: About the Jets...
description: The Jets, who already have had to shuffle their offensive line for their game against Chicago Sunday, face another problem. Rich Caster, the tight end, was kicked the right knee in practice Wednesday. I don't know I'll be able to play or not, Caster said. It all depends on how the knee feels after I put heat on it tomorrow. It's a,deep bruise and I've just been able to put ice on it so far. If Caster is unable to play, his place in the lineup will be taken by Willie Brister, a rookie.... The Jets will have another rookie on the starting offensive lineRoger Bernhardt. He will start, at guard and Garry Puetz will switch to center.... Wayne Mulligan, the starting center, remains in the hospital with pneumonia, and the backup center, Warren Koegel, has knee and ankle injuries... Joe NamatI reported after yesterday's practice that he felt better than he had felt all week since suffering a back spasm last Sunday.

title: Town Is Losing Water
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. (UPI)This town has discovered it has a major leak problem. A report to City Council indicated that nearly half the water the city buys from the Greenbrier resort hotel leaks out of the municipal water lines.

title: The Stage
description: What's this? A rock musical about Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and the My Lai massacre?. Yes, and a striking one. Will wonders never cease?

title: Dr. Frederick F. Yonkman, 72,
description: HOLLAND, Mich., Sept. 19 (AP)Dr. Frederick F. Yonkman, who developed one of the first tranquilizers, died Monday while on vacation in New Brunswick, Canada. He was 72 years old,

title: Parade of Witnesses Backs City Ombudsman Bill
description: A bill to establish a city ombudsman was enthusiastically supported yesterday by a parade of witnesses at a city Council hearing yesterday. But it appeared that the legislation was in grave trouble within the Charter and Governmental Operations Committee, which conducted the hearing.

title: DR. CHARLES HAINES
description: Dr. Charles Everett Haines, a consulting surgeon at New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital since 1924. died there Wednesday at the age. of 80. He lived at 59a Locust Avenue, New Rochelle.

title: 4 MILK GROUP SUES TO REGAIN $332,000
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 19 (AP)Associated Milk ProRicers, Inc., has sued its for mer general manager for $332,000 it alleges he misappropriated through political contributions.

title: Net and G.N.P. Data Revised Downward
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Both corporate profits and the gross national product were revised downward today by the Commerce Department, largely because of the technical effect of the takeover by Saudi Arabia of 60 per cent of the ownership of Aramco, the oilproducing company in that country.

title: The Pop Life
description: What is one to make of a pop singer who isn't really very popular? Clearly such a singer must be counted a failure in one significant sense, since there is a builtin populism to the esthetics of popular music.

title: JAWORSKI CALLS NIXON TO TESTIFY IN COVERUP CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19A second subpciena, this one obtained by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, has been sent to Los Angeles for delivery to former President Richard M, Nixon commanding his appearance at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: Defusing the Presidency
description: COS COB, Conn.  The American Presidency has become a greater risk than it is worth. The time has come to seriously consider the substitution of cabinet government or some form of shared executive power.

title: WILLIAMS JOHNSON, F.T.C. ECONOMIST
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 19 (AP)Williams Summers Johnson, Government economist, died today of complications from a stroke suffered in July 1972. He was 61 years old.

title: Bache Announces Quarter Loss Despite Profit in Fiscal Year
description: Bache & Co., Inc., the brokerage firm, reported yesterday that it lost $1.02million in the fiscal quarter ended July 31 although it showed a profit of $257,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year ended on that date.

title: Rockefeller Says His Assets Are Valued at $62 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller, saying he was acting to counter what he termed incomplete and therefore misleading data leaked to the press, reported today that his net worth and that of his wife totaled $62.5million, plus the income from two trusts worth $120million.

title: Connors Ousts Case On Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19, (AP) Topseeded Jimmy Connors took an openingset tiebreaker, 7 points to 5, and went on to score a 7.6, 6.3 victory tonight over Ross Case of Australia, seeded 14th, in the third round of the $100,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

title: HARRY C. MOSS
description: Harry C. Moss, a lawyer with the Central Intelligence Agency in Washington, died of cancer Monday at his home in Fairfax, Va. He was 39 years old.

title: Ford Will Request Delay on $24Barlion In Federal Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) President Ford will isk Congress within the next few days to cut back or postpone $24billion in Government spending, Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today.

title: DOUBLE RECOVERY OF OIL COSTS SET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19 (UPI)A major oil corporation said today it.was told by the Government that it was permissible to use a loophole inl price regulations to make a double recovery on its costs.

title: Market Place
description: In a bear market like the present one, the question arises, How long has it been since the market was this low?

title: Dr. Clarence Mills, 81, Fought Smoke Pollution
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (AP)  Dr. Clarence A. Mills, a pioneer environmentalist who I campaigned for an antismoke law, died Tuesday at the age of 81.

title: KISSINGER TELLS OF HOPE TO WIDEN TIES WITH SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Secretary of State Kissinger said today that reduced. tensions between,the United States and the Soviet Union had opened the. way for much broader EastWest collaboration, on such crucial global matters as food, energy and the environment.

title: Notes on People U.S Agency Rehires Santarelli
description: A Federal crimefighting agency, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, has quietly rehired its former chief, Donald Santarelli, who resigned earlier this year after criticizing President Nixon's handling of the Watergate scandal.

title: 4 IN FORT LEE CASE PLEAD NOT GUILTY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Four top officers of Investors Funding Corporation of New York were released in $100,000 bond each today after they pleaded not guilty to charges that they had authorized $1.4 million in bribes to try to win support for a $250million highrise project near the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Erupts
description: VOLCANO, Hawaii, Sept. 19 (UPI)  Fountains of lava spurted 80 feet high today with an eruption of Kilauea Volcano on, the island of Hawaii. The eruption occurred shortly after midnight in the southwest rift zone. The lava overflowed from a crater called the Halemaumau fire pit and crossed a road.

title: Jim Garrett Suspended By W.F.L.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 19 (AP)The commissioner of the World Football League suspended Coach Jim Garrett of the Houston Texans team today for conduct detrimental to the league.

title: Indian War Threatened
description: BONNERS FERRY, Idaho, Sept, 19 (UPI)Law enforcement officers have warned of another Wounded Kneetype of confrontation if the Kootenai Indian tribe carries through its threat to seize 1.6million acres of its tribal lands. The Indians have set a deadline of midnight tonight for the Government to take action toward a treaty to settle the 120year dispute. The 67member Kootenai tribe has threatened war unless a treaty is negotiated for the land, in northern Idaho and northwest Montana.

title: CLOSURE REJECTED ON CONSUMER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Senate supporters of legislation to establish a consumer protection agency failed today for the fourth, time to end protracted debate by conservative opponents of the measur.

title: Books of The Times
description: It may be a bit cynical, but it is nevertheless reasonable, to suggest that the sluggish state of the economyand the resulting collapse of the officebuilding boomwas the best thing that could have happened to , the landmarkspreservation business, both here and elsewhere. At just the time in the late nineteensixties when public consciousness of our disappearing architectural heritage was mounting, the greatest threat to that heritagenew skyscraper constructionall but disappeared.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Attorney General's office announced yesterday the indictment of three members of the Little Ferry Planning Board on extortionconspiracy charges. Meanwhile, spokesman disclosed that three former borough officials, GerryV. Ozeah, Edward Gorleski, and Russell Stout, and a restaurant owner, Frank G. Swagger, had pleaded guilty in the alleged scheme.

title: D.A. to Write to Persons Investigated and Cleared
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 14 Henry G. Wenzel 3d, the Suf folk County District Attorney said today that he was writing personal letters to persons who had been investigated by his office or by a grand jury and were subsequently cleared.

title: Historical Park in Boston Is Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Congress has passed and sent to the White House a bill that provides for $27million for a proposed Boston National Historical Park.

title: Fears of H.E.W. Cuts Spur Protests at Inflation Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Ford Administration's antiinflation conference on social services boomeranged on its organizers today soon after it opened.

title: 2 Truck Drivers Capture a Suspect In PurseSnatching
description: Two truck drivers, one of them at the wheel of a 20ton flatbed loaded witth 20 tons of newsprint, sped after and captured a young pursesnatching suspect on West 44th Street yesterday aftern000n. The suspect a 15yearold youth, had allegedly grabbed a pocketbook from an elderly woman at Ninth Avenue.

title: TRANQUILIZER DRUG IS LINKED TO CANCER
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)Three medical studies published today suggest that women over 50 years old stand a three to four times greater risk of contracting breast cancer if they, are taking a certain family of tranquilizer drugs used to treat high blood pressure and psychosis.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A large water main and a major steam pipe burst on Park Avenue near 78 Street around 4 A.M., flooding the area and sending 15storyhigh geysers of intensely hot, highpressure steam into the air which threw sections of pavethent, asphalt, rocks and other debris welt hurled against nearby apartment buildings and onto their roofs.

description: Steve Robinson, whom the nosecution had charged with he stabbing of Prof. Wolfgang Friedmann exactly two years ago, was sentenced yesterday to serve at least eight years and four months in prison for having robbed the Columbia :'niversity scholar.

description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Sept. 19Vic Hadfield, the former captain of the New York Rangers who was traded brusquely and without warning to the Pittsburgh Penguins at the end of last season, has something to prove this year.

description: The stock market turned in its best performance in six weeks yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial ay.erage up 22.14 points. A factor was the belief of many investors that tight money pressures were easing. Details on Page 51.

title: Officer Who Killed Youth, 14, Is Relieved of His Police Duties
description: A white police officer who shot and killed a 14yearold black boy in Brooklyn last Sunday night was relieved of police duties and stripped of his firearms yesterday as city officials and community leaders sought to end the nightly disorders on the streets of Brownsville.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 (AP)United States District Judge Miles Lord has issued a temporary restraining order that prohibits the National Collegiate Athletic Association from imposing any sanctions against the University of Minnesota if ,a freshman, Reed Larson, plays hockey for the Gapheri, ,Larson, former Minneapolis Roosevelt High. Schooll star, had been ruled ineligible by the N.C.A.A. because as a 17yearold junior he signed an agreement with an agent to negotiate his contract when he turned professional.

description: Sept. 19  The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were estimated at $1,021,000,000, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $977,000,000. Total retail store sales were about 1$10,373,000,000, up 9 per cent from last year's $9,520,000,000.

description: MONTREAL, Sept. 19 (Rett ters)  Public transit service here will begin to return, to normal tomorrow following settlement of a strike that has closed subways for more than, five weeks.

description: A 60yearold Staten Island man with an arrest record dating to 1948 and a 38yearold former convict were found slain in gangland style in their latemodel cars yesterday in separite sections of the city. The killings did not appear to be related, the police said.

title: OmegaAlpha Reports Bankers Have Reduced Its Debt Further

title: Stocks on Amex and OTC Advance
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Patents resumed their boycott of two schools, one in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn, as public schools in the city reopened yesterday after being closed on Tuesday. and Wednesday because of the Jewish holiday of Rosh aShanah. At Public School 34, East 11th Street and Avenue D, parents kept 525 of the 618 enrolled pupils out to protest. for a second day, personnel decisions and other actions by District 1 school authorities. At Public School 167, 1025 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, 1,200 of the 1,800 pupils stayed out of classes for the third school day because of a zoning dispute.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Representative Earl F. Land grebe, Republican of Indiana a selfdescribed fiscal conserva tive, proposed to his House col leagues today that they take 10 per cent cut in their $42;500 ayear salary to fight inflation

description: Harold A. Stevens, an associate judge of the. State Court of Appeals, who was defeated in the Cent. 10 primary for a nomination by his own Democratic party for his present post, declared yesterday he would work for the Republican ticket headed by Governor. Wilson.

title: Haughton Drives to 5th Jug Victory
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 "I wonder when the bubble will break, said Billy Haughton. Harness racing's first $20million driver, who won the Little Brown Jug for 3yearold pacers here today for the fifth time, driving Armbro Omaha to a short neck victory over George Sholty's Boyden Hanover in the final heat in 1:584/5.

title: Funny, Marvelous Fellini Amarcord
SOS for DST
description: Almost as if by stealth, Congress is in the process of repealing aroundtheyear Daylight Saving Time. When the plan was adopted last fall, the principal argument was that it would save electricityand therefore fuel. The same reasoning prompted its wartime introduction in this country and in Western Europe, where several countries made it a permanent arrangement. That reasoning is not refuted by the simple fact that one can now get gasoline without waiting on line.

title: Covert Abuses
description: President Ford's defense of covert action by intelligence organizations against foreign governments is faulty both in its particular application to Chile and as a general tenet on foreign policy. The belatedlyrevealed campaign against the Government of the late President Salvador Allende adds just one more example of how executive powers can be abused when the element of effective accountability is absent.

title: Boy, 4, Drowns in Cesspool
description: CENTREVILLE, Ill., Sept. 19 (UPI)  Otis Johnson, 4 years old, drowned last night when he apparently fell into a cesspool at a neighbor's house, the police said. The child apparently wandered onto the yard of Barbara Jackson and fell into the open pool. He was pronounced dead at Christian Welfare Hospital.

title: 2 MORE TRISTAR JETS ORDERED BY SAUDI'S
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today thatSaudi Arabian Airlines has signed a contract to buy two more Tristar airliners that would be powered by an advanced version of the RollsRoyce RB211 engine.

title: Pilot Says He Was a V.I.P. to Captors.
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Sept. 19  Emmet James Kay, the American civilian pilot who was freed in Laos yesterday by the proCommunist Pathet Lao, said today that he had been treated as a very important person during his 16 months of captivity.

title: About New York
description: Michael, the elderly secutility guard with liver spots on his hands called out, when did you last hear from Ireland?

title: Screen: 'Minamata':The Program
description: "Minamata," the Japanese-made documentary that opened the Film Forum's fall season last night, is persuasive and often shocking evidence of the present dangers of pollution. Although the feature occasionally might call for fuller explanations, the awesome, sometimes death-dealing blight that struck Minamata, the fishing and manufacturing town on the island of Kyushu, is a sobering, forceful case history that leaves little doubt as to the dire results of man's current approach to the disposal of modern-living wastes.For the record, Minamata can point to its simple fishermen who have worked its waters for centuries, a large, modern fertilizer factory and, for the last two decades or so, to the sad distinction of being the home of "Minamata disease." This is attributed to the mercury-poisoned effluvia from that factory that made the cycle from fish to humans whom it incapacitatedor killedin various ways.Noriaki Tsuchimoto, the director of "Minamata," who is a stranger to this observer, and a fairly large complement of associates shot their black-and-white footage in Minamata, its environs and Osaka in 1971, largely in question-and-answer sessions with victims or their survivors.The results are either dolefully factual or pitiably tearful but nearly always painfully arresting Dedication and devotion are obvious in the help given by affected families, friends and hospital personnel to children and grown ups afflicted by cerebral palsy-like retardation, paralysis, blindness or deafness.If these touching scenes in a major portion of the film are subdued, "Minamata," nevertheless, strongly implies and occasionally illustrates what appears to be big industry and governmental apathy before it builds to a literally riotous climax as the diseased and their sympathizers descend on a meeting in Osaka of the impassive president and board of directors of the Chisso company, operators of the plant, to demand reparations and justice.One would like to read more details in the literal English subtitles such as the specifics of the infection or the newspaper accounts of last July, which listed 428 victims, 69 of whom died. An epilogue points out that the Chisso company paid about l.5-million to 138 victims last year.On the basis of the bleak record poignantly and pointedly presented in "Minamata," that statistic doesn't seem to be the answer to the terrible, perhaps portentous, problem of pollution.

title: FINANCE LEADERS CAUTIOUS ON FED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19A very cautious and qualified endorsement of further easing in the very restrictive Federal Reserve Board monetary policy appears likely to emerge tomorrow when leaders in the world of finance meet for their presummit meeting here.

title: 15 MAJOR GROUPS URGE PUBLIC JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Fifteen major national civil rights, labor and civic organizaLions called today for broad programs of publicservice jobs and improved unemplOyment insurance and regular costofliving increases for welfare and Social Security recipients.

title: NESSEN MAY GET TERHORST'S POST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Ron Nessen of NBC News has been chosen by President Ford as the White House press secretary, according to several sources close to the President.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
People in Sports

Harraway, the Birmingham Americans fullback, said the group had no connection with the National League's players group, which struck the N.F.L. camps this year.

title: Europe's Summit
description: The politicoeconomic crisis in West Europemarked by inflation, oilpayments deficits, rising unemployment, falling governments and a growing danger of social violencehas made concerted action by the Common Market's nine member countries both more difficult and more necessary. So far, the difficulties have prevailed. But a new impetus for common action seems to have emerged from the informal dinner summit of the Nine last weekend at the Elysee Palace in Paris.

description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. Sept. 19Walt Frazier looked at the unfamiliar faces at Monmouth College today where the Knicks opened their training camp, and said, Seems strange. Where did everybody go?

title: News Sumirtary and Index FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1974;The Major Events, of the, Day
Was Ford Conned On Chile?
description: WASHINGTONThe disclosure that the Central Intelligence Agency financed the series of strikes that preceded the overthrow of President Allen'de in Chile ought to make Gerald Ford hide his face. Either he has been conned by the C.I.A. into grossly misleading the American people and giving his approval to international gangsterism; or he did it on his own.
