Dewey Thruway backed up about five miles today at the western approach to the Tappan Zee Bridge because of repair work, state authorities said. Repaving and other repairs caused backups in traffic since the work began early Monday, but they became Norse today, the Thruway police said.

title: Eckstein Expects No Economic Upturn for 12 Months
description: The next 12 months are 12 months of nothing, the economist Otto Eckstein said at a meeting of worried business executives here yesterday.

title: C.I.A. Is Linked to Strikes In Chile That Beset Allende
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19 The Central Intelligence Agency secretly financed striking labbr unions and trade groups in Chile for more than 18 months before President Salvador Allende Gossens was overthrown, intelligence sources revealed today..

title: CLOSURE REJECTED ON CONSUMER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Senate supporters of legislation to establish a consumer protection agency failed today for the fourth time to end protracted debate by conservative opponents of the measure.

title: CLEAR WARRANTIES APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The House passed today legislation to require that warranties on consumer purchases be clearly stated. The measure also outlines way for the buyer to get warranties enforced.

title: Many Linger in Zaire Fight or Not
description: KINSHASA, ZAIRE, Sept. 19Marguerite Mays went shopping today for wood and ivory carvings, copper masks and malachite jewelry. Her daughter, Billie, spent most of the day in the Intercontinental Hotel's swimming pool. To Mrs. Mays, divorced wife of the baseball player, Willie Mays, the postpone ment of the world heavyweight boxing championship fight from next Tuesday until at least sometime in late October has not been catastrophic.

title: Changes in Other Weapons Outpace Nuclear Race
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 The balance of military power may have, shifted more over the last year because of changes in the nature and deployment of conventional weapons than because of the nuclearweapons race.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Boca Grande by Loren Singer (Doubleday, $6.95). A psychological thriller.

title: Boulez Leads Philharmonic in Mahler and. Dvorak
SHAH IN SINGAPORE ON EASTERN TOUR
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 19  It has been called, unimaginatively, a goodwill trip  yet nothing could be more accurate. For the Shah of Iran, off on a tour of five Asian and Pacific nations, is guaranteed nothing but goodwill from heads of government only too willing to help him invest his surplus oil riches and direct the oil itself to their ports.

title: Blazers Top Bell, 2421, On Aerial; (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
Doctors Concerned On Emotional State Of Separated Twins
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP)Siamese twin girls successfully separated in a complex operation were reported doing extremely well today, but doctors were concerned about their emotional recovery.

title: Islamic Fast Loses Rigor In Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 19 The people of Teheran, who like to feel there is a distinctTeheranian way of doing most things, have begun to observe, in their own fashion, solemn Moslem month of Ramadan.

title: Court Will Consider Ousting State Judge
Jackson, ExFoe, Backs Lowenstein Candidacy
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Sept. 19Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, who is considered a main contender for the Democratic nomination for President and was a supporter of this country's role in the war in Vietnam, today endorsed the Congressional candidacy of Allard K. Lowenstein, a stanch peace advocate.

title: Police Call Bosco Apparently the Only Eyewitness
description: A police official said yesterday that except for the officer whose bullet killed a 14yearold black boy in Brownsville, Brooklyn, last Sunday, there were apparently no other eyewitnesses to the shooting.

title: Ford Lists 2 Speeches
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) President Ford will travel to Provo, Utah, and San Francisco on Oct. 2 for speeches to students at Brigham Young pniversity and a conference of United Press International editors, the White House announced today.

title: Advertising: The System s Stand
description: The press is an advocate for the adversary and the adversary is usually against the system, so the system's only recourse is to achieve balance through advertising or so a, leading ad agency executive said yesterday.

title: Ambulance Is at Hand
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)A city emergency ambulance set a speed record recently when a girl was sobbed and beaten at a local high school. When the incident occurred, the ambulance crew was already there, demonstrating first aid to students.

title: A PRELATE IN ISRAEL RESIGNS IN DISPUTE
description: HAIFA, Israel, Sept. 19 (UPI)  The Most Rev. Joseph M. Rays, Greek Catholic Archbishop in northern Israel, announced his resignation today, charging interference in his diocese by Partriarch Maximos V Hakim and Pope Paul VI.

title: RICHARD B. DAVIS
description: Richard Barry Davis, executive vice president of DavisDelaneyArrow, Inc., a printing and publishing concern here, died, apparently of a coronary attack yesterday in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived on Walker Brook Road, Washington, Conn.

title: Transportation Bond Issite Approved by State Senate
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19  The Byrne administration's $300million transportation bond issue was approved by the State Senate here this evening.

title: ZACK TAYLOR, LED ST, LOUIS BROWNS
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP)James Wren (Zack) Taylor, who managed the hapless St. Louis Browns under the innovative ownerpromoter Bill Veeck, died today at his Orlando home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

title: 77th St. Residents Meet With Police On Block Murders
description: Frightened by a series of murders on their block which came to light only after the recent arrest of a suspect, more than 200 residents of West 77th Street, opposite the American Museum of Natural History, met at their local police station last night to ask why they had not been told of the murders as they occurred over the last two years so they could better protect themselves.

title: Police Use Cars and Clubs To Quell Brownsville Riot
description: Police officers in radio cars drove into riotous crowds of Brownsville youths late Wednesday night an dat least half a dozen stragglers were struck with police nightsticks.

title: Government Jet Takes Julie Eisenhower West
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)  Julie Nixon Eisenhower flew to San Clemente, Calif., today on a Government courier plane, a courtesy that has primarily been accorded to other former first families, a White House military aide said.

title: Team Canada Wins, 41 , And Leads Soviet Series
NEW BOSTON AREA HIT BY VIOLENCE
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19  Racial fighting broke out this afternoon at Hyde Park High School in an area of the city that had previously been quiet as Boston integrated its schools by busing.

title: On Urban Rights
description: CHICAGO. This nation's major domestic problem is the ,existence of mass poverty, disproportionately among minority groups, in this most affluent of all countries.

title: Canada.Increases Gas Export Price
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 20Canada ordered an increase in the export price of natural gas today, with drastic prospects for United States consumers, who use, about 40 per cent of the Canadian output of the fuel.

title: A LARGE PROTEST ERUPTS IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20Several hundred demonstrators spilled into Saigon streets this afternoon in the first largescale antiGovernment eruption since the signing of the Paris peace agreements 19 months ago.

title: Transport Chiefs Propose Environmental Law Curbs
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20A wide range of transportation leaders added their voices today to the burgeoning campaign to help fight inflation by easing some environmental and consumersafety laws.

title: Busing Protests Spread to East Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP)Antibusing demonstrations spread to East Boston today as city, schools ended the first week of courtordered integration that was accompanied by sporadic violence and racial tension.

title: FOOD IS UP AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Consumer Price Index rose 1.3 per cent in August, the largest monthly increase since 1947 except for times when price freezes had just been lifted.

title: Lesbos, Just Off Turkey, Is Weary of Alert
description: MYTILENE, Greece, Sept. 15What can we do ,to protect;our homes and our lives? asked a woman who can see the lights, of Turkey from the veranda her house here on these of cool evenings. Lesbos We can do nothing  absolutely nothing! Such sentiments, heard widely, sum up the mood on this Greek island of 90,000 people in the Aegean Sea a few miles off the west coast of Anatolia.

title: Restored Greek Voice
description: It was a poignant moment in Greece this week when the Athens newspaper Kathimerini came off the presses for the first time in seven and a half years. Rather than accept the mindless censorship of the bullying colonels, publisher Helen Vlachos closed down the journal which she had long guided with intelligence and energy.

title: TEST OF STOCK TAPE TO START ON OCT. 4
description: A fourmonth test of the proH posed combined stock market tape of Big Board stocks will begin on the New York Stock Exchange Oct. 4, the Consolidated Tape Association said yesterday.

title: A 13th Moon of Jupiter Is Reported Discovered
description: A California astronomer has discovered what appears to be a new and 13th moon of Jupiter. It has been photographed on three successive nights from the observatory atop Mount Palomar.

title: Atom Breeder Plant Up $1Billion in Cost Since 1972 Estimate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)The estimated cost of the prototype of the breedertype nuclear power plants planned for late this century has increased by more than $1billion during the last two years.

title: WALL ST. SUITS SEEN FROM COMPETITION
description: Price competition on Wall Street  which the Securities and Exchange Commission insists must be introduced by next May, will set off a rash of lawsuits against stockbrokers, a leading antitrust lawyer forecast here yesterday.

title: Court to Hear Rao Challenge to Nadjari
description: The Appellate Division asked yesterday to hear arguments concerning the. propriety of the me4ns used by the state's special prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, to obtain a perjury indictment last May against United States Customs Court Judge Paul P. Rao Sr.

title: Environmental Agency Predicts 13.5% Better Mileage in 75 Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that 1975 automobiles would get about 13.5 per cent better gasoline mileage, on the average, than 1974 models.

title: Coffee Pact Extended
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (UPI)the executive board of the International Coffee Organization agreed today to extend the present International Coffee Agreement for a further year, until Sept. 30, 1976. The board also postponed the date set for completing the negotiations for a new agreement from Sept. ,30, 1974 to May 31, 1975.

title: Brandt Book Set for Fall
description: The NorthAmerican edition of three autobiographical works by Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, will be published by Little, Brown & Co

title: Canada Increases Gas Export Price; U.S. to Bear Brunt
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 20Canada, ordered an increase in the ex (port price of natural gas today, with drastic prospects for United States consumers, who use about 40 per cent of the Canadian output of the fuel.

title: Four Drown in Florida Cave
description: BRANFORD, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP)  Four young men drowned Wednesday night while diving in an underwater cave near here. The men, all Floridians, were Thomas Bennett Crowder, 19 years old, of New Smyrna Beach, and James Barten Bennett, 23, Eric Allen Sedwick, 23, and Henry Louis Nielsen, 22, all of Maitland.

title: ITALIANIICE DEALER KILLED IN BROOKLYN
description: The vice president and manager of a Brooklyn store selling Italian ices was fatally shot by a gunman who apparently fled without stealing anything.

title: WINE TALK
description: Probably the most difficult group of wines to judge for readiness to drink are red Bordeaux. There are great wines of the 1947 vintage that are not yet ready to drink and indifferent wines of the 1970 vintage that in another year will be over the hill.

title: BURNS SAYS DROP IN INTEREST RATE EASES TENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Dr. Arthur. F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, called encouraging today the recent decline in shortterm interest rates and said tensions in the nation's financial markets have been reduced to some degree in recent weeks.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A survey of American painting, ranging from a 1902 pastel by Childe Hassam to a 1964 fluorescent alkyd by Frank Stella, will open Tuesday at the Executive Mansion in Albany. The exhibition, entitled Twentieth Century American Painting, is drawn from the collections of 10 upstate and Long Island institutions, including the MunsonWilliamsProctor Institute of Art in Utica and the AlbrightKnox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

title: The Ballet
description: It was disappointing that Maya Plisetskaya decided not to perform the announced excerpts from Swan Lake, Act III, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and to substitute instead Swan Lake, Act II, which she had already danced on the opening night. If anything, passionate and effulgent, she was even finer than before, but it would have been nice to see her Odile again.

title: Mrs. Marcos in Peking; Visits Chou in Hospital
description: MANILA, Sept. 20 (AP)Imelda Marcos, wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, flew to Peking today to open a new era in relations with China. The President, meanwhile, stressed the need for a continued United Statei military presence in Asia.

title: New Jovian Moon
description: A California astronomer is believed to have discovered a new and 13th moon of Jupiter. Page 32.

title: Time Inc. to Lift Cover Price Of Its People Magazine to 40c
description: Time Inc. announced yesterday that its People magazine planned to raise its cover price from 35 to 40 cents with the Oct. 7 issue, which goes on sale on Sept, 30. A spokesman blamed rising costs  nothing singular for the move. He said the magazine, which made its debut with the March 4 issue of this year, has a circulation of about one million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Ford Administration seems to be pursuing the same course in the fight against inflation which has failed to produce any slowdown or decrease during the past five years. In any case, it does not fight directly against inflation but rather hopes to affect inflation by slowing the economy and causing thereby a deflation or controlled recession.

title: Bicentennial Spirit at the Smithsonian: A History of Clothing
description: WASHINGTONI've always wanted to see what a cotton gin looked like, Joan Mondale was telling Brooke Hindle, the director of the National Museum of History and Technology, part of the Smithsonian. Institution.

title: Ford Bids Congress Trim Spending by $600Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20President Ford asked Congress today to defer or rescind about $600million in spending in the current fiscal year, which ends next June 30.

title: Man, 22, Accused Of Bank Robberies Notes
description: A man arrested Thursday night on a drug charge was accused yesterday in 10 Maehattan bank robberies and two robbery attempts in a period from last January to the day before his arrest.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: THUN, Switzerland, Sept. 20 (AP)The Soviet Union, taking four gold medals and setting two world records, dominated today's opening events of the world shooting championships. The Soviets set world team marks for women's air rifle and men's free pistol shooting. They won both individual and team gold medals for the air rifle and free pistol events. The other gold medals went to Poland in the men's individual air rifle and to West Germany in the men's team air rifle.

title: Fight Reset for Oct. 29, but Cut Still a Question Mark
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 20The postponed heavyweight championship boxing match between George Foreman, the champion, and Muhammad Ali will be held at 3 A.M. on Oct. 30, local time (10 P.M. on Oct. 29, New York time), according to Zaire officials and the promoters here.

title: India, Soviet UnionSplit Davis Cup Singles Matches
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Amritraj brothers split their singles matches today as India gained a 11 standoff with the Soviet Union on the opening day of their interzone Davis Cup tennis semifinal at Poona in western India.

title: Queen Ends Parliament; Britain In fiatIon Eases.
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters) Queen Elizabeth officially dissolved Palliament today after its shortest sitting of the century and freed politicians to campaign in the second general election of. the. year.

title: Books of The Times
description: INDIRA a biography of Prime Minister Gandht By Krishan Bhatia 290 pages. Praeger. $10.

title: The Men Who Will Control Mozambique: Their Aim Is More Than Black Power
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 20The Front for the Liberation of Mozambique, which is about to take control of this Portuguese colony in eastern Africa, is perhaps the most disciplined, effective and militant revolutionary organization in the short history of independent black Africa. It will almost surely bring great changes to Mozambique and may also cause serious shocks in whiteruled, southern Africa.

title: Dave Anderson
description: It's know as the Summer Game, so by the rites of the autumnal equinok it should have ended before today. But baseball is really just beginning now, Perhaps it should be known as the September Game because it's so much better when the games dwindle down to a precious few. It's criticized as too slow. But when a game is important, that same slowness adds to the drama, rather than detracting from it. The pause between pitches. The manipulations of the manager. In recent weeks the Yankees have kept New York alive and now even the Mets are indirectly in the pennant race: Beginning last night, the Mets play more than half their remaining games against the Pittsburgh Pirates, who are struggling with the St. Louis Cardinals for the National League East title. Meanwhile, the, Yankees, having slipped into second place behind the Baltimore Orioles in the American League East before last night's. doubleheader. with the Cleveland Indians, were put into a realistic. perspective by Bill Virdon, their realistic Manager.

title: Severed Twin Girls Visited by Mother
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP)  Siamese twin girls separated Wednesday in a rare operation were reported today to be doing extremely well.

title: Wanted: New Home for a MiniManhattan
description: Ten years have passed since Guy C. Miller packed away the stuff of a lifelong dream.

title: A 1.6% JUMP HERE
description: Consumer prices in the New. YorkNew Jersey area rose per cent in August, the sharpest onemonth rise recorded in the nation and the steepest increase here in a year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: T. S. Reece, 65, ExHead Of Continental Trailways
description: DALLAS, Sept. 20 (AP)T.S. Reece, president of Continental Trailways from 1966 until his retirement last June, died here today after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Bosco Shot Because I Was Going to Die
description: Police Officer Frank Bosco yesterday emotionally recount ed his fatal shooting of a 14yearold black youth in Brook lyn last Sunday night. I didn't shoot him because he was black, I shot him because was going to die, he said.

title: BELMONT REPORTS 4 DRUGGING CASES
description: Four horses saddled by different trainers were drugged in recent races at Belmont Park, and racing investigators are known to be looking for a suspected fixer.

title: CRUDE 010 COST COULD RISE BYO',
ATLANTIC FLIGHTS TO BE CONDENSED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) The United States and Britain have agreed to cut aircraft seat capacity on transAtlantic flights by 20 per cent in an attempt to avert bankruptcies among United States airlines, particularly Pan American World Airways, it was announced today.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND COUNTER RISE.
O.A.S. Votesto Review Cuba Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Permanent Council of the Organization of American States voted unanimously today to review the economic and political sanctions imposed 10 years ago against Cuba.

title: Untimely Fish Bill
description: The S'enate Foreign Relations Committee has presented an adverse report on a proposal to extend United States jurisdiction over coastal fishing to two hundred miles flagrant violation of existing international law. The Senate would do well to abide by this committee's deci. sion rather than that of the Commerce Committee, which has given the bill its support.

title: Chief Justice Injured While Riding a Bicycle
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 20 (AP)  Warren E. Burger Chief Justice of the United States received facial scrapes and a possible broken finger today when he lost control of a bicycle he was riding near his home in this Washington suburb, the police rereported.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Buyer Held in $1Million Theft

title: U.S. Loan for Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The United States has agreed to load Bangladesh $25million to help her buy essential imports. The agreement was signed yesterday by the United States Ambassador, Davis Boster, and the Bangladesh Planning Commission secretary, Syed Uzzaman.

title: Suits Foil Effort to Curb Oral Drugs in Diabetes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Food and Drug Administration's efforts to discourage overuse of controversial drugs for diabetics have been frustrated for years by lawsuits, despite a major study that cast serious doubt on the drugs safety and efficacy, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs testified today.

title: 50,000 Argentine Workers Stage Rally in Support for Mrs. Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20About 50,000 Argentine trade unionists rallied today to give President Isabel Martinez de Peron a sorely needed political lift in the face of terrorism and labor discontent that are shaking her Government.

title: Erving's Knees Pass First Court Test
description: FARIVIINGDA LE, LI., Sept. 20Julius Erving's milliondollar, tender knees were back on the basketball court today.

title: BERN REPORTS 4 DRUGGING CASES
description: Four horses saddled by different trainers were drugged in recent races at Belmont Park, and racing investigators are known to be looking for a suspected fixer.

title: Grimsley, Jackson Pitch Orioles Past Red Sox, 21
description: With 48,924 fans cheering against them27,287 in Fenway Park and the rest in Shea Stadium in New Yorkthe Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox anyway last night in their mad race with the Yankees for the American League East title.

title: Sales of Mutual Funds Outpace August Cashins
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (Reuters)Sales of mutual funds exceeded redemptions by $127.4million in August, largely on the strength of continued investor interest in specialized money market funds, the Investment Company Institute reported.

title: Market Adviser Dies in Plunge; Linked to Gold Stocks Decline
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 21 (AP)The body of an Indianapolis investment adviser linked to a financial storm among mining stocks two weeks ago was found today at the base'of the highrise apartment building in which he lived.

title: Hearing on Texans Move Delayed
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)A state district court judger set a hearing today for Monday to determine whether to continue a temporary restraining order preventing the Houston Texans from moving to their new home of Shreve, port, La., before next week's game against Memphis. Judge Arthur Lesher Said attorneys for the.World Football League and L. A. Frey and Company met most of the day without reaching an agreement, so he reset ,Tuesday's scheduled; hearing to Monday.

title: A Feeling That Women Are Finally Making
description: They swapped business cards over Scotch, closed deals during dinner, and, after coffee, one or two of the women casually smoked cigars.

title: More Welfare Funding Urged At Inflation Meeting in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The bulk of the participants in the latest antiinflation conference here, today said programs for the poor had deteriorated., and called for, increased fund.ing with tax increases based on ability, to pay.

title: High Costs of Transport Tied to U.S. Regulations
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20Governmental restrictions were cited today by many speakers at the antiinflation conference here as the major obstacle in combating inflation hi the transportation industries.

title: Antiques: Hooked Rugs
description: Hooked rugs those fuzzy fabric pictures of Staffordshirelike cocker spanielS, flowers in pots, Biblical lions and scenes of rural America, have, at long last, been resurrected from collectors attics and museum storerooms for a major exhibition.

title: POLICE SAVE Ma AND ARREST HIM
description: A police emergency unit brought a 29yearold man down from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon, after he threatened to jumpreportedly for the third time this month. This time he was arrested and the police said that would prevent him from walking out of a hospital where he was expected to be taken for observation.

title: FORD'S SON TARDY IN DRAFT REGISTR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Like hundreds of other young men in the country, Steven Ford, the President's youngest son, has technically violated the law by failing to register with his local draft board on time

title: Contract Awards
description: Two contracts totaling $17million for shopfabricated power piping by the Commonwealth Edison Company and the FosterWheeler Corporation have been awarded to the Benjamin F. Shaw Company, Wilmington, Del.

title: Vietnam Outlook: Still a Tunnel, Still a Light
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam There is a new version of the old light at the end of the tunnel in. Vietnam.

title: Throwing Lapses, Wildness Thwart Sadecki Effort
Okonite Loan Extended
description: OmegaAlpha, Inc., of Dallas announced yesterday that its wholly owned subsidiary, the Okonite Company, had gotten an extension of its $17million bank loan with a group of banks headed by the Bank of America. Okonite, with headquarters in Ramsey, N. J., is a major manufacturer of electrical wire and cable with seven plants in New Jersey, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Kentucky and California.

title: Nixon Scheduled to Enter Coast Hospital on Monday
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to enter Memorial Hospital Medical Center of Long Beach in California next Monday morning for tests and treatment of the phlebitis condition that has caused painful swelling in his left leg, according to an official of the hospital.

title: DRUG SELLER GETS LIGHTER SENTENCE
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 20A Rochester man who could have been given life imprisonment after pleading guilty to charges of, selling heroin to a policeman was sentenced today to three to six years in the State Correctional Institution at Attica. The sentence was imposed by Judge Andrew C. Celli of Monroe t County, who last month called the mandatory sentencing provision of the da;g.ir.w unconstitutional.

title: Court Budgets Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The Judicial Conference, the panel of judges that adminishas approved budget estimates for the Federal court system of more than $300million for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1976, a spokesman said today.

title: MARKET PRICES MIXED AT CLOSE; Dow Index Is Down 3.29, but Advances Outnumber Declines by 9 to 5
Cracking The Nixon Health Case
description: He is a big blond guy who looks like he might have played some football in college and he is sitting there in the office when I get back from being beaten up in The Case of the Dissonant Tango,

title: Hurricane's Toll 1,300 in Honduras; Thousands Missing
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Saturday, Sept. 21The Honduran National Emergency Committee yesterday reported 1,336 people dead and more than 4,200 missing in floods caused by Hurricane Fifi, which poured torrential rains on four other CentralAmerican nations.

title: A 1.6% JUMP HERE
description: Consumer prices in the New YorkNew Jersey area rose 1.6 per cent in August, the sharpest onemonth rise recorded in the nation and the steepest increase here in a year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: TV Review
description: The 197475 season, continued and concluded (for the time being). The following new series are opening this weekend:

title: Woodson Is Considered For Civil Service Chief
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20Assembly Speaker S. Howard Woodson is being seriously considered by Governor Byrne as his nominee for president of the state. Civil Service Commission, informed sources reported here today.

title: Bridge: How Different Lines of Play  Lead to Different Squeezes
description: Connoisseurs of squeezes have often noted that they have a protean quality: different lines of play by the declarer or the defense will often lead to a different squeeze ending. A striking example of this is the diagramed deal reported by Charles Pollack of New York from a Reisinger Knockout Team match last May.

title: G.E. LEAVING EXXON ON URANIUM STUDY
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from a joint study of the uranium enrichment business with the Exxon Nuclear Company, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation. The study had been announced by the two companies in July, 1973, and the initial oneyear evaluation phase had been extended earlier this year.

title: CITIBANK OFFERS 4YEAR AUTO LOAN
description: The first fouryear auto loan to be offered by a major New York bank was introduced here yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: The Chicago Bulls were surpiised but pleased to,have Bob, Love, their allstar forward report to their training camp in, suburban Wheaton College Thursday night for his.eighth'seasim In the National Baikotball Association. There had been rumors that he might hold out, as he did last season, in an effort to renegotiate his fiveyear. contracta practice that Dick Motta, the Bulls', coach and player personnel director, has refused to consider.

title: TROY IS REMOVED AS QUEENS LEADER IN DRIVE BYNAME
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. was ousted as Queens Democratic leader yesterday in move led by Mayor Beame and by Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: City Hall Park Gets A Preview of Parade
description: A halfdozen bands and choral groups from cities in West Germany filled City Hall Park with music for two hours at midday yesterday in a preview of today's Steuben Parade up Fifth Avenue.

title: Seniors Golf Title Won by Billows
U.S. Begins Roundup of Wild Horses in West as Their Population Grows
description: SWAMP CREEK FIELD, Ore.The dawn came about A.M., first pink, then blazing yellow bands of light that Slowly dimmed the stars. Then came the pale blue cloudless sky that stretches for so many hundreds of miles over this rugged southeastern section of Oregon.

title: Bosco Shot Because I Was Poing to Die
description: Police Officer Frank Bosco yesterday emotionally recounted his fatal shooting of a 14yearold black youth in Brooklyn last Sunday night. I didn't shoot him because he was black, I shot him because was going to die, he said.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SEPTEMBERFEST It was first a few year ago that a new group ca,,ed Aware, New York, was founded here to promote the idea that residents of this frequently tempestuous community have a lot more in common than in conflict. It started off with fundraising concerts and benefits of varying kinds and has now reached the point where it has won endorsernent from top city officials.

title: Art: Ilya Bolotowsky Has a Real Radiance
EDWARD J. HUNT
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 20 Edward J. Hunt, superintendent of recreation and member of the Board of Recreation here for 48 years, died yesterday at St. Joseph Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 44 Sterling Place.

title: Giants Reed Happy in Defense Role
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 20When Henry Reed first learned of the plans for him to play the 53 linebacker in the New York Giants defense this year he was unimpressed.

title: DR. ISADORE ROSEN
description: Dr. Isadore Rosen, chief of I dermatology at Mount Sinai Hospital from 1929 to 1946, idled there Thursday at the age of 93. He lived at 784 Park Avenue.

title: New Jersey. Sports
description: WAYNEThe new varsity swimming coach at William Paterson College will be drawing upon her own long and illustrious swimming career as she tries to build a compel,. itive team.

title: P.B.A. Says Laundry Crew at Ancora Includes Murderers and Drug Pushers
description: MILLVILLE, Sept. 20A state plan to house Leesburg Prison inmates at the Ancora Psychiatric Hospital where they work on the laundry detail was attacked here today by a spokesman for prison correction officers, who charged that many of the laundry workers were murderers, rapists, sex violators

title: BURNS SAYS DROP IN INTEREST RATE EASES TENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, called encouraging today the recent decline in shortterm interest rates and said tensions in the nation's financial markets have been reduced to some degree in recent weeks.

title: Despite Protests, WNCN Proceeds With Change
description: While lawyers for at least two citizens groups have prepared petitions asking the Federal Communications Commission to preserve classical music programing by WNCN, the station's owner is mounting a splashy promotion campaign to introduce on Oct 5 an entirely new station to succeed WNCN at 104.3 on the FM band.

title: Capital Policewoman Is Slain on Duty
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A young policewoman, a member of the District of Columbia police force for less than a year, was shot and killed by a suspect she was pursuing at a garage entrance in downtown Washington today. Federal authorities said it was the first recorded death of a policewoman in the line of duty in the United States.

title: SINGING DEBUT MADE BY ROBERT KEENEY
description: Despite the formidable odds against those who hope to put together a combination of voice, singing skill, interpretive ability and charisma that will make them winners in The professional music world, there is never an end to aspirants in all stages of preparation.

title: New Florida State Coach Takes A Few Cheers to the Press Box
description: Darrell Mudra, Florida State's new head football coach, has a doctorate in education and a belief in a more democratic and less authoritarian approach to coaching football.

title: New Jovian Moon
description: A California astronomer is believed to have discovered a new and 13th moon of Jupiter. Page 32.

title: Shutout by GuruMurcer's Triple Wins Opener
CNA BARRING FUNDS FOR LARIVIN GROUP
description: The board of directors of the CNA Finincial Corporation announced yesterday in Chicago thatqt would not provide any further financial support to the arwin Group, Inc., its homebuilding subsidiaiy.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES PODELL GOT A FEE
description: A key witness testified yesterclap, that his brother's cornpany had paid $10,000 to Representative Bertram L. Podell of Brooklyn for legal services involving the Civil Aeronautics Board as well as the Bahamian Government:

title: ATTEMPT TO OUST CUNNINGHAM FAILS
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader whose control of the county organization is among the state's firmest, has overwhelmed a drive by party independents to loosen his grip.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Susan and Robert Dunlap don't have too much of a supply problem for the cozy mufflers and stoles handwoven of natural colored wool they turn out: They have their own flock of 50 sheep on their salt water farm on Mount Desert Island in Maine.

title: Application Filed to Build An Oil Refinery in Matti:
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 20The New England Energy Conpany filed an application today with the Maine Department at Environmental Protection to construct a 250,000barrekt day oil refinery in Sanford.

title: Ford Aides Split Sharply on Food and Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20President Ford's speech at the United Nations Wednesday, linking the world's food and energy problems, represented a compromise of sharp differences within the Administration.

title: Unspent U. S. Highway Money Piling Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20At a time when many Government agencies are asking for ever higher levels of funding, unspent money for federally aided highway projects is piling up at the rate of $1.7billion a year and is scheduled to reach a total of about $6billion next year.

title: Ford and Gromyko Join in Vowing Continuing Efforts for Middle East Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20President Ford and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met for the first time today and later issued a statement that they had agreed on the importance of the continuing efforts for lasting and equitable peace in the Middle East.

title: People in Sports
description: The Chicago Bulls were surprised but pleased to have Bob Love, their allstar forward, report to their training camp in suburban Wheaton College Thursday night for his eighth season in the National Basketball Association. There had been rumors that he might hold out, as he did last season, in an effort to renegotiate his fiveyear contracta practice that Dick Motta, the Bulls coach and player personnel director, has refused to consider.

title: Business Bankruptcies Show Increase in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 20 (Reuters) The administrative office of the United States courts said today that business bankruptcies of all kinds are on the rise.

title: Miss Casals Upset In Slims Tourney
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP)Martina Navratilova stunned secondseeded Rosemary Casals in three sets today, advancing to the semifinals of the $50,000 Orlando Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: EDWARD E. CARR
description: Edward E. Carr, chief meteorologist of R. Dixon Speas Associates, an aviation consulting and planning concern, died yesterday. He was 50 years old and lived at 14 Hewlett Lane, Great Neck, L. I.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street Flushing Meadow, Queens P.M.

title: Water Emergency Ends
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 20 (UPI)  A twoday water emergency declared after a water main break here was called off early today by Mayor Fred L. Ashton.

title: Hundreds Are Dead In Honduras Storm
description: GUATEMALA, Sept. 20 Hundreds of bodies were found floating in receding waters in the northern Honduran town of Choloma, and the police there estimate that 4,000 villagers may have been killed in floods caused by hurricane Fifi, the Honduran National Emergency Committee said today.

title: Water Emergency Ends.
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 20 (UPI)  A twoday water emergency declared after a water main break here was called off early today by Mayor Fred L. Ashton:

title: Jeweler Is Convicted In Conspiracy to Buy Stolen Antique.Gems
description: NEWARK, Sept. 20 (UPI)A Federal jury today convicted a Tampa, Fla., jeweler on conspiracy charges related to the purchae of $10,000, in stolen antique jewelry and coins that two of his codefendants withheld from their employer.

title: U.S. and 11 Others Detail OilPool Plan
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20Representatives from 12 oilconsuming nations including the United States agreed here tonight on the details of a plan under which countries affected by oilproducers embargoes would receive supplies from a common pool when their oil imports dropped by more than 7 per cent.

title: U.S. SEEKS FLOOR FOR MILK PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Agricultural Department proposed today a new minimum farm price for milk that could amount to as much as two cents a quart more than recent returns to dairymeb.

title: Sovier Shifts Policy Aythorizes Show of Nonconformist Art
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20Soviet authorities, who encountered protests abroad after the forceful disruption of an unofficial outdoor art show last Sunday, reversed themselves today and told a group of nonconformist artists that they could hold another show in eight days.

title: College Football at a Glance
Opera: Bellini Beauty
description: Bellini's I Puritani is pretty thin soup, dramatically speaking. Every now and then when something happens to confuse her the heroine goes. mad and sings a snappy polanaise or other florid show stopper, but magically recovers her senses in time to take part in a love duet. This is one of those works from the bel canto era that were intended to please the ear, no more.

title: TROY IS REMOVED AS QUEENS LEADER IN DRIVE BY BEANIE
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. was ousted as Queens Democratic leader yesterday in move led by Mayor Beame and by Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: Nixon Scheduled to Enter Coast Hospital on Monday
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to enter Memorial Hospital Medical Center of Long Beach in California next Monday morning for tests and treatment of the phlebitis condition that has caused painful swelling in his left leg, according to an official of the hospital.

title: Harry Wolfson, 86, Philosopher Of Religion at Harvard, Is Dead
description: Prof. Harry Austryn Wolfson, philosopher and one of the world's leading scholars on comparative religion, died Thursday at Harvard University's Stillman Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal is the unanimous choice of the executive council of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Orangization to become next director general. If endorsed by the agency's general membership this fall, he will become the first black African to head a specialized agency of the United Nations.

title: Kissinger Chile Briefings Said to Omit Mention of C.I.A. Link to Labor Unrest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Secretary of State KisSinger did not mention any Central Intelligence Agency involvement with labor unions and trade groups in. Chile when he briefed Congressional leaders and the Ford Cabinet in separate meetings this week, reliable Administration, and.Congressional sources said today.

title: Extortionist Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UPI) Nile D. Marx, convicted last August of trying to extort $100,000 from Patricia Hearst's parents, was sentenced today to from five years to life in prison.

title: SWINDLER IS GIVE! UP TO FIVE YEAR
description: Robert Tomarkin, a forme investment banker who swindled about $600,000 fron the financially troubled Frank lin National Bank, was sen tenced to up to five years it prison yesterday by a State Su preme Court Justice.

title: Savings Units Push Exemption In Taxon First $1,000 of Intetest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Savings and loan bankers, anxious to dam this summer massive loss of deposits, are pushilig the drive for Federal income tax exemption on the first $1,000 in interest paid on a depositor's savings account.',

title: Wilson's Camp Labels. Carey Ultraliberal and Hysterical
description: The Wilson campaign characterized Representative Hugh L. Carey as ultraliberal yesterday, denouncing the Democrat as hysterical Hugh and accusing him of appealing to the emotions and prejudices of voters.

title: Soviet Lofts 8 Satellites
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has put eight artificial earth satellites into orbit with a single carrier rocket, the Tass press agency reported today.

title: Scottish Bank Founders
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Another British bank foundered today and the Government bailed out RollsRoyce but refused to help Aston Martin, maker of luxury cars.

title: Ethiopia Pledges to Respect Foreign Property
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept, 20 (Agence FrancePresse) Ethiopia's provisional military government pledged today that it would not nationalize foreign property or investments, but it said the aristocracy would have to give its money back to the people.

title: Assembly's Democratic Leaders Offer ThreePoint Plan to Finance SchoolF.
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20The Assembly's Democratic leadership today announced a threepoint program to restructure the fi nancing of New Jersey's public schools before the courtimposed deadline of next Dec. 31 for such a plan.

title: Desert Vixen Favored in Beldame Today
Barber Leads by Stroke On 68136 in Ohio Golf
Image Converter Draws Camera Makers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20An invention that is already attracting attention  among camera manufacturers was patented this week by two members of the Syracuse University faculty. It is a very simPatents pie method of converting an optical image  or Week some aspect of that itTlage  to electronic signals.

title: METERING BY UTILITIES HIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Installation of electricity and gas meters in individual apartments in place of mass metering for entire buildings would cause tenants to conserve energy, an electric utility conference was told today.

title: More Freehold Students Join Boycott of :Classes
description: FREEHOLD, Sept., 20 (UPI)The rate of absenteeism in the Freehold Regional High School District rose today as more students joined a boycott of classes to protest the termination of athletic and extracurricular activities in the district.

title: SUSPENSION ASKED FOR 2 PESTICIDES
description: An administrative law judge recommended yesterday that the Environmental Protection Agency suspend all further manufacture of two widely used pesticides, aldrin and dieldrin because the judge said, they pose an unacceptable cancer risk to man.

title: 2 Indicted for Bomb Threat
description: FRESNO, Calit., Sept. 20 (AP)  Two young men have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here for threatening to blow up Castel Mr Force Base. Airman Gary Ray. Garza, 19 years old, and James Michael Knowlton, 18, of Atwater, were indicted yesterday.

title: A.E.C. Files a Suit Against Con Edison Seeking $1.7Million
description: The Atomic Energy Commission has filed a civil action against the Consolidated. Edison Company seeking $1.7million, plus interest and costs, for electricity it supplied the utility in 1970.

title: Businessman Sentenced
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (UPI)Ronald F. Calvert, a 39yearold businessman, was sentenced today to 45 years in prison for his part in the conspiracy to kill Victor G. Null, a heavily insured inventor, and on 12 counts of mail and wire fraud. Mr. Null, 34, was found shot to death Nov. 9, 1972, in his East St. Louis, Ill., officeworkshop, where he had been working on a pollutionfree rotary engine.

title: SYREETA'S SINGING HAS SOPHISTICATION
description: Stevje Wonder's name is invoked over and over again at the Bottom Line, West Fourth Street, where Syreeta, a young singer, made her New York debut on Thusrday. The reasons are valid: Syreeta Wright is the former wife of the rock artist and is also a songwriting collaborator. Much of her performance was given over to singing the songs that she and Mr. Wonder composed, all quietly soulful, making. no major philosophical points but emerging as entertaining enough.

title: HOMICIDAL ESCAPEE IS. HUNTED IN STATE
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 20 (UPI)A search was under way throughout western New York today for a man, described by the po. lice as homicidal and extremely dangerous, who walked out of the Buffalo psychiatric center Tuesday.

Hill Samuel in Glasgow
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  The Hill Samuel Group i: opening a new office in Glas cow on. Oct. 24. The ne% office will provide Scottish companies with a wide rang( of investment banking services including loan and deposit facilities, a statement said.

title: A Media Approach to Inflation
description: TORONTOUntil now there have been many equilibrium theories Of inflation. I am going to propose a disequilibrium theory based on the discontinuous nature of the electric information of today.

title: Kept in Dark on Spy Case, Brandt Tells Investigators
description: BONN, Sept. 20  Former Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that the Government's: security agencies left him in the dark for nine months after he was informed that an aide, Gtin'ter Guillaume; was suspected of being a spy for East Germany.

title: Ford Invites SchueIler Band
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) President and Mrs. Ford have invited Gunther Schueller and his New England Conservatory Ragtime Ensemble to entertain at a White House dinner Wednesday night honoring President Giovanni Leone of Italy. Mr. Schueller's.ensemble recorded the Grammy Award winner Scott Joplin, the Redback Book.

title: PEARL HALPERN
description: Pearl Halpern, who served from 1950 to 1965 as president of. Dress Makers Local 22, In,ternational Ladies Garment Workers Union, died yesterday at: the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in the Bronx. She was 90 years old and lived at 330 West 28th Street.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Is at Disadvantage As 3d Game Is Adjourned
Man Gets Degree Without a Credit
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20Nicholas France wanted a college degree, but he didn't want to go to college. Yesterday, at an impressive graduation ceremony here, the State University of New York let him have his cake and eat it too; he became the first person in the country to receive a bachelor's degree without a single college credit.

title: Building of Battery Park City Finally Starts
description: After eight years of planning and controversy and replanning and more controversy, ground was finally broken yesterdayso to speakfor the first of 16,000 apartments scheduled to rise in Battery Park City, the vast development on a milelong strip of Hudson River landfill in Lower Manhattan.

description: Attorney General William B. Saxbe has announced Justice Department study of the Wounded Knee trial and other cases in which the defendants have asserted that their prosecutions were politically based. One major focus of that study should be the Federal Bureau Investigation.

description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 20 (UPI) Edwin Newman, an NBCTV newsman, said today, now that Ronald H. Nessen had left his post at NBC to become President Ford's press secretary, it ought to be understood by everyone that he's on the other side.

title: JAMES DAVIS DEAD; ABSTRACT ARTIST, 73
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 James Edward Davis, an artlist, teacher and experimental film producer, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

title: Jaworski Asks U.S. Court For Nixon Medical Check
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, suggested today that the United States District Court send a team of physicians to San Clemente, Calif., to determine how ill former President Richard M. Nixon might be.

description: Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania proposed yesterday national rail trust fund to channel $12.9billion into the nation's railroads over a sixyear period.

title: Larry Woods Adds Beef to Jets '
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.L, Sept. 20 His teammates call him Grady  after the Sanford and Son television character "because I have a beard and they say I talk slow, but the Jets call Larry Woods part of the Solution to their longtime defensiveline problem.

RESTAURATEUR, 64:, SLAIN IN ROBBERY
description: A 64year.old restaurat cur was, robbed and fatally stabbed on the Upper West Side early yesterday as he was on his way home with his wife.

title: $10 Million Marijuana Is Seized in Arizona
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP)United States customs agents seized nearly 19 tons of marijuana today at Nogales, Ariz., believed to be the biggest single seizure ever made in the United States, Customs Commissioner Vernon D. Acree announced here.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Benefits Upheld in Migrant's Death

title: Saudi Official Emphasizes Efforts to Reduce Oil Costs
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yemeni, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Oil and Minerals, insisted yesterday that his country was the chief friend of the oilconsuming nations although his Government has raised the price it charges the major foreign oil companies for its crude.

title: JOSEPH LUSTGARTEN
description: Joseph Lustgarten, a retired industrial psychologist, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at the Park Royal Hotel, 23 West 73d Street.

title: CHINA SAID TO NAME MAO DEFENSE HEAD
description: TOKYO, Sept. 20 (Reuters)Mao Tsetung is named head of state and commander of the armed forces in what was described in a newspaper here today as the draft of a new Chinese Constitution.

title: Black Leaders Are Installed in Mozambique and Call for Changes
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 20An interim Government, dominated by the liberation front that for 10 years had waged a war for independence, was installed in this Portuguese colony in East Africa today.

title: Union Backs 15 for House
description: McAFEE, Sept. 20 (AP)The New Jersey American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations has endorsed 14 Democrats and one Republican in Congressional races this fall and announced a campaign to register 100,000 new. voters. The endorsements were made as a threeday executive board meeting here ended.

title: Inflation Parley. Hears of Hospital Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20New cost of living data presented to an Administration antiinflation conference here today showed enormous recent increases in health care costs, which point to bills of $200aday for hospital rooms for New Yorkers shortly.

title: New Press Secretary Ronald Harold Nessen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20In early 1970, the name of Ron Nessen, a National Broadcasting Company correspondent covering urban affairs in Washington, was submitted to the White House for Man appointment as in the public affairs diNews rector for the Food and Drug Administration. The Nixon White House refused to approve the appointment, without an explanation to the F.D. A

title: Beleaguered Pan Am
description: President Ford has made the right decision in rejecting Pan American World Airways request for a direct Federal subsidy of $10.2 million a month, or about $125million a year. Although the subsidy was sought as an emergency measure, it could well have slid into permanenceas have subsidies to the maritime industry.

title: Sawhill Sees Gas Ample, Coal a Potential Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill said today that the gasoline supply was so abundant in the United States now that price wars had broken out among service stations in a number of cities.

title: People and Business
description: The Tennesse Valley Authority power system today faces one of the most critical periods in its history because of the short supply and rising cost of coal, Aubrey J. Wagner, the authority's chairman, said yesterday in Memphis.

title: White House Says Nixon Obtains Regular Briefings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Although it is 42 days since resigned the Presidency in the; face of virtually certain impeachment, Richard M. Nixon remains an almost.tangible presence in the daily affairs of President Ford's White House.

title: Britain's Rate of Inflation Shows Only Small Increase
description: LONDON, Sept. 20The British Government reported to day that the rate of inflation, a major issue in the current national election campaign, showed the smallest monthly increase in August in three years.

title: Bar Chiefs Oppose Pretrial Pardoning In W atergate Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The American Bar Association called on President Ford today not to issue any more Federal parlons)before criminal defendants have been tried and convicted, except under extraordinary circumstances.

title: Terry Waldo, Pianist, Brings Ragtime to the Village Corner
description: In a year when the Academy Award went to a film score based on piano rags by Scott Joplin and when the New England Conservatory Ragtime Ensemble is one of the hotter attractions on the concert cir ult, it is not surprising that someone has finally had the notion of putting ragtime into a New York nightclub.

title: YOUTHS MOURNING THEIR SLAIN FRIEND
description: Friends and relatives of Claude Reese Jr. huddled yesterday around the dingy fourstory walkup tenement where the slain 14yearold and his family lived, and they spoke with remorse about the fate of a youth who could find something to laugh about and make others laugh. For, in Brownsville, overwhelming blight and filth offer little to feel good about.

title: Business Briefs
description: Dollar Gains as Gold Slips Abroad

title: H.E.W. vs. Inflation
description: Delegates to the antiinflation conference convened by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare have shown by their skeptical and even angry response that they are too sophisticated to become party to an academic shell game. When Alan Greenspan, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told the representatives of the poor, the elderly and the handicapped that Wall Street brokers have percentagewise been hardest hit by inflation, he only dramatized the Administration's basic misperceptions. Even without this gaffe, it was clear that the meeting would have rejected Mr. Greenspan's unfeeling effort to sell the idea that cutting Federal support of social welfare programs is a requisite in the war against Inflation.

title: ROBERT W. YOUNG,87, EXHEAD OF 3M, DIES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 20 Robert Winthrop Young, retired chairman of the board of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing International Company, now known as the 3M Company of St. Paul, died yesterday at his home on Bayberry Lane. He was 87 years old.

title: Wanted New Home for a MiniManhattap
description: Ten years have passed since Guy C. Miller packed away the stuff of a lifelong dream.

title: Art: Social History of a Century
description: The art of painting is no longer very much concerned to tell a story nor is it very much burdened with the obligation to document the passing social scene. Yet both the narrative and the documentary functions of painting have a venerable history and they have by no means lost their power to inform and entertain even today.

title: CourtNamed Counsel Backed For DraftEvasion Cases Here
description: Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein ruled yesterday that his court could appoint legal counsel for fugitives who have been indicted for violations of the Selective Service

title: Europe Sets a Rise In Farm Supports
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20 After three days of talks in Brussels, the Agricultural Ministers of the Nine Common Market countries decided at 5:30 A.M. today to raise European Economy Community support prices for all farm products 5 per cent effective Oct. 1.

title: FOOD IS UP AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Consumer Price Index rose 1.3 per cent in August, the largest monthly increase since 1947 except for times when price freezes had just been lifted.

title: 3dParty Nominee Fishes for Votes
description: Jerry Tuccille, a small fish in a big pond as the Free Libertarian candidate for Governor, went fishing for votes yesterday on the site where Chester A. Arthur, the President believed by some people to have done better at fishing than at governing the country, was sworn in 93 years ago.

title: Hospital Union Organizing Spurred by Change in Law
description: Since amendments to the National Labor Relations Act became effective nearly four weeks ago, half a dozen unions have been seeking to represent 50,000 hospital employes in northern New Jersey who, for the first time, are covered by the act, which no longer excludes workers in nonprofit hospitals.

title: SUGAR FUTURES INCREASE IC LIMIT
description: World sugar futures jumped the penny a pound limit yesterday in the three nearest deliveries, following some earlymorning selling.

title: MICHAEL BRICK, 2, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Michael Brick, chairman of the department of higher and adult education at Teachers College, Columbia University, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived at 520 West 122d Street.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ford Will Visit South Korea On Way Home From Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) President Ford will visit South Korea Nov. 22 and 23 following his trip to Japan, the White House announced today.

title: Zenith Suing Japanese
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Zenith Radio Corp of Chicago announced today that it has filed suit in Philadelphia against major Japanese television an& electronic products manufacturers and their Japanese and American subsidiaries and affiliates, including Motorola Inc., charging them with violations of United States antitrust laws and the antidumping act of 1916.

title: Court Study to Co On
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) President Ford signed legislation today to give a special 16member panel nine more months and more than twice as much money to complete study of the Federal appellate Court, system.

title: RAMAPO COLLEGE OPENS A BUILDING
description: MAHWAH, Sept. 20Ramapo College, the state college founded in 1971'oday dedicated Its new fourstory, $5.5million science building with nearly 200 faculty members and guests watching from the newly seeded lawn in front of the building.

title: D.A. Pleads Guilty To Beating Women In Bondage Survey
description: WELLSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 20 (UPI)Allegany County District Attorney John. D'Arcy today pleaded guilty to five counts of an indictment charging him with tying up women and, in some cases, whipping thOm after saying he was conducting an official survey on hondage.

title: Ordinary working stiff
description: For the first time since the thirties, a surge of literary interest in the ordinary working stiff again seems in the making. True to the waning of fiction perhaps, this new found concern with the invisible working man has passed from novelists like Steinbeck and James T. Farrell to journalists like Studs Turkel and sociologists like Daniel Yankelovich. Both are busily sun, veying an upsurge of blue collar discontent  a modern discontent  inflamed not by unionbusters and breadlines but by a stubborn, ominous inflation coupled with the challenges and expectations of the longhaired young workers now pouring into the factories.

title: PARLEY STRESSES INFLATION IMPACT
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21Transportation leaders will urge at President Ford's conference on inflation next week that an inflationary impact statement be required before the Goyernment embarks on any major new projects.

title: Is it time to disengage?; The Korean Connection
description: Once again, the United States finds itself in the role of the pitiful, helpless giant, the unhappy hostage of a small foreign land. Once again, the country is trapped by its own antiquated policy. Here it is carrying on a vast program of military aidincluding the current commitment of 38,000 American troopsto provide an ally with protection from the spread of Communist totalitarianism when the ally itself has turned into a distasteful police state. Is it not time, then, to rethink the policy that led us to this circumstance? Or, are there still, in spite of everything, compelling reasons,

title: Colson Begins Serving Term At U.S. Prison in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 21 (UPI)Charles W. Colson, former White House special counsel who pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice in the Daniel Ellsberg case, has started serving his onetothreeyear sentence at the Maxwell Air Force Base Federal prison here.

title: Huntington Youth Wins Nassau CrossCountry Race
The World In Summary
description: President Ford went to the United Nations last week to call on the nations of the world to join in a global strategy for food and energy, but the only applause to interrupt his speech came in response to a passage praising Secretary of State Kissinger.

description: TRENTONAfter several weeks of study, the Senate Committee on Law, Public Safety and Defense has unanimously accepted State Attorney General William F. Hyland's report dealing with State Police tactics in South Jersey.

title: $44.80 Chance Scores
description: SALEM,N.H.,Sept.21(AP) Double Theory rallied in the stretch to win the $10,000. Rocking. Horse Juvenile Stakes by four lengths today before a crowd of 7,621at Rockingham Park. The winner covered the six furlongs in 1:11 4/5 and paid $44.80, $8.20 and $5.80 for $2 the board.

title: MetsTop Pirates,42,on Homer
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21The Pirates hopes of taking progress in their pursuit of the National League East crown ran into a detour this afternoon. Checking Pittsburgh's momentum was Jerry Koosman, who pitched a sixhitter in gaining a 4to2 triumph.

Iris Murdoch's novel about one man and two women
