description: HUNTINGTONThe. exhibition of Art Deco, which opens at the Heckscher Museum today, is, another reminder of the grip that nostalgia has on the art world today. It seems only yesterday that Art Nouveau was being removed from dusty attics and cellars and presented to the public with a fresh shine.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Seven million Japanese have taken up golf, and many of them are swinging away with clubs made in the United States.

title: Great Green Covers to Grow Over the Ground
description: GROUNDCOVERS come in a variety of stimulating options, both evergreen and deciduous, having showy flowers, interesting textures, and fall fruit. You need not always rely, however, on the Big Four. ivy, pachysandra, myrtle and grass to resolve problems and create visual excitement.

title: U.S. Crop Losses Dim Prospect For Large World Food Program
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Secretary of State Kissing) faces the awesome task at. ti United Nations on Monday detailing United States plat for food aid to a world Which few truths that he ca provide are likely to be pale able.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Probably all their bonus money has been spent by the New York Knicks who won the 1973 and 1970 National Basketball Association titles. But all N.B.A. players make good money. The difference between solvency and stature is a championship ring. It's not for sale in a jewelry store. It must be won. The ring those Knicks wear is big and round and gold with a small Sports diamond in the shape of a basketball. But of many of those with The Tinsel the ring suddenly aren't Knicks anymore. Willis Reed has joined Dave DeBusschere and Jerry Lucas in retirement. Dean Meminger was lost in the expansion draft. Only four Knicks remain who contributed significantly to the 1973 titleWalt Frazier, Bill Bradley, Earl Monroe and Phil Jackson. Realise tically, those four doubt that the current Knicks can earn another champion ship ringunless.

title: HIGHLIGHTSOF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX rose to 150.2 (1967=100) in August, a gain of 1.3 per cent from the July level and 11.2 per cent higher than in August, 1973. . President Ford's inflation adviser, L. William Seidman, said the Administration would probably complete a plan within six weeks to curb inflation.... The United States basic balance of payments deficit widened to $2.7billion in the second quarter, the largest deficit since the third quarter of 1972.

title: Rutgers College Finally Gets First Sorority
description: NEW BRUNSWICK Twelve sophomores and juniors have established Rutgers College's first sorority, Delta Beta Psi.

title: Water Still an Issue In Dover Township
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP State, county and municipal agencies, aided by a privately owned water company, are cooperating to restore potable water to the Pleasant Plains section of this Ocean County township.

title: CONFLICT IS LAID TO RENT UNIT AIDE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 21A Westchester tenants organizetion charged today that one of the public, or impartial, members of the county's new rent guidelines board, Peter J. Toner, was closely aligned with, realestate interests.

title: INCHON RIDING OUT ITS RECORD TIDES
description: INCHON, South KoreaThe famed 30foot tides of Inchon have been tamed.

title: Ocean Grove Blue Laws Facing Their First Challenge in More Than a Century
description: OCEAN GROVEThe religious ordinances that regulate life in this Methodist community are being ,challenged for the first time in more than 100 years.

title: State Inquiry Sought on NaturalGas Rate Rises.
description: TRENTONA number of legislators have asked the State Attorney General to determine whether any irregularities allegedly committed by the Federal Power Commission involved public utility companies operating in New Jersey.

title: Warren Yields On Delinquents
description: MANSFIELD TOWNSHIP After six months of dickering, Warren County has acceded to state demands that the new juvenile center here be used for the detention of delinquents only. Warren authorities had wanted all juvenile cases to be treated at Warren Acres, as the tacility is known, but this would have been in violation of a recently enacted juvenile code.

title: Rains Bring Relief to SubSaharan Region
description: DAKORO, Niger, Sept. 15Fields of millet, taller than a man and heavy with ripening grain, surround the large camp of nomad herdsmen and their families who were driven to this southern region of Niger by last year's drought and famine.

title: Meminger Given Hawks Suspension
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 21 (AP)  Dean Meminger, Atlanta Hawks guard, has been suspended for failure to report to the team's training camp at Savannah.

title: Jennifer Smith Wed To Richard Huntley
description: Jennifer Anne Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm E. Smith Jr. of Nissequogue, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon in St. James, L. I., to Richard Kenneth Huntley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Huntley, also of Nissequogue. The ceremony was performed in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. McCrae Cobb.

title: Boat Racer Killed In Michigan Mishap
description: MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Sept. 21 (AP)One man was killed and another injured when a racing boat flipped over during a boat race on nearby Lake St. Clair today.

title: Teacher Groups Increase Election Campaign Outlay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The nation's teachers organizations have vastly increased the amount of money they are giving to political candidates this year and have become one of the.best financed special interest groups in the nation.

title: Germans Upset About TV Commercials
description: MAINZ, West Germany The soccer players in a re, cent game between Hamburg and Frankfurt took to the field in jerseys with advertisements for Remington Shavers and Campari, the Italian aperitif.

title: Yanks Rally to Top Indians,147; Lead by a Game as Orioles Lose
Sunday Observer
description: Who's the ape?

title: Red Smith
description: George Foreman's frank and open countenance is more open this Sunday than last. Muhammad Ali says he is, responsible; he says he had a vision of George with a wounded eyebrow, and his power worked too early. Both men are billeted in President Joseph Desire Mobutu's place at N'Sele, Zaire's equivalent of Camp David, and evidently they will remain there Sports beside the old Congo Until they have fought of for the heavyweight The Times championship of the world.

title: Ohio State Romps, Led By Griffins
Son for the Gnichtels
description: A son was born Sept. 3 to Mr. and Mrs. William Van Order Gnichtel of New York and Tannersville, N. Y., at the Harkness Pavilion.

title: R. McKim Bell, Lawyer, Weds Lisa Bloomingdale
description: St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church was the setting in Los Angeles yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lisa Bloomingdale to Robert McKim Bell. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and, Mrs. Alfred S. Bloomingdale of Holmby Hills, Calif., and a great granddaughter of the late Lyman G. Bloomingdale, founder of the New York department store. The bridegroom, known as Kim, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Bell of Los Angeles.

title: Mighty Electronic Monster Has Come To Carnegie Hall
description: THERE is a monster in Carnegie Hall, and last week it was sitting heavily on the stage. Some people were warily looking at it. There was Julius Bloom, who runs Carnegie Hall. There was Allan van Zoeren, general director of the Rodgers Organ Company of Hillsboro, Oregon. There was Christopher Jaffe, the acoustician. There was Richard Torrence, concert manager who has many organists on his roster. There was a newspaper reporter, and there was a clutch of technicians who are currently ministering to the needs of the monster.

title: T. D. Adamson 3d Weds Miss Harrison
description: Virginia Gatewood Harrison and Thomas Darnley Adamson 3d were married yesterday afternoon in the Westover Episcopal Church in Charles City, Va. The Rev. Robert. Harvey performed the ceremony.

title: Task Force Is Revived by Beame To Handle SingleRoom Hotels
description: Mayor Beame moved yesterday to revive the taskforce approach in dealing with singleroomoccupancy hotels. His action followed the discovery that a series of killings on the West Side may have been committed by a resident of one such hotel, the Park Plaza.

title: U.S. Communist Suggests C.I.A. Held Soviet Art Show
description: The leader of the American Communist party said yesterday that the nonconformist art show broken up in Moscow last Sunday might have been staged by the Central Intelligence Agency and that local Soviet citizens seemingly overreacted.

title: 9 NIEMAN FELLOWS NAMED BY HARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 (AP)Harvard has named nine more reporters and editors to study at the university this year as Nieman fellows in fournalism.

title: Yanks Win, Lead by
description: The Yankees rallied to beat the Cleveland Indians yesterday, 147, and take a onegame lead over the Baltimore Orioles with nine games left in the hot Eastern Division race. The Orioles lost to the Boston Red Sox, in 10 innings. Details in Section 5.

title: MODERN ARTISTS AID CHAIR AT COLUMBIA
description: Twelve prominent modern artists have produced original works that will be sold to endow a profetssorship at Columbia University in honor of Meyer Schapiro, who for nearly 50 years has been inspiring students to become art historians, museum officials, art critics and artists.

title: Three Hurt in Derailment Of Amtrak Train on Coast
description: REDDING, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)The southbound Amtrak Starlight derailed today 26 miles north of Redding. Three of the 200 persons aboard suffered minor injuries.

title: Annsley Chapman to Wed Nov. 30
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Chapman of Kentfield, Calif., formerly of New Canaan. Conn., of the engagement of

title: Massachusetts Revenue Cut
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP)State tax collections for the first two months of the fiscal year 1975 were $25million below the $315.7million collected in July and August of last year, Tax Commissioner Nicholas L. Metaxas said Tuesday. The $144million collected in personal income taxes was about $21million below the yield last year.

title: Statewide RentControl Law Is Seen Emerging as a Primary Legislative. Issue
description: TRENTONLobbyist groups representing the divergent interests of landlords and tenants are actively preparing legislative packages that aim to define and regulate the volatile area of tenantlandlord relations.

title: 4 Shows Next Weekend In Nassau and Suffolk
description: Long Island will be the magnet for the dog show fanciers next weekend. Three allbreed events and one specialty have drawn a total of 4,189 dogs.

title: Greenwich Plans A Historic Bonfire
C.U.N.Y SETS POLICY ON DRAFT EVADERS
description: The City University is prepared to allow Vietnam era draft evaders and deserters to tutor students to meet the public service requirement of President Ford's earned reentry amnesty program.

title: 11 OIL CONCERNS SUE ENVIRONMENT UNIT
description: DENVER, Sept. 21 (AP)The American Petroleum Institute and 11 major oil companies filed suit yesterday in United States District Court seeking to at aside effluent controls and guidelines set up by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: SubSahara Africa Waits for Help
description: NEW HAVENEach year the desert creeps farther down into the Sahel Sahel, Arabic for border, is the term for the six, countries at the edge of the Sahara's southern rim: Chad, Mali, Mauritania Niger, Senegal and Upper Volta.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST homes now have hot water and heating lines made of copper pipe which is joined with special soldered fittings  commonly called sweat fittings short for sweat fittings (short for sweatsoldering, the technique involved in joining pipes and fittings.

title: Maxine Cromwell to Be Wed Dec.
description: Mr. James H. R. Cromwell of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Maxine Hope Cromwell of Malibu, Calif., to Dale Edgar Hopkins, also of Malibu, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Hopkins of Long Meadow, Mass.

title: Suffolk Prosecutor Race: 2 Seek to Unseat Wenzel
description: The three candidates for District Attorney of Suffolk County appear to be running on the same platform at times. They all want to fight corruption; they want to curb gambling and stop the loan sharks; they want to put the confidence men behind bars. And they promise to do all of this immediately.

title: Contractors In Suffolk Must Get Licenses
description: A new Suffolk County law that goes into effect Oct, 29 should aid homeowners who feel they have been victimized by contractors, according to officials of the county's Consumer Affairs Department.

title: Tocks Island Coalition Set Up
description: BELVIDEREA fourcounty coalition has taken up arms against the proposed Tocks Island Dam project.

title: Peggy Lee Sings In Empire Room; Lacks Simplicity
description: Peggy Lee, who has had her ups and downs in the last 30 years, is, going through one of her downs in the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Tulane Passes Send Army to 3114 Loss
BRANIFF AND UNION AGREE TO END STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, (AP)  The Air Line Pilots Association and Braniff Airways agreed tonight to end a dayold strike that idled 9,278 employes while their differences are being studied by a factfinding panel, a Federal mediator said.

title: News of the Screen
description: Tandein Productions, headed by Norman Lear and Bud Yorkin, may represent one of television's top sucecss stories with four hit series"All In the Family, Sanford and Son, Maude and Good, Times, but Mr. Yorkin is, nevertheless, leaving television for the movies.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: PITTSBURGHFor anyone coming from New York, Pittsburgh can be something of a surprise. The ride in from the airport at night covers seemingly endless miles of darkness. And then you burst out of a mountain tunnel to confront the vigorous city across the riverthe Golden Triangle ablaze with skyscraper lights, a colored geyser sending water into the smogless air.

title: Buchen Said to Put A Hold on Transfer Of Gifts to Nixons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Gifts to former. President Richard M. Nixon and his family that fill 1,100 crates and boxes and may be worth more than $2million are being detained by the Ford Administration, The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions.

title: Bronson looks as if at any moment he's about to hit someone
What They Are Saying
description: Augie Tammariello, Southwestern Louisiana's football, coach, is thankful for his kicker: God sent us Rafael Septien. He's The best fieldgoal kicker in America. Septien is from Mexico City.

title: Tennis Court Loss Protested in Queens
description: Angry regular tennis players at Cunningham Park in Queens charged last week that the city had acted without concern for Its residents when it permitted a Nassau County businessman to control half of the public courts in the park during part of the year.

title: Goodyear, Its Plans Uncertain, Is Expected to Cut Back Expenses
description: MOSPORT, Ontario, Sept. 21A Goodyear official for the Canadian Grand Prix at Mosport Park has confirmed what persons connected to this sport have long believed:

title: WorldInterest or SelfInterest?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21If this were a book instead of a newspaper column, I would give it one of those fashionably long titles such as, Some Preliminary Thoughts on America's World Responsibilities Upon Being Denounced as a NeoIsolationist.

title: SCHOLARS IN WEST ACCUSED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21A foreign affairs Journal today charged Western universities such as Columbia and Harvard with harboring Soviet studies departments that were involved in subversion against communism and the Soviet Union.

title: The Region/continued
description: A Brooklyn man left his home on a recent Friday evening, telling his wife he would be back in a few hours. His body was found three days later in the burning trunk of a car. He had been shot in the head and stomach, and his head had been wrapped grotesquely in a plastic bag. A few days earlier, another Brooklyn man stumbled into a courtyard Sheepshead Bay. Help me. I'm shot! he begged residents sitting on their porches. He pleaded with them not to call the police, but someone did; he was rushed to a hospital and his life was saved. A week before that, a man was shot in the head as he watched the dice play at a Brooklyn synagogue's Las Vegas Nite. The wound was fatal.

title: 2Block Trenton. Mall Termed a Failure
description: TRENTON  A twoblock pedestrian mall in the heart of the state capital is falling far short of its goal of reviving the city's downtown area.

title: First 4 Deserters Are Cleared For Jobs in Clemency Program
description: The first four deserters processed under President Ford's clemency program were out of the Army and on their way to alternative service jobs yesterday, six days after Mr. Ford announced his conditional amnesty plan to restore the essential unity of Americans.

title: Ilajayne Presberg Is Wed
description: Ilajayne Presberg and Lawrence H. Silverman were married last evening by Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal and Cantor Robert Block at the Oceanside (L. I.) Jewish Center. The bride is a senior assistant buyer with B. Altman & Co. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Presberg of Freeport, L. L Her mother is office manager of Mulholland, Minion & Roe, law firm in Garden City, L. I., and her father is assistant to the vice president of John Meyer of Norwich in New York, a division of W. R. Grace & Co. The bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Silverman of Kings Point, L. I., Is an account executive with Petrocelli Clothes, Inc., of which his father is

title: Miss iss McGlone Becomes Bride
description: Stacey Elsa McGlone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William McGlone of Scarborough, N. Y,, and John Henry Gemmill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gemmill of Washington and Franklin, Me., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Richard G. Jordan of St. John's Episcopal Church of North Guilford, Conn. The ceremony was performed on the top deck of the McGlone home, which overlooks the Hudson River.

title: A little bit of crud
description: I think we are all willing to have little bit of crud in our lungs and a full stomach rather than a whole lot of clean air and nothing to eat, the Texas legislator from Tyler says in a newspaper interview quoted in the epilogue of Expendable Americans. And I don't want a bunch of environmentalists and communists telling me what's good for my life and family.

title: Jazz by Webster Lewis Mixes With the Poetry of Arne Falck
description: Friday evening at Town Hall could hardly have been considered dull. Here was Lionel Hampton officially presenting Arne Falck's poetry, translated from the Norwegian; another musician, Webster Lewis, who calls his music postpop space rock bebopgospeltabernacle, offering the premiere of a musical suite dedicated to Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and, to top it all off, Norwegian actress, Brett Borgen, reading Ibsen.

title: David Baby Marries Beverly Ann Brunelle
description: Beverly Ann Brunelle and David Prindiville Baby were married yesterday afternoon in the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Somersworth, N.H., by the Rev. Daniel St. Laurent.

title: Princeton Enrolling Resident Students
description: PRINCETON  Breaking with tradition, Princeton University has started to accept applications for a special continuing education prograin.

title: New Canaan Turns Back Rippowam
Conferees Nearing Crucial Votes on Strip Mining Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Three years of Congressional hearings, intensive lobbying and protracted floor debate, and the spur of a previous legislative failure, have finally brought the most important environmental bill before Congress this year close to final passage.

title: INDIAN POLITICIAN BACKS OUTCASTS
description: MADRAS, India  Satyavani Muthu is a widow who smiles cheerfully and speaks with revolutionary wrath.

title: Two Contrasting Styles in Prints: Images and Words
Pleasantville Wins No. 34
SPOTLIGHT
description: The overriding challenge with any company growth plan, whether it is for five years or for 15 and regardless of any astronomical numbers you put into it, is that it can only succeed if you are able to cope with the problems of today.

title: SYRIA STRONGER, LEADER ASSERTS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 President Hafez alAssad of Syria emphasized his untry's, desire for peace today, but warned at the same time that there could be no peace in the Middle East so long as Israel continued to occupy Arab territory and the Palestinian people remained dispossessed.

title: The Doctor Dances After a Day in the Lab
description: WATCHUNGFive days a week, Dr. Polly Roy Bishop works at the Rutgers Institute. of Microbiology, where she is a research associate in molecular virology under the supervision of her husband, Dr. David Bishop, an associate professor of microbiology.

title: Wall Street Tries Hard to Forget Nixon
description: Wall Street once gave its heart, its hurrahs and its campaign money to Richard M. Nixon. But lately the nation's nerve center of finance has been doing its best to forget about the President who resigned and scandal on Aug. 9.

title: Special Status Sought for Montauk Homes
description: MONTAUK  A late 19th century housing development laid out by Frederick LEM Olmsted and designed by the architectural firm of Stanford White is under consideration for designation as a Federal historical district.

title: Susan Weiser Married
description: At Temple Shaaray Tefila here last night, Susan Lee Weiser, an actress, was married to William Franklin Finley, an actor and painter by Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Weiser of New York. Her father is a former member of the State Offtrack Parimutuel Betting Commission and a former State Assemblyman. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. William F. Finley of Los Gatos, Calif., and the late Mr. Finley, who was a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Duane Thomas will replace Larry Brown at running back tomorrow for the Washington Redskins against the St. Louis Cardinals, Coach George Allen said today.

title: Stanton Couple Compete as Riders
description: STANTONMr. and Mrs. Edgar Hotz may be the only couple in New Jerseyand one of the few in the United Stateswho ride in the upper levels of recognized dressage competition and compete against each other from time to time.

title: F. W. Stetson 2d Marries Mary Treat
description: Mary Esther Crowell Treat, daughter of Judge William W. Treat of New Hampshire Probate Court and Mrs. Treat of Stratham and Wolfeboro, N.H., was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick W. Stetson 2d. The Rev. Robert H. Schacht Jr., minister emeritus of the First Congregational Church of Providence, RI., and the Rev. David Howe performed the ceremony in the Melvin Village (N. H.) Community Church.

title: Pamela L. Purvis, Designer, Married
description: Pamela Lee Purvis and Charles Cameron Jordan were married yesterday afternoon at St. Olaf's Roman Catholic Church in Poulsbo, Wash. The Rev. Richard Gallagher performed the ceremony.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: For John Bfanchi, little in life has changed since last year when it was revealed that an elderly widow he had befriended while working as a delivery boy in an East Side supermarket had bequeathed to him what amounted to a $50,000 tip.

title: The Plainspoken Realism of George Caleb Bingham
AccUrate End Play Enables Chess : Korchnoi to Squeeze a Draw
Ford Foundation Weighs Reducing Grants by 50%
description: The Ford Foundation, squeezed like most private philanthropies by falling stock and bond markets and mounting inflation, is considering a reduction of as much as 50 per cent in its annual grants.

title: Black Leaders Open Parley on Impact of Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21About 60 leaders of black civil rights, church, fraternal and political organizations began two days of closed meetings today to seek a consensus on how to solve what they term the disproportionate impact of inflation on minority groups and the poor.

title: Heinrich Schwarz, ExCurator, Wesleyari Art Professor, Dead
description: Dr. Heinrich SChwarz, professor emeritus of art and retired curator of the Davison Art Center collection at Wesleyan University in Connecticut, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He lived at the Stanhope Hotel here. He was 79 years old.

title: landicapped Week Oct. 612
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)President Ford has proclaimed Oct. 6 to 12 as National Employ the Handicapped Week and urged Americans to make better use of the skills of disabled persons.

title: Numismatics
description: THE U.S. Mint has announced that it is ready to fill orders for the second pair of medals commemorating the Battle of StOny point and the exploits of Mad Anthony Wayne and Col. Francois Louis Teisseidre De Fleuryin its historic 10piece America's First Medals series. At the same time, the Mint reported it would respond to popular demand and give collectors a second chance to obtain the complete series.

title: A Scandalous Woman
description: Here are nine new stories by Edna O'Brien. They offer the pleasures her readers have come to expect: the brisk and deadly pleasures of fairy tale. She is adept at evoking gardens of Eden: a rural Irish childhoodEden and the Eden of sexual delight. Snakes abound. Penalties threaten. The dangling apple is too bright to be wholesome, but the girl approaching cannot gain this grim knowledge without risk. As though, exhausted by this primal dilemma, Miss O'Brien's heroines seem, once fallen, unable to rise. Their Fall is always sexual. If they do totter to their feet, it is to fall again, like the girl in the musichall ditty who Went away to London,/For to hide her grief and shame,/But there met another squire,/And so lost her name again. Six of these stories deal with some aspect of this sad odyssey. It is odd stuff to find oneself enjoying in 1974.

title: Park Is Planned To Assist Disabled
description: MINEOLAMitchel Park, the new 67acre complex being constructed on Mitchel Field, has been designed to accommodate handicapped persons, County Executive Ralph G. Caso has announced.

title: Reaction Mixed to OneWay Traffic in Hackensack
description: HACKENSACK  An experiment designed to alleviate traffic congestion in this city's downtown area ended at 6 P.M. yesterday. Municipal officials and the police termed the 10day test sufcessful, while response frqm merchants ranged from high praise to damnation.

title: New Bay State Lottery
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) A new daily lottery called the 24 Hour Game will begin Oct. 1, William E. Perrault, the state lottery director, has said.

title: Actor Walter Brennan Dead; Winner of 3 Academy Awards
description: OXNARD, Calif., Sept. (AP)  Veteran actor Walter Brennan, who won three Academy Awards, died tonight after a long battle with emphysema. He was 80 years old.

title: Community Boards Assert Growing Influence in the Financing of Capital Projects
description: The city's 62 community boards, which have been recommended for greatly enlarged powers under any reorganization of municipal government, have already begun to assert considerable influence in one important areathe financing of capital projects in the five boroughs.

title: Congressional Study Backs Spending Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 21The Congressional Joint Economic Committee unanimously supported today President Ford's decision to hold total Federal spending at or below $300billion in the current fiscal year.

title: 59% in Poll Favor Amnesty Program Like the Ford Plan
description: Nearly six out of 10 people questioned favor conditional amnesty for Vietnam war deaerters and draft evaders, according to a Gallup Poll made public today.

title: The Region In Summary
description: With the opening of two new campuses this month, New York State will have 38 community colleges, a. system second, in size only to California's. The institutions, nine of them in New. York City, provide twoyear college courses and vocational training for 210,000 students.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT; Must the Budget Be Uncontrollable?; Big Snag Is Growth of Entitlement Programs
Belmont Race Charts
Dance,At 55,What's Ahead for Fonteyn?
description: TWENTYFIVE years ago next month (on Oct. 9 to be precise), a young girl ran down flight of steps at the Metropolitan Opera House, glittered her way through a darting series of pas de chats, bestowed a princess smile on the diamond horseshoe, and entered her realm to a blaze of Tchaikovsky and contributory cheering. It was Dame Margot Fonteyn, making her New York debut. She was not then, of course, a Dame Commander of the British Empire. But come to think of it she was not such a young girl, either. That night the 16yearold Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty was being danced by a 30yearold Miss Fonteyn. Moreover, she had first danced that role 10 years earlier, in 1939, and by her New York debut she had already danced Aurora more often than any other ballerina, past, present or future. Yet she was then only at the dawn of her career.

title: New Delhi Cracks Down on Smugglers
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 21The Indian Government has begun vigorous antismuggling campaign in support of moves to combat price increases and hoarding.

title: Bayh Asks Inquiry Into Indictment of 2 Reporters
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 21United States Senator Birch Bayh urged Attorney General (William B. Saxbe yesterday to conduct a civil rights investigation into the indictment here of two reporters for The Indianapolis Star, both members of the newspaper team reporting alleged police and political corruption in Marion County.

title: Concern Here Robbed Of $150,000 in Pearls
description: Two men pretending to be making a delivery entered the Caro Yamaoka Company, a jewelry concern on the 13th floor at 515 Madison Avenue, at 53d Street, shortly before noon yesterday, drew guns, handcuffed the owner, his brother and an employe and escaped with about $150,000 in pears, according to the police.

title: Earthquake in California
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)  A light earthquake Shook an area from east of Riverside through the Coachella Valley today. No damage was I reported.

title: EUGENE DUFFIELD, PUBLISHER, EDITOR
description: Eugene S. Duffield, who had had careers in journalism, education, government and publishing, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, in Tamarac, Fla. He was 66 years old and until recently had lived in Saratoga Springs, N. Y.

title: Aides Concerned as Kissinger Faces First Sharp Criticism on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21.for the first time since becoming Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger has found himself A. target of, sharp criticism on Capitol Hill.

title: Businessme Sing a Similar Song
description: PITTSBURGHThe two business and mananufactaring conferences. on inflation held last Week in Pittsburgh and Detroit did not find the weapon to defeat President Ford's Public Enemy NO. 1. But they did offer an opportunity to examine American business thinking. Is it indeed the monochromatic stereotype, where businessmen look alike, think alike :and Sound alike? Perhaps not so much as the foes of business asslime but more than,those businessmen who like to think of themselves as individualists would care to admit.

title: His Swift Rise Is Not So Unusual, and the NATO Job Is Suited to Him
description: To the stillgrowing list of government problems illuminated by Watergate's twoyear run in the news, add another situation that deserves attention: the politicalization of the nation's topranking military officers.and mounted the, campaign to convince Richard Nixon to resign.

title: On Labor's Agenda for 1975: Millions of Public Employes
description: After a quartercentury in which the percentage of the total work force enrolled in unions kept sinking, labor sees its first solid hope for a turnaround in the recruiting drives it plans next year among the 13.5 million employes of Federal, state and local governments.

title: Anne O'Laughlin Wed to Warren Baker
description: Anne Capp O'Laughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Laughlin Jr. of Barrington, Ill., was married there yesterday afternoon to Warren von Credo Baker, son of Marjorie Credo Baker of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and Elias Bloxom Baker of Fairhaven, N.J.

title: EDWARD A. CASEY
description: Edward A. Casey, who had been with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Inc., advertising agency, for some 41 years, died Thursday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at the Riverview.Hospital, Red Bank, N. J. He was 61 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: Gromyko and Ford Complete 2 Days of Discussions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21President Ford concluded two days of discussions today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union on the Middle East, limitations of strategic arms and bilateral relations.

title: Rockefeller's Old School Ties Remain Strong
description: One day last June Nelson A. Rockefeller opened his estate at Pocantico Hills in Westchester County to a goodsized crowd of people for a daylong outing.

title: Clarkstown North Beats Suffern, 336.
M. C. Higgins, The Great By Virginia Hamilton. 278 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $6.95.
description: They say the pity of youth is that it's wasted on the young. Since we're well into our thirties and because we love the stories of Virginia Hamilton we must agree. Before motherhood descended upon us we could curl up in corner with Zeely or The Planet of Junior Brown and cry all alone remembering... wishing... hoping about a childhood of our dreams. Now we gather child, dog, and gerbils (after we have extracted their promise not to chew the book) around us on the couch, under the quilt, with a big bowl of popcorn and share M. C. Higgins, the Great. Actually we're proud to share Virginia Hamilton with our family. They should know the good things.

title: Donna Brown Bride of W. S. Rasmussen
description: Donna Jean Brown and William Sweyn Rasmussen were married in a Quaker ceremony yesterday at the Kennett Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: Opera: Strong Faust by City Troupe
description: The New York City Opera brought together a strong cast for the season's first performance of Gounod's Faust, which was givenat the. New York State Theater on Friday night. Three of the seven were doing their roles with the company for the first time, and another was making his company debut, but all had been joined with the three holdovers from casts of previous seasons into a cohesive unit that made good musical and dramatic sense.

title: SelfInterest Stymies Inflation Fight
description: The battle for a bigger share of a smaller pie has begun. Although a mountain of verbiage tends to obscure the message, the series of presummit meetings on inflation has exposed the country's impatience with sluggish growth and the deep national belief in the simple credo: More, more, more.

title: Oil HangupThe SplitPrice Rule

title: To Read And Look At
description: Rich, tasty colors and vivid expressions such as are found in the illustrations by Aliki in GO TELL AUNT RHODY (Macmillan, $5.95), always attract children. Capturing unabashedly the rural pleasures of the American past, Aliki has dipped into 18thcentury landscapes for just the right settings. The children's faces tell us how it feels to live on a farm, to have an Aunt Rhody and to be excited and a little frightened by the death of a goose. Unhappily the song fails her after the first verse, because the rhythm changes abruptly when the refrain is dropped, and although the story continues in the pictures, the last eight pages have no words at all. Read aloud, the effect is eerie, as if off the

title: St.Peter's Routed By Fordham, 310
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21Fordham rolled up 302 yards on the ground tonight in defeating St. Peter's, 310, in a season's opener in Roosevelt Stadium.

title: The Real Economic Threat
description: The United States and the rest of the nonComn.unist world are facing an extreme threat to the global economy that is receiving only peripheral attention in the conferences President Ford has initiated to fight public enemy No. 1inflation. The threat is unprecedented; involves sudden and massive transfers of income, wealth and power to the small group of oilexporting countries, with corresponding drain of staggering dimensions upon the resources of oilimporting countries. Only few days ago the oil exporters, meeting in Vienna, again made clear their determination to maintain and even increase their take.

title: It was mucho worse
description: In his first book, Down These Mean Streets, Piri Thomas established himself as an eloquent spokesman for a group in society rarely heard from. As a darkskinned Puerto Rican, trapped irrevocably between the white world and the black, Thomas wrote with moving effect of his search for personal identity, his struggle for survival on the Spanish brand of Harlem streets. Like so many nonwhites growing up in their America, Thomas's passage into manhood took him along the familiar route of drug addiction, crime and prison confinement It is his experience behind barsseven years for armed robbery. and felonious assaultthat Thomas examines in his new book, Seven Long

title: Handicapped Aid Teachers

Charles Ficca, who heads the Psychology Department, fell to talking about the possibility of adopting an alternative to the usual, classroom method of training teachers to work with handicapped youngsters.

title: Ingmar Bergman and The Battle of the Sexes
description: EVERYONE reads relations between men and women in a different way. In a Thurber cartoon a giantess peers down on her husband who comes up to her instep. She's not unfriendly, just dangerously large. Rodgers and Hart decided that love, in spite of ali the selfceceptions required to believe a lie, was better than the absence of it. They celebrated conjugal mayhem: The broken dates/The endless waits/The conversations with the broken plates. Ibsen brooded about a nonerotic form of female bondage and Strindberg gave every impression of loathing women.

title: A Cat in Search of Total Approval

The ceiling is dazzling white, with a jagged edge, like a chunk out of lives.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Wilson announced yesterday that more than 93.000 people were taken off the welfare rolls during the fiscal year that ended NO) 30 for failure to comply with work rules. Mr. Wilson said the figure had been reported by the state Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, who said a monthly average of 19,114 welfare recipients were required to report to the State Employment Service. Of that total, an average of 3,463 were assigned to the public works program.

title: Love Feast By Frederick Buechner 248 pp. New York: Atheneum. $7.95.;
description: Tragedy, some literary scholars claim, is declarative. Comedy is interrogative. In an age of strong faith religious writers could drape their characters in a tragic mantle and soar from man's depths to the heights of heaven without suffering the bends. Nowadays religious writers seem more cautious. They move obliquely and by indirection because the gate is strait indeedif not shut altogether and they are never certain how many people share their preoccupations. Frequently a nervous comedy has become their mode and the answers they offer can be divined only from the quality and pattern of their questions.

You go to your show, I'll go to mine has become the unspoken pattern, and producers who have dared go into rehearsal with a costly project have generally gauged it to a limited segment of the population that could be counted on to rally round.

title: Is the Rate Decline Here to Stay?
description: Interest rates have moved lower. The rate banks pay each other for Federal funds, or uncommitted bank reserves, has declined from 1300BD per cent in midJuly to an average of 11.4 per cent in the past week. Commercial paper, or corporate promissory notes, has fallen by 215D of 1 per cent or more. And Treasury bill rates, which peaked late in the game at 9.7 per cent, nosedived in recent days below 8 per cent.

title: AROUND THE
The pseudoscientific method
description: Recent times have seen notable progress in the study of man, in efforts to learn more about the process which during the past five to ten million years has transformed a nearape into a nearhuman beingand there are prospects of exciting discoveries to come. But you would never know it from consulting most popular books on the subject. Current practice leans heavily on the fine art of selective omission: Some 99plus per cent of the available information is ignored and the rest mustered to support cliches at best and incredible nonsense at worst about why we behave as we do and how this could he improved.

title: Meredith in Mississippi Hike
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 21 (AP)  James Meredith, who was, wounded during a civil rights march eight years ago, set out today on a 50mile hike to promote voter registration. Mr. Meredith, who integrated the University of Misiissippi in 1962, is trying to qualify as an independent candidate for Congress.

title: Going beyond the clichs
description: There is a persistent American myth based on a meltingpot theory: its contention is that American democracy will eventually, like the mills of God that grind slowly. but exceedingly sure, convert all its polyglot races, colors, creeds and nationalities, if not into true blue WASPS, then into almost perfect facsimiles. There are, of course, those who continue to make the right kind of noises about the country's rich and diverse cultural heritage, and on various national days there are parades and festivities, but these are rituals of form rather than of content. The more institutionalized the ritual becomes, the more distant the memory of its living origins and the more its content.

title: Traffic Deaths Show Drop
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UPI)Traffic deaths in the United States were reduced by 4,000 in the first four months of 1974, mostly because of a reduction in the speed that cars are driven, the National Safety Council said Tuesday. The fatality rate was a 24 per cent drop to 12,480 deaths through April 30, compared with a total of 16,500 through a corresponding period of 1973.

title: More Than Once, They Have Tried to Set Up a Kurdistan
description: LONDONSix months after war was renewed last spring between Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq and the forces the Arab government in Baghdad, fighting between the 'two has reached a new peak of violence. Especially since summer weather permitted fullscale campaigning around the Kurdish mountain strongholds, the war has intensified, With 90,000 Iraqi troops and 300 tanks involved and Kurdish refugees from Iraqi bombing and ground thrusts flocking in thousands over the border into Iran.

title: 19 Hospitalized as 2 Tank Cars Explode in Houston Rail Yard
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)Two tank cars exploded in a railroad yard today and the giant shock wave broke windows and damaged buildings up to five miles away. Dozens of persons were injured, 19 were hospitalized, and blazing fires threatened to trigger more explosions.

title: Acting lessons
description: Diderot argued that the paradox of acting is that an actor must be cold and tranquil in order to project emotion. Actors who play from the soul, he said, are mediocre and uneven. We are not moved by the man of violence, but by the man who possesses himself. Like Diderot, we still take most of our standards for acting from the theater. The great actor is the great impersonator, professionally adept at becoming another person and maintaining that character throUgh as many performances as possible. Movie actors, we tend to feel, don't have craft; they have sensibility. At best, they only play themselves.

title: Greek Daily Is Revived After Exile

title: Long Distance By Penelope Mortimer 204 pp. New York: Doubleday &
description: This is an ambitious modern novel in that there is not much going on in it, and such action as there is has been nicely obscured beneath a very slick surface. Roughly: a woman in her middle years enters some sort of institution. During her stay she encounters other inmates or guests, an acting company, a man named Gondzik who becomes her lover and turns out to be a spy for the administration, a swimming pool, a gardener, a dog, together with a fairly anonymous crowd of perverts. The woman narrates and she is anonymous too. In the dim mood of the story one picks out Kafka, then something more stagy and clinical, perhaps Pinter, until at last one reaches the happy lulled

Although this kind of recognition had existed in Europe long before, it was first given status in this country by Gilbert Seldes in The Seven Lively Arts in 1924. And just this year Henry Pleasants published a book on The Great American Popular Singers in which he approached their work with the critical apparatus usually reserved for concert and opera artists.

To others they will suggest nothing so much as William Faulkner's brassstealing, barnburning, horsetrading, manure tracking IV unquestionably cunning and tenacious Snopeses.

title: Headliners
description: Gail A. Cobb was appointed to the Washington, D.C., police force last October. Like all other police officers, she Was required to have some regular patrol experience. She was on duty in downtown Washington last Friday when a call came in to pursue two men who had brandished a sawedoff shotgun at two other police officers and then fled. She was following one of the men down the ramp of garage when he suddenly turned and shot at her with a handgun, hitting her in the chest and wrist. Miss Cobb died shortly thereafter. She was the first policewoman killed in the line of duty United States history.

title: WellArticulated Thoughts Fascinate Agee's Friend
description: In a brownstone 32 narrow steps above Greenwich Village's Perry Street, the Rev. James Harold Flye sits at his, circa 1915 model Remington deciding exactly how to express his thoughts in the letter he is writing, Composing a letter still presents a challenge to him, even after his 30year correspondence with James Agee, the late Pulitzer Prizewinning author who died in 1955 at the age of 46.

title: The Official Answer Is No, but Responsible Critics Say Yes
description: The danger that American nuclear weapons stored abroad could be stolen by terrorist groups is being debated anew, and it includes the possible threat to the thousands of nuclear bombs and missiles positioned from West Germany to South Korea.

title: James Cunningham Offers Witty Dance On Battles of Sexes
description: James Cunningham has formed a roaringly successful dance piece out of current confusions over sexism, gender identity and sexual orientation. The episodes are created with a securely fastened but:floridly inflamd sensibility that has a Playboy 4bunny doing serious interpretive dancing and a Marine sergeant struggling against the seductive specter of a rose. The company presented the work, Dancing With Masie Paradocks, for the first time here Friday night at New York University's School of Education auditorium.

description: CAMDENIn the wake of the large number of attorneys involved in the Watergate scandal, New Jersey's three law schools are reexamining and revising their efforts to stress the importance of professional ethics and responsibilities.

title: From innocence to worldliness
description: Hal Bennett's fourth novel is, in several important regards, an impressive and provocative piece of work. It is also, in ways not much less important, frustrating and heavyhanded. Bennett writes with grace, humor, feeling and intelligence; he has a vivid, angry imagination that can both shock and delight. But when that imagination runs to excess, as in this novel it does rather frequently, it gets Bennett into trouble.

title: The Lumber Recession
description: PORTLAND, Ore,  The OregonWashington Plywood Corporation plant with its 205foothigh smokestack covers seven acres of the peninsula jutting into Tillamook Bay, dominating the landscape of Garibaldi, small Oregon coast community.

title: Ideas&Trends/contInued
description: The Russians just don't know what to do about art, as last week's goingson attest. They believe what Plato believed: When the laws of art are altered society alters with them. So the laws of art must not alter, and the masterpieces of even 60 years ago, Vasily Kandinsky's monumental Composition VI, for instance, must never be put on view. It is too soon to show them, an inquiring visitor will be told.

title: The New Store Wasn't Finished but the Party Went On Anyway
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 21The store isn't finished yet but Andrew Goodman, the grand vizier of Bergdorf Goodman, is not one to let himself be bothered by such minor details. The party went on, naturally.

title: Duke Repeats as Best In Ox Ridge K.C. Shovv
The Met's Own Ills Sound Like an Opera Plot
description: TOMORROW NIGHT the Metropolitan opera celebrates the opening of its 90th season with a revival of last year's new production of Verdi's I Vespri Siciliani with Cristina Deutekom, Placido Domingo, Sherrill Milnes and Paul Plishka singing and James Levine in the pit. Behind yet another opening, however, there lies a truly horrific maze of multifaceted financial, administrative and artistic difficulties. Whatever the outcome of the company's struggle to survive, the early and mid1970s will go down surely as an onerous era for the world's largest opera company.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, Sept. 22Doug Wilkins has tough act to follow: himself.

title: Dr. Charles Trad Marries Janet Liva
description: Janet Helene Liva, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vinicio G. Liva of Hackensack, N. J., was married yesterday in Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church there to Dr. Charles A. Trad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Trad of Deal, N. J.

title: John Bennett Weds Isabel E. Loscalzo
description: Isabel Elaine Loscalzo, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony E. Loscalzo of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Montauk, L.I., was married yesterday at noon to John Joseph Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bennett of Flushing, Queens.

title: Antietam, Again
description: On a September day in 1862, near Antietam Creek in Maryland, 23,000 Americans died in the bloodiest battle of the Civil War. Many wars and casualties later, another battle is in progress to save this historic region from the new commercial sharpshootershamburger.and pizza stands, purveyors of plastic rifles and fake Minie balls, and possibly another priVate steel tower similar to the one that now desecrates Gettysburg.

title: Raiders'
Modernist Art in Soviet A Legacy of 50's Thaw
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22  The artists who have challenged the Kremlin's canons of acceptable art by trying to stage a showing of their nonconformist works are children of Nikita S. Khrushchev's cultural thaw of the late nineteenfifties. And it is the more flexible standards of that era they are seeking to reassert.

title: Cost of Fixing Old Car Has Risen Sharply, Too
description: At a time when prices for new cars are keeping many Americans out of showrooms, motorists across the country are discovering a hard fact at their local garage: The cost of fixing their old cars has risen 10 to 25 per cent or more this year.

title: Cards Top Cubs in 9th, 65, Raise Lead to 1 Games
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) Ted Simmons's runscoring single with two out in the ninth inning gaye the St. Louis Cardinals a 65 victory over the Chicago Cubs today, increasing the Cardinals lead in the National League East to 1 games over Pittsburgh.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PLANNERS PEANUTS There are a great many ways around this town to see how the lumbering machinery of 400,000 city employes performs for you. You can form an opinion on the effectiveness of government simply by driving over a pothole or visiting City Hall. This last opportunity is one that New Yorkers usually don't indulge in, but it's well worth the trip.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Motorists who are insured through the assignedrisk plan will be able to purchase higher levels of liability insurance and broader coverage, beginning Jan. 1, the State Superintendent of Insurance, Benjamin R. Schenk, said.

title: PORT AGENCY AID SOUGHT BY BEAM
description: Mayor Beame is drawing ui a proposal under which thi Port Authority of New Yorl and New Jersey would contrib ute money to help keep tlu subway and bus fare at 35 cents, he said yesterday.

title: A Builder, 25, Challenges Rinaldo in 12th District
description: ELIZABETHThe 12th ConIressional District has sent Republicans to Washington repeatedly since 1956, and political observers believe that Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo Jr. will be returning again after Election Day in November,

title: JOSEPH KOHLER, 15. MAKES PIANO DEBUT
description: Joseph Kohler, who is 15 years old, made his.New York debut Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. To say that his was an unsuccessful piano recital would hardly scratch the surface: The young man simply showed no evidence of talent or of sound training. One can hardly blame him for thinking himself ready for so important an appearance in public, but those who presumably advised him to take the step ought to be ashamed.

title: Eugene C. Bennett Dies; Led Mail Order Business
description: Eugene Cowles Bennett, a founder and former president of Bennett Brothers, Inc., a national mail order business with offices here and in Chicago, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J. He was 94 years old and lived in Upper Montclair.

title: Meg Gemson Is the Bride of Jay Ashman
description: The marriage of Meg Gemson, daughter. of Dr. and Mrs. Bennett Gemson of New Hyde Park, L.I., to Jay Ashman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Ashman of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday. Rabbi Jerome Malino performed the ceremony at Stonehenge, a restaurant in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Builders Group Sees Housing Crisis as Result of Money Squeeze
Yanks Retain Lead; Giants Lose, Jets Win
description: The New York Yankees beat the Cleveland Indians, 21, yesterday at Shea Stadium and retained their onegame lead in the American League's Eastern Division.

title: V. A. Patients Split on Amnesty
Fittipaldi Triumphs in Canada Grand Prix
description: BOWMANVILLE, Ontario, Sept. 22Emerson Fittipaldi won the Canadian Grand Prix today despite Mario Andretti and moved into a tie with Clay Regazzoni in the world driver standing with one race remaining.

title: BINGHAM'S FATHER BOTH HAPPY AND SAD
description: SALEM, Conn., Sept. 22 (AP) Alfred Bingham was. both happy and sad today.

title: Young Artists Sketch Identities
description: NEWARK, Sept. 22  The works of more than 350 children who responded artistically to the question Who am I? went on display here today at the Newark Museum.

title: NICOLAS MOLDAVAN, VIOLIST, DEAD AT 84
description: Nicolas Moldavan, a violist who played in the Lenox, Flonzaley, Stradivarius and Coolidge Quartets during a career of more than four decades in this country, died Saturday of cancer at the New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 15 West 72d Street.

title: Troy Weighs Role In Wake of Ouster
description: Matthew J. Troy, Jr. watched the television image of Mayor Beame yesterday disclaiming any role as the puppeteer behind the politicians who last week teamed to oust Mr. Troy as Democratic county leader of Queens.

title: Joan P. Straus Is Remarried
description: Joan P. Straus and Joseph F. Cullman 3d, both of New York, were married yesterday afternoon at the bridegroom's summer home in East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Michael Gelber performed the ceremony: The bride was attended by her children, Tracy and Chip Straus.

title: Met Opera Accepts Plan For More Minority Jobs
description: The Metropolitan Opera has agreed to a threeyear plan to improve minority job opportunities in all categories, onstage and backstage.

title: Steelers, Broncos Make 35 to 35 History
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers and Broncos played to 3535 tie yesterday in Denver and it made National Football League history. It was the first regularseason game to require 15minute extra session since the rule was established to try and reduce the number of ties this season.

title: 6 Years After Furor, Columbia Will Get a Gymnasium
description: Columbia University's new gymnasium will open next month, six years after massive student and community demonstrations forced the abandonment of a site in Morningside Park, and 50 years after the university's administration first decided that a new facility was necessary.

title: 6 Years After Furor, Columbia Will Get a Gymnasium
description: Columbia University's new gymnasium will open next month, six years after massive student and community demonstra. tions forced the abandonment of a site in Morningside Park, and 50 years after the university's administration first decided that a new facility was necessary. The $12.7million building has been built on 50,000 square feet in the grove area at the north end of Columbia's main campus, at 120th Street and Broadway, filling the space between Pupin Physics LabOratories and Uris Hall.

title: Korff Reports Formation Of a Nixon Justice Fund
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 (Reuters)Rabbi Baruch Korff, who led a campaign to keep Mr, Nixon in office, announced here today the formation of an international Nixon Justice Fund to raise money to pay for the former President's legal expenses.

title: 5 Nations to Meet at Camp David On World Economic Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Plans for an informal Big Five meeting on world economic ills were being made today following a White House meeting between President Ford and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan.

title: Rangers Win in Debut, Bothered by New Rules
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 22The New York Rangers won their opening exhibition game today, but the National Hockey League's new rules suffered a setback. Scoring five goals in the last period, the Rangers topped the Detroit Red Wings, 75, and then departed from Kitchener where they had been training since Sept. 7. They next play the Boston Bruins tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Dance: Uptown Series
description: For its new concert series at Barnard College, Dance Uptown is presenting Many of its programs in an outdoor setting. Rain forced Saturay night's offerings into the Minor Latham Playhouse but the four choreographers represented provided an evening of interest.

title: ORGANIZED LABOR, SPLIT IN PRIMARY, SWINGS TO CAREY
description: Organized labor in New Yorlo, State, whose support was split three ways in the primary elec. tion, appears to be rallying be hind Representative Hugh L Carey, the Democratic nominee for Governor; in increasingly substantial numbers.

title: ROME VOWS FULL COOPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Vice Presidentdesignate Nel son A. Rockefeller, arriving for the start ,tomorrow morning of his confirmation hearing, said again today that he would be delighted to do whatever Congress asked to resolve any potential conflict of interestincluding placing his holdings in a blind trust.

title: Consumers Are Found Little Inclined to Spend
description: Consumers are even less Inclined to spend money now than they were in the trough of the 1970 recession,, the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization, reported today.

title: A ROLE STILL SEEN FOR GRAND JURORS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Justice Department says that the grandjury system no longer serves to protect individuals against zealous prosecutors, but that it should not be abolished.

title: As Gold Mirage Nears Reality, Plans Are Made for Selling Metal
description: For the first time since 1934 when the United States went off the gold standard, Americans will soon be able to buy gold wafers and bars.

title: U.S. ACTS TO SPUR WORK ON PIPELINE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Government has decide( to invoke the Defense Produc. don Act to make sure that construction of the oil pipeline across Alaska does not fall hind schedule this winter, ficial sources disclosed today.

title: U.S. Considers Reduction Of Atom Arms in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 22The Defense Department has begun a serious study of whether to reduce the United States large stockpile of nuclear weapons in Western Europe. Senior Defense officials, including Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, assume that: the study will lead to the conclusion on strictly military grounds that some nuclear weapons should be withdrawn.

title: PORT AGENCY AID SOUGHT BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beanie is drawing up a proposal under which the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would contribute money to help keep the subway and bus fare at 35 cents, he said yesterday.

title: U.S. Bishops Hear Pope
description: ROME, Sept. 22. (AP)Pope Paul urged 80 American bishops today to exert their power in the Roman Catholic Church with fidelity and courage, as a fourth of the Catholic hierarchy in the United States attended mass in the Sistine Chapel. Cardinal Cooke of New York, Humberto Cardinal Medeiros of Boston and the archbishops of Indianapolis, Atlanta, Anchorage, Portland, Omaha, Hartford and Cincinnati were on hand.

title: WALL ST. EXPECTS CUT IN PRIME RATE
Rear Window
description: WASHINGTONLooking down and across the street from my eighthfloor window at The New York Times Washington bureau the other day, could see a platoon of blue helmeted policemen in flak jackets, carrying rifles, preparing to rush down a ramp into a garage.

title: For an Ombudsman
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer's bill, for a municipal ombudsman is a promising ,answer to a weakness that has plagued every form of government since Shakespeare wrote of the insolence of office and the law's delay. Anyone knows the need who has ever waited for hours in a government office to make a complaint, only to be told to return the following Wednesday, or been shunted from extension to extension over the telephone, or abandoned the complaint altogether rather than endure the runaround.

title: Mozambigie Attempts To Stem Exit by Whites
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 22 (Reuters)The head of the blackled transitional Government in Mozambique tried today to stem the flood of white sets tiers leaving the country.

title: John Bone Sr., 54, Officer Of American Export Lines
description: John E. Bone Sr.,,a vice president of the American Export Lines and formerly director of its nuclear ship Savannah project, died Saturday at Valley Hospital, Ridegwood, N.J. He was 54 years old and lived at 85 North Pleasant Avenue, Ridgewood.

title: NIXON READY TO GO INTOHOSPITALTODAY
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Callf., Sept. 22 (UPI) Former President Richard M. Nixon spent a quiet day today on the eve of his hospitalization for tests and treatment of his worsening phlebitis.

title: If You Can't Beat Em...
description: Robert Strauss, the genial chairman of the Democratic National Committee, hasn't called the yet to ask how the Democrats should go about winning the 1976 Presidential election. But if he does call, and I expect he will, it is comforting to know that am ready with the answer.

title: City to Study Cause Of Steam Explosion
description: A full investigation of the steam explosion that rocked Park Avenue at 78th Street was pledged yesterday by Environmental Protection Administrator Robert A. Low, acting at the request of Mayor Beame.

title: FREEHOLD SETTLES TEACHER DISPUTE
description: FREEHOLD, Sept. 22Teachers and the Freehold Regional Board of Education reached contract agreement today, paving the way for the district's highschool students to return to their classrooms.

title: Henry Rosner Weds Ruth Michaels
description: Dr, Ruth Gruber Michaels, an author, lecturer and former foreign. correspondent, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Henry J. Rosner, assistant commissioner of the city's Department of Social Services in charge of fiscal affairs and assistant administrator of the Human Resources Administration.

description: Following is the text of the Reaffirmation of Allegiance and Pledge to Complete Alternate Service that military deserters must sign under President Ford's conditional amnesty plan:

title: 100,000 Cheers Greet Mobutu Gift, a Rebuilt Stadium
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 22President Mobutu Sese Seko presented the multimilliondollar 20th of May Stadium this morning to the Ministry of Youth and Sport and the people of Zaire. Close to 100,000 citizens in and surrounding the newly rebuilt stadium roared their thanks.

title: ANNIE LANDER GREEN
description: Annie Lander Green, a vice president and sales representative of the Adams Group, book publishers here, and an executive with publishing houses here for many years, died Thursday at her home in Weathersfield Center, Vt.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Defense Department has begun a serious study of whether to reduce the United States large stockpile of nuclear weapons in Western Europe.

description: The Bolshoi Ballet  or rather the Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet  have departed. They wound up their brief season over the weekend but true to form, novelties were being pulled out of the toeshoe until the very last.

title: Cliffs on Mercury Attributed to Early Shrinkage
A Royal Salute Honors Basie
description: Possibly because Count Basie has seemed to reduce the art of leading a big jazz band to the casual flick of a finger on the piano keyboard, he has rarely received as much recognition as he should for his contributions to jazz.

title: Soviet Artists to Reject Offer for a New Show
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (UPI) A group of nonconformist artists whose outdoor exhibition was broken up by. trucks and bulldozers a week ago has decided against accepting official approval for a showing next Saturday, one of the artists, Oskar Rabin, said today.

title: NUCLEAR VESSEL DRIFTS OFF JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Sept. 22Japan's first nuclearpowered ship, the Mutsu, has been drifting off the Pacific coast of Japan for the last three weeks unable to find a port.

description: POONA, India, Sept. 22 (AP)India, led by the Amritraj brothers, advanced to the 1974 Davis Cup final by defeating the Soviet Union today in their semifinal series.

title: Death of a Market Adviser Calls Forth Echoes of 29
description: The tragic death this weekend of E. George Schaeferthe investment adviser who indicated to his clients that they should sell gold stocks in a Sept. 6 bulletin that appeared to represent an overnight change of heart after six years of recommending the issueswas reminiscent of Wall Street suicides that followed the stock market crash of 1929.

title: Varieties of Religious Spokesmen Seeking More Out of TV Shows
description: It is an index to the atmos phere in religious television programming that many who have a hand in the making say that the ideal program would not mention God, synagogues churches or temples. It would not preach, shout or deliver sermons. The ideal program they say, would be nonreligious in appearance and project ar ethical, moral, social, humanistic and subliminal religious message.

title: Balloon Fall Kills Two
description: TRACY, Calif., Sept, 22 (UPI) A hotair balloon carrying three persons sprang a leak and plunged into a grove of walnut trees from 2,000 feet yesterday, killing two men and critically injuring a 19yearold woman.

title: About New York
description: Two editors from McCali's magazine , were on 44th Street between Madison and Lexington Avenues the other day when they passed a telephone booth. The telephone began to ring, and one of the editors, an inquisitive woman, decided to answer it.

description: The Metropolitan Opera has agreed to a threeyear plan to improve minority job opportunities in all categories, onstage and backstage.

description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 22 (UPI)The Soviet Nationals and Team Canada, whose international hockey series is now deadlocked at a victory for each team and one tie, move to Vancouver tomorrow night for their fourth and final game in Canada before the action shifts to Moscow,

title: PARAMOUNT TO NAME TV OFFICER ITS CHIEF
description: Paramount Pictures, Inc., which has experienced a series of successes at the box office in recent years, will elect Barry Diller, 38 years old and vice president for prime time programming at ABCTV, as its chairman and chief executive officer on Oct. 1.

title: Foreign Films Grace the Fall Season
description: In recent years, we've had clumps of cop movies, waves of gothic or occult films, batches of Mafia or black gangster pictures and cycles of Kung Fu. But apart from calamity movies, the upcoming film season is distinctly trendless; there's not even much nostalgia.

title: Flatlands Mirrors City's Industrial Hopes
description: We got the space we needed, and we had an assured labor force here. That's why we stayed.

title: PublicSchool Pupils Reported Deficient in Math and Reading
description: New Jersey's publicschool children continue to show marked deficiencies in mathematics. and reading skills, according to one interpretation of preliminary scores from the second round of controversial statewide achievement tests administered by the state's Department of Education.

title: SHOP TALK
description: I Peter Hamburger is a tease. His lamp designs only look like wireless wonders. The bases are made of seethrough plastic tubing that, at first glance, appear empty.

title: Mrs. Mitchell, in Britain, Has Quarrel at Airport
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP)Martha Mitchell caused a disturbance today at a London airport when she refused to submit to a routine security check, an official of British Airways reported.

title: Personal Finance: Tax Forms Shift
description: It is about seven months before income taxes for 1974 are due and more than three months before even the most careful taxpayers usually begin assembling their records. But the Internal Revenue Service has been busy for. some time preparing the new income tax forms that will be mailed at the end of the year and the beginning of 1975.

title: Jill.G.Altman Bride of Lawrence Tarr
description: Jill G. Altman and Lawrence Tarr were married yesterday, at noon at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Rabbi H. Leonard Poller of the Larchmont (N.Y.) Temple.

title: Paul Robinson, Cartoonist Of Etta Kett Strip, Dies
description: Paul D. Robinson, creator of the cartoon strip Etta Kett, which appeared in 50 newspapers across the country more than 40 years, died Saturday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived at 14 Hillbury Road, Essex Fells, N.J.

title: Brooklyn Man, 22 , Is Shot In Apparent Police Error
description: In an apparent case of mistaken identity, a 22yearold Brooklyn youth was shot in the eye by a police officer early yesterday as he sat in a car with three other unarmed companions in Washington Heights.

title: Music: Cocker's Return
description: All sorts or events are being taken these days to signify the death of the nineteensixties, and Joe Cocker's concert Saturday night at the Academy of Music works as well as any.

title: Work Will Begin on Oct. 1 On a White House Pool
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Construction of a White House swimming pool is scheduled to start about Oct. 1 so it can be completed for President Ford to use by the end of the year.

title: Brooklyn Man, 22, Is Shot In Apparent Police Error
description: In an apparent case of mistaken identity, a 22yearold Brooklyn youth was shot in the eye by a police officer early yesterday as he sat in a car with three other unarmed companions in Washington Heights.

title: Julie Wilson Laces SupperClub Songs With Lusty Vigor
description: Julie Wilson's svelte appearance makes her such a perfect image of the sophisticated supperclub singer that it is always a pleasant shock to find that she is much more. Some songs she sings at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street, fit the supperclub image. But Miss Wilson covers so much musical ground in the course of an hour and projects herself in so many ways that it is impossible to pin her down to any preconceived patterns.

title: Books of The Times
description: ADMISSIONS. Notes From a Woman Psychiatrist. By Judith Benetar, M.D. 219 pages. Charterhouse. $7.95.

title: Former Minister Resigns From British Labor Party
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  Britain's governing Labor party, buoyed by opinion polls predicting victory in next month's general election, suffered a blow tonight at the start of the campaign with the resignation from the party of a former minister, Lord Chalfont.

title: Kissinger Plans New Initiatives in U.N. Speech Today
description: Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in New York yesterday for a major address to the (United Nations General Assembly today on food, oil and nuclear problems and his first land with highlevel Greek and Turkish officials on the Cyprus crisis.
