description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23siecretary of LaborPeter J. Brennan said today that he beieved the growth of publiceM.iloye unionism would continue and predicted the passage of le;islation governing bargaining or Federal employes.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Justice Department said yesterday it, was investigating the failure of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to divest itself of Avis, Inc., and Levitt & Sons, Inc., as required under a controversial 1971 antitrust settlement.

title: Sorry, We're Here for Eternity
description: Soon it will be possible to extend human life indefinitely. After thousands of years of desperate struggle against death and deepest anguish at its inevitability there is at last hope of winning that struggle. In research centers around the world efforts are now accelerating to overcome aging and, in time, death itself.

title: Soviet Ties Canada, 55; Hull Gets 3
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 23 (UPI)The Soviet Union scored two goals with only four minutes remaining tonight to tie Teach Canada, 55, despite a Bobby Hull's three goals in the opening period.

title: Suits in 17 States Charge Failures. To Enlarge Food Stamp Programs
description: Legal services groups started Federal suits yesterday against 17 states, including New York, and the Department of Agriculture, charging violations of Congressional orders to enroll poor people in the food stamp program.

title: Saigon Pledges Truce Commission $2.8Million
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23The Saigon Government said today that it would contribute $2.8million to the bankrupt International Commission of Control and Supervision, the international group charged with supervising the Paris peace agreements.

title: Destabilized at the Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23George took out the check book and Martha. started opening the bills., The first. one was from the C.I.A. It was. for $8million and it was marked seriously overdue.

title: Soviet Plans ICBM Tests
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP)The Soviet Union said today that it will conduct rocket firing tests in the northwest Pacific between Sept. 25 and Oct. 5. Ships and planes were warned to remain out of the region centered on Lat. 36 degrees 3 minutes N., Long. 178 degrees 12 minutes lonsdtude W.

title: Seaplanes Start Two Daily. Flights Linking Manhattan and Washington
Factories First, Then Homes In New Town Arising Upstate
WILSON BLAMES CAREY ON FUNDS; ?? Lack of U.S. Aid to Foe and Others in the House
description: Governor Wilson continued on the attack yesterday, bring. in to Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island his message that the. Democrats in Congress Representative Hugh L. Carey among them, are responsible for, the lack of Federal aid for Nor York City and can be blamed if the 35cent subway fare goes up.

title: Music: A Whitney Blend
description: The Whitney Chorale and Orchestra, two groups of mostly Juilliard students under Leo Warbington's direction, offered a curlosly mixed program Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Uruguay, Argentina, the Soviet Union, Britain, Indonesia, Japan, Turkey, Zambia, Norway and Qatar in general debate.

title: Rep. Wyman Cites Letter by Jaworski In Move on Envoy
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 23 (AP)United States Representative Louis C. Wyman released today a letter from the Watergate special prosecutor's office asserting that it had found no evidence on which to file criminal charges against Mr. Wyman in a controversial ambassadorial appointment.

title: 9 Belmont Jockeys to Appeal $250 Fines for Refusal to Ride
Virdon Says 6 Victories Should Do It
description: In the serenity of his office, where temperature and temperament have remained the same throughout the long baseball season, Manager Bill Virdon sized up his Yankees chances yesterday.

title: Prince Nikita Romanoff, Russian Pretender, Dead
description: Prince Nikita Romanoff, pretender to the Russian throne, died Sept. 12 in Cannes, France. He was 74 years old.

title: Fairport Teachers on Strike
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 23 (AP)Teachers struck in suburban Fairport today in a dispute over new contract terms, but the schools remained open. School officias said they would ask for a court order to halt the walkout. They said attendance at the sdhools ranged from about 50 per cent to nearly 100 per cent.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford sent a telegram saying, Yours has been a long and distinguished career. Helmut Schmidt, the West German Chancellor, cabled his sincere congratulations, to the dean of American publicists who has stimulated the American and the world press with his independent spirit.

title: BLACKS ASK STEPS ON DEPRESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept: 23Black leaders called today for a millionjob public service work program and for tax reforms to ease what they described as depression that inflation has produced among blacks.

title: 400 Students Walk Out in Protest of Boston Integration Plan
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23  High school students walked out of classes in the Charlestown section of this city today as Boston entered its second full week of a courtordered school integration plan.

title: Councilman Target Of Federal Inquiry On School Unit Job
description: City Councilman Samuel D. Wright is under investigation by Federal lawenforcement officials for alleged abuse of his power as chairman of the Ocean HillBrownsville community school board, a post he resigned from last year sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Cliff Arquette, 68, Comic Actor, Charley Weaver of TV, Is Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP) Cliff Arquette, who created the Charley Weaver Character on television,died today of a heart attackat St.., Joseph's MedicalCenter. He was 68 years old.

title: $339,000 in Hurricane Aid
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept.23 (UPI) American Red Cross officials estimate that they have spent $339,000 in emergency assistance to Louisiana families who suffered losses,from hurricane designated Carden. The Louisiana division of the Red Cross housed and fed 71,537 persons in 206 shelters during the hurricane.

title: RATES MOVE DOWN IN BILLS AUCTION
British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE CUP

title: Showing That They Still Care About the European Styles.
description: Everybody knows the European couture's sphere of influence is contracting. The world no longer holds its breath waiting for the emergence of a new sleeve, a new seam.

title: British Quietly Open Race; Parties Muted, Public Cool
description: LONDON, Sept. 23Britain's election campaign opened today in a low key, with muted appeals from politicians and an evident lack of enthusiasm among the public.

title: Post for Rumsfeld
description: Donald Rumsfeld, Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, will replace Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. as President Ford's top staff aide, Government sources said yesterday. Details, Page 25.

title: POLITICAL PARTIES REVIVED IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, Sept. 23 (Reuters) The Greek Government today restored freedom of action to all political parties in Greece and legalized the Communist !party, outlawed since it tried to seize power in an armed rebelson in 1947.

title: F.D.A. Hearing Set To Resolve Dispute Over a Sweetener
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would hold a public hearing to resolve the issues raised by professor's contention on Aug. 16 that the sugar substitute Aspartame can cause brain damage to children when combined with a common food additive.

title: The Lelkowitzes List Their Joint Net Worth
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, made public yesterday figures showing tha the and his wife have a Joint net worth of $528,458. The total includes $136,804 in Mr. Lefkowitz's name; $289,654 in the name of his wife,, Helen; and $102,000 in joint assets. They listed no liabilities.

title: Statement of Sherman In 1884 Is Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Senator Edward M. Kennedy's announcement today that he would not accept hiS party's Presidential nomination in 1976 recalled a similar statement made 90 years ago by Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, the Civil War hero who led the Union Army in its march through Georgia in 1864.

title: FREDERIC BOWNE, ACTIVE IN QUEENS
description: Frederic Bowne, a member of the historic Bowne family of Queens, died yesterday at Elmhurst (Queens) General Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 34.41 79th Street, Jackson Heights.

title: Advertising
A CONNECTICUT AIDE HOPEFUL ON LOTTERY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)  The Connecticut state lottery will Meet Justice Department standards if it stops receiving Its lottery tickets and subscriptions across state lines, the Special Revenue Commissioner, John T. Macdonald, said today.

title: 4 HELD IN SERIES OF KIDNAPPINGS
description: Four members of what the police described as a gang of professional kidnappers who preyed on major narcotics dealers were arrested here yesterday in connection with an August abduction case an which a Bronx bus driver took only a few hours to produce $131,000 to ransom his 21yearold nephew.

title: T.V.A. ASKS CUTBACK IN ELECTRICITY USE
description: KNOXVILLK, Tenn., Sept. 24 (AP)  The Tennessee. Valley Authority, confronted with A critical power shortage, called today for a voluntary 20 per cent cutback in the use of electricity throughout the sevenstate area it serves.

title: Kissinger Proposes Cyprus Mediation
description: Secretary of State Kissinger informed the Greek and Tulkish Foreign Ministers in separate meetings yesterday that he was ready to play an active role in helping them resolve the Cyprus crisis and he agreed to meet them again next week.

title: Bridge:Local Organization Appoints A New Executive Director
SENATE UNIT BACKS FEDERAL CUSTODY OF NIXON'S TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Senate Government Operations Committee approved today three pieces of legislation designed to preserve Government custody of former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and papers.

title: Police Kill 2 Gunmen Accused Of Robbing Mourners in Darien
description: Two suspects in a burglar: were killed and a third was seriously wounded yesterday in a shootout with the police a tollbooth on the Connecticu Turnpike in Greenwich.

title: Educational Park Dream Is Now a Nightmare
description: Robert Steinis's house, the home his father bought for the family 47 years ago with savings scrimped from a subway motorman's salary, is slated to be demolished soon for a children's basketball court soon, and Bob Steinis is not happy about it.

title: Ford Presents Anticrime Program
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24President Ford announced to day a new program to take career criminals out of circulation.

title: OPEC Aide Denies Reports of a Plan To Raise Oil Prices
description: Abdel Rahman Khene, Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, denied reports yesterday that OPEC had already decided to raise crude oil prices by 12 per cent as of. Jan. 1.

title: Kissinger's Warning
description: In his eloquent if gloomy resume before the United Nations General Assembly of the threats to world stability, Secretary of State. Kissinger emphasized a point often overlooked: problems that have been at least manageable through the postwar periodlocal rivalries, economic conflicts, the spread of nuclear knowledgenow threaten to become uncontrollable.

title: Gromyko Lauds Detente; Makes Gesture to Israel; Russian, at U.N., Stresses ThawOutlines Terms for Israeli Relations
The Ups and Downs of Gasoline Prices Here
description: Regular gasoline  49 cents a gallon, said the sign yesterday at the Little Falls Friendly Service Station, on the eastbound lane of Route 46 in Little Falls, NJ.

title: 3 Cities File a Suit On State School Aid
description: The state's three largest cities New York, Buffalo and Rochester  yesterday challenged the constitutionality of the state's education aid formula, charging that under it the large cities have been arbitrarily shortchanged.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: North: Increasing cloudiness today; chance of rain tonight. Temp range 4570. South: Partly sunny, pleasant today; cloudy, cool tonight, Temp range 4163. Details on Page 75.

title: Man Holding Knife Is Shot; Police Account Is Disputed
description: A distraught man brandishing a knife was shot and killed early yesterday by.one of four policemen who had surrounded him in the hallway outside his mother's apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Music: 1920 Masterpiece
description: Some of the small, expert foreign chamber ensembles that visit here never seem to get beyond the 18th century as far as repertory is concerned. The Camerata Bariloche fortunately does. In its concert at Hunter College on Monday night the Argentine group turned half of its program over to music of this century.

title: House Unit Votes Protection Against Information Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) The House Government Operations Committee unanimously approved today a bill to give private citizens protection against the Government's computer information banks.

title: The Ups and DOWAS of Gasoline Prices Here
description: Regular gasoline  49 cents a gallon, said the sign yesterday at theLittle Falls Friendly Service Station on the eastbound lane of Route 46 in Little Falls; N.J.

title: About New York Floating a Publicity Balloon
description: It is daredevil time again, and Malcolm S. Forbes, the president of Forbes magazine, said yesterday that in a few months he would cross the Atlantic Ocean in a bal loon. He did not say exactly why he wanted to do this, and he even denied that he was a daredevil. In fact, he said, the odds that we make it are better than the odds that you make it safely across Park Avenue.

title: Yanks Lose Twice, Drop to 2d As orioles Down Tigers, 54
description: The New York Yankees tripped over the supposedly fallen Boston Red. Sox last night, dropped both halves of a critical doubleheader an tumbled out of first place with only six games left in the American League's Eastern freeforall.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 24 (AP)  Saudi Arabia hopes to complete negotiations leading to the full takeover of the Arabian American Oil Company by the end of this year, Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, said at a news conference here today.

title: 4 EPISCOPAL BISHOPS CHARGE FOUR OTHERS
description: Four Episcopal bishops have filed formal charges against the four bishops who participated in the controversial ordination of 11 women deacons to the priesthood in Philadelphia last July. The action could result in an ecclesiastical trial.

title: Contract Award
description: A $214million contract for the construction of a manufacturing plant in Algeria has been received by GIE International, Inc., a subsidiary of General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. The plant will produce TV sets and other entertainment products as well as components. Construction will begin in December with completion scheduled for late 1977.

title: U.S.State Dispute Snags Milk Adulteration Inquiry
description: Ten months after the Dairylea Cooperative admitted to adulterating thousands of galldns of milk and falsifying records to cover it up, neither state nor Federal lawenforcement agencies have begun criminal investigations against the individuals responsible because of what the agencies indicate is confusion over jurisdiction and a lack of communication.

title: Gromyko Lauds Detente; Makes Gesture to Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union today vigorously championed the improvement in SovietAmerican relations and insisted it had led to solid accomplishments.

title: EUROPEAN INTERESTS INVEST IN BECKER
description: European financial interests S G. Warburg & Co., Ltd., and Cie, Financiere de Paris et des PaysBashave invested $20million in A. G. Becker & Co., Inc., the New York investment banking concern, Paul R. Judy, board chairman of Becker, said yesterday.

title: WHYTEHUDSON DUO SHOWS VOCAL FLAIR
description: The qualities that make two performers a good team are sometimes elusive, but in the case of Ronny Whyte and Travis Hudson, who have Moved into the St. Regis Room Of the. St. RegisSheraton, the basic reason seems to be that they need each other. In the course of an evening, Mr. Whyte and Miss Hudson go through a variety of situations sitting together at the piano and singing, each singing to his or her own piano accompaniment, Mr. Whyte providing accompaniment while Miss Hudson singsand the evidence is that the more they are together, the better they are.

title: SAIGON COUNTERS NEW OPPOSITION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24A lull in opposition activity has fallen over Saigon as the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu maneuvers to contain the shrillest protests against it in years.

title: New and Gripping Cat at the ANTA
description: People used to think that Tennessee Williams's plays were about sex and violence. How wrong they werethey are about love and survival. Mr. Williams's Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is now 20 years old, and in its first day it was regarded as something of a shocker. Now even though a certain fourletter word has been restored where a euphemism once reigned stupidly supreme, I doubt whether anyone is going to be shocked now. But I hope they will he affected. This is a gripping and intensely moving play, a play that can hold its own with anything

title: McGuinn, Stalwart of the Byrds Opens as Solo at the Bottom Line
description: Roger McGuinn, who seems firmly settled into his solo career by now, opened a twonight stand at the Bottom Line Monday night, and offered an evening of rock that didn't quite match up to his past accomplishments.

title: India and Portugal End 1961 Breach Over Goa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24India and Portugal announced agreement today to reestablish diplomatic relations, interrupted since Indian forces invaded Goa in 1961.

title: Pan Am Employes Take Airline's Case to Public
description: In the darkened cockpit of a Boeing 727 jetliner bound for Berlin over East Germany one day early this month, James Hotchkiss, a Pan American World Airways pilot, and Dennis Panzer, a flight engineer, talked about Pan Am's deepening financial crisis and their personal sense of frustration.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Northern Electric Bids for Shares of Dictaphone
description: The Northern Electric Company, Ltd., of Montreal announced yesterday that it intends to make a cash tender offer for the outstanding shares of the Dictaphone Corporation. In making the announcement, John C. Lobb, chairman of Northern Electric, said the cash offer for Dicta phone's 4 million shares would be at a substantial premium above recent market prices. Merger News

title: French Aide Sees Caution At U.N. on Oil Showdown
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24Foreign Minister Jew Sauvagnargues of France said today that delegates to the United Nations and their governments seemed apprehensive about the implicit threats" contained in American statements about the world energy situation.

title: Moscow Yields on Site For Another Art Show
description: MOSCOW, Sept 24The Moscow city authorities acceded today., to the request of a group of nonconformist artists to hold an outdoor exhibition at noon on Sunday, instead of Saturday, and gave them their choice of site.

title: GARDEN CITY ACTS ON SCHOOL CHIEF
description: The Garden City Board of Education has voted unanimously to suspend indefinitely Dr. John P. Gainey, the district superintendent, because of his unauthorized use of a school vehicle.

title: Alleged Slayer of 11 Not Fit to Stand Trial
description: Calvin Jackson, who is said to have implicated himself in the murders of 11 women on West 77th Street, has been ruled not fit to stand trial at this time by two courtappointed psychiatrists.

title: 74 CROP PROSPECT IN WORLD WORSENS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The outlook for world grain production, with lovernments already worried over increasing hunger, has grown worse in the last month, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: Kaline Gets Hits 3,000 and 3,001 at Baltimore
Police and F.B.I. Expand Hunt for Boy's Abductor
description: RUTHERFORD, Sept. 24Borough policemen and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation expanded their search tonight for the kidnapper of a 7yearold boy who disappeared Monday from a grammar school playground.

title: Ford to Visit Oklahoma
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 24 (UPI)Senator Henry Bellmon, Republican of Oklahoma, announced today that President Ford would make a political campaign visit Oct. 22 on a trip also scheduled to take the President to Tennessee and Ohio. Mr. Bellmon said Mr. Ford would probably appear in the downtown Convention Center and at Will Rogers Airport.

title: Toothless Watchdog?
description: Riding shotgun without ammunition on the pricewage front is the dismal assignment President Ford has given to Prof. Albert E. Rees of Princeton, his choice to head the powerless new Council on Wage and Price Stability.

title: Australia Devalues Dollar 12 Per Cent
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Australian Government announced today that it was devaluing its dollar by 12 per cent. The new rate against the United States dollar is one Austra lien dollar to 1.3090 American dollars.

title: A Clarification
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday reported that Madeline H. McWhinney, president of the First Women's Bank, said that Edwards & Hanly had been engaged as underwriters for a sale of capital stock of the bank, which is now expected to open here after Jan. 1. The incorporators of the bank are having discussions with Edwards & Hanly with respect to its acting as a nonexclusive selling agent.

title: Slain Policewoman Honored in Capital By 2,000 Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24More than 2,000 police officers from throughout the country paid tribute here today to Police Officer Gail A. Cobb, believed to be the first policewoman in the United States to be killed in the line of duty.

title: Stars Receive W.F.L. Approval To Move Franchise to Charlotte
description: The New York Stars apparently have received permission from the World Football League to move their franchise to Charlotte, N. C.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sept. 24 (AP)Peter Korol of the Soviet Union swept top honors in the lightweight competition today at the 28th world weight lifting championships, totaling 671 pounds in the snatch and the jerk. Korol, 33yearold Ukrainian army officer, defeated 17 others to become the first athlete in the fourdayold competition to win gold medals in a class for the snatch, the jerk and the combined total. The 148pound Korol snatched 286 pounds and then jerked 385.

title: Soprano Lauds Teaching of Violinist Father
description: Lots of young women are daddy's girls, prized and cultivated by their doting fathers. Catherine Malfitano, a 26yearold soprano from the Upper West Side whose career is burgeoning fast, fits that pattern neatly, but in a very special way.

title: Successor to Haig
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Donald Rumsfeld, named today to succeed Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., but not to replace him as White House chief of staff, is a takecharge personality who has a knack for getting close to Presidents and for getting himself out of deadend political situations.Man in the News

title: PRICES ON AMEX STAGE A RETREAT
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell yesterday, mostly on profit taking after a threeday rise.

title: Inmate Labor Replaced At Middlesex Jail Farm
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, Sept. 24There was a biting chill in the air early this morning as men and women farmworkers climbed down from the old yellow bus that had brought them from South Jersey to the Middlesex County workhouse here.

title: Stars Gain 220 Lead, Trounce Wheels, 377
description: Amid reports that the New York franchise will move to Charlotte, N. C., the Stars took on the Detroit Wheels at Downing Stadium, Randells island, last night in a World Football League game.

title: 74 CROP PROSPECT IN WORLD WORSENS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The outlook for world grain production, with governments already worried over increasing hunger, has grown worse in the last month, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: Pacts at Philadelphia Papers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP)Guild members at The Inquirer and The Daily News, two of the city's three daily newspapers, accepted a new 13month contract tonight. Wage increases under, the new contract, whichexPires Nov. 8, 1975, range from $11.50 for those earning $170 to $32 for those over $380.

title: MISSILES IN LEBANON MEET ISRAELI JETS
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24Israeli Air Force jets attacking today in southern Lebanon encountered opposition from Strela groundtoair missiles, a military source said tonight.

title: HOUSE APPROVES MEASURE TO HALT ARMS AID TO TURKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The House of Representatives, rejecting appeals from its town leaders and from Secretary of State Kissinger,, voted Over. whehningly today to cut off military, aid , to Turkey until substantial progress had been achieved toward a military Set. tlement on Cyprus.

title: ISRAELIS IN U.S. FACE RESERVE ASSIGNMENT
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24In a move aimed at increasing available manpower, Israel's chief of staff announced today that a senior officer would be sent to the United States to begin arrangements for classifying Israelis living there for military reserve duty.

title: Jersey Sports Authority Given 31 Racing Days at Garden State
TV: The California Kid
description: With appropriate gratitude, ABCTV is giving the starring role on its 200th Movie of the Week, tonight at 8:30, to the character that has made possible so many movies of the week and actionadventure series: the automobile. The name of the movie, and the name of the car involved, is The California Kid.

title: Dow Off 9.62 to 654.10
How Police Firearm Training Works
description: We're not going to be telling you when to shoot and when not to shoot, a police instructor reminds the 29,000 active city policemen, from rookie to Chief Inspector, who each, year take the depa'rtment's required one day firearms refresher course.

title: Telesat Buys Teleprompter Unit To Bring TV to Remote Quebec
description: Telesat Canada, the corporadon that owns and operates the Canadian domestic satellite system, has bought for $100,000 Teleprompter's experimental mobile earth station to transmit live TV, programs to a remote location in northern Quebec.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES AGAINST TAX PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The House Ways and Means Committee voted down today a tax proposal that had received considerable support as a possible means of reviving the depressed housing industry.

title: State Mental System Called One of Worst
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Leading authorities of the American Psychiatric Association said today that the New York State mentalhealth system was among the worst in the country and that similar agencies in all other states were working poorly.

title: New Rochelle Teachers Resume Salary Talks
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 24A threatened teachers strike was averted tonight when the United Teachers of New Rochelle decided to resume negotiations with the school board.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)Despite economic pressures, support by the business community for the arts, especially from large, consumeroriented corporations, has increased by $34million to $144million in the last four years, the Business Committee for the Arts said today.

title: Stars Receive W.F.L. Approval To Move Franchise to Charlotte
description: The New York Stars apparently have received permission from the World Football League to move their franchise to Charlotte, N. C.

title: Defense Fund Bill Totaling 82.5 Billion Is Passed by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)The Senate having been told that cuts made in the Pentagon budget would not imperil the nation's security, approved and sent to the White. House today an $82.5billion defense appropriations bilk

title: CAROLINA DEMOCRAT SAYS HE WON'T QUIT
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 24Charles D. Ravenel, the brightest star to rise on the South Carolina political horizon in years, refused today to withdraw from the 1974 Governor's race, despite yesterday's State Supreme Court finding that he did not meet residency requirements.

description: NEWS INDEX

title: Adelphi U. Offering a StudyandSki Course
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 24College students skiing in the Catskills or listening to lecture on a hotel veranda there will have an opportunity to earn college credits in an unusual educational program announced today by Adelphi University.

title: A Deep Underwater Oil Pipeline Is Laid
description: Dispatch of The Times, London

title: STATEWIDE SWING MADE BY ABRAMS
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 24Robert Abrams, the Democratic nominee for Stater Attorney General, today accused Louis J. Lefkowitz of being an apologist for the Establishinent wit in 18 years as Aft orney, General had failed to adequately defend the publicinterest.

title: G.M. DELAYS PLAN ON ROTARY ENGINE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24The General Motors Corporation announced today it was indefinitely delaying plans to introduce the rotary engine because It was unable to get the power plant to meet all antipollution standards.

title: When You Pull Your Gun, You're on Own, Police Say
description: We're not going to be telling you, when to shoot and when not to shoot, a police instructor reminds the 29,000 active city policemen, from rookie to Chief Inspector, who each year take the department's required one day firearms refresher course.

title: For Customers Over 65, The Food Is HalfPrice
description: In Washington, Government officials attack inflation by jawboning. In New York, Abe Lebewohl tries to attack it with marrow bonesas well as chicken soup with matzo balls, stuffed cabbage and, in fact, anything on the menu.

title: Lingering Tragedy
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts said that he pulled out of the 1976 Presidential election campaign because of his responsibilities to his familyand this is widely accepted as truebut obviously there were political considerations as well.

title: Ford Advisers Say Economic Meetings Produced No Quick Solution
description: WASHINGON, Sept. 24Ford Administration officials, preparing for Friday's socalled summit meeting on inflation, are saying the same thing they said before 12 preliminary conferences an dover a hundred hours of debate: There are no quick solutions to the nation's economic problems.

title: Jersey's Jobless Fund Is Facing Need to Borrow Federal Money
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24Because of the state's high unemployment rate, the New Jersey unemployment insurance fund will be bankrupt within a matter of months and Trenton, for the first time, will have to borrow from the Federal Government to pay unemployment benef its to the state's jobless high state officials disclosed today.

title: Chase Unit to Phase Out CommercialPaper Function
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust announced yesterday that it was phasing out its $125million commercialpaper operation by Oct. 31.

title: Sirica to Rule Monday on Use of Transcripts in CoverUp Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Judge John J. Sirica will rule Monday on whether transcripts of tape recordings may be used by jurors in the Watergate coverup trial to supplement recorded voices heard on headphones.

title: Meanwhile, On the Hill, Lobbying and Politicking As Usual
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  While President Nixon was resigning and President Ford was pardoning him, Congress has been in session most of the time and working on several bills of major significance in human or institutional terms. The lobbyists took no vacation; the usual pressures and political instincts have been at work.

title: ROCKEFELLER GIVES ATTICA DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24In his second day before the Senate RuleS Committee, Vice Presidentdesignate. Nelson A. Rockefeller defended today his role in the Attica, N.Y., prison revolt in 1971 and explained his views on subjects ranging from mass transit to the disposition of the Nixon tapes.

title: Islanders Lose, 42
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Sept. 14 (UPI)Don Seiling a rookie, scored two goals tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 42 National Hockey League exhibition victory over the New York Dave Burrows also scored for the Penguins.

title: S.M.U. Crowds Down
description: DALLAS, Sept. 24 (AP)Dick Davis, the athletic director at Southern Methodist University, said today the Mustangs might reschedule some of their home games on the road unless attendance increases. Only 13,767 fans turned out in the Cotton Bowl Saturday to see S.M.U. defeat Virginia Tech, 2825.

title: Lawyer Is Indicted on Charges He Obtained Unsound Loans
description: NEWARK, Sept, 24 (UPI)A Federal grand jury today indicted a suspended HoHoKus lawyer on charges of having obtained, with the help of the president of a Jersey City bai $1.75millibn worth of financially unsound loans ands., overdrafts over a threeyear period.

title: Boston Mayor Says Busing Controversy Is Placing an Impossible Burden on City's Police
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24  Mayor Kevin H. White said tonight that it was an impossible and improper burden to charge the city's police with implementing the controversial school busing plan ordered here by the Federal District Court.

title: Writedown for Chock Full
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said yesterday that while it would report an operating profit for its fiscal year ended July 31, it would also have a $7.3million writedown of its securities portfolio. The portfolio of more than $18million contains about $17million in utilities securities.

title: Acting Nebraska Governor Calls Legislature in Session
description: OMAHA, Sept. 24 (AP)State Senator Richard Proud of Omaha, acting as Governor while Gov. J. J. Exon and Lieut. Gov. Frank Marsh are out of the state, called today a special session of the Nebraska legislature on Oct. 7 to discuss the state's 9 per cent usury limit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeal court ruled yesterday that former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin could remain free at least until Friday while he appealed a recent denial of a new trial.

title: FRESHFOOD COSTS REPORTED DIPPING
description: Led by a sharp decline of 3 per cent in freshproduce prices, the wholesale prices paid by the city for its fresh fruits and vegetables declined 0.9 per cent for the last two weeks in September, according to the Municipal Service Administration.

title: NEWS REVIEW PANEL UPHOLDS THE TIMES
description: The National News Council yesterday found unwarranted a charge by the United States A'mbassador to South Vietnam, Graham A. Martin, that an article in The New York Times on aid to South Vietnam contained numerous inaccuracies and halftruths.

title: U.S. and Soviet Seek a Rise in Tourism
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24 Soviet and American delegations declared today that a favorable climate for expanded tourism existed and they set up a joint working group to promote it.

title: New W.F.L. Nickname
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Sent. 24 (AP)This city's new World Football League team became the Shreveport Steamer today after 40,000 to 50,000 entries were filed in a contest to name the former Houston Texans franchise.

title: Sirica to Rule Monday on Use of Transcripts in CoverUp Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Judge John J. Sirica will rule Monday on whether transcripts of tape recordings may be used by jurors in the Watergate coverup trial to supplement recorded voices heard on headphones.

title: SELASSIE'S SON LISTS TERMS FOR RETURN
description: GENEVA, Sept. 24Crown Prince Asfa Wossen called today for a parliamentary form of government in Ethiopia under a new constitution reflecting the legitimate will and aspirations of the entire nation.

title: MRS. FORD GOES TO THE HUSTINGS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24Betty Ford, who yearned not to be First Lady, only a good wife and mother, donned one of her most attractive suits today and ventured into the political arena for the first time as a national celebrity.

title: Elderly Poor Face Peril On Fuel, Senate Panel Told
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The elderly poor may face winter of devastating hardship because of high fuel prices, the Senate. Committee on Aging was told today.

title: NIXON GETS A DRUG TO PREVENT CLOTS
description: LONG BEACH, Calil., Sept. 24 Former President Richard M. Nixon doctor said today that he had begun giving his patient drugs to present formation of new blood clots in the phlebitisdamaged veins of his left leg and to help eXisting blood clots heal.

title: Educational Park Dream Now a Nightmare
description: Robert Steinis's house, the home his father bought for the family 47 years ago with savings scrimped from a subway motorman's salary, is slated to be demolished soon for a children's basketball court soon, and Bob Steinis is not happy about it.

title: HEALTH AID PLAN VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Senate overwhelmingly approved today legislation designed to induce medical and dental schools to designate 25 per cent of their students for future service in medically underserved areas.

title: UNDERCOVER MAN KIDNAPPED HERE
description: An undercover police officer trying to infiltrate an extortion gang was abducted by its members at, gunpoint yesterday, touching off a tense, threehour surveillance and rescue operation that ended when the policeman was taken from his captors.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Senate sponsors of legislation to set up a consumer protection agency acknowledged today that they could not break a filibuster against the bill and that it was dead for this session of Congress.

title: Witness Links Satkin to Pay For Setting Fatal Passaic Fire
description: PATERSON, Sept. 24  A convicted felon testified under a grant of immunity here today that he had been paid $700 to set a fire on May 11, 1973, that resulted in the death of a woman and three children.

title: Flushing Grand Prix?
description: Flushing Meadow Park badly needs a friend. The proponents of a Grand Prix racetrack  a nice, quiet, contemplative sport have trained their guns on Flushing Meadow after receiving a rebuff from the city on Central Park, which they would have considered the ideal location for car racing. The prospective 200,000 spectators will require not only a track but also a grandstand and guard rails and police for the crowds, to say nothing of comfort stations, first aid and refreshmentsall guaranteed to make a pastoral idyll of the old World's Fair site.

title: Jets Prefer To See Q.J. Play Sunday
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 24 The Jets aren't about to send 0. J. Simpson a bouquet of flowers or even a getwell card, but if it'll make 0. J. feel any better, their defense would like to see him play in their game at Buffalo Sunday.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Wealthy antiwar Democrats who helped the 1972 Presidential campaigns of Senators Ed.. mund S. Muskie and George McGovern will gather here next week to plan liberal strategy for the 1976 Democratic National Convention.

title: Jordan Orders Investigation by Police Of Puerto Ricans Charge of Brutality
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24Mayor Paul T. Jordan has ordered the Police Department to investigate an incident at tavern in a predominantly Hispanic neighborhood in which four young Puerto Rican men Were allegedly beaten by the police and then were arrested on assault charges.

title: Billows Gains Lead In N.Y. Senior Golf
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 24  Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, 60 years old, took the secondround lead in the New York State senior men's golf championship at the Grossinger Country Club today with a oneoverpar 72 for a total of 152.

title: Energy War Rumblings
description: Will the warnings of the danger of world depression and a breakdown of world order and safety, issued this week by President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger to the oilexporting countries, cause them to cut their prices enough to restore balance to the world economy? Or will the Arabs, Iranians, Venezuelans and others regards the American warnings as a highlevel economic bluff, backed with some muted but essentially meaningless saberrattlingand ignore it?Economic Analysis

title: Burial on Soviet Peak: A Husband's Tribute
description: MOSCOW  The husband of the leader of the women's mountaineering team that perished in a storm atop Lenin Peak in August climbed the 23,400foot mountain himself to recover his wife's body and bury her and seven companions there.

But at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, everyone seems confident that the museum will he in shape for its longawaited opening Tuesday night.

title: Firestone Dividend to Rise
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday in Akron, Ohio, that it was raising its quarterly dividend to 27% cents from 25 cents, dividend is payable Oct. 21 to shareholders of record Oct. 4, and makes the new indicated annual rate $1.10 per share.

title: Eagles Heroics Make Monday TV a Hit Again
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24Tam Dempsey, the irascible clubfooted kicker, provided the big boot in another incredulous Monday evening television production as the Philadelphia Eagles upset the Dallas Cowboys, 1310, last night. it was Dempsey's 45yard kick with 25 seconds to play that decided the contest for the home side and delayed what notv seems an inevitable stroke for Monday night football, the suddendeath overtime

title: VENEZUELAN LEADER REPLIES TO FORD BID
description: President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela charges that many of the developing countries have become impoverished because of the need to hand over larger amounts of oil, food and resources to obtain machinery and other manufactured goods.

title: Landlords Deed City 5 Buildings Having About 30 Code Violations
description: The leaders of two major landlord groups yesterday turned over to Mayor Beame's staff the deeds to five South Bronx apartment buildings that, the landlord. leaders said, were in very good condition and virtually violation free but had to be abandoned by their owners because harsh rent control and inflation made them financial losses.

title: 2 in Zaire Confirm New Date for Bout
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 24 (AP)A copromoter the world heavyweight championship fight and the chairman of the fight committee said today they had received assurances that. George Foreman's injured eye had healed satisfactorily and that the bout with Muhammad All would take place Oct. 30 here (Oct, 29 in the United States). John Daly of the Hemdale Leisure Corporation of London, copromoter, said he had been informed by Foreman's camp that the cut above the right eye had been inspected and that no problems had developed. Bula Mandungu also confirmed that the bout would take place Oct. 30. It originally was slated early tomorrow morning here.

title: FARM GROCERIES UP $25 FOR YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The retail cost of a year's supply of farmproduced groceries jumped $25 in August to a record annual rate of $1,751 for a typical household, figtires released today by the Agriculture Department showed.

description: Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Vice Presidentdesignate, who has an estate in Pocantico Hills, N. Y., a Washington mansion and a ranch in Venezuela, may be violating a cardinal rule of the monied classdipping into capital.

description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 24Federal and state authorities are investigating allegations of, corruption in the awarding ot contracts by the Long Island State. Park Commission.

title: Carleton F. Rosenburgh Dead; Directed Building of Fisher Hall
description: Carleton F. Rosenburgh, a retired director and senior vice president of the Turner Construction Company, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y. He was 69 years old and lived in the Rivermere Apartments, Bronxville.

description: Roomwatching, that game decorhungry New Yorkers love, was played with gusto at Bloomingdale's last night.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The New York Stock Exchange got a somewhat cool reception today when it formally presented to the Securities and Exchange Commission its proposal for an 8 per cent increase in the sales commission on all but the smallest and largest securities transactions,

Rosenthal, a New York Democrat who has devoted himself to the cause of the consumer, warns Western Union patrons that a telegram is not worth the $7.45 it now costs, including the $3 delivery charge. Patrons of the utility's decaying service will have no trouble getting this message even if they get no other.

title: Cyprus a Major Issue in Turkish Cabinet Crisis
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept, 24 A Cabinet crisis that has ended the coalition Government of Premier Bulent Ecevit raises new obstacles to a negotiated settlement of the Cyprus crisis between Greece and Turkey.

title: Notes on People
description: In a display of candor, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada announced yesterday that he had changed his mind and would not address the United Nations General Assembly during its current session, for the simple reason that he has nothing important enough to say. Canada's statement will be delivered instead by the new External Affairs Minister, Allan MacEachen, today.

title: ARGENTINES GIVEN EMBASSY REFUGE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24The Mexican Embassy here said today that it had granted asylum to a former rector of the University of Buenos Aires who, according to friends, received a death threat from a rightwing terrorist group.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 24How do a basketball player and a swimmer react at a school with no basketball and, swimming teams? Why, they learn how to row a boat.

title: New U.S. Hard Line on Oil: A Reflection of Frustration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The hard new line Washington is taking in public about oil prices charged by foreign countries reflects disappointment and frustration that the United States campaign to bring about price reductions has failed, and failed conspicuously. The degree of frustration was indicated by President Ford in his speech to an international energy conference in Detroit yesterday. He said: News Analysis

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

description: The preservation of jobs in shipping and related industries emerged yesterday as the top priority among government officials, civic groups, members of local planning boargis and others who met to discugs comprehensive planning for the city's 578 miles of waterfront.

title: Hasidic Sett Gets $300,000 US. Loan For Small Business
description: The Orthodox Jewish Satmar Hasidic sect of, Brooklyn has been given $300,009 by the Government to help its members set up small businesses, in a grant that the United States Department of Commerce called unusual yesterday.

title: SHANKER URGES WIDER EDUCATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Albert Shanker, the newly elected president of the American Federation of Teachers, proposed today a threepronged program to improve educational services for young and old while helping to solve the problem of increasing unemployment among teachers.

title: ExRepresentative Injured
description: BANGOR, Me., Sept. 24Clifford G. McIntire, 66 years old, who served as a Republican Representative in Congreis from 1952 to 1966, Was in crit ical condition here today, from head injuries suffered in an accident.

title: Books of The Times
description: Maybe I'm getting dyspeptic or something, but Love Feast, the concluding volume of Frederick Buechner's comic religious trilogy, didn't satisfy me the way that the earlier novels, Lion Country and Open Heart did. It's a little puzzling, because the characters hadn't worn thin before. As I began reading Love Feast, I was glad to reencounter Leo Bebb, founder of the Church of Holy Love, Inc., and purveyor of instant religious diplomas, who Instead of mortifying his flesh before his Lord, occasionally exposes it to his congregation. I had missed Laverne Brownie Brown, with his freewheeling interpretations or the scriptures and his habit of addressing everyone as dear". (You know the old prayer Keep me ever restless until I find my rest in thee.... Rest doesn't mean a nap, dear.). And though Leo Bebb's wife, Lucille, who used to sit all day sipping Tropicanas in front of a TV set with the green turned up too high, has long since committed suicide, and the ancient millionaire Indian Herman Redpath, who used to exploit Holy Love, Inc., as a sex restorative, has long since gone to the Happy Hunting Ground in the Sky, I was happy to find their spirits still very much present in Love Feast.

title: MOSCOW STEPS UP ANTIU.S.CARTOONS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24After a honeymoon with the new Administration of President Ford, the Soviet press has embarked on an upswing in antiAmerican propaganda described by the United States embassy as the strongest in a year or more.

title: Slavery Charge Termed Ridiculous by Farmer
description: Michael Sorbello, a Swedesboro farmer, said yesterday that the Federal grand jury indictment Monday of his foreman on charges of keeping Puerto Rican laborers in slavery was ridiculous. Arthur H. West, president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, a statewide organization of farmers, echoed the statement.

title: ROCKEFELLER GIVES ATTICA DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24In his second day before the Senate Rules Committee, Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller defended today his role in the Attica, N.Y., prison revolt in 1971 and explained his views on subjects ranging from mass transit to the disposition of the Nixon tapes.

title: People and Business
description: William J. Feltner, whi has been a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers since October, 1973, confirmed yesterday that he planned to leave his post next Fenruary after the council completed its annual report to the President. Mr. Fenner, who is 69, emphasized that his decision was not based on any policy disagreements or disenchantment with Government work.

title: Parking Rules Eased
description: Alternate sideof the street parking regulations will be sus:, pended tomorrow for the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the Department of Traffic announced, Only the following regulations. will be suspended: alternate side parking restrictions either from 8 A.M. to 11 A.M., or 11 A.M. to 2 P.M., and, in the garment district, 2 A.M. to 6 A.M. Parking meter regulations and all other parking and standing rules will remain in effect.

title: Israel to Define Territorial Objective Before Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 24Israel intends to draft specific political and territorial proposalsincluding mapsin preparation for her next round of negotiations with her Arab neighbors, a senior Government official said today.

title: 3 Cities File.a Suit On State School Aid
description: The state's three largest cities New York, Buffalo and Rochester  yesterday challenged the constitutionality of the state's education aid formula, charging that under it the large cities have been arbitrarily shortchanged.Cities Challenge State Grants To Schools as Discriminatory

title: CLARK URGES RISE IN BENEFITS HERE
description: Ramsey Clark, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, suggested yesterday that Social Security benefits for those in metroPolitan areas where the cost of living exceeded the national average be increased to equalize this disparity.

title: U.S.State Dispute Snags Milk Adulteration Inquiry
description: Ten months after the Dairylea Cooperative admitted to adulterating thousands of gallons of milk and falsifying records to cover it up, neither state nor Federal lawenforcement agencies have begun criminal investigations against the individuals responsible because of what the agencies indicate is confusion over jurisdiction and a lack of communication.

title: Japanese Premier Links Oil Question To Peace of World
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 24  Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan said here today that the question of oil prices was related to the peace of the world. He said also that there was need for a frank and open worldwide assessment of the problem.

title: $6Billion Pipeline For Gas Is Proposed
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24The El Paso Company announced here today that it has filed a formal application with the Federal Power Commission for approval of a controversial allAmerican $6billion project to bring Alaskan natural gas to the lower 48 states.

title: State Mental System Called One of Worst
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Leading authorities of the American Psychiatric Association said today that the New York State mentalhealth system was among the worst in the country and that similar agencies in all other states were working poorly..

title: HEALTH AID PLAN VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Senate overwhelmingly approved today legislation designed to induce medical and dental schools to designate 25 Per cent of their students for future service in medically underserved areas.

title: Artists Families Needing Aid Get It From Rauschenberg's Group
description: Robert Rauschenberg, one of the country's most important modern painters, can still remember when.. when he left Port Arthur, Tex.. when he earned living expenses working as a window display man... when $50 meant more to me than $50,000 does now.

title: TREASURY OFFERS TWOYEAR NOTES
description: The Treasury auctioned $2billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average rate of 8.34 per cent as Treasury securities trading in the secor dary, market fell in price following their recent strong runup. The moves in the secondary market were attributed to profit taking by dealers.

title: Kaiser Sets Steel Imports
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI)  The Kaiser Steel Corporation has agreed in principle to import semifinished steel from a group of Japanese mills, finish it and sell it on the United States market. About 160,000 tons are to be imported in the next two years by Kaiser. The company said the Japanese imports would enable it to keep its finishing plant at Fontana, Calif., running at full capacity.

title: Trade With Bulgaria
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce and its Bulgarian counterpart have signed an agreement establishing a new BulgarianUnited States economic council to promote trade. Details on Page 55.

title: Worst Violators of Rules on Posters Are Listed
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administrator yesterday made public a list of political candidates who he said were the 12 most flagrant violators of city rules against placing campaign posters on public property.

title: Relief Is Slow in Reaching the Victims of Honduran Hurricane
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Sept. 24Vast supplies of food, medicine and clothing have been arriving from abroad for victims of last week's hurricane, but they are not reaching the needy fast enough.

title: Red Smith
description: In Bill Virdon's first season as manager of the Pirates, the team finished first in the National. League East with the best Wonlost record in the majors. When he was tired the following September, not because of any shortcoming on his part but because Joe L. Brown, the general manager, suffers from the curious delusion that nobody except Danny Murtaugh can manage a team, the Pirates were second with decidedly brighter prospects than the Mets, who then came on to beat Pittsburgh back to third. The Pittsburgh sports writer, Charley Feeney, protested that Virdon had not been given a chance to lose. He won't have that trouble with the Yankees, Charley was assured when New York took Virdon on for 1974. They've been losing for a decade. Today, six games away from the finish, Virdon still has a chance to lose. Whether he seizes the opportunity or rejects it, he ought to be a shooin as the American League's manager of the year. (It might seem to some that if Earl Weaver can bring the Orioles on to beat the Yankees at the wire, he ought to receive that distinction but the higher power that decides these things ignores Weaver unless his team loses.) Sports of The Time.

title: Music Fete in Zaire Has Poor Box Office But Makes a Big Hit
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 24A threeday music festival of African and black American musicZaire 74ended here just before 6 A.M. today with disappointing cash receipts but claims by its producers of fantastic success.

title: MAFIA TAPS MAFIA; TWO ARE INDICTED
description: Organizedcrime members in Brooklyn have been wiretapping the telephones of their enemies illegally in attempts to gain the advantage in the currept mpb wars, Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold said yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The United States Chamber of Commerce and its Bulgarian counterpart signed an agreement today establishing a new BulgarianUnited States economic council, aimed at expanding trade and other economic relations between the two countries.

title: MANILA TRADE TIE WITH PEKING SET
description: MANILA, Sept. 24  China and the Philippines, which do not have diplomatic relations, have concluded an informal trade agreement.

title: THE MODERN JOINS IN ROTHKO BATTLE

title: Bank Robber Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI)Leaster Smith, the former commonlaw wife of John Clutchette, one of the Soledad Brothers has been sentenced to six years in Federal prison as the Robin Hood bandit who held up 10 banks and gave some of the loot to the poor.

title: NBC to Cover Salute To Congress of 1774
description: NBCTV will provide live coverage at 12:30 this afternoon of the House of Representative's 200th anniversary celebration of the institution of the First Continental Congress.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The House of Representatives, ignoring the pleas of its own leaders and Secretary of State Kissinger, voted 307 to 90 yesterday to suspend military aid to Turkey until substantial progtess is made toward a Cyprus settlement. The cutoff was appended to an otherwise routine measure and sent to the Senate, which last week urged President Ford to halt the aid to Turkey.[1:8.]

title: HOUSE APPROVES MEASURE TO HALT ARMS AID TO TURKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The House of Representatives rejecting appeals from its own leaders and from Secretary of State Kissinger, voted overwhelmingly today to cut off military aid to Turkey until substantial progress had been achieved toward a military settlement on Cyprus.

title: Hicks Getting Painful Feel of Giant Line
Opera:Met Starts Its 90th
HAROLD W. WEBB, 90, TAUGHT AT COLUMBIA
description: Harold W. Webb, a retired Columbia University physics professor, died Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, East Orange, N.J. He was 90 years old and lived at 328 Westview Avenue, Leonia, N.J.

title: 100 Hurt in Wreck in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 24 (AP)At least 100 people were injured today when, express train hit a deraile freight 40 miles north of Tokyo, officials said.

title: 10% of the Nation's Gas Stations Closed in a Year
description: Almost 20,000, or about 10 per cent, of the nation's gasoline stations were forced out of business between June 30, 1973 and June 30, 1974 according to a, private, but authoritative survey of the country's retail distribution.

title: Eva H. Simons, 77, Dies; Led New School Concerts
description: Eva Haym Simons, widow of Dr. Hans Simons, a president of the New School for Social Research, died Sunday at the Riverdale Nursing Home in the Bronx. She was 77 years old and lived at 85 Landscape Avenue, Ygnkers.

title: College Advises on Snakes
description: OROVILLE, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI)Students registering at the new Butte College in a rural area north of here have been told not to panic if they are bitten by a rattlesnake. The 5,000student campus opened for the first time yesterday. During construction workers found 44 rattlesnakes.

title: Kiah Sayles Is Dead at 56; An Aide to Sports Figures
description: Hezekiah (Kiah) L. Sayles Jr., a former associate of. Joe Louis, the boxer, and of Jackie Robinson, the baseball player, died Friday of cancer in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old.

title: GARDEN RETURNS TO PROFITABILITY
Jersey jobless Fund Faces Need to Borrow From U.S.
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24Because of the state's high unemployment rate, the New Jersey unemployment insurance fund will be bankrupt within a matter of months and Trenton, for the first time, will have to borrow from the Federal Government to pay unemployment benefits to the state's jobless, high state officials disclosed today.

title: FOREBODING EASES ON CONFERENCES
description: As the Ford Administration's program to curb inflation heads for a twoday conference in Washington Friday and Saturday, it appears that a number of potential obstacles that the President and his aides had feared might, disrupt a series of preliminary meetings have been surmounted.

title: SEPT.1120 SALES OF CARS OFF 5.6.%
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24Domestic newcar sales declined 5.6 per cent to an estimated 190,000 units in the Sept. 11.20 period from 201,447 units a years earlier.

title: CBS Defends Lack of TV For Rockefeller's Hearings
description: Richard S. Salant, president of CBS News, yesterday defended the network's decision not to provide live coverage of Congressional hearings on the confirmation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President.

title: What's More Eternal Than the Eternal City? The Dominant. Party in Italy's Government
description: ROMEObservers like to point out that political instability is one of the causes of the transitoriness of Italian Governments. None of them, in fact, have lasted more than a year since the end of World War II.

title: Body Found Off S. I.
description: The body of a man reported missing when an Exxon pier collapsed last Friday in Bayonne, N.J., was recovered yesterday in the waters off Staten Island, the police reported. He was identified tentatively as Aaron Brokaw, 32 years old.

title: DR. SAMUEL BROCK
description: Dr. Samuel Brock, a neurologist and psychiatrist, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

title: Trial in Paternity Suit Against Biaggi Begins
description: The trial in a patrenity suit against Representative Mario Biaggi by a former campaign worker began yesterday in a closed session at Family Court.

title: Jets Prefer To See O.J. Play Sunday
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 24 The Jets aren't about to send 0. J. Simpson a bouquet of flowers or even a getwell card, but if it'll make 0. J. feel any better, their defense would like to see him play in their game at Buffalo Sunday.

title: French Aide At U.N. on Oil Showdown
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24Foreign Minister JeaN Sauvagnargues of France said today that delegates to the United Nations and their governments seemed appreher sive about the impiicit threats" contained in American state ments about the world energy situation.

title: People in Sports
description: Wilt Chamberlain's situaton remains unsettled. After returning from Europe a few days ago, the 7footlinch basketball star showed up at the San Diego Conquistadors training camp yesterday but in a visiting role,

title: $10Billion Home Mortgage Bill Approved by Senate Bank Unit
SENATE UNIT BACKS FEDERAL CUSTODY OF NIXON'S TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Senate Government Operations Committee approved today three pieces of legislation designed to preserve Government custody of former President Richard M. Nixon's tapes and papers.

title: Yom Kippur Will Begin With Kol Nidre Tonight
description: Yom Kippur, the most sacred day on the Hebrew calendar, begins at sundown today.

title: A Splashy Musical Comedy From the 13th Century
description: The musical comedy was not invented on Broadway, as some popular historians seem to think, but was thriving at least seven centuries ago in the time of Adam de la Halle. The French monk and trouvere, or poetmusician, made a name for himself around the middle of the 13th century with risque plays for which he provided words and music, interweaving speech and song in a way that proved to be a precursor of the style known as opera comique.

title: Kodak Confirms It Has Raised Film Prices
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday confirmed a report that it had increases prices last Friday on a wide, range of commercia films and photographic papers Products for use by amateur photographers were not affected. The increases were reported to be in the range of 7 to 8 per cent, but the company declined to give details.

title: TOPPER FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Copper prices rose yesterday on news from Chile that the Government was studying ways of limiting exports of the metal to lift prices.

title: The Watergate Gap
description: With each passing week, uncertainty increases about filling, in any definitive way, the large, serious remaining gaps in the Watergate story.

title: Public TV to Ease Into Its New Season
description: Unlike the commercial television networks, which screened the premieres of practically all of their series in a single week earlier this month, the Public Broadcasting Service will introduce much of its new schedule sporadically over the next two months.

title: Nomads Driven to Niger By Drought Fear Future
description: NIAMEY, Niger, Sept. 24About 70,000 members of the Tuareg nation, nomads who have never recognized the borders that cut across the desert through which they drive their cattle, have been swept into Niger by the drought and famine of the last years and show no signs of wanting to leave.

title: NO WAR OVER OIL, SCHLESINGER SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States was not contemplating military action against the oilproducing countries in the Middle East, but rather was seeking a solution to rising oil prices through amicable discussions.

title: HALT ORDER IGNORED BY GOV1 LIMOUSINE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25 The state police began an investigation today of an incident in which the Governors limousine, carrying Acting Gov. S. Howard Woodson Jr., exceeded the speed limit and passed by a trooper trying to flag down the vehicle. The incident occurred Tuesday as Mr. Woodson and an aide were returning to the State House from a meeting in Camden.

title: Senator Seeks to Restrict Nixon's Use of Government Employes as Staff Members
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The chairman of a Senate appropriations subcommittee promised today to press for legislation that would limit Richand M. Nixon's use of Government employes as members of' the former President's staff.

title: Screen: SuddenWealth
Tests Show Aerosol Gases May Pose Threat to Earth
description: Two scientists have calculated that gases released by aerosol cans have already accumulated sufficiently in the upper air to begin depleting the ozone that protects the earth from lethal ultraviolet radiation.

title: Crime Figure, Housing Policeman Held in Hijack Plot
HOUSE UNIT MEETS ON CHILEAN LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 A House Armed Services subcommittee today began a proceeding that could lead to disciplinary charges against Representative Michael J. Harrington for his release of secret Central Intelligence Agency testimony on Chile.

title: 2 Coeds Are Found Strangled In Bronx and Brooklyn Homes
description: Two young women, one a student at Brooklyn Community College, the other a student at Bronx Community College, were found strangled Tuesday night in their apartments in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: OPEC OFFICIAL SEES POSSIBLE PRICE RISE
description: VIENNA, Sept. 25 (AP)The Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the world might face 12 per cent rise in the price of oil next year, spread out on a monthtomonth basis.

title: Miss Evert Advances At Denver
description: DENVER, Sept. 25 (UPI)Topseeded Chris Evert beat Kathy Pigeon, 60, 60, last night in the first round of the $50,000 Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament,

title: SOURCE OF LEAKS SOUGHT BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting an inquiry aimed at pinpointing the source of leaks of classified information from its Watergate files to newsmen, a bureau spokesman confirmed today.

title: American Express Finds Some Errors In Its Bank Unit
description: The American Express International Banking Corporation has found irregularities involving perhaps a few million dollars in securities accounts of a small number of clients of its Basel, Switzerland, branch, it was learned yesterday.

title: Yom Kippur Anniversary of War Finds Israelis Sad and Insecure
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 25 Members of the Israeli civil guard will be permitted to carry their weapons while attending Yom Kippur services in synagogues this year, according to a special ruling handed down by Chief Rabbi Shiomo Goren. The rabbi explained that given the events of the Day of Atonement last year, his unusual ruling constituted a justifiable precaution.

title: Foolish Pleasure Scores in Cowdin
description: Just before the main race at Belmont Park. yesterday, the rain came down in a heavy burst. It made no difference, to John Greer's foolish Pleasure. The colt just went out and did what he was expected to do, win the $60,300 Cowdin. To. Foolish Pleasure, the victory was not unusual. It se'rved to extend, his record. to six straight victories, and it, rewarded his backers. in the crowd, of 15,510 with a staight payoff of $3.80 for $2.

title: Court Orders Galley Freed But the Army Will Appeal
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 25United States District Judge J. Robert Elliott overturned today the murder conviction of former Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and ordered him released forthwith from incarceration at Fort Leavenworth in Kansas.

title: NO WAR OVER OIL, SCHLESINGER SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States was not contemplating military action against the oilproducing countries in the Middle East, but rather was seeking a solution to rising oil prices through amicable discussions.

title: Advertising
description: The United States Postal Service has awarded Its $13millionplus advertisin contract to Young & Rubicam The business has been at Needham, Harper & Steers which was a finalist for the account along with Ogilvy & Mather Grey Advertising and Humphrey Browning & MacDougall Boston. Y. & R. will be paid a fee, not receive a media commission on the $10million that will go into media advertising. The contract is good for a year and the Postal Service will have options to renew for two additional years.

title: NO BIG MOVES SEEN FROM I.M.F. MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Next week's annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund is not expected to produce any important decisions or actions, a high Treasury official said today.

title: ExC.A.B. Aide Testifies Podell Sought Air Route
description: A retired official of the Civil Aeronautics Board testified yesterday that Representative Bertram L. Podell hid urged the C.A.B to help a small Florida airline obtain approval of route to the Bahamas.

title: Seghi Gets New Pact
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (UPI)  Phil Seghi, the Cleveland Indians general manager, signed a new twoyear contract today, club officials announced, wiping out the year remaining on his existing agreement.

title: Lebanon's Cabinet Resigns in Dispute Over Gun Controls
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25The Cabinet of Premier Takieddin Solh of Lebanon resigned today.

title: Foolish Pleasure Scores in Cowdin
U.S. Team Questions Honduras Hurricane Estimate
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, Sept. 25  The United States Army's disaster survey team today estimated the death toll from last week's hurricane here to, be considerably lower than that announced by the Honduran Government.

title: VIETNAM TRUCE UNIT IS GIVEN U.S. FUNDS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25The United States today contributed $4 million more to the financially troubled International Commission of Control and Supevision, thereby deferring a financial crisis for about two more months.

title: Mother Pleads for Return
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J. Sept. 25 The mother of George Kaloyerakis, 7yearold kidnapping victim, today made a plea to his abductor for the safe return of the boy as the Federal Bureau of Investigation offically took over the case after a car believed to have been used in the abduction was found in Manhattan.

title: FORD CONSIDERING TAXRELIEF PLAN TO HELP THE POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Ford is sympathetically considering proposing tax relief for lowerincome workers to help them cope with inflation, White House officials said today.

title: Scientific Award to Mark 100th Birthday of Marconi
description: The establishment of a Guglielmo Marconi Await to mark the 100th birthday this year of the radio pioneer was announced yesterday by Dr. Jo seph E. Slater president of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies.

title: A Year Later, the Mideast Ledger
description: WASHINGTONToday is Yom Kippur, the holy day on which Jews both seek atonement for their own acts of violence and read the Book of Jonah to renew their prophetic commitment to oppose the violence of all surrounding Ninevehs.

title: Dave Anderson
description: uietly, the owners of the Cleveland Indians are approaching a historic decision  the selection of Frank Robinson as major league baseball's first black manager.

title: South Pacific Commissioners
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  President Ford announced yesterday the appointment of Stanley S. Carpenter, an Interior Department official, to a twoyear term as senior United States commissioner on the South Pacific Commission. Mr. Ford reappointed Aaron G. Marcus of Honolulu to a similar term as United States commissioner on the panel.

title: People in Sports
description: Zelmo Beaty, whose career in professional basketball spans 11 years, has left the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association to play with the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association. Rumor had been rife for weeks that the move was imminent. The Golden state warriors held the N.B.A. rights to Beaty, so compensation must be made.

title: People and Business
description: George L. Shinn, president of Merrill Lynch & Co., the holding company for the giant brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., has been named chairman of a special industry committee to study the feasibility of a merger between the New York and the American stock exchanges, the Securities Industry Association said yesterday.

title: Tests Show Aerosol Gases May Pose Threat to Earth
description: Two scientists have calculated that gases released by aerosol cans have already accumulated sufficiently in the upper air to begin depleting the ozone that prOtects the earth from lethal ultraviolet radiation

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WIDENED IN MONTH TO REACH RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The United States had a record monthly deficit of more than $1.1billion in its trade with foreign countries in August the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 2 Key Indian States Hit by Crop Failures
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 25India's two key foodproducing states, the Punjab and Haryana, are suffering major crop failures because of drought and acute power shortages.

title: Mother in Jersey Pleads For Her Kidnapped Son
Foreman Bows to Pressure, Will Fight Ali Oct. 29
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 25 George Foreman, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said late tonight that he would definitely defend his title here against Muhammad, Ali on the night of Oct. 29, New York time.

title: Seattle Paper Raises Price
description: SEATTLE Sept. 25 (UPI)The Seattle PostIntelligencer announced today it was raising its newstand price from 10 to 15 cents, effective Sept. 30 The increase is the first newsstand price increase for the paper in 13 years.

title: BONN TURNS DOWN FARM PRICE MOVE
description: BONN, Sept. 25The West German cabinet refused today to ratify the European Common Market decision to raise farm price supports by 5 per cent until its eight partners agree to drop protectionist measures. It also called for a review of the bloc's agricultural policy.

title: Europeans Confer on Oil With Arabs at U.N. Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 25Representatives of the nine European Commor Market countries and of 18 Arab League nations met here today amid suggestions that their joint efforts might help avoid a confrontation between oil producing and oil consuming nations.

title: 3 World Marks Set At Lexington Track
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 25 (AP)  Three world records were shattered today, the opening day of the 99th Grand Circuit meeting at the Red Mile here. Nero, driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $34,845 Meadowlands stake race with a combined time of 3:53 3/5 for the two elimination heats.

title: Brezhnev Hails Ford on Detente Policy
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25In his first public comment on the change in American leadership, Leonid I. Brezhnev today hailed President Ford's pledge to pursue joint efforts to improve SovietAmerican relations.

title: Jack Paar's Mother Dies
description: Lillian Paar, mother of the entertainer Jack Paar, died of a heart attack Tuesday in a Norwalk, Conn., hospital. Mrs. Paar who lived in Indianapolis, was visiting her son in New Canaan, Conn. Also surviving are a daughter and four grandchildren. Mrs. Paar waS the widpw Of Howard Paar, a railroad Man.

title: Billows Captures State Senior Golf
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 25  Ray Billows, a 60yearold golfer from Poughkeepsie, won the New York State men's senior championship by five shots at the Grossinger Country Club today with a 54hole total of 233.

title: New Discount Rate On Some of Its Loans Established by Fed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) The Federal Reserve Board set a new discount rate today for banks that borrow unusually large amounts over an extended period from the Federal Reserve system.

title: SOUTH AFRICA POLICE BREAK UP 2 RALLIES
description: CAPE TOWN, Sept. 25South African police, using dogs, tonight dispersed a crowd of 700 blacks and some white students who were gathering in Durban to attend an illegal rally in support of the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique.

title: Head of F.P.C. Concedes Potential Interest Clash
