description: WASHINGTON, Sept.25  John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission told a Congressional committee today that there had indeed been potential conflicts of interest in the ownership by commission employes of stock in energy companies.

title: WILLIAM SLOANE, 68, PUBLISHER, IS DEAD
description: William M. Sloane, a bookl, publisher and writer, died yesterday at his home in New City, N.Y. He was 68 years old and lived at 44 South Mountain Road.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CUTS VENTURE IN URANIUM
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (UPI)  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today it was halting investment in Uranium Enrichment Associates, a joint corporate venture to determine the possibilities of private industry entering the uranium enrichment business.

title: Illinois Loses McCray
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 25 (UPI)  Mike McCray, a sophomore quarterback of the University of Illinois, will undergo back surgery and miss the rest of the season and spring practice, the Illini coach, Bob Blackman, said today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: JACKSON, Wyo.  We clambered up a wooded ridge known as Timbered Island near the Moose entrance of Grand Teton National Park at dawn, to make the, sounds that inspire an amorous bull elk to combat.

title: ROCKEFELLER BALKS ON PRIVILEGE ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Senate Rules Committee concluded its twoandahalf day interrogation of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller today, with Mr. Rockefeller refusing to commit himself on how he would apply the doctrine of executive privilege should he succeed to the Presidency.

title: Toward Cyprus Peace
description: The overwhelming approval by the House of a binding cutoff in military aid to Turkey until substantial progress is made toward a Cyprus settlement dramatizes American revulsion against the massive Turkish aggression on the island. The 307to90 vote was also aimed at forcing Administration compliance with laws that mandate such a cutoff when a recipient country misuses American military assistance.

title: Kissinger on Balance
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25At his confirmation hearings a year ago, Secretary of State Kissinger was asked his view of C.I.A. covert operations. He replied in terms of American values: I would say that our genius does not reside in clandestine activities on a broad scale. He added the caveat that he thought it would be dangerous to abolish certain types of these activities.

title: Worry Rises That Rockies; Face Pollution and Crowds
description: EAST GLACIER, Montana, Sept. 6Vast sections of the Rocky Mountain West this country's last relatively unspoiled natural regionare on their way to becoming cluttered and polluted industrial wastelands filled with raw boom towns, and social misfits as a result of the drive to exploit the region's energy and mineral wealth.

title: HYLAND STUDYING USE OF DUMDUMS
description: TRENTONAttorney General William F. Hyland is investigating the use of a controversial powerpoint bullet that has been adopted in recent months by the state police and a growing number of municipal police forces.

title: Steamer Defeated By Southmen, 173
JOHN A. BRADLEY, 79, EXTIMES REPORTER
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 25 (AP)John A. Bradley, retired reporter for The New York Times, died here yesterday in a hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A program of 12 shortsubject films, produced here and abroad, will complement the 21 features to be presented at the 12th annual New York Film Festival starting tomorrow.

title: Coast Court Accepts Nixon Bar Resignation
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 25 (AP)The California Supreme Court accepted today former President Richard M. Nixon's resignation from the state bar.

title: 2 Aged Women Found Slain In Apartment in Mt. Vernon
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 25 (UPI)Two old women were found murdered today in the bedroom of their apartment on the sixth floor of a center for the aged.

title: Geography Society In Need of Funds
description: Just after the American Geographical Society was founded in New York in 1852, one of its first efforts was a daring campaign for the construction of a railroad all the way from the populous East Coast; across the wild and unexplored interior of the United States, to the distant PaCific Coast.

title: U.S. AGENT IS FREED IN NARCOTICS DEATH
description: SAN FRANCISCO Sept. 25 (AP)A judge dismissed murder charge today against Federal narcotics agent who fatally shot a man fleeing a 1972 raid on a suspected drug laboratory in a mountain cabin.

title: SADAT BIDS HEGAZI TAKE PREMIERSHIP
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat moved today to relinquish the Premiership, appointing First Deputy Premier AbdI Aziz Hegazi to take over the post and form a new Cabinet.

title: Giants'
description: Pete Gogolak, the New York Giants placekicker, was instrumental in alerting the Darien, Conn., police to a burglary going on in a neighbor's home on Tuesday. which led to the shootout that left two of the alleged. robbers dead and third seriously wounded on the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: C.A.B. Orders the Airlines To Cut Security Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON; Sept. 25 Asserting that most airlines have been making an improper, indirect profit from their antiskyjacking procedures, the Civil Aeronautics Board ordered reduced passenger surcharges, for airport security today.

title: White House Is Said to Be Considering Con Ed's Roddis as No. 2 Energy Aide
description: The White House was reported yesterday to be considering the appointment of Louis H. Roddis Jr., the No. man at the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, to be the No. 2 man in the Federal Energy Administration.

title: WITNESS RECALLS SATKIN PAYMENTS
description: PATERSON, Sept. 25A secretary testified under a grant of immunity today in Superior Court that a Passaic landlord she worked for paid an arsonist $700 to set a fire last year in three buildings that killed a woman and three children.

title: Basques Book Tells How They Killed Spanish Premier
description: PARIS, Sept, 25  The Basque terrorists who killed Premier Luis Carrero Blanco of Spain last December say in a book just published that they also contemplated killing Secretary of State Kissinger at the same time.

title: Tracy S. Voorhees Dead at 84; Was Assistant Army Secretary
description: Tracy S. Voorhees, a Govern ment official and a lawyer, died yesterday at his summer home at Sugar Hill, N. H; He was 84 years old and lived at 184 Columbia Heights in Brooklyn.

title: Stephen Leacock Jr. Dies
description: ORILLIA, Ontario, Sept. 25 (AP)Stephen Leacock Jr., the only child of the Canadian, humorist, was found dead at his home here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 591 years old. Mr. Leacock was a former instructor of English at Montreal's McGill University.

title: National Gallery Buys A French Masterwork
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has acquired one of the extremely rare paintings of the 17thcentury French artist Georges de La Tom The gallery is known to consider the painting. its most important acquisruvit since it bought a portrait. by Leonardo da Vinci in 1967 from Prince Franz Josef II of Liechtenstein at price of $5million to $6million.

title: An Alleged ,Victim Of Confessed Slayer Refutes His Story
description: A 74yearold woman who had, reportedly been identified by Calvin Jackson as one of the 10 women he told the police he had murdered at the Park Plaza Hotel said yesterday that Mr. Jackson was not the man who had attempted to kill her.

title: STUDENTS IN BOSTON GO TO ARBITRATOR
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Delegations of white and black students planned to sit down tomorrow with a private arbitrator to try to hash out the racial problems that have erupted into violence at Hyde Park High School in the first two weeks of forced integration of the city's schools.

title: 3,000 Policemen Attend Rites For Slain Yorkers Patrolman
description: YONKERS, Sept. 25 (AP)More than 3,000 policemen, many with tears in their eyes, attended funeral services today for Patrolman Harold Woods; who died Sunday of wounds suffered during a supermarket holdup early last week.

title: Police Identification Faulty
description: The Police Department incorrectly identified the four officers who were named in an article in yesterday's Times as being present at 345 Fountain Avenue in Brooklyn when Eugene Gregory, a distraught knifewielding man, was shot and killed. The correct names of the four are: Richard Fleming, who fired the single shot that killed Mr. Gregory; William Cooney, William Gluck and Robert Bernabo.

title: Nassau District Attorney Given Hernandez Case
description: The case of Sandino Hernandez, the jockey who was apprehended last Friday after he was alleged to have been in possession of a battery, was referred yesterday to the office of the Nassau County District Attorney by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Cut in Prime Rate
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that they were reduc ing the prime rate  the interest rates they charge on loans to the most creditworthy corporationsto 11 per cent from 12 per cent. Details on Page 39.

title: Fire Damages CityOwned Tenement
description: Fire, believed to be the work of an arsonist, broke out yesterday in a dilapidated fourstory Brooklyn tenement where disgruntled residents complained afterward of neglect, poor service and deterioration permitted by the landlordthe City of New York.

title: Jersey Investigates Police Use of Bullet Opposed by A.C.L.U.
description: TRENTON, Sept.25Attorney General William F. Hyland is investigating the use of a controversial powerpoint bullet that has been adopted in recent, months by the state police and a growing number of municipal police forces.

title: PHILLIPS OFFICIAL DENIES A CONFLICT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Testimony before a House subcommittee today portrayed an oil industry executive who was on loan to the Treasury Department as actively involved in shaping oil and propane regulations, despite a department memorandum intended to keep him from running afoul of the conflictofinterest statutes.

title: GREENSPAN URGES BUDGET CUTS NOW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Alan Greenspan, President Ford's chief economic adviser, sought to persuade a skeptical House Budget Committee today that rising Government spending and borrowing were the root cause of inflation and that a budget cut now was important.

title: GOING OUT guide
description: AGES OF MAN I Anthropology is a field not long for this world, some people say, because primitive societies are succumbing more and more to the traumatic effects of modernism. On the other hand, more and more anthropologists are responding by studying how those same primitive societies have been forced to change and adapt.

title: 3 Runs in..9th Send Tigers to 54 Defeat
Accord in Utility Strike
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 25 (UPI)The Kansas City Power & Light Company reached tentative agreement last night on money issues with three locals of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers to end a 78day strike. Utility supervisors and executives have maintained service to customers in Missouri and Kansas since the strike began.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The same 38 items in the Market Basket of a family of four, cost $62.84 last week, 64 cents more than a week earlier and up from $55.27 a year ago, according to figures released yesterday by the Department of Consumer Affairs. The consumer's wallet has become a disaster area, said Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor C. Guggenheimer.

title: 2 COMPUTER MAKERS LIFT RENTAL PRICES
description: Two more computer makers Honeywell, Inc., and the Memorex Corporationjoined other major manufacturers in raising rental prices. Honeywell said it was lifting its domestic rental and selvice charges in a range from 2 to 10 per cent, effective Oct. 1 except where contracts require 90day notification.

title: 2 Hotels Called Centers of Crime
description: Two huge singleroomoccurancy hotels, only a few hundred yards apart on Manhattan's upper West Side, have become the city's most crimeridden buildings, the police said yesterday.

title: London Stocks Plunge
description: LONDON, Sept 25 (Reuters) Stock prices plunged to a 16year low on the London Stock Exchange today as a massive wave of selling hit the market. The Financial Times index of 30 leading industrial stocks dropped 8.5 points to close at 182.7, its lowest level since August 12, 1958.

title: U.S. Controller Is, Sued by Big Board
National Gallery Buys A French Masterwork
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has acquired one of the extremely rare paintings of the 17thcentury French artist Georges de La Tour. The gallery is known to consider the painting its most important acquisition since it bought a portrait by Leonardo da Vinci in 1967 from Prince Franz Josef II of Liechtenstein at a price of $3million to $6million,

title: City Firemen's Union Endorses Wilson as'Eminenttly Qualified
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association, which represents the city's 10,800 firemen, announced yesterday its endorsement of Governor Wilson.

title: Cut in Prime Rate
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that they were reducing the prime rate  the interest rates they charge on loans to the most creditworthy corporationsto 11 per cent from 12 per cent. Details on Page 39.

title: Stars Confirm Transfer to Charlotte
description: The migration of World Football League teams into the Deep South and reports of floods of red ink all over the league continued yesterday as the New York Stars officially announced their sale and shift to Charlotte, N. C., effective immediately.

title: Beatrice Foods Raises Its Sales and Net Income
Health Insurance Plan Wins 11.1% Rise
description: The State Insurance Department has approved a rate crease for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York that will raise rates as much as 13.4 per cent for some subscribers and cost the city an extra $3.3million in premiums for municipal employes.

title: ISRAELIS AGAIN RAID SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 25 (Reuters)  Israeli Air Force planes today attacked guerrilla targets for the second consecutive day.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania has voluntarily reported that he paid no Federal income taxes from 1967 through 1969. Mr. Shapp, a candidate for reelection, said also that for the last eight years he has reported total income of $11.5million and paid about $2.9million on that income. In 1966, Mr. Shapp said, he paid $2million in taxes, due largely to income from the sale of an electronics company he had founded.

title: SERWIN IS GRANTED  A STAY OF SENTENCE
description: A STAY OF SENTENCE TRENTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)Former Secretary of State Paul Sherwin today was granted a stay of sentence in his bribery conspiracy convection until the State suprime Court de cides wheather to hear his casse

title: A.&
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25The County Executive's office announced today that the A. & P. supermarket chain had agreed to participate in a fivemonth old program offering discounts to the elderly.

title: 3 Bodies Found Off Texas
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Coast Guard said today that a shrimp boat with the bodies of two men and a woman aboard had been found drifting about eight miles south of Port Aransas. The Nueces County Medical Examiner said that the three had apparently died from gas poisoning and that no foul play was evident. The bodies were not immediately identified.

title: Miss Decker to Run
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Amateur Athletic Union announced today that Mary Decker, 15 years old, of Garden Grove, Calif., the leading women's halfmiler, had accepted an invitation to run in meets in Tokyo and Kobe, Japan. The A.A.U. said the 98pound, 5foot4inch high school junior would compete in the 800meter run at the Japan women's athletic meet Sept. 28 and 29 in Kobe City

title: Opera: Turandot at Met
description: Alberto Erede, who had not conducted at the Metropolitan Opera for 20 years, was back with the company on Tuesday night for its first performance of Turandot of the season. The Italian conductor had not previously led the Puccini work here before.

title: HOUSE FACES RIFT ON REORGANIZING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Despite a warning that it would tear. the Congress all to pieces, the House Rules Committee today sent two rival proposals. to reorganize House committees to the floor for what is expected to be aJong and hitter, fight next week.

title: Honduras Relief Group Set Up at Church, Here
description: The Honduras Emergency Committee, under the direction of the Honduran consulate, has been set up at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church, at 30 West 16th Street.

title: Personal Finance
description: Although most securities have suffered sharp declines in recent months, new investors are coming into the market to take advantage of what they believe to be good buys.

title: DEALERSHIP LIMITS FOUGHT BY OILMEN
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)Representatives of major oil companies and independent service stations clashed today at a hearing on a bill designe,d to eliminate companyowned service stations in New Jersey.

title: Jones to Resign as Publisher of Amsterdam News
description: Clarence B. Jones, who three years ago became publisher and editor of The New York Am. sterdam News in a major transfer of ownership, will resign those positions at the end of next month.

title: Chess: Time Pressure a Factor As Fifth Game Adjourns
Lefkowitz, in a Reversal, Says MilkAdulteration Inquiry Is On
description: In an apparent reversal of his earlier reported position, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he is, in fact, conducting an investigation into the adulteration of milk by the Dairylea cooperative from 1967 to 1973.

title: TV: Most PrimeTime Characters Share Single Distinction
description: Wedded life may still be touted, in, conjunction with the myth of bliss but it has become a distinct liability in the peculiar arena of television programing. The dominant position in primetime entertainment is now monopolized by what the ad agencies might refer to as the unmarrieds.

title: Soybeans Up Limit For 3d Day in Row
description: For the third day in a row soybean prices jumped the 20centabushel limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. At the close, however, distant deliveries showed easting tendencies in contrast to Monday and Tuesday's firm closings.

title: Solomon Is Upset at Coast Net
U. OF TEXAS HEAD OUSTED IN DISPUTE
description: AUSTIN, Tex, Sept. 25beep divisions between the administration and faculty of the University of Texas resulted today in the appointment of Dr. Lorene L. Rogers to succeed Dr. Stephen H. Spurr, who was dismissed yesterday as president of the Austin campus.

title: Youth Dies of Injuries
description: LAUREL, Miss., Sept. 25 (UPI)  A Meridian, Miss., high school football player died here early today from head injuries sustained in a B team game against Laurel Sept. 16. Gary Scott Castle, a 15year old, 130pound guard, leit the game in the second half when he became dizzy. He was rushed to the hospital, where he underwent surgery, but he never regained consciousness.

title: 500, at City Hall, Protest Reese Slaying
description: More than 500 people marched around City Hall yesterday to protest the fatal shooting Sept. 15 of Claude Reese Jr., a 14yearold black boy, by a white policeman. Carrying a banner that read Stop Killer Cops and shouting epithets such as Drop dead at a ring of uniformed policemen, the demonstrators, mostly black youths who had come by chartered bus from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, where the shooting occurred, then massed without incident on nearby Murray Street for an hour of speeches.

title: Shearson Hayden Obtains $5Millions In Loans by Banks
description: Shearson Hayden Stone, Inc a new brokerage house formed between Hayden, Stone, Inc., and Shearson, Hammill & Co., Inc., said yesterday that it had obtained $5million in new loans from the First National City Bank and the Continental. Illinois National Bank and, Trust Company  raising its;, bank debt to $19.2million.

title: Dr. Robert Evans, 62, Dies; Hematologist and Teacher
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (AP)Dr. Robert S. Evans, hematologist and one of the senior faculty members at the. University of Washington School of Medicine, was killed today in a threecar collision near here. He was 62 years old and lived in Redmond, a suburb.

title: Tugs Free Dutch Tanker Off Southern Tip of Chile
description: PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, Sept. 25 (AP)The Dutch oil tanker Metula, caught on rocks in the Straits of Magellan at the tip of South America since Aug. 9 was freed today by tugs the Chilean navy said.

title: F.T.C STANDS FIRM ON QUESTIONNAIRE
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 25The Federal Trade Commission Was rejected the initial legal maneuver of a group of 193 maJor United States corporations to kill a controversial program requiring them to report on the profits and sales of the different products they manufacture.

title: Cardinals Regain Top Spot
New Jersey Briefs
description: State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke denied diplomas yesterday to eight of nine Burlington highschool seniors who missed more than 30 days of school last year. He said the students must attend makeup classe sto complete course requirements for their diplomas.

title: Suspect Convicted in Teacher's Murder
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 25  A.Middlesex County Court jury today returned two guilty verdicts against Frederick Krug, a 27yearold East Brunswick man, on charges of kidnapping and Murdering Phyllis Thomson, 28, on Sept. 2, 1973.

title: City Board Decides Tomorrow On Modification of Rent Rises
description: The city's Rent Guidelines Board is expected to decide tomorrow on a major modification of the highly controversial rentrise limits affecting some 400,000 apartments here.

title: France Imposes Fuel Cuts And Limit on Oil Imports
description: PARIS, Sept. 25The French Cabinet set a $10.1billion ceiling today on spending for oil imports next year and ordered cutbacks in industrial and home heating consumption. The action was one of the strongest yet taken by any Western nation to reduce fuel bills.

title: Wilson and Carey to Get New Scripts for TV Ad Blitz
description: The two gubernatorial candidates are planning new sets of television commercials for extensive schedules of electronic stumping with the Wilson campaign budgeting $1.2million for TV advertising and the Carey camp room imp that i can afford about half that much.Governor Wilson's ads including a new series that will move from the initial statesmanGovernor approach to that of more actively criticizing the Carey record, have already be gun on a daily basis during these final six weeks before the election.

title: Nixon's Lung Damaged by Blood Clot
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 25A piece of a blood clot has broken off from former President Richard M. Nixon's phlebitisdamaged left leg, floated through his heart and destroyed a dimesized area in his right lung without causing any chest pain, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

title: Child's Skeleton Brings Arrest Of Man Here in Son's 70 Death
description: The accidental discovery of a child's skeleton last month in a limepacked suitcase in the basement of a Bronx tenement led last night to the arrest of a 30yearold man who was charged with having killed his 8yearold son more than four years ago.

title: Ford Names Educator
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)President Ford today named Bruce H. Hasenkamp, 36 years old, an education consultant, to be director of the President's Commission on White House Fellowships. Mr. Hasenkamp is a former assitant dean of Stanford Law School.

title: Sauce for the Gander
description: WASHINGTONNelson Rockefeller told the Senate this week that he paid not one shiny dime of Federal Income taxes for the year 1970.

title: Screen: Early Spring, From Japan
DAY OF ATONEMEN OBSERVED BY JEWS
description: Yom Kippur began last nigh with rabbis here delivering sermons that emphasized the ethi cal, moral and spiritual value of the day and the need for men and nations to apply them achieving a world peace.

title: JOHN M'CARTEN, 63, WRITER AND CRITIC
description: John McCarten, writer for The New Yorker magazine for 40 years and its film or drama critic for about 20 of them, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. McCarten, who had lived in Dublin for the last six years, was 63 years old.

title: Suffolk Standstill Budget Offered to Match Inflation
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 25 John V. N, Klein, the Suffolk Cnunty Executive, today proposed what he described as a $473.5million standstill budget for fiscal 1975, saying the 14 per cent rise in spending had been caused by inflation rather than new programs and would mean a substantial increase in property taxes.

title: Saving Wildlife
description: The more we urbanize, the more we crowd out destroy wild life. The plow, the chain saw, the bulldozer and the automobile undeniably are the worst enemies foxes, raccoons, skunks, rabbbits, deer. But over the years man has managed to rescue some birds and animals threatened with extinction or decimation, as figures from the Wildlife Management Institute show.

title: Judge Acquits a Protester Who Felled Weather Tower
description: GREENFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)Samuel Lovejoy, accused of destroying a weather tower as a protest against a proposed nuclear plant, wa acquitted by a judge today.

title: ExC.A.B. Aide Testifies Podell Sought Air Route
description: A retired official of the Civil Aeronautics Board testified yesterday that Representative Bertram L. Podell had urged the C.A.B to help a small Florida airline obtain approval of route to the Bahamas.

title: F.D.A. Said. to Be Lax on New Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Doctors accused the. Food and Drug Administration today of laxity in dealing with manufacturers applications to market drugs that have been questioned on safety grounds.

title: Bridge: California Bidding Style Being Used With Success
description: A style of bidding that is littleknown in New York but finds favor among Californian experts is Walsh. Its originator, Dick Walsh, has retired from tournament play, but two of his former teammates are using it with success: Paul Soloway and John Swanson of Los Angeles will play it in the world team championship in Bermuda in January.

title: Yanks Win in 10th, 10; Orioles Cling to First
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON A NOKNOCK CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)Senate and House negotiators have agreed on legislation to revoke controversial noknock powers of Federal narcotics agents and the District of Columbia police.

title: Judge Gesell Bars Effort To Void Pardon of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of United States District Court here refused a request today from a New York law professor that the pardon President Ford granted former President Richard M. Nixon be declared unconstitutional.

title: Dtente
description: No one is going to oppose the ideal of SovietAmerican dtente, in its pure meaning, any more than one would willingly choose a world of tension and hostility preference to a generation of peace. The issue whether the pursuit of detente is being wisely conducted, with proper regard for fundamental interests and full realization of pitfalls as well as rewards.

title: The Real War on Crime
description: By any yardstick of reporting and bookkeeping, the 47 per cent rise in violent crime in the past five years constitutes an appalling record. The Nixon Administration's muchtouted war on crime and the obedient legislative response by a gettough Congress can now be put down as predictable failures. Noknock powers police search and other authoritarian measures that were to unfetter the law in rooting out criminals did more to undermine the liberties of the innocent than to curb the illegal acts of the guilty.

title: TEXAN BUYS SHARE OF CAPITAL PAPER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)Joseph L. Allbritton, millionaire banker from Texas, has been named chairman of the board and chief executive officer of The Washington StarNews.

title: FORD CONSIDERING TAXRELIEF PLAN: TO HELP THE POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25President Ford is sympathetically considering proposing tax relief for lowerincome workers to help them cope with inflation, White House officials said today.

title: Financial Follies Set
description: The Financial Follies, an annual lampoon of the year's activities in finance, business and government, will be held on Nov. 15 at the AmericanaHotel. Tickets for the dinnershow are available from the., New York Financial Writers Association, P.O. Box 4306, New York, N.Y., 10017.

title: Worry Rises That Rockies Face Pollution and Crowds
description: EAST GLACIER, Mont. Vast sections of the Rocky Mountain West  this country's last relatively unspoiled natural regionare on their way to becoming Cluttered and polluted industrial wastelands. filled with raw boom towns and social misfits as a result of the drive to exploit the region's energy and mineral wealth.

title: SUBTLETY IN DANCE BY NAJMA AYASHAH
description: Najma Ayashah's concert of North Indian dance at the Cubiculo on Tuesday evening was tastefully selected and per. formed. She was assisted by Sabah Nissan, who gave short history of Kathak dance and described each work before the program began.

title: The Wives Came Along As Experts
description: It was a man's world at theQueens branch of Abraham & Straus the other evening, when the store, anxious to introduce its male shoppers to its expanded men's department, put on snappy little fashion show.. About 100 men (and a number, their wives) showed up to look at he fall creations as well as to receive expert advice on clothes and grooming from a battery of specialists.

title: 20 Years for Extortion
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 25 (AP)James W. Johnson, convicted of extorting $200,000 in the March kidnaping of Eunice Kronholm, thewife of St. Paul Dank president, was sentenced to 20 years in Federal prison today by United States District Court Judge Edward Devitt. Mr. Johnson was convicted Aug. 7 on the Federal extortioncharge, after acounty court had acquitted him of state kidnaping charge.

title: Commonwealth Ministers Studying Curbs on Inflation
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 25Finance Ministers ft horn 34 Commonwealth countries opened a twoday meeting here today on measures to check an erosion of the world's economy that threatens disaster for the poOrer nations in the group through inflation and other negative factors.

title: ShangriLa Absorbed by Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 25 (AP)The mountain state of Hunza, which says it is the original ShangriLa, has lost its last vestige of independence and become part of Pakistan.

title: Shea Battle Site Echoes 73 Mets
description: The Battle for First Place was resumed in the American League last night, but in New York most of the headshaking was still over the Battle of Shea Stadium among the 46,448 fans Tuesday night. The final score in that one was two guards treated at the hospital and eight fans booked for brawling.

title: DEFENSE IN COVERUP SEEKS TRIAL DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Defendants in the Watergate coverup trial, scheduled to get under way Tuesday, renewed today their pleas to the Supreme Court for a delay.

title: Health Unit Post Filled
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25 (AP)David A. Wagner, a health administrator from Philadelphia was named deputy state health commissioner. He will take lover his new job on Mondey.

title: 2d Woman Chosen for A.K.C. Post
description: The American Kennel Club, for the first time since it was organized in 1884, hired a woman field representative last year  Mrs. Irene Nail of Fort Worth. Now it has added a second, Mrs. Helen Lee James of Topeka, Kan. She is well qualified for the post for she has been active in all phases of the sportobedience, showing, breeding, judging and clubwork.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25Capt. Robert Ryder modestly admits to being an athlete of some repute. However, his athletic prowess in baseball and football wasn't what prompted a committee of race track and State Racing Commission personnel to designate him thoroughbred horseman of the year for 1974.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A WEAKENED BILL ON MASS TRANSIT CUTS AID TO FARE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Proclaiming the death of any prospects for longrange masstransit legislation in this session of Congress leaders of HouseSenate conference proposed today a. watereddown version of stopgap legislation that would not save New York City's 35cent fare.

title: Nixon's Lung Damaged by Blood Clot
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 25A piece of a blood clot has broken off from former President Richard M. Nixon's phlebitisdamaged left leg, floated through his heart and destroyed a dimesized area in his right lung without causing any chest pain, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

title: PARK OPENS INQUIRY INTO IRREGULARITIES
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 25Members of the Long Island State Park & Recreation Commission held a special meting today to discuss allegations of irregularities involving commission employes, and they expressed 'shock and surprise over the reports.

title: DRAFT VIOLATIONS OF MANY DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The chairman of the Presidential Clemency Board said today that there might be thousands of men now in hiding or living abroad who fear they are draft delinquents but who are not.

title: Rocket Attack Kills Four On Outskirts of Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 25 (Reuters)Four persons were killed and five were wounded in a renewed rocket attack by insurgents on the outskirts of Phnom Penh last night, the military police reported today.

title: GREECE REJECTS U.S. AS CYPRUS MEDIATOR
description: UNITED NATIONS., N.Y., Sept. 25  Foreign Minister George Mavros of.Greece rejected today an offer by Secretary of State Kissinger to mediate in the Cyprus crisis.

title: INLAND STEEL PLANS EXPANSION PROGRAM
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Inland Steel Company an nounced today the largest expansion program in its history The move is expected to create 1,000 to 1,500 new jobs at the company's Indiana Harbor Works alone.

title: NEW BULLET'S USE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 25 The controversy over issuing Connecticut state troopers a more powerful revolver erupted again today following the first shooting in which the new pistols were used. Two men were killed and a third was wounded in the gun battle on the Connecticut Turnpike here yesterday.

title: POTENTIAL DEFEAT OF AID BILL IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25According to Congressional and Administration sources, the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, postponed debate on a foreignaid bill today after receiving a telephone call from President Ford and after being told by Senate supporters of the bill that it was not likely to pass.

title: Koosman Credits Pilot for Coolness
description: Jerry Koosman of the New York Mets credits his coolness on the mound to former catcher Clyde McCullough, his 1966 manager at Auburn, N.Y.

title: France Imposes Fuel Cuts And Limit on Oil Imports
description: PARIS, Sept. 25The French Cabinet set a $10.1billion ceiling today on spending for oil imports next year and ordered cutbacks in industrial and home heating consumption. The action was one of the strongest yet taken by any Western nation to reduce fuel bills.

title: Court Orders Calley Freed But the Army Will Appeal
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 25United States District Judge J. Robert Elliott overturned today the murder conviction of former Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and ordered him released forthwith from incarceration at Fort Leavenworth in Kansas.

title: STEEL UNION. VOTES RAISES FOR OFFICERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 (AP)The bicentennial convention of the United Steelworkers of America voted today to give $290,000 in raises to its 25 directors and three international officers, including a $15,000 raise for the union's president, I. W. Abel.

title: Two Big Banks Here Reduce Prime Lending Rate to 11%
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the country's fifth largest bank, announced yesterday that it was lowering the interest rate it charges on loans to the most creditworthy corporations.

title: Rockefeller Friends Insist That Family Is Powerful
description: Friends and acquaintances of Nelson A. Rockefeller challonged yesterday his assertion that his family did not wield colossal economic power, but they agreed that the Vice Presidentdesignate exercised little or no personal control of the companies in which much of his $218million fortune is invested.

title: There's Humor,Suspense,Drama Too, As British Party Chiefs Meet Press
description: LONDON, Sept. 25Wheth er or not the general election on Oct. 10 will turn out to be as significant as the politicians say the choice of captain may not matter great deal if the rapids are very violent and the motor very rickety the campaign has begun with a reassuringly familiar note of theater.

title: ROCKEFELLER BALKS ON PRIVILEGE ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Senate Rules Committee concluded its two andahalfday interrogation of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller today, with Mr. Rockefeller refusing to commit himself on how he would apply tile doctrine of executive privilege should he succeed to the Presidency.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is a sadness that squirms beyond recognition in Edna O'Brien's stories. To her heroines, the bed is a bier for defunct hopes. Hopes are made ,to be dashed. Men are horn to confirm their women's forebodings. It is always ruining, as Paul Verlaine said, in these women's hearts. Lamentation is their vocation, a Martha Graham dance with an offstage voice.

title: The Mutations, British SciFi, Arrives
Deserters in Canada Face Agony of DecisionMaking on Amnesty Issue
description: VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 25"I don't trust those guys this much.

title: Yom Kippur Anniversary of War Finds Israelis Sad and Insecure
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 25Members of the Israeli Civil guard will be permitted to carry their weapons while attending Yom Kippur services in synagogues this year, according to a special ruling handed down by Chief Rabbi Shlomo Goren. The rabbi explained that given the events of the Day of Atonement last year, his unusual ruling CON stituted a justifiable precaution.

title: Sayreville Is Upheld On Ouster of Janitor
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)  The State Commissioner of Education today upheld the dismissal of a Sayreville High, School janitor who had called' a teacher a nogood little punk and who had been accused of performing his job duties inefficiently.

title: CYPRIOTES SUSPEND PRISONER EXCHANGE
description: NICOSIA, Thursday, Sept. 26, (Reuters)  Prisoner exchanges in Cyprus have been suspended indefinitely because Turkish Cypriotes objected to requests by Greek Cypriotes to be repatriated to the Turkishoccupied north of the island, the International Red Cross said today.

title: A Rare Thing: Indian Restaurant With Food to Get Excited About
CBS Radio to Drop Abby for a Series About U.S Women
description: The CBS radio network announced yesterday that it would drop at yearend the daily fiveminute feature, Dear Abby, a radio version of Abigail Van Buren's newspaper column of personal advice, for a new series entitled The American Woman. Dear Abby has had a 12year run on the network, on the air Mondays through Saturdays.

title: SOMERS REZONING STIRS NEW DISPUTE
description: SOMERS, N.Y., Sept. 25The Somers Town Board voted last night to rezone a controversial 57acre site froth residential to commercial use, starting a new dispute in a town already split over an investigatior. into zoning irregularities.

title: Energy Crisis Is Arousing Opposition to U.S. Exports of Coal
description: The exportation of coal, the nation's most abundant fuel commodity, is running into scattered opposition because of growing uncertainty, particularly among utilities, over the nation's ability to meet its immediate energy needs.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Sept. 25 (AP)The three favorites survived the opening round of match, play today in the 20th annual United ,States Golf Association senior tournament. The qualifying leader, Ed Tutwiler Indianapolis, eliminated Ery Parent of Seattle, 2 and over the 6,665yard Harbour Golf Links course.

title: Solvay to Acquire Celanese Corp. Plant
description: The Celanese Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with Solvay & Cie, S. A., a large chemical manufacturer based in Brussels, to sell Solvay its high density polyethylene plant in Deer Park, Tex., for about $80million. The plant produces about 400 million pounds a year of polyethylene resin pellets, which are used for milk bottles and other packaging requirements.

title: SOMERS REZONING STIRS NEW DISPUTE
description: SOMERS, N.Y., Sept. 25The Somers Town Board ,voted last night to rezone a controversial 57acre site from residential to commercial use starting a new dispute in a town already split over an investigation. into zoning irregularities.

title: U.S. to Appoint Panel of Blacks To Avert Undercount in Census
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.'25 Moving to avoid an undercount in the 1980 census, the Department of Commerce plans to up a committeeof blacks advise the Bureau of the Consus on how to improve counting techniques among blacks,

title: CANADA PROPOSES MORE ATOM CURBS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25Canada, a major supplier of nuclear materials and technology for peaceful uses, called here today for tighter international controls on nuclear materials.

title: Hunger and Indifference
description: The lawsuits instituted by legal services groups against foodstamp administrators in seventeen states and the United States Department of Agriculture to force them to bring the eligible poor and pearpoor within the program are actions that never should have been required.

title: BETTINA F. WHYTE
description: Bettina F. Whyte, who had been an advertising representative, specializing in the theater, for The New York Times, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and The Long Island Press for many years, died yesterday at her home, 240 Central Park South. She was 87 years old.

title: WAY TO REMOVE GASES IS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Environmental Protection Agency declared today that recent experience had demonstrated conclusively that the socalled scrubbing technique for removing sulphur gases from smokestacks was effective and reliable.

title: The Only Man Convicted for My Lai
description: To some Americans, he was the symbol of the nation's moral confusion over Vietnam. To others, he was the coldblooded murderer of helpless women and children. And to many a substantial majority, according to polls at the time of his conviction in 1971he was a scapegoat in the country's cynical attempt to salve its conscience, a lowly lieutenant who said he was only following orders and who became the only defendant out of 25 enlisted men and officers to be convicted for his role in the My Lai massacre.

title: Harvard, Celebrating Own Centennial Saturday, Says It Started Football
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association and many of its member institutions spent thousands of dollars in 1969 promoting the football centennial. There was such a clamor by colleges saying Rutgers and Princeton started it all in 1869 that not even the Russians were heard claiming they invented football.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yeterday was:
Cut in Prime Rate Lifts Parts of Credit Markets
Dr. Norbert Goldenberg, 65; A Physician and Publisher
description: Dr. Norbert Goldenberg, physician and newspaper publisher, died yesterday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: Jackson Seeks to Save Horses Captured in Disputed Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, asked today that the Bureau of Land Management preserve the remnants of a freeroaming band of horses that was captured in a controversial roundup near Howe, Idaho, in February, 1973.

title: Paramount Halts Film Exports to Iran Over Oil Price
description: The Paramount Pictures Corporation, a subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., has halted all shipments of its films to Iran until that nation agrees to pay more for them, in line with her higher charges for Iranian export oil.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
Contract Awards
description: The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, Anchorage, Alaska, has awarded a $130million contract to install four tanker berths for the TransAlaska Pipeline Marine Terminal at Valdez, Alaska, to Peter Kiewet Sons Company and the WilametteWestern Company.

title: Wounded Knee Jurors Ask Saxbe Not to Appeal Case
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 25 (AP)Seven jurors and three alternates who heard the Wounded Knee case have sent a letter to Attorney General William B. Saxbe asking that the Justice Department not appeal the dismissal of charges against two Amercian Indian Movement. leaders.

title: Market Finishes Mixed
A WEAKENED BILL ON MASS TRANSIT CUTS AID TO FARE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Proclaiming the death of any prospects for longrange, masstransit legislation in this session of Congress, leaders of a HouseSenate conference proposed today a watereddown version of stopgap legislation that would not save New York City's 35cent fare.

title: A $50Million Hotel At the Trade Center Is Planned by Texan
description: A $50million, 20story hotel the first new one in lower Manhattan since the turn of the century will be built as the fi nal Component of the World Trade Center.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25  Final figures today showed that the auto industry's domestic car sales in the Sept, 1120 period totaled 193,184 units, a decline of 4.1 per cent from the 201,447 units sold in the yearearlier period.

title: Letters to the Editor Balance of Payments: Problems of OilImporting Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Aides Dismayed By House Vote to Halt Aid
Metropolitan Briefs
description: An associate of a reputed underworld crime leader, released on $1,500 bail in connection with a felonious hijacking case in Brooklyn last March, was indicted yesterday fr conspiring with a city Housing Authority policeman to hijack a truckload of liquor valued at $40,000 three weeks later.

title: A $50Million Hotel At the Trade Center Is Planned by Texan
3 IN GANG ARRESTED AS ARSONISTS HERE
description: Three 14yearolds who told the police they were leaders of a youth gang were arrested on arson charges last night after allegedly setting fire to the roof of adjacent stores in the West Farms section of the Bronx.

title: Dance: The Korean Way
description: Sun Ock Lee, a Korean dancer who now lives in New York, presented a recital of traditional Korean dances and modern compositions that blended Western and Oriental idioms, Tuesday night at Japan House.

title: Ellen S. Meyers Is Dead; Social Worker in Brooklyn
description: Ellen Sustrin Meyers, a certified social worker with the Department of Social Services and its predecessor agencies for some 39 years, died Tuesday in the Brookdale Medical Center, Brooklyn. She was in her sixties and lived at 374 Mayfair Drive South, Brooklyn.

title: Goography Society In Need Funds
description: Just after the American Geographical Society was founded in New York in 1852, one of its first efforts was a daring campaign for the construction of a railroad all the way from. the popu,lous East Coast, across the wild and unexplored interior of the United States, to the distant Pacific Coast.

title: Limiting Handguns
description: BOSTONWe burled Donald Brown in May. He was murdered by three men who wanted to rob the supermarket manager he was protecting. Patrolman Brown was 61 years old, six months from retirement. He and his wife intended to retire to Florida at the end of the year. Now there will be no retirement in the sun, and she is alone.

title: Panel Adds 12 Amendments to Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The House Ways and Mean Committee completed today an other round of work on its big tax bill, adding to the already complex measure 12 specialin terest amendments, most of which affect only one company or one industry.

title: Dictaphone Asks Holders To Reject Northern's Bid
description: Shareholders of the Dictaphone Corporation were urges by directors yesterday to reject the offer of Northern Electric Company to purchase for $12 a share in cash any and all shares of Dictaphone. Northern electric is the 990 per cent owned manufacturing subsidiary of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada. It had made its offer on Tuesday.

title: Ryder Cup Post Doubtful for Miller
Ford Appointees Checked By Watergate Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The special Watergate prosecutor at the request of the White House, is investigating many of President Ford's appointments to high office to assure that they are not tainted by the Watergate scandal, officials close to the investigation disclosed today.

title: Business and Industrial Loans Dipped at Major Banks in Week
Allen L.,Whitman, Engineer, At Bell Laboratories, Dies
description: Allen Lee Whitman, a former research electrical engineer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Bell Telephone Laboratories died. Tuesday at the GreenwichLaurelton Convalescent Home in Greenwich, Conn. He was, 77 years old and lived at 665 River Road, Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Beame Gathers Power
description: A pattern can he found ac cording to City Hall politician in such seemingly separate an as Mayor Beame's unusual] timed announcement that he city budget is running in the red in Contrailler Harrison J. Gold in's notably Iow key disclosure of his atest audit re port and in the ouster of Matthew J. Troy Jr. as the leader of Queens Demo crats.

title: DoctorTraining Repayment Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The house is considering a health manpower bill that would require doctors to repay directly, for the first time, some of the money that the Federal Government spends on their education.

title: Books of The Times
description: Up to the 400th or 500th page of Centennial, James A.. Michener's enormous fictional meditation on the history of Cdforado, I found myself having a high old time. I'd adjusted myself to Mr. Michener's occasionally gushing prose (It was in the autumn, however, that the aspen came into its true glory, for then each leaf turned a brilliant gold, so that a single tree seemed an explosion of vibrating loveliness.). The absurd early chapters  where the dramatis personnae include Time, the Cretaceous Period, a diplodocus, an oehippus, and an eagle and rattlesnake locked in mortal combatseemed safely behind me (like the Old Testament, Centennial be gins with the Beginning, only it's more thorough).

title: Carey Forges Broad Union Of Democrats and Liberals
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic candidate for Governor, has put together since his landslide victory in the Sept, 10 primary a Democratic Liberal coalition that covers an unusually broad spectrum from Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, to Alex Rose, the leader of the Liberal party.

title: Lawyer and Wife Slain in Home
description: An elderly lawyer and his wife were stabbed to death in their home in Waterbury, Conn., last night, apparently by an intruder who rang their doorbell as they prepared to retire early after attending Yom Kippur services.

title: $2 Bet Pays $503.60 for U.S. Record
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26 (AP)  Colonial Charm, a 4yearold mare owned by Castleton Farms of Lexington, set a world record for trotting mares today in the $4,830 Transylvania Stake.

title: Soviet Warship Sinks
description: A Soviet guidedmissile destroyer exploded and sank recently in the Black Sea, a Turkish press agency: reported: The Pentagon declined to confirm the report. Details on page 7.

title: Allstate Training Center Loses Its Accreditation for 3 Months
description: The New York State Insurance Superintendent, Benjamin R. Schenck, said yesterday that he had suspended the accreditation of the Allstate Insurance Company's agent training center in Morristown from Sept 21 to Dec. 19.

title: Guilty in Fatal Bombing
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 26 (AP)Ernest Burton Jr., 24 years old, was found guilty today of nine counts of firstdegree murder in the firebombing last March of a tavern here. Nine persons died and six others were injured when the, bomb was tossed into the Caboose Bar.

title: Why Wait for Ford?; IN THE NATION
description: The Ford Administration is now giving intense, active study to the proposition that tax relief should be afforded to lowincome workers in this curious period of inflation and economic stagnation. If that is not just talk, such a proposal would be splendid way for President Ford to break out of his singletrack economic concentration on cutting the nonmilitary budget.

title: Judge Delays Calley's Release To Allow Army Time to Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)A Federal appeals court judge today delayed until Monday the release of former Lieut. William L. Cailey Jr., while Army considers, appealing lower court ruling that turned Mr. Calley's conviction for murder in the My Lai sacre in Vietnam.

title: SOFTER BILL ON AID TO TURKEY BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The DemOcratic and Republican leaders of Congress met today with President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger and agreed to support a weaker version of legislation to suspend military aid to Turkey than the House voted Tuesday.

title: EDMUND A. ROSSI
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP) Edmund A. Rossi, who was president of the Italian Swiss Colony. Winery for 27 years, died Tuesday at a hospital in Pacifica, Calif. He was 86 years old.

title: Wallace Accused on Hiring of Blacks
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 26The former director of the Alabama Department of Public Safety told a Federal judge today that Gov. George C. Wal, lace had repeatedly instructed him not to obey one of the judge's orders regarding the hiring of black state troopers.

title: SENATE UNIT CUTS FUNDS FOR NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) A Senate subcommittee voted today to deprive former President Richard M. Nixon of more than half of the $850,000 requested for his return to private life and insisted that none of it be spent for household servants.

title: A Noted Songwriter Remains in a Coma After Mugging Here
description: George Forrest, the 59yearold songwriter who collaborated with Robert Wright on Kismet, The Song of Norway, and many other hits, was critically injured by a mugger near his Brooklyn Heights home early last Monday and has been in a coma since the assault.

title: Nixon Clot Responding
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon was reported to be responding well to therapy and medical sources said that a blood clot, in his right lung had apparently not destroyed tissue. Page 21.

title: Colson, Now in Prison, Asks Ford for Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26(UPI)Charles W. Colson, former special Presidential counsel, who is now in prison for a Watergaterelated crime, has asked President Ford for the deputy Presidential press secretary, said today.

title: Meeting Slated on Crisis
description: PARIS, Sept. 26The French, reacted with anger bordering on outrage today to West Germany's rejection of a 5 per cent increase in guaranteed prices for Common Market! farmers as the nine member! nations hastily agreed to an! emergency meeting next Wednesday in Luxembourg to try to deal with the crisis.

title: Manager Picks Starters for Last Drive
description: We've got to win every game, it's our only chance, Manager Bill Virdon said yesterday as he led his New York Yankees to Cleveland for the final five games of the team's most dramatic shot at a pennant in 10 years.

title: Van Impe Injured
description: VANCOUVER, British Co. lumbia,Sept.26 (AP)Spokesmen for the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League said today that Ed Commerce, Inc., the Hartford fensemen, needed 18 stiches for a head cut suffered in an exhibition game.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford announced two important nominations yesterday: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand to he Army Chief of Staff and David K. E. Bruce to be the United States representative to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. General Weyand, who will succeed the recently deceased Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, is 57 years old. Since he did not go to West Point, but was graduated instead from the University of California at Berkeley, he is something of a rarity in the highest Army circles. General Weyand succeeded General Abrams as commander of United States forces in Vietnam and was in charge there when the shooting stopped. He has been in the Army since 1938, first as an intelligence officer and later an infantryman.

title: 339 Deserters of Military In Some Proceeding Stage
description: CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind., Sept. 26 (UPI)Processing center spokesmen said today that 339 deserters had been processed or were going through the steps of processing here under President Ford's conditional amnesty program.

title: Credit Markets Are Lifted By Loan Decline at Banks
LEFKOWITZ TO ACT IN DAIRYLEA CASE
description: Attorney General Louis J Lefkowitz said yesterday that he planned to present his criminal case against the Dairylea milk cooperative to an Albany County grand jury sometime in October.

title: Yom Kippur A Quiet Day In the Golan
description: MEROM GOLAN, Israelioccupied Syria, Sept. 26At 1:30 P.M. last Yom Kippur, two Syrian MIG21 fighters streaked over this frontier kibbutz and bombed and rocketed the Israeli army position just south of it. With no more warning than that, Merom Golan was in the midst of war.

title: Chess:
Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 25 (AP)  Three world records were shattered today,, opening day of the 99th Grand Circuit meeting at the Red Mile here. Nero, driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $34,845 Meadowlands stake race with a combined time of 3:53 3/5 for the two elimination heats.

title: Confused U.S.Indian Relations
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 26 India's relations with the United States have become confused, reflecting a significant conflict in the New Delhi Government. The Americans are not quite sure what's going to happen next. On the one hand Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has condemned the United States and hinted darkly that the Central Intelligence Agency has been intent on subverting India. On the other hand the Foreign Minister, Swaran Singh, had a substantive 55minute talk with President Ford, the other day it was the first time in more than three years that an Indian Cabinet officer had conferred at the White House.

title: ExConvict Accused In Berman Murder To Get a New Trial
description: A 38yearold former convict who had been charged with the slaying of a freelance film producer here last year, and whose case was declared a mistrial late Wednesday night, will be retried in the next few weeks, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: PRIORITY CHANGES ON GAS OPPOSED
description: NEWARK, Sept. 26 (AP)At a hearing before the Board of Public Utility Commissioners here today, Public Service Electric & Gas Company representatives said the utility was against changing the order in which gas service to industrial customers would be curtailed in the event of a naturalgas shortage in New Jersey.

title: Nixon's Condition Termed Better
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 26  The blood clot that traveled from former President Richard M. Nixon's left leg to his right lung sometime in the past is responding satisfactorily to anticoagulation therapy, Mr. Nixon's doctor said here today.

title: Nikolai Polokous Dies; Britain's Coco the Clown
description: PETERBOROUGH England, Sept. 26 (UPI)Nikolai Polokous, who as Coco the Clown brought laughter to British circus audiences for 60 years, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 78 years old.

title: ATHENS REPORTED FLEXIBLE ON NATO
description: ATHENS, Sept. 26 (UPI) Greece may consider rejoining the military command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if her allies help to find a just solution to the Cyprus problem, a high Greek official said today.

title: STEELE IS AHEAD IN FUNDRAISING
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 26Running from behind with a selfimposed $100 limit on campaign contributions, United States Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican candidate for Governor of Connecticut, has raised more money from more people than has his Democratic opponent, United States Representative Ella T. Grasso.

title: Storm Upsets Americans, 2621
Bell System Memo Hits Phone Concerns'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Poor performance by telephone companies was in large measure responsible for the massive telephone service failures that afflicted a number of large metropolitan areas in recent years, a Bell System internal document indicates.

title: The New Newer Newest South
description: LITTLE ROCKThe South is a land of many legends but none is quite so enduring as the legend of the New South. There are some who assert that the South is credited with another rebirth every time two or more liberals are counted in a public assembly, or whenever Southerners set up a program and tour for visiting innocents from the North, as Reg Murphy of The Atlanta Constitution and his fellow Atlantans did to entertain a convention of newspaper editors last April.

title: Deserter Leaving Canada Enters U.S. Like a Tourist
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 26Tne 1965 Malibu sped along Canadian Highway 99 in an afternoon haze that held the heat of an Indian summer that everyone in Vancouver said was the best in memory.

title: Advertising
Rockefeller Panel Focuses On Attica and Abortions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The issues of abortion and Attica dominated. the final day of the Senate Rules Committee's hearings today as more than a dozen witnesses, including Angela Daivis, testified fay and against Nelson A. Rockefeller's confirmation as Vice President.

title: OPEC Denies Meeting Is Set to Discuss U.S.
description: VIENNA, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  The Arganization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today there were no plans for a special ministerial conference to discuss relations between the United States and governments of oilproducing countries.

title: State Panel Urges Curbs On Shady Charity Sales
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26The State Commissioner of Investi gation today recommended the enactment of stiff laws to curb fraud and deception by profitmaking companies that operate in the name of the allegedly handicapped.

title: Urban Foresters See How City's Trees Cope With Their Hostile Environment
description: A band of 40 foresters toured Manhattan yesterday to see how some of the world's bravest trees coexist with traffic, dogs, rock salt, air pollution and underground utilities and to check out, in particular some of the newer varieties developed for survival in city streets.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The executive committee of the National Book Committee which oversees the National Book Awards is to discuss the question of ceasing to operate altogether among other options at the executive body's next meeting on Monday John C. Frantz reported yesterday.

title: CONSTRUCTION UNION ENDORSES WILSON
description: The New York Stale Conference of the International Union of Operating Engineers, which puts its membership at 45,000 announced its endorsement of Governor Wilson yesterday.

title: Ann S. Petluck, 66, Dies; Lawyer, Refugee Expert
description: Ann S. Petluck, a lawyer and social work administrator specializing in immigration and refugee work, died Wednesday at University Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 441 East 20th Street.

title: Carey Forges Broad DemocraticLiberal Coalition
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, the Democratic gubernatorial, candidate, has put together since his landslide victory in the Sept. 10 primary a rare DemocraticLiberal coalition that covers an unusually broad spectrum from.Meade H. Esposito, Brooklyn Democratic leader to Alex Rose, Liberal party leader.

title: Ending of Drug Penalties Urged in Jersey Report
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26The Attorney General's office here is drafting a report to Governor Byrne that will recommend the abolition of criminal penalties for users of marijuana or hashish.

title: 2 CENTER EMPLOYES FACE RAPE CHARGES
description: Two maintenance men at the Children's Center, 1 East 104th Street, were arrested on rape charges late Wednesday night. after two teenage girls who live there were caught sneaking off to meet them in an area that was off limits.

title: Jaworski Asks Separate Strachan Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26In an unexpected, last minute change of position, the special Watergate prosecution asked United States District Judge John J. Sirica today to sever the case of Gordon C. Strachan from that of the five other defendants charged with the Watergate coverup.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A fugitive from Trenton State Psychiatric Hospital, who was charged with murder in 1967, was captured by the North Brunswick police after he begged for breakfast from a housewife.

title: Three Hybrid Corns Tailored to the State
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 26 Six years ago a team of corn researchers began a series of experiments in crossing varieties that resuited in the development of three new hybrids that are now recommended for use by New York State farmers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Union Backs Rise in Dues
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 (AP)After a bitter twohour debate, the United Steelworkers of America biennial convention endorsed today a propoial to raise dues for several hundred thousand steelworkers. The delegates approved an amendment removing a current $10 ceiling on monthly, dues from the union's constitution. All union members will be required to contribute two hours pay monthly regardless of their salaries.

title: Hyndman Is Ousted In U.S. Senior Golf
About Real Estate
description: Here comes the latest edition of the city's Directory of Publicly Aided Housing Developments, a fascinating document. It describes in detail the housing built under programs administered by the Housing and Developand Administration.

title: U. S. Attorney Discloses 2d Inquiry on Helstoski
description: NEWARK, Sept. 26The existence of a second Federal grand jury investigation into the business affairs of Re presentative Henry Helstoski, Delbocrat of the NinthDistrict, wag disclosed today by Jonathan L, Goldstein, United States Attorney for New Jersay.

title: TV: Sunrise Semester Enters 18th Year on CBS
description: Back in he early days of radio, broadcasting was being heralded as a revolutionary tool in the quest for mass adult education, serious education in the sense of cognitive learning. It has not, needless to say, turned out that way. Early on, the broadcasters discovered advertisers. The mutual alliance has been solidly based on the fact that mass education cannot produce a fraction of the dollars brought in by mass entertainment.

title: 40 Elevator Holdups In Apartments Laid, To ExConvict Here
description: A 27yearold former convict, identified by the police as the muchsought elevator robber who had created a oneman crime wave by holding up dozens of apartmenthouse residents over the last three months, was arrested yesterday after an investigation that had made him the leading target of detectives in three precincts.

title: Murder Case Witnesses Recant 7 Years After 2 Got Life Terms
Yom Kippur Ends With Rabbis'
description: Yom Kippur the Day of Atonement ended at sundown yesterday as rabbis and heads of Jewish secular and religious groups called on American Jews to rededicate themselves to the precepts of the most sacred day on the Hebrew calen dar.

title: 40 Elevator Holdups In Apartments Laid To Former Convict
description: A 27yearold former convict, identified by the police as the muchsought elevator robber who had created a oneman, crime wave by holding up dozens of apartmenthouse residents over the last three months, was arrested yesterday after an investigation that had made him the leading target of detectives in three precincts.

title: Manager Picks Starters for Last Drive
description: We've got to win every game, it's our only chance, Manager Bill Virdon said yesterday as he led his New York Yankees to Cleveland for the final five games of the team's most dramatic shot at a pennant in 10 years.

title: Utah Files a Suit For Alleged Fraud By Merrill Lynch
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 26 (AP)The Utah Attorney General's office has filed suit against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the nation's largest stock brokerage firm, in an attempt to recover funds allegedly lost in a Utah State University investment program.

title: 2,000 Catholics in Seoul Renew Protests
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Sept. 27  More than 2,000 Roman Catholics clashed with riot policemen in the busiest section of Seoul last night in continuing confrontation with the Government over the arrest of Bishop Daniel Chi and other political prisoners.

title: Cardinals Rehearse For Title
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26With the hourlong honking of happy automobile horns still echoing in their ears, the St. Louis Cardinals came here this evening to start their final six games of the reguular season  three day games here starting tomorrow, three night games in Montreal starting Monday.

title: SAWHILL TO SEEK REFUNDS ON FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)The Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill said today he had ordered the agency to seek refunds of about $40million in windfall profits that he said oil companies made from a loophole in energy regulations.

title: De La Tour Is a Rediscovery of Modern Scholarship
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The art of Georges de La Tour is one of the great discoveries of 20th century art historical scholarship. Although his work was much admired by royal patrons and connoisseurs in 17thcentury France, it fell into obscurity in the 18th and 19th centuries, and virtually disappeared from public view. It is only in recent decades that painstaking research, topether with a radical revision of taste has won the artist a place in the front rank of French

title: Red Smith
description: Baseball's 162gage schedule comes to an end next Wednesday night, to be followed by the pennant playoffs, the World Series and the quail season. There are, however, other matters, other matters that must be dealt with before the year's books can be closed, including the Sinister Case of the Loving Husband. This is a bittersweet tale involving the eternal triangle  boy, girl and general manager. As soon after the World Series as is feasible, probably in early November, an arbitrator will be asked.a thorny question Is it true, as of oil and water, that connubial affection and the national pastime do not mix?

title: SOVIET DESTROYER IS REPORTED SUNK
description: A Soviet destroyer of a type armed with guided missiles reportedly exploded and sank recently in the Black Sea in what is believed to be the worst peacetime naval disaster since the loss of the United States submarine Thresher in 1963 with a crew of 129.

title: U.S. and Iceland Sign A New Accord on Base
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The United States and Iceland agreed today on modifications in their 23yearold defense pact allowing the American military to staff a base of the North Atlantic Treaty. Organization at Keflavik.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION Bits of Paradise: 21 Uncollected Stories by F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, selected by Matthew J. Bruccoli with the assistance of Scottie Fitzgerald Smith (Scribners, $7.95)..

title: OCT. 23 TRADING SET ON FUEL OIL FUTURES
description: Futures trading in two new contracts  homeheating oil and industrial fuel oil (also called Bunker C oil) will begin Oct. 23 on the New. York Mercantile Exchange. The exchange, is a center for trading in a variety of commodities such as potatoes, platinum and foreign currencies.

title: Farmers Interested in Milk Work Hard to Improve Corn
GREEK EXPRESIDENT UNDER HOUSE ARREST
description: ATHENS, Sept. 26 (UPI)George Papadopoulos, the former Greek President, is being held under house arrest at his seaside villa outside Athens, a Government spokesman said today. Fifteen guards have surrounded the villa 25 miles southeast of Athens.

title: HARRY HARTZ
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (UPI)Harry Hartz, who three times finished second in the Indianapolis. 500 automobile race, died today in Indianepolis Methodist Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: President to Attend Game
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) President Ford and his wife, Betty, will attend the National Football League game in Washington Monday night between the Washington Redskins and Denver Broncos, an aide said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal District Judge Robert Ward rejected a suit brought by 214 New York National Guard members who sought release from their final year of duty because their home units had been called to duty during the 1970 mail strike in New York City. The men were not mobilized for service at the time because they were in the training period of their six years of duty. Thousands of National Guard members, however, were called up for active duty to help move the mail and then were granted a oneyear release from duty by former. Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: FORD'S ADVISERS SEE NO FAST CURB ON INFLATION RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 White House economic advisers have concluded that, while the nation does not face a depression and mass unemployment, it will take 18 to 36 months to reduce the rate of inflation in a major way.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: FEDERAL RESERVE TO BACK FRANKLIN IN FOREIGN FIELD
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a move to help solve the problems of the ailing Franklin National Bank, assumed responsibility yesterday for the bank's contracts to buy and sell foreign currencies.

title: The Future Is Now
description: There are no light switches in the. World Trade Center!

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The Department of Commerce said today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.2billion, down one per cent from last year's $1.33billion. Total retail store sales were $10.2billion, three per cent from last year's $9,93billion.

title: Blazers Aerials Beat Fire, 290
Rome Synod Opens Today on Subject Of Evangelization
description: ROME, Sept. 26The fourth Synod of Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church opens here tomorrow to discuss evangelization in the modern worldhow to bring the Gospel to the world and the world to the Gospel.

title: Molly Ballantine Triumphs As 110 Ruffian Is Scratched
description: The star of the show failed to appear in the $119,000 Frizette at Belmont Park yesterday, but Jerome Castle's Molly Ballantine proved to be a most capable understudy.

title: Maytag Raising Prices Of Appliances 5%
description: NEWTON, Iowa, Sept. 26 (AP)The Maytag Company announced today that prices for its home appliances would be increased an average of 5 per cent effective Oct. 14.

title: Urgings of Rededication Mark End of Yom Kippur
description: Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, ended at sundown yesterday as rabbis and heads of Jewish secular and religious groups called on American Jews to rededicate themselves to the precepts of the most sacred day on the Hebrew calendar.

title: In Greece, Reds Start A New Life
description: ATHENS, Sept. 26The Greek Cominunist party has just moved jnto new offices and there are only a few deoorations on the walls: color portraits of Marx and Lenin, with their names in Russian characters. Across the room is a penandink drawing of a Greek guerrilla fighter wearing a bandolier of bullets.

title: Fishing Report for Local Area
description: Although many sportsmen begin to think of upland bird hunting at this time of year, October is traditionally the most glorious and most productive month of the year for surf fishermen from Cape Cod and the outer islands south through New Jersey.

title: PENTAGON TO ADD AARMS SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The Defense Department said today that it was drafting plans for a substantial increase in measures to protect atomic weapons stored overseas from terrorists.

title: Pirates Down Mets, Tie Cards for Lead
Macy Net Off
description: R. H. Macy & Co., operators of the worldknown New Yorkbased department store chain, reached a record level of sales for the fiscal year that ended Aug. 3, but profits dropped 10.6 per cent.

title: Try ItMaybe You'll Like It, Maybe You Won't
description: What's to be done in a case like this?...

title: Soybeans Up Limit Fourth Day in Row; Corn Also in Gains
description: Speculative buying on fears about the crop size pushed prices of soybeans and corn up their daily limits yesterday. For the beans it was the fourth 20 cents a bushel daily limit rise this week, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Interracial Talks to Open in SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Sept. 26South Africa today officially informed the United Nations that whites and nonwhites would start talks on the future pattern of constitutional development in SouthWest Africa.

title: Suite Robbed of Jewels At SherryNetherland
description: A resident of the SherryNetherland Hotel, on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street was robbed last night of jewelry of substantial value, the police reported.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Economic Committee10.30 A.M.

title: Contract Awards
description: Fluor Engineers & Constructors, Inc., a subsidiary the Fluor Corporation has been named by the Namhae Chemical Corporation, of Seoul, Korea, as managing prime contractor for a $200million fertilizer manufacturing facility in South Korea. In turn, Fluor has awarded major subcontracts to the M. W. Kellogg Company; the Chemical Construction Corporation; and Davy Power Gas, Inc. United States goods and services will be financed through credit from the United States ExportImport Bank; the Export Funding Corporation, a private company, and commercial bank syndicate, headed by the Bank of America.

title: EDITH L. DILWORTH.
