title: Klein Offers Austerity Budget
description: HAUPPAUGE  Even before John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, unveiled his 1975 austerity budget to reporters last week, his face was undharacteristically grim,. Economic conditions were worsening in this oncebooming county, he said, and there was very little the county administration could do to alleviate the situation.

title: The American Nesting Instinct
description: Elsie de Wolfe, who claimed to be the first woman interior decorator in America, did not deny that a man's house was his castle, but she insisted that it certainly was a woman's home. A man, she said, may build and decorate a beautiful house, but it remains for a woman to make home for him. It is the personality of the mistress that the house expresses. Men are forever guests in our homes, no matter how much happiness they may find there.

title: Curtain Is Rising on Fall Season at the State's Private and Public Art Galleries
description: New Jersey's private and public art galleries are starting the fall season with a variety of shows devoted to local and other artists.

title: REP. RARICK LOSES IN LOUISIANA RACE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28 (AP)Jeff LaCaze, a 29yearold television sportscaster who quit his job to enter the race, defeated Representative John R. Rarick today for the Democratic nomination to Louisiana's Sixth Congressional District seat, which Mr. Rarick had held for eight years.

title: TiPit's tour through lowlife Quebec
description: MarieClaire Blais made her literary debut with La Belle Bete (Mad Shadows) in 1959 at the age of 20. Much was made of the author's youth, her background of poverty and the precocious intensity and skill of her writing. Some critics predicted a brilliant career, others saw her as an odd child prodigy, sure to burn out early. Now, 15 years later, she is one of the best known and certainly the most acclaimed Quebec writer extant. She has published two volumes cif poetry and eight novels, has won France's most coveted literary prize (The Prix Medicis, in 1966) andalmost unique among Quebec writers has been widely translated. Her work has been unevenfew of her novels are handled as flawlessly as A Season in the Life of Emmanuel (1966) or carry the total conviction of The Manuscripts of Pauline Archange (1970)but it's a tribute to her powers as a storyteller that no matter how tenuous her tale, she holds the reader to the end like the Ancient Mariner in reverseher message not one of salvation and forgiveness but of suffering, cruelty and degradation in a world rank with human passions but devoid of grace.

title: Nassau Police Using a Talking Rogues Gallery
description: MINEOLAWhile law en forcemeat agencies large any smallincluding New York City's finestrely on tit traditional sheafs of mui shots used :or crime wit ness identification since be fore prohibition, the Nassau County Police Departmen has moved into the compute age with a multifaceted talking rogues gallery.

title: Dutch Plan 3 New Stations For Nuclear Power by 1985
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 28 (Reuters)The Netherlands will build three more nuclear power stations of 1,000 megawatts each by 1985, Economics Minister Ruud Lub, bers announced this week. A megawatt is a million watts.

description: THE advent of the 1975 High Fidelity Music Show at the Statler Hilton this Thursday, plus a little advance knowledge of what is likely to be on display there, has set me thinking. To be sure, there will be more quad equipment on display than at the last show, two years ago, but otherwise everything will be pretty much the same.

description: SOUL, South Korea, Sept. (UPI)  A South Korean military court of appeals today upheld jail sentences for 36 dissident college students convicted of having violated special presidential decrees banning antiGovernment activities.

title: Good Black Poems One by One
description: For almost 10 years now, the Broadside Press in Detroitrun singlehandedly by Dudley Randall without subsidy of grantshas been issuing poems by black writers. The 45 small eloquent volumes and single broadsides.now make a sizable pile, and have been joined by tapes (11), anthologies (8), posters (5) and an assortment of other thingsan associated British series; an African cookbook, the beginning of a series of writings by black critics, and children's books. Though Randall's is not the only black press, it is the most imaginative; its 82 broadsides (at last count) are the next thing to pomes pennyeach, to borrow Joyce's words, costing as they do only 50 centstoo much for some black families, possible for others.

description: The Lieutenant, the new rock musical that recently received generally favorable reviews after presentation at the cityoimed Queens Playhouse in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, is opening on Broadway in midNovember. The theater will be announced later.

title: BIG OIL IMPORTERS OPEN KEY SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Foreign ministers and finance Ministers from the United States and four other major oil importing nations assembled here this afternoon for a twoday session to spur Western coordination for meeting the crisis caused by the rise of oil prices. The meeting was originally scheduled for the Presidential retreat at Camp David, in the Catoctin Mountains near Thurmond, Md. Because of heavy rains, it was decided to hold the sessions at the State Department.

title: The American Way of Sex
description: This book of interviews with girls in the massageparlor trade purports to let all us poor squares in on the picture of what life will be like in the near future, when those hypocritical repressions keeping us from taking oh 9 or 10 men a day for good money are swept away. But lest my defensive crusty attitude shroud in highmindedness my prurient fascination and envy of these girls incomes, let me lay those cards on the table first and acknowledge that the book feeds those

title: What They Are Saying

title: The Messengers Will Come No More
description: Leslie Fiedler is, of course, better known as a critic than as a writer of fiction, and criticism has in fact been the more congenial medium for the exercise of his most engaging qualites of fictional invention. He is preeminently a novelist of ideas, using fiction to illustrate the ideas with a cartoonlike simplicity and, sometimes, vividness. The four volumes of fiction he published in the early and mid1960's deal with the social, cultural and political issues that characteristically occupied intellectuals, and particularly Jewish intellectuals, during that period. Now, after a hiatus of eight years, Fiedler has written a new novel, once again reflecting the current preoccupation of the American adversary culture"which, now on the other side of the period of political activism and campus unrest, are very different from the questions that concerned Fiedler and his ambience decade

title: Kurds Say Iran Arms Them and That Soviet Sends Advisers to Iraq

title: Letters to the Editor

title: He Retains a Solid Following, But Won't Say Where He'll Lead It;...And George Wallace Probably Will Be in It
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.The latest Gallup poll arrived here Friday just in time to. catch George Wallace as he headed out of state once again in search of his political future. George Wallace is running; recovered from another of those little infections that periodically attack his partially paralyzed body. It is not clear at this point just what he is running for but he is running.

title: FAST ACTION VITAL IN CANCER CASES
description: If laboratory tests confirm the surgeon's initial view that the cancer had not spread from Betty Ford's right breast, her chances of being well 10 years from now approach 90 per cent, according to recent studies.

title: Executive Life Styles
description: Every man, as Hamlet pointed out, has business and desire, such as they are. The desires of those who have business, and what they do about them have engaged the beadyeyed attention of an organization called the Life Extension Institute, which gives annual checkups to business executives. What really goes on in the executive suite and on the business trip, between meetings and during off hours? The Institute and its medical head, Dr. Harry J. Johnson, seem to have been nagged by this question. Since they regularly had thousands of executives trooping through their offices anyway, Dr. Johnson and his men reasoned, why not take the opportunity to conduct a survey of their sexual habits and then subject the results to analysis by computer?

title: Sports News Briefs

This production, which is also slated to be released by Paramount, will costar Robert Mitchum and Charlotte Rampling, who is starred with Dirk Bogarde in The Night Porter, the British drama opening here Tuesday.

title: To the Unknown Hero
description: Hans Erich Nossack's early manuscripts, unpublishable during the Nazi era, ware cremated in a 1943 air raid on his native Hamburg. This apocalyptic experience along With the ambiguities of survival inspired in his subsequent works a creative response ambiguous enough to have earned him substantial reputation. Vice President of the Academy of Sciences and Literature at Mainz, he holds the Chair for Poetics at the Goethe University in Frankfurt and was referred to by none other than Jean Paul Sartre as the most interesting contemporary German writer.

title: Why six million have deliberately chosen an ultimate form of contraception.
description: An extraordinary number of Americansthe current estimate is six millionhave voluntarily had operations to make themselves sterile. They have shown a remarkable willingness to abandon less drastic and permanent methods of birth control and have sought deliberately to achieve the barrenness that once was considered a curse. According to the 1970 National Fertility Study, onesixth of all married couples in this country who were using contraception in that year had been sterilized. Among couples where the wife was between 30 and 44, sterilization was the most popular form of contraception usedit accounted for a quarter of all the couples in this age group.

title: Moving, Moving, Moving
description: To move or not to move is seldom the question. If it were, 40 million Americans would not move every year and commercial movers would not occupy 29 yellow pages in the Manhattan telephone directory.

title: A.E.C. AIDE SCORED ON SAFETY VIEWS

title: WHAT IS A MAESTRO?; Sculptor, general, hypnotist, disciplinarian,; Big Papa, foreman, psychologist, tyrant, character, catalyst
description: One hundredodd musicians are up there on stage playing their respective hearts out. The sheer physical force of the sound they produce jointly is awesome. Theirs is a performance of instrumental virtuosity and excellence that is not only extremely beautiful but irresistibly communicative as well. Yet, despite the mastery of their craft, the orchestra men are shortchanged because tradition today dictates that the public reserve its real enthusiasm, its resounding bravos, for one man alonethe conductor.

title: An Urban Shopping Center
description: The design concept is much like that of Ghirardelli Square in San Francisco and Canal Square in the Georgetown district of Washington. Take some old buildings with character, add some compatible new structures, face them all around an inviting inner plaza and fill the whole thing with shops and services.

The United States had a record trade deficit in August of more than $1.1billion.... The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will assume responsibility for the Franklin National Bank's contracts on foreign currency.

title: Opera: Ariadne Is Back
description: Sarah Caldwell's.production of Ariadne auf Naxos returned, essentially unchanged, to the New York City Opera repertory yesterday afternoon. If the stage business wasn't so crisp as last fall, it was no sloppier than last spring, and Miss Caldwell's tendency to stress the comic over the noble seemed less bothersome than before. And whatever one may think of the gags and gimmicks, the whole has a sense of style to it rare on the NeW York operatic scene.

title: L.I. Rabbi to Head Two Major Groups

A field of 11 competed in the 21st running of the weightforage test, which had a gross value of $115,400 and a first prize of $69,240, and a crowd of 30,523 saw Forego take the top money.

title: In Celebration of the Tepee
description: A TOILET in Every Tepee? asked The Woodstock. Times in a front page headline, and for a few days it promised to be the biggest confrontation between straights and freaks since 1969, when the town fathers closed the swimming hole because hippies were skinny dipping in it. The problem this time was tepees: not just the dozen or more that had been pitched discreetly in the woods during the past several years, but one flagrantly visible tepee, tall and white, with a crown of branching poles, that had materialized in a clearing near Route 375, a main thoroughfare leading into town. It was built and occupied by the Friends of the Sacred Hoop, a commune that produces videotapes on American Indian life, and someone had filed a complaint So the town sent the building inspector out to take a look, and the building inspectOr did whathe had to do, served a violation notice on said Friends for putting up a structure without a building permit and living in it without approved sanitary facilities. title: Purdue Upsets Irish
New '
description: This collection makes you look forward to reading short stories, which have ebbed to such a trickle nowadays. They offer sudden, brilliant revelations of feeling or mood or character that are not characteristic of longer fiction. Tribal Justice is an umbrella title that applies to most of these protagonists, outsiders trying to gain a foothold in alien cultures. Some succeed, like the hero of The Fabulous Eddie Brewster, an excollaborator from France who gets on in smalltown America. And some do not meld very well, like the narrator of How I Becamea Jew, a Southern boy in a Cincinnati public school. There is a broad geographical range from Montreal to northcentral Florida, which is the scene of a memorable hurricane in Relief. In this story, the high wind blows away what amenities exist between neighbors, middleclass and migrant. The author admits to having attended 25 different schools before the ninth grade. Perhaps that is why the best of the stories have the fresh, if apprehensive, vision of a new boy

title: Havana Playing Host to Javits and Pell

title: Nicholas Maw Here For U.S. Premiere
description: FOR quite a while now many composers have turned their backs on the symphony orchestra, saying it is obsolete or dead and refusing to write for it. Some of this has been inspired by the economic factor. A composer who writes for a chamber end semble spends less time on the work and has a better chance of getting it performed. But in the way musical styles have been developing there has also been a genuine aversion to bigness and a preference for the small malleable forms that allow for, among other things, experimentation.

description: Judge and Mrs. Duncan Chapin Gibb of Front Royal, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Courtney Chapin Gibb, to Dr: John Gerard Dardis of Washington, son of Mrs. Christopher Patrick Dardis of Dublin and the late Mr. Dardis,

title: Charter. Study Unit Cites Construction Red Tape
description: Finding out the status of proposed city school, park or library can be one of the most frustrating experiences which a citizen can have, let alone the city's own problems in getting the school built in the first place, the State Charter Study Commission said last week.

title: Who Is the World's Best Organist? Ask Virgil Fox
description: VIRGIL FOX is a curious Saturday night and Sunday morning kind of musician.

title: Home Improvement
description: STANDARD size glazed ceramic tiles (4x4 inch) are now available to doityourselfers in 12inchsquare sheets consisting of nine tiles joined together with a factoryapplied flexible silicone rubber grout that not only eliminates the need for grouting each joint separately after the tiles are up it also makes a joint that is highly resistant to staining and the formation of mildew and one that is completely waterproof In addition being flexible It is also impervious to another common problem normally encountered oh ceramic tile willsthe rubber groat will not dry out or crack like conventional grout frequently does after it ages for some time.

title: Turkey Upset by Doubts About Stable Government
description: ANKARA, Sept. 27Turkey's summer euphoria over her successful military action in Cyprus has given way to uncertainties over who will govern this country at a time of international tensions over Cyprus and domestic concern over inflation.

title: Family Seized in Drug Raid
description: BORDENTOWN, N. J., Sept. 28 (UPI)Six members of family in this township were arrested today following a raid that the state police said turned up large quantities of maiiton, cocaine, LSD, syringes and needles; $15,000 in cash, and firearms. Arrested were Theodore Tolle, 67; his wife, Mary Anne, 54; the couple's son, Richard, 24; his wife, Karen, 23, and another son, Loreain, 28, and his wife, Karen, 24.

title: Greenwich, New Caanan Win
WILLIAM DE MIN
description: William de Min, former president of the Manufacturing Textile Export Company and of the Textile Export Association, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N. J. He was 82 years old, and lived at 180 Walnut Street, Montclair, N. J.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThere is a ring of orches tration in the rash of economic summitry that has descended on this capital city this weekend.

title: A Few Secrets for Longevity of Spring Bulbs
description: BULB garden can be a pleasure for many springs for those who are willing to plant it correctly and give it a modelite amount of season to season cam In my own front yard a 15 by 30 foot bulb planting (filled With annual flowers in summer) lit erally stops traffic each May because it contains hundreds of plants that seem to flower more, beautifully each year.

title: Red Smith
description: Al Jolson was probably the, bestknown entertainer during his reign, from the late 1920's well into the 1940's, writes Phil Bieber, who has brightened this space more than once with anecdotes of his years on the race track with his late brother, Isidor. Jolie adored his high position, catered without stint to the audience, and in the process accumulated wealth. Second only to the theater, Al loved horse racing. On every possible occasion he was at the track. Big as an actor, he was also big in betting. He owned a modest string of horses trained by the late Ike Perlstein and also Oy Col. John Donovan, now an official at New Jersey tracks.

title: He Started to Design It Himself...
WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The nation's retail industry is having nervous tremors over the state of its inventories. Four months are left in the industry's fiscal year in which to achieve its anticipated sales of $135billion.

title: EXHOSPITAL AIDE FACES LONG TRIAL
description: MIAMI, Sept. 28Sanford Bronstein, former president the bankrupt Cedars of Leba non Hospital of Miami, went trial here this week accused misappropriating $525,000 the hospital's funds.

title: Opera: Met's Madama Butterfly Is Poorly Cast
description: In its casting, the first Madama Butterfly of the new Metropolitan Opera season Friday night wouldn't quite qualify for the Golden Age; in fact, it might have had to struggle a bit to qualify for the Leaden Age. But at least the conducting made the evening of some interest.

title: Fellini Again At the Top Of His Form
description: A MARCORD (I remember in the vernacular,of Romagna) is Federico Fellini's 13th feature and as full of marvels as anything he's ever done. It takes place in the early 1930's in a small Adriatic resort town that seems to be Fellini's recollection of Rimini, where he was born and grew up, although it's sometimes as exotic as the ancient Rome of Satyricon and as familiar as the Rimini Fellini remembered I Vitelloni.

title: U.S. Casts Doubt on States'
description: A Federal official said yester day that although all state men talhealth agencies were sup posed to review treatmen received by mental patients re leased to private facilities, the Government has not receives one complaint about such pri vate institutions from any stab in the nation.

title: Law Rescues Some Lions
description: SANTA FE, N. Mex., Sept. 28 The New Mexico Game Commission this week reestablished adult mountain lions as the only legal game for cougar hunters. Nursing females are excepted. The action rescinded a recently passed controversial regulation that would have allowed hunters to shoot all mountain lions and their kittens

title: Banks'
description: A whitehaired executive of a small, regional bank shook his finger under the nose of an officer of a real estate investment trust recently, and shouted angrily, That's our money You loaned it out You get it back!

title: Is Anyone Writing Serious Music in Russia Today?; The big men of the past generation continue to produce, but if they have anything to say it remains a secret. How long can the Soviet ideologists, sit on their, creators and intellectuals?
description: OUR Russian friends are at it again. It was with a sinking feeling that one read of the events in Muscow on Sept. 15, when goon squads Moved in to break up an outdoor exhibition of what was described as nonconformist art. Judging from photograph of one of the paintings reproduced in American newspapers the following day, the nonconformist art was no more avantgarde than early Cezanne. Maybe in 1890 this kind of painting would have been considered unusual. But the Russian bear is afraid of it. And the Russian painter, or intellectual in general, is still as much under wraps as he was in Stalin's day'.

title: 2 Nixon Servants Not on Its Payroll, Park Service Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The National Park Service is complaining that, contrary to what some of the highest Government officials have said, Manolo and Fina Sanchez are not on the park service payroll.

title: Underground Soviet Art: A Politicized Pop Style
description: Two years ago, when Mrs. Yekaterina Furtseva, the Soviet Minister of Cultural Affairs, was visiting New York, she was taken on a private visit tO the Museum of Modern Art. As it happened, the museum had just acquired an outstanding example of the kind of avantgarde art that flourished in Russia in the years just before and just ,after the Bolshevik Revolution  Vladimir BaranoffRossine's painted cubist sculpture, Symphony No. 1 (1913). When she was shown this work, Mrs. Furtseva recoiled in horror, saying: We no longer allow our artists to do things like that!

title: Tenafly Orchestra Changes Its Name
description: TENAFLYThe Tenafly Orchestra has a new name, the North Jersey Community Orchestra.

title: French Set To Appear At National
description: It has been a long time since the French appeared al the National Horse Show, 22 years to be exact. They will be at the National this year and will make stops at the other two shows on the fall indoor circuit as well  Washington and Toronto. Ted Cushny, the National's president, made the announcement yesterday. The National is scheduled for Madison Square Garden Nov. 512.

title: Marc Alain Frauenfelder Weds Claudia Porter Viek on Coast
description: Claudia Porter Viek, daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Lee of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Peter Vick, was married in San Francisco yesterday afternoon to Marc Alain Frauenfelder, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Frauenfelder of, Red Hook, N.Y.

title: Wyoming Wins, 2016
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Sept, 28 (AP)A freshman quarterback, Rick Costello, started his first collegiate game and drove Wyoming to two fourth quarter touchdowns today as the Cowboys defeated Air Force, 2016.

title: Amtrak Passengers Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The number of persons riding Amtrak's passenger trains continued to increase in August and ridership for the first eight months of the year is now 26 per cent over last year's totals, a spokesman for the agency said this week.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A hitherto unknown Sherlock Holmes story? Nicholas Meyer says he has come up with one in THE SEVENPERCENT SOLUTION (Dutton, $6.95), and since nobody wants ,to call the good man a liar, let's go along with him. It is indeed a strange tale that Dr. Watson has to tell this time.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now": Eleanor Holmes Norton, the city's Human Rights Commissioner.

title: Dena Reichel Married To Britton Chance Jr.
description: Dena L. Reichel, a former American Airlines stewardess, was married yesterday afternoon in Huntington, L.1., to Britton Chance Jr., the naval architect she met during the Newport to Bermuda race this spring.

title: State Closes a Nursery School
description: TRENTONDetermination by the state's Department of Institutions and Agencies to crack down on substandard nursery schools and childcare centers resulted last week in the first closing of a nursery school.

title: Boston U. Gets Grant
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP)Boston University announced Tuesday that it had received a $245 535 grant from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administratinn to study the effectiveness and operations of Youth Services Bureaus throughout

title: The Silent Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Thee, language we use is a clue to our seriousness. Consider the word: tradeoff. Ever since anxieties about the physical environment broke into. the consciousness of the public about five years ago, leaders in government, Industry and labor have routinely asserted their own dedication to protecting our air and water and soiL

title: Belgian Study Planned Of AntiInflation Ideas
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 28Premier Leo Tindemans of Belglum said yesterday that he would set up a ministerial committee to study the wide response he has received to an appeal for suggestions on how the Government can fight inflation.

title: Employment Service Cuts Red Tape for Jobless
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's dismal employment picture, highlighted by an outofwork rate now reaching more than 8.3 per cent, has forced the state's Labor Department into a reevaluation of the bureaucracy of its Employment Service.

title: Columbia Loses to Lafayette
MOSCOW HINTS CURB AT ART SHOW TODAY
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (Reuters) City authorities indicated today that only artists and their friends will be allowed to attend a show of nonconformist artists tomorrow.

title: The Nation In Summary
HOSTAGE ESCAPES DOMINICAN SIEGE
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 28One of the hostages held by Dominican leftists in the Venezuelan Consulate escaped today, but seven others, including a United States woman diplomat and the consul, were still held captive.

title: Prints From the Twenties Shown
description: Although the postWorld War I period was one of political and cultural isolation in the United States, it was, nevertheless, a time that fostered feverish activity in the visual arts.

title: Mary Anderson Wed in Suburbs To J. E. Reichel
description: In the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Mary Wells Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Anderson of New Canaan, was married to Jeffrey Eugene Reichel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Reichel of Wayzata, Minn and Sanibel Island, Fla.

title: Hackensack Prevails on Conversion Kick

description: October, 1973, seems likely to be remembered in history as a major turning point in world affairs.

description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 28Montclair State rolled to its third straight victory tonight, trouncing William Paterson College, 430,

title: Dave Anderson
description: Ever since he was sentenced in 1967 to triple life imprisonment for the murder of three patrons of a New Jersey tavern, Rubin Carter never asked for sympathy. Only justice.

title: Golden Retriever Named Best at Suffolk
3 Thugs Sought in Nevada In $1Million Bank Robbery
description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 28 (Reuters)The Federal Bureau of Investigation and police searched today for three Halloweenmasked gunmen who escaped with more than $1million from the First National Bank in Reno.

title: Role of Farmers Is Questioned in Peonage Cases
How Salem Saved Itself from Urban Renewal
description: THOSE who deal in urban disaster are entitled to a little encouragement once in a while. Nine years ago, we wrote a piece that held up Salem, Mass., one of America's most historic cities, as the tragic, prototypical example of how urban renewal could go wrong. The resuts were destroying not only history and architecture but also the identity and character that are the soul of a city or town. Nor was Salem alone. The process and the product were being diestamped across the country in the name of traffic improvement and the tax base in the most destructive assault on the American since the Civil War.

title: The Making of a House
description: A beautifully designed house in harmony with its surroundings does not necessarily reflect the architectclient relationship. Building a house can be a stormy process, exacerbated by delays, unexpected hikes in costs, misunderstandings between workmen, architects and clients, and by the fact that when most people build a house, they see as a reflection of themselveseither as they are or as they wish they were. This may be the first time the client has come to terms with the questions of Who am I and what do I want? There can also be conflicts between architect and client as to just whose identity is being reflected in this new house.

title: Coed Gym Classes on Rise in State
description: EAST BRUNSWICK Something new has been added to 16yearold Mardi Verbanic's school curriculum this year: coed gym. She is one of a growing number of female high school students throughout the state who is participating in such a program.

title: A Toad For Tuesday
description: One has grown so accustomed to grim children's books in this grimmest of all possible worlds that a genuinely nice children's story comes as a surprise. Gone, for a moment, are urban problems, divorce, sex, drugs, death, the ghettoand in their place pops up the story of a toad. Warton.

title: Princeton's Rally Ties Rutgers, 66
Dr. Lynn Borgatta, Interne, Is a Bride
description: Dr. Lynn Borgatta was married yesterday at her home to Dr. Stephen E. Moshman. Paul Migliore, a leader in the Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony.

title: In Westchester, StainedGlass Windows and StoneGround Corn
description: TWENTY miles upHudson from Manhattan stand two remarkable monuments to our American herit age with its dual thrust toward God and Caesar. One is the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, a quiet fieldstone building ablaze with scripture when the light shines through the nine stainedglass panels by Marc Chagall and the rose window by Henri Matisse. The other is just a mile downhill, Philipsburg Manor, where the miller still raises the sluice that frees the river that turns the wheel that starts the gears that spin the stones that grind the corn that spills into a trough where it's scooped into bags and soldjust as it was in 1690. Philipsburg IVIanor is a living museum, restored as farm, grist mill, barn and family dwelling so that visitors can experience 18thcentury Hudson Valley life in all its varied detail.

title: Ford's Wife Undergoes Breast Cancer Surgery
Patricia Bandler Bride Of Henry Hornblower 3d
description: St, Luke's Episcopal Church in Katonah, N. Y., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Patricia Bandler to Henry Hornblower 3d, an antiques and art dealer in Boston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen Bolle.

title: 1,000 Attend Dinner in Honor Of the President of Italy Here
description: President Giovanni Leone of Italy had lunch with Mayor Beame at Gracie Mansion and dinner with 1,000 dignitaries at the WaldorfAstoria yesterday and, just for fun, took a ride on the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Coverage in Case of a Kidnapping
description: Political terrorist activity, both in the United States and abroad, has resulted in some changes in the corporate way of life. Companies have increased security they have imposed a more secluded, even hidden, lifestyle on employesand they have sought insurance against the danger of a kidnapping and ransom demand.

title: Photography
description: CORNELL Capa, Charles Harbutt and Arnold Newman, who all have recent books or gallery exhibitions, have in common the fact that they have all worked for Life magazine. Nevertheless, they have very different approaches to photography, and it is interesting to see how the same magazine background produced three such different photographers.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Alfred B. Fitt's excellent article (Amnesty, Sept. 8) prompts me to wonder what sort of reception the men returning home could expect from their fellow citizens, friends, employers and others with whom they would come in close daily contact,

title: World News Briefs
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Lieut. Gen. Amen Michael Andom, chairman of Ethiopia's provisional military council, stepped down today as Chief of Staff of the armed forces because of work pressure, the council said.

title: Repression in Peru
description: One of the outstanding journalists of the Americas attempting to appeal an eighteenmonth jail sentence, inflicted on the ground that an article in his Peruvian magazine damaged the honor and reputation of high Government officials. Enrique Zileri's offense was that he raised questions about the settlement Peru's military rulers made with the United States last February involving compensation for nationalized American properties.

title: The 350,000 Cubans in south Florida make a remarkable success story. Even if Castro fell tomorrow, great numbers would not return.
description: MIAMI, Fla. A 28yearold college instructor sips strong, sweet Cuban coffee and speaks in distant voice about the life he left behind Havana at the age of 12. My parents sent me out of Cuba alone because they were afraid I was already involved in the underground and would end up in prison. They were right.... I felt very passionately. But I followed my parents wishes. I went to school in Michigan, found my present teaching job in Alabama. Now I want to return to my own culturebut for me the return no longer means Havana. Miami is the capital of Cuban life in our new country. This has become the new Cuba on American soil.

title: 2 SENATORS URGE INQUIRY ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 28 (UPI)  Senators Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, and Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, jointly announced today that they would ask Congress to order the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, to make a full investigation of former President Richard M. Nixon's role in Watergate..

title: Artistic Excellence Loses Out to Social History the Whitney
description: THE exhibition called The Painters America: Rural and Urban Life, 18101910, which Patricia Hills has organized at the Whitney Museum of American Art, follows by less than a year the same museum's great exhibition of The Flowering of American Folk Art 17761876, organized by Jean Lipman and Alice Winchester. The new exhibition has nothing like the force of revelation that made the folk art show such an overwhelming experiencesuch an overwhelming esthetic experience. Indeed, the focus of The Painters America is not really esthetic at all. Miss Hills, the associate curator of 18thand 19thcentury art at the Whitney, has conceived of this selection of 115 paintings by 71 artists as a sort of social history of American life in the period under consideration. Some excellent artists are represented, but the emphasis is on social evidence rather than artistic excellence.

title: T. M. Neely Marries Kate Debevoise
description: Kate Stephenson Debevoise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson R. Debevoise of Short Hills, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Matthew Neely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Neely of Spring Lake, Mich. The ceremony was performed in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Millburn, N. J., by the, Rev. Joseph D. Herring. He was assisted by the Rev. J. Elliott Lindsley of Germantown, N. Y.

title: How to Sail in Heavy Air:
description: Although novices should try to avoid it, and some people prefer not to get caught in it, heavyair sailing can be packed with thrills. In local waters around New York, summer and earlyautumn winds are usually light, but places like Great South Bay, the Shrewsbury River (where I do much of my sailing), Barnegat Bay and Buzzards Bay are blessed with afternoon sea breexes that pipe up to 20 knots or more on many days. Handling them, or the stronger winds that can hit any body of water in a squall or with the approach of a storm, Is an important part of sailing. If you do it right, it is great fun.

title: Those Same Old Sounds Are Back From Rock's First Golden Era
description: IN pop land, it seems a brandnew generation of listeners materializes every two, three or four years. Roger McGuinn, once guitaristcomposer of that superground The Byrds, sings a tune on his most recent solo album entitled Same Old Sound, and the lyrics deal with the requirements exerted on performers by these new audiences. Ob serves McGuinn, I've been all around the world. Playing songs for all the boys and girls... And everywhere I'm bound, I got to play that same old same old sound... I did it for your sister last year, Going to slip in right into your ear..."

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
Clarence King, ExProfessor Of Social Work, Is Dead at 90
description: Clarence King, a professor emeritus of the New York School of Social Work of Columbia University, died Friday in an automobile accident in Nantucket, Mass;, where he lived. His age was 90.

title: Headliners
description: Albert E. Rees, a 53yearold Princeton University economist, has been chosen by President Ford to head the new Council on Wage and Price Stability. The council will deal with matters and policies that relate to inflation. A lowkey Democrat and labor specialist, Mr. Rees is said to be cool to a return to wage and price controls as a means of curbing rapid inflation, but is unwilling to tole them out. He served on. committees in former President Nixon's stabilization program in 197174.

title: 2 Hijack a Small Plane, Drop Explosive in Ulster
description: DUBLIN Sunday, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Two gunmen hijacked a light plane last night and forced the pilot to take them on a bombing mission over Northern Ireland, the police said.today.

title: The Real America
description: In the longago era of President Nixon ascendant, Ben J. Wattenberg and Richard M. Scammon wrote The Real Majority, a book asserting that liberals won't run the country because they don't have the votes. Now Wattenberg takes his thesis a step further: in his new book, lie argues that liberals don't understand the country eitherbecause they don't know the facts.

title: Unusual Khrushchev Tombstone Draws Hundreds
description: Moscow, Sept. 28It Was one of those bright, warm, leafy fall afternoons today and the tourists were out in droves, strolling through the cemetery of Novodevichi monastery, where Russia's notables are buried.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: CanAm Demise/America's Cup Yachting and Fair Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Controversial Shopping Mall Defended by Trenton Mayor
description: TRENTONMayor Arthur J. Holland contends that a twoblock pedestrian mall in the heart of the city will fulfill its purpose of reviving the downtown area, even though he admits he is not entirely happy with its looks.

title: Attempting to Cope
description: When members of the International Monetary Fund gathered for their annual meeting last year in Nairobi, Kenya, the focus was on ways to transform temporary arrangements for floating rates into a more permanent and stable world monetary system.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Continental Grain Company has leased approximately 120,000 square feet at 277 Park Avenue. The lease has a term of more than 15 years and an aggregate rent of more than $20million. The transaction is believed to be the largest this year involving a Park Avenue property.

title: Is That Silver Teaspoon Cheap Enough Now?
description: In 1964 a teaspoon in sterling contained $1.29 worth of silver. Last February the same teaspoon, weighing about one ounce, had $6.70 worth of silver. And by Friday, the silver in such a spoon had dropped in value to $4.29,

title: Not Here, Note Now
description: No useful purpose on be served by a debate on the Palestinian issue in the current session of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: A Standard Slip Becomes an Unusual
description: For half a century, the Montgomery Ward catalogue has been showing cozy, knitted slips, made by the same mill in the South. Except for little old ladies with rheumatism and farmers wives in unheated houses, few people pay much attention to them these days, although they are still there on page 203 of the new catalogue.

title: Reviving Hoboken Saves Old Homes
description: HOBOKENThis Hudson River city has decided to continue an experiment aimed at rehabilitating oneand twofamily brownstones and keeping longtime residents here.

title: Me and My Captain Written and illustrated by M. B. Goffstein. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $3.95. (Ages 6 to 9)
description: Me is a she, a little wooden dolt on the shelf. The Captain, wooden, too, is master of a model fishing boat anchored on the window sill below. She dreams of'him coming up to see her, marrying, showing him her treasures, eating the plaster figurine food, laughing, joking. And the doll dreams on: the Captain would have to go away on a long voyage and her life would be the same as before except now there would be someone to watch for and wait for and hope for good weather for. And possibly something to tell him about when he returnsa baby. But if the dream never comes to pass, just looking down at the Captain's boat on the sill below makes her feel happy because he is there.

title: Booklets Available On Canoeing, Golf
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Community Affairs has published a general guide on canoeing and canoe trails in New Jersey.

title: A New Shelter for Young
description: EAST ORANGEThe second phase of a new program to provide housing for juveniles in need of supervision will begin this week under the direction of the Children's Aid and Adoption Society of New Jersey.

title: How About Banks as Bail Bondsmen?
description: It is not a matter of murder or whatnot but Philadelphia's Board of Trustees thinks it may know of a source of lowinterest bail money for lowincome suspects in cases of minor crimes: Banks.

title: The Eurodollar Bubble
description: When the United States suffered a huge trade deficit in August, here's one angle the international monetary experts may have overlooked: For many weeks dollars have been flowing into this countrywell, sort of.

title: Legislative Notes; On With the (Budget) Show
description: TRENTONWalter Wechsler, the state's retiring Budget Director and for nearly 20 years one of the principals of the Abe and Walt Show at legislative appropriations hearings, has finally become a oneman act.

title: SOVIET SAYS TIBET IS BASE FOR CHINA
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28The Soviet news agency Tass charged this week that China had turned Tibet into a huge military base, menacing her neighbors, especially India, with a network of missile bases and longrange artillery.

title: Alternative Energies
description: Central to any program for blunting the socalled oil weapon ofthe international cartel is a viable prospect of alternative sources of energy. Congress is about to complete action on an ambitious longterm program for energy research and development which stands good chance of. providing just that. It could pe a major source of encouragement in efforts to weld a united front of oilconsuming countries to bring down the crushing cost of oil.

title: Tis the Season to be Cutesy. Fa. la. la. la. and So Forth
description: BRING back sex and death. The Waltons have a lot to answer for. After two weeks of the whOlesome new TV season, feel as though I've been locked inside gigantic hot fudge sundae with my mouth wired open. Cute animals, cute forest rangers, cute teachers, cute bass players, cute pioneers and cute Alex Karras....

title: The Shah: A Man in Search Of Ways to Spend the Money
description: TEHERANNot so many years ago a statement by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi that Iran intended to become world power within a generation or so would have been quietly absorbed by the diplomatic community here and forgotten as a harmless vision of grandeur.

title: Michaele C. Nelson Has Nupti$13
description: Michaele Cameron Nelson was married yesterday afternoon in Reading, Pa., to Barclay Cooke Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooke of Englewood, N. J., and Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Charles Sutton of Christ Episcopal Church in Reading performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Cameron 3d, parents of the bride.

title: The CoverUp Trial Is All Set to Begin
description: WASHINGTONAt 8 A.M. this Tuesday, bailing any last minute changes, the cars will start pulling up at the United States Courthouse on Pennsylvania Avenue. First the court. staff, and the press then the defendants and their lawyers then the prosecutors, who have waited 14 months for this day ever since the special Watergate prosecution was established.

title: Judith Barnes Is Bride of John Vogel Jr.
description: Judith Ann Barnes, daughter of Mrs. Catherine Barnes and Harry D. Barnes of Ra,leigh, N. C., was married yesterday morning to John H. Vogel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Vogel of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Helen Farmer Wed To Clifford Culley
description: In the First Congregational Church, Litchfield, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Helen Morey Farmer was married to Clifford Jay Culley by the Rev. Alan Hundevad.

title: A Clash in Philosophies Underlies School Dispute
description: GREAT NECKThis affluent North Shore community, which has always prided itself for its educational excellence, is in the throes of a bitter fight over an attempt by the majority of the Board of Education to dismiss its Superintendent of Schools.

title: Ann Brown Bride Of William Farrell
description: Ann Barbara Brown and William Lawrence Farrell, who received master's degrees in business administration from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday afternoon in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N. Y. The Rev. Thomas Hartman performed the ceremony.

title: Sally Stevenson to Bc Married To Karl Fisohet in december
description: Mr. and Mrs John R. Stevenson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Hopkins Stevenson, to Karl H. Fischer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gunther F. Fischer, of Caracas, Venezuela. A December wedding is planned.

Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Okla. State Is Toppled By Baylor
Notes: Green Light For Railroad Guide
description: IN its halcyon days, The Official Guide of the Railways was an American institution, its 1,500 pages crammed with train schedules and parlorand sleepingcar routes, details of each train's equipment, maps, mileages and voluminous lists of stations and railroads. The guide once showed a stop for a through train, at a station where it was not actually scheduled to stop; when the error was pointed out to the railroad's traffic manager, he exclaimed: If the Official Guide says the train stops there, then, dammit, have it stop. there! Such was the power of the guide.

title: Austria Tops Hungary
description: VIENNA, Sept. 28 (UPI)Austria defeated Hungary, 10, in an exhibition soccer match before 40,000 spectators today, marking Austria's first victory against Hungary in 10 years.

title: The Big Purples
description: Every year is an aster year, and every autumn seems to be specially favored with those flowers that were named for the stars. But this is a special year for the purple asters, especially those big, spectacular ones called New England asters.

title: Fashion
description: Until the coat season arrives, nothing beats the look of a sweater. A heavy cardigan or pullover takes the place of a jacketand fits better into the soft, flowing scheme of things this year. Many of the new sweaters have matching mufflers.

title: JAMES L. MAXWELL

title: Post Rolls for 398 Yards In 247 Defeat of Wagner
Do Chickens have Lips?
description: Some months ago, at a dinner party, toward the end of the evening, a young woman asked a young man, Will I see you tomorrow? The young man replied, Does a chicken havd lips? That was the sum total of their exchange. She seemed to understand exactly what he meant. was mystified and fascinated. He could have meant yes, no, maybe, unfortunately, impossible, or it all depends on the constellations of the Zodiac. Such ambiguity was breathtaking.

title: Hanna's Skirt Inspires a Very Complicated Kind of Laughter

Written and first performed in 1965, it enjoyed regular revivals and rerevivals in Off Off Broadway. showcases before attaining its present eminence as a solid Off Broadway hit at the Top of the Village Gate. With a kind of cockroach pertinacity, it has survived. nine furtive years with its original cast ana companynotbly Heidi Hanft an the title role and director Neil Flanagan substantially unchanged. Indeed, this play is a thing of such unkillable energy that even success, at this point, may be unable to spoil it. it.

She has summed up the women's movement in 10,000 words for psychiatry textbook; she has scrutinized Freud's view of female sexuality for a study of women and analysis; and she has addressed women teachers on favorite subjects, including Realizing Human Potential and Woman's Place in A Changing World.

Sailboats and powerboats, coming back strong from what was supposed to be a fuelless year, fill 270 slips. Promoters say the sailboats make up the second largest show of its kind in the world (Annapolis is first).

description: MONROE, La.As Verdiacee HamptonGoston describes it, she was an early and fervent supporter of Federal general revenue sharing. It was a renewal of my faith in my country, Mrs. HamptonGaston said recently. I believed Nixon's rhetoric about power to the people. I believed it.

description: After their second marriage and divorce (to each other) Nell's parents arrange that Nell and her younger brother Hugo will live in New York with Dad, who writes science books at home, while Mom will live in the country with her friend Greta and commute to her New York job. The kids can't live fulltime at Greta's place because she's not the maternal type. Whether Mom is or not, we're not told.

title: 24 Cokes Cost $23.38 At Inflation Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 At the conference on inflation, the Cokes delivered to the press room cost nearly a dollar a bottle.

4 Seized in Hijacking. of Truck Cargoes
description: The former head of a Brooklyn antipoverty program andl another man scheduled to go on trial this week in a case of attempted murder and kidnapping were arrested with two other men in Queens late Friday night and charged with possession of hijacked truck cargoes worth more than $250,000.

title: An Odd Ring
description: WASHINGTON  To those who remember a notorious Government. agency called the W.P.A., or who have read about it, the sound of bankers and businessmen and conservative politicians, praising the idea of public service employment takes getting used to.

title: Dealers in smack and their victims
description: So much current fiction is mere weltanschauung tethered to a subject. So much autobiographical surmise. You read the plot as a superficial gloss on the author's aspirations and complaints, his literary education, his or her psychotherapy; and when you are finished the chief consequences of the action in any social setting have become merely the concocting of the novel.

title: Books . About handcrafts, building, gardening, antiques, architecture and interior design.
description: A backtonature movement has been welling up in American society and along with it a deep nostalgia for the arts and values of the colonial past. In the search for the indigenous arts and skills of an earlier America, a new respect for handcrafts and individuality has been developing as many of the books presented here bear witness. An exquisite panorama of the work of potters, weavers, glass blowers, jewelers and wood turners which demonstrates that centuriesold traditions can be preserved even as modern applications lend a new vitality to ancient forms, as demonstrated by sixthgeneration Irish chairs, Carob leaf hats from Colombia, blownglass teapots from the United States, appliqued ceremonial hangings from Dahomey. The 64 color plates and 190 blackandwhite illustrations are given additional meaning by the opening essay by Octavio Paz, the Mexican poet and philosopher, who sees the return of hand craftsmanship in the United States, and Western Europe as one of the symptoms of the great change that is taking place in our contemporary sensibility. This is a very special book. Beginning with an awareness of beauty in the commonplace and a respect for natural materials, one discovers that design is everywhere  and everyone is a designer. This relationship between man, society and nature in shaping our environment is explored by the author in this remarkably thorough study of design, its history, principles, process and application. Hundreds of excellent illustrations covering the fine arts as well as crafts and industrial design reinforce the eloquent text. The silversmith, the furniture maker, the jeweler, the costume and dress designer are examined. Helen Evans covers the general (architecture, landscape design, urban theory, experimental art forms) and the specific (Tiffany lamps, Barcelona chairs, Bojeson monkeys, San Blas Indian textiles, Japanese rice paper, plastic baby toilets, macrame dresses, glass coffee makers). Have I missed anything? The author certainly has not. Another celebration of doing one's own thing. There's a surprising number of wellbuilt little octagons popping up in the woods these days, writes Art Boericke. His text and the accompanying color photographs by Barry Shapiro will tempt even the most timid to collect a few posts and beams, some loved bits and pieces for building materials and take a deep walk into the woods in search of a building site. The handhewn shelters shown in the bookoften made and decorated with found objects, driftwood, stained glass, shells, stones, unconventionally shaped windows and doorsexhibit a spontaneity and richness of imagination rarely seen in our more disciplined contemporary structures. With barn siding, native stone, adobe brick, logs and salvaged lumber, the builderimprovisers whose work is shown have created homes that are their personal statements about a way of life, a way that may still be possible. Some of the houses seem almost medieval with a monkish austerity; others are decorated with the gingerbread of Grimm's fairy tales. Others reflect the most modern architectural techniques. For those who need a lot of help in building their own home, not only how, but how much will it cost and how long will it take, this is the book. It takes no architectural or building expertise to follow these precise directions, clarified still more with 400 illustrations, although the tiny handwritten text may present some difficulties to the bifocal set. (There is also an edition set in regular type.) There are separate sections on how to site and how to finance a homemade home. A helpful bibliography accompanies each chapter. The roof section is particularly appealing with its drawings of the French mansard, the pyramid, spire, dome, hip, gambrel, shed and valley gable. It is the gable roof that is recommended here, since the book concentrates on teaching the reader to build a traditional, early American, wood frame house. It is not necessary to build a house to profit from the book: the amateur fixitupper or repairman will find it useful. With enormous grace, the author details the latest trends as well as the basic techniques of these crafts. There are splendidly lucid drawings of stitchingwhether it be flat, seed, looped or knottedand color and black and white illustrations of wall hangings; hand woven, threedimensional sculptures; decorative pillows; puff patchwork. A good book for the beginner and experienced stitcher alike. A joyful book in which Sharon McKain reveals that she, in fact, is the Great Noank Quilt Factory and that is actually one living room equipped with one sewing machine. Her work, which ranges from back packs and tobacco pouches to the traditional, warm, comfy down quilts, is illustrated in color photographs and blackandwhite line drawings. Her designs are simple and contemporary yet hark back to early American geometrical forms. The Cathedral Window Quilt, the Windmill Quilt and the YoYo are particularly charming.

title: Acupuncture Tied To Psychoanalysis
description: THE SPRINGS  A link between the ancient healing at of acupuncture and the modern science of psychoan alysis is being forged here by Dr. Leon Hammer, a physician trained in both discipilines who insists the two have much in common and is using the needle to treat mental illness.

title: Joan
description: It is possible to gauge the solemnity of a political event in America by the number of wives required to be present. At the recent resignationinauguration, for example, it was wonderful to observe the crowd of wives who had been dusted off and brought to the East Room to shed a tear, beam with pride, etc. Were they there to create the illusion that both sexes were deeply involved in the transfer of power? Or are we expected to believe that the wives of important men have a significant influence upon their husbands and therefore are entitled to take part in the rituals? If so, why didn't John Chancellor's wife Appear at his side during those historic days and nights? Why, in fact, were no women at all other than Helen Gahagan Douglas asked to contribute to the general vacuity the networks presented the night of Nixon's resig

title: Gypsy Is Still Mysteriously Perfect Theater
description: THE special genius of American musical comedy doesn't lie in its stars, though God knows that Ethel Merman and Mary Martin and Bobby clark and Victor Moore have had a thumping great deal to do with it. It doesn't even lie in the songs, for all that the American musical stage has fired off Gershwin and Kern and Rodgers and Berlin scores like rockets around the world. We are well aware that it rarely lies in the librettos: librettos are most often necessary nuisances be smothered as swiftly as possible by half a dozen more glittering values, except on those occasions When Kaufman or Hammerstein or Burrows is in top form. Everything's important, to be sure. But one thing is more important than the whole bundle of others when an unforgettable musical is born. The fit.

Turner, 40 years old, of San Francisco, now associate executive of the Synod of the Pacific, will begin his work as the new synod's executive next January at the synod's headquarters in Syracuse.

title: Roll, Jordan, Roll
description: The question of Negro slaveryits origins, evils, economic value and ultimate consequenceshas now evoked nearly two decades of searching reexamination. Since the 1950's no other question in American history has occasioned more lively controversy sweeping reinterpretation. The,, debate has tested new methods of discovering and weighing evidence; has moved into esoteric regions of social psychology, folklore, anthropology, econometrics and constitutional law; and, by reaching out for comparative soundings in other cultural and historical experiences, has broadened the very meaning of historical understanding.

title: Church Claims a Record

Larry Dodge, youth director at the church, said the youths finished reading all 260 chapters of the New Testament in 16 hours and nine minutes.

title: Is Decorator a Dirty Word?
description: Do interior decorators want to be architects as much as architects want to be interior decorators? It seems so. Architects have traditionally only been interested in doing interiors as a part of the total architectural package. Interior decorators, on the other hand, in addition to supplying the decoration, are rapidly slipping into the role of architect by making structural changes.

After two years of pro football, Miss O'Brien is still playing before a few hundred fans, without headlines, without being recognized on the streets of Dallas and for a twofigure salary625 a game.

title: Design Trend/1
description: There is a shift from the insistent patterns of seasons past to more subtle use of prints. There is news also in the backgrounds for these more sophisticated prints: The trend is to dark shiny walls. Designer Kevin McNamara covered the walls of his living room with a glossy tortoise shell vinyl. The corner banquette is upholstered in a cotton fabric with a squiggly print. Pillows are covered in dotted white linen. Natural accentsthe sisal rug and bamboo blindsgive the room a summery look. Across from the fireplace, an antique Louis XVI desk (right) is placed in front of the windows. Twin Louis XV arm chairs are leather covered on the front and upholstered in a quiet plaid on the back. Rattan and wicker have moved indoors to give contemporary interiors a yearround feeling of summer. Designer Robert Perkins paired wicker piecesthe folding beach chair, round cocktail table and small chairside tableswith a sofa and slipper chair covered hi awningstriped upholstery in the studio apartment of Kecia Keeble. Floors are covered in natural sisal. Shiny satin pillows mixed with striped ones spill over the sofa. Junglesized plants add drama. The lacquered Chinese table and chest (in foreground) hold sang de boeuf vases of fresh greenery. Serene monochromatic schemes are replacing those hot, hardontheeyes primarycolor schemes. Designers Mica Ertegun and Chessy Rayner of Mac II painted the walls of this Fifth Avenue apartment in a highshine charcoal brown. Everything else in the roomthe lowpile velvet rug, the three large sofas and the occasional chair, and the draperiesis a crisp white. The side tables. English antiques, blend with the twin modern Parsons tables covered in tortoise shell and the lacquered Chineseinspired coffee tables. The two English Chippendale arm chairs have subtle brownandwhite polka dot print seats. There's a fresh interest in trompe l'oeil floors now that sturdy clear polyurethane coatings protect painted floors and make them easy to keep up. The new painted floors have nothing of the peasant about them, but are another facet of the new subtlety. Designer Richard Neas painted the floor of his apartment with large squares that simulate the striation of cut agate. Another trompe l'oeil effect is the ceiling cove painted in a crisscross treillage. Twin armoires for clothes and books flank the daybed that sits in a mirrored alcove. The color schemepearl gray walls and offwhite upholstery mingled with beige and chamois accents in pillows and upholsteryreflects the trend to quiet, often monochromatic interiors. The furnishings are a mix of period and modern with a gilt chandelier, a Louis XV desk, a slipper chair covered in and Lucite coffee table. There is always a Thirties revival and this season it consists of those plump overstuffed Hollywood forms that have been cropping up occasionally in the past few seasons. This time _ they're paired with satin. Designer Robert Patino of PatinoWolf put them together in this Manhattan bedroom. The bed has the flourishes typical of the lookthe rolled upholstered base, bun feet and arched channeled headboard. The occasional chair is covered in satin, and the roundcornered side tables are lacquered white.

title: The World In Summary
description: The tendency in Latin America toward violence and terrorism to solve political problems once again has in volved a United States Government official. Terrorists in the Dominican Republic have abducted Barbara A. Hutchison, 47 years old, United States Information Service director there, and at least eight other persons, and de mended a $1million ransom from the United States and the release of 38 political prisoners from Dominican jails.The terrorist group, said to be leftists led by a plane hijacker who recently got out of jail, called itself The Freedom Movement of the 12th of January. They threatened to blow up the Venezuelan Consulate and kill the hostages unless their demands were met. Miss Hutchison, the first U.S. woman diplomat ever kidnapped, is the third highranking United States Government official to be abducted in the last six months.

title: Letters: :Discord Over Spanish Guitar Caper
description: To the Editor: Brook Zern's story of his difficulties Avith the police in Seville after the theft of a guitar  Encounter: Strum and prang (Travel Section, Sept. 15)pis amusing but does not make sense,He was released because he is not guapo, or handsome (which a witness said the culprit was), and the punch line in the article is that only much later did he learn what the word means. However, Mr. Zern was able to follow his ,many interviews with the police in Spanish and even could read an obviously scribbled note while it was upside down. Guopo is a common word (not only in Seville) and is found in every dictionary. Incidentally, did he buy the guitar? A. E. REICHENBERGER Deansboro, N.Y.

title: From Brazil, 'Night of Scarecrow,' Bizarre Musical
description: Any movie maker who sets out to tell the story of his people, to pit good against evil and cowboy against hired gun, to mix in local myths and Christian symbolism, to match reality with fantasy, to inveigh against the evils of capitalism, to tell a story of tortured loveand, what's more, do it all as a musical  had better bring in a masterpiece.Srgio Ricardo, a Brazilian singer, composer and movie maker, set out to do all of these things in a film called "The Night of the Scarecrow," shown last weekend at the 12th New York Film Festival.It is not a masterpiece.It is, instead, a lavish and self-indulgent film so encumbered with ambitiousness and artistic and intellectual baggage, and committed in so many directions, that it can manage only sporadic and somewhat frenzied efforts at the full realization of any of its goals.Stripped of its burden of pretension, "The Night of the Scarecrow" is the story of impoverished Brazilian peasants exploited by the greasy landowner whose parched fields they work. The peasants are championed by a cowboy figure; the landlord, by a pack of hired, motorcycle-riding soldier-gunmen. Drawn to the peasants' champion and the leader of the gunmen, and torn between the two, is a peasant woman.Upon this basic structure have been piled the Scarecrow, part Christ figure, part minstrel; a bosomy dragon representing evil; the landowner's bourgeois retinue  given to clown make-up or satanic garb, whichever best serves the demands of the moment's symbolism; a mad holy man; a peasant chorus, and a set of insect-wing motorcycles and cycling costumes that appear to have come out of "The Wild One" by way of Attila the Hun and Tinker Bell.However many its faults, "Night of the Scarecrow" is too busy a film to be accused of dullness. At its best, this revolutionary pop opera is full of color and movement; and some of its musicpulsing with rhythm or wailing with despairis captivating, although the lyrics, at least in their English translation, seem less accomplished.Set beside the exceptionally good "Os Fuzis" ("The Guns"), a Brazilian film by Ruy Guerra, shown last June at the First Avenue Screening Room, that deals with essentially the same subject matter in the same locale from the same viewpoint, "The Night of the Scarecrow" comes off as a case of egregious bloat.

title: Opera: Met's Giovanni
description: Saturday night's Dun Giovanni closed the Metropolitan Opera season's first weekan unnecessary marathon that saw seven different operas hurled into repertory within six daysand turned out to be a mostly good, oldtashioned Met performance. There was no particular distinction to the direction and the musical side of things was uneven, but at least there was enough to admire to make one feel that one had seen a decent representation of the work.the part exhilaratingly, shaped the Italian with relish ish and projected an unusually malevolent Don. This wasn't a particularly seductive lover, or one who evoked much sympathy. But in its own machobravado way, Mr. Milnes's idea of the character had an undeniable appeal.
