title: Leonardo Legend Grows as LongLost Notes Are Published
description: Engineers at the Sperry Gyroscope Company, seeking in the nineteentwenties to devise a roller bearing arrangement that would keep stable a fastspinning aircraft gyro, hit upon what they considered to be an ingenious solution to the problem.

title: Aide of Public Defender Says Others Knew of Recantations in Carter Case
description: A senior investigator for the New Jersey Public Defender said yesterday that there was information from other people that both principal witnesses in the murder case against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and a codefendant had made informal statements recanting their testimony before the witnesses current formal recantations.

title: SHIFT IN STRATEGY BY ADMINISTRATION ON AID IS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Administration officials said today that President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger ordered various Government agencies late last week to stop lobbying for a new foreign aid bill, in an effort to block amendments that would restrict Presidential freedom of action in foreign affairs.Rather than trying for a new bill, the officials said, the Administration sought to extend foreignaid spending by means of a continuing resolution, which is based on last year's legislation. This strategy, however, caused problems both for countries that were not included in the bill last year and for American agencies with commitments for steppedup programs in the new bill.The continuing resolution, passed by Congress last June, runs out tomorrow.A Blow to EgyptiansHerman F. Eilts, the United States Ambassador in Cairo, cabled Mr. Kissinger last week that the new strategy was a blow between the eyes for the Egyptians and that it would leave President Anwar elSadat in a highly embarrassing and conceivably dangerous position.The Administration had requested as part of the new aid bill $250million in assistance for Egypt for clearing the Suez Canal, restoring cities along the canal and helping Egyptian trade. Egypt would not qualify for that aid under last year's bill.The Agency for International Development has also expressed unhappiness about the new strategy, since it would mean about $200million less in programs to help nations increase food production.The Administration had asked for about $255million in additional aid for food and nutrition in the new bill, and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had approved $200million.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Prison Fire Forces EvacuationPrisoners at the Sussex County Jail in Newton set fire to mattresses in their cell, filling the prison building with smoke and forcing all 26 inmates to evacuate. Sheriff Jerald Willis said that six prisoners were admitted to Newton Memorial Hospital for treatment for smoke inhalation.

title: Maine Democrat Plans Bill To Eliminate Dog Fights
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Representative Peter [Kyros, Democrat of Maine, has announced that he will introduce a bill designed to eliminate the scent of money, cruelty and excitement from dog fights.

title: New Orleans Jazz Given With a Twist By Newish Shakers
description: A light and springy variant of New Orleans jazz was brought to New York yesterday afternoon by the Louisiana Shakers, a fivepiece band whose roots are in New Orleans although it was organized in California. Playing at the RFK Theater on West 48th Street (formerly the Ritz), the Shakers dispensed with two of the most traditional New Orleans jazz instrumentstrumpet and trombone  and used only two saxophones, alto and tenor, as a front line.

title: Rice for the Hungry
description: The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives is reconsidering its refusal to let the full House vote on a bill that would lower the cost of rice to a hungry world. The bill, which would lift much of the restriction on rice growing, would benefit not only the poor consumer in America's cities but also those Arkansas and Mississippi farmers who would gladly substitUte. rice for more economically uncertain crops but cannot do so because of present Governmentimposed limitations. That explains the bill's unusual combination of support from Congressmen so rarely in tandem as Representatives Rangel of New York and Whitten of Mississippi.

title: 42 Theft Suspects at Party Find Police Are the Hosts
description: Undercover detectives held a party for alleged thieves in a Queens warehouse Saturday night. Before they could ask for refreshments, the 42 guests were charged with theft of $700,000 in property and arrested by undercover police who had played the role of fences for several months.

title: News Summary and Index
State Senate Gets Grant For Energy Crisis Study
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP)The National Science Foundation'can has granted $39,700 to the New York State Senate to help legislative leaders in the Northeast develop a regional response to the energy crisis.

title: RELIEF CUTS EVICT OLD AND DISABLED
description: Tens of thousands of the city's aged, blind and disabled are being driven by economic necessity to move from their small and often squalid quarters in singleroom occupancy hotels into even less desirable places.

title: Stage: Fornes Aurora
description: Untested experiment is out of the question in the commercial climate of Broadway, and even with Off Broadway that former haven of the new and the inexpensiveprices have escalated against the daring. Of course, both Broadway and Off Broadway can be the expansive hosts of pretested experimental work (that is largely how they sustain themselves), but the financial situation is such that nothing much new can pos sibly originate in either area, except, perhaps, in the musical.

title: A BROOKLYN GROCER IS SLAIN BY ROBBERS
description: The owner of a Brooklyn grocery store was shot and. killed yesterday by two robbers who first were pelted with canned goods by a young clerk and then chased apparently emptyhanded from the store by la German shepherd dog who may have bitten one of them.

title: Aston Martin, at $32 ,000 , May Become Extinct Car
description: LONDON, Sept. 29  Aston Martin, one of the most renowned names in the luxury sports car field, is facing the prospect of bankruptcy because of tight money in Britain and strict antipollution standards in the United States.

title: State G.O.P. Committee Wilson's Top Contributor
description: The Republican State Committee is fast developing as Governor Wilson's counter to Edward M. Carey, Representative Hugh L. Carey's brother and chief angel. The Wilson campaign financial report filed with the State Board of Elections today shows a $200,000 state committee contribution to the Wilson campaign atop an earlier contribution of $350,000.

title: Major Bills in Congress
Ford Rejected as Gambit Nixon Bid to Yield Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Ford dismissed as conversational gambit an offer two weeks ago by former President Richard M. Nixon to relinquish the unconditional pardon granted to Mr. Nixon, a senior White House official said tonight.

title: Dirks, Back on Wall St., Joins Bernard.. Herold
description: Raymond L. Dirks, the stock market analyst who uncovered widespread fraud at the Equity Funding Corporation of America 18 months ago and then was forced to leave Wall Street after the New York Stock Exchange charged him with fraud, is back on Wall Street again, his new employer said yesterday.

title: 40 Detectives Seek Clues in Police Officer's Killing
description: Forty detectives canvassed apartments, hotels, restaurants and bars along and near West 79th Street yesterday in search of details that would shed light on the murder and dismemberment of Police Officer Patrick J. Kelly.

title: Robert Mazur Marries Marilyn Cohen
description: White Plains. The elder Mr. Mazur is president of Mazur Brothers, Inc., retail furniture dealers there,

title: Russell Willis Dead at 56; NBC News Writer and Editor
description: RUssell Willis, a writer, editor and producer for NBC News from 1946 until his medical retirement early this year, died yesterday of cancer in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 501 West 121st Street.

title: WALKER DRIVES ON IN FREEWAY STYLE
description: Jerry Jeff Walker is certainly a survivor, emerging out of the rock clutter of the late nineteensixties. And, as far as New York is concerned, he is a definite cult figure, as proven by the audience at his first Cernegie Hall concert Saturday. It was freakish in its attention to his folkrock.

title: ISRAELIS ENTERING LEBANON NIGHTLY
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 29Israeli military officials said today that Israeli soldiers have been crossing into Lebanon nightly in search of suspected guerrilla hideouts and stopping vehicles on a Lebanese road parallel to the border to search them for for terrorists and weapons.

title: Rams Surprised By Patriots, 2014
description: Almost nobody believed In the New England Patriots.

title: Miller Sets Golf Mark
description: Johnny Miller won the Kaiser International tournament yesterday for his eighth victory of the season and set a pro golf tour record of $346,933 in earnings. Story on Page 47.

title: Miller Wins No. 8, Sets Money Mark
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) Johnny Miller scored his eighth victory of the year and set a pro golf tour record of $346,933 in money winnings today with an eightstroke victory in the Kaiser International open.

title: State Cites Illegal Freeing Of Drug Defendants Here
description: Louis Venegas of Manhattan had nine previous narcotics convictions when he appeared before Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin on Oct. 22, 1970, for sentencing.

title: 66 Bar Shooting Is Recalled in a Quiet Place
description: PATERSON, Sept. 29This is a quiet neighborhood place, shouted Mrs. Doris Bryant, the weekend barmaid at the small Lafayette Grill bar room today over the din of rock music from a jukebox.

title: Bridge: Inflation Rears Ugly Head In Field of Books on Game
Breast Cancer Study Finds Radical Surgery Has No Advantage Over Simple Mastectomy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Findings in a nationwide study of breast cancer indicate that the traditional type of radical surgery undergone by Betty Ford offers no advantage over a lessmutilating technique, the director of the National Cancer Institute said today.

title: PRIOR RECANTING CITED ON CARTER
description: A senior investigator for the New Jersey Public Defender said yesterday that there was information from other people that both principal witnesses in the murder case against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and a codefendant had made informal statements recanting their testimony before the witnesses current formal recantations.

title: From Sea Shining Sea, Junk
description: You can't get good ice cream anymore. (Everything is getting worse or going away. The Woman's Home Companion is gone, and so is The Saturday Evening Post, and Look and Life, and soon even Time may run out for all of us as well. Colleges are going into bankruptcy. Restaurants I like are closing.) It tastes like gum and chalk. Virginia was. peaches,, strawberries, and cream with touches of rouge on her ripe, lustrous, cheeks.,. She shaped her lipstick often by pressing her mouth together. Her legs were smooth and glistening in unruffling silk stockings, and even her somewhat. chubby feet seemed rich and sweet as butter compressed into her shiny tight shoes with their high spiked heels. Women wore shiny black pumps with. high spiked heels when I was young, and evillooking, skinny men were unshaven and wore loose black socks in the dirty movies I saw. (Penny and other girls make me take my socks off for just that reason. My wife never saw any of these movies and doesn't. I often leave them on with her as ruse. I am an evillooking, skinny man in an old dirty movie, and I am defiling her. My wife has no idea that she is a character actress in a dirty movie of mine. She may, howeVer, for all know, be the leading performer in one of her own.)

title: Rangers Top Flyers, 51; Polis Stars
Polls Put Wilson Ahead in Subdued British Campaign
description: LONDON, Sept. 29With 10 days to go before the elections, Prime Minister Harold Wilson is comfortably ahead in the polls, his Conservative party challenger, Edward Heath, is keeping his gloves on and the British are sitting back looking for the drama in it all.

title: Bronx Internist Is Victor In Fifth City Marathon
A Soviet artist displaying his work at the second fall outdoor art show near lzmailovo Park in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29More than 10,000 people flocked today to the biggest officially sanctioned show of modern and unorthodox art by Soviet painters since the avantgarde rnovement in this country in the nineteentwenties.

title: Ford Hints at Change In 76 Election Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)President Ford. indiCated today that his wife's fllness might affect his plans to run for a full team in 1976.

title: 90 Feared Dead in Slide
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, Sept. 29, (Reuters)  A landslide crashed into a shantytown on the outskirts of this industrial city in central Colombia, the police said, and it was feared that 90 lives had been lost.

title: Ross, a Rookie, Captures Virginia Stock Car Race
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., Sept. 29 (AP)Earl Ross, a portly rookie from Ailsa Craig, Ontario, survived a steady stream of spinouts and wrecks today and scored an upset victory in the Old Dominion 500 Grand National stock car race. The 32yearold protege of a legendary exdriver, Junior Johnson, thus became the first rookie to win a major Grand National event since 1961, when Nelson Stacy took the Southern 500 at Darlington, S. C.

title: F.T.C. SAYS CHAINS WEIGH AN ACCORD Discussions Called No Sign That Validity of Bilking Charge Is Accepted
description: All five leading retail chains that the Federal Trade Commission has charged with bilking chargeaccount customers out of more than $2.8million in credit balances have indicated their willingness to discuss the entry of a consent agreement on the charges, according to commission officials.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BOTTOM'S UP In the nineteensixties, people who liked rock music, and the explosion of new forms that rock music took, used to be able to enjoy the new sounds in a variety of Spartan environments. There were the soggy fields of Woodstock, the hard wood floors of the Fillmore West and the ratty seats of the Fillmore East. But now the people who were willing to put up with all that have grown up. And for them, there is The Bottom Line, the city's newest rock music night spot, a place that books some of the best groups that come to town.

title: Inch of Rain Recorded Here Over. Weekend
description: A muggy warm front splashed more than an inch of rain on the metropolitan area over the weekend, bringing the total rainfall for the month to more than double the September norm.

title: Storm Threatens Barbados
description: BRIDGETON, Barbados, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Barbados and the Windward Islands took emergency precautions today as new hurricane headed in from the Atlantic.

title: Jrayits and Pell Say That Castro Seems Interested in Better Ties
description: HAVANA, Sept. 29  Senators Jacob K. Javits and Claiborne Pell said tonight that they believed Premier Fidel Castro was interested inthat is our impressionin working toward better relations with the United States, a normalization of relations.

title: Rout Keeps Up HopesTwo Games Left
House Primed for Floor Fight Today Over Reorganization An Issue That Many Wish Would Go Away
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House of Representatives, which likes to describe itself as one of the great deliberative bodies, is on the verge of something many of its most powerful members wish would just go away  a family fight in public.

title: A Fresh Look. in Baubles and Bangles To Match the New Changes in Clothes
description: A diamond as big as the Ritz is still a comforting thing to have in a bank vault. But a tiny sparkler on a thin gold chain has a lot more cachet as the crowds at Tiffany's these days will attest.

title: Montana StripMine Foes Irate At Secret Coal Export to Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A quietly arranged shipment to Japan of coal stripmined in Montana has aroused protests from an organization of ranchers who fear the environmental consequences of Montana's impending coal boom.

title: Joseph Alsop, After 37 Years, Ready for Less Combat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29It is very entertaining, said Joseph W, Alsop, particularly if you are a combative man, to sort of lay about you.

title: Watergate CoverUp Trial Begins Tomorrow as Uncertainty Exists Over Later Appearance by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The case of the Watergati coverup goes to trial Tuesday morning, two years and threi months after the coverup be gan and nearly two month after it caused the final col lapse of the Nixon Presidency.

title: Books of The Times
description: Women deserve what they inspire, says a French proverb, and I have been wondering just what Janp Clifford, the heroine of The Odd Woman, inspires. She is too reserved and analytical, too conscious of too many things at once, to inspire passion. Too intelligent and selfpossessed to inspire pity. Too intangible to call forth love. She doesn't even inspire talk, for though she is good at it, it has, in her case, an almost medicinal quality, like hormone pills for a deficiency. What she inspires, I think, is a term paper in a fashionable seminar, one with a title like Woman in Limbo.

title: Concert: Early Music
description: When the New York Pro Musica Antigua disbanded at the end of last season, many people must have thought that the earlymusic revival inspired by Noah Greenberg, the Pro Musica's founder, had run its course. But yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral Chinch of St. John the Divine, 10 performing groups and some 2,000 eager devotees assembled to prove the doubters wrong.

title: OIL NATIONS PLAN PRICE STRATEGY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29The major oil exporting countries are discussing the possibility of holding an emergency ministerial meeting next month on the mounting consumer pressure, led by the United States, for lower prices.

title: U.S. Rail Agency Seeking $ 14Million Rise in Budget
description: The United States Railway Association, the Federal agency working on plans to reorganize bankrupt railroads in the Northeast, is running out of funds itself and has asked Congress to raise its budget for the year to $40million, an increase of $14million.

title: Advertising Fiberglas Drive Tied to Energy
description: Earlier this month in 47 markets (but not this one or the West Coast), OwensCorning Fiberglas started its first television advertising campaign. It will be spending $2million in the fourth and first quarters on commercials tailored to each individual market.

title: Christians in Politics Backed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Representative Robert F. Drinan, a Jesuit priest, said yesterday that Christians should involve themselves in politics to bring morality into the system. The Massachusetts Democrat spoke at a Men's Fellowship luncheon at the Union United Methodist Church. Although published reports said that Humberto Cardinal Medeiros of the Boston Roman Catholic Diocese believes priests should not enter politics, Father Drinan refused to comment directly on these reports.

title: CLARA LOUISE WHELAN
description: Clara Louise Whelan, a daughter of Charles A. Whelan, cofounder of United Cigar Stores Company of America, died yesterday in Emery Manor, Matawan, N.J. She was 83 years old and a former resident of INew York and of Allenhurst, N.J.

title: Bulldog Best In Show on Long Island
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29A Long Island dog, Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone, came through in the moonlight on the raindrenched grounds of New York Institute of Technology tonight and was named best in a field of 2,077 at the 52d annual show of the Westbury Kennel Club.

title: Sardi's Opens a FullCourse DinnerTheater on L.I.
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., Sept, 29With celebrities and limousines and even a pair of autograph hounds on the front steps, Vincent Sardi's new restaurant brought a little bit of Broadway to the flatlands of Nassau County tonight.

title: A Number of Businessmen Are Pessimistic as White House Inflation Conference Ends
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A number of the nation's leading businessmen and financiers departed yesterday from the White House conference on inflation deeply pessimistic about the Ford Administration's monthlong exercise in publicly debating inflation and the outlook for controlling soaring prices.

title: CAREY BUSES END RUNS TO NEWARK
description: After 36 years, Carey Trans. portation last night gave up its bus operations between New York City and Newark International Airport because of revenue losses, but the service was taken over this morning by Transport of New Jerseyat a reduced fare.

title: Nancy Accola Wed To T. C. Ballantyne
description: Nancy Howard Accola, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. John Accola of New Canaan, Conn., and Martha's yineyard, Mass., was married yesterday in New Canaan to Thomas Campbell Ballantyne, son of Mrs. Ford Ballantyne. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and the late Mr. Ballantyne.

title: Card Players Slay 2 Attempting to Rob Their Game in Home
description: Police investigators said yesterday that two men who reportedly had tried to rob card game in a private home in Queens were shot dead and their bodies were wrapped in canvas and trundled away.

title: Ophuls's 'Liebelei' Is Romantic, but Not Sentimental
description: The conviction that the past can be canceled out, that it "doesn't count" any more, is one of the illusions that feed romantic tragedy. That notion is beautifully illustrated in Max Ophuls's adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's "Liebelei," which was shown at the 12th New York Film Festival last Friday. As elsewhere, Schnitzler also stressed the importance of living in the present, of savoring what may be suddenly snuffed out.The movie, made in 1932 and set in Vienna, 1910, focuses on a touching love affair between a shy singer (Magda Schneider) and a vulnerable young officer (Wolfgang Liebeneiner) whose feelings surface most sensitively, despite all his strict military training. Before they met, he was involved with a married baroness. He breaks with his mistressbut although the liaison is over, her husband kills him in a duel. Evidently, being punished for the wrong thingor paying for a chapter of life that's pastwere recurrent themes of Schnitzler's. And meeting the right person after you've spent too long with the wrong one was the kind of irony that the playwright was fond of exploring."Liebelei" embodies what Edmund Wilson defined as Schnitzler's gift for "lightly handled tragedy," and Ophuls's own lightness of style is as beguiling here as it later was in Schnitzler's "La Ronde." Amid the waltzes, the cafes, the elaborate staircases and winding back streets, the moments of emotional consequence are marvelously detailed. When the Baron (Gustaf Gruendgens) learns of his wife's adultery, he runs through his own palatial home and glares at the rooms where the couple met in a manner that's truly frightening; later, when he discovers that one of her keys fits her lover's door, he grinds it to and fro in the lock with outraged bitterness.Ophuls was at his best when he caused climates of feeling to build or change. As the singer and the officer begin to fall in love, their mutual absorption is subtly conveyed as they dance very slowly to rapid, noisy musicthey don't know that they're not with the rhythm. This scene is cleverly contrasted by the next one, in which the officer dances correctly but unenthusiastically with the woman whom he no longer wants. When the herocelebrating his freedom from the Baronessromps and fools about with his friends before a party, he and they seem particularly childlike and innocent; hence they (and we) are utterly unprepared for the Baron's sudden, threatening entrance.The movie makes the code of "honor" appear very stupid  and when another youthful officer protests that any shot that isn't fired in self-defense is "criminal," his rebellion against the military is a denunciation of all senseless duels. All in all, it's a privilege to see a movie that is romantic without being sentimental. Since that distinction is rarely respected now, it's exhilarating to learn what Ophuls achieved more than 40 years ago.

title: Dominicans Siege Reported to Hinge On Asylum Request
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 29Mexico has reportedly been asked unofficially if she would grant asylum to Dominican political prisoners in return for the release of six hostages being held in the Venezuelan consulate here by leftist guerrillas. Mexico has not replied yet.

title: Red Smith
description: Ken Aspromonte is unemployed and Frank. Robinson is the heir presumptive to his portfolio as manager of the Cleveland Indians. As one of the finest baseball players of his time and an acknowledged leader who has served his apprenticeship managing in the winter leagues, Robinson is clearly qualified for distinction as the first black manager in the major leagues. If he receives it, most decent people will applaud. Yet this does raise a question: Where does it all leave Larry Doby?

title: Wilson Orders Civil Service To End Ethnic Breakdowns
description: ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP)Governor Wilson ordered the State Civil Service Department today to stop collecting ethnic information on state employes.

description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 29The South Carolina Democratic Party will hold a state convention tomorrow to recommend a replacement for Charles D. Ravenel as gubernatorial nominee.

description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (UPI) Nearly all the 34 crewmen of the Panamanian freighter Sun Shang perished when their ship sank in heavy seas during typhoon whose toll is now at least 44, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency reported today.

New Jersey Sports
description: DEAL PARK, Sept. 29Jett Segal doesn't have much trouble finding shelves for the almost 300 trophies she has won in water skiing championships. She just uses her old skis for the display in the family recreation room. The wide trick skis hold the bigger trophies, such as the one for third place, overall, at the national girls championship last month. The longer slalom and jumping skis support the smaller trophies, such as those for the New Jersey and regional championships.

title: A Political Novice Beats Conservative In Louisiana Race
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 (UPI)Jeff LaCaze, a former television sportscaster who defeated conservative Representative John Rarick in yesterday's Runoff for the Democratic nomination in the Sixth District, said today that voters had responded to his race because he had never deviated from a clean, issuesoriented campaign.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 2,000 UkrainianAmericans, including large contingent from New Jersey, marched down Fifth Avenue from East 58th Street through thunder and rain protest the treatment of Ukrainian Nationalist intellectuals in the Soviet Union. Singing the preSoviet Ukrainian, national anthem and carrying Free Ukraine flags"blue for the sky and yellow for the wheatfields"they held a rally in Bryant Park and then a demonstration in East 47th Street near the United Nations.

description: Betty Ford spent a reasonably good night after her breast operation, her doctors said, and her condition continued satisfactory. Page 27.

description: James T. McKeon, a partner in. the law firm of Kuzmier a McKeon and vice president of the Metropolitan Trial Lawyer Association, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 68 year old and lived at 32 Barnard Place in Manhasset.

title: Television
Film Festival: 'Stavisky,' Moody Rogue of the 30's:Belmondo at His Best in Resnais Creation He Charms, He Broods and Topples Regime
description: The difficulty of knowing what is true, of discovering what really happened, ripples throughout Alain Resnais's "Stavisky"  a spell-casting mood piece that is also factually frustrating. Ideally, it should be possible to relish this fascinating movie on its own. But, since so little French history of the nineteen-thirties is provided, it's likely to send you flying to the library. ("Stavisky" isn't perplexing just to Americans; a colleague reports that a Parisian audience was also bewildered.) The movie opened last night at the New York Film Festival and will be repeated tonight. It doesn't yet have a commercial releasebut it will be startling if it's denied one.Briefly the real Stavisky was an entrepreneur, an impresario and an accomplished swindler who bribed politicians, the police, the courts and the press; he also squandered all of his own wealth. When he flooded France with fake vouchers in 1932, the banks were closed. As a result, there were violent street riots early in 1933, in which a number of persons were shot by the police. The Government could no longer rely on the loyalty of the army or the police, and Premier Edouard Daladier was forced to resign. (Stavisky himself appears to have been an apolitical adventurer, although he had a megalomaniacal belief that he could solve the economic problems of Europeand also end unemployment. Apparently, the press dwelled on the fact that he was a Russian Jew, and the fascist agents in France exploited the anti-Semitic issue by insisting that foreign crooks were out to ruin the nation.The movie mutes the last point, but the characterization of Stavisky seems very faithful to the accounts of the period. He appears as a dual personality: a graceful bon vivant who luxuriates in every conceivable pleasure and an acute melancholic. There's a charming moment when he explains the difference between happiness and pleasure: he says that happiness can occur in a single moment, but that pleasure requires a huge investment of time  and that it's available only to the rich. He's also obsessed by suicides and by mysterious deaths. He was once a scruffy hood, but his friends remark that his present self despises his past one.As Stavisky, whom a journalist of the thirties called "a gentleman among gangsters and a gangster among gentlemen," Jean-Paul Belmondo is at his best. Despite the tycoon's grandeur, he still breaks into a mobster's strut: arms swinging, wearing his shoulders high, he lunges forward with his torso aslant, while his respectable companions walk erect. Mr. Belmondo has all the authority and the gaiety of the man who refused to believe that he could make a mistake. But although others later call him crazy, we don't really see that aspect of his nature  perhaps because of the stubborn sanity that Mr. Belmondo brings to even his loopier roles.Charles Boyer is effortlessly elegant and supple as a baron who enjoyed Stavisky's company. The eyebrows rise delicately above those knowing eyes, and it's a treat to watch him playing with Mr. Belmondo: They seem to greet each other across the span of movie history. Anny Duperey at first appears as a brittle, expensive moll; she then emerges as a sympathetic person. The teasing, troubling musical score by Stephen Sondheim and the stunning art deco interiors suit the subject to perfection. There is also an engaging use of the theater: A reading from Jean Giradoux's "Intermezzo" and a performance of "Coriolanus" gently distill the themes of disorder and death.As usual, Mr. Resnais flirts with time: Here, there are many flash-forwardsmainly to a parliamentary committee, where witnesses testify about the Stavisky case. Most of these leaps into the future work very well, although there are a few too many of them. Less successful is the insertion of Leon Trotsky. Both he and Stavisky were exiles, but since their lives never touched, the revolutionary's appearance in the movie is unsettling. (Also, one wishes that the riots had been filmed  but perhaps they were omitted due to expense.) Meanwhile, despite its mystifications, "Stavisky" is one of the most rewarding films I've seen this yearand also one of the most intelligent.

title: Mrs. Ford's ordeal
description: As the American people.extend to Betty Ford their prayerful wishes for a speedy and full recovery from her operation for cancer of the breast, there are fortunately solid grounds for optimism based on statistical evidence. Advances in medical research, combined with diligent personal and professional efforts at early detection, have dramatically improved the cancer victim's chances of return to full health.

title: Deserter Who Hid In Pigpen 30 Years Forgiven by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (UPI)A Soviet army deserter has surrendered to authorities after spending 30 years hiding in a darkened corner of a Ukrainian pigpen, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today.

title: Leone Leaves for Home
description: President Giovanni Leone of Italy flew back to Rome yesterday after an official visit to the United States that included talks with President Ford and an address to the United Nations General Assembly.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTIONA Breeze From the Gulf, a play in two acts by Mart Crowley (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $9.95; Noonday Paperback, $3.95).

title: FINANCE MINISTERS END TALKS ON OIL; NO DECISION SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The finance ministers of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain and France ended two days of talks here today with no indication that they had agreed on action to meet the problems caused by rising oil prices.

title: Hospital Cook Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of a L.I. Girl
description: HAUPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 29.A 30yearold cook at Huntington Hospital was arrested this morning and charged with murdering the 16yearold girl who was found stabbed to death last week in Northport. She once worked in the same hospital as a volunteer.

title: Baltimore Stays A HalfGame in Front
Coping When a Fire Destroys Everything You Own
description: It all began around 8 P.M. one Satutday night when 15yearold Donna Hunte arrived at her Upper West Side apartment building after attending services at the neighborhood Seventh Day Adventist church.

title: Judith L. Margolis Bride of H. J. Katz
description: Judith Louise Margolis and Herbert Julian Katz were married yesterday afternoon in Temple Beth Emeth in Albany. Rabbi Bernard Bloom and Cantor Howard Stahl officiated.

title: Shah Is Questioned on Issue Of Political Prisoners in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 29The subject of Iranian political prisoners in the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi made a rare appearance in print here yesterday.

title: Cahill's Son Fined On Traffic Charge; License Suspended
description: LONG BEACH TOWNSHIP, Sept. 29John P. Cahill, the 23yearold son of former Gov. William T. Cahill, was fined $100 yesterday by a Municipal Court judge, who also suspended Mr. Cahill's driver's license for six months.

title: Sleepers Wake
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29 ; At the turn of last year William E. Simon, the new energy czar, said he was determined not to let the American people go to sleep again after the. Arab oil embargo ended. To that end, he said, the Federal Energy Office was preparing dramatic legislation to make Americans use less energy.

title: News Summary and Index
WILFRED L. DEMPSEY
description: Wilfred L. Dempsey, senior partner in the law firm of Dempsey, Dempsey and Sheehan in Summit, N. J., died Saturday in St. Elizabeth Hospital, Elizabeth, N. J. He was 68 years old and a resident of Summit.

title: Giants Upset Cowboys, 146
description: IRVING, Tex., Sept. 29It finally came together for the New York Giants today in a stunning 146 upset of the Dallas Cowboys at Texas Stadium.

title: Rancher Weds Lucie B. Sides
description: The marriage of Lucie Boyce Sides to Richard Mather Bourdon of Rapid Canyon Ranch in Sheridan, Wyo., took place at noon yesterday in Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. Rollin J. Fairbanks, an Episcopal clergyman, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Whittemore Sides, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is a son of Robert Slayton Bourdon of Wolcott, Vt., and Mary Mather Bourdon of Sheridan.

title: Mrs. Ford Recovering
description: Betty Ford spent a reasonably good night after her breast operation, her doctors said, and her condition continued satisfactory. Page 27.

title: Economic Charade
description: One of the most memorable works of art of the period between World Wars I and II was Kurt Jooss's ballet The Green Table in which diplomats periodically assembled, went through a charade of discussion and finally dispersed. The end of the ballet was performed by a figure representing Death.

title: NEW MEXICO SENATOR CONVICTED OF BRIBES
description: SANTA FE, N. M Sept. 29 ; State Senator Anthony A. Lucero of Albuquerque yesterday was convicted by a State District Court jury of. bribery to influence favorably the outcome of two state contractorlicense examinations.

title: Cubans Have Mixed Feeling Over Paper's Spanish Page
Expectations in Ethiopia
description: The young officers who deposed Emperor Haile Selassie in Ethiopia are already havingto learn one of the enduring political truths: it is much easier to.bring off a revolution and to overthrow an, existing system than it is to, govern.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: As acting head of the State Division of Consumer Affairs, Deputy Attorney General Douglas J. Harper has had to grapple with a rising caseload of complaints, a staff that is extremely thin and Investiga. tory delays that sometimes spin out a lot longer than he would like.Apart from the standard remedies of bigger budgets and more personnel, Mr. Harper thinks solve of his agency's problems could be solved by establishing more county and municipal consumeraffairs offices with a grant of broad lawenforcement powers.Only a few of the 100 or so municipalities in the state that have opened consumer affairs offices have seen fit to equip them with subpoena powers or the right to prosecute civil violations.The same limitations apply to the six of the state's 21 counties that have so far opened consumer affairs agencies. Their function is largely one of mediation between businessmen and consumers. When that breaks down, their only recourse is to pass major violations on to Mr. Harper and his colleagues at the state level.The consumer would be better off, said Mr. Harper, if there was no need for referral on cases that could he handled on the local level. The response would be much quicker.There seemed to he no legal reasons, according to Mr. Harper, why municipalities cannot give their consumer agents enforcement powers. The counties, however, appear to be a somewhat different cup of tea. They have no legislative powers, and hence appear to have no right to give their consumer affairs officials the kind of teeth needed to deal with violations where arbitration is no help.

title: Concert
description: Three rather elaborate chambermusic works of the early 19th century were played at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night by the Da Vinci Chamber Players. Spohr's Octet in E and Berwald's Septet in B flat are relatively rare items in concert programs, but the concluding work of the evening, Beethoven's Septet in E flat is something of a standard nowadays when chambermusic players in sufficient quantity and variety get together to give concerts.

title: Gromyko Headed Home
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, who was here to attend the 29th session of the United Nations General Assembly, unexpectedly departed from Kennedy International Airport at 9:30 last night aboard a Soviet jetliner bound for Moscow.

title: 300YearOld Covent Garden Market Prepares to Move Across the Thames
description: LONDONThe brown cobblestones of Covent Garden were littered with pungent rotting cabbage leaves, flattened tomatoes and broken celery sticks in the early morning. The shouts of Cockney workers could be heard above the rumble of the truck engines.

title: StripMine Foes Assail Secret Export
description: By ZEN A. FRANKLIN Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A quietly arranged shipment tc Japan of coal stripmined in Mcintana has aroused protest: from an organization of ranch. ers who fear the environmental consequences of Montana's impending coal boom.

title: Colts Oust Coach
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Howard Schnellenberger was dismissed as head coach of the Baltimore Colts today after the National Football League team's 3010 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. The Colts owner, Robert Irsay, told the team in the locker room after the game that he was turning over the coaching duties to the general manager, Joe Thomas. The Colts have lost three straight games this season.

title: PATROLS DOUBTED AS BAR TO CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Sharp changes in the levels of routine police patrol had virtually no effect on crime or the fear of crime during an elaborately monitored experiment ins selected areas of Kansas City, Mo., the Police Foundation reported today.
